0.question: I am a 23 year old male (73 kg 5'9) with no previous history of seizures until I had a seizure 1 month ago and went through all sorts of tests like CT, MRI, Echo test(3 times), Holter test, EEG(3times),Video EEG, Liver Function Test, Multiple blood tests and all came back normal.I was taking anxiety medications and my neurologists are saying i don't have epilepsy and the seizure was the side effect of the meds i took. But now my issue is i feel dizzy or disoriented whenever i play games for half an hour. l didn't have this issue before and I am used to flashing lights (i frequently goes to parties and concerts).I talked about this to my neurologists and they are saying i dont have epilepsy and this probably caused due to eyestrain. But today my screentime was short but when i started playing at night...after half an hour i started feeling disoriented (I play valorant and Apex Legends).l still have anxiety and dissociation issues btw. Any advice is appreciated.
0.answer:
I can’t replace your own doctors’ advice, but I can help you think through what might be happening and what you can do next.

1) What could be causing the new “dizzy / disoriented” feeling?  
   • Eye-strain and “visual motion sensitivity.” Fast-moving, high-contrast images (first-person shooters, racing games, VR, etc.) can overload the visual/vestibular system and produce light-headedness, disorientation or nausea even in people who have never had seizures. This is more likely if you:  
     – game in a dark room with a bright screen,  
     – sit too close, or  
     – play on a low-refresh, high-flicker monitor.  
   • Anxiety / hyper-vigilance. After any significant health scare, the brain stays on “red alert.” Adrenaline surges, rapid breathing and muscle tension can mimic or magnify dizziness.  
   • Medication or withdrawal effects. Benzodiazepines (alprazolam, clonazepam, etc.) or SSRIs/SNRIs can cause disequilibrium—especially if the dose has changed.  
   • Migraine or vestibular migraine. These can present purely as dizziness, worsened by screens, without head pain.  
   • Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness (PPPD). A form of chronic dizziness often triggered by a single vertigo, migraine, panic or—in some cases—a one-time seizure. Visual environments (supermarkets, scrolling screens, video games) are typical triggers.  
   • Very rarely, photosensitive epilepsy. True photosensitive seizures are uncommon in adults and your normal EEGs argue against it, but they aren’t impossible; you’d usually see brief eye fluttering, facial twitching or jerking rather than just “feeling odd.”

2) Practical steps you can try now  
   Screen/visual hygiene  
   • 20-20-20 rule: every 20 min look at something ≥20 ft away for 20 s.  
   • Keep room lights on; avoid a stark dark room + bright monitor.  
   • Sit ≥60 cm (2 ft) from the screen; use ≥120 Hz refresh if possible.  
   • Reduce in-game brightness, motion blur, camera shake and field-of-view extremes.  
   • Consider a matte screen filter or blue-light–blocking glasses if glare is strong.  

   Body mechanics & general health  
   • Maintain good posture; a raised monitor so you’re not craning your neck.  
   • Stay hydrated; eat before you play. Hypoglycaemia or dehydration can feel like “wooziness.”  
   • Sleep 7–9 h; lack of sleep raises seizure threshold, anxiety and dizziness.  
   • Limit caffeine/alcohol right before gaming sessions.  
   • Schedule brief stand-up or stretching breaks every 30–45 min.  

   Anxiety management  
   • Slow, diaphragmatic breathing (e.g., 4-4-6 pattern: inhale 4 s, hold 4 s, exhale 6 s).  
   • Grounding techniques when you start to feel “unreal” or dissociated (touch a cold object, name 5 things you see, 4 you feel, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste).  
   • Cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT) or mindfulness apps can reduce symptom-focused anxiety.  

3) Medication check  
   • Ask the prescribing doctor if the dose or timing of your anxiety medication (or any recent change/withdrawal) could explain disequilibrium.  
   • If you are tapering a benzodiazepine, do so slowly and under supervision—rapid taper increases dizziness and lowers seizure threshold.  

4) When to go back to the neurologist (or seek urgent care)  
   • Any repeat blackout, jerking, loss of awareness or face/arm twitching.  
   • New visual symptoms: flashes, field loss, coloured zig-zags (possible migraine aura).  
   • Vertigo so intense you can’t stand, vomiting, or hearing loss.  
   • Dizziness combined with chest pain, palpitations, or fainting.  
   • A pattern: every gaming session triggers the same neurological symptoms despite all of the above adjustments.  

5) Other specialists that may help  
   • Ophthalmologist/optometrist – to check refraction, eye-tracking problems.  
   • Vestibular therapist – teaches gaze-stabilisation and habituation exercises if PPPD or vestibular migraine is suspected.  
   • Physical therapist – posture, neck musculature, balance training.  
   • Psychologist specialising in health anxiety / CBT.  

6) Keep a diary  
   Date / start time / game / lighting / caffeine / sleep hours / meds / symptoms (1–10 intensity) / what stopped it. Bring this to your follow-up; patterns often become clear.

Bottom line  
Your extensive normal work-up and your neurologists’ opinion make true epilepsy unlikely, but a single seizure can leave anyone on edge. The disorientation you feel after ~30 minutes of fast-paced gaming is most consistent with visual motion sensitivity + anxiety (or a migraine/vestibular variant). Tweak the gaming environment, take scheduled breaks, keep hydrated, manage anxiety and review any medication changes. If the problem persists, escalates, or is accompanied by definite neurologic signs, circle back to your neurologist for re-evaluation.

1.question: 25M, Caucasian, 172cm, 77kg, fit and athletic, do lots of sports, no previous illnesses or conditions, head injury when I was 4 years old with no obvious consequencesDuring summer of 2018, I had my first what doctors described consciousness crisis. We were about to go rafting and I was walking in my wet suit through very cold water while it was very hot outside. My friends said that I just collapsed down and fell into the water. Last thing I remember was walking and then I just woke up on the river bank with everyone around me. I had blood coming out of my mount because I bit my tongue quite badly. I had no recollection of what happened and I was very confused and had no idea where I was or what year it is. Was taken to a hospital and they did an ecg and xray of my lungs and head and they also ran a blood test. Everything was in good order. The night before I didn't get the best sleep and we also drank a couple of beers.Fast-forward 2 years and 7 months, celebrating new year with my friends. I had just 1 beer and took a couple of puffs of weed. We had a long and good sleep and the next day we went on a little road trip. Everything was fine up until the evening. I was sitting on a couch and my friends said that I just let out a heavy suppressed scream and I collapsed on to the floor hitting my head on the corner of the table (still got a little scar). Woke up after 10 minutes confused AF because it felt like time travel. They took me to the hospital and I hot a CT scan of my head and urine an blood test and again everything was okay. The next day I went to a neurologist and he ordered an EEG after a sleepless night and an MRI and once again everything was totally fine. He das prescribed me 50mg of Lamotrigin to take in the morning and evening 25mg each (50mg in total).Now for almost 3 years I had no issues. Important to note that before the first seizure and after the first seizure I have experienced almost every epilepsy trigger multiple times. I went to rave parties and raved for 12 hours straight with flashing light while drunk and hungry. Listened to loud music, had sleepless nights, smoked week, have been blackout drunk amongst other things.So I am incredibly confused as to why have I collapsed twice in this 2,5 year period.Does this count as epilepsy?
1.answer:
I cannot give you a personal diagnosis on-line, but I can explain how neurologists think this through and why (based on what you wrote) most would record the label “epilepsy.”

1. How doctors define epilepsy  
   • International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) definition:  
     – At least two unprovoked (or reflex) seizures occurring >24 h apart, OR  
     – One unprovoked seizure with an estimated ≥60 % risk of another over the next 10 years, OR  
     – An epilepsy syndrome diagnosed on clinical grounds.  
   • “Unprovoked” means no correctable, transient cause such as low sugar, infection with fever, drug withdrawal, etc.

   You have had two episodes separated by >24 h, neither linked to a clear, reversible metabolic cause. By strict ILAE criteria, that fulfills “epilepsy.”

2. Why “normal tests” do not rule it out  
   • MRI is normal in roughly 40 % of people with generalized epilepsies.  
   • A routine EEG finds inter-ictal epileptiform discharges in only about 50 % of patients. Even with a sleep-deprivation EEG the yield rises to ~70 %. So a normal EEG/MRI is common.  
   • The diagnosis remains clinical: witness description, tongue-bite (especially lateral), post-ictal confusion and shoulder soreness, duration (tens of seconds to a few minutes), and amnesia.

3. Could it have been something else?  
   • Convulsive (anoxic) syncope from a heart rhythm problem can look identical. However, syncope rarely lasts >1–2 min and usually produces front-of-the-tongue bites rather than the side.  
   • Cardiac work-up: You had an ECG in the ED, but if suspicion persists many neurologists order a Holter monitor, event recorder, or tilt-table test, because arrhythmias can be intermittent.  
   • Heat/cold, standing in water, cannabis, alcohol, and sleep deprivation can all act as immediate precipitants for seizures—and for syncope—so the context alone does not settle the issue.

4. Why you were put on lamotrigine  
   • After two unprovoked events the 10-year recurrence risk is ≥60 %.  
   • Lamotrigine is a broad-spectrum anti-seizure medication tolerated well by active young adults.  
   • 50 mg/day is only a starting dose; usual target is 100–300 mg/day in divided doses. Titration is slow (e.g., +25 mg every 1–2 weeks) to avoid rash. Some doctors pause when they reach the smallest dose that keeps the patient seizure-free; others keep going to a more standard maintenance dose. Ask your neurologist what the plan is.

5. Why you have stayed seizure-free despite “triggers”  
   • Triggers do not cause seizures by themselves; they only lower the threshold. AEDs raise the threshold, often enough to outweigh the triggers.  
   • Around 30 % of people with newly treated epilepsy become completely seizure-free on the first drug tried; you may simply be in that group.

6. Practical implications if the label is “epilepsy”  
   • Driving: Most jurisdictions require 6–12 months seizure-free before licensing; check local rules.  
   • Lifestyle: Heavy sleep deprivation, binge drinking, and recreational drugs raise relapse risk even on medication.  
   • Drug levels/side-effects: Regular follow-up, particularly if you increase dose, change weight, or add other medications.  
   • Duration of therapy: After 2–5 years without seizures many neurologists discuss a slow taper off medication, but only if MRI/EEG are normal and there are no continuing risk factors. This is individualized.

7. When to seek re-evaluation  
   • Any further event suggestive of a seizure or unexplained faint.  
   • New neurologic symptoms.  
   • Rash, vision changes, mood swings (possible lamotrigine side-effects).  
   • If you plan major changes (e.g., stop meds, try for pregnancy, high-altitude trekking).

Take-home  
Two unexplained events with unequivocal loss of consciousness, tongue-bite, and post-ictal confusion separated by years fulfill current criteria for epilepsy, even with normal imaging and EEG. Remaining possibilities such as arrhythmic syncope are not 100 % excluded, so, if it has not already been done, you could discuss prolonged cardiac monitoring with your doctors. Continue the medication as directed and keep regular follow-up with neurology.

2.question: Age 28, Sex male, Height 181, Weight 64,  Race caucasianDuration of complaint 2 weeks. Any existing relevant medical issues bone infection (being treated) chest pain after 3 epilepsy attacks within 2 weeks and every time under influence of drugs, thats what worries me.Current medications 3 types of antibiotics.  Include a photo if relevant
2.answer:
I’m not your personal physician, but chest-pain that keeps returning after seizures is something that deserves an in-person, urgent medical assessment. Because you’re 28 and otherwise young, it’s tempting to assume it’s “just muscle soreness,” but several potentially serious problems can present exactly the way you describe. Below is general information and why getting checked promptly is important.

Why chest pain can follow a seizure
• Muscle strain or rib-cage injury: Violent tonic–clonic contractions can over-stretch the chest muscles or even fracture a rib. Pain is usually sharp and worse with movement or deep breaths.  
• Aspiration or pneumonia: If stomach contents are inhaled during the seizure you can develop chemical irritation or infection in the lungs, leading to chest pain and shortness of breath.  
• Pneumothorax (collapsed lung): Rare, but forceful muscle contractions can tear lung tissue, producing sudden, one-sided chest pain and breathlessness.  
• Cardiac stress: Stimulant drugs (cocaine, amphetamines, MDMA, etc.) or severe hypoxia during a seizure can trigger heart-muscle strain, arrhythmias, or—in extreme cases—heart attack.  
• Esophageal injury: Violent retching or vomiting post-ictally can cause tears (Boerhaave syndrome) or severe acid reflux.  

Red-flag symptoms that need emergency care now
• Chest pain that is heavy, squeezing, or radiates to arm, jaw, or back  
• Shortness of breath, coughing up blood or frothy sputum  
• Irregular, racing, or very slow heartbeat; dizziness, fainting  
• Fever, chills, or sweats (possible pneumonia or sepsis)  
• Severe, persistent abdominal or back pain with chest pain  

Actions to take right away
1. Seek immediate medical attention (call emergency services or go to the nearest ED) if any red-flag features are present or if the pain is moderate–severe and hasn’t been evaluated yet.  
2. When you’re seen, provide the following details:
   – Exact timing of seizures and chest-pain episodes  
   – Recreational or prescription drugs taken beforehand (type, dose, route)  
   – Current antibiotics (names, doses) and any other medications or supplements  
   – Whether you lost consciousness, vomited, bit your tongue, or noticed breathing problems  
3. Ask whether an ECG, cardiac enzymes, chest X-ray/CT, and basic labs (CBC, electrolytes, drug screen) are needed.  

Steps you can work on with your healthcare team
• Optimize epilepsy control: review anti-seizure drug regimen (if you’re not on one, discuss starting; if you are, ask if levels are therapeutic).  
• Substance use: candidly discuss any recreational drug use—the combination of stimulants + seizures + chest pain is particularly risky.  
• Infection management: the bone infection and multiple antibiotics make it important to monitor for drug interactions, liver function, and immune status.  
• Lifestyle: ensure adequate rest, hydration, and avoidance of alcohol or stimulants while recovering from infection and seizures.  

If you cannot be evaluated immediately
– Avoid further drug use.  
– Rest in a safe environment with someone nearby who can monitor you.  
– Keep a log of pain intensity, location, and any associated symptoms (shortness of breath, palpitations, nausea).  

Bottom line
Recurring chest pain after seizures—especially when drugs are involved—can signal problems ranging from simple muscle strain to heart or lung injury. Because some of these are time-sensitive and potentially life-threatening, please seek direct medical care as soon as possible, ideally today.

3.question: My husband (40M) had his first (that we know of) seizure - it was a tonic-clonic seizure - about a month ago. He had an EEG and is awaiting MRI.Before getting the EEG, his neurologist said he most likely doesn't have epilepsy due to his age and since he has only had one seizure. But after she received his EEG results, she said he does have epilepsy and needs to start medication. Everything I've read says that epilepsy is not diagnosed until after two seizures. I have also read that epilepsy is commonly misdiagnosed. I have been trying to learn about EEGs and epilepsy, but I'm not entirely clear on how they diagnose the condition. Is there a specific electrical firing seen that takes place that means it is absolutely epilepsy? Or is it just if you have an abnormal EEG then they guess it's epilepsy and not something else?I definitely have some questions for the neurologist, but I don't want to throw out the idea of misdiagnosis unless I have a basis to stand on. Any information and insight would be greatly appreciated.
3.answer:
Short answer  
•  Strictly speaking, two unprovoked seizures are the “classic” route to the diagnosis of epilepsy, but that is not the only route.  
•  Since 2014 the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) has considered the diagnosis established after a single seizure if the patient’s risk of having another unprovoked seizure is ≥ 60 % over the next 10 years.  
•  The most common reasons that put a person into this high-risk group are ① a clearly epileptiform EEG and/or ② an epileptogenic lesion on MRI (stroke scar, brain tumor, cortical malformation, etc.) or ③ the patient meets criteria for an epilepsy syndrome.  
•  Interictal epileptiform discharges (spikes, sharp waves, spike-and-wave, etc.) on EEG are highly specific for epilepsy, although not absolutely pathognomonic. About 2 % of healthy people will have “false-positive” epileptiform-looking transients, but when the EEG is read by an experienced neurophysiologist the specificity is ~90 %.  

Why the neurologist changed her opinion  
Before seeing the EEG she only knew: a 40-year-old had a single generalized tonic-clonic seizure. In adults more than half of first seizures are provoked (metabolic disturbance, alcohol withdrawal, etc.) and many never recur, so she told you “probably not epilepsy.”  
After she saw the EEG she apparently found unequivocal epileptiform activity, which moves your husband into the ≥ 60 % recurrence-risk category and therefore meets the modern definition of epilepsy. The recommendation to start an anti-seizure medicine follows current guidelines because the benefit of preventing another seizure outweighs the risks of the drugs once the recurrence risk is that high.  

What exactly does the EEG show?  
1. Normal background: The routine EEG records 20-30 minutes of brain voltage from scalp electrodes.  
2. Interictal epileptiform discharges (IEDs):  
   • Spikes (duration <70 ms) or sharp waves (70–200 ms) often followed by a slow wave.  
   • Can be focal (e.g., left temporal spikes) or generalized (3-Hz spike-and-wave).  
   • They look very different from normal rhythms (alpha, beta, theta).  
   • When an experienced reviewer calls a pattern “unequivocal IED”, the chance the patient truly has an epilepsy disorder is very high (specificity roughly 90–95 %).  
3. Other abnormalities: Focal slowing, periodic discharges, etc., don’t by themselves diagnose epilepsy but may suggest a structural lesion.  

Sensitivity and specificity  
•  Sensitivity of a single routine EEG for detecting IEDs in someone with epilepsy is only 30–60 %. That is why many people with definite epilepsy have a normal EEG.  
•  Specificity is much higher: < 2 % of the general population shows spikes. So a clearly epileptiform EEG is treated as strong evidence of an epileptic disposition.  
•  Misinterpretation is the main source of “false-positive” EEGs. When the recording is reviewed by board-certified electroencephalographers the misdiagnosis rate falls sharply.  

So is the diagnosis 100 % certain?  
No medical test is perfect. The EEG result has to be integrated with the clinical picture, blood work, MRI, etc. Reasons a spike-looking wave could be misleading include:  
•  Benign variants (e.g., wicket spikes, small sharp spikes).  
•  Artifact (muscle, eye movement, electrode pop).  
•  Rarely, some nonepileptic disorders (encephalitis, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) produce epileptiform-like patterns.  

Questions to ask the neurologist  
1. What exactly was abnormal on the EEG? Was it “unequivocal epileptiform discharges”? Focal or generalized?  
2. What is my estimated risk of another unprovoked seizure?  
3. Are there other factors (family history, nocturnal seizure, exam findings) that influenced your decision?  
4. Will the MRI result change management?  
5. Which medication are you recommending and why? What are the side-effects and driving-license rules in my state?  

Bottom line  
Your husband has not been “diagnosed on a hunch.” The current international definition allows the diagnosis of epilepsy after a single seizure if the EEG (or MRI) shows a high likelihood of recurrence, and a clearly epileptiform EEG fulfills that requirement. Asking the neurologist for the details of the EEG findings and how they translate into a ≥ 60 % recurrence risk is completely appropriate, but the approach she is taking is consistent with modern epilepsy guidelines.

4.question: ale, (controlled) epilepsy, lamotrigine 450 mg a day, average height and weight. I’m wondering what the opinion is for a person with epilepsy to donate plasma? I was turned away once when I disclosed my epilepsy to the people there, but I’m wondering why. I’ve had 5 seizures in almost 20 years, the most recent being April 2021. I’m just wondering if there’s a legitimate, medical reason I shouldn’t donate plasma? Thank you :)
4.answer:
Short answer  
Epilepsy itself is NOT an automatic, country-wide, permanent bar to donating plasma. The FDA, the American Red Cross and most other national blood services allow a person with epilepsy to donate as long as

• seizures are well-controlled, and  
• you have been seizure-free for a defined period (usually 6–12 months), and  
• the medication you take is not disqualifying.

However, every collection company or blood center can impose stricter rules. Some centres simply choose to defer anyone who reports “epilepsy” because it is easier than screening on a case-by-case basis or because of insurance/liability issues. That is probably why you were turned away.

Why centres worry

1. Donor safety  
   • Plasmapheresis removes 600–800 mL of plasma and returns saline plus an anticoagulant (citrate).  
   • Falling blood pressure, anxiety, pain, or the citrate-induced fall in ionised calcium can provoke light-headedness, tetany or—in rare cases—seizure-like activity even in people without epilepsy.  
   • A person with a seizure disorder is theoretically at slightly higher risk, so some operators take the conservative route and defer.

2. Operational/insurance concerns  
   • If a donor has a convulsive event in the chair, staff must treat it as a possible adverse donation reaction. Even if the event is unrelated to epilepsy (e.g., vasovagal syncope), it creates paperwork and potential liability.  
   • Training and staffing standards differ: some commercial plasma centres do not have on-site physicians and therefore prefer to avoid higher-risk donors.

3. Medication in the plasma  
   • Lamotrigine levels in donated plasma are tiny (typically < 1 µg/mL). The pooled plasma fraction used for manufacturing contains trace amounts far below therapeutic or toxic levels, so this is NOT a reason for deferral in the U.S. or Canada. A few countries (e.g., some EU states) exclude donors taking any antiepileptic drug, but this is rare.

Current guideline examples (U.S.)

American Red Cross   
• Eligible if seizure-free ≥12 months with or without medication.

AABB (American Association of Blood Banks)  
• Accept if “conditions are well-controlled on stable therapy and seizure-free for 6 months.”
• Medical director can approve shorter intervals on a case-by-case basis.

Private plasma centres (e.g., CSL, Grifols, Octapharma)  
• Policies vary; many require seizure-free ≥12 months AND written clearance from your physician.

So, is there a legitimate medical reason you personally shouldn’t donate?

Given:  
• 5 seizures in 20 years, last in April 2021 (≈3 years seizure-free).  
• On a standard maintenance dose of lamotrigine (450 mg/day).  
• No other medical contraindications.

From a purely medical standpoint you meet the usual criteria for acceptance. The deferral you experienced was centre-specific, not a universal rule.

How to proceed

1. Ask the centre for its written eligibility policy for “seizure disorder/epilepsy.”  
2. If they allow donation with documentation, request a brief clearance letter from your neurologist stating:  
   – Diagnosis of epilepsy,  
   – Last seizure date,  
   – Stable on lamotrigine,  
   – No restrictions from a neurologic standpoint.  
3. Ensure good preparation: normal meal, plenty of fluids, adequate sleep, continue all meds.  
4. Inform the phlebotomist that you have been cleared but let them know immediately if you feel light-headed, tingling around the mouth/fingers (sign of citrate), or aura.  
5. If one centre refuses, try a hospital-based blood bank; they tend to follow AABB/FDA rules rather than blanket exclusions.

Bottom line  
Epilepsy controlled for more than a year on lamotrigine is not a medical contraindication to plasma donation under most national guidelines. The single deferral you encountered reflects that centre’s internal policy and not a universal “no.” With a neurologist’s note and by choosing a donor site that follows standard eligibility criteria, you should be able to donate safely if you wish.

5.question: I (27F) had temporal lobe epilepsy from about age 8 until I was 10, when I had surgery to remove the gliosis (and part of my right hippocampus?) that caused my seizures. Every medical questionnaire and intake form I’ve ever had to fill out asks me if I have a history of a seizure disorder and/or epilepsy, and I always check yes and have to explain to whatever professional I’m seeing that I haven’t had a seizure since I had my surgery.I still want to be honest on these forms obviously, but I’m wondering is it even relevant to my current health anymore?As a note, I had my drivers license briefly suspended once when I was 17 or 18 because the DMV found out I’d used to have seizures and needed me to provide a doctors note clearing things up, so it’s important to me to know when it’s actually relevant to divulge my history.
5.answer:
Short answer
• Medically you no longer meet the definition of “active epilepsy.”  
• You do, however, have a “history of epilepsy (resolved after surgery).”  
• For health-care questionnaires it is best to keep checking the seizure/epilepsy box and add the words “remote – surgically cured age 10, seizure-free x 17 yrs, off medication.”  
• For situations that are NOT health-care related (employment, insurance, DMV once you have been cleared, school forms, etc.) you do not have to volunteer the information unless a question specifically asks for “any PAST history of seizures.”  

Why it still matters to medical professionals
1. Anaesthesia / conscious sedation – some agents lower the seizure threshold; the anaesthetist will want to know your past history even if the risk is now very small.  
2. Certain drugs (bupropion, tramadol, high-dose antibiotics, some antidepressants, stimulants, hypoglycaemics, etc.) are avoided or used more cautiously in anyone with a prior seizure disorder.  
3. Should you ever present with a transient neurologic symptom (syncopal spell, migraine aura, fainting, memory lapse) the differential diagnosis is different in someone who has once had epilepsy.  
4. Late recurrence, although rare, is not zero. After temporal-lobectomy the lifetime risk of another seizure after a 10-year seizure-free period is in the 3–10 % range—higher than the background population but low enough that you are considered “resolved.”  
5. Part of your right hippocampus was removed; that can matter to neuro-psychological testing or interpretation of future MRI scans.

The international definition
The International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) now recognises a category called “epilepsy resolved”:
• seizure-free ≥10 years AND  
• off anti-seizure medication ≥5 years.  
You fulfil that definition. Saying “epilepsy – resolved after surgery” is accurate and tells clinicians all they really need.

Driving
Most US/Canadian/Australian/European jurisdictions allow driving after 6–12 months seizure-free; you are miles beyond that. Once you have provided a clearance note you do not have to keep re-declaring it unless the DMV form specifically asks for ANY past history (few do). Keep a copy of the neurologist’s clearance in case the issue pops up again.

Other contexts
Employment pre-offer questionnaires: Under the Americans with Disabilities Act an employer cannot ask about medical history before making a conditional job offer. After a conditional offer they can ask medically-related questions but only if the same questions are asked of every candidate. Answer truthfully if it is asked; otherwise you do not need to bring it up.

Life, health or disability insurance: most application forms ask for “EVER had epilepsy or a seizure disorder?”—in which case you must tick “Yes” and write “childhood temporal lobe epilepsy, surgically cured, no seizures since 2006, no meds.”

Sport, scuba, sky-diving, pilot licence, military entrance: they all have their own rules and usually regard “any seizure after age 5” as potentially disqualifying, so disclose if asked.

How to fill the form
History of seizures/epilepsy?  ☐ No   ☑ Yes  – “Temporal lobe epilepsy, surgery age 10, seizure-free 17 yrs, no medication.”

That single extra line prevents misunderstanding, gives the clinician useful context, and avoids unnecessary caution or over-restriction elsewhere.

Bottom line
• For medical care you should keep listing it—just label it as “resolved.”  
• For non-medical situations you only need to disclose if the question specifically asks about PAST seizures; otherwise you can honestly answer “No” because you do not have an active seizure disorder.

6.question: 27 years old male Non smoker 73 kg 180 cm No other chronic illnessFor the past decade, I've been dealing with two distinct issues.- The first involves zigzag flashes across my field of vision, which are then followed by a mild headache lasting about an hour.- The second is an abrupt sensation of déjà vu or dream recall that leaves me feeling anxious and uncertain about my own memories.Both of these "auras" typically last around 20 minutes. I haven't sought treatment yet since these episodes occur infrequently—sometimes just once a year or once every few months.I'm unsure if what I'm experiencing is related to epilepsy or migraines?If anyone has had similar experiences, I'd greatly appreciate your insights.
6.answer:
What you describe sounds very familiar to neurologists, because there are two common conditions that can look exactly the way you’re describing:  

1. Migraine with aura (especially a “visual aura” that precedes the headache).  
2. Focal (partial) epileptic seizures, most often coming from the temporal lobe.

Below is some detail that may help you understand why both are on the list and what the next steps usually are.

────────────────────────────────────────
1. Visual zig-zag flashes → mild headache
────────────────────────────────────────
Typical features of a migraine aura  
• Positive visual phenomena: bright, shimmering, zig-zag or “fortification” patterns that spread slowly across one half of the visual field.  
• Gradual evolution: usually takes 5–20 min to build, total aura ≤60 min.  
• Followed by headache (often throbbing, one-sided, made worse by activity, ± light/sound sensitivity, nausea).  
• Completely reversible without any permanent visual loss.

That description is almost textbook for migraine with aura. When the episodes are that infrequent (one a year or every few months) you usually don’t need daily preventive medication; simple measures (hydration, NSAID, or a triptan if the headache is more than mild) are enough. Still, seeing a doctor at least once is worthwhile to make sure nothing else is going on if the pattern ever changes.

────────────────────────────────────────
2. Sudden déjà-vu / dream-like feeling, anxiety
────────────────────────────────────────
This is trickier. Both migraine and epilepsy can produce what neurologists call a “psychic aura,” but it is far more characteristic of focal seizures arising from the mesial temporal lobe.

Typical temporal-lobe (focal aware) seizure  
• An abrupt, brief (seconds to 1–2 min) wave of déjà-vu, jamais-vu, dream-like unreality, fear, or a rising “stomach” sensation.  
• No loss of consciousness, but sometimes staring, subtle facial movements, hand automatisms.  
• Often followed by a period of normal feeling (no or minimal headache).  
• Can remain isolated for many years or later spread to bigger seizures.

In migraine the same symptoms can occur, but they are usually:  
• Slower in onset (builds over minutes, like the visual aura).  
• Often followed by headache or other migrainous symptoms.  
• Part of a wider aura picture (visual, sensory, language, etc.).

Your description (“abrupt,” leaves me “anxious,” lasts ~20 min, no mention of headache afterward) leans me a little more toward a focal aware seizure than a migraine aura, but without an EEG/MRI no one can be certain.

────────────────────────────────────────
Why bother getting it sorted out?
────────────────────────────────────────
• Safety: If it is epilepsy, there is a small but real risk a bigger seizure could occur (driving, heights, swimming, etc.).  
• Treatment differences: Migraine therapy ≠ seizure therapy.  
• Prognosis: Both conditions are very treatable, but knowing which one you have determines whether you need rescue medication only (migraine) vs. daily antiseizure medicine or at least precautions (epilepsy).

────────────────────────────────────────
What a neurologist will usually do
────────────────────────────────────────
1. Detailed history + exam.  
2. Brain MRI (to be sure there is no structural lesion in temporal lobe, occipital lobe, etc.).  
3. Routine or ambulatory EEG. An interictal EEG that shows sharp waves in the temporal region strongly supports epilepsy; a normal EEG doesn’t completely rule it out but lowers the odds.

If the work-up points to epilepsy:  
• Seizure-free patients with rare focal aware seizures sometimes choose no medication and just observe, but that decision should be made with a neurologist after reviewing risk, driving regulations, lifestyle, etc.  
• If medication is started, low-dose lamotrigine, levetiracetam, carbamazepine, etc., are typical first-line choices.

If the work-up points to migraine:  
• Keep a simple headache diary to look for triggers (sleep deprivation, skipping meals, dehydration, caffeine withdrawal, stress).  
• Acute therapy only as needed. Preventive therapy usually considered if you reach 4+ headache days per month or if attacks are highly disabling.

────────────────────────────────────────
Red flags that need urgent evaluation
────────────────────────────────────────
• Aura or visual disturbance lasting >60 min or causing permanent visual loss.  
• Sudden “worst headache of my life.”  
• Weakness, speech difficulty, or one-sided numbness that doesn’t fully resolve.  
• New seizures with loss of consciousness or convulsions.

────────────────────────────────────────
Bottom line
────────────────────────────────────────
Zig-zag vision followed by headache = almost certainly migraine with visual aura.  
Sudden déjà-vu episodes of uncertain origin = could be another form of migraine aura, but temporal-lobe epilepsy is at least as likely.

Because the evaluation is straightforward (neurologic visit, MRI, EEG) and the implications for safety and treatment differ, it’s worth arranging that work-up even if the events are infrequent.

(Online advice can’t replace an in-person medical assessment—take this as educational information and book a neurology appointment to get a definitive answer.)

7.question: My partner (20M) has been having these ‘seizure-like’ behaviours for as long as he can remember (so assuming his whole life). There are 2 separate ‘actions’ which he isn’t sure are related or not.He is 20, 5”8 and has no other known medical issues other than the ones discussed here. He is pretty healthy otherwise and always has been including weight per age and hitting correct milestones etc. He is also not on any medication.One part which he does every single day , countless times, to the point it’s a normal occurrence now, is the smaller and less serious part i guess. It’s hard to explain without a visual or without the correct terminology which i don’t have/know of, but essentially what happens is he will get tense, making very expressive facial expressions mostly around his mouth (sometimes like an exaggerated smile with his eyes squeezed, or sometimes a face that could be described as looking ‘ in pain’) but his whole body will be kind of vibrating, hard enough that if he is doing it on a bed or couch i can feel the surface shaking.Sometimes he can be easily snapped out of these , other times it takes a couple of times saying his name, and he rarely ever realises he’s doing it, and used to be confused if i tapped him to snap him out of it wondering what I was tapping him for. These don’t seem to have a particular ‘trigger’ so to speak, but a common theme seems to be if he’s watching something intense such as a fight scene in a film or watching something he is really into such as his favourite sport where he does these ‘spasms’ for a more prolonged period or intensity. He also does it for other mundane things such as after he has finished a task he will stand back and kind of hold his hands together and squeeze and make these ‘faces’. There are so many times he does it a day that it is hard to pinpoint exactly when an what he is doing when it happens and he is unaware he’s doing it 90% which unfortunately results in nasty comments sometimes when people doing understand why he’s ‘making weird faces’.
7.answer:
I can’t tell you exactly what is happening to your partner on-line, but I can give you a framework you can take to a physician (ideally a neurologist) so the right tests and referrals are done quickly.  
Below I’ll break the problem into: 1) why these spells probably are NOT epileptic seizures, 2) what they are more likely to be, 3) why it still matters to be examined, and 4) how to prepare for the appointment.

1. Why these daily episodes do not look like epileptic seizures  
• Frequency/duration – Epileptic seizures that involve the whole body are rarely dozens of times per day for years on end.  
• Responsiveness – You can usually pull him out of the spell by calling his name. In most epileptic seizures awareness is lost or markedly impaired and you cannot break the event.  
• No post-ictal phase – Epileptic seizures are often followed by confusion, sleepiness, or headache. He seems to resume what he was doing normally.  
• Clear emotional/excitement link – The shaking is strongest when he is engrossed in a film, sports, finishing a task, etc. Seizures usually occur in a fashion that is not tied so tightly to situation or emotion.  
• Lifelong history without progression – Epilepsy that starts in childhood and continues into adulthood usually changes character over time, or at least is picked up by teachers / doctors sooner because of the outward convulsions, falls, tongue-biting, incontinence, etc. That history is missing here.

2. What is more likely

A. Complex Motor Tics / Tourette Syndrome  
• Tics can be facial (grimaces, jaw movements), vocal (throat-clearing, sniffing), or involve the trunk/limbs (shoulder jerks, body shudders).  
• They flare with excitement, stress, intense concentration, fatigue.  
• People are often only partly aware of them (“I didn’t realise I was doing it”); others can voluntarily suppress them for short periods but then feel an inner urge to release the tic.  
• Tourette’s = ≥2 motor tics + ≥1 vocal tic for >1 year, starting before age 18. Even without vocal tics the diagnosis of “persistent (chronic) motor tic disorder” can be made.

B. Motor Stereotypies or “stimming”  
• Repetitive, purposeless motor acts seen in some perfectly healthy people as well as in ADHD or Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).  
• Classically triggered by excitement or intense focus.  
• Very little or no sense of an urge beforehand (unlike tics), often start in early childhood, and can last much longer than a few seconds.

C. Less common movement disorders  
   – Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia (PKD)  
   – Myoclonus/dystonia syndromes  
   – Drug-induced dyskinesias (if he ever took neuroleptics, stimulants, anti-nausea meds)  
   These are all much rarer but a neurologist will consider them.

3. Why an evaluation is still important  
• Even “benign” tics/stereotypies can cause social embarrassment, anxiety, or muscle pain. Behavioural therapy, medication, or occupational / speech therapy can lower the frequency or intensity if he wants help.  
• Some tic disorders are linked with ADHD or OCD; treating those can lessen the movements.  
• A small minority of patients who present with apparent tics do turn out to have focal seizures or another neurological condition, so a basic work-up (neurological exam, possibly an EEG and/or MRI) is prudent.  
• If it IS a tic disorder, a formal diagnosis protects him in work or university settings and (if ever needed) for disability accommodations.

4. Preparing for the appointment  
a. Make short video clips (phone is fine) of several episodes: when mild, when intense, when you interrupt him, when you can’t. The neurologist will thank you.  
b. Write a one-page “timeline” covering:  
   – Age first noticed.  
   – How often per day/week.  
   – Triggers (excitement, fatigue, stress, boredom, foods/caffeine, etc.).  
   – Whether he feels an urge or warning beforehand.  
   – Whether he can voluntarily stop or postpone the movement.  
   – Any associated sound/words.  
   – Any other diagnoses (ADHD? anxiety? OCD?).  
   – Family history of tics, seizures, autism, migraines, etc.  
c. List all medicines / supplements ever tried and any recreational drug or stimulant use.  
d. Record anything that makes spells better or worse (sleep deprivation, exercise, alcohol, video games, etc.).  
e. Note any episodes that do NOT fit the usual pattern (e.g., loss of consciousness, falling, tongue-bite, urinary incontinence, prolonged confusion). Mention these clearly; they are what push a doctor to order an EEG first.

What to expect from the doctor  
• Detailed neurologic and psychiatric history and exam.  
• Possible EEG if there is any doubt about seizures.  
• Sometimes MRI (if additional red flags).  
• Tic-disorder–specific questionnaires; possibly a referral to a movement-disorder specialist if the general neurologist is uncertain.  
• Discussion of treatment choices: education/reassurance only, Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT), medications such as guanfacine, clonidine, topiramate, or dopamine-blocking agents if needed.

Bottom line  
Everything you describe – the frequency, the ability to interrupt, the situational triggers, the life-long history – fits best with complex motor tics or stereotypies, not epileptic seizures. They are usually benign but a formal neurological evaluation is still worthwhile for confirmation, counselling, and (if he chooses) treatment. Bring videos and a clear timeline; that one visit will likely provide answers that have been missing for years.

8.question: I have tc seizures about twice a month or so. I have recently run out of my generic keppra 3 days ago. I will not be able to get a new script for keppra until Monday. I do have my rescue medication (generic Ativan) which I have never had to take before. should I take this every 12 hours like I do my keppra?
8.answer:
I’m not your personal physician, but there are a few general-practice points that are important here:

1. Keppra (levetiracetam) = maintenance medicine  
   • Designed to be taken on a fixed schedule, every day.  
   • Stopping it abruptly can increase your seizure risk.

2. Lorazepam (Ativan) = rescue medicine  
   • Intended for an ongoing seizure, a seizure cluster, or a seizure lasting longer than usual (typically >5 min), not for routine twice-daily use.  
   • Regular around-the-clock dosing can quickly cause heavy sedation, impaired breathing, loss of coordination, and tolerance/withdrawal problems.

Because of that difference, simply substituting lorazepam every 12 h in place of levetiracetam is generally not recommended without a prescriber specifically telling you to do so.

What you can do right now

• Call the prescribing neurologist’s after-hours number or on-call service. Most neurologists have someone available for medication issues over the weekend. Explain you ran out; they can often phone in a short “bridge” supply to get you through until Monday.

• Contact your pharmacy. In many U.S. states a pharmacist can provide a 72-hour “emergency refill” of a non-controlled maintenance drug like levetiracetam when the prescriber can’t be reached. Ask if they can legally do that for you.

• If neither option is possible and you begin to have prolonged seizures or repeated seizures without recovery, use the lorazepam exactly as your rescue plan states (usually 1–2 mg once, possibly repeated once if seizure activity continues, but confirm the directions on your rescue prescription). Then seek medical attention.

• Minimize triggers while you’re off Keppra: get plenty of sleep, avoid alcohol and stimulants, stay hydrated, and reduce stress as much as you can.

• If you do experience a tonic-clonic seizure that lasts >5 minutes, a cluster of seizures, or anything that seems different from your usual pattern, treat with lorazepam per instructions and call EMS (911 in the U.S.).

Key take-away
Do not start taking the rescue lorazepam on a fixed 12-hour schedule unless a doctor specifically instructs it; instead, do everything you can—including calling your neurologist, primary care provider, or pharmacist—to obtain at least a small interim supply of levetiracetam. Use the lorazepam only if you actually need to abort a prolonged or cluster seizure.

If you cannot reach anyone and feel unsafe, go to the nearest emergency department; they can give you levetiracetam and ensure you have a prescription to cover you until Monday.

I hope you get the refill quickly and stay seizure-free this weekend.

9.question: 25MI don't get it. I'm awake and alert in the middle of the day. and everything's fine. I wake up early and my brain says, "screw you, here's a seizure. Have fun."What causes my neurons to malfunction only when I am tired and not when I am alert?
9.answer:
First, a quick disclaimer: only a clinician who has examined you, reviewed your EEGs/MRIs and taken a full history can tell you exactly why you’re having seizures at a particular time of day.  What follows is general information about why seizures often cluster around sleep and waking and what you can do about it.

----------------------------------------------------
Why “tired-time” and “wake-up” seizures are common
----------------------------------------------------

1. Sleep-wake transitions are electrically noisy  
   • When we fall asleep, cycle through the stages of sleep and then wake up, the brain shifts from one rhythmic pattern to another (delta ➜ theta ➜ alpha, etc.).  
   • Those large, synchronized brain waves are great for EEG technicians, but they are also fertile ground for an abnormal burst of synchronization—the essence of a seizure.  
   • The brief moment when the switch is flipped (falling asleep or just waking) is therefore a well-known seizure trigger.

2. Sleep loss lowers the “seizure threshold”  
   • Every brain has a threshold: the point at which enough neurons fire together to produce a seizure.  
   • Sleep deprivation, even a couple of hours, lowers that threshold by altering ion channels, inflammatory mediators and neurotransmitter balance (less GABA inhibition, more glutamate excitation).  
   • A night of shortened or fragmented sleep therefore makes it easier for a seizure to start the next morning.

3. Circadian chemistry shifts at dawn  
   • Cortisol, adrenaline and sympathetic tone all rise sharply between 4 a.m. and 9 a.m.  
   • Potassium and calcium levels in the extracellular fluid change, and body temperature starts to climb.  
   • Those changes increase cortical excitability just when you are waking up.

4. Some epilepsy syndromes are “morning-biased” by nature  
   • Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy, Generalized Epilepsy with Tonic-Clonic Seizures on Awakening, and several frontal-lobe epilepsies have a classic pattern of myoclonic jerks or tonic-clonics within an hour of waking.  
   • Even in focal epilepsy, about one-third of patients have their seizures almost exclusively from 5 a.m. to 1 p.m.

5. Metabolic factors  
   • Overnight fasting + early-morning insulin surges can drop blood glucose quickly.  Hypoglycaemia is not a primary cause of epilepsy, but low glucose can further push an irritable brain over the edge.  
   • Mild respiratory acidosis (from slower breathing in deep sleep) reverses quickly on waking; that acid-base shift can affect neuronal firing.

----------------------------------------------------
Practical things that usually help
----------------------------------------------------

Sleep hygiene  
• Target the same bedtime and wake-time every day.  
• Minimum 7–8 h of sleep; more if your neurologist advises.  
• Keep phone/computer light low for an hour before bed; avoid last-minute caffeine or alcohol.

Medication timing  
• If you already take an anti-seizure drug, ask whether shifting part of the dose to late evening or adding a small early-morning dose would keep levels steadier overnight and through the dawn peak.

Avoid additional triggers on “short-sleep” days  
• Alcohol, stimulant over-use, fasting, dehydration and intense flashing lights all lower the seizure threshold further when you’re sleep-deprived.

Safety precautions  
• If you often seize in the shower, switch to baths, sit on a shower stool or have a roommate around.  
• Consider a bed alarm / seizure-monitor watch if tonic-clonics occur at night.

Track patterns  
• Use a seizure diary app or simple notebook.  Note bedtime, wake-time, stress, alcohol, menstruation (if relevant), missed meds.  Patterns give your neurologist ammunition to fine-tune treatment.

----------------------------------------------------
When to call or re-visit your neurologist
----------------------------------------------------

• First-ever seizure or any change in seizure type, frequency or recovery time.  
• Injuries during seizures or prolonged post-ictal confusion.  
• Signs you may also be having seizures during sleep (bitten tongue, wet bed, muscle soreness).  
• Trouble tolerating medication side-effects.  
• Considering pregnancy (many seizure meds need adjustment).

----------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
----------------------------------------------------
The brain is most seizure-prone when it is shifting gears—especially if it’s underslept.  Hormonal surges, changes in neurotransmitter balance and the big, slow waves of sleep all make it easier for neurons to “fire together and wire together” in the wrong way.  Good sleep routine, optimized medication timing and avoidance of other threshold-lowering factors usually reduce or eliminate these morning strikes.  Bring a detailed sleep/seizure log to your neurologist; they can tailor the plan to keep those dawn neurons from misbehaving.

10.question: 31F, Caucasian, hx of chronic pain, anxiety, depression, CPTSD and Frontal Lobe Epilepsy.Last summer, I went in for a simple o/p procedure that was just supposed to be under mild sedation. I brought specific directions from my neurologist for medication protocols. However, I was met with a combative and rude anesthesiologist that decided he knew better, changed my plan, and ultimately induced me with propofol which was both stated and written to have caused me seizures in the past.I am missing a window of time for nearly 3 hours where I apparently had a cluster of seizures in the recovery ward. Eventually, they decided to contact my neurologist as well as my partner, both of which stated I needed to be given lorazepam to stop the seizures. They were getting ready to transport me via ambulance to the ER when I came around, absolutely freaked out and somewhat incoherent. My partner arrived as quickly as he could and all I said is I wanted to go home, so they allowed me to sign myself out and he took me home, not being told outright how bad things really went. I ultimately was able to request my records and went on to report the anesthesiologist.Ever since then, I haven’t been the same. My neurologists office has been indifferent to my situation. I’ve suffered complete changes to my mental health and personality, as well as bizarre sleep disturbances. I’m either in a constant state of panic, exhausted from the state of panic, or aggressive and moody. I wake up almost every night between 3-3:30am completely alert and ended up wandering around or on my phone for 1-2 hours until I pass back out. I was also having some breakthrough seizures in my sleep.Current meds: escitalopram 15mg q24 (recent increase) lacosamide 200mg q12 gabapentin 400mg q8-12 buspirone 5mg q12 (new) tizanidine 2-4mg before bed celecoxib 100mg q12-24 Vyvanse 30mg as needed (which I did quit for a while to see if it was the culprit. No change)Failed meds: temazepam venlafaxine lorazepam apriprazoleI just want my life back. I’m under the care of a new mental health facility because I felt like the last one wasn’t taking me seriously. Going to work or school is nearly impossible and I cry several times per day along with multiple panic attacks. We’ve considered an IOP or inpatient hospitalization if this isn’t under control soon.
10.answer:
I’m really sorry you’re having to carry all of this.  What happened in the recovery room was a genuine medical trauma on top of an already-difficult neurologic and psychiatric picture, so it makes sense that you now feel as if everything has been “scrambled.”  Below is an organized way to think about what might be happening and the practical steps you (with your clinicians) can take.  Nothing here replaces in-person medical care, but it can help you prepare for your next appointments and advocate for yourself.

------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Why you may feel “completely different” since the surgery
------------------------------------------------------------------
A.  Neurologic factors  
   • Repeated focal-to-bilateral or generalized seizures can temporarily or permanently change cortical excitability, neurotransmitter balance and sleep architecture.  
   • Post-ictal confusion can last longer after clusters, sometimes producing days to weeks of irritability, emotional lability or a “personality shift.”  
   • Frontal-lobe epilepsy itself can worsen mood, impulse control and sleep (many frontal seizures cluster in the early-morning hours, 2-4 a.m.).  
   • Certain anti-seizure medicines (including lacosamide) occasionally provoke anxiety, agitation or insomnia.

B.  Psychiatric / psychological factors  
   • A peri-operative event in which you lost time, had uncontrolled seizures and felt ignored by medical staff can easily fulfill criteria for a new or worsened PTSD.  
   • Severe sleep disruption, chronic pain, SSRI dose still below the usual therapeutic range (escitalopram 20–40 mg/day), and stimulant “as-needed” use can together keep the nervous system in a perpetual fight-or-flight state.

C.  Physiologic / iatrogenic contributors to track  
   • Night-time awakenings could be true nocturnal seizures, medication side-effects, or trauma-related hyper-arousal.  
   • SSRIs, lacosamide, gabapentin and tizanidine can all influence REM sleep and may interact (e.g., escitalopram + celecoxib can raise SSRI levels).  
   • Subclinical hyponatremia, B-vitamin deficiencies, thyroid or cortisol abnormalities can worsen panic and fatigue.

------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Immediate safety steps
------------------------------------------------------------------
• Put a written seizure rescue plan in place (e.g., intranasal midazolam or rectal diazepam, who gives it, when to call 911).  
• If suicidal thoughts intensify, use 988 in the US or go to the nearest ED immediately.  
• Let your new mental-health team know you are willing to consider IOP or short-term inpatient care if symptoms surge again—this is proactive, not a failure.

------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Medical work-up to request or repeat
------------------------------------------------------------------
Neurology  
   ◻  Long-term (at least one-night) video-EEG to see whether those 3 a.m. awakenings are seizures.  
   ◻  MRI brain with epilepsy protocol (if not done since the cluster).  
   ◻  Serum anti-seizure-drug levels, electrolytes, liver/kidney function.

Sleep  
   ◻  Polysomnography if video-EEG inconclusive; look for concurrent sleep apnea or periodic limb movements.

General labs  
   ◻  CBC, CMP, TSH, free T4, B12, folate, ferritin, vitamin D, fasting cortisol.

Neuropsychology  
   ◻  Testing can document objective cognitive / mood changes and guide rehab or disability paperwork.

------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Medication questions to bring to your prescribers
------------------------------------------------------------------
Escitalopram  
   • 15 mg is often sub-therapeutic for severe anxiety/PTSD. Usual target 20 mg; can go to 40 mg with ECG monitoring (QTc).  
   • If no response at 6–8 weeks on 20 mg, consider switch to sertraline or fluoxetine, both first-line for PTSD, or augment (see below).

Buspirone  
   • 5 mg twice daily is a starter dose; effective range 20–60 mg total daily divided TID.  It works only if taken every day.

Anti-seizure agents that help mood  
   • Lamotrigine: mood-stabilising, antidepressant properties, effective for focal epilepsy; slow 6-week titration to avoid rash.  
   • Valproate can calm agitation but is usually a last choice in women of child-bearing age because of teratogenicity and weight gain.  
   • Topiramate sometimes helps migraines and weight but can cloud cognition.

Sympathetic over-drive / nightmares  
   • Prazosin at night (1–10 mg) reduces trauma-related awakenings in many PTSD patients.  
   • Propranolol 10–40 mg three times daily (or LA 60–120 mg) can blunt daytime surges without impairing seizure threshold.

Anxiolytic rescue that also covers seizures  
   • Scheduled benzodiazepines are tricky with frontal-lobe epilepsy, but a prn clonazepam 0.25–0.5 mg up to bid during flare-ups can break the panic–seizure–panic loop; discuss risk/benefit.

Stimulant strategy  
   • If Vyvanse is helpful for executive functioning, try converting to the smallest daily dose at the same time each morning—“as-needed” peaks and troughs often aggravate anxiety/sleep.

------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Non-pharmacologic pillars (as powerful as meds)
------------------------------------------------------------------
Targeted therapy  
   • EMDR, prolonged-exposure or cognitive processing therapy for medical trauma/C-PTSD.  
   • DBT or RO-DBT for the mood swings, impulsivity and self-criticism that often follow frontal seizures.  
   • A structured IOP can deliver these rapidly if you can’t wait months in standard outpatient.

Sleep hygiene & seizure-proofing nights  
   • Fixed bed/wake time, no screens 60 min pre-bed, low-lux lighting.  
   • Blue-blocker glasses or f.lux software after sunset.  
   • 3–5 mg melatonin 2 h before bed (safe in epilepsy) or 25–50 mg diphenhydramine occasionally (anticholinergic load is a consideration).  
   • Keep the bedroom <68 °F, 65-70 % humidity, white-noise machine to break “alert” silence.

Body-based regulation  
   • Daily 20-30 min gentle aerobic activity (walking, stationary bike) resets cortisol curves and may reduce seizure frequency.  
   • Trauma-sensitive yoga, paced breathing (4-7-8 or box breathing) and progressive muscle relaxation lower sympathetic tone in minutes.

Pain management without escalating meds  
   • Physical therapy focused on core strength & biomechanics, TENS unit, trigger-point injections, or low-dose naltrexone (ask pain specialist).  
   • Mindfulness-based stress reduction courses shown to improve both chronic pain and epilepsy quality-of-life scores.

------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Advocacy / accountability for the original event
------------------------------------------------------------------
• If you have not already, request the full anesthesiology and nursing intra-operative records (they are often separate from the basic surgical note).  
• File a detailed narrative with the hospital’s risk-management department and your state medical board if not done—this sometimes opens access to counseling funds or expedited second opinions.  
• Consider a legal consultation (malpractice statutes vary by state; many firms will review the case at no cost).

------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  Putting it all together
------------------------------------------------------------------
Bring this list to ONE “captain” physician—ideally an epileptologist or a psychiatrist with neuropsychiatry interest—and ask for a coordinated plan with clear timelines:

1. Complete work-up (EEG, MRI, labs) within next 4–6 weeks.  
2. Adjust anti-seizure regimen (possible lamotrigine trial) and push SSRI to full dose or switch.  
3. Add prazosin or propranolol for nights/days respectively if nightmares or adrenaline surges persist.  
4. Escalate buspirone to evidence-based dose or stop it if ineffective.  
5. Enroll in trauma-focused therapy or IOP by a set date.  
6. Re-assess every 4 weeks; if no ≥30 % symptom improvement by 12 weeks, move to inpatient or advanced interventions (VNS, RNS, ketamine-assisted psychotherapy, etc., depending on findings).

------------------------------------------------------------------
Crisis & support resources (US)
• 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline (call/text/chat 24 / 7)  
• Epilepsy Foundation Helpline 1-800-332-1000 (M-F)  
• PTSD Alliance (ptsdalliance.org) – lists trauma-informed therapists by ZIP

You have already done the hardest part—recognising that something changed and demanding help.  With a focused neurologic re-evaluation, an assertive PTSD-specific treatment plan, and possibly some medication fine-tuning, many people in your situation regain stability over months, not years.  Bring a support person to appointments if possible, keep records of every step, and remember that seeking higher levels of care is a sign of strength, not defeat.  You deserve— and can still achieve — a full, safe life.
