I’m not your personal physician and can’t give you a firm diagnosis on-line, but I can help you understand what typically fits – and does NOT fit – the picture you’re describing, and what sort of evaluation is usually recommended.

--------------------------------------------------
1. What you’re noticing
--------------------------------------------------
A. Orthostatic (position-related) symptoms  
• Resting heart-rate (lying or sitting) is much lower than standing heart-rate – sometimes by 20–60 beats/min.  
• When you first stand you feel dizzy, vision “grays out,” may see spots; it clears in ~10–20 s.  
• You rarely/never actually pass out.

B. Intermittent “black-out” episodes (every few years)  
• Prodrome: intense nausea, feeling cold but sweating, maybe headache.  
• Sudden muffled hearing/tinnitus; vision tunnels to black.  
• You remain upright and can move, but have no memory (“acting on autopilot”).  
• You eventually “snap back,” often after a bump or startle (e.g., spilling water).  
• Began in childhood, seem to have become more dramatic over time.

C. Other clues  
• Heat intolerance and unpredictable sweating.  
• Family history: maternal grandmother had multiple strokes.

--------------------------------------------------
2. What these patterns most commonly represent
--------------------------------------------------
1. Orthostatic intolerance spectrum  
   • Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS): heart-rate rises ≥30 bpm (≥40 in teens) or exceeds 120 bpm within 10 min of standing, with dizziness, visual blurring, nausea, trembling, etc.  
   • Orthostatic hypotension (drop in blood pressure on standing).  
   • Neuro-cardiogenic / vasovagal syncope: the same autonomic circuitry can cause a sudden reflex drop in heart-rate and/or blood pressure → global brain hypoperfusion → “grayout,” muffled hearing, tunnel vision, faint. Many people don’t fully collapse; they may slump, lean on a counter, or “freeze” while still technically standing or sitting.

   Your description of a sudden “whoosh” of nausea, sweating, muffled hearing, shrinking vision, then blackness strongly matches vasovagal syncope. The fact that the episodes began at age 8, last seconds to minutes, and do not leave focal weakness also argues for a benign syncopal mechanism, not stroke/TIA.

2. Why this is probably NOT a transient ischemic attack  
   • TIAs cause focal neurological deficits (one-sided weakness, speech trouble, facial droop, loss of coordination, etc.) that appear abruptly, usually without the sweaty/nauseated prodrome, and there is no “tunnel vision” sequence.  
   • TIAs are very uncommon in children and teens unless there is a congenital cardiac or clotting disorder.  
   • Global blackout with preserved posture is cerebral hypoperfusion, not a vascular clog in one brain artery.

3. Could it be epilepsy instead?  
   • Complex partial (focal impaired-awareness) seizures can look like “blank spells” with automatisms and amnesia.  
   • However, seizures usually are NOT triggered by standing up, heat, dehydration, or prolonged upright posture; prodromal nausea and muffled hearing are less typical than a focal aura (smell, déjà vu, metallic taste, etc.).  
   • An EEG would be needed only if history or exam raised red flags for seizures.

4. Underlying autonomic dysregulation (dysautonomia)  
   • Heat intolerance, excessive or paradoxical sweating, orthostatic symptoms, and vasovagal episodes can all stem from autonomic nervous system imbalance.  
   • POTS, neuro-cardiogenic syncope, and related syndromes often coexist.

--------------------------------------------------
3. Important (but less likely) things that still must be ruled out
--------------------------------------------------
• Significant cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., heart-block, SVT, VT) – because they can mimic vasovagal syncope and can be dangerous.  
• Structural heart disease (e.g., hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, cardiomyopathy after viral infection).  
• Endocrine causes (thyroid excess, adrenal insufficiency).  
• Anemia or major blood loss, severe dehydration, infection.  
• Medication / substance effects (stimulants, beta-blockers, alcohol, etc.).

--------------------------------------------------
4. What a doctor will usually do
--------------------------------------------------
1. Detailed history + physical exam (cardiac, neurological, autonomic).  
2. Orthostatic vitals: BP and HR lying, sitting, standing 1, 3, and 10 min.  
3. Baseline ECG.  
4. Lab work: CBC, chem panel, ferritin, TSH, cortisol if indicated.  
5. Echocardiogram and/or 24–48 h Holter or 2-week event monitor to look for arrhythmias.  
6. If syncope remains unexplained → tilt-table test (gold standard for POTS / neuro-cardiogenic syncope).  
7. If seizure is still a possibility → EEG, possibly brain MRI.  
8. Imaging for stroke/TIA is usually NOT necessary unless you ever develop focal deficits or other stroke risk factors appear.

--------------------------------------------------
5. What you can do in the meantime
--------------------------------------------------
Lifestyle / preventive measures often make a big difference even before formal diagnosis:

• Hydration: at least 2–3 L water/day unless restricted by a doctor.  
• Salt: 3–5 g/day (unless you have high blood pressure or other contraindication). Sports drinks can help.  
• Compression stockings (20–30 mmHg thigh-high) to reduce lower-body pooling.  
• Avoid rapid position changes; rise gradually from lying/sitting.  
• Physical counter-maneuvers when you feel the prodrome: leg-cross and tense, buttock clench, handgrip, tip-toe “calf pumps” – these raise blood pressure transiently.  
• Regular aerobic and lower-body strength exercise, ramped up slowly.  
• Identify and avoid personal triggers: heat, long standing, dehydration, skipping meals, alcohol.  
• If episodes cluster: keep a diary (time of day, position, food intake, stress, menses, medications).

--------------------------------------------------
6. When to seek urgent care
--------------------------------------------------
• Any episode with true loss of consciousness that results in injury.  
• Chest pain, palpitations > a few minutes, or very slow pulse (<40 bpm) or very fast (>150 bpm) with symptoms.  
• New, persistent one-sided weakness, drooping face, trouble speaking (call 911 – “FAST” stroke check).  
• Shortness of breath, unexplained severe headache, or vision loss not resolving in seconds.

--------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
--------------------------------------------------
Your story fits best with orthostatic intolerance / vasovagal syncope, possibly in the POTS spectrum. TIA/stroke is unlikely given the age of onset, prodrome, and global rather than focal symptoms. Seizure is less likely but not impossible. You need a structured evaluation by your primary care provider or a cardiologist / neurologist who handles syncope and autonomic disorders. Basic tests (orthostatic vitals, ECG, labs) are simple and often clarify the situation quickly; a tilt-table or Holter monitor may follow.

Make an appointment soon, keep a symptom log, stay well-hydrated and salted, and use the counter-maneuvers described above. If anything feels suddenly worse or different from your usual pattern, treat it as an emergency.

12.question: 18M 72kg/160lbs 180cm healthy non-smoker and non-drinker. My blood pressure normally around 55/110 and my mother has epilepsy. I hyperventilated for some reason and stood up, passed out and woke up. I had a little dream when I passed out. My friend who was with me said I was swinging my right leg and scraping the carpet with my right hand for about 10 seconds. I remember scratching the carpet unintentionally for about 2 seconds. I'm feeling a little foggy. It happened a few hours ago. Was it an epileptic seizure or something else?
12.answer:
What happened could have been either  

1. a faint (syncope) with some brief, automatic or “convulsive” movements, or  
2. a true epileptic seizure.  

From the little you and your friend describe, syncope seems a bit more likely, but nobody can make the call with certainty over the Internet.  
Below is why, what to watch for, and what to do next.

-------------------------------------------------
Why syncope looks more likely
-------------------------------------------------
• Clear trigger: you were hyperventilating, then you stood up. Hyperventilation lowers the carbon-dioxide level in the blood and causes the brain’s blood vessels to constrict; standing up suddenly also drops blood pressure. That combination often produces a temporary lack of blood flow to the brain → faint.  

• Typical duration: loss of consciousness in syncope is brief (seconds). Your friend says you were out ≈10 s; seizures often last longer.  

• Brief, random movements are common in fainting. When the brain is momentarily starved of blood/oxygen it may produce a few jerks or limb thrashing (“convulsive syncope”). They are usually short (<15 s), asynchronous and stop as soon as blood flow returns.  

• Rapid recovery: people usually come around quickly after a faint and are only mildly “foggy.” Post-ictal confusion after a generalized seizure often lasts minutes to hours and is more profound. (You’re foggy a few hours later, but that can still happen after a bad faint.)  

• You recall part of the event. Partial recall can happen with syncope; in a generalized seizure memory is usually completely lost for the convulsive part.

-------------------------------------------------
Why epilepsy cannot be ruled out
-------------------------------------------------
• A family history (your mother) does raise personal risk.  
• Your friend thought the movements were mainly on the right side. A focal seizure can present like that (though syncope can also produce asymmetric jerks).  
• You had a “little dream.” Some seizures begin with a dream-like or déjà-vu aura; however, many people report short dream fragments from fainting, too.

-------------------------------------------------
Red-flag features that would push the needle toward “seizure”
-------------------------------------------------
• No clear trigger (you had one)  
• Tongue bitten on the side, not the tip  
• Loss of bladder or bowel control  
• Cyanosis (turning blue)  
• Eyes forced to one side or open and staring blankly  
• Convulsions >30 s, especially if rhythmic and symmetric  
• Confusion, headache or muscle soreness that lasts >1–2 h  
• Repeated attacks or stereotyped events

-------------------------------------------------
So what should you do now?
-------------------------------------------------
1. Get checked once. Any first-time loss of consciousness with witnessed limb movements deserves at least a basic medical evaluation (vital signs, orthostatic blood pressures, blood sugar, ECG, brief neurologic exam). Go to an urgent-care clinic or emergency department today if you are still foggy, have a headache, nausea/vomiting, new weakness, or hurt yourself falling.  

2. See your GP or a neurologist even if you feel fine. They will decide whether you need:  
   • Orthostatic blood-pressure testing, blood work, ECG or Holter monitor (to rule out heart rhythm problems).  
   • An EEG or MRI if the story sounds seizure-like or if you have another episode.  

3. Avoid obvious risks until you know more: no driving, climbing, swimming alone, operating machinery, or sleeping on top bunks for the moment.  

4. Learn first-aid steps: If another spell starts, anyone with you should gently lay you flat (or on your side if there’s shaking), protect your head, and time the event. If it lasts >5 min or you don’t wake up promptly, call emergency services.  

5. Reduce faint triggers: stay hydrated, don’t skip meals, rise from sitting slowly, and practice controlled slow breathing rather than hyperventilating if anxious.

-------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
-------------------------------------------------
Because you had a clear fainting trigger and only a few seconds of limb movements, a “convulsive syncope” is most plausible. Still, only an in-person medical evaluation can confirm that and rule out epilepsy or a heart rhythm problem. Arrange to be seen soon and seek urgent care sooner if any worrisome symptoms recur.

13.question: Female, 47, 65kg, 1.62cm, no other medicine or illness until thus far. No smoke, drinking, children or cases in the family.Up until I was 7 I took Gardenal. Then stopped - and my late granduncle was the top pediatric neurologist in the country - and did EEGs yearly until about 25.Had deja-vus up until college, never thought they could be considered related to epilepsy.When I was 45, epidemic, worst job in the world. Colleagues were in Rio, London, Lagos and Dubai. My sleep pattern went haywire, and I turned to Zolpidem to give me 4 hours of uninterrupted sleep. Started at 5mg. As pressure grew, isolation, trouble in the job, slowly I grew the dosage. Had a burnout, left the job, and now I was taking 500mg to 600mg a day. Yes, 2 to 3 boxes. A day. I was floating in mid-air, barely ever lucid.Then I started having tonic-clonics. 8 in few months. I was deeply scared and built a team of therapist, psychologist and neurologist. Good news, nothing physical in the brain. Other good news is that I quit Zolpidem cold turkey, had withdrawal, suffered a lot... But quit.
13.answer:
I’m very glad you were able to stop the massive zolpidem intake and that you already have a neurologist, psychologist and therapist involved.  Below is an overview of what is probably happening, why the tonic-clonic seizures appeared, what usually comes next, and the practical steps most neurologists recommend after a situation like yours.  Use it as background for your next appointment; only your own physicians can give you definitive, personalised instructions.

────────────────────────────────────────
1.  Why did the seizures start?
────────────────────────────────────────
You had three powerful, converging seizure-triggers:

•  Zolpidem mega-doses  
   – 600 mg/day is 60–120× the usual 5–10 mg nightly dose.  
   – At that level the drug itself can paradoxically lower the seizure threshold (especially when blood levels swing wildly between “over-sedated” and “wearing off”).

•  Abrupt cessation (cold-turkey withdrawal)  
   – Z-drugs act on the same GABA-A receptors as benzodiazepines and barbiturates.  Stopping suddenly after very high, chronic exposure can provoke a hyper-excitable nervous system → withdrawal seizures, sometimes delayed several days.

•  Severe sleep disruption & stress  
   – Both independently increase seizure risk, even in people who never had epilepsy.

Add to that a remote history suggestive of childhood epilepsy (Gardenal = phenobarbital) and episodes of déjà-vu (possible focal aware seizures), and your brain was already somewhat seizure-prone.  The perfect storm produced the 8 tonic-clonics.

────────────────────────────────────────
2.  Is this “epilepsy” now or purely withdrawal?
────────────────────────────────────────
After a single, clear withdrawal seizure many people never seize again once the drug clears and sleep is restored.  
However, because:  
• you had eight events,  
• you may have had focal seizures (déjà-vu) since childhood, and  
• you likely had a predisposition that phenobarbital suppressed early in life,  

the safest assumption—for now—is “possible underlying epilepsy unmasked by zolpidem.”  That is how most neurologists will frame it until enough time passes (usually 6–12 months seizure-free) with normal EEGs and no medication triggers.

────────────────────────────────────────
3.  Typical work-up & follow-up
────────────────────────────────────────
• Brain MRI with epilepsy protocol (thin cuts through temporal lobes).  
  – You already said “nothing physical” was seen, which is reassuring.

• At least one standard EEG; many specialists also order:  
  – Sleep-deprived EEG or 24- to 72-h ambulatory/video EEG, because interictal abnormalities can be intermittent.

• Basic labs (electrolytes, calcium, magnesium, glucose, liver/kidney tests, vitamin B12/folate, thyroid) to rule out metabolic provokers.

• Medication/withdrawal timeline carefully documented.

• If all of the above are normal and you remain seizure-free for 6–12 months, the diagnosis may revert to “provoked seizures” rather than chronic epilepsy.

────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Should you start long-term anti-seizure medication (ASM)?
────────────────────────────────────────
This is controversial in withdrawal cases.  Guidelines suggest:

• If seizures occurred only in the first 7–10 days after stopping and you remain seizure-free afterward, you might avoid long-term ASM.  
• If seizures recur beyond the acute withdrawal window, or if EEG shows epileptiform discharges, most neurologists start an ASM (often levetiracetam, lamotrigine, or low-dose valproate, depending on profile).  
• Temporary ASM “cover” for 3–6 months is also an option some specialists use.

Ultimately it depends on your risk tolerance (e.g., driving, living alone, job safety) and your EEG/MRI results.

────────────────────────────────────────
5.  What you can do right now
────────────────────────────────────────
Sleep Hygiene & Lifestyle
• Prioritise 7–9 hours of regular, night-time sleep.  Go to bed and get up at consistent times.  
• No caffeine after midday, no screens in bed, dark/cool/quiet room.  
• Daily exercise, preferably outdoors, at least 30 min.  
• Strictly avoid alcohol and recreational drugs for at least several months; both disrupt sleep and lower seizure threshold.  
• Balanced meals, hydration, stable blood sugar (don’t skip breakfast).  

Stress Management
• Continue therapy/CBT, mindfulness, breathing exercises.  
• Structure your day if you are not working: fixed wake-up/meal/exercise/social times.  
• Consider a support group (in person or virtual) for former Z-drug/benzodiazepine users—shared experience lowers relapse risk.

Medication Safety
• Do not re-introduce zolpidem or any benzodiazepine/z-drug “just once” for sleep—this is the commonest path to relapse.  
• If sleep becomes unbearable, discuss non-habit-forming options with your doctor:  
  – Melatonin 1–3 mg, trazodone 25–50 mg, mirtazapine 7.5–15 mg, or cognitive-behavioural therapy for insomnia (CBT-I).

Seizure First-Aid & Safety Precautions
• Shower instead of taking baths; if you must bathe, someone should know and check in.  
• No swimming alone; avoid heights (ladders, rooftop work).  
• Place padding on sharp furniture corners in the bedroom.  
• Wear a medical alert bracelet stating “seizure risk.”  
• Teach close family/friends seizure first-aid:  
  – Roll on side, nothing in mouth, time the seizure, call ambulance if >5 min or cluster.

Driving / Operating Machinery
• Most jurisdictions require 3–6 months seizure-free before resuming driving; some require a neurologist’s clearance.  
• Check local regulations and your neurologist’s recommendation.

Documentation
• Keep a seizure diary: date, time, duration, preceding triggers (stress, missed sleep), post-ictal feelings.  Even “déjà-vu” episodes should be logged.

────────────────────────────────────────
6.  Red-flag reasons to seek immediate medical care
────────────────────────────────────────
• Another tonic-clonic seizure, especially >5 min or repeated without full recovery.  
• New focal neurologic deficit (weakness, speech trouble, visual loss) after a seizure.  
• Confusion that lasts >1 hour longer than usual post-ictal phase.  
• Sudden severe headache, stiff neck, fever.  
• Signs of infection, metabolic imbalance, or withdrawal delirium.

────────────────────────────────────────
7.  Long-term outlook
────────────────────────────────────────
• Many patients who seize only in the context of Z-drug or benzodiazepine withdrawal remain seizure-free once the CNS stabilises (4–6 weeks).  
• If you truly have a latent temporal-lobe epilepsy, about 60–70 % achieve excellent control on a single ASM.  
• Maintaining regular sleep alone can reduce seizure risk by 30–50 % in predisposed individuals.

────────────────────────────────────────
8.  Key questions to ask your neurologist
────────────────────────────────────────
1. Do my EEG/MRI findings suggest a chronic epilepsy or purely provoked seizures?  
2. Should I start a preventive anti-seizure medication, and for how long?  
3. How long must I stay seizure-free before I can drive/work/travel safely?  
4. What rescue medication (e.g., intranasal midazolam) should my family keep?  
5. How can we monitor for subclinical seizures or nocturnal events?  
6. What non-addictive options exist if insomnia returns?

────────────────────────────────────────

Bottom line: your tonic-clonic seizures were almost certainly triggered by the combination of gigantic zolpidem doses, abrupt withdrawal and severe sleep deprivation, on a background of possible childhood-onset focal epilepsy.  You’ve already done the most important, hardest step—stopping the zolpidem.  Over the next 6–12 months, meticulous sleep hygiene, stress control, ongoing neurological follow-up and, if advised, a temporary anti-seizure medicine will give you the highest chance of remaining seizure-free for good.  Keep the lines of communication open with your care team, and don’t hesitate to seek urgent help if anything changes acutely.  Wishing you a calm, restorative recovery.

14.question: I (30F) had a seizure for the first time 3 days ago. I had had a couple beers, smoked a joint, and did some shrooms (none of which is unusual for me). I have no family history of epilepsy, and am in generally good health.I was checked out by paramedics immediately after the seizure who said I looked fine and it was probably from the shrooms. I went to my PCP the next day and she ordered a couple blood tests which all came back normal. I am waiting for brain imaging to be approved by my insurance.Now it’s three days later and I still feel exhausted and weak and slow. I could barely get through my workday today. Is this normal? Is extreme fatigue indicative of something?Also I don’t know if it’s relevant at all but about a month ago I started experiencing extreme nausea to the point I was calling off sick at work, vomiting in the middle of the day, and had just had a doctors appointment to discuss that the week before.
14.answer:
I’m not your personal physician and can’t examine you, but I can give you some general information that should help you decide what to do next.

1. ​Post-seizure (“post-ictal”) fatigue  
   • Feeling wiped-out, slow, foggy or weak for hours to a couple of days is very common after a generalized (whole-body) seizure.  
   • Some people bounce back in a few hours; others need 3-5 days before they feel normal.  
   • Red flags that are NOT typical post-ictal symptoms and should prompt another call/visit right away: steadily worsening headache, repeated vomiting, worsening confusion, new weakness or numbness on one side, visual loss, fever, or another seizure.

2. ​Why a first-time seizure is worked up even when drugs/alcohol are on board  
   • Alcohol, cannabis and psilocybin can all lower the brain’s seizure threshold, but they may only unmask an underlying problem (epilepsy, infection, bleeding, tumor, metabolic abnormality, etc.).  
   • The usual evaluation includes:  
     – Basic labs (electrolytes, glucose, liver/kidney tests, CBC) — you’ve had some of these.  
     – Brain imaging (a same-day CT if there is any doubt about bleeding; an MRI is more detailed and is normally recommended in everyone with a first unprovoked seizure).  
     – An EEG, ideally within a week or two, looking for epileptic activity between seizures.  
   • Until a neurologist reviews all of this, the episode is classified as an “unprovoked first seizure,” and standard safety advice applies (no driving, swimming alone, climbing ladders, operating heavy machinery, drinking, or recreational drug use).

3. ​Fatigue vs. something more serious  
   • If the tiredness is gradually improving each day and you have none of the red-flag items above, it’s probably ordinary post-ictal recovery.  
   • If you’re just as exhausted on day 4 or 5 as you were on day 1, or if new symptoms appear, call your doctor back or go to the ED.

4. ​The nausea/vomiting you had last month  
   • Persistent, unexplained nausea can have many causes (GI, hormonal, migraine, medication side-effects, etc.).  
   • When someone later has a first seizure, neurologists also wonder whether the nausea could have been a subtle focal seizure (from the insular or temporal lobe) or a sign of raised intracranial pressure (rare but important, e.g., a mass or hydrocephalus).  
   • That’s another reason the MRI is worth pursuing even if the drug use seems like an obvious trigger.

5. ​What you can do while waiting  
   • Rest, hydrate, eat normally, and try to keep a regular sleep schedule. Sleep deprivation is a strong seizure trigger.  
   • Write down exactly what happened before, during and after the event (or get the witnesses’ account). This helps the neurologist.  
   • Avoid alcohol, cannabis, and psychedelics until you’re cleared; they all lower the seizure threshold.  
   • Have someone stay with you if possible, at least at night, until you feel back to baseline.  
   • If you must be alone, keep a charged phone nearby and consider a medical-alert app or device.

6. ​When to seek immediate care (call 911/ED)  
   • A second seizure, or even a brief recurrence of abnormal jerking or staring.  
   • Persistent or worsening headache, repeated vomiting, confusion, one-sided weakness, speech difficulty, fever, or stiff neck.  
   • A seizure lasting >5 minutes or repeated seizures without full recovery between them.

Bottom line  
Three days of pronounced fatigue can be perfectly normal after a first generalized seizure, but you still need the planned MRI (and preferably an EEG) to rule out other causes. Follow up promptly with your PCP or, better yet, a neurologist, avoid anything that might provoke another seizure, and watch closely for the warning signs listed above.

That has happened a handful of times in my life in the past and I went years without it happening and it’s back, and it’s scary and feels horrible. I’m wondering if it’s all because of the trazodone or if I had this since I was a kid (since I’ve experienced that weird shaking in a box sensation multiple times through my life) and the trazodone made it all come to the surface?Meds I take: klonopin 1mg, vitamin d, probiotic, melatonin 2mg, trazodone 25mg.
15.answer:
I can’t give you a diagnosis over the Internet, but the collection of things you’re describing is worrisome enough that you should be examined promptly by your own clinicians, ideally starting with your primary-care physician or an urgent-care/ED visit and then a neurologist.  Below is some information you can use when you talk with them.

1.  Could this be a focal (partial) seizure?
   • Temporal-lobe and frontal-lobe seizures can present exactly as “spells” of sudden fear/doom, autonomic surges (rapid heart-beat, warmth, nausea), light-headedness, déjà-vu or “out-of-body” sensations, and odd sensory disturbances—all without loss of consciousness and lasting seconds to a few minutes.  
   • After-effects such as fatigue or brief confusion (a “post-ictal” period) are also typical.  
   • Facial or chin twitches can be focal motor activity.  
   • Trazodone, melatonin, and clonazepam at the doses you list rarely provoke seizures, but trazodone and abrupt benzodiazepine dose changes can lower the seizure threshold.  Having been on clonazepam may even partially suppress or “mask” seizures so that they look milder or atypical.  
   • Only a careful neurologic exam, a brain MRI, and an EEG (sometimes an ambulatory 24- to 72-hour EEG or inpatient video-EEG) can settle the question.

2.  Vestibular or basilar migraine
   • Migraine variants can cause photophobia, dizziness or a sense that the room is spinning/rocking, tinnitus, nausea, and even a sense of impending doom.  They can happen without a pounding headache (“acephalgic migraine”).  
   • Motion illusions in bed (“my head is being shaken in a box”) can be part of vestibular migraine or a benign inner-ear problem such as BPPV, but vestibular migraine fits better with the light sensitivity and head/eye sensations.

3.  Dysautonomia / panic-spectrum events
   • Panic attacks, POTS, or vasovagal pre-syncope cause surges of catecholamines that mimic what you feel.  
   • You already have an anxiety history, but you know your usual panic feeling—and you’re clear this feels different.  Still, your evaluators will want to consider this, especially because clonazepam can blunt anxiety and possibly alter how attacks present.

4.  Cardiac or vascular causes
   • Brief drops in cerebral blood flow from arrhythmia, TIA, or orthostatic hypotension can cause near-syncope, tinnitus, photophobia, and a sense of doom.  A heart rhythm strip (EKG and possibly longer Holter/event monitor) plus routine labs and blood pressure/orthostatic testing are worth doing.

5.  Medication side effects or interactions
   • 25 mg trazodone is a low dose, but idiosyncratic reactions are possible.  
   • Melatonin and clonazepam together can exaggerate vestibular instability in some people.  
   • Abruptly missing or delaying clonazepam doses can provoke withdrawal phenomena that include perceptual distortion, tremor, and possible seizures.

6.  Less common but important possibilities
   • An intracranial mass, inflammation, or infection.  
   • Endocrine/metabolic disorders (thyroid, electrolyte, B-vitamin deficiency).  
   • Ocular conditions (uveitis, acute narrow-angle glaucoma).  

Red-flag features in YOUR story that merit a timely work-up
   • New or worsening headaches with photophobia.  
   • Cognitive changes (short-term memory, difficulty reading aloud).  
   • Focal twitches around your mouth.  
   • Recurrent brief neurologic spells that are NOT your typical panic attacks.  
   • Interference with sleep and daily functioning.

What to do next
1.  Arrange an in-person evaluation as soon as you can.  If the spells become more frequent, last longer than 5 minutes, involve loss of awareness, or produce weakness/numbness, go to the emergency department.  
2.  Until cleared by a clinician, do not drive, swim alone, climb, or operate dangerous machinery; if these are seizures you could suddenly lose awareness.  
3.  Keep a symptom diary: date/time, what you were doing, exact sensations, duration, recovery time, possible triggers (sleep loss, alcohol, missed medication, stress, flashing lights, hormonal cycle).  If someone can witness an event and record it on a phone (safely), that can help the neurologist.  
4.  Bring all medications and supplements to the visit.  Do NOT stop clonazepam abruptly—this can cause withdrawal seizures.  If your prescriber wants to taper it or adjust trazodone, do it under supervision.  
5.  Likely tests your clinicians may obtain:
      • Complete neurologic and vestibular examination  
      • Brain MRI with and without contrast  
      • Routine and possibly extended (sleep-deprived or ambulatory) EEG  
      • Basic labs: CBC, CMP, magnesium, calcium, B12, thyroid panel  
      • EKG ± 24-hour Holter/event monitor  
      • Formal ophthalmologic exam if photophobia and visual floaters persist.

Bottom line
Your description does overlap with focal seizure auras, but other disorders—especially vestibular migraine—could look similar.  Only an in-person assessment and appropriate tests can sort this out, and given the potential seriousness, you should be evaluated promptly. Bring the above information and your diary to the appointment, and push for a neurology referral if one isn’t offered right away.

16.question: UK female 40 162cm 77kgs no smoking, alcohol or drugsDiagnosis of autism, asthma, Ehlers Danlos type 1 and presumed epilepsyMedication is Levetiracetam 1250mg twice a day and Fostair inhalers and cetirizine over the counterRecently had an EEG for nocturnal episodes of unilateral clonic and tonic movements lasting 20 to 160 seconds witnessed by partner and on video plus brief (30 sec max) daytime episodes of twitching and ‘swooping’ sensation in head - all improved but not stopped by Levetiracetam. MRI and CT scans normal. Neurolgist reported on EEH as ’essentially normal’ with no other details, but has advised GP diagnosis is presumed epilepsy however described it as a difficult case to diagnose. My question is why would he describe the EEG as ‘essentially normal’ rather than just normal?
16.answer:
In EEG reporting, the wording is chosen very deliberately because the report becomes part of the medical-legal record and often guides future investigations, insurance decisions, DVLA clearance, etc.  
“Essentially normal” is a short-hand that neurologists use when:

1. No definite epileptiform or pathological abnormalities are present,  
2. BUT there are one or more minor, non-specific or technical findings that mean the tracing is not “text-book perfect,” or the study has limitations that have to be acknowledged.

The phrase therefore tells the next clinician (and the patient) that:
• Nothing was seen that clearly explains the events or mandates a new diagnosis,  
• Nevertheless the record is not, in the strictest sense, completely normal or completely conclusive.

Typical situations that lead to the qualifier “essentially” include:

• Limited recording time or failure to capture sleep – Routine EEGs last 20–30 min; if the spell did not occur, the EEG can only assess the background rhythm.  
• Artefact – Muscle tension, movement, ECG pick-up, or electrode popping might obscure brief portions.  
• Benign variants – Small sharp spikes, wicket spikes, 14- and 6-Hz positive bursts, or slow posterior alpha that are considered normal variants but can resemble pathology to the untrained eye.  
• Mild, non-specific abnormalities – Slight asymmetry of background, occasional slow waves related to drowsiness, medication effect, or hyperventilation; usually of no clinical significance.  
• Medication effects – Levetiracetam and many other antiepileptics can “quiet” cortical activity, so if there had once been epileptiform discharges they may now be absent.  
• Clinical correlation needed – The neurologist wants to emphasise that an EEG that is not definitely abnormal does not rule out epilepsy, especially when events are infrequent, nocturnal, or focal.

Why this matters in your case
• Routine scalp EEG has a sensitivity of only about 50 % after a single recording; up to 30 % of people with proven epilepsy never show interictal discharges on standard EEG.  
• Nocturnal focal seizures are particularly easy to miss; they are often deep-seated (temporal, fronto-mesial) and do not always produce surface spikes.  
• Your spells have improved on levetiracetam, which both supports an epileptic aetiology and at the same time may suppress the very EEG features clinicians look for.

Thus the wording “essentially normal” fits a scenario in which the EEG did not capture a clear abnormality but the clinical story (witnessed unilateral clonic–tonic events, brief daytime events, response to medication) still strongly suggests focal epilepsy.

Possible next steps that neurologists often consider (not instructions, just possibilities):

• Sleep-deprived or prolonged (24–72 h) ambulatory EEG, ideally with video, to increase yield.  
• In-patient video-EEG telemetry, especially if events remain frequent or diagnosis is still uncertain.  
• Review of medications, adherence, triggers, and safety advice (driving, baths, swimming, heights).  
• Screening for other mimics (e.g., parasomnias, movement disorders, non-epileptic attacks) if treatment response plateaus.

Key points to remember
• “Essentially normal” ≠ “normal”: it flags minor limitations or variants but reassures that nothing frank was observed.  
• A normal or essentially normal EEG never excludes epilepsy; the diagnosis is clinical, supported by tests.  
• Levetiracetam’s partial success and the description of your spells are why the neurologist still leans toward “presumed epilepsy” despite an unremarkable EEG.

If you remain unsure, you can ask your neurologist to explain exactly what, if anything, was seen in the EEG that made it “essentially” rather than strictly normal, and whether further monitoring could be useful.

17.question: I want to donate plasma, partially because I have O negative blood and would be available every 4 weeks to donate. And partially because I discovered donating plasma also has health benefits for the donors such as reducing micro-plastics in the body.From what I can see online in the UK if you’re epileptic you can’t donate plasma/blood. I was wondering if anyone knew the reason for this? Is it because the medication I take could cause issues if it was in the blood?Or is it more of a ‘we’re worried you may have a seizure while donating’ kind of risk where a doctors note might mitigate risks?If it’s the latter, it seems a shame that something which could have a positive impact for both parties isn’t allowed so I just wanted some insight into the matter as I can’t see anything online which actually talks about the reasons behind the restriction.Female, 27, Epileptic, medication: Keppra and Eslicarbazepine, other than being epileptic I am healthy in all other respects (BMI: 20, non-smoker, non-drinker)
17.answer:
In the UK the rule is set out in the NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) donor-selection guidelines:

Epilepsy  
• Accept – only if the donor has had no seizures for at least 3 years and has been off all anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) for the same period.  
• Defer – permanently while the donor is still having seizures or is still taking AEDs.

So in practice anyone who, like you, still needs Keppra® (levetiracetam) or eslicarbazepine is not allowed to give blood, platelets or plasma.

Why the rule exists

1.  Donor safety  
   • A standard whole-blood donation removes about 470 mL of blood; a plasma donation removes an even larger volume of plasma and returns the red cells, using citrate as an anticoagulant.  
   • Both procedures transiently lower circulating blood volume and blood-pressure and, in the case of plasma donation, can produce temporary low calcium levels (from the citrate).  
   • Dehydration, hypotension, hypocalcaemia, anxiety and pain all lower the seizure-threshold. NHSBT therefore regards anyone with an established tendency to seizures as being at higher-than-usual risk of having a fit during, or shortly after, the procedure. A convulsion while a needle is in the arm (and the donor is connected to apheresis tubing) is dangerous both to the donor and to staff.

2.  Recipient safety  
   • Whatever is in the donor’s plasma – including prescription medicines – is transfused into the recipient.  
   • The amount transferred is small, but NHSBT uses the “precautionary principle”: if a component is likely to go to premature babies, small children or very sick adults, any potentially active drug is considered an avoidable risk.  
   • Pharmacovigilance data on transfusing low levels of AEDs are scant, so the simplest way to keep the blood supply as drug-free as possible is to exclude donors who are still taking them.

3.  Administrative clarity  
   • Sessions are run by nurses and donor carers following a long list of “yes/no” rules. Allowing case-by-case exceptions (e.g. “bring a doctor’s letter”) would slow the process and introduce inconsistency and medico-legal uncertainty. A single, easily-applied rule keeps things safe and efficient.

Is it different elsewhere?

Yes.  The United States Red Cross, for example, accepts donors who have been seizure-free for 12 months, even if they are still taking medication.  Different service structures, insurance frameworks and risk-assessment models lead to different thresholds.  The UK has simply chosen a more conservative line.

Can the rule be changed for you?

Unfortunately no.  Until you have been seizure-free without Keppra or eslicarbazepine for three years, NHSBT will continue to defer you.  A GP’s or neurologist’s letter will not override the national guideline, and individual staff have no discretion to do so.

Anything else you can do?

• When/if you eventually stop medication and remain seizure-free for three years, you could re-apply.  
• You could encourage eligible friends or relatives to donate.  
• You might volunteer at donor sessions or help with recruitment campaigns—roles that do not involve any medical exclusion.

Bottom line

The exclusion is not a judgement on your general health; it is a risk-management policy designed to protect both you and potential recipients.  While it may feel frustrating, it is unlikely to be relaxed in the foreseeable future while you are still taking anti-epileptic medication.

18.question: My friend is 19 and pregnant. She’s in her 11th week of pregnancy and started experiencing “seizures” while sleeping and then also while awake. so she admitted to the hospital but the doctors couldn’t figure out what’s wrong. She doesn’t have any history of epilepsy or seizures even in her family. she did experience sepsis about a couple months ago while she was pregnant with her last baby (she had to abort it). This time around apparently just her magnesium levels were low in the blood tests and her oxygen saturation levels were around 93% when she would start getting dizzy and about to experience a “seizure”. I say “seizure” because apparently the docs at the hospital didn’t think they were proper seizures and ive never seen one of hers so idk either but she would experience amnesia after them, be very confused and dazed. She also wouldn’t experience any pain during the seizures but would afterwards when she came out of them. I’m only really looking for advice.
18.answer:
I’m not a substitute for a qualified clinician, but here are the main points most obstetricians/neurologists would run through when a 19-year-old in early pregnancy begins to have new “seizure-like” spells.

1. Make sure they really are epileptic seizures  
   • Video EEG monitoring, if available, is the gold standard.  
   • About one-third of “seizures” that start in pregnancy turn out to be something else:  
     – Syncope (fainting from low BP, arrhythmia, pulmonary embolism, hypoglycaemia).  
     – Psychogenic non-epileptic events (PNES).  
     – Sleep disorders (REM-behaviour disorder, night terrors).  
     – Migraine or vestibular events.

2. Rule out pregnancy-specific causes that can imitate or trigger seizures  
   • Eclampsia / pre-eclampsia: typically after 20 weeks, but rare early cases and molar pregnancies do occur. Ask about headaches, visual changes, RUQ/epigastric pain, BP >140/90, proteinuria.  
   • Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis or ischaemic/haemorrhagic stroke (pregnancy is hyper-coagulable).  
   • Amniotic fluid or pulmonary embolism (saturation drops, sudden syncope/seizure). An urgent leg Doppler, CT-PA or V/Q scan may be needed if PE is suspected.

3. Correct metabolic triggers  
   • Low magnesium can provoke seizures and dangerous heart rhythms; IV or oral replacement is usually safe in pregnancy.  
   • Also check Na⁺, Ca²⁺, K⁺, glucose, B12, folate, thyroid function, liver function, infection screen.

4. Look for structural / infectious CNS disease  
   • MRI brain without gadolinium (safe in pregnancy) if focal findings, persistent confusion, severe headache, meningism or abnormal neurological examination.  
   • Lumbar puncture if infection, encephalitis, or autoimmune encephalitis is on the radar.

5. Cardiovascular work-up if spells begin with dizziness/SpO₂ 93 %  
   • 12-lead ECG and possibly 24-h Holter for arrhythmia or prolonged QT.  
   • Echocardiogram if murmur or cardiac history.  
   • Orthostatic vitals to rule out vasovagal or autonomic syncope.

6. Immediate safety advice for your friend  
   • Do NOT drive, swim alone, or climb heights until a diagnosis is clear.  
   • Keep a seizure diary: time, duration, description, triggers, recovery period, meds taken, preceding food intake/BP/SpO₂. A phone video of an episode is invaluable to the neurologist.  
   • If a spell lasts >5 min, occurs back-to-back without full recovery, or involves significant bluish colour, call EMS – that is treated as status epilepticus.  
   • During an event: turn her on her left side, cushion head, loosen tight clothing, do not restrain or place anything in mouth, time the episode, check blood glucose if possible.

7. Specialist follow-up  
   • High-risk obstetric (Maternal-Fetal Medicine) clinic plus Neurology.  
   • If episodes persist, admission to an Epilepsy Monitoring Unit for continuous video-EEG is often decisive and can be done in pregnancy.  
   • Many anti-seizure medicines are relatively safe in pregnancy if truly needed (levetiracetam, lamotrigine); folic acid 4 mg daily is standard if any AED is prescribed.

8. When to seek care immediately  
   • Severe or new persistent headache, vision loss, right-upper-quadrant/epigastric pain, BP ≥160/110.  
   • Vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, loss of pregnancy symptoms.  
   • Any focal neurological deficit (weakness, slurred speech).  
   • Fever, neck stiffness, photophobia.  
   • Prolonged or repeated seizures, or any episode with major injury or fetal distress.

Practical next step  
Because the in-hospital work-up was unrevealing and magnesium was low, the very next things most clinicians would do are: (a) replete magnesium fully, (b) arrange outpatient video-EEG or re-admit to an Epilepsy Monitoring Unit, (c) get an MRI brain, and (d) have Maternal-Fetal Medicine and Neurology jointly follow her. If at any point her BP rises, urine shows protein, or she develops severe headache/visual changes, treat as possible pre-eclampsia/eclampsia until proven otherwise.

Encourage your friend to keep all appointments, take her prenatal vitamins (plus any magnesium prescribed), stay hydrated, and avoid situations where a sudden loss of consciousness could injure her or the baby.

19.question: 22F, 110 poundsCurrent Medications- Lamictal 200 mg in the AM & PM so 400mg total a day. Vyvanse 40mg once a day, don't take on the weekends unless I am scheduled to work.I smoke medical marijuana and HARDLY drink, probably 3 times year.Background- So I need to say now that when I was explained all of this I was 16 so it is very dumbed down and I still do not fully understand it lol. But when I was 15 I took 47 coricidin cough and cold pills and was not breathing by the time EMS arrived. I was intubated for about three weeks and once I began being able to breathe on my own it was clear I was in some form of psychosis. I was ripping IV's out, biting nurses, running down the halls and a lot more crazy shit. My dad recorded some of these breakouts and its actually horrifying to see because for me it is all black. I don't remember any of it. I simply took the pills and woke up 2 months later in a mental hospital confused as shit. I believe I had dextromethorphan toxicity. Anyway fast forward 6 months and I had my first seizure. I have grand Mal seizures where I full on flop. They usually last about 2 minutes and my Husband (he saw my first seizure and pretty much every one since then) says that before I start full on seizing I become real quiet and look up to my left. After doing all of the tests (sleep test, EEG & MRI) my neurologist explain to me that there was a lesion in my brain with secretions firing off and if they fire off at the right time I have a seizure. Then more recently I had a newer MRI done where my neurologist said there was only a tiny possible lesion? I dont understand how it would get smaller? I still have seizures if I do not take my medication. I actually think I have more now because if I miss one dose Ill have a seizure, whereas as a teenager I was shit about taking my medications and did not have near as many seizures.So my questions is could my lesion be shrinking and if so would my seizures stop?
19.answer:
I’ll answer your main question first – “Can a brain lesion get smaller and, if it does, will my seizures stop?” – and then go over a few things that usually come up when someone in your situation follows-up with a neurologist.

1. Can a lesion disappear or shrink?
• Yes, some lesions do get smaller on later MRIs.  
  – If the original MRI was done while the brain was still swollen or inflamed from the overdose/ lack of oxygen, what the radiologist called a “lesion” could have been a mix of true injury plus surrounding swelling (edema). Swelling subsides, so the abnormal area that shows up on MRI can look smaller 6–12 months later.  
  – Dead brain tissue can “contract” (turn into a thin scar, called gliosis or encephalomalacia). That also looks smaller.  
  – Sometimes it’s simply technical: different scanner, different slice thickness, different radiologist, so a focus that looked obvious on one MRI is described as only “possible” on another.

2. If the lesion shrinks, do seizures automatically stop?
• Unfortunately, not necessarily. Once a patch of cortex has been injured it can remain electrically “irritable” even after it has scarred down or even if it is too small to be seen on routine MRI.  
• Seizures come from a network: the original scar is the spark, but surrounding healthy cells can learn that abnormal firing pattern and keep producing seizures even after the spark is smaller.  
• Some people do grow out of post-injury epilepsy, but the chances depend on several things:  
  – How long you’ve been having seizures (the longer, the more likely the brain has cemented that pathway).  
  – Whether you have risk factors that make the brain more susceptible (sleep deprivation, stimulant medication, marijuana, missed doses, hormonal changes, etc.).  
  – EEG findings: people whose EEG becomes completely normal over time have a better chance of remission.  
• In adults who have a clearly identifiable structural lesion, the long-term odds of never needing medication again are lower than in childhood “idiopathic” epilepsy, but remission can still happen. A rough guide: if someone remains completely seizure-free for 2–5 years on medication AND the follow-up EEG is normal, a careful taper can be tried. Even then, 20-40 % will relapse.

3. Why does missing even one dose cause a seizure now when it didn’t before?
• Lamotrigine has a half-life of 25–30 hours. If you’re on a steady twice-daily schedule, blood levels are pretty smooth; if you miss a single dose your level can drop below the threshold that protects you. Because you now go longer between seizures, when one does happen it often tracks to a clearly visible trigger such as a missed pill.  
• Earlier in the course you were having more frequent seizures, so the relationship to triggers was harder to spot.

4. How to improve seizure control and maybe increase the chance of someday tapering:
• Take lamotrigine at the same times every day. Use smartphone alarms, blister packs, or a weekly pill organizer.  
• Keep a seizure/ trigger diary: date, time, missed dose? sleep pattern? alcohol? cannabis? illness? menstruation? This helps a neurologist decide if medication adjustment is needed.  
• Stimulants: Vyvanse can lower seizure threshold in some people. If it clearly precedes seizures (especially on workdays) discuss dose or alternatives with both your neurologist and psychiatrist.  
• Cannabis: data are mixed; THC in high doses can provoke seizures, while high-CBD preparations can help. Because “medical marijuana” products vary, mention exactly what you use.  
• Alcohol binges, sleep deprivation, flashing lights, and stress are classic triggers – minimize them.  
• Consider getting a rescue medication (e.g., intranasal midazolam) for prolonged seizures.  
• Update EEG every couple of years and MRI as your neurologist recommends. If seizures ever become drug-resistant (≥2 well-chosen medications at adequate doses and still >1 seizure/ year), you could be evaluated for epilepsy surgery even if the MRI lesion looks small.

5. Practical points about your current regimen:
Weight ≈ 50 kg  
Lamotrigine 400 mg/day → ~8 mg/kg, within the usual maintenance range (5–10 mg/kg). If side-effects (rash, dizziness, vision changes) appear, report immediately.  
Make sure any prescriber who starts or stops other meds checks for lamotrigine interactions (e.g., estrogen-containing birth-control pills can lower its level; valproate can more than double it).  
Get a blood level once in a while (some clinicians do it only if there’s a problem; others yearly).

Bottom line
A lesion that was once obvious can look smaller later without meaning the epileptic focus is gone. Your chance of ultimately becoming seizure-free without medication isn’t zero, but it depends far more on long-term seizure control, normalizing EEGs, and avoiding triggers than on MRI appearance alone. For now the best way to keep yourself safe – and to maximize the odds of remission down the road – is rigorous adherence to lamotrigine, careful lifestyle management, and regular follow-up with your neurologist.

20.question: 40 years old, 10 stone (140 pounds)Epilepsy-Asthma-Thyroid-Scoliosis-Bladder conditionMeds: Epilim chrono 500mg, Epilim 200mg, Etanercept, Ventolin, LevothyroxineI take one 200mg Epilim pill in the morning and two 500mg ones in the evening. In the morning I take the 200mg pill with my breakfast fine, but when I take the 500mg tablet after dinner, I swallow the tablet with water like in the morning, I'm coughing up the water and the pill is getting lodged in my throat. This has been happening every other day in the last 2 weeks.I'm coughing up phelgmn and I've tried warm water to force the pill down as it is a enteric-coated pill, which reacts with water straight away. The longer the pill stays in my throat, it scrapes my throat and blood comes out with my spit. My throat is sore afterwards which takes two days to recover. I have to take my Epilepsy pills for life.I'm afraid to keep taking the 500ml tablets in the evening, as I keep having this reaction.Should I take 5 of the 200mg pills instead to make up the 1000mg required in the evening which are easier to swallow or do something else?I'm going to speak to my pharmacist and GP tomorrow morning as well about it.
20.answer:
Short version  
• Don’t keep forcing the 500 mg tablets down – the bleeding means your gullet is already being injured.  
• Do NOT simply swap tonight’s dose for five 200 mg tablets without the prescriber’s agreement – the 200 mg tablets are an immediate-release formulation and will give a quite different blood-level profile from the 500 mg “Chrono” (prolonged-release) tablets. Sudden changes in valproate levels can precipitate seizures.  
• Phone or see your GP / epilepsy team / pharmacist as soon as possible.  In most countries they can change you, the same day, to one of the following which are much easier to swallow:  
 – Liquid sodium valproate (Epilim liquid 200 mg/5 mL)  
 – Prolonged-release granules/sachets that you sprinkle on a spoon of soft food (Epilim Chronosphere, Episenta MR sachets, etc.)  
 – Smaller strength Chrono tablets (e.g. 300 mg or 250 mg) that you take as several tablets but which are physically smaller.  
 – Halving the 500 mg Chrono tablet along its score line (allowed for most brands) so each piece is only 250 mg – then take four halves one after the other with plenty of fluid.  

Longer explanation  

1. Why the 500 mg “Chrono” tablet is a problem  
• It is large, enteric-coated and designed not to dissolve until it reaches the intestine.  
• If it lodges in the oesophagus it starts to absorb water and swells; that is why it “sticks”, scrapes, and causes bleeding. Repeated episodes can produce ulceration or a stricture.  

2. Why you should not change to 5 × 200 mg tablets on your own  
• Your current daily dose is 200 mg IR in the morning + 1000 mg MR at night = 1200 mg.  
• Five 200 mg tablets would still be 1000 mg, but they are immediate-release. Blood concentrations would rise quickly, fall earlier in the night and be low by morning. That can:  
 – increase side-effects (sedation, tremor, nausea)  
 – increase seizure risk in the early morning hours when levels have dropped.  

3. Safer, authorised alternatives your prescriber can issue immediately  
• Liquid valproate:  5 mL = 200 mg.  You would take 25 mL (just over one tablespoon) at night instead of the two 500 mg tablets.  
• Modified-release sachets/granules:  Each sachet is 500 mg; you pour the contents onto a spoonful of yoghurt/jam and swallow.  No chewing and no big tablet.  
• Smaller MR tablets:  300 mg or 250 mg Chrono tablets exist; four of them (4 × 300 mg = 1200 mg total day dose) are often easier to swallow.  
• Halving the 500 mg Chrono tablet:  Most brands have a score line and the SPC states they may be broken. Two halves swallowed separately with plenty of fluid are easier than one whole tablet.  

4. What you can try tonight if you must take the 500 mg tablets and cannot get a replacement in time  
• Drink a full glass of water beforehand to “prime” the oesophagus.  
• Use the “lean-forward” technique: put the tablet well back on the tongue, take a mouthful of water, tilt your chin slightly toward your chest, and swallow.  
• Use a tablespoon of thick yoghurt, custard or apple purée: bury the tablet in the spoonful and swallow the whole thing in one go, then follow with water. The coating prevents interaction with the food as long as you do not chew.  
• Stay upright for at least 10–15 minutes afterwards.  
If it still sticks or causes bleeding, seek same-day medical review.  

5. Get the throat/food-pipe checked  
Because you are now getting bleeding and soreness that lasts for days, your GP may want to arrange an ENT or gastro-oesophageal assessment to rule out ulceration or an underlying narrowing.  

Bottom line  
Do not alter the formulation or dose of valproate on your own; contact your pharmacist/GP urgently and ask to be switched to an easier-to-swallow modified-release form (liquid, granules, or smaller tablets) and have your throat evaluated if the trauma persists.

21.question: 23F, 5'8, 134 lbs, medications: trokendi xr switching over to topiramate, nonsmoker, epileptic, no location, and no photo.Hello, my medication trokendi xr is currently on backorder, and my neurologist sent a new prescription in for some generic topiramate. The only question I did not get to ask him was if I have to continue only taking 1 a day since trokendi is an extended release or if I have to take 2 a day. Thanks!
21.answer:
Short answer  
• If the pharmacy gives you an immediate-release (IR) topiramate tablet, the total daily dose is normally split and taken twice a day (every ~12 hours).  
• If the pharmacy gives you an extended-release (ER) topiramate capsule (sometimes labeled “topiramate ER” or “topiramate-XR”), you still take it once a day just as you did with Trokendi XR.  

Why the number of doses matters  
Trokendi XR releases medication slowly for 24 h, so one dose keeps your blood level steady all day. Plain topiramate tablets dump the dose in a few hours; blood levels fall before the next day, so they are prescribed in two divided doses to maintain seizure control and avoid side-effects from peaks and troughs.

How to tell which product you received  
• Look at the label: If it says “topiramate 25 mg tablet,” “topiramate 50 mg tablet,” etc., with no “ER,” “XR,” or “extended-release,” it is the immediate-release form (take twice a day).  
• If it says “topiramate ER,” “topiramate XR,” “topiramate extended-release,” or something like “24-hour sprinkle capsule,” it is the once-daily form.  
• Tablets are usually small, flat or round, and can be split; ER products are capsules filled with beads and should not be split or chewed.

Common one-to-one switch  
Example: 100 mg Trokendi XR once daily → 50 mg immediate-release topiramate twice daily (50 mg AM + 50 mg PM). For migraine prevention 50 mg XR once daily → 25 mg IR twice daily.

Do NOT change the number of doses on your own  
Even a single missed or incorrectly timed dose of an anticonvulsant can provoke seizures. Call your neurologist or ask the dispensing pharmacist to confirm exactly how they want you to take the product they dispensed.

Key points to ask/confirm  
1. Is this immediate-release or extended-release?  
2. What total milligram dose per day am I supposed to take?  
3. How should I space the doses (e.g., 8 am and 8 pm)?  
4. Do I need a taper or can I make a direct switch starting with the next dose?  

Until you receive a clear answer from your prescriber or pharmacist, continue taking your current once-daily XR dose if you still have capsules. If you have run out, contact the pharmacy/neurologist urgently for exact instructions rather than guessing; seizure risk outweighs the inconvenience of an extra phone call.

22.question: Before I start of with everything I am diagnosed with BPD, epilepsy, anxiety, aura headaches, pcos, and vertigo. It started with me just getting vertigo in 2019 and it went away with medication but came back within a week and i got chest pains and went to see a cardiologist and everything was okay. I was then sent to a neurologist and they finally diagnosed me with epilepsy but I don't have seizures. for awhile though i was having episodes of "falling into the ground" feelings and if i was in the car it would feel like i was falling back. I would just get odd feelings like that. i was told i basically have micro seizures. there's times where i get dizzy and don't feel good or just don't feel right and im guessing it could just be depersonalization but I'm honestly not sure. l've been now struggling with a migraine for over a month now and i had a mri done that came out normal and im having another one and a mra done tomorrow to see if something looks off. I've been struggling with migraines for awhile but never like this. I'm honestly just hoping maybe someone has had a similar experience or a answer? idk I've been in so much painMedications: metaformin Aimoveg, only one shot so far venlafaxine bupropion Mag oxide ToprimateHeight; 5'7 Weight: 180 I only smoke sometimes , I never drink alcohol
22.answer:
I can’t diagnose you over the Internet, but I can walk you through the most common explanations your neurologist and headache-specialist colleagues usually think about in a case like yours, why the tests you’re having make sense, and what questions or changes you can raise at your next appointment.

1. “Status migrainosus” (a migraine that never completely breaks).  
   •  Any single attack that lasts > 72 h—even if the pain waxes and wanes—is called status migrainosus.  
   •  MRI/MRA are done once to be sure nothing more sinister (aneurysm, venous clot, tumor, Chiari malformation, etc.) is hiding behind the pain.  
   •  A typical rescue plan in the infusion suite or ER is: IV fluids + an anti-emetic (metoclopramide or prochlorperazine) + NSAID (ketorolac) ± steroid (methyl-prednisolone) ± DHE. If you’ve only been given oral medicines at home, ask whether “breaking the cycle” with an infusion or steroid course is appropriate.  

2. Vestibular or “dizzy” migraine.  
   •  Fits vertigo going away, coming back, and the falling-sensation in the car.  
   •  Topiramate and Aimovig are both standard preventives for vestibular migraine; it can take 8–12 weeks (two to three Aimovig injections) to judge benefit.  
   •  Vestibular-rehab PT can speed recovery of balance symptoms even while medications are still being fine-tuned.

3. Focal aware seizures (“micro-seizures”).  
   •  Brief “I’m falling through the floor/I’m not really here” spells can indeed be focal seizures arising from the temporal lobe.  
   •  Topiramate treats both epilepsy and migraine, so it is a logical choice.  
   •  Venlafaxine and bupropion both lower seizure threshold. If seizures are not fully controlled, your neurologist may want to taper or switch one or both.

4. Medication-related dizziness or headache.  
   •  Venlafaxine: dose changes or missed doses can cause head “zaps,” dizziness, nausea.  
   •  Bupropion: can cause anxiety-like dizziness and, rarely, headaches.  
   •  Metformin: lactic-acidosis headache/dizziness is extremely rare but GI upset is common and can mimic nausea of migraine.  
   •  Magnesium oxide: generally well-tolerated; high doses can cause diarrhea → dehydration → more headache.  
   •  Nicotine: even “occasional” smoking is a migraine trigger in some people.

5. Hormonal / PCOS contribution.  
   •  Estrogen fluctuations are a classic migraine trigger. Irregular cycles in PCOS can mean the “withdrawal” drop in estrogen is unpredictable, hence unpredictable attacks.  
   •  Some patients benefit from a continuous combined oral contraceptive (no placebo week) or from a progestin-only method to level hormones—worth asking your gynecologist and neurologist together, because estrogen can affect seizure threshold.

6. Other medical mimics to be sure have been excluded  
   •  Anemia, thyroid dysfunction, vitamin-B12 deficiency, POTS (postural tachycardia) and low blood pressure can produce chronic light-headedness and “not quite here” feelings. Simple blood work and lying/standing vitals rule most of these out.

What to discuss/ask next time you see your neurologist

•  “Do you think this is status migrainosus or vestibular migraine that hasn’t responded yet? Should we try a steroid burst, DHE, or an infusion to break it?”  
•  “Do my current doses of venlafaxine or bupropion raise concern about seizure threshold? Would an SSRI (e.g., sertraline) or another non-stimulant option be safer?”  
•  “Would adding an acute CGRP pill (ubrogepant/rimegepant) or a gepant as preventive be reasonable while we wait for Aimovig to kick in?”  
•  “Should I keep a daily headache/vertigo diary—pain level, aura, triggers, meds taken, menstrual cycle—to guide adjustments?”  
•  “Would vestibular-rehab PT or a referral to an otoneurology clinic be helpful?”  
•  “Are my labs (CBC, iron, thyroid, B12, fasting glucose) current?”

Self-care steps that genuinely help chronic migraine and vestibular symptoms

•  Hydration: 2–3 L of water daily, especially if you take magnesium or smoke.  
•  Regular sleep schedule (same bedtime/wake time ±30 min).  
•  Balanced meals every 4 h while awake; avoid long fasting stretches that trigger hypoglycemia.  
•  Limit caffeine to ≤ 200 mg/day (≈2 small cups coffee) at consistent times.  
•  Aerobic exercise 30 min most days—shown to reduce migraine frequency and help PCOS/insulin resistance.  
•  Relaxation practice (breathing app, meditation, progressive muscle relaxation)—helps anxiety and down-regulates the “migraine switch.”

Red-flag reasons to go to the ER (even if MRI was normal last week)

•  Sudden “worst headache of my life” or abrupt change in pattern.  
•  New neurological deficit (weakness, speech slurring, double vision) lasting > 60 min.  
•  Uncontrollable vomiting, dehydration.  
•  Fainting or true loss of consciousness.

Bottom line

Your work-up so far (MRI/MRA, EEG) is what neurologists do to be sure nothing dangerous is being missed. The most likely scenario, given normal imaging and your symptom pattern, is a stubborn vestibular/status migraine combined with focal aware seizures and anxiety. All of these can feed off each other, but they are treatable. Push for an aggressive “break the cycle” plan, review whether venlafaxine/bupropion are helping or hindering the seizure side of things, and keep a meticulous diary. Most patients do find the right preventive/acute combo; it sometimes just takes a few medication cycles and good communication with the care team.

23.question: So i had an epilepsy seizure when i was like 4-5 months old. I took medication daily for 7 years, and i had no more seizures. Im 17 years old now. Can my epilepsy come back? If it can what can cause it?
23.answer:
I’m not able to give you personal medical advice, but I can tell you what the studies and guidelines say so you know what to discuss with your own doctor.

1. How often does epilepsy return after many seizure-free years?  
• In children who have been seizure-free for at least two years and then stop medication, about 70-80 % will remain seizure-free long-term.  
• If you reach 10 years without a seizure (and 5 years off medicine) the risk of ever having another one falls to roughly 5-10 % over a lifetime—only a little higher than the risk in people who never had epilepsy.  
• The exact risk depends on why you had seizures as a baby, what your EEG or brain scans looked like, and whether you have any other neurologic problems. Your own neurologist (or pediatric neurologist who followed you) can tell you which risk group you fit into.

2. Things that can make a recurrence more likely (lower the “seizure threshold”) in anyone who has ever had epilepsy:  
• Sleep deprivation or severe fatigue  
• Heavy alcohol use or binge drinking (especially the “hangover” period)  
• Recreational drugs such as cocaine, MDMA, amphetamines, synthetic cannabinoids, etc.  
• High fevers or serious infections  
• Certain prescription or over-the-counter medicines that are known to provoke seizures (e.g., bupropion, tramadol, some antibiotics at high doses, diphenhydramine/Benadryl in excess, large doses of decongestants)  
• Hormonal fluctuations, notably around menstruation in females  
• Strong flashing lights or video-game type strobe effects if you have photosensitive epilepsy on EEG  
• Significant physical or emotional stress, dehydration, skipping meals, or very low blood sugar  
• Head injury (especially concussion or anything that leads to bleeding in the brain)

3. Practical steps to keep the risk low:  
• Maintain regular sleep—aim for 7–9 hours every night.  
• Moderate or avoid alcohol; never binge-drink.  
• Stay away from recreational drugs.  
• Treat fevers promptly and stay well-hydrated when you’re ill.  
• Use protective headgear for activities with head-injury risk (cycling, contact sports, etc.).  
• Check the label or ask a pharmacist about any new medication you take.  
• Manage stress with exercise, mindfulness, or counseling if you need it.

4. When to seek medical review now:  
• If you have even a single episode that might have been a seizure (unexplained blackout, sudden confusion, muscle jerks while awake, etc.).  
• If you develop new neurologic symptoms (persistent headache, weakness, vision changes).  
• Before you start driving (some states still require a note confirming you have been seizure-free).  
• If you plan to take stimulant medication (e.g., for ADHD) or any drug your doctor says could lower seizure threshold.

Key takeaway  
Because you have gone more than a decade without a seizure, the odds are strongly in your favor that it will not return. Still, the risk is not zero, so it’s smart to minimize the triggers listed above and keep a regular check-in with a physician who knows your history. If you ever do experience something that feels like a seizure, get evaluated promptly—many people do very well if treatment is restarted early.

24.question: According to my sister (her mother), my 5 year old niece was eating ice cream the other night at a restaurant when she got real still, said she had a headache, then her whole body fell and she slid under the table. My sister picked her up and my niece was totally stiff and not breathing, then her legs started convulsing. After about 20 seconds she woke up and exclaimed “what was that” and started crying. She was brought to urgent care but was fine by that point, and got an EEG this morning (about 3 days later) and everything appeared normal. My niece later described it as falling asleep without even trying. Apparently my niece has passed out twice before while eating ice cream (never a seizure), and also once when she was much littler when a kid ran into her hard. All the doctor said about this recent episode is it’s “interesting”.What could be causing this? Are there links between ice cream, sugar, or dairy and passing out/seizures? Could it be a pain response to brain freeze? To my knowledge there is no family history of seizures. My sister is really worried and I’m just trying to help find answers.
24.answer:
First, remember that only the doctors who are actually caring for your niece can make a diagnosis.  
What follows is an explanation of the main conditions that are usually considered when a healthy‐looking preschool child abruptly “passes out” and briefly jerks or stiffens while eating ice-cream or after a sudden bump, yet is perfectly normal a minute or two later and has a normal routine EEG.

1. Reflex / situational syncope with brief “anoxic seizures”  
   • Also called reflex anoxic seizures, convulsive syncope, pallid breath-holding spells, or in older children “swallowing / deglutition syncope.”  
   • Trigger: a sudden, powerful vagal reflex (overshooting of the vagus nerve) that momentarily slows the heart or even causes a 2-5 s cardiac pause. Pain (being run into), fright, or strong stimulation of nerves in the mouth, throat, or face—especially by something very cold—can all set it off. Classic examples are a toddler who faints after a minor head bump, or an older child who keels over while swallowing ice-cold water.  
   • What it looks like: The child goes pale, eyes roll up, posture goes limp, then within 5–15 s oxygen to the brain is low enough that the body may stiffen and jerk for another 5–20 s. As soon as the heart resumes its normal rhythm the child regains consciousness quickly, often with only brief confusion and then is entirely normal.  
   • Tests: Routine EEG is usually normal because the event is not due to electrical brain malfunction. A resting ECG can be normal as well; a Holter/event monitor or tilt-table test sometimes shows the transient slowing of the heart.  
   • Prognosis: Generally excellent—most children “outgrow” it by early school age. Avoiding known triggers (very cold drinks gulped quickly, sudden pain) helps.  

2. True epileptic seizure  
   • Less likely when attacks always start with a very specific physical act such as biting into ice-cream. Sugar, dairy, or “brain freeze” are not recognized seizure triggers, and epilepsy almost never causes a child to stop breathing and become pale before the jerking starts—the jerking itself is usually the first sign.  
   • A normal inter-ictal EEG lowers the odds but does not rule epilepsy out completely; however, the story you give fits convulsive syncope far better.  

3. Cardiac arrhythmia (e.g., long-QT, CPVT)  
   • Must always be excluded in any child who loses consciousness abruptly. Ice-cream does not trigger arrhythmias directly, but vagal swings, exertion, or adrenaline surges can.  
   • The pediatrician will usually order at least a 12-lead ECG; sometimes Holter, exercise test, or echocardiogram are added.  

4. Metabolic problems (hypoglycaemia, calcium drop, allergy, etc.)  
   • Unlikely here: the attacks are too sudden, too brief, and resolve without treatment.  

Is there something unique about ice-cream?  
Cold substances applied to the hard palate trigger the “trigeminal–vagal” reflex responsible for the familiar but harmless “brain-freeze” headache. In a very small subset of people, that same afferent volley can produce an exaggerated vagal response: heart rate and blood pressure drop, and they faint. The same reflex explains the well-described but rare “swallow syncope” in adults who pass out while drinking cold carbonated beverages.

Why does she jerk if it’s only a faint?  
Any time blood flow to the brain stops for more than 6–8 seconds, the cerebral cortex becomes electrically silent; another few seconds later the deeper centers that normally inhibit spinal reflexes go offline and the limbs may stiffen or twitch—an “anoxic seizure.” Because the electrical storm begins in the brainstem rather than the cortex, a routine EEG after the event is usually normal.

What should the family do now?  
• Keep a diary of every spell (date, what she was doing, color change, eye position, breathing, length of unresponsiveness). A phone video is invaluable.  
• Ask the pediatrician whether an ECG, Holter/event monitor, or tilt-table test has been or should be done to document any heart-rate pause. A referral to both pediatric neurology and pediatric cardiology is common.  
• In the meantime have her sit while eating anything very cold; small bites or sips instead of large mouthfuls; avoid gulping ice-cold drinks in hot weather; and keep a close eye on her whenever she’s in a situation that has triggered episodes before.  
• If an episode lasts longer than a minute, is followed by prolonged confusion, or is accompanied by bluish color that does not rapidly clear, call EMS.

Key take-away  
The pattern you describe—specific trigger (ice-cream or sudden pain), color change, limpness, brief apnea, stiffening/jerking, rapid full recovery, normal exam and EEG—fits reflex anoxic syncope far better than epilepsy or food-related allergy/toxicity. The condition is alarming but usually benign and often disappears with age, yet cardiac causes must be excluded and guidance from a pediatric neurologist/cardiologist is essential for complete reassurance.

25.question: 27 female, I suffer from autism, epilepsy, depressionLymph node on left side of neck is swollen, hearing loss, ears feel blocked, headache and can’t sleep or eat much. I take lamotrigine and clozapam
25.answer:
I’m not able to examine you and this information can’t replace an in-person assessment, but I can help you think through what might be going on, what to watch for, and how soon you should be seen.

1. Possible causes to keep in mind  
• Ear or upper-respiratory infection (viral or bacterial): ­fluid behind the eardrum or an acute middle-ear infection can block hearing and make the nearby lymph node enlarge.  
• Outer-ear infection (swimmer’s ear): ­pain when you press/pull the ear, sometimes accompanied by swollen nodes.  
• Tonsil or throat infection (strep, mono, dental abscess, etc.): ­can enlarge neck nodes and give referred ear pain/fullness.  
• Mastoiditis (infection of the bone behind the ear): ­rare but serious; often causes fever, worsening pain, tenderness or redness behind the ear.  
• Drug reaction: ­Lamotrigine can (rarely) cause swollen nodes as part of a hypersensitivity reaction (usually within weeks of starting or after a dose increase and typically with fever and rash).  
• Other causes (less common in your age group but important if symptoms persist): thyroid problems, salivary-gland issues, autoimmune disease, lymphoma, etc.

2. Red-flag symptoms that mean you should seek care right away (ER / same-day clinic)  
• High fever, chills, or drenching night sweats  
• Rapidly enlarging or very painful lump, redness spreading over the skin, or swelling that makes it hard to turn your head  
• New weakness, numbness, vision changes, severe vertigo, gait problems (especially with your epilepsy history)  
• Trouble swallowing, breathing, drooling, or muffled “hot-potato” voice  
• Severe headache unlike your usual ones, neck stiffness, or vomiting  
• Rash, especially if you recently adjusted your lamotrigine dose  
• Persistent vomiting or inability to keep fluids down  
• Seizure activity different from usual

3. What you can do while arranging follow-up
