• Schedule an urgent visit with your primary-care clinician or an ear-nose-throat (ENT) specialist within the next 24–48 h if no red flags but the symptoms are ongoing. You will likely need:  
  – Physical exam of ears, throat, and neck  
  – Possible ear canal cleaning or eardrum check with a tympanogram  
  – Basic blood work or a throat culture if infection is suspected  
  – Imaging (ultrasound of the node or CT of the neck/ear) if it doesn’t improve within a couple of weeks or if atypical features appear  
• Symptom relief (if you do NOT have contraindications):  
  – Ibuprofen or acetaminophen as directed for pain and fever  
  – Warm compresses on the swollen node (15 min, 3–4 times/day)  
  – Stay well-hydrated; warm tea or broth can soothe the throat and help drainage  
  – Sleep with the head of the bed slightly elevated to reduce ear pressure  
  – Try gentle Valsalva (pinch nose, close mouth, exhale gently) or yawning to pop ears—stop if painful.  
• Continue lamotrigine and clonazepam as prescribed. Stopping lamotrigine suddenly can provoke seizures. If you’re prescribed an antibiotic, tell the prescriber about your epilepsy drugs—some antibiotics (e.g., clarithromycin) can raise lamotrigine levels.  
• Track specifics: size of the node (take a picture or note if it’s grape-size vs. marble-size), fever readings, any drainage from the ear, and changes in hearing. This helps your clinician decide on treatment and whether imaging is needed.  
• Appetite & sleep: lack of both can worsen seizures and mood. Aim for simple, soft foods (soups, smoothies, yogurt) and maintain a regular sleep routine (bedtime/wake time). If anxiety or depression is keeping you awake, let your doctor know; they can adjust therapy or refer you for additional support.

4. Likely next steps a clinician might take  
• If middle-ear infection is confirmed: oral antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin) ± nasal steroid or decongestant spray.  
• If outer-ear infection: antibiotic + steroid ear drops, keep ear dry.  
• If fluid without infection (serous otitis): nasal steroid spray, auto-insufflation exercises, and monitoring; ENT may place a tube if it persists.  
• If mono or viral infection: supportive care; antibiotics do not help (and amoxicillin in mono can cause rash).  
• If abscessed lymph node: may need needle aspiration or incision/drainage.  
• If drug reaction suspected: blood tests, stop/adjust the drug under strict medical supervision.

Bottom line  
With a swollen neck node, blocked ears, hearing loss, and headache, you should be evaluated in person within the next day or so at urgent care or by your primary/ENT doctor—sooner (today) if any red-flag features appear. In the meantime, treat pain, stay hydrated, and continue your seizure medications. Keep careful notes on your symptoms, and don’t hesitate to seek emergency care if breathing, swallowing, or neurological symptoms worsen.

26.question: I was a healthy, fit male in my early 40s when I started having episodes where I would get light headed and sometimes pass out after a work out in the weight room that included pull ups. Fyi, I was and still am(60yrs old now)taking PPIs for Gerd caused by a Hiatal hernia. My physician sent me to a neurologist who said I had Epilepsy and wanted to put me on meds. I explained it only happened after work outs, I refused the meds. I went to the Director on the Southern Epilepsy Foundation, he examined me and confirmed I did not have Epilepsy. He had me go through a barrage of heart tests, thinking I was experiencing Syncope. They reached no conclusive explanation. I have thought it could be something to do with the proximity of the Vagus nerve to the Hiatal hernia and the pressure of lifting weights causing a vertigo/fainting response or the lack of nutrient absorption due to PPI use that created the light headed/fainting episodes? My physician said to stop doing pull ups. I haven’t had an episode in a few years now. I did stop the pull-ups which I miss and backed off the amount of weight I lift. Still on PPIs. Any thoughts? Thank you for any feed back.
26.answer:
What you describe – light-headedness or transient loss of consciousness that occurred only within a few minutes of an intense weight-room session (especially sets of pull-ups) – fits best with the broad heading “exercise-associated syncope.”  
When someone faints around exercise physicians first want to rule out dangerous cardiac disease, then look at neuro-vascular reflexes, metabolic issues, and (much less commonly) true seizure.  You have already had an extensive cardiac and neurologic work-up, so the discussion below concentrates on the more “benign” – but still disconcerting – mechanisms that can be missed on standard testing.

1.  Likely physiologic mechanisms

   a.  Valsalva/weight-lifting (neuro-cardiogenic) syncope  
       •  Heavy resistance exercise almost always involves breath-holding and a Valsalva manoeuvre.  
       •  During the strain phase venous return to the heart falls; when the strain is released there is an abrupt fall in arterial pressure followed by a reflex vagally-mediated bradycardia.  
       •  In susceptible people this sequence produces transient cerebral hypoperfusion and a faint.  
       •  A tilt-table test or having someone reproduce the manoeuvre while on a cardiac monitor can show the fall in blood pressure and/or a transient sinus pause.

   b.  “Head-up, arms-over-head” or carotid-sinus-related syncope  
       •  Pull-ups require neck extension and contraction of the sternocleidomastoid muscles that lie over the carotid sinus.  
       •  In middle-aged and older men carotid-sinus hypersensitivity is common. Pressure on or stretching of the sinus triggers a vagal reflex → sudden slowing of the heart and vasodilatation.  
       •  Again, nothing abnormal will show on a resting ECG or echocardiogram.

   c.  Post-exercise venous pooling (“post-exercise hypotension”)  
       •  When dynamic exercise stops abruptly muscle pumping ceases and blood pools in dilated leg vessels; cerebral perfusion can fall 15–30 %.  
       •  If you jumped off the pull-up bar and stood still this could add to the above reflexes.

   d.  Subclavian / vertebral flow limitation (rarer)  
       •  An atherosclerotic or congenital stenosis of the proximal subclavian artery can “steal” blood from the vertebral artery when the arm is raised overhead → vertebro-basilar insufficiency, dizziness or syncope.  
       •  Duplex ultrasound with arm-raising or MR-angiography would detect this.

   e.  Large intrathoracic hiatal hernia (“upside-down stomach”)  
       •  A very large hernia can intermittently compress the left atrium or trigger vagal reflexes when intrathoracic pressure rises.  
       •  This usually produces post-prandial or bending-over syncope rather than exercise-specific episodes, so it is lower on the list but still conceivable.

   f.  PPI-related electrolyte deficiency  
       •  Long-term proton-pump inhibitors can produce hypomagnesaemia, hypocalcaemia or vitamin-B12 deficiency, which may cause nonspecific dizziness or true arrhythmias, but they do not match the tightly exercise-linked pattern you describe.

2.  Why routine cardiac testing can be negative  
   •  Resting ECG, echocardiography, even treadmill tests are done under steady breathing and without the intense strain/Valsalva present in the weight room.  
   •  Reflex syncope typically needs the provoking manoeuvre (Valsalva, neck pressure, abrupt posture change) to show itself.  
   •  Arrhythmias such as brief sinus arrest or AV block during a vagal reflex may last only seconds – they can be missed unless you are being monitored at the moment of the event.

3.  How to prove the diagnosis (if you ever want to)  
   •  Tilt-table test with a Valsalva manoeuvre while on continuous beat-to-beat BP monitoring.  
   •  Carotid sinus massage under ECG/BP monitoring (contra-indicated if significant carotid plaque).  
   •  Exercise or arm-up duplex/CT-angiography if subclavian steal is suspected.  
   •  Ambulatory loop monitor or patch while reproducing the gym routine.  
   •  Serum magnesium if on long-term PPIs, and orthostatic BP measurements.

4.  Practical management (most of which you are already doing)  

   Technique & training  
   •  Breathe – do not hold your breath during the concentric phase; exhale through pursed lips, inhale on recovery.  
   •  Avoid “lock-out” or breath-hold at the top of a pull-up.  
   •  Use slightly lower loads / higher repetitions to reduce peak intrathoracic pressure.  
   •  If you feel presyncopal (tunnel vision, ear ringing) immediately stop, lower the weight, and perform light leg movements or march in place to augment venous return.

   Hydration & recovery  
   •  Adequate salt/fluid intake before resistance sessions.  
   •  Cool-down with walking or gentle cycling to maintain muscle pump.

   Carotid-sinus precautions  
   •  Limit extreme neck extension; keep head in neutral alignment during overhead work.  
   •  If needed, swap classic pull-ups for lat-pull-downs or rows, which do not require chin-up neck posture.

   Medical follow-up  
   •  If you decide to restart pull-ups, consider a supervised session wearing a patch monitor or loop recorder so that any event can be captured.  
   •  Have serum magnesium (and possibly B-12) checked periodically while on PPIs.  
   •  If hiatal hernia symptoms progress, or if you ever develop syncope unrelated to weight lifting, a gastro-enterologist or surgeon should re-evaluate the hernia.

5.  When to worry / seek immediate care  
   •  Syncope accompanied by chest pain, palpitations, or occurring while lying supine.  
   •  Family history of sudden cardiac death, previously unknown murmur, or abnormal ECG.  
   •  Episode producing injury, prolonged confusion, or focal neurologic deficit.

Bottom line  
Everything you have described, including the fact that simply eliminating breath-holding pull-ups stopped the episodes, points toward a benign reflex syncope precipitated by the Valsalva manoeuvre, neck extension, and abrupt cessation of vigorous upper-body exercise.  PPIs and the hiatal hernia are very unlikely to be the primary cause, though checking magnesium once in a while is prudent.  If you wish to re-introduce pull-ups, do so gradually, with conscious breathing and perhaps under physiologic monitoring to document that nothing dangerous is happening.

27.question: I wanted to share my experience with you to maybe get some more information about my situation.For 10 years, I have been experiencing every couple of months sudden deja vu like feeling followed by dissociation. I don’t lose consciousness or memory or have any shaking or stuff like that. The episodes are over in around 20 minutes as the feeling fade away.I’m really curious if the reason is pure anxiety (I have general anxiety disorder) or maybe something else.What makes me think about it is the fact that the episodes are sudden and apparently not related to stress.
27.answer:
I’m not in a position to diagnose you online, but I can give you an overview of the possibilities that doctors usually think about when someone describes brief, stereotyped spells of déjà-vu followed by feeling “spaced-out” or detached from reality. Then I’ll list the kinds of information a clinician will want and the tests that are sometimes ordered, so you can decide whether it’s worth pursuing a formal evaluation.

1. Anxiety-related phenomena  
   • Panic / “limited‐symptom” panic attacks  
     – Can appear to come “out of the blue,” last 5–30 min, and leave people feeling unreal (derealization) or detached from themselves (depersonalization).  
     – Often there are subtle bodily cues that the person has learned to tune out (slight heart-race, GI flutter, breath-holding) that set the spell off.  
   • Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder  
     – Spells can be spontaneous or triggered by fatigue, bright lights, caffeine, or stress you don’t consciously notice.  
     – Déjà-vu is less typical but can occur.

2. Focal (partial) seizures from the temporal lobe  
   • Classic description: sudden déjà-vu, strange familiarity or fear, odd smells/tastes, a “wave” rising in the stomach, then trance-like staring.  
   • During the seizure, people can look awake but may not respond normally; afterwards they may be tired for minutes.  
   • Most seizures last 30 s–2 min. A post-ictal fog can prolong the total spell to ~20 min.  
   • Frequency can be every few weeks to months.  
   • Neurologists evaluate with a detailed history, an EEG (sometimes prolonged/ambulatory), and often an MRI.

3. Migraine aura without headache  
   • Aura can be purely sensory/psychic and last 5–60 min.  
   • Déjà-vu and dissociation are uncommon but reported.

4. Medication, sleep-deprivation, or substance effects  
   • Antidepressants, antihistamines, cannabis, dissociatives, and even heavy caffeine use can prime the brain for brief dissociative spells.

5. Other psychiatric or neurologic conditions  
   • PTSD “flashback-like” sensations, manic or psychotic prodromes, and some neurodegenerative illnesses (very unlikely at your age unless other symptoms are present).

What professionals look for to separate these possibilities  
• A detailed description of the very start of the spell:  
  – Any smell, taste, rising sensation, visual distortion, sudden fear?  
• Your appearance to observers:  
  – Do you stare, mumble, fidget, make chewing motions, or keep responding normally?  
• Precise duration: use a clock or phone to time the next event.  
• Level of awareness: can you answer questions, form memories, do math?  
• Post-spell feeling: drained, headache, nausea, need to sleep?  
• Triggers: lack of sleep, menstrual cycle, alcohol, missing a meal, stress, bright lights, video games, etc.  
• Safety issues: spells while driving, on ladders, near water or heat.

Typical work-up if a seizure is on the table  
• Physical and neurologic exam.  
• EEG (routine 20‐minute; if unrevealing and suspicion stays high, 24-72 hr ambulatory or inpatient video-EEG).  
• Brain MRI with epilepsy protocol.  
• Basic labs (glucose, electrolytes, liver/kidney function, sometimes prolactin level drawn within 20 min of a witnessed spell).

When it still looks more psychiatric than neurologic  
• Assessment for panic, generalized anxiety, depersonalization/derealization disorder, PTSD.  
• If spells are infrequent and not dangerous, reassurance plus cognitive-behavioral therapy, grounding techniques, paced breathing, and/or an SSRI/SNRI can reduce both anxiety and dissociative episodes.

Why bother getting evaluated if it might “just” be anxiety?  
• Temporal-lobe seizures are easily missed because they rarely involve convulsions, yet they carry driving restrictions and treatment implications.  
• Even when the cause is anxiety, having a clear diagnosis and a plan (medication adjustment, therapy, lifestyle tweaks) usually makes the episodes less frightening and less frequent.

Practical steps you can take now  
1. Keep a “spell log.” Note date/time, how long it truly lasts (use a stopwatch), what you were doing, and any sensations before/during/after.  
2. If possible, have a friend or family member observe you during an episode and jot what they see.  
3. Review current meds, supplements, caffeine, alcohol, and sleep pattern; correct anything obvious (sleep <6 h/night, high caffeine, etc.).  
4. Make an appointment with your primary-care doctor or a neurologist. Bring the log.  
5. While waiting, practice grounding techniques: naming objects in the room, feeling textures, slow 4-7-8 breathing. These don’t stop seizures but can shorten anxiety/dissociative spells.  
6. Until seizures are ruled out, think about safety: avoid climbing heights, swimming alone, and consider not driving right after a spell starts.

Key take-away  
Anxiety disorders can absolutely produce sudden déjà-vu‐plus-dissociation episodes, but temporal-lobe seizures are common enough and similar enough that most clinicians would at least want to rule them out. A short neurologic evaluation (history, exam, EEG, maybe MRI) can give you clarity; if everything is normal, the focus can shift back to optimizing anxiety management.

I hope this gives you a clearer picture of why the episodes happen and what the next steps could be. Bring this information to a healthcare professional you trust so you can get a tailored plan.

28.question: Female and Male, age 26 and 27. Female with epilepsy, male no medical diagnosis. Female on Keppra and Lamotrigine.My husband and I lived in a nice little basement suite for 3 years. Wishing a couple months of moving in, I developed epilepsy (unrelated head injury). Because of this I began taking medications. Not that long after I started to get morning sickness (without being pregnant). Every day for 2 years I woke up nauseous and vomited half of those times. It was believed it was my medication as epilepsy meds are pretty rough sometimes. About 6 months after moving in, my husband began waking up with nausea about 50% of the mornings. He has a high stress job and we believed it to be anxiety. In addition to that, we adopted our old cat about a year after moving in. He has a few medical issues and takes medication morning and night. He would vomit 5/7 mornings a week. The vet believed this to be part of his medical issues. All of that lined up until we moved 2 weeks ago. None of us have been sick since. As in, our last bouts of being sick was the day we woke up in our old place and moved. No nausea, no vomiting, not a dry heave in sight. If it was just one of us, it could be psychosomatic. I’d even be willing to believe that if it was both humans. But why the cat too?If it wasn’t the medication, anxiety and cat’s diagnosis, what was happening in that house???TLDR: 2 adults and a cat experienced nausea and vomiting for years, stopped instantly the day we moved.EDIT: Thank you all so much for the answers. It has made me very relieved that we left and we plan to take action. The house is for sale, which is why we moved, so we are going to inform the current owner, the real estate agent as well as the tenants who lived above us. We are also looking at our other options around ensuring this is properly taken care of so no one else gets hurt. I’ll also follow up when it sells to ensure the new owner didn’t get left with the fall out.Thank you all again!
28.answer:
The pattern you describe is classic for an environmental exposure – something in (or entering) that basement suite was making every mammal in the space sick each night and the symptoms vanished the moment the exposure stopped.  
The single most common culprit that fits every detail is chronic, low-level carbon-monoxide (CO) poisoning.

Why CO fits so well
• Odourless, colourless, silent – you would not notice it.  
• Low levels (30-150 ppm) cause non-specific symptoms: nausea, vomiting, queasy stomach, headache, dizziness, anxiety-like feelings, “morning-sickness-type” nausea.  
• Symptoms are worst on awakening because you have just spent 6-8 h in a closed room with the furnace / water-heater / boiler / gas dryer / gas fireplace cycling. Once you go outside the CO clears from your blood within minutes to hours, so you can feel completely normal the rest of the day.  
• Cats, dogs, and birds are affected too – smaller body mass makes them ill even sooner, so a cat that vomits most mornings fits.  
• It would explain why your wife’s antiepileptic medicines and your husband’s work stress seemed to be the cause (those are believable explanations), yet all three of you stopped being sick the day you left even though the same medicines and job stress are still present.

Other possibilities exist (heavy mould with mycotoxin production, sewer-gas infiltration, volatile solvents, pesticide misuse), but they usually produce noticeable odours, respiratory complaints, eye irritation, or persist after the person has left the premises.  A “perfectly fine as soon as I walk out the door” picture is very hard to achieve with anything except carbon monoxide.

What you should do now
1. Inform the owner/landlord, the listing real-estate agent, and the upstairs tenants immediately. Tell them there may be a CO problem and that all fuel-burning appliances, chimneys, and flues need to be inspected and repaired before anyone else occupies the space.  
2. Strongly recommend that they install battery-powered, UL-listed carbon-monoxide detectors on every level, especially near bedrooms. (Many plug-in or combination smoke/CO units do not alarm until CO is already at dangerous levels; a dedicated, digital read-out detector is ideal.)  
3. If you still have access, you can bring a portable CO monitor into the old suite; readings over 9 ppm are unacceptable for long-term exposure, and anything over 35 ppm violates most residential codes.  
4. Buy a CO detector for your new home as well. They cost about as much as a family pizza and can literally save lives.

I’m glad all of you feel better – and that you moved when you did. Chronic, low-level CO poisoning is under-recognised and far more common than most people realise, but it is 100 % preventable once it’s identified.

29.question: 22 M, 150 lb, 5'8", white, myoclonus and "brain zaps" for the last two months. No history of seizures or epilepsy.Two months ago, while taking 10 mg fluoxetine daily, I decided to take some recreational substances. I can't undo this and am sober now so please don't give me too hard a time about this. I consumed 8 beers, 5 grams of kratom powder, and 50 mg of THC. The night before this, I had taken essentially the same combination minus the THC. I felt pretty much fine and fell asleep, maybe a little woozy from all the substances. However, I woke up early in the AM twitching. I didn't feel feverish or seriously unwell, so I didn't go to the doctor (I also don't have a GP right now).The twitching has persisted for the last two months. It's only when I'm sitting or lying down. It's gotten somewhat better over this time, but is worse when I'm tired or have coffee. I also experience the "brain zaps" seen in SSRI discontinuation syndrome. On a bad day, I'll twitch up to once a minute. Over the last two months, I also have seen a general shift away from twitching and toward "brain zaps."I haven't gone into urgent care or set a new appointment with a GP (which would be in, like, 2024) because I read there's no real treatment for the SSRI discontinuation brain zaps, and the twitching doesn't really get in the way that much. But I sort of notice that whenever I twitch I lose focus, which is concerning.Does this sound like something that will continue to slowly go away, or have I given myself epilepsy? My one interpretation is that I probably had mild serotonin syndrome and that combined with abruptly stopping my the fluoxetine could cause my symptoms, and that it'll just go away sooner or later. On the other hand, maybe I had a really severe seizure while I was asleep and now I have given myself epilepsy. I don't know if you can tell, but I will feel really bad if I have permanently disabled myself with drugs, but I guess any way you slice it, these are mild, localized seizures, right?
29.answer:
I can’t examine you, order tests, or make a diagnosis over the internet, but I can give you some perspective on what you’re describing and why it deserves an in-person evaluation sooner rather than later.  I’ll group the points into questions people in clinic usually want answered.

1.  Does what you’re feeling sound like “classic” epilepsy?  
   • Epileptic seizures almost always involve a sudden, brief burst of abnormal electrical activity that either           (a) impairs awareness, or  
           (b) produces a very stereotyped, repetitive movement pattern, or  
           (c) causes a clear sensory change (smell, taste, vision, déjà-vu) followed by loss of awareness.  
   • Most people with myoclonic epilepsy will “jerk” both arms at once, often right after waking, and             frequently drop objects.  
   • What you’re describing—single twitches scattered around the body while you’re relaxed, preserved          awareness, no tongue-biting, no loss of bladder control, no one witnessing you stare off or go rigid—        is not the standard presentation of epilepsy. It sounds much more like benign muscle fasciculations /          myoclonic jerks.  
   Bottom line: epilepsy is not the most likely explanation, although only an EEG can fully rule it out.

2.  Could this be prolonged serotonin-related myoclonus / SSRI withdrawal?  
   • Fluoxetine (Prozac) has a long half-life. Even a “low” 10 mg dose sticks around for weeks (its active         metabolite, norfluoxetine, ~9 days).  
   • Kratom has some serotonin-receptor activity of its own. Alcohol acutely raises serotonin, and high             doses of THC can as well. You gave your nervous system a big serotonergic push two nights in a row.  
   • Mild serotonin toxicity can produce exactly what you felt that first morning: tremor, myoclonus, feeling         “buzzed/woozy,” but still able to walk and talk. When the drug levels fall, the same receptors can               “overshoot” and you get the well-known SSRI discontinuation symptoms (“brain zaps,” head-rushes,         odd electric sensations).  
   • In most people those symptoms fade over days to weeks. Two months is longer than usual, but still           well within the range reported in case series for fluoxetine + other serotonergic agents.  
   • Things that rev up the nervous system—caffeine, sleep deprivation, anxiety—typically make the               twitches worse, exactly as you’ve noticed.

3.  Could a single bad episode “cause” permanent epilepsy?  
   • Acute toxic or withdrawal seizures (from alcohol, cocaine, bupropion, etc.) rarely convert into                 chronic epilepsy unless there is structural brain damage (stroke, hemorrhage, head injury, infection).  
   • A one-time metabolic or drug-related insult almost never “rewires” the brain permanently.  
   • So, while anything is possible, the odds that one weekend of substance mixing created lifelong               epilepsy are extremely low.

4.  When should you get checked, and what would a doctor actually do?  
   • The two-month duration, plus your concern about cognition (“I lose focus when I twitch”), warrants a           real neurological exam.  
   • A basic work-up usually starts with:  
       – Complete metabolic panel (electrolytes, calcium, magnesium)  
       – CBC, thyroid tests, B-12/folate  
       – Possibly CK (muscle enzyme) to be sure you’re not breaking down muscle.  
   • If the story still fits myoclonus, an EEG (can be done as an outpatient within a week or two in most           cities) settles the “seizure vs. non-seizure” question in >90 % of cases.  
   • An MRI is ordered only if the exam or EEG suggests an underlying structural lesion.  
   • If it’s judged to be SSRI-withdrawal myoclonus, options include:  
       – Re-starting a tiny dose of fluoxetine (e.g., 2.5–5 mg every other day) and tapering more gradually.  
       – Symptomatic meds such as low-dose gabapentin, clonazepam, or propranolol.  
       – Lifestyle measures: good sleep hygiene, hydration, limiting caffeine, graded exercise, magnesium             repletion.  
     (None of these guarantee 100 % relief but they shorten the course for many patients.)

5.  Red-flag symptoms that should trigger urgent / ER evaluation:  
   • Jerks strong enough to fling limbs or make you bite your tongue.  
   • Any spell where you “come to” and realize you’ve lost time.  
   • Sudden decline in strength, balance, or speech.  
   • Persistent, worsening headache or vision changes.

What you can do right now while waiting to be seen:  
   • Stay off kratom, cannabis, and heavy alcohol for the time being—anything serotonergic or                    pro-convulsant can keep the nervous system irritable.  
   • Taper or stop caffeine for a week and see if the twitch rate falls.  
   • Keep a brief log (date, approximate number of twitches per hour, what you’d eaten / drunk, how            much sleep) to show the clinician. Patterns in the log often point to triggers.  
   • Over-the-counter magnesium glycinate or citrate (200–400 mg elemental Mg nightly) is safe for most        healthy adults and sometimes helps fasciculations.  
   • If anxiety about the symptoms is high, consider a brief telehealth visit or urgent-care visit, even if a            full neurologic work-up has to be scheduled later.

Key take-away: The description fits post-serotonergic myoclonus / SSRI “brain-zaps” more than epilepsy, and the natural history is gradual improvement, not lifelong disability. Nevertheless, two months of persistent twitching is long enough that a basic neurologic evaluation (labs + exam ± EEG) is appropriate. It’s very unlikely you permanently “gave yourself epilepsy,” but only a clinician who sees you can make that call.

30.question: My little sister, age 12, was diagnosed with epilepsy for the last 1 year. She has been taking necessary medications for its cure and prevention. However, she has been ill for the last few days and we ran a few tests waiting to get reports tomorrow. It's 3am now and she has been acting and moving her body weirdly while sleeping for the last hour, we're suspecting she's having nocturnal epilepsy. Moreover, she has been telling us she feels tremor in her stomach for the past 3 days. It would be really nice if anyone could answer the following questions    What could be the general cause of any epilepsy such as this?    What precautions should we take as a family or her as an individual to ensure a speedy cure or preventions?    What should we do or ensure when she has this during sleeping?    What habits should be changed to reduce risks of serious injuries by epilepsy?
30.answer:
I’m very sorry your family is having a frightening night.  
Because I can’t examine your sister and do not have her full medical record, everything below is general information and not a substitute for urgent medical care. If the odd movements last longer than 5 minutes, repeat without her fully waking up, or are accompanied by breathing difficulty, bluish lips, or injury, call your local emergency number right away.

────────────────────────────────────────
1.  What causes epilepsy in a child who was previously healthy?
────────────────────────────────────────
“Epilepsy” simply means a tendency to have unprovoked seizures.  The underlying reason varies from child to child and often remains unknown (“idiopathic”), but common categories are:

•  Genetic / developmental  
   – Benign Rolandic epilepsy (often only at night)  
   – Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy  
   – Channelopathies (abnormal ion-channel genes)

•  Structural brain problems  
   – Birth injury, scarring after head trauma  
   – Malformations of cortical development  
   – Tumor or previous stroke

•  Post-infectious / inflammatory  
   – Meningitis, encephalitis, autoimmune encephalitis

•  Metabolic / toxic  
   – Inborn metabolic errors, severe electrolyte or glucose disturbance, certain drugs

•  “Unknown”  
   – In about 40 % no definite cause is found even after MRI and EEG.

Night-time (nocturnal) seizures are common in several of these syndromes, especially the benign focal epilepsies of childhood.  A “tremor in the stomach” can be an aura if the seizure focus is in the temporal or frontal lobe, but it can also just be anxiety or gastro-intestinal upset; only an EEG will clarify this.

────────────────────────────────────────
2.  General measures to improve control and prevent further seizures
────────────────────────────────────────
Medication adherence  
•  Give antiepileptic medication at exactly the dose and times prescribed; a single missed dose can precipitate a seizure.  
•  If vomiting occurs within 30 minutes of a dose, call your doctor for advice; a replacement dose is often needed.

Sleep hygiene  
•  Children with epilepsy should get 9-10 hours of regular, good-quality sleep.  
•  Fixed bedtime and wake-time, no screens at least 30 minutes before bed, dark cool room.

Illness management  
•  Fever, infection, and dehydration lower seizure threshold. Treat fevers quickly (acetaminophen/ibuprofen if allowed) and keep fluids up.  
•  Consult your neurologist if she needs any new medicines; some cold remedies contain stimulants that can trigger seizures.

Identify and avoid triggers  
•  Sleep deprivation, emotional stress, flashing lights or video-game patterns, sudden loud noises, and some medications can act as triggers.  
•  Keep a seizure diary (time, duration, what she ate, stress, menstrual cycle once that starts, etc.) to spot patterns.

Healthy lifestyle  
•  Balanced diet, regular exercise (most sports are safe), maintain normal weight.  
•  Avoid caffeine, energy drinks; absolutely no alcohol or recreational drugs as she gets older.

Regular follow-up  
•  Neurology reviews as advised (usually every 3-6 months at her age).  
•  Blood tests to check drug levels or side-effects, periodic EEG / MRI if recommended.

Rescue plan  
•  Ask the neurologist for a written “seizure action plan” and rescue medication (intranasal/rectal midazolam or diazepam) for seizures lasting longer than 3-5 minutes.

Psychological support  
•  Anxiety, mood changes, and stigma can be significant. School counsellors, epilepsy support groups, or a psychologist can help.

────────────────────────────────────────
3.  What to do when she has a seizure during sleep
────────────────────────────────────────
DO  
1. Stay calm, note the time, turn her phone to video if possible (helpful for the doctor).  
2. Gently roll her onto her side (recovery position) so saliva can drain and the tongue cannot block the airway.  
3. Loosen tight clothing around neck, remove glasses.  
4. Cushion her head with a pillow or soft object.  
5. Keep the area safe: move sharp or hard objects, if she’s on a high bed consider putting a mattress on the floor next to it.  
6. Observe breathing and colour.  
7. After the convulsion stops, keep her on her side until she wakes; she’ll be confused and sleepy. Reassure her.

DO NOT  
•  Do not restrain her limbs.  
•  Do not put anything in her mouth (no spoon, no fingers, no water).  
•  Do not try to give oral medicine or food until she is fully awake.  
•  Do not perform CPR unless she stops breathing after the seizure ends.

Call emergency services if  
•  The convulsion lasts longer than 5 minutes or is followed by another without regaining consciousness.  
•  She injures herself, has difficulty breathing, or turns blue.  
•  It’s her first seizure or you’re unsure.  
•  She remains unresponsive more than about 10-15 minutes after activity stops.

Night-time safety devices  
•  Baby monitor or seizure-detection mat / smartwatch.  
•  Low bed or mattress on floor.  
•  No heavy quilts that can wrap around the neck; use lightweight bedding.

────────────────────────────────────────
4.  Habits and environmental changes to reduce risk of injury
────────────────────────────────────────
Home safety  
•  Shower rather than bathe; if she must bathe, someone should check in every few minutes, water level shallow, doors unlocked.  
•  Use shatter-proof glass or apply safety film to mirrors, patio doors.  
•  Padding on sharp furniture edges in her room.  
•  Keep floors clear of clutter, no loose rugs.  
•  Cook on back burners, use microwave rather than open flame when alone.  
•  Sleep on a low bed or mattress; avoid bunk beds.  
•  Consider a medical ID bracelet stating “Epilepsy – seizure risk”.

Sports & recreation  
•  Swimming is fine with direct supervision by someone who knows seizure first-aid.  
•  Wear a helmet for cycling, skating, skiing; avoid climbing heights without safety gear.  
•  Contact sports (soccer, basketball) are usually allowed once seizures are controlled; scuba diving, hang-gliding, and high-altitude climbing are generally discouraged.

School & social life  
•  Inform trusted teachers, school nurse, coaches about her seizure-action plan and rescue medicine.  
•  Encourage normal activities; social engagement and exercise improve seizure control and mental health.

Devices & alarms  
•  Smartphone apps or smartwatches can alert parents if abnormal motion or heart-rate spikes occur at night.  
•  A baby monitor with video may help you assess events without repeatedly entering her room and waking her.

Driving (for future reference)  
•  Most countries require a seizure-free period (e.g., 6–12 months) before licensing. Adulthood planning should include this discussion.

────────────────────────────────────────
Key red-flag situations that need medical review sooner rather than later
────────────────────────────────────────
•  Any noticeable change in seizure pattern or frequency.  
•  New neurological symptoms (persistent stomach aura, headache, vision changes, weakness).  
•  Side-effects of medication: severe drowsiness, rash, abdominal pain, jaundice, mood change.  
•  Prolonged vomiting or inability to keep meds down.  
•  Status epilepticus (seizure > 5 min) or clusters needing rescue medication.  
•  Concern for depression or anxiety.

────────────────────────────────────────
Take-home messages
────────────────────────────────────────
1. Most children with epilepsy, including nocturnal forms, lead normal lives when medications are taken regularly and sleep is protected.  
2. Good seizure first-aid is simple: keep her safe, time the event, recovery position, call for help if it lasts > 5 min.  
3. Identifying triggers, ensuring medication compliance, and regular neurology follow-up are the strongest “preventive” steps.  
4. Modify the home and certain daily habits to avoid burns, falls, drowning, or head injury.  
5. If tonight’s episodes continue or you feel unsure, it is perfectly appropriate to wake your on-call neurologist or go to the emergency department.

I hope this helps you feel more prepared while you wait for tomorrow’s appointment. Wishing your sister a swift improvement and many peaceful nights ahead.

31.question: I had a brain surgery 12 years ago to remove an AVM on the right side of my brain. A few years after the surgery, I was put back on epilepsy meds after I had a seizure. I've had seizures in clusters since then. That's the background, but my question isn't regarding epilepsy.My concern: I tried to get into weightlifting. However, every time I try to use my left shoulder, it just falls over. Same thing goes with left arm exercises- it just starts trembling and becomes useless after about 5 reps. Exercises I cannot do include shoulder presses, lat pulldowns, shoulder presses, dumbbell curls. Shoulder presses and dumbbell curls are the main exercises that show my problem. Even with ten reps of 5 pounds my arm starts falling over and becomes completely useless. I tried this for weeks without any progress. I can do leg exercises completely fine. Further, I have uneven arms and shoulders. I had my neurologist check for scoliosis, which I do not have. She told me my weakness is a result of brain surgery, which I don't know can cause this sort of limitation, especially because it doesn't get in the way of everyday tasks. I only notice it when trying to lift. I did some research, and came across something called hemiparesis. I'm wondering if this could be the issue/result of the brain surgery and is something my doctor didn't consider. If this is the condition, or if it isn't, is there anything I can do to fight this limitation? Could there be some type of treatment I can do to help with this? My information: Male, 22 years old, 5'5,
31.answer:
What you are describing – the left arm and shoulder “giving-out” within a few repetitions, a visible size difference between the two sides, and the fact that the problem involves several different shoulder/arm movements while your legs are normal – is almost textbook for a mild (sometimes called “latent” or “sub-clinical”) hemiparesis of the left upper limb.  
Key points that support this:

• Your AVM and the surgery were on the RIGHT side of the brain; the right motor cortex and the fibres that descend through the internal capsule control the LEFT side of the body.  
• A small amount of permanent damage or scarring in that area often produces only subtle weakness at rest but becomes obvious when the limb is asked to generate high power or to work repeatedly.  
• Tremor or “clumsiness” that worsens as the muscle tires is common in central (brain-origin) weakness.  
• Only the arm/shoulder is affected; the leg is much better because the representation of leg muscles in the motor cortex is in a different anatomic strip that may have been spared, and because leg strength recovers more easily after brain injury.  
• Shoulder asymmetry usually reflects loss of muscle bulk on the weaker side rather than true scoliosis of the spine.

So yes, what you have very likely IS a mild hemiparesis that has been unmasked by heavier resistance work.  It is entirely plausible that neither you nor your doctors noticed it in day-to-day life; the brain and the musculoskeletal system are very good at finding work-arounds for normal activities.

Could anything else explain it?  
• Local shoulder problems (rotator-cuff tear, nerve injury in the arm, cervical disc disease) normally cause pain, numbness and weakness limited to specific movements, not the global rapid “fatiguing” you describe.  
• Some anti-seizure drugs (e.g., valproate, phenytoin, phenobarbital) can cause generalized muscle weakness or tremor, but that would affect both arms and your legs as well.  
• Focal motor seizures (“negative myoclonus”) can make a limb suddenly flop, but they come and go in seconds or minutes, not predictably after the fifth rep of every set.  
None of these fits as well as latent hemiparesis.

Can anything be done about it?  Almost always, yes – but it is a neuro-rehabilitation project, not ordinary gym programming.

1. Get a proper baseline assessment.  
   • Ask your neurologist for a referral to a Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation (PM&R) physician or a neuro-trained physiotherapist.  
   • They will grade true muscle strength (Manual Muscle Testing), tone, reflexes, co-ordination, and measure limb girth.  Sometimes an EMG/nerve-conduction study is added to be sure no peripheral nerve lesion is hiding in the mix.  
   • If your last brain MRI is many years old, the neurologist may want a new one to correlate the clinical findings with the old surgical site.

2. Have your anti-epileptic drugs reviewed.  
   • Some AEDs worsen fatigue or tremor.  If you are on high-dose valproate, phenytoin, phenobarbital or topiramate, your neurologist may consider switching or reducing the dose (only if safe for seizure control).  
   • AEDs can produce chronic vitamin-D deficiency and secondary muscle weakness; a simple blood test and supplementation can correct that.

3. Start a neuro-specific strengthening program.  Principles your therapist will use:  
   • Very low initial loads (sometimes just the weight of the arm) with high repetitions to retrain motor unit recruitment.  Elastic bands, pulleys, water or air resistance machines and cable stacks that let you add weight in one-pound steps are handy.  
   • Emphasis on scapular stabilisers (lower trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids) – without a stable shoulder-blade even a healthy deltoid cannot press.  
   • Unilateral training: working the left arm alone forces the brain to send more drive to that side.  
   • Bilateral symmetrical tasks (rowing machine, lat-pull bar) often help; over time, the stronger side “pulls” the weaker side along via inter-hemispheric connections (“cross-education” effect).  
   • Functional electrical stimulation (FES) or neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) of the deltoid, biceps or wrist extensors can provoke extra muscle fibre recruitment while you exercise.  
   • Mirror therapy, mental-imagery practice, or constraint-induced movement therapy (short periods where the good arm is lightly restrained to make you use the weak arm) can all enhance cortical re-mapping.  
   • Very gradual progressive overload: typically add 0.5–1 lb every 1-2 weeks if you can complete the target reps with good form.  
   • Plenty of rest between sets; central (brain) fatigue recovers more slowly than simple muscle energy stores.

4. Watch your form and avoid early discouragement.  
   • Overhead presses are among the last movements to come back because they require the highest integrated shoulder control.  At first do them seated with back support, then standing with a dowel or an empty bar, then progress to dumbbells.  
   • Tremor that appears near the end of a set and stops when you rest is not dangerous; it is a signal to stop that set.  
   • Track progress in tiny increments: an extra repetition, a steadier movement, one pound more on the cable machine all count as gains.

5. Maintain aerobic fitness and leg work.  
   • Cardiovascular conditioning improves cerebral blood flow and, indirectly, motor recovery.  
   • Leg and trunk exercises are safe for you and will keep total training volume up while you rebuild the arm.

6. Re-evaluate every 3–6 months.  
   • Most people with mild post-surgical hemiparesis can recover 60–90 % of normal strength with discipline and appropriate therapy, but plateau periods are common.  Periodic reassessment lets the rehab team modify the program.

Bottom line  
A mild hemiparesis of the left upper limb is the most likely explanation for your shoulder/arm limitations.  It is a well-recognised, long-term consequence of right-hemisphere brain surgery, often inapparent until higher-demand activities are attempted.  The condition can be improved considerably – though usually not “cured” overnight – with a structured neuro-rehabilitation program, meticulous progression of resistance work, and a review of any medication or metabolic factors that might add to weakness.  Ask your neurologist for a PM&R/physiotherapy referral and start the process; with systematic training you should be able to gain significant, and lasting, functional strength.

32.question: I’m a 22 year old female and I have quite a track sheet of medical issues. I’m posting on here because I’m not sure if they are related and I really don’t know which road to go down.I’ve had ruptured ovarian cysts consistently since I was 12. every time I ovulate. I’ve been on birth control since I was 13 because of that. I have insanely painful periods and I know my hormones are out of wack but I’ve never been diagnosed officially with PCOS or endometriosis but I think I could have either one. not sure.I got diagnosed with epilepsy last February after two grand mal seizures on the same day. coincidentally(?) I had just gotten off birth control to try and heal my body naturally. my seizures seem to align with my menstrual cycle. I’m on Keppra and it’s controlling my tonic clonic seizures but I have breakthrough absence seizures 3x a week. originally my first EEG only showed right temporal lobe seizures but my most recent EEG showed right and left temporal lobe and left frontal lobe seizures.while I was in the epilepsy monitoring unit last week for a 7 day EEG during a pretty intense grand mal seizure my heart rate hit 275 bpm. I’ve always felt little heart flutters but this was intense. I have a Holter monitor now, and I was diagnosed with supraventricular tachycardia. I’m getting an ablation next week. the flutters happen after every seizure but sometimes just on their own without seizure activity.can someone please help me connect the dots, or point me in the direction of someone who can help? I’m really up for any suggestions right now because I want to go back to my normal life. thank you!
32.answer:
I know it feels as if three separate body systems are “going wrong,” but there is a common thread that can link many of the things you’re experiencing: fluctuating female‐sex hormones acting on a sensitive brain (catamenial epilepsy) and on a hormonally “irritable” ovary, plus the surge of adrenaline that accompanies seizures and can trigger a latent supraventricular-tachycardia circuit.

Below is an overview of how the pieces may fit together, the tests/ specialists that are most helpful, and the practical next steps to discuss with your doctors.

----------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The cycle-related seizures = “Catamenial epilepsy”
----------------------------------------------------------------
• What it is  
  – In about one-third of women with epilepsy, seizures cluster at predictable points of the menstrual cycle, usually the 3–4 days before bleeding starts and/or the first 3 days of menses (perimenstrual pattern C1) or around ovulation (peri-ovulatory pattern C2).  
  – Estrogen is mildly “pro-seizure” (it excites cortical neurons); progesterone and its metabolite allopregnanolone are “anti-seizure” (they enhance the brain’s GABA inhibition). When progesterone drops suddenly just before a period or right after ovulation, the balance tips toward excitation and seizures can break through.  

• Why your seizures appeared after stopping the pill  
  – When you were on continuous combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) from age 13 there were no ovulatory hormone peaks and troughs; once you stopped, you re-established a normal estrogen/progesterone swing, unmasking catamenial seizure vulnerability.  

• How the EEG fits  
  – Multifocal discharges (right & left temporal, left frontal) are common in genetic or catamenial generalized epilepsies; they do not by themselves mean the epilepsy is worsening, only that you had more “capture” of interictal spikes while hormones were at a pro-seizure stage.  

----------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Recurrent ruptured cysts, painful periods → PCOS? Endometriosis?
----------------------------------------------------------------
• Recurrent mid-cycle cyst rupture each time you ovulate strongly suggests the ovary releases a dominant follicle but the follicle does not seal properly and bleeds—very typical in PCOS or luteal-phase defect.  
• Severe dysmenorrhoea + pelvic pain between periods ± painful bowel/bladder/sex points toward endometriosis.  
• Neither diagnosis is made by symptoms alone. Work-up = pelvic ultrasound for polycystic morphology, serum LH/FSH/testosterone, AMH, and (if endometriosis suspected) MRI or diagnostic laparoscopy.  

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Tachycardia after seizures and also at other times
----------------------------------------------------------------
• Almost every generalized tonic–clonic seizure is followed by a sympathetic surge: HR 120–180 bpm is routine; >200 bpm can happen.  
• You ALSO have a true electrical re-entry circuit (AVNRT or accessory-pathway SVT) documented on Holter. A big shot of adrenaline in the post-ictal period is the perfect trigger for that circuit—hence why flutters are common after seizures but can also appear randomly.  
• A radio-frequency ablation next week is appropriate and has a 90–95 % cure rate. Even after ablation you may still notice sinus tachycardia after seizures—perfectly normal—but the paroxysmal narrow-complex SVT should disappear.  

----------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Putting it together
----------------------------------------------------------------
 • Sex-hormone fluctuations ↔ seizure threshold (catamenial epilepsy)  
 • Catamenial seizures ↔ huge catecholamine surge ↔ SVT in a person with a re-entry pathway  
 • The same hormone fluctuations are also driving ovarian-cyst formation and period pain.  

No single rare syndrome is needed to explain the triad; it is a common constellation once you recognise the hormonal component.

----------------------------------------------------------------
5.  What can be done now?
----------------------------------------------------------------
A. With your epileptologist  
   1. Keep a seizure & menstrual diary (apps such as “Seizure Tracker” let you overlay cycle data).  
   2. Confirm the pattern (C1, C2, or both).  
   3. Catamenial treatment options (evidence-based):  
      • Increase levetiracetam dose by 20–30 % during the vulnerable 7-day window each cycle.  
      • OR add clobazam 10–20 mg/day only during that week.  
      • OR acetazolamide 250 mg bid during that week.  
      • Natural micronised progesterone 200 mg TID or 300 mg vag. days 14–28 (works best if serum progesterone is low).  
      • Continuous COCP or progestin-only pill (no placebo week) or a long-acting progestin IUD/implant can flatten the hormone curve and often stops catamenial seizures entirely.  
   4. If seizures remain >1 per year after optimisation, ask about VNS or responsive-neurostimulator (RNS).  

B. With a gynaecologist / reproductive endocrinologist  
   1. Pelvic ultrasound with Doppler; hormonal panel (LH, FSH, estradiol, progesterone on day 21, testosterone, DHEAS, prolactin, TSH, AMH).  
   2. Trial of continuous hormonal suppression:  
        • Continuous combined pill, OR  
        • Progestin IUD plus add-back estrogen patch, OR  
        • GnRH agonist (leuprolide, etc.) for 6 mo if endometriosis is suspected.  
   3. Laparoscopy only if pain persists / imaging equivocal.  

C. With your electrophysiologist / cardiologist  
   • Go ahead with the ablation; ask the lab to do isoproterenol challenge to be sure no accessory pathway is missed.  
   • After ablation: obtain 2-week monitor to confirm arrhythmia elimination; if any residual racing HR >150 bpm persists post-seizure it is likely sinus tachycardia only.  

D. General measures that cut seizure risk 10–20 % on their own  
   • Minimum 7 h sleep every night (catamenial seizures become much worse with sleep debt).  
   • Magnesium 400 mg nightly and vitamin D repletion if low.  
   • Limit caffeine to <200 mg/day; avoid binge alcohol.  

----------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Which specialists, in what order?
----------------------------------------------------------------
1. Epileptologist (you already have) – ask specifically for “catamenial protocol” visit.  
2. Electrophysiologist – ablation next week.  
3. Reproductive-endocrinology/infertility (REI) or gyn. endocrinologist – to coordinate hormone suppression that is safe with epilepsy meds.  
4. Optionally, an endocrinologist if PCOS labs are abnormal or if BMI/insulin resistance become issues.  

----------------------------------------------------------------
7.  Key questions to bring to each visit
----------------------------------------------------------------
Epileptologist  
• “Can we formally diagnose catamenial epilepsy from my diary/EEG?”  
• “Which rescue or pulse therapy do you recommend?”  
• “Would continuous birth-control hormones help in my case, and which formulation interacts least with Keppra?”  

Gynaecologist  
• “Based on ultrasound and labs, do I meet criteria for PCOS or endometriosis?”  
• “What continuous hormonal regimen will both prevent cyst rupture and blunt my estrogen swings?”  
• “Will a progesterone-only IUD (e.g., Mirena) be sufficient, or should we add systemic therapy?”  

Cardiologist  
• “Is my SVT typical AVNRT or an accessory pathway?”  
• “What is the success & complication rate of the planned ablation?”  
• “After ablation, if my heart rate still hits 160–180 bpm post-seizure, when should I call you?”  

----------------------------------------------------------------
Take-home
• Your problems are real and interconnected, but they are also all very treatable.  
• Catamenial seizure control + cyst suppression + fixing the SVT circuit can give you back a normal life.  
• A seizure/period diary is the single most powerful tool you can start today; bring it to every appointment.  

You are already doing everything right by seeking care. Push for a coordinated plan among neurology, gynecology/endocrinology, and cardiology, and you should see substantial improvement within just a few cycles.

33.question: After standing from a prolonged period of sitting (especially when looking at a screen) I have 'episodes' which include spasms and staring. These occur multiple times a day, and I have had an ambulatory eeg. This has been happening for the last 4 years approximatelyThese came back to show that I don't have epilepsy, however my brain waves slow down and they suspect that I have mild cerebal hypoxia.My question is how bad is mild cerebal hypoxia because when severe, it can be very serious. Does the fact that it happens so frequently flag a matter of concern for my brain or general health?I have researched a little about this, but there's not much on mild cerebal hypoxis nor the frequency at which they occur in my personal case. I will be seeing a cardiology specialist at some point, but the waiting period could be very long.Information about myself: 19 male and have type 1 diabetes (since February 2016). Also I had a blood test in December, with all normal results. Apart from this, I have no other known medical conditions and am in relatively good shape.
33.answer:
What your EEG report is really saying  
The EEG did not show epileptic discharges (spikes or sharp waves).  
Instead it showed a generalized “slowing” of the rhythm at the moment you were having an episode.  
That pattern is typical when the cerebral cortex is not getting quite enough blood-borne oxygen and glucose – in other words, transient cerebral hypoperfusion / hypoxia.  
It does ​not​ mean that brain cells were dying; it simply means they were working in “power-saving mode” for a few seconds.

How much hypoxia can the brain tolerate?  
• Total loss of circulation for 4–6 minutes can produce permanent injury.  
• Partial or brief loss (a few seconds, occasionally tens of seconds) is usually completely reversible; the EEG and your symptoms return to normal as soon as normal flow is restored.  
• There is no evidence that many brief, self-limited episodes cumulatively damage the brain, provided each one is short and you do not actually lose consciousness for a prolonged period or fall and injure yourself.

Why it is still worth taking seriously  
“Not dangerous to the brain” is not the same as “nothing to worry about.”  
Frequent near-syncope indicates that something in the normal blood-pressure/heart-rate reflex system is not working optimally.  Until that cause is found and treated you remain at risk for:  
• A full faint with a fall and injury.  
• An episode occurring while driving, swimming, etc.  
• The underlying disorder (for example an arrhythmia, autonomic neuropathy, or volume depletion) progressing.

Most common explanations in a 19-year-old with type 1 diabetes  
1. Orthostatic (postural) hypotension: blood pools in your legs when you stand, your BP drops, cortical perfusion falls.  
2. Vasovagal or “neuro-cardiogenic” syncope: an exaggerated reflex in response to standing, prolonged sitting, screens, stress, etc.  
3. Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS): the heart races instead of raising blood pressure effectively.  
4. Early diabetic autonomic neuropathy: diabetes can damage the nerves that tighten blood vessels when you stand.  
5. Dehydration, low salt intake, anemia, certain medications, or (less likely in your case) cardiac rhythm problems.

Why the spasms and staring?  
During a faint or near-faint the cerebral cortex is under-perfused; brief ​myoclonic jerks​ or a blank stare are common and are called “convulsive syncope.” They can look like a seizure but do not originate from the epileptic circuits of the brain.

Will waiting months for your cardiology visit harm your brain?  
Unlikely, as long as the episodes remain brief and you protect yourself from falls.  Nevertheless, the sooner the cause is identified the sooner you can stop them from happening.

What you can do while you wait  

Monitor  
• Check capillary glucose during or immediately after an episode to rule out hypoglycaemia.  
• Measure blood pressure and heart rate lying, sitting and after 1, 3, 5 minutes of standing (orthostatic vital signs) and keep a log.  
• Note provoking factors: long screen time, meals, dehydration, warm rooms, alcohol, etc.

Lifestyle / first-aid measures  
• Stand up slowly; before rising tense your calf, thigh and abdominal muscles or march in place.  
• Hydrate well; 2–3 L fluid a day unless restricted.  
• Adequate dietary salt (unless you have hypertension or kidney disease).  
• Compression stockings to knee or thigh.  
• Avoid prolonged standing; shift weight, fidget, cross and uncross legs.  
• If you feel an episode coming on, sit or lie down with legs elevated; place head between knees if no place to lie.

Discuss with your doctors  
• Full orthostatic BP/HR assessment or tilt-table test.  
• ECG and possibly a 24- to 48-h Holter or event recorder to rule out arrhythmia.  
• Echocardiogram if heart structure is in question.  
• Autonomic function tests (Valsalva, deep-breathing ratio, QSART, etc.) if diabetic neuropathy is suspected.  
• Review of all medications, caffeine, alcohol, supplements.  
• Hemoglobin / iron studies to rule out anemia.

Take-home points  
1. The “mild cerebral hypoxia” reported on your EEG represents very short, fully reversible drops in brain perfusion.  
2. Frequent episodes are not expected to produce cumulative brain injury, but they are a sign of an underlying circulatory/autonomic problem that deserves evaluation.  
3. The most common mechanisms in someone your age – orthostatic hypotension, vasovagal syncope, POTS, early diabetic autonomic neuropathy – are manageable once properly diagnosed.  
4. Use the preventive measures above and keep a detailed symptom log; this will help your cardiologist, neurologist, or internist reach a diagnosis more quickly.

(And, of course, if an episode lasts longer than usual, is accompanied by chest pain, palpitations, significant confusion afterwards, or leads to injury, seek medical attention immediately.)

34.answer:
I can’t give you a formal diagnosis on-line, but the pattern you describe is not “nothing.”  
Below is a way to think about what may be going on and how to move forward when you feel “stuck” in the system.

──────────────────────────────────  
1.  What could tie these symptoms together? (Differential diagnosis)  
──────────────────────────────────  
A. Primary seizure disorder  
•  Photosensitive generalized epilepsy (flashing lights trigger) or juvenile myoclonic epilepsy can start in the teens/20s, cause morning myoclonic jerks/tics, and be worsened by alcohol, cannabis, sleep-loss, or other drugs.  
•  Normal routine EEG does NOT rule out epilepsy (sensitivity ~50 %). You often need prolonged (24–72 h) VIDEO-EEG, sometimes with sleep-deprivation or photic stimulation.  

B. Psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (PNES) / Functional neurological disorder  
•  Can coexist with true epilepsy (about 10–20 % of patients have both). Events are often prolonged, occur in stressful contexts, and routine EEG is usually normal.  

C. Complex / hemiplegic migraine or basilar-type migraine  
•  Can give you severe headache, face/limb numbness, weakness, transient loss of consciousness, white-matter spots on MRI, and respond poorly to routine EEG.  

D. Syncope / autonomic dysfunction  
•  Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) or vasovagal syncope can produce fainting spells, jerking movements from cerebral hypoxia (“convulsive syncope”), profound fatigue, and GI upset. A tilt-table test or 24-h ambulatory BP/HR monitor would help.  

E. Metabolic / nutritional or malabsorption disorder  
•  Low folate, anemia, low Na⁺, low vitamin D with high albumin (dehydration) and post-prandial pain raise the question of celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, chronic gastritis, or other malabsorption. Folate and Na⁺ depletion can lower seizure threshold and cause paresthesias.  

F. Autoimmune / inflammatory or demyelinating illness  
•  Multiple sclerosis, autoimmune encephalitis, systemic lupus, Sjögren, etc., can give you white-matter lesions, seizures, tics, fatigue, and GI/autonomic symptoms. Negative MRI once does not exclude early MS; contrast MRI, spinal fluid, and antibody panels might be needed.  

G. Toxic / genetic / other  
•  Wilson’s disease (abnormal copper), thyroid/adrenal disorders, channelopathies, heavy-metal exposure, mitochondrial disease, etc., are rarer but worth considering if common causes are excluded.

──────────────────────────────────  
2.  What tests/consults would close the main diagnostic gaps?  
──────────────────────────────────  
Neurology  
•  Admit to an Epilepsy Monitoring Unit for 48–72 h VIDEO-EEG with photic stimulation and sleep-deprivation.  
•  Repeat brain MRI WITH and WITHOUT contrast on a 3 T magnet; include MR angiography/venography if headaches are severe.  
•  Consider lumbar puncture for CSF (cells, protein, oligoclonal bands, autoimmune-encephalitis panel, infection panel).  
•  Serum autoimmune/paraneoplastic antibodies (NMDA-R, LGI1, GAD65, etc.).  

Cardiology / Autonomic lab  
•  Tilt-table test, 24-h Holter or implantable loop recorder.  
•  Orthostatic vital-sign diary at home (HR & BP supine, sitting, standing).  

Laboratory (many can be drawn together)  
•  CBC, iron studies, B12, folate, reticulocyte count  
•  CMP including Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺, Na⁺, K⁺, liver & renal panel  
•  Thyroid function (TSH, free T4), morning cortisol, ACTH  
•  Celiac panel (tTG-IgA ± total IgA)  
•  ESR, CRP, ANA, ENA panel, rheumatoid factor  
•  Ceruloplasmin, serum copper, 24-h urine copper (Wilson’s)  
•  Vitamin B1, B6, B2, zinc levels if available  
•  Consider heavy-metal screen if exposure risk exists.  

Gastroenterology  
•  Upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsies if celiac labs positive or suspicion high.  
•  Breath test for SIBO, stool studies for calprotectin, pancreatic elastase if chronic diarrhea.  

Sleep Medicine  
•  Overnight polysomnogram if daytime sleepiness persists after anemia correction. Sleep deprivation can precipitate seizures.  

Psychiatry / Psychology  
•  Evaluation for PNES, anxiety, depression, trauma. Video-EEG is crucial because PNES and epilepsy often coexist.

──────────────────────────────────  
3.  Practical steps you can take RIGHT NOW  
──────────────────────────────────  
1. Symptom diary: date, time, trigger, warning signs, loss of consciousness (Y/N), convulsion pattern, recovery time, meds/substances taken, menstrual cycle day if applicable.  
2. Phone video: Ask family/friends to record spells from start to recovery. Epileptologists find this extremely valuable.  
3. Treat the correctable:  
   •  Begin iron/folate/Vit-D supplementation ASAP (with physician guidance).  
   •  High-protein, nutrient-dense diet; consider gluten-free trial only AFTER celiac testing (going GF first can mask labs).  
   •  Hydration + electrolytes (low Na⁺ can provoke seizures).  
4. Triggers to avoid until evaluated: sleep deprivation, alcohol, recreational drugs, flashing lights/strobe environments, fasting, dehydration.  
5. Written request for referral: When primary clinicians say “there’s nothing wrong,” hand them a concise one-page timeline and ask specifically for (a) Comprehensive Epilepsy Center referral, (b) Autonomic laboratory/tilt-table test, and (c) GI evaluation for malabsorption. Written requests obligate a reply in most systems.  
6. Second opinion: Seek an academic medical center with a multidisciplinary neuro-immunology or epilepsy program. Bring all imaging on a CD and lab results.  

──────────────────────────────────  
4.  How to communicate with clinicians without being labeled a “drug seeker”  
──────────────────────────────────  
•  Lead with objective problems (documented anemia, low sodium, fainting with injuries).  
•  Emphasize that you do NOT want narcotics; you want an explanation and treatment plan.  
•  Bring an organized binder: list of dates, tests, results, imaging discs, medication/allergy list, and family history.  
•  Take a support person to visits.  
•  Use phrases like, “What would you consider the next step if this were your family member?” or “What dangerous conditions have we ruled out, and which still need to be excluded?”  

──────────────────────────────────  
5.  Interim safety measures  
──────────────────────────────────  
•  No driving until seizure vs. syncope is clarified (legal requirement in many regions).  
•  Shower sitting, not standing; avoid swimming alone or heights.  
•  Medical ID bracelet: “History of convulsive episodes—may be epileptic or syncope—do NOT restrain—turn on side—call EMS.”  
•  Teach family/friends basic seizure first aid (timing, positioning, no objects in mouth, call EMS if >5 min).  

──────────────────────────────────  
6.  Why your earlier tests may have been “normal”  
──────────────────────────────────  
•  Routine EEG is only 20–50 % sensitive.  
•  MRI interpretation: Small nonspecific white-matter foci are called “normal” if you’re <40 and have no clinical context; however they may correlate with migraine or early demyelination.  
•  Syncope often gives a normal ECG unless caught in the act; POTS hides on a standard cardiac work-up unless orthostatic vitals/tilt-table are done.  
•  Autoimmune/inflammatory markers fluctuate; the right panel may not have been drawn.  

──────────────────────────────────  
Bottom line  
You have objective abnormalities (nutrient deficiencies, white-matter spots, fainting, photo-triggered convulsions) plus serious quality-of-life impairment. A comprehensive re-evaluation—ideally at an academic epilepsy/autonomic center—with prolonged video-EEG, repeat MRI, tilt-table, and a malabsorption work-up is warranted. Meanwhile, correct nutritional deficits, record events, avoid known triggers, and ensure personal safety.

If you keep encountering “there’s nothing wrong,” change venue: many patients only get answers when they reach a tertiary-care center or enroll in an Epilepsy Monitoring Unit. Persistence, documentation, and a clear, non-confrontational request for specific next steps are your best tools.

35.question: Hi all, I don’t know if Im looking in the right place but wanted to get some advice I have these “fits” where for about 10 seconds I can’t control my left side of my body or speak, it usually cause my arm to go up in the air, and my face to scrunch up, I am fully conscious and aware of what is happening during these episodes but I can’t control them, I am able to tell when I am about to have one, they normally happen when I stand up to fast, and jumped unexpectedly, or when I’m very nervous, I have had an EEG and an MRI scan about 4 years ago nothing showed up and no epilepsy was diagnosed either. I am not on any medication or anything, my doctor could not diagnose me and just told me to live a healthy lifestyle. I am just desperate to put in the right direction to try find a diagnosis and a solution as it is so embarrassing and it affects my day to day life. Thank you for your time
35.answer:
I’m not your doctor, but I do work with patients who have brief, paroxysmal (sudden-onset, short-lasting) movement episodes like the ones you’re describing. There are only a handful of conditions that cause

• seconds-long attacks  
• full awareness preserved  
• unilateral (one-sided) posturing/jerking or “clenching” of the face, arm, and sometimes leg  
• reliable triggers such as sudden standing, startle, or emotional stress  
• normal MRI and routine EEG between attacks

The two possibilities neurologists think about first are:

1. Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia (PKD) or other “paroxysmal dyskinesias”.  
   • Classic PKD attacks are precipitated by a sudden movement (e.g., rising from a chair, being startled).  
   • They last a few seconds to a minute, people stay completely conscious, and the limb may posture, jerk, or shoot upward just as you describe.  
   • MRI and standard EEGs are usually normal because this is a movement-disorder problem, not a structural brain lesion.  
   • Attacks often start in the teens or twenties but can appear later.  
   • They respond dramatically (in 70-90 % of cases) to a very low dose of carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, or sometimes phenytoin—far lower doses than those used for epilepsy.

2. Focal aware (formerly “simple-partial”) seizures with dystonic posturing.  
   • Seizures can also be triggered by startle or exertion in a few people.  
   • An EEG done during—not between—an attack (“video-EEG monitoring”) is usually needed to prove this diagnosis.  
   • Anti-seizure drugs can stop them, but only once the diagnosis is verified.

Other, less common considerations include hemifacial spasm, episodic ataxia, hyperekplexia (startle disease), and functional (psychogenic) attacks. A very brief transient ischemic attack (TIA) is unlikely because TIAs almost never repeat dozens or hundreds of times with the exact same pattern and trigger.

What to do next

1. Capture the event on video.  
   • Have a family member or friend film an episode on a phone. Movement-disorder and epilepsy specialists rely heavily on seeing what actually happens.

2. Ask for referral to a neurologist who specializes in movement disorders or an epileptologist.  
   • Take the video and a written log that lists date, time, trigger, duration, and what recovers first.  
   • Explain that PKD and focal seizures are the two main entities you want ruled in or out.

3. Testing that is often helpful  
   • 24- to 72-hour ambulatory or inpatient video-EEG to see if epileptic activity appears during an event.  
   • If events cannot be captured, a trial of a very low dose of carbamazepine (50–100 mg twice daily) is sometimes used as a therapeutic test for PKD—provided seizures have been reasonably excluded.  
   • Orthostatic vitals or tilt-table testing only if there is also light-headedness, which you have not mentioned.

4. Lifestyle measures may lessen frequency but rarely eliminate true PKD/seizure activity. They include adequate sleep, avoidance of excessive caffeine/energy drinks, and stress-reduction techniques.

Key point: A normal routine EEG and MRI do NOT rule out either PKD or focal seizures, because those tests usually look normal between attacks. The right diagnosis generally comes from (a) seeing the spell, (b) capturing it on video-EEG, or (c) observing that it disappears with an appropriate medication.

Bring your video, diary, and these points to a neurologist; they will know the next steps. If you cannot get in quickly, consider asking your primary doctor to start the referral process and order a prolonged ambulatory EEG so that you are in the queue by the time you see the specialist.

I hope that steers you toward the help you need and, ideally, to a treatment that keeps the episodes from intruding on your daily life.

36.question: [21M] epileptic from quemotherapy, and 5 years cancer free.Is there a variation that could allow me to safely take them? For instance "lf you have X specific kind of epilepsy, or if you aren't taking X medication you can take them" Does the dose matter? I have read people say that would have seizures when microdosing but not when doing high doses. How does that work? Thank you so much!
36.answer:
I’m not your physician and this isn’t a substitute for individual medical advice, but the short answer is that, with our current state of knowledge, no classical psychedelic (LSD, psilocybin-mushrooms, DMT/ayahuasca, mescaline, etc.) can be called “safe” for a person who already has epilepsy.  There are simply too many unknowns and too few systematic data.  Below is what is actually known, what is still speculation, and the practical points neurologists usually discuss with patients who ask about this topic.

1.  Why seizures are a concern with psychedelics  
   • All classic psychedelics are strong 5-HT2A (serotonin) agonists.  
   • Activation of that receptor increases cortical excitability and glutamate release—exactly the opposite of what most antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) try to do.  
   • Excitability + sympathetic stimulation (↑blood pressure, ↑temperature, sleep deprivation, flashing lights, hyperventilation, etc.) can tip a vulnerable brain into a seizure.  
   • Case reports exist for generalized tonic-clonic seizures after LSD, psilocybin, DMT, MDMA and 2C-B in people with and without a prior epilepsy diagnosis.  They are rare but real.

2.  “But I’ve read that some people only seize on micro-doses and not on high doses—how could that be?”  
   • Micro-dosing is typically done repeatedly (every 1–3 days).  That means many more chances for a seizure to occur, often while the person is living normal life (work, driving, lack of sleep, skipped meals).  
   • With a full (“macro”) dose, people usually clear their schedule, have supervision, rest afterward, and do it infrequently—fewer total exposures and fewer situational triggers.  
   • There is no solid physiological evidence that high doses are inherently safer; it’s probably behavioral context and statistics.

3.  Does the TYPE of epilepsy matter?  
   Not enough data.  We have single-digit numbers of documented psychedelic-related seizures in temporal-lobe, juvenile myoclonic, and post-traumatic epilepsies.  No controlled trials compare risks between focal vs generalized syndromes.  Every respectable research protocol to date lists “history of any seizure disorder” as an exclusion criterion.

4.  Does the AED you’re on change the risk?  
   • Inducers like carbamazepine, phenytoin and phenobarbital may shorten a psychedelic’s action (by revving up CYP3A4), but that doesn’t make them safer; it may just mean you redose sooner.  
   • Lamotrigine is sometimes reported to blunt psychedelic intensity, but it has no proven protective effect against a serotonin-driven seizure.  
   • Valproate, levetiracetam, topiramate, zonisamide and the others haven’t been studied with psychedelics at all.  
   • Bottom line: being on effective AED therapy lowers your baseline seizure risk, but no AED can guarantee protection once a strong pro-convulsant stimulus is added.

5.  Does time since last cancer treatment matter?  
   Post-chemotherapy epilepsy usually reflects cortical scarring, radiation necrosis, or chemo-induced vascular changes.  Those structural vulnerabilities remain even after you’re “cancer-free.”  Five years of remission is great, but it doesn’t remove the scar tissue that makes you epileptic.

6.  Are any psychedelic analogues “safer”?  
   No data.  4-AcO-DMT, 1P-LSD, ALD-52, etc., are metabolized into the same parent compounds that raise the concerns to begin with.  Calling them safer would be speculation.

7.  Harm-reduction steps if someone decides to take the risk anyway  
   (Again, this is not a recommendation—only the precautions neurologists usually list.)  
   • Remain fully seizure-free on stable AED doses for at least 12 months.  
   • Have a trusted sober sitter who knows basic seizure first aid and when to call EMS.  
   • Avoid sleep deprivation, flashing lights, strobe visuals, overheating, alcohol, stimulants and any additional serotonergic drugs (SSRIs, tramadol, bupropion, MAOIs, etc.).  
   • Take your AEDs exactly on schedule the day of and after.  
   • Start with the smallest conceivable dose and leave at least several weeks before considering another exposure.  
   • Make sure you are somewhere you can lie on your side safely if a convulsion occurs, and not driving, swimming, on a balcony, around fire, etc.
