   • Be prepared for the possibility that the psychedelic’s effects will feel blunted or dysphoric because many AEDs dampen glutamatergic signaling.

8.  Talking with your neurologist  
   • Neurologists cannot legally give you permission to take an illegal substance, but they can clarify YOUR individual seizure triggers, review your imaging, EEGs, AED blood levels, and assess whether your baseline risk is already high or low.  
   • If you are considering participation in a legal research study (psilocybin for depression, for example), you would still be excluded under current protocols—but that could change in the future as more safety data accumulate.

Key take-away  
At present there is no variant of classical psychedelic use that can be declared “safe” for anyone with a diagnosed seizure disorder, regardless of the type of epilepsy, the AED regimen, or the dose.  Some people take the risk and do fine; a smaller (but non-zero) number seize.  Because a single generalized convulsion can mean loss of driving privileges, injury, or status epilepticus, most clinicians advise against it.  If you’re determined, keep your neurologist in the loop, maximize baseline seizure control, and apply every harm-reduction measure you can.

37.question: I am 20M (age,sex) and currently on lamotrigine (150mg/day)I was ‘diagnosed ’ with epilepsy over two years ago. (When I was 18) I have never been evaluated for adhd.In the two years I started noticing some attention problem. (Adhd-like symptom).. Being distracted by other things, etc sometimes it could be ‘fixated’ to something even it’s not important and I was Chasing deadlines for assignments etc. I just cannot get my mind off those shits and start procrastinating things that are very important .I tried different methods such as setting my phone’s wall paper to a photo I took, the view of a famous university I’ve been looking forward to admit to. It only worked for a very short period of time. Not until the very last moment then I starts to regret and do whatever I can to complete the assignment/ important things.These behaviors is driving me crazy, also my GPA.I feel very nervous about meeting the conditional offer from the famous university because all of this. I really needed the offer and cannot afford losing it.I spoke to a counselor at my college and she thought, despite she doesn’t think I have adhd, but considering I have epilepsy. Maybe I could seek advice from a doctor, but a specialist consultation can cost a lot…
37.answer:
I’m not in a position to diagnose you, but I can walk you through the main issues that usually come up when a person with epilepsy wonders whether they also have ADHD, and what your practical next steps can be.

1. How common is ADHD in people with epilepsy?
• 20-40 % of children and 15-25 % of adults with epilepsy meet full ADHD criteria—several-fold higher than in the general population.  
• So your concern is genuinely plausible and worth exploring.

2. Could something else be mimicking ADHD?
Before jumping to ADHD, doctors try to rule out other causes of in-attention that are especially common when someone has seizures:
• Focal aware seizures (“auras”) or brief absence seizures can look like staring spells or day-dreaming.  
• Post-ictal periods (minutes to hours after a seizure).  
• Medication effects—lamotrigine is one of the “cleanest” anti-seizure drugs cognitively, but some people do feel slower or more distractible.  
• Sleep deprivation (very frequent in students, and a seizure trigger).  
• Anxiety, depression, or chronic stress.

Because of those possibilities, a quick visit with your regular doctor (or neurologist if you still follow with one) is usually the starting point. They can:
• Review the timing of your last seizures.  
• Check blood levels of lamotrigine.  
• Screen for mood or sleep problems.  
• Decide if a formal ADHD evaluation is justified.

3. What does a formal ADHD evaluation involve?
• Standardized symptom checklists (e.g., ASRS, Conners, Brown, Vanderbilt).  
• A timeline—true ADHD has been present since childhood, even if it got noticed only when academic demands increased.  
• Reports from someone who knew you as a child (parent, caregiver, school records) if available.  
• Screening for learning disorders, anxiety, depression.  
• Sometimes brief neuropsychological testing if the picture is unclear.

Costs vary, but you do NOT necessarily need an expensive neuropsychological battery. Many primary-care doctors, student health services, or community mental-health clinics can do the history/scale portion and start treatment or refer you.

Lower-cost avenues:  
• University student-health center or counseling service (often included in tuition).  
• Public/teaching hospitals’ neurology or psychiatry residents’ clinics.  
• Sliding-scale community mental health centers.  
• If you’re in the U.S.: Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs).  
• If in the U.K.: NHS GP → ADHD right‐to‐choose services.  
• If in Canada/Australia: GP referral to public hospital ADHD clinic.

4. “If I do have ADHD, are stimulants safe with epilepsy?”
This is the question that makes many clinicians cautious. The evidence:

Large cohort and meta-analysis data: methylphenidate or amphetamines do NOT significantly increase seizure frequency in most patients whose epilepsy is reasonably controlled. In fact, some studies suggest seizure rates fall because better attention → better medication adherence and sleep.

Key caveats:
• A very small minority (≈2–4 %) report a temporary uptick in seizures; usually dose-dependent and reversible.  
• Start low, go slow, and keep your neurologist in the loop.  
• Keep taking lamotrigine—stopping an anti-seizure drug abruptly is far riskier than adding a stimulant in a controlled way.

Non-stimulant options (if you or your doctor prefer):
• Atomoxetine (Strattera) – no seizure signal.  
• Guanfacine XR / clonidine – often used if anxiety or tics coexist.  
• Bupropion – sometimes avoided if seizures are poorly controlled but is generally safe once epilepsy is stable.

5. Non-medication strategies you can start immediately
These don’t replace treatment, but they often boost GPA while you’re sorting diagnosis out.

Structured work blocks  
• Pomodoro (25 min work + 5 min break ×4 → 15 min break).  
• Use a physical timer so your phone stays out of reach.

Externalize memory  
• Kanban or Trello board for tasks (“To-do / Doing / Done”).  
• One notebook or app only (avoid multiple lists).

Environment  
• 1-tab browser rule; browser extension that locks distracting sites.  
• Study in the most boring room you can find—minimal visual clutter.  
• Noise-canceling headphones or brown-noise track.

Body hacks  
• 7–8 h sleep, consistent bedtime—crucial for seizure control and attention.  
• 20-30 min brisk exercise most days; proven to boost executive function.  
• Caffeine in moderate, scheduled doses (not late evening).

Accountability  
• 5-min daily check-in with a classmate or friend: “Today’s 3 top tasks.”  
• If your college offers peer academic coaching, sign up—it’s often free.

6. Preparing for a doctor visit
Bring a one-page summary:
• Timeline—when attention issues started, how they impact grades.  
• Any childhood evidence (report cards, teacher comments, parent recall).  
• Seizure diary, last seizure date, current lamotrigine dose/time.  
• Sleep schedule, caffeine, alcohol, recreational drug use.  
• List of strategies you’ve tried.

That sheet saves the clinician time and reduces the number of visits (and cost).

Bottom line
• Attention problems are common in epilepsy and deserve evaluation.  
• Many people safely use ADHD medication alongside lamotrigine once a clinician confirms the diagnosis.  
• Start with the most affordable access point (student health, GP).  
• While you wait, adopt external structure and lifestyle tweaks—they can lift performance enough to protect your GPA and conditional offer.

I hope this clarifies your options and gives you concrete next steps. You’re not “lazy” or “broken”—you’re dealing with overlapping neurological issues that can be managed with the right plan. Good luck, and keep advocating for yourself.

38.question: Hey, so I am male, early 30s, white. Currently taking : Lamictal 400mg Fluoxetine 10mg Omeprazole 40mg Gabapentin 300mg 3x day as needed Vitamin D DX : Bipolar type 2 Social phobia (not sure exactly how my psych phrased it) Anxiety Abdominal epilepsy Acid reflux Tobacco (on/off), marijuana use, almost never drink or use any other drugs. I will do my best to be brief. I have had serious mental health issues since I was a child. First suicide attempt was at 7. Institutionalized at 15 for suicidal ideation, and have had therapy since then. I restarted medications at 21. I have had a lot of bad experiences with medical professionals. Very abusive docs when institutionalized. My last doctor told me to treat my bipolar disorder with a multivitamin. The doctor before prescribed me an anti depressant, had a manic episode, then changed to lamictal 100mg. He also called me a drug seeker because I wanted muscle relaxers to treat a weird medical episode that was causing severe neck pain. This turned out to be abdominal epilepsy. I have used urgent cares on rare occasion to get antibiotics, etc. But I haven't had a pcp since I was 20. How can I find a PCP that is comfortable working with mental health patients? What do I need to have done to get on track? I am aware that I am extremely high risk for suicide, between bipolar, loss of a sibling to suicide, childhood sexual abuse. I feel it's more important than ever to get a grip on my physical health so I can have a long life with my wife and my parents, and live to take care of them in their golden years. Currently see a therapist and a psych for med management. I'm also working with my therapist now to work through my problems with seeking medical care. Any other questions I am happy to ask.
38.answer:
I’m glad you’re thinking about building a solid primary-care relationship—it really can add years and quality to your life. Below is a practical “road-map” broken into four parts:

1. How to locate the right primary-care clinician  
2. How to set up the first visit and what to bring  
3. Preventive-care & monitoring checklist for a man in his early 30s on your medication regimen  
4. Ongoing safety and self-advocacy tips

----------------------------------------------------
1. Finding a primary-care clinician who is comfortable with mental-health conditions
----------------------------------------------------
A. Use your existing supports  
• Ask your psychiatrist, therapist, or even your pharmacist: “Who are the PCPs you like working with for patients on Lamictal, antidepressants, etc.?” These professionals usually know who is receptive.  
• Local NAMI (National Alliance on Mental Illness) or DBSA (Depression & Bipolar Support Alliance) chapters often keep informal “friendly provider” lists.  

B. Look for integrated or “behavioral-health-friendly” settings  
• Family-medicine or internal-medicine practices that advertise a “Patient-Centered Medical Home” or “Integrated Behavioral Health” model. Many community health centers and teaching-hospital clinics work this way.  
• Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) routinely care for complex psychiatric patients and accept most insurances plus sliding scales.  

C. Screening questions to ask the front desk before you book  
• “Does Dr. X manage patients who are on mood stabilizers?”  
• “Is your practice comfortable coordinating care with my psychiatrist?”  
• “Do you have same-day slots if my mental condition suddenly changes?”  
If they sound defensive or dismissive on the phone, keep looking—how they treat you now is a preview of the relationship.  

D. Do a quick background check  
• Board-certified in Family Medicine or Internal Medicine?  
• Any patient reviews that repeatedly mention listening skills, mental-health friendliness, or trouble with refills? Make sure negative comments aren’t all about “wouldn’t give me Xanax,” which can simply mean they follow guidelines.

----------------------------------------------------
2. Preparing for the first appointment
----------------------------------------------------
Bring (or upload to the portal) a concise “medical one-pager”:
• Current meds (name, dose, start date, purpose, side-effects)  
• Diagnoses (psychiatric, neurological, GI) and dates of major events (hospitalizations, seizures, suicide attempts, etc.)  
• Allergies & intolerances  
• Family history (especially suicide, mood disorders, cardiac disease, cancer)  
• Lifestyle factors: tobacco on/off, marijuana use, alcohol (rare)  

Also bring/wear: BP log (if you have one), copy of last labs or imaging, vaccination card, list of goals (e.g., “I want to reduce reflux meds,” “I want a suicide safety plan that involves you as well as my therapist”).

Ask the PCP to:
• Obtain your records from prior hospitals/clinicians (sign release forms).  
• Coordinate a joint medication-safety plan with your psychiatrist (fax or secure message).  
• Discuss a plan for urgent access (same-day call-backs, portal messages, etc.).

----------------------------------------------------
3. Preventive & medication-specific checklist for a 30-year-old male
----------------------------------------------------
Baseline / annual labs  
☑ CBC & CMP (liver & kidney function—for Lamictal, gabapentin)  
☑ Fasting lipid panel & blood pressure every 3-5 yrs (more often if abnormal or on psych meds that can change weight/lipids)  
☑ HbA1c or fasting glucose (esp. if BMI >25 or strong family history)  
☑ TSH (hypothyroidism can mimic depression)  
☑ Vitamin D level (already supplementing, but re-check q 6-12 mo)  
☑ Magnesium & Vitamin B12 after >12 months of daily omeprazole use  
☑ Lamotrigine level (optional; not routinely required but some clinicians do a trough level if dose changes or symptoms appear)  
☑ Urinalysis & kidney function (gabapentin is renally cleared)  
☑ STI/HIV/Hep-C screening at least once (sooner if risk factors change)

Immunizations  
• Tdap booster every 10 yrs (one should be Tdap, not Td)  
• Annual flu shot  
• COVID series + boosters per CDC updates  
• HPV vaccine series (approved up to age 45) if not completed as a teen  
• Hepatitis B series if you don’t show immunity  
• Varicella/MMR catch-up if no documented immunity

Physical & other screening  
• Dental cleaning q 6 mo; eye exam q 1-2 yrs  
• Skin examination for melanoma (especially in lighter skin tones)  
• Weight, BMI, waist circumference each visit  
• Mood / substance-use screeners (PHQ-9, GAD-7, AUDIT-C) integrated into visits  
• Colon-cancer screening starts at 45; lung-cancer CT only if 20+ pack-year smoking history

Medication tune-ups  
– Omeprazole: If symptoms allow, attempt step-down (e.g., H2 blocker as needed, lifestyle). Consider H. pylori testing or EGD if long-standing reflux.  
– Gabapentin: Review efficacy and sedation; ensure no drug interactions.  
– Lamictal: Watch for new rash, oral ulcers, flu-like signs—seek care urgently.  
– Fluoxetine: Monitor for hyponatremia (esp. if fatigue, confusion).

Lifestyle targets  
• Exercise ≥150 min/week moderate activity; resistance 2×/wk  
• Tobacco quit plan (nicotine replacement, bupropion, varenicline, or behavioral program)  
• Nutrient-dense diet, weight management (helps reflux & mood)  
• Sleep hygiene (consistent schedule, limit THC near bedtime)  
• Limit or avoid alcohol (keeps mood and reflux more stable)

----------------------------------------------------
4. Suicide-prevention & self-advocacy
----------------------------------------------------
Safety plan  
• Crisis numbers in your phone: 988 (U.S.), local warm lines, psychiatrist on-call line  
• Written plan: warning signs → coping skills → people to call → professional contacts → means-restriction steps (gun locks, limited pill counts, etc.)  

Ask the PCP to put a “suicide risk flag” in your chart so any on-call clinician sees it and follows the plan you and your psychiatrist created.

Trauma-informed strategies  
• Bring a support person to visits or join via speakerphone.  
• Tell the physician up front: “I’ve had medical trauma; please explain what you’re doing before you touch/examine me.”  
• Use the patient portal to ask clarifying questions in writing—helps avoid feeling rushed or dismissed.  

Know when to switch  
If a provider shames you, ignores your input, or refuses to coordinate care, thank them, request copies of all records, and move on. You are hiring them, not the other way around.

----------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
You already have a therapist and psychiatrist; the missing piece is a PCP who will (1) monitor the physical effects of your psych meds, (2) keep routine health maintenance on track, and (3) be an additional safety net. Use referrals from people who already work well with mental-health patients, ask pointed questions before you schedule, and walk into the first visit with an organized one-pager and clear goals. Combine that with the preventive-care checklist above and the suicide-safety steps you’re developing with your therapist, and you’ll have a comprehensive plan to protect both your mind and body for the long haul.

39.question: My bf is a 33M, 220 lbs, history of epilepsy, high cholesterol, has high blood pressure on occasion, ADD, allergy to augmentin, and kiwi. He takes lamotrigine, phenobarbital, Lamictal. He vapes, never drinks, and smokes marijuana on occasion. He hasn't had a seizure in three years fortunately. He went to the Dr yesterday and his Dr told him his med levels are at a level 2 when they should be at around a 7. Dr showed him that the levels dropped to dangerous levels in three years despite an increase in meds in those years. Any insight in what this could be? He's waiting on more blood tests.
39.answer:
I can’t tell you exactly why your boyfriend’s antiseizure-drug level is low, but I can outline the common reasons the neurologist will be thinking about while the repeat labs are pending.  

WHAT “A LEVEL OF 2 WHEN IT SHOULD BE 7” USUALLY MEANS  
• For lamotrigine (brand name Lamictal) the usual therapeutic trough range quoted by many labs is roughly 3–15 µg/mL.  
• For phenobarbital the therapeutic range is 15–40 µg/mL.  
Because you wrote “Lamotrigine, phenobarbital, Lamictal,” I’m going to assume the doctor was talking about lamotrigine (Lamictal) and the result was ~2 µg/mL, well below the lower limit. A sub-therapeutic level puts him at risk for a breakthrough seizure even though he has been seizure-free for three years.  

WHY WOULD THE LEVEL FALL EVEN THOUGH THE DOSE HAS BEEN INCREASED?  
1. Missed, irregular, or wrong-time dosing  
   • Far and away the most common reason. People with ADD often have trouble with rigid dosing schedules.  
   • Even missing 1–2 doses in the 48 h before the blood draw can cut the trough level in half.  

2. Blood drawn at the wrong time  
   • Lamotrigine has a half-life of ~25 h. The sample should be taken just before the next dose (“trough”).  
   • If the lab was drawn earlier (e.g., 3–6 h after a dose) it can give a falsely low or high number, depending on the drug.  

3. Drug interactions that accelerate metabolism  
   • Phenobarbital itself induces liver enzymes (UGT and CYP) that metabolize lamotrigine; if phenobarbital was started or its dose was raised, lamotrigine levels can fall 40–60 %.  
   • Nicotine (cigarettes or vaping) and marijuana smoke can also induce certain liver enzymes.  
   • Over-the-counter or herbal products (St John’s wort, some cold medicines, rifampin, carbamazepine, phenytoin, some HIV meds) may do the same.  
   • Cannabidiol (CBD) used chronically in high doses can lower lamotrigine a bit; THC smoke mainly works through the nicotine-like induction route.  

4. Malabsorption or stomach issues  
   • Chronic diarrhea, celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, gastric bypass, certain antacids and proton-pump inhibitors, or chronic vomiting can reduce the fraction of oral drug that gets into the bloodstream.  

5. Body-weight change  
   • He’s 220 lb (~100 kg). Because lamotrigine dosing isn’t strictly weight-based after adolescence, a 30-40 lb weight gain over three years sometimes turns an adequate dose into an inadequate one.  

6. Lab error or a different lab method  
   • Not common, but the first thing many neurologists do with an unexpected low is simply repeat the test.  

7. Very unusual causes  
   • Rare genetic “ultra-rapid” UGT metabolizers.  
   • New liver-enzyme activity because of liver disease (opposite problem if the liver fails: levels go up).  

WHAT YOUR BOYFRIEND (AND YOU) CAN DO WHILE WAITING  
• Take every dose on time. A pill organizer or phone reminder helps, especially for people with ADD.  
• No skipped or “double-up later” doses.  
• Write down the exact time of the last dose and give it to the lab nurse at the next blood draw.  
• Let the neurologist know about every prescription, OTC, herbal, or recreational drug (including nicotine vapes and cannabis).  
• Aim to have the next blood test drawn right before a dose (“trough”), unless the doctor asks for something different.  
• DON’T increase doses on his own while waiting for instructions; over-correction can push levels too high and cause rashes, dizziness, or toxicity.  
• If he develops any seizure aura, unusual jerks, or confusion, call his neurologist or go to the ED—sub-therapeutic levels mean his seizure threshold is lower right now.  

BOTTOM LINE  
A low lamotrigine (or phenobarbital) level after years of stability is usually due to missed doses, drug interactions, or timing of the lab. The follow-up blood work, a careful medication/supplement history, and perhaps another level drawn at the correct time will let his neurologist sort out which cause is at play and whether the dose really needs to be changed.

40.question: Age: 21 Sex: Female (But I go by He/Him) Height: 5'3 Weight: 106lbsOver the past few months I've been seeing a psychiatrist and she's put me on numerous pills. The first set of pills were Wellbutrin XL 300mg (One I'd already been taking) Venalafaxine ER 37.5mg, Hydroxyzine HCL 25mg, and Ondansetron 4mg. So far my only "diagnosed" issues are depression and a very severe panic/ anxiety disorder so these were meant to help me avoid panic attacks, mood swings, depression and nausea. However, I also explained that sometimes I smoke weed, she said I should avoid it, but occasionally it'd be fine. Same with Alcohol. So far alcohol has been just fine, but when I did weed It was a horrifying experience for me and my family. My body wouldn't stop shaking, all of my muscles felt tight and for some period of time I couldn't move and my breathing was very forced? I also was hallucinating bad. I kept asking my mom to look at my stomach because there was an air bubble that would travel to my heart and kill me. And I was so afraid I was going to die, but my mom kept assuring me that I was fine and that I was probably just tripping and that I needed to sleep. But I was so scared and didn't want to die alone so I slept in her room. It's been a few weeks since then and I haven't touched anything weed related since. But I still feel... Like ever since then I'm not exactly the same? I've been more suicidal than I've ever been in my life, and my muscles and joints feel bruised and I can barely stand to go grocery shopping my body feels so tired and in pain like I've run a marathon. Like I explained this to my psych and she didn't really seem to care. She's now got me on Oxcarbazepine 150mg that I take 2 times daily, along with everything else I was taking. I still have to take the Venalafaxine, but I'm weaning off of it. But so far I am still anxious, suicidal, and in more pain than I've ever been. And every now and then I'm seeing things like a weird grey cloud with a face in my bedroom or I'll think my hands are turning grey when they aren't.
40.answer:
I’m really glad you reached out, because several of the things you describe are red-flag symptoms that warrant prompt, in-person medical attention rather than just waiting for the next routine visit.

1.  What’s worrisome right now  
   • Persistent or escalating suicidal thoughts  
   • New visual hallucinations (seeing a grey cloud with a face, hands changing colour)  
   • Marked physical symptoms—global muscle pain, weakness, fatigue—that are new since the last medication change  
   • A prior episode that sounded like an acute toxic or panic reaction (tremor, rigidity, feeling you “couldn’t breathe,” intense fear of dying) after cannabis

2.  Possible medical explanations  
   These are only possibilities; you need an examination and labs to sort them out.  
   • Drug interactions / side-effects  
        – Bupropion (Wellbutrin) at 300 mg can, in a small minority, provoke anxiety, tremor or even psychotic-like symptoms, especially when paired with another activating antidepressant (venlafaxine).  
        – Venlafaxine + bupropion also raises serotonin and norepinephrine simultaneously; some people develop severe agitation or rare serotonin toxicity.  
        – Oxcarbazepine can cause low sodium (hyponatraemia). A sodium level that drops even moderately can produce confusion, muscle cramps, fatigue and hallucinations.  
        – Any anticonvulsant-type mood stabiliser, including oxcarbazepine, carries an FDA warning for increased suicidal ideation in a small percentage of patients.  
   • Cannabis on top of stimulating meds can precipitate panic or a short-lived psychotic reaction, and sometimes leaves a “post-intoxication” derealisation/anxiety state that lingers for weeks.  
   • Medical problems that can mimic psychiatric ones (thyroid disturbance, anaemia, vitamin B12 deficiency, infection, autoimmune illness, etc.) have to be ruled out because rapid weight loss and diffuse muscle pain are not classic antidepressant side-effects.

3.  What to do today  
   • If suicidal thoughts feel at all close to action, treat it as an emergency:  
       – Call 988 (US) or your local crisis line.  
       – Go to the nearest emergency department or call 911 and say, “I’m thinking of killing myself.”  
   • Even if you feel you can stay safe:  
       – Phone your psychiatrist’s office today. Tell the receptionist or on-call clinician, “I’m having new visual hallucinations and worsening suicidal thoughts; my muscles feel bruised everywhere. My psychiatrist needs to call me back today.”  
       – Ask explicitly whether you should have labs (basic metabolic panel for sodium, CBC, thyroid, B12, etc.) before continuing oxcarbazepine.  
       – If you cannot reach your psychiatrist quickly, go to an urgent-care or ER and bring a list of every medication and dose.  
   • Do NOT add or stop any of the prescription medicines on your own today; abrupt changes—especially venlafaxine—can worsen everything. Let a clinician tell you how/if to taper.

4.  Cannabis and alcohol going forward  
   • With the drug combination you’re on, cannabis is not “occasionally fine.” It can magnify anxiety and, in susceptible people, trigger psychosis. Best to stay completely abstinent at least until things are stable for several months.  
   • Alcohol in small amounts is often tolerated, but it can worsen depression, interfere with sleep and interact with oxcarbazepine. Keep it minimal or skip it entirely for now.

5.  Non-medication steps while you’re waiting to be seen  
   • Sleep hygiene: same bedtime, no screens for 30 min prior, cool dark room.  
   • Nutrition: three protein-containing meals daily (hypoglycaemia can amplify anxiety).  
   • Hydration: at least 2 L fluid/day unless a doctor says otherwise; ask whether you should limit or maintain fluids while sodium is being checked.  
   • Gentle physical activity (short walks, stretching) if your doctor confirms nothing medically dangerous is going on.  
   • Quick grounding skills when you start to feel “unreal” or see things: name five objects you can see, four you can touch, three you can hear, two you can smell, one you can taste. It won’t cure psychosis but it often reduces panic.  
   • Support network: keep someone informed of how you feel each day—family, close friend, therapist, or online peer support if nothing else.

6.  Questions to ask your psychiatrist at the next contact  
   • Could my sodium or other labs be off since starting oxcarbazepine?  
   • Is the combination of bupropion + venlafaxine too activating for me?  
   • Given the hallucinations, should we consider reducing or stopping bupropion first?  
   • What is the plan for monitoring suicidal thoughts while we adjust meds?  
   • Should I have a therapist for weekly CBT/DBT alongside medication management?

Bottom line: new hallucinations, body-wide pain, profound fatigue and intensified suicidal thoughts after a med change are not “just anxiety.” Please treat this as urgent—contact your psychiatrist today or go to an ER to be evaluated, get basic labs, and discuss a safer medication plan. You are not alone, and with the right assessment and adjustments most people do get past this rough patch.

41.question: As a preface, just want to include that I do have a doctor's appointment scheduled for these issues, but just wanted to get other people's opinions to see if I'm overthinking things. 5'10, about average weight, no drug use except nicotine. These symptoms precede any nicotine use, and seem unaffected by it. I have no history of seizures in early childhood, although a lot of the symptoms I list below have affected me since I was about 10. I do seem to have a family history with epilepsy, although I don't know all of the details. A few weeks back, I was reading a book -- and at one point, the author went into detail about Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. Interested by the concept, I looked it up, and found that many of the symptoms seem to line up with what I had called my migraine auras for years. Random tastes or smells, always enjoyable but never lasting for more than 5 seconds. Bursts of euphoria for absolutely no reason, gone within a minute or two. Strong dissociation at times, linked to no negative events, just out of nowhere. I thought this was interesting but didn't investigate it further until I thought about my sleep issues. If I don't sleep well, and attempt to nap later in the day, sleeping is sometimes nearly impossible. I'll instead be essentially semi-conscious, in a dream-like state, seeing random events unfold. When I "wake up" from these, my body feels as if it's buzzing, I feel completely exhausted, and I have no memory of the specific things I saw other than they occurred. I have no idea how long these moments last. And, the last issue, also sleep related and usually occurs again if I'm tired and attempt to nap -- I'll be able to fall asleep, but as I wake up, I'll feel locked-in, similar to sleep paralysis. I feel that same buzzing again, throughout my head and torso, and my head particularly seems to move around quickly. A couple weeks back this resulted in me (luckily, not too painfully) hitting my head against the wall. I only truly remembered that happening the next evening. As far as I remember, I went back to sleep after it happened with no further incidents. Thanks for any advice or opinions you may have :)
41.answer:
I’m not your doctor and can’t give you a diagnosis, but I can walk you through how a neurologist or sleep specialist is likely to think about the symptoms you’ve listed and what the next steps usually look like.

1. “Auras” while fully awake  
   • Very brief (seconds-to-a-minute) smells/tastes, sudden waves of euphoria, déjà-vu/​dissociation are classic descriptions of focal aware seizures that start in the temporal lobe (“temporal-lobe auras,” “uncinate fits,” or, in rare cases, “ecstatic seizures”).  
   • Migraine aura can give odd smells/​tastes, but those auras usually last 5-60 minutes, not 5 seconds, and are often (though not always) followed by a headache.  
   • Other possibilities: spontaneous “phantosmia,” anxiety/panic phenomena, medication effects, or sinus disease—but the very short, stereotyped, come-and-go nature makes focal seizures high on the list.

2. Episodes that occur when you nap or are sleep-deprived  
   • Drifting in and out of sleep while “watching” dream-like scenes, then waking up exhausted, sounds a lot like hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations plus sleep inertia—both common when you’re overtired.  
   • The body “buzzing” and an inability to move on awakening fits typical sleep paralysis, which is also more common with sleep deprivation.  
   • However, if the buzzing is followed by actual jerks, head-banging, or activity you don’t remember (and you hit the wall), then REM sleep behavior disorder, NREM parasomnias, or nocturnal seizures are possible. An overnight video EEG or formal sleep study often sorts these out.

3. Risk factors you’ve already flagged  
   • Family history of epilepsy—raises the index of suspicion.  
   • Symptoms beginning around age 10 and remaining stereotyped for years—again fits focal epilepsy more than most psychiatric or migraine phenomena.  
   • No early childhood convulsions—doesn’t rule epilepsy in or out.

What a neurologist is likely to do
• Detailed history: exact duration, frequency, triggers, recovery time, awareness, any automatisms (lip smacking, fiddling, staring), headache afterward.  
• Routine EEG, and often a prolonged or video EEG if the first study is non-diagnostic.  
• MRI (to look for mesial temporal sclerosis, old head trauma, tumors, cortical dysplasia, etc.).  
• If sleep events are prominent, a full overnight polysomnogram with an expanded EEG montage can catch both parasomnias and nocturnal seizures.

What you can do while waiting for the appointment
1. Keep a diary. Note date/time of each episode, what you were doing, how long it lasted, any triggers (sleep loss, stress, flashing lights, alcohol), how you felt afterward. Take it to the visit.  
2. Get as regular and adequate sleep as possible; poor sleep lowers the seizure threshold and worsens sleep-paralysis/​parasomnias.  
3. Go easy on cocaine-like stimulants, excess caffeine, or alcohol. Nicotine’s relationship to seizures is mixed, but heavy vaping/​smoking can fragment sleep.  
4. Until you’re cleared, play it safe with driving, climbing ladders, swimming alone, or operating machinery—brief focal seizures can still be dangerous if they happen at the wrong moment.

Red-flag situations that merit urgent review or ER visit
• A convulsive (whole-body) seizure lasting >5 minutes or a cluster of two or more back-to-back.  
• Sudden, unexplained injuries, tongue-biting, incontinence on waking.  
• New neurological deficits (weakness, trouble speaking, vision loss).

Likely outcomes
• If EEG/MRI confirm focal epilepsy, first-line medications (levetiracetam, lamotrigine, carbamazepine, etc.) control seizures in ~70 % of people.  
• If work-up points instead to primary sleep disorders, treatment ranges from improved sleep hygiene and scheduled naps to medications (e.g., for narcolepsy or REM sleep behavior disorder).  
• Migraine aura without headache can be managed with typical migraine preventives if needed.

Bottom line
Your “migraine auras” do have features that overlap strongly with temporal-lobe seizures, and the sleep events could be parasomnias but might also be nocturnal seizures. You’re doing the right thing by seeing a doctor. Bring a detailed symptom diary, and ask whether both a routine EEG and (if negative) a video EEG or sleep-lab study are appropriate.

42.question: Male 31 non smoker 6’1” 250lbs, no history of epilepsy/seizuresI have always had sensitivity to lights while driving, especially at night. Things such as normal car headlights and signals have not caused a problem, however when it’s been raining or wet it causes the lights to be reflected off the pools of water it often disorients me and causes a dizzy feeling. I am in An area where it doesn’t rain now and yesterday had to drive through a tunnel covered with a crazy amount of LED lights, and with them reflecting off the cars I became almost instantly overwhelmingly dizzy and nauseous and had to pull over for 15 minutes for it to stop. I am not sure what is causing it, but I am afraid to drive at night or in certain areas because of this issue.
42.answer:
What you describe is fairly common, but it is NOT normal.  
Sudden, intense dizziness/nausea that forces you to stop the car is a safety problem and needs a formal medical work-up.  
Below is an overview of what is probably happening, the most likely diagnoses, what can be done in the meantime, and when to seek help urgently.

────────────────────────────────
1.  Why wet roads, tunnels and LED lights are the worst  
────────────────────────────────

• Wet pavement, chrome bumpers and tunnel tiles turn every headlight into dozens of bright, moving reflections.  
• LEDs often “flicker” at 100–120 Hz. Most people don’t consciously notice it, but a sensitive brain can pick it up as strobe-like flashing.  
• The visual scene is therefore full of rapidly changing, high-contrast light patterns.  
• Your inner-ear (vestibular) system senses fairly smooth, straight-line motion of the car, while your eyes see chaotic motion. That sensory mismatch often produces dizziness and nausea—much like car-sickness or VR-sickness.

────────────────────────────────
2.  Most common medical explanations  
────────────────────────────────
The exact label has to come from an exam, but the usual culprits are:

A. Migraine-related (even without headache)  
   • “Migraine-associated vertigo,” “visual vertigo,” or “vestibular migraine.”  
   • Light, glare, flicker and complex patterns are classic migraine triggers.  
   • You do NOT need to have head pain to have a migraine variant.

B. Benign vestibular disorders that cause “visual dependence”  
   • After a bout of vestibular neuritis, concussion, or even minor inner-ear imbalance, the brain leans more on vision for balance. Busy visual scenes then overwhelm it.

C. Binocular vision/eye-muscle problems or uncorrected refractive error  
   • Even mild astigmatism, convergence insufficiency or lack of anti-glare coating can turn night driving into a glare-fest that the brain interprets as dizziness.

D. Less common causes  
   • Epileptic photic sensitivity (rare and usually produces jerking/blank spells, not just dizziness).  
   • Eye disease (early cataracts scatter light) or neurological disease (multiple sclerosis, Chiari malformation, etc.). These are much lower on the list at your age but still checked for.

────────────────────────────────
3.  What to do right now (safety first)  
────────────────────────────────
• Until you are evaluated, avoid night driving, wet-road driving and brightly lit tunnels if at all possible.  
• Keep your windshield, mirrors and glasses scrupulously clean; even a light film dramatically increases glare.  
• Try polarized sunglasses in the daytime and an anti-glare, lightly amber/rose tinted lens (FL-41 or similar) at dusk or in tunnels. They cut reflections and damp LED flicker without being dark like regular sunglasses.  
• Dim your dashboard and cockpit screens; bright periphery lights increase “visual noise.”  
• Take breaks, use fresh air, and stay well hydrated—minor dehydration makes motion-related nausea worse.  
• If an episode starts, pull over immediately, close your eyes, and focus on slow breathing until symptoms settle.

────────────────────────────────
4.  The work-up you should arrange  
────────────────────────────────
1. Comprehensive eye exam  
   • Check refraction, astigmatism, glare testing, cataract screen, and binocular vision.  
2. Neurology or ENT (otoneurology) evaluation  
   • History & neuro exam, bedside eye-movement testing, caloric or video head-impulse test for inner-ear asymmetry.  
   • Consider MRI only if “red flags” (weakness, sensory loss, double vision, etc.).  
3. Headache/migraine assessment  
   • Even if you rarely have headache, ask whether this is “vestibular migraine.”  
4. Possible vestibular physical therapy referral  
   • If you prove to have “visual dependence” or mild vestibular hypofunction, tailored exercises reduce the sensitivity dramatically.  

If you have obstructive sleep apnea (body-mass index ≈33 puts you at risk) bring this up—untreated OSA can worsen migraine and dizziness sensitivity.

────────────────────────────────
5.  When it is an emergency  
────────────────────────────────
Go to the Emergency Department (don’t drive yourself) if you ever get:  
• Vertigo plus true spinning of the room, severe imbalance or falling  
• Double vision, slurred speech, facial droop, limb weakness/numbness  
• New severe headache (“worst of life”)  
• Loss of consciousness, seizures, or involuntary jerking movements

────────────────────────────────
Bottom line  
────────────────────────────────
Glare- and flicker-induced dizziness is often a migraine-related or visually-induced vestibular problem. It is very unlikely to be a seizure disorder, but it is still potentially dangerous while driving. A structured eye and vestibular/migraine evaluation can usually identify the issue and there are effective treatments—lenses, medications, vestibular therapy and migraine prevention strategies. Until you are formally assessed, minimize high-glare driving situations and pull over at the first hint of symptoms.

43.question: Hello :) 26, male, 5'9, 87kg, Indian, generalised epilepsy for eight years, currently taking lamotrigine; I drink and live in the UK. I've had generalised epilepsy since I was 14, and it hasn't improved. I've had the same neurologist since I was diagnosed, and he told me nothing different to this date. It sucks because the only thing he ever tells me is they don't know the cause. At this age, it's still shit that I'm still not allowed to drive, I have seizures about once a month, and it worries me when I travel abroad or even at work. I would like to see if you guys have any advice, any different opinions or anything else that could help me. Thank you very much :)
43.answer:
I’m sorry you’re still struggling after so many years.  A single medication that only partly controls “generalised epilepsy” is NOT as good as modern care can usually offer.  Below is a practical check-list you can take to your GP and neurologist (or a new one) to push things forward.  None of it replaces seeing a specialist, but it should arm you with the right questions and options.

1.  Make sure the diagnosis is right
   • “Generalised epilepsy” is a broad label.  About 15–20 % of people given that label later turn out to have focal epilepsy that secondarily generalises, a genetic-generalised syndrome that needs a different drug mix, or a structural lesion missed on the first MRI.
   • Ask for a review in a tertiary “Epilepsy Centre” if you have not had:  
     – 3-Tesla MRI with an epilepsy protocol  
     – long-term video-EEG telemetry or ambulatory EEG  
     – antiepileptic-drug (AED) serum-level monitoring to confirm absorption/adherence.  
   • If those tests haven’t been done (or were done many years ago), NHS guidelines say you are eligible for referral.

2.  Optimise medication (70–80 % of people become seizure-free on the right drug or combination)
   • Lamotrigine is often first-line but only controls about half of patients on its own.  Target dose for generalised seizures is usually 300–500 mg/day; if you are on less, there may still be room to increase.
   • Reasonable second-line add-ons for generalised tonic-clonics:  
     – Levetiracetam (Keppra) – quick titration, minimal interactions  
     – Valproate – very effective, but discuss fertility, weight, and teratogenic issues (less of a problem for men, but still monitor liver and weight)  
     – Topiramate, Zonisamide, Perampanel, Clobazam (intermittent or chronic)  
   • Combination therapy: lamotrigine + valproate or lamotrigine + levetiracetam are common when monotherapy fails.
   • If you have absence or myoclonic components, ethosuximide or brivaracetam could be considered.

3.  Non-drug options that can help
   • Ketogenic or Modified Atkins Diet: not just for children; about 1 in 3 adults who try it get ≥50 % seizure reduction.  Requires a dietitian familiar with epilepsy.  
   • Vagus-Nerve Stimulation (VNS): outpatient day-case procedure, gives 25–50 % reduction in many patients who are drug-resistant.  
   • Deep-brain stimulation of the anterior thalamus is NICE-approved for some refractory generalised cases, though evidence is still emerging.  
   • Responsive neurostimulation and corpus callosotomy are niche but available options through specialised centres if seizures remain severe.

4.  Lifestyle factors you can control
   • Alcohol: the occasional pint is usually okay, but binge drinking and the “hangover dehydration” period are potent seizure triggers—many patients seize 12–24 h after heavy drinking rather than during it.  
   • Sleep: aim for regular 7–9 h.  Even one night of <5 h or a long-haul flight with jet-lag doubles seizure risk for the next 48 h.  
   • Medication timing: set two phone alarms; missing just one dose of lamotrigine can precipitate a breakthrough.  
   • Stress and exercise: aerobic exercise actually lowers seizure frequency; high-intensity or contact sports need planning but are not forbidden.  
   • Weight: BMI≈28 (87 kg/175 cm) is mild obesity; 5–10 kg weight loss alone can improve sleep quality and drug kinetics.

5.  Safety, driving and travel
   • DVLA: You need 12 months seizure-free for an ordinary car licence.  If seizures occur only during sleep for 3 years you can apply for an exemption (“asleep-only epilepsy”).  
   • At work: ensure at least one colleague knows basic seizure first-aid; wear a medical-alert tag; keep an up-to-date rescue-med (e.g., 10 mg buccal midazolam) if prescribed.  
   • Travel: carry a seizure action plan, doctor’s letter for medication, and split pills between hand luggage and hold; buy travel insurance that covers epilepsy (e.g., via “Free Spirit” or “InsureandGo”).  
   • SUDEP reduction: sleep on your side, consider a seizure-alert bed alarm or smartwatch if you live alone.

6.  Mental-health & quality-of-life support
   • Rates of depression and anxiety are higher in epilepsy; NICE recommends annual screening.  Cognitive-behavioural therapy can reduce both mood symptoms and seizure frequency.  
   • Epilepsy Action, Epilepsy Society and Young Epilepsy all have UK helplines, local groups, and travel/benefits advice.

7.  When and how to get a second opinion
   • Drug-resistant epilepsy is defined as seizures persisting after TWO adequate drug trials.  You qualify now.  
   • Ask your GP to refer you to the nearest Comprehensive Epilepsy Centre or to a different consultant with an “epilepsy & seizures” subspecialty listing.  Under NHS “choice” rules you can request this.  
   • Bring a concise seizure diary, medication history (names, doses, side-effects), and a list of specific questions (e.g., “Could we try Keppra add-on?” “Do I meet criteria for VNS?” “Should we repeat the MRI?”).

Key take-away: One seizure a month after 12 years on a single AED meets criteria for drug-resistant epilepsy, and several additional treatments exist.  Pushing for a full re-evaluation at a tertiary epilepsy centre is the single most useful next step.

I hope this gives you concrete talking points and some optimism that better control is genuinely achievable.  Good luck, and feel free to print this out for your next appointment.

44.question: 22F, 5’5, 173lb, whitehi there! weird thing happened last night and i’m nervous and hoping someone might have some input for me. i recently started taking prozac (10mg) in conjunction with lamictal (125mg) (which i’ve been on for about 6 weeks) for MDD. i’ve had a huge decrease in appetite which has led to me forgetting to eat a lot. yesterday i ate very little - almost nothing, without realizing. i was smoking weed with my partner and i started to feel really unwell. i have a low tolerance so i didn’t think much of it. i remember telling him i wanted to lay down, and next thing i knew i woke up to him holding me and saying my name over and over. he asked me a bunch of questions about my surroundings and personal information (address, birthday, etc.) to make sure i was aware and coherent. he said i was sitting there, mentioned i wanted to lay down, and then my body stiffened/seized up and i slid down the chair backwards until i was on the floor and he started trying to wake me up. he said in total, i was out for less than a minute, but he was worried i was having a seizure. while i was out, i was having what felt like a short lucid dream where i was rolling down a mountain, if that’s important. when i came back to my senses, i was sweating a lot, and was nauseous. i laid on the floor for a little bit until i felt okay, and then went to bed. today i feel fine.i figured i just fainted bc i hadn’t eaten and i was smoking, but i know serotonin syndrome can cause seizures so i’m just feeling very anxious and wondering if i’m worrying over nothing. i’ve never fainted or had a seizure so i don’t really know what either one feel like.
44.answer:
I can’t tell you for certain what happened (only a clinician who has actually examined you and, if needed, run some tests can do that), but I can give you the medical reasoning we use when someone describes an episode like yours.

1.  Could this have been serotonin-syndrome related?  
•  Unlikely.  Serotonin syndrome usually needs either a much higher dose of an SSRI, two serotonergic drugs, or a strong interacting drug (e.g., tramadol, MAO-Is, linezolid, MDMA, etc.).  
•  Typical serotonin-syndrome clues – agitation, very high heart rate, shivering/rigidity with rhythmic “clonus,” high fever, diarrhea – aren’t in your story.  
•  Lamotrigine isn’t serotonergic.  So serotonin syndrome moves way down the list.

2.  Could it have been a true epileptic seizure?  
•  Possible, but some points lean against it: no rhythmic jerking reported, you regained full orientation in seconds, no tongue-biting or incontinence, you felt sweaty/nauseated (common after faint), and you’d eaten almost nothing all day.  
•  Cannabis (THC) can lower seizure threshold in rare cases, but lamotrigine actually protects against seizures.  
•  A first-time seizure in a young adult still deserves medical follow-up because we can’t rule it out on the internet.

3.  Most likely: “convulsive syncope” (a fancy term for passing out with brief stiffening/jerks).  
•  Weed + empty stomach = vasodilation + low blood sugar → blood pressure drops → the brain is briefly under-perfused, you faint.  
•  In up to 20–30 % of simple faints there’s a few seconds of stiffening or brief jerks, which can look like a seizure to a bystander.  
•  You sweat and feel nauseous because the “fight-or-flight” part of your nervous system kicks in trying to raise your blood pressure back up.

4.  Things worth checking anyway:  
•  Vital signs and orthostatic blood pressure (lying vs. standing).  
•  Basic labs (CBC, electrolytes, glucose) if you haven’t eaten much.  
•  An ECG to be sure your heart rhythm is normal.  
•  Discuss medication timing/doses, marijuana use, and eating patterns with your prescriber.

5.  When to seek care immediately (ER/urgent care):  
•  Another loss of consciousness, any episode lasting >1 min, or you stay confused >5-10 min afterwards.  
•  Repeated vomiting, severe headache, trouble speaking, weakness, chest pain, or palpitations.  
•  Injury from the fall, tongue-biting, or loss of bladder control.  
•  Fever, muscle rigidity, or uncontrollable shaking (would raise serotonin-syndrome or other concerns).

6.  Practical steps you can take now:  
•  Eat something with both carbs and protein at regular intervals; set alarms if appetite is poor.  
•  Hydrate, especially before and while using cannabis.  
•  For the next couple of weeks avoid or greatly limit weed until you’re sure this was just a fainting spell.  
•  Keep a record: how much you eat, medication times/doses, any light-headedness, and any further episodes.  
•  Arrange a non-urgent appointment (soon) with the clinician who prescribed your meds; bring your partner’s description of what he saw.

Bottom line: From what you’ve described, a simple faint brought on by not eating + cannabis is most probable; serotonin syndrome is very unlikely; a first-time seizure can’t be ruled out 100 % and merits at least a phone call to your doctor and possibly a basic work-up if they think it’s needed. If anything like this happens again, get seen right away.

45.question: Hi. I’m 22F. So 5 years ago I was diagnosed with epilepsy after a full-tonic (like a stereotypical?) seizure having had myoclonic seizures constantly for like 2 years before then. No one took me seriously until the major one. During the diagnosis and since, I was constantly asked to describe what I NOW know are myoclonic seizures, but no one ever said they were. I was on Lamotrigine (around 100mg morning and night) until 2020, then was on Keppra (500mg morning and night). In 2021 I was told that since i hadn’t had a seizure in over 3 years I could stop medication (which wasn’t actually true- I hadn’t had a full on seizure in over 3 years but I still had myoclonic ones when having sleeping problems but no neurologist seemed to understand that they were seizures?). The ECG came back clear but I was too nervous to stop meds but in 2022 I was recommended to stop meds again and the ECG was clear again too, so I did. From May 2022 I was absolutely fine with zero issues at all. Then one night in September, I was only able to sleep 2 hours and had dozens of myoclonic seizures until I had a full on seizure. Completely out of the blue. I was then put on 250mg Keppra morning and night but the new neurologist prescribed Lamotrigine…but only 25mg every morning. I was fine on 500mg Keppra/day but then ran out and hadn’t been told how to make the switch, so I just replaced the meds. In the days right after, I’d have a small myoclonic seizure while trying to fall asleep but I thought I was just trying to adjust. A few days later though, I woke up (after minimum 6 hours of sleep) and had dozens of myoclonic seizures only seconds apart and I spent hours trying to fight off a major seizure. After a few hours break we went to A&E because I was begging for meds I wasn’t prescribed. They just said to take 25mg Lamotrigine at night so I immediately did. When I went to bed the constant myoclonic seizures resumed from midnight until 5-6am. All day/night I thought I’d have to end my life rather than go more days like this. The next few days got gradually better and the pharmacists were horrified I was prescribed so badly. But ever since then, I have been on 100mg Lamotrigine + 1g Keppra morning then 1g Keppra at night and regularly have myoclonic seizures while trying to fall asleep so have to take Clobazam. Sorry for the novel, but why has everything gone so downhill??
45.answer:
Short answer
Nothing “mysterious” has happened to your brain – you almost certainly have a life-long generalised epilepsy (most likely juvenile-myoclonic epilepsy, JME).  
People with JME:

• start with myoclonic jerks on waking or while falling asleep in their teens  
• are exquisitely sensitive to sleep-loss, alcohol, stress and abrupt drug changes  
• can have a big (“generalised-tonic-clonic”) seizure after a run of myoclonic jerks  
• have a relapse rate of ≥ 80–90 % if medication is stopped, even after years seizure-free  
• need a regular antiseizure drug at a full therapeutic dose, usually for life.

You were doing well while you were fully protected (lamotrigine 200 mg/day, then levetiracetam 1 g/day). The problems started because the drugs were stopped, then restarted at a sub-therapeutic dose, and one of them (Keppra) was withdrawn abruptly. Sleep deprivation and the stress of all this then pushed you into a prolonged series of myoclonic jerks that almost led to a second generalised seizure.

Detailed explanation
1. Why are the EEGs “normal”?  
A routine 20- or 30-minute EEG is abnormal in only about 60 % of JME patients. If no myoclonic jerks or photic stimulation bring out the typical 4–6 Hz polyspike-and-wave discharges during the recording, the tracing can look normal. A normal EEG never rules out epilepsy.

2. Why did things fall apart so quickly?  
• Withdrawal: Both levetiracetam and lamotrigine have to be cross-tapered. You need 2–4 weeks to build lamotrigine up to 100 mg twice daily (even longer if you are also on valproate) before backing down the levetiracetam. Stopping 500 mg BID Keppra suddenly → rebound seizures.  
• Underdose: 25 mg daily lamotrigine is only the first step of the titration schedule; it gives almost no seizure protection.  
• Sleep loss: Missing even one night is a classic trigger for myoclonic clusters in JME.  
• “Kindling”: A run of seizures increases cortical excitability so the threshold for the next seizure is lower, which is why clusters can happen.

3. Are these jerks “really” seizures?  
Yes. Myoclonic jerks in JME are epileptic discharges that recruit enough muscle groups to give the sudden “fling” movement. They respond to the same drugs that stop the larger generalised seizures.

4. Current medication plan (typical)  
Example for a 50–60 kg adult with JME:

Lamotrigine:  
 Week 1: 25 mg once daily  
 Week 2: 25 mg twice daily  
 Week 3: 50 mg twice daily  
 Week 4: 75 mg twice daily  
Target: 100–150 mg twice daily (some need 200 mg BID)

Levetiracetam: keep full dose (500 – 1000 mg BID) intact until lamotrigine is ≥ 100 mg BID, then taper levetiracetam by 250–500 mg every 1–2 weeks as agreed with your neurologist – or simply stay on the two-drug combination if you tolerate it and remain seizure-free.

Clobazam / clonazepam: can be used as a rescue or brief bridge (5–14 days) during titration but is not ideal long-term because of tolerance and sedation.

5. Why not just stay drug-free?  
In JME the chance of another generalised seizure after medication is stopped is roughly 9 out of 10 (higher in women who are sleep-restricted or drink alcohol). Every breakthrough tonic–clonic seizure carries:  
• injury risk, loss of driving licence, work restrictions  
• SUDEP risk (small but real)  
• psychological impact.

6. Lifestyle tweaks that make a real difference
• Regular sleep schedule, 7–9 h every night.  
• Limit or avoid alcohol; never binge-drink.  
• Caffeine only earlier in the day; no energy drinks at night.  
• Keep well hydrated, balanced diet.  
• Manage stress (exercise, mindfulness, CBT – whatever works for you).  
• Adherence: take meds at the same times every day; use phone alarms or blister packs.

7. Next steps you should take
• Make sure your current neurologist (or preferably an epilepsy specialist/epileptologist) knows what happened so that your drug plan can be formalised in writing.  
• Ask for a clear cross-taper schedule if a future change is needed.  
• Consider a prolonged (> 24 h) EEG or ambulatory EEG if there is any doubt about diagnosis or drug efficacy.  
• Discuss contraception/pregnancy plans, because lamotrigine, levetiracetam and alternatives (valproate, topiramate) have differing safety profiles.  
• Ask about having a rescue plan in writing (e.g., clobazam 10 mg at onset of a cluster, repeat in 8–12 h if needed, when to seek emergency help).  
• Driving: follow your local regulations about seizure-free intervals on medication.

Take-home message
What you are experiencing is the natural behaviour of juvenile-myoclonic epilepsy in the face of abrupt drug withdrawal and sleep loss. With a steady, therapeutic drug dose, good sleep hygiene and avoidance of triggers, most people with JME are completely seizure-free and lead normal lives. The critical step now is to stabilise on an adequate dose and avoid further sudden medication changes.

46.question: Hi all, yesterday I (20F) went to the beach. I was feeling fine, talking to my family, and then all I remember is laying on my side in the sand with a lot of concerned people around me. Apparently I seized up, fell back into the sand, and was clutching at the air with a pained expression before falling completely unconscious and drooling foam (doing some of my own research, I'm guessing this was a tonic-clonic seizure, as I was "out" for several minutes after the muscle spasms). After waking up, I was unable to tell the medics my age — it was as if I'd forgotten what numbers were, it was scary.I was promptly taken to the nearest ER and spent the rest of the afternoon and early evening doing blood tests, a urine test, an EKG, and a CT scan. So far, everything looks normal. I was given fluids and eventually discharged. Later this week I'll have an MRI done, and I have an unrelated neurologist appointment to follow up about chronic headaches (I will definitely mention the seizure).Since being discharged I've been pretty steady on my feet, just tired and achy in my arms and back. I have some mild tremors in my hands and legs but those predate the seizure. I'm limiting my screen time and will not be driving for a little while. I've also been instructed to lower my dosage of Wellbutrin as it carries a higher seizure risk. I'm staying with my family over the summer, thus I won't be alone if something were to happen at home. My partner is an EMT which gives me more comfort if something were to happen at her place.My first question is: how common is this type of thing? I'd only heard of epilepsy causing seizures before yesterday, and all of my testing so far shows no abnormalities. My second question is: should I wait a while before returning to hobbies like dancing or using my sewing machine? I'm a very careful person but even then, I don't want to endanger myself unnecessarily. Thanks in advance!
46.answer:
(I’m not your doctor; the following is general information that you can take to your own clinicians.)

1.  How common is a “one-off” seizure and why can it happen when all the tests are normal?

•  Frequency.  About 8–10 % of people will have at least one seizure at some point in their lives.  Only about 1 %–3 % go on to develop epilepsy (recurrent, unprovoked seizures).  
•  Normal tests are typical after a first event.  In 30 %–40 % of first-time tónico-clonic seizures the CT, blood work and even MRI/EEG are entirely normal; the episode is labeled a “first unprovoked seizure” unless a clear reversible trigger is found.  
•  Possible precipitants in your situation  
  –  Medication: Bupropion (Wellbutrin) is well-known for lowering the seizure threshold, especially above 300 mg/day, if doses are missed, or with dehydration/heat.  
  –  Heat, dehydration, sleep deprivation, alcohol, illness, flashing light, recreational drugs and hormonal shifts all make the brain more “twitchy.”  
  –  Occasionally a single seizure is the first sign of epilepsy, but that diagnosis is usually made only after two unprovoked events or one event with a very high risk of recurrence (certain MRI or EEG findings, serious head trauma, brain malformation, etc.).

What happens next in the work-up?

•  MRI – looks for subtle structural problems a CT can miss.  
•  EEG – picks up abnormal electrical patterns that raise the likelihood of another seizure (ask the neurologist about arranging one if it isn’t already ordered).  
•  Medication review – you are already tapering the Wellbutrin; avoid other drugs that lower the threshold (tramadol, some antibiotics, excessive caffeine, stimulants, alcohol binges).

What’s the outlook?

•  After a single unprovoked seizure the risk of another in the next two years is ∼20 % if MRI/EEG are normal and there is a clear provoking factor (e.g., a medication) and ∼40 % if everything is normal but no precipitant is found.  
•  If you go 2–3 years seizure-free the chance of ever having another drops a lot.

2.  Activity questions    

For the first week or two most neurologists use the rule “nothing where a sudden loss of consciousness would put you or someone else in real danger.”  Once you are seen in follow-up and the MRI/EEG results are back, activity recommendations can be individualized.

Generally sensible precautions until then:

Allowed right away
•  Walking, light stretching, gentle dance practice on the floor with someone around  
•  Reading, crafts that do not involve rotating blades or very sharp tools  
•  Screen time in moderation (tired eyes or flicker rarely trigger seizures unless you are one of the small group with photosensitive epilepsy).

Better to postpone or do only with supervision
•  Full-out dancing on stage, climbing, cycling in traffic, driving a car (many regions require 3–12 months seizure-free and physician clearance after a first seizure), swimming alone, bathing in deep tubs, using power saws, or operating a sewing machine for long sessions when nobody else is home (needles close to the fingers + abrupt loss of consciousness can cause injury).  
•  Heavy weight-lifting over your head or contact sports until muscle soreness is gone and the neurologist clears you.

Self-care in the meantime

•  Get very regular sleep.  
•  Stay well hydrated; avoid over-heating.  
•  Limit alcohol and avoid recreational drugs.  
•  Keep a “seizure diary”: date, time, what you were doing, possible triggers, how long it lasted, how you felt afterward.  
•  Make sure at least one friend/family member knows basic first aid for seizures (place on side, protect head, time the event, do not restrain, call EMS if >5 min, no breathing, or injury).

Red-flag reasons to call your doctor or return to the ED sooner

•  Another seizure, especially one that lasts >5 min or clusters (more than one without full recovery).  
•  Persistent weakness, confusion, severe headache or fever.  
•  Any new neurologic sign: difficulty speaking, vision loss, one-sided numbness/weakness.

Bottom line

A single seizure with normal initial tests is fairly common and often never recurs, especially when a reversible trigger such as bupropion, heat or dehydration is present. Continue the work-up as planned, follow your physician’s advice about driving and medication changes, and ease back into activities that carry little safety risk until you’ve had your neurology follow-up and results of the MRI/EEG.

47.question: Hello, I am 24 and I was diagnosed with epilepsy around 2 years ago, and prior to this I thought epilepsy was 1) you were born with it, and 2) it was caused due to flashing lights. My epilepsy seemingly comes out of nowhere, it is not caused by ANYTHING. (I don't know my specific weight, this is just for the subreddit rules - I'm the average weight for a UK male) Absolutely nothing seems to triggers my seizures, I have only ever had 1 seizure in public, and that was the first one I ever had. I have been clubs, I have been night clubs, flashing lights do not effect me, they just seemingly occur out of nowhere, and I was hoping someone could give me more information on this kind of thing.
47.answer:
(I’m not your doctor; this is general information only. Please keep taking whatever medication you were prescribed and keep your follow-ups with your neurologist.)

What epilepsy actually is  
A seizure happens when a group of brain cells fire in a sudden, synchronized burst. When the brain has a tendency to do this repeatedly and for no reversible reason, we call it epilepsy. That “tendency” can develop at any age; about one-half of people who develop epilepsy do so after childhood.

Causes (the “why it started”)  
About 6 in 10 people with epilepsy never get a clear structural cause on scans—this is called idiopathic or cryptogenic epilepsy. The other ~40 % have a detectable reason, for example:  
• Prior head injury, stroke, meningitis or encephalitis  
• Developmental or genetic conditions (e.g., cortical malformations)  
• Brain tumour or scar tissue  
• Auto-immune inflammation, metabolic disorders, etc.

If your MRI and other work-up were normal, you’re in the idiopathic/cryptogenic group; it doesn’t mean nothing is “there,” only that current tests don’t show it.

Triggers (things that can tip you into a seizure)  
A trigger is not the same as the cause. The brain is already “hyper-excitable”; the trigger just nudges it over the edge. Common triggers are:  
• Sleep deprivation or irregular sleep pattern  
• Physical or mental stress  
• Fevers or infections  
• Alcohol (especially the hang-over period), recreational drugs  
• Missing medication doses  
• Hormonal changes (menstruation)  
• Flashing lights / repetitive visual patterns (only ~3 % of patients; that type is called photosensitive epilepsy)

Many people—about 1 in 3—cannot find a reliable trigger at all. Their seizures feel truly “out of the blue.” That’s frustrating but not unusual.

Why night-club lights don’t bother you  
Photosensitive epilepsy usually starts in early adolescence, is more common in females, and most patients react to specific frequencies of flicker (15–25 Hz). If you don’t have that cortical hyper-responsiveness, strobe lights will be no more dangerous to you than to anyone else.

Age of onset  
Although childhood epilepsies get more public attention, there are common adult-onset epilepsies:  
• Focal epilepsy of temporal or frontal lobe origin (often idiopathic)  
• Genetic generalized epilepsy that just didn’t manifest until adulthood  
• Auto-immune epilepsies in the 20-40 age range

How to live with “untriggered” epilepsy  
1. Medication adherence: the single most effective way to reduce breakthrough seizures.  
2. Regular sleep: go to bed and get up at roughly the same time.  
3. Limit alcohol; avoid binge drinking.  
4. Keep written or app-based seizure diary—even if episodes feel random, patterns sometimes appear over months.  
5. Prevent “secondary” triggers: treat fevers promptly, manage stress, stay hydrated.  
6. Safety: shower rather than bath, cook on back burners, let flat-mates know what to do, consider a medical alert bracelet.  
7. Driving (UK): you must be seizure-free for 12 months (or 6 months for a first unprovoked seizure under specific circumstances) before resuming; DVLA forms have to be completed by your neurologist.  
8. Follow-up scans: most patients have at least one MRI and one EEG; some need prolonged EEG or repeat imaging.

Prognosis  
Roughly 70 % of people obtain good seizure control with the first or second anti-seizure medication. Of the remainder, some become candidates for surgical or device therapies (vagus-nerve stimulation, responsive neuro-stimulation, etc.). Long-term outlook is good when seizures are controlled and medication side-effects are minimal.

Reliable UK resources  
• Epilepsy Action (epilepsy.org.uk)  
• Epilepsy Society (epilepsysociety.org.uk)  
• NHS information pages

Key take-away  
Most epilepsy isn’t caused by flashing lights, and many cases begin in adulthood without an obvious precipitating event. The absence of an identifiable trigger doesn’t mean anything has been missed—it simply reflects the underlying brain tendency. Work closely with your neurologist, keep a seizure diary, look after sleep and medications, and your chances of long-term control are very good.

48.question: I am not a doctor, but I know my body and I am no fool. I also try to avoid going to the doctor unless necessary, so I try to make sure I have to go before I do. My doctors tend to mark me up to either being a hypochondriac or having drug seeking behaviour.For example: I have very severe epilepsy, and the Keppra I am on is no longer working; I am having multiple seizures in a row every month along with, almost constant myoclonic jerks in my legs. I asked my doctor to please change me from the Keppra about 6 months ago, when it first started showing signs of no longer working. Last month I had 9 focal-to-generalized seizures without becoming aware between them.In short, pharmaceutical companies tell me to ask my doctor about certain meds, but when I do, they blow me off.Bonus Question: What do you recommend for these seizures? They are almost always triggered by hormones, stress level, and being asleep.Thanks in advance!
48.answer:
I’m not your physician and can’t give you individual medical advice, but I can outline some practical ways to (1) get a clinician to take your report of worsening seizures seriously and (2) understand what treatment options are usually considered when levetiracetam (Keppra) is no longer adequate.

PART 1 – HOW TO BE HEARD

1. Document everything.  
   • Keep a seizure diary: date, time, duration, description, any warning, recovery time, possible trigger (stress, sleep loss, menstrual phase, illness, missed dose, alcohol, etc.).  
   • Bring objective proof if you can: phone videos of events, ER records, witness statements, pill-bottle refill dates that show you are adherent.  
   • List all adverse effects (e.g., mood or behavioral changes Keppra is notorious for).  

2. Make a focused agenda before the visit.  
   “Since January my monthly seizure count has gone from 0–1 to 8–10. Here is the log. I’m taking levetiracetam 1500 mg b.i.d. with perfect adherence. I would like to discuss treatment escalation or referral to an epileptologist.”

3. Use the language doctors use.  
   • “Drug-resistant epilepsy” is defined as failure of two adequately dosed, appropriately chosen antiseizure medicines. Once that definition is met, guidelines recommend referral to a comprehensive epilepsy center for evaluation of additional medications, diet therapy, neurostimulation or surgery.  
   • Say: “I meet criteria for drug-resistant epilepsy. Guidelines suggest a referral; can you arrange that?”

4. Bring a support person.  
   A family member who has witnessed seizures can corroborate your history and reduce the chance you’ll be labeled “drug-seeking.”

5. Ask for a longer or separate appointment.  
   A standard 15-minute visit isn’t enough time to tackle this; many offices can schedule a longer “medication management” slot if asked.

6. If rapport is gone, get another opinion.  
   • Self-refer to a level-3/4 epilepsy center listed at www.naec-epilepsy.org.  
   • Your insurer often allows a second neurologic opinion without a primary-care referral if you explain that seizures are uncontrolled.

PART 2 – WHAT USUALLY COMES NEXT WHEN KEPPRA FAILS

The exact choice depends on seizure type, EEG/MRI findings, comorbidities, child-bearing potential, insurance coverage and side-effect profile, but these are the tools epilepsy specialists consider:

A. Add-on or switch to another antiseizure medicine (ASM)  
   ▸ Sodium-valproate/divalproex (Depakote) – broad-spectrum, especially good for generalized and myoclonic seizures but teratogenic and can cause weight gain and tremor.  
   ▸ Lamotrigine (Lamictal) – broad-spectrum, less cognitive dulling, needs slow titration to avoid rash.  
   ▸ Topiramate (Topamax) – broad-spectrum, may help migraines and weight loss; beware cognitive fog and kidney stones.  
   ▸ Zonisamide, perampanel, clobazam, brivaracetam (similar to Keppra but sometimes works when Keppra doesn’t), lacosamide, cenobamate, etc.  
   ▸ For clearly catamenial (“hormone-triggered”) epilepsy: cyclic natural progesterone, clobazam pulses, or acetazolamide around menses.

B. Rational polytherapy  
   Seizure specialists often pair drugs with different mechanisms (e.g., sodium-channel blocker + SV2A drug + GABAergic drug) at moderate doses rather than maximizing one drug to toxic levels.

C. Non-pharmacologic options  
   ▸ Vagus-nerve stimulator (VNS)  
   ▸ Responsive neurostimulation (RNS) or deep-brain stimulation (DBS) for suitable focal epilepsies  
   ▸ Ketogenic or modified Atkins diet (works in adults too, not only children)  
   ▸ Epilepsy surgery if imaging and EEG point to a resectable focus. A video-EEG monitoring stay is needed to evaluate this.

D. Lifestyle & trigger management  
   ▸ Strict sleep hygiene (fixed bedtime, no all-nighters, treat sleep apnea).  
   ▸ Stress-mitigation: CBT, mindfulness, exercise.  
   ▸ Avoid missed doses, alcohol binges, flashing lights if photosensitive.  
   ▸ For women, track seizures against menstrual cycle; catamenial patterns can guide therapy.  

E. Acute seizure-cluster rescue plan  
   Benzodiazepine nasal spray (midazolam, diazepam) or rectal gel to stop a string of seizures before it becomes status epilepticus.

PART 3 – PUTTING IT TOGETHER FOR YOUR NEXT VISIT

1. Hand the doctor a one-page summary and seizure log.  
2. State your goal: “I want to reach zero generalized seizures or as close as possible.”  
3. Ask explicitly: “Do I now meet criteria for drug-resistant epilepsy, and if so, can you refer me to an epilepsy center?”  
4. If medication change is appropriate, ask:  
   “Which broad-spectrum ASM(s) do you think would best match my seizure type and side-effect tolerance? I’ve read about lamotrigine, valproate, brivaracetam—could we discuss pros and cons?” (Note you are not demanding a specific drug, just opening the door.)

5. Before leaving, clarify follow-up:  
   • When will the new medicine reach target dose?  
   • At what seizure count do I call, go to the ER, or use rescue medication?  
   • When will I have a referral appointment scheduled?

If your current neurologist still dismisses you after you present objective data, that itself is a reason to switch providers. Uncontrolled generalized seizures carry a real risk of injury and SUDEP (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy); most clinicians take that very seriously when it’s laid out factually.

Key resources  
• Epilepsy Foundation Helpline: 1-800-332-1000  
• National Association of Epilepsy Centers center locator: www.naec-epilepsy.org  
• Document templates for seizure diaries: www.epilepsy.com/seizure-diary

Bottom line  
You already meet the definition of “medically refractory” epilepsy if Keppra was properly dosed and another adequate trial has failed. The standard of care is medication reevaluation or referral to an epilepsy specialist. Systematic record-keeping, clear goal-setting, and, if necessary, a fresh neurologic opinion will usually get you the evidence-based treatments you deserve.

49.question: My partner (28M) used to have over 50 grand mal seizures a month after a car accident. They had their front temporal lobe removed a couple of years ago to reduce them and that seemed to help. I’ve haven’t known him long and we have only been living together for about 4 weeks. He had one grand mal a couple of weeks ago and I made sure to catch him before he fell, laid him on his side, and stayed with him until he came to. I informed his grandmother as well because he lived with her before this and I honestly was scared. Well, today he has had 1 cognitive seizure this morning and now we’re up to four grand mal seizures. His grandmother is telling me this happens sometimes but it’s seriously scaring me. He’s in pain and his family is saying not to call an ambulance because he will lose his license and I know he would hate me for that. I’ve been trying to make sure that he stays hydrated and takes his medicine in the small windows that he’s awake and coherent, but he’s being a jerk to me when he is awake, saying that I’m bothering him and he “doesn’t need any medicine”. I love this person with all my heart and want to get him help, but his family would know more about his condition than I would. I really don’t know what to do. Any advice would be appreciated
49.answer:
I’m going to be very direct, because the stakes are high.
