1. Four generalized (“grand mal”) seizures in one day is NOT routine care-at-home territory.  
2. Clustered seizures can slide into status epilepticus (continuous or repeated seizures without full recovery of consciousness). Status is a medical emergency that can cause permanent brain injury, respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias and death.  
3. A driver’s license is not worth a life. If the law in your area requires a seizure-free interval to keep a license, he will likely lose it anyway once his neurologist hears what’s happening.

When to call an ambulance (standard epilepsy guidelines)  
• Any convulsive seizure lasting ≥ 5 minutes.  
• A second seizure starts before the person is fully awake.  
• Repeated seizures in a cluster when that is NOT the person’s clear, documented baseline.  
• Breathing, color, or heart rate look abnormal at any point.  
• Serious injury, head injury, or you can’t roll him safely onto his side.  
• You just feel something is wrong and you don’t have rescue medication to stop the cluster.

Your partner is already past several of those thresholds today.

Practical steps right now

1. Call emergency services. Tell dispatch “adult with epilepsy having repeated generalized seizures today, needs evaluation.”  
2. While waiting, do standard first-aid: clear the area, protect his head, time the seizure, recovery position afterward, check for breathing.  
3. If he HAS a rescue prescription (rectal diazepam, intranasal/buccal midazolam, clonazepam wafer, etc.) give it exactly as prescribed—if he’s coherent enough to cooperate or if the formulation allows you to administer. If he’s never been given rescue medication, that is another sign his outpatient plan is inadequate; paramedics can give IV/IM benzodiazepine.

4. Gather information for the paramedics/ER:  
   • Medication list and last doses actually swallowed.  
   • Time and description of each seizure today.  
   • Any recent illness, fever, missed medication, alcohol, sleep deprivation, head trauma, stress, etc.  
   • Contact details for his neurologist/epilepsy center.

5. Expect him to be confused, irritable or combative post-ictally. That’s brain chemistry, not “being a jerk.” Keep your voice calm, lights low, don’t argue.

Dealing with family pressure

• A well-intended relative saying “this happens, don’t call” does not outrank medical reality. They may have grown so used to his seizures that they underestimate danger, or they worry about cost or the license. But clustered generalized seizures two years after a lobectomy absolutely warrant acute evaluation.

• If they challenge you, say: “I understand you’ve seen many of his seizures, but current guidelines say repeated convulsions can turn into status and kill him. I’d rather have him alive and angry than risk his life.”

Long-term actions (once today is safe)

1. Neurologist follow-up ASAP. He may need:  
   • Serum levels of his antiseizure meds (under-dosing, malabsorption, or drug interactions).  
   • Imaging or EEG to look for new foci.  
   • Adjustment or addition of medication, rescue prescription, or VNS/RNS discussion.  
   • A written Seizure Action Plan you can keep on the fridge.

2. Set up a rescue-med kit at home/work/car. Everyone who might be alone with him (including you, roommates, coworkers) should know how and when to use it.

3. Review seizure triggers: missed doses, sleep debt, heavy alcohol or stimulants, illness, flashing lights, etc.

4. Driving: Most U.S. states (and many other countries) require 3–12 seizure-free months to drive. Doctors, not partners, generally report. If he’s having breakthrough events, the neurologist will document it. Hiding a cluster at home only delays the inevitable and puts him, passengers and strangers at risk if he drives.

5. Counseling/Support. Post-lobectomy patients can have mood changes, irritability, executive-function problems. A neuropsychologist or counselor can help both of you adapt. Consider an epilepsy support group so you’re not the only caregiver voice arguing with family habits.

What to tell your partner later

“I called 911 because I love you. Seizures can kill in minutes. We can work on getting your license back and keeping your independence, but we can’t do that if you’re not here.”

Bottom line: You are not overreacting. Four convulsive seizures in a day is an emergency. Call.

50.question: gender (male) age (17) can anxiety or stress lead to epilepsy and seizures without being prone to one all your life ?
50.answer:
Short answer  
• Ordinary anxiety or day-to-day psychological stress does not, by itself, “give you” epilepsy.  
• Stress can, however, do three different things:
  1. Trigger a seizure in someone who already has a biologic seizure tendency.  
  2. Produce events that resemble seizures (psychogenic non-epileptic seizures, panic attacks, syncope) even though no epileptic activity is occurring in the brain.  
  3. Worsen other conditions (sleep loss, substance use, etc.) that in turn lower the seizure threshold.

Why stress usually does not CREATE epilepsy  
Epilepsy means you have a continuing tendency to have unprovoked seizures caused by abnormal electrical activity in the cerebral cortex. Most epilepsy begins because of one (or more) of these:
• Genetic differences that make certain brain networks hyper-excitable.  
• A structural change (injury, stroke, tumor, scar tissue, malformation).  
• A metabolic or immune problem affecting the brain.  

Psychological stress can raise blood pressure, release cortisol, disturb sleep, and change breathing patterns, but it does not normally produce the kind of permanent structural or genetic change that actually generates an epileptic focus. Therefore, in someone who has never had seizures and has no underlying lesion, ordinary stress almost never starts epilepsy.

When stress CAN help precipitate a seizure  
If a person already has epilepsy, stress can be a “precipitating factor.” Mechanisms include:
• Sleep deprivation (frequently stress-related).  
• Hyperventilation (seen during anxiety attacks) which alters blood CO₂ and neuronal excitability.  
• Hormonal effects of cortisol and adrenaline.  

These influences make it easier for an existing seizure focus to “fire,” but they are not primary causes of the focus itself.

Events that mimic epilepsy but are driven by stress  
1. Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (PNES, sometimes called dissociative or functional seizures)  
   – Episodes can include shaking, unresponsiveness, or staring.  
   – No abnormal electrical discharges appear on EEG during the event.  
   – Often linked to psychological trauma, anxiety, or other mental-health issues.  
   – Managed with psychotherapy rather than antiepileptic drugs.

2. Panic attacks & hyperventilation  
   – Can cause trembling, numbness, visual changes, and brief loss of consciousness (fainting), sometimes with brief convulsive movements (convulsive syncope).

3. Vasovagal syncope (fainting)  
   – Anxiety and pain may activate a vagal reflex → drop in blood pressure → brief loss of consciousness and jerking.

Could chronic severe stress ever raise long-term epilepsy risk?  
Animal studies show that sustained high-stress hormone levels can alter neuronal networks, and a few human studies hint that extreme, chronic stress (combat, torture, severe abuse) might raise seizure risk by promoting inflammation or sleep debt. Those cases are very rare; for the vast majority of people stress alone is not enough to generate epilepsy.

What you should do if you experience spells or are worried  
• Keep a diary: note date, time, what you were doing, sleep the night before, caffeine/energy drinks, medications, substance use.  
• See a physician promptly if you experience:  
  – Loss of consciousness or awareness.  
  – Full-body shaking, tongue-biting, or incontinence.  
  – Confusion afterward that lasts more than a minute.  
  – Any injury during an episode.  
  – Family history of seizures or neurologic disorders.  
• Your doctor may order an EEG, MRI, or blood tests to distinguish epileptic from non-epileptic events.  
• Regardless of cause, good seizure-prevention habits help:  
  – 7–9 h of consistent sleep.  
  – Regular meals and hydration.  
  – Limited caffeine and no recreational drugs.  
  – Stress-management skills (exercise, relaxation breathing, therapy).

Bottom line  
At 17, you do not need to fear that typical anxiety or exam stress will suddenly make you epileptic. Stress can provoke seizures only in people who already have an underlying predisposition, and it can produce seizure-like episodes (PNES, fainting) that look dramatic but are not epilepsy. If you ever have an unexplained spell, get it evaluated—you want a clear diagnosis and peace of mind.

51.question: My daughter 13(F).She is 5'6", 120 pounds, white--she's lost 5 pounds in the past 3-4 months and is already quite skinny. Today, she had multiple instances of dizziness/lightheadedness and fell down from it.She has an extensive medical history, but her current diagnoses are: Epilepsy (since she was 2, more specifically Abnormal Doose Syndrome) Neurogenic Bladder & Bowel Disorder (not Dysfunctional Elimination Syndrome) Raynauds ADHD Sensory Processing Disorder Neuropathy Temperature Regulation Issues Anhidrosis Generalized Anxiety Insomnia (clinically diagnosed) Additional information on Neurogenic Bladder & Bowel Disorder:She can void on her own, but her bladder is 2x larger than it should be and she was catheterized for 4 years before she figured out how to void on her own. Metabolic Panel (14)Celiac Test—Negative Sed Rate, WestergrenCMP14+eGFRTSH+Free T4Lipid PanelVitamin D, 25-Hydroxy (this was slightly low) t-Transglutaminase (tTG) IgAt-Transglutaminase (tTG) IgGImmunoglobulin A, Qn, SerumC-Reactive Protein, QuantH. Pylori Test—Negative I know this is a lot of info, but I am open to hearing any ideas. She's in constant pain, it never goes away, just goes from at least a 4 up to 9-10 on the pain scale. 51.answer:
I am sorry your daughter is going through this.  With the information you have provided it is impossible to give a single “answer”, but there are several conditions – some common, some uncommon – that still need to be actively ruled-out.  Below is a framework you can take to her paediatrician / gastro-intestinal (GI) and neurology teams to speed things up and to make sure nothing is missed.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
1.  FIRST  ‑  RED-FLAG ISSUES THAT NEED URGENT ASSESSMENT
-----------------------------------------------------------------
•  Unrelenting pain (4–10/10) now limiting oral intake  
•  5-lb weight loss in three months in a thin 13-year-old  
•  Dizziness / near-syncope with falls  
•  Long drug list that can mask or worsen GI symptoms (Linzess, bisacodyl, Mg-citrate etc.)  

Because of these, she should be seen quickly (days, not weeks) by her primary doctor or, if pain/dizziness worsen, in an Emergency Department attached to a children’s hospital.  At minimum she needs:

  – Orthostatic vitals, full abdominal examination  
  – Point-of-care urinalysis (make sure no UTI)  
  – A plain abdominal film (look for retained stool, dilated loops, volvulus, free air)  
  – Basic chemistries (looking for electrolyte losses from the cathartics/dehydration)  

-----------------------------------------------------------------
2.  MOST LIKELY “MECHANICAL / ORGANIC” CAUSES STILL ON THE TABLE
-----------------------------------------------------------------
A.  Massive stool load / intermittent colonic or sigmoid volvulus  
     • A redundant megacolon can twist intermittently and give sharp, sudden pain that
       becomes generalized as the twist releases.  
     • Plain film ± contrast enema will demonstrate this.  A surgeon or motility
       specialist may still need to consider a carefully planned colonic resection
       even though the earlier team was worried about scar tissue.

B.  Chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction (CIPO) / severe dysmotility  
     • Fits with her known visceral neuropathy (neurogenic bladder & bowel,
       anhidrosis, Raynaud).  
     • Pain typically worsens right after meals and with movement because gas and
       food cannot be propelled forward.  
     • Abdominal x-ray shows mixed small- and large-bowel dilation; gastric
       emptying study and antro-duodenal manometry are diagnostic.

C.  Median arcuate ligament syndrome (MALS) – compression of the celiac artery  
     • Classic triad: thin adolescent girl, sharp epigastric pain after eating or with
       exercise, weight loss.  
     • Doppler ultrasound of the celiac artery with inspiration/expiration or a CT/MR
       angiogram confirms diagnosis.

D.  Superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMAS) – duodenal compression between the
     aorta and SMA  
     • Presents with early satiety, “food sits like a rock”, post-prandial pain,
       occasional bilious vomiting.  
     • Needs an upper GI series or CT angiogram.

E.  Gall-bladder, pancreas, gastric or esophageal disease  
     • Ultrasound of liver/biliary tree, amylase/lipase, and an upper endoscopy are
       still warranted even though routine blood work is unremarkable.  
     • The “lump in throat” may be esophageal dysmotility, reflux or EoE.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
3.  FUNCTIONAL / NEUROGIC CONTRIBUTIONS THAT MAY BE ADDING LAYERS
-----------------------------------------------------------------
•  Visceral hyperalgesia – the gut nerves fire at lower thresholds in children with
   epilepsy, autonomic neuropathy or anxiety.  
•  Dysautonomia / POTS  – explains Raynaud, temperature issues, light-headedness; GI
   tract is often involved (gastroparesis, pseudo-obstruction).  
•  Medication-related cramping – Linzess, bisacodyl and Mg-citrate can themselves
   trigger colicky pain, dehydration and orthostasis.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
4.  WORK-UP TO REQUEST FROM A PEDIATRIC GASTROENTEROLOGIST
-----------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Imaging  
    • Supine & upright abdominal X-ray (baseline stool burden, gas pattern)  
    • Abdominal/pelvic ultrasound (gall-bladder, kidneys, ovaries)  
    • MR or CT enterography ± CT angiogram (rule out MALS, SMAS, volvulus,
      bowel wall thickening, pancreatitis, IBD)  
2.  Endoscopy  
    • EGD with biopsies (peptic disease, EoE, H. pylori double-check, celiac)  
    • Colonoscopy only if alarming features or calprotectin elevated  
3.  Motility / functional tests  
    • Gastric emptying study  
    • Antro-duodenal or whole-gut manometry (if pseudo-obstruction suspected)  
4.  Laboratory additions  
    • Stool calprotectin, fecal occult blood, alpha-1-antitrypsin  
    • Lipase, amylase, bilirubin, GGT, fasting and post-prandial lactate  
    • Autoantibodies if small-fiber / autonomic neuropathy suspected (AChR-ganglionic,
      GAD65, ANA, ENA)  

-----------------------------------------------------------------
5.  THINGS YOU CAN DO WHILE WAITING
-----------------------------------------------------------------
•  Keep a detailed pain / food / stool / activity diary (timing is diagnostic).  
•  Ensure a strictly daily stool output – you may need to switch from stimulant
   laxatives (bisacodyl) to osmotic agents (high-dose PEG 3350) or a nightly tap-water
   / saline enema after discussion with GI; stimulant cramps can mimic her pain.  
•  Hydration, salt supplementation, and compression socks can reduce the dizziness
   if dysautonomia is present.  
•  Very small, low-fat, low-residue meals every 2–3 hours rather than large meals.  
•  Discuss with neurology whether Lamictal / Keppra levels are therapeutic (both can
   give GI symptoms at high serum concentrations).  
•  Ask about a temporary course of a neuromodulator (low-dose amitriptyline or
   gabapentin) for visceral pain once mechanical causes are excluded.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
6.  WHEN TO GO TO THE ER
-----------------------------------------------------------------
•  Bloody stool or emesis  
•  Projectile or bilious vomiting  
•  Pain suddenly different / worse or with rigid abdomen  
•  Persistent dizziness or fainting, reduced urine output, inability to take fluids

-----------------------------------------------------------------
BOTTOM LINE
Your daughter’s normal basic labs are reassuring, but they do not exclude
obstructive or vascular problems, severe dysmotility or autonomic dysfunction,
all of which fit her history and current symptoms.  An expedited referral to a
paediatric gastro-intestinal motility centre (or at least imaging and endoscopy
through a general paediatric GI service) is warranted, with close coordination
between GI, neurology and, if necessary, paediatric surgery.  Until then,
maintaining hydration, daily stool output and documenting symptom patterns will
both help her comfort and provide valuable data for the specialists.

52.question: Not sure if this is allowed- (20F/medical MJ patient/white) I've been trying to get this figured out for YEARS now, no one takes me seriously. Does anyone know about temporal lobe epilepsy? For years I've had severe deja vu (I can literally tell what's going to happen before it does) that is accompanied by severe nausea and head tingling/pressure. The pressure is in the occipital lobe and temples, and it never lasts longer than 10 minutes. It'll go on multiple times a day for a week, then disappear for months. I keep logs of what happens during, before and after and how long they last JUST in case. It's not that bad but it really makes me feel like pure shit and like I'm going to die when it happens
52.answer:
I can’t diagnose you on-line, but I can tell you how what you’re describing fits (or doesn’t fit) with temporal-lobe epilepsy, what else can imitate it, and how to get someone to take it seriously.

1.  Does this sound like focal (temporal-lobe) seizures?  
   •  Classic “aura.”  Many people with temporal-lobe epilepsy have very brief stereotyped episodes that begin with an odd feeling in the stomach or chest, sudden déjà vu/jamais vu, a metallic or burnt-rubber smell, or a wave of fear.  
   •  Autonomic symptoms.  Nausea, sweating, light-headedness, and a sensation of pressure in the head or ears are common because the temporal lobe is tied into autonomic control centers.  
   •  Duration.  Focal aware seizures typically last 10–90 seconds; occasionally a few minutes. What you describe (“never longer than 10 minutes, several a day for a week, then none for months”) is within the range neurologists hear, although 10 minutes is on the long side.  
   •  Recovery.  Most people feel washed out or sleepy for a minute or two but are otherwise normal between events—again similar to your log.  
   •  Stereotyped.  Doctors put a lot of weight on whether every spell is almost identical. If yours are, that increases the chance they’re seizures.

2.  What points don’t quite fit?  
   •  Occipital pressure.  Temporal seizures can “spread” and give scalp tingling, but occipital pain/pressure is more typical of migraine aura.  
   •  Ten-minute episodes are longer than the average focal seizure; neurologists call anything >5 min “prolonged.”  
   •  Predicting exactly what will happen isn’t classic; most patients describe a powerful “already lived this” feeling rather than true foreknowledge.  
   •  Cluster-then-remission can be seen in seizures, but it’s also common in migraines and panic attacks.

3.  Other common look-alikes your doctor should think about.  
   •  Migraine aura (especially “Alice-in-Wonderland” or basilar migraines).  
   •  Panic attacks/dysautonomic storms.  
   •  Drug effects—including cannabis. THC can provoke déjà vu, derealization, nausea, and surges of anxiety that mimic temporal seizures.  
   •  Occipital lobe seizures (rarer, but visual phenomena—flashes, shapes—are usual, which you don’t mention).  
   •  Cardiac arrhythmias and presyncope (usually there’s near-blackout or palpitations).  
   •  Certain endocrine swings (hypoglycaemia, pheochromocytoma) or POTS.

4.  How a neurologist would work this up.  
   •  Detailed history—including the log you’re already keeping (great job; bring it).  
   •  Routine EEG. A normal EEG does NOT rule out epilepsy (only ~40 % of temporal-lobe patients show abnormalities on the first study).  
   •  MRI brain with epilepsy protocol to look for mesial temporal sclerosis, tumors, cortical malformations.  
   •  If routine EEG & MRI are unrevealing but suspicion stays high: prolonged video-EEG (24 h up to several days) or ambulatory EEG you wear at home.  
   •  Consider migraine diary, tilt-table test, cardiac monitor if history suggests.

5.  How to get taken seriously.  
   •  Spell out the disability: how often it happens, that you have to stop what you’re doing, that you’re nauseated, can’t drive, etc.  
   •  Use the words “recurrent brief episodes of altered awareness” and “possible focal seizures”; those phrases put you in the neurologist’s lane.  
   •  Bring a witness (family/friend) who’s seen an episode, or film one on your phone if it’s safe.  
   •  Ask directly for “an EEG and an MRI to rule out seizures.” If a primary doctor refuses, request referral to an epilepsy clinic; most large cities have one.  
   •  Call your insurance yourself and ask which neurologists are covered; self-refer if your plan allows.  
   •  Epilepsy Foundation help-line (1-800-332-1000 in the U.S.) can tell you the nearest accredited center.

6.  Things you can do right now.  
   •  Keep the detailed log you’re already maintaining (date, time, length, what you were doing, sleep the night before, food, cannabis/alcohol, stress, hormonal cycle).  
   •  Note any triggers: lack of sleep, flashing lights, missed meals, specific cannabis strains, etc.—and try to eliminate them.  
   •  Ensure adequate sleep and regular meals; both missing sleep and low blood sugar lower the seizure threshold.  
   •  Consider pausing recreational cannabis (even though you’re a medical patient) long enough to see whether the clusters stop; this will be one of the first questions a neurologist asks.  
   •  Safety: Don’t swim alone, climb, or drive until you know these aren’t seizures. Even if you’ve never blacked out, some focal seizures can generalize without warning.

7.  When it’s an emergency.  
   •  Any single episode that lasts >5 min continuously.  
   •  A run of back-to-back events with no full recovery between them for >30 min.  
   •  Added loss of consciousness, full-body shaking, or breathing difficulty.  
   •  New neurologic deficits (vision loss, weakness, slurred speech).  
   •  Injury or severe vomiting/dehydration.  
   In those situations call 911 or go to the ED.

Bottom line: What you describe does sound very much like stereotyped focal (probably temporal-lobe) seizures, but migraine aura and a few other conditions remain possible. An EEG and brain MRI are standard first steps; if those are inconclusive, prolonged video-EEG monitoring is the gold standard. Keep your logs, insist on a neurology referral, and take interim safety precautions. You don’t have to “wait till it gets worse” to be taken seriously.

53.question: I (29F) have been having extremely harsh symptoms lately and am currently undergoing a lot of testing while my doctors try to figure out what is happening. I have been to several doctors and they have different opinions on what’s going on. Because the tests are all coming back inconclusive, I’m hoping this sub can help me.History:I’ve been on antidepressants for over 8 years, my current combination (Wellbutrin & Cymbalta) for over two years without any noticeable side effects. I don’t smoke or do drugs other than the occasional edible. I’m diagnosed with chronic depression and IBS. The consumption of edibles (I’ve tried HHC and THC, to relax and take away pain) seems to worsen my symptoms, even at low doses.Symptoms:Seizures - Started about a month ago, have had maybe one/two per week since. Whether or not they are seizures is debated as my doctors don’t all agree what I have are seizures. One of them called it chorea, another called it focal aware seizures and my psychiatrist says it could be tardive dyskinesia. (I have had a tardive dyskinesia episode once as a reaction to metaclopramide and it didn’t feel at all like this. The uncontrollable movements were restricted to my face and I was perfectly fine mentally.) I have uncontrollable movements all over my body but I’m conscious throughout. The episodes last anywhere from 2 minutes to a half hour. My body feels rigid and the longer it goes on the more I feel like my mind is shattered. I can feel my thought process is impaired during an episode but I’m not unresponsive and can communicate with a lot of effort.Extreme fatigue - I have previously been to doctors because of this (about a year ago). I can sleep for 24 hours straight if no one wakes me up. Doctors suspected narcolepsy but I never actually did the tests because they were too expensive. It was chalked up to my depression.Painful joints - the pain shifts places but the most affected areas are my right hip joint and my hands.Mouth sores - they’re painful and take around a week to heal.Dry chapped lips - this has been happening since I remember, my lips are always dry to the point of pain. For example, if I don’t put on a thick layer of chapstick before bed, I wake up with my lips cracked and bleeding.Low fevers the week before my period - has been going on for about a year. Can’t find an underlying reason for this.Hair loss - something I’ve chalked up to my depression over the years but I now have places where my hair density is really low.Diagnosis - No idea. Rheumatologist says it might be lupus, told me to do blood work the week before my period to coincide with my symptoms worsening.Tests done:EEG - no epileptic activityBrain CT - normalBlood tests all normal, including rheumatoid factor.Haven’t yet done ANA, dsDNA, C3, C4 and a couple other things.Thank you in advance!
53.answer:
I can’t examine you and I can’t give you a diagnosis over the internet, but I can try to put the picture together and suggest the main problems your doctors will usually try to rule-in or rule-out when they see the combination you describe.

1. Neuro-psychiatric events (seizure-like / choreiform movements, “mind feels shattered”, preserved awareness).
2. Marked fatigue/somnolence.
3. Migratory arthralgia (hip, hands).
4. Recurrent painful oral ulcers and chronic cheilitis.
5. Low-grade peri-menstrual fevers.
6. Patchy alopecia.
7. Only non-specific tests performed so far (EEG, CT, routine bloods) – all unrevealing.

Putting those pieces together the three broad categories your doctors will usually think about are:

A. Systemic autoimmune disease.  
   – Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is at the very top of that list because it can give EVERY symptom you mention: neuro-psychiatric SLE (focal aware seizures, chorea), profound fatigue, migratory joint pain, aphthous ulcers, low-grade fevers that often flare pre-menstrually, inflammatory alopecia and sicca-type lip changes.  
   – Sjögren’s syndrome can overlap with lupus and give the lip dryness, ulcers, arthralgia and fatigue; it also produces anti-Ro/La antibodies that can cause chorea.  
   – Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (which can accompany lupus or exist alone) can also present with focal seizures/chorea and would be checked at the same time (anticardiolipin, β2-glycoprotein I, lupus anticoagulant).  
   – Behçet’s disease (recurrent oral ulcers + joint pain + CNS involvement) is another, although fevers and hair loss are less prominent and genital ulcers are usually present.  
   – Mixed connective-tissue disease (anti-RNP-positive) and undifferentiated autoimmune rheumatic disease would be considered if the classic antibody patterns for lupus are absent.

   Core tests that still haven’t been done (you list them yourself) and really should be obtained before the picture can be cleared up:  
        • ANA by immunofluorescence with titer and pattern.  
        • Anti-dsDNA (high specificity for lupus).  
        • ENA panel: anti-Sm, anti-RNP, anti-Ro (SSA), anti-La (SSB).  
        • C3 and C4 complements (often low in active lupus).  
        • Antiphospholipid panel (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin IgG/IgM, β2-GP1 IgG/IgM).  
        • ESR/CRP, CBC with diff (looking for leukopenia/lymphopenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia).  
        • Comprehensive metabolic profile, spot urine protein/creatinine ratio and urinalysis (silent kidney involvement is common in lupus).  

   MRI brain with contrast and, if needed, a lumbar puncture for autoimmune encephalitis antibodies are the usual next neuro steps when CT and routine EEG are non-diagnostic but events continue.

B. Endocrine / metabolic / nutritional problems that can mimic or coexist with A.  
   – Hypothyroidism (fatigue, arthralgia, hair loss).  
   – Adrenal insufficiency (hyperpigmentation? weight loss? but can give fatigue and low-grade fevers).  
   – Iron-deficiency or ferritin < 30 µg/L, B12 or folate deficiency, vitamin D deficiency.  
   – Wilson’s disease (low ceruloplasmin, Kayser-Fleischer rings) can produce chorea, psychiatric change and hepatic dysfunction in a 29-year-old but does NOT explain ulcers/fevers so is lower yield; still, a single ceruloplasmin test is cheap.  
   – Chronic infections (HIV, hepatitis, syphilis, Lyme) are routinely screened because they can give systemic and neuro manifestations.

C. Medication / functional / toxic causes.  
   – Bupropion (Wellbutrin) is well known to lower the seizure threshold, especially if the daily dose is ≥300 mg, if there is concomitant THC, alcohol withdrawal, electrolyte disturbance or sleep deprivation. It doesn’t explain the ulcers, fevers or alopecia, but it can be the trigger for the actual motor events.  
   – Duloxetine rarely, but occasionally, causes dyskinesias; genuine tardive dyskinesia is much more common with antipsychotics.  
   – Cannabis (including HHC/THC edibles) can precipitate dyskinesia, worsen bupropion-related seizures, cause orthostatic hypotension and exacerbate fatigue.  
   – Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (functional neurological disorder) are always considered when EEG is negative, but the presence of systemic auto-immune clues means physicians usually exclude organic causes first.

What you can do now / Discussion points for the next appointment

1. Finish the basic autoimmune work-up (ANA panel, complements, antiphospholipid antibodies, ESR/CRP, CBC, metabolic panel, urinalysis). Those tests are inexpensive compared with a sleep study and are indispensable if lupus is on the table.

2. Brain MRI with and without contrast. If it is clean but events persist, inpatient video-EEG monitoring or lumbar puncture for autoimmune/paraneoplastic antibody panel is the standard path.

3. Basic endocrine/nutritional screen: TSH, free T4, morning cortisol, ferritin, iron studies, B12, folate, vitamin D, ceruloplasmin, HIV/syphilis serology. Most are one blood draw.

4. Keep a detailed symptom diary: date/time of events, length, triggers (stress, missed meals, sleep deprivation, THC use, menstruation), associated fever, rash, joint pains, new ulcers, medications taken that day. Patterns often jump out that aren’t obvious in the office visit.

5. Discuss medication risks explicitly with your prescriber: exact daily dose of bupropion, any missed doses, alcohol use, and the clear observation that THC worsens your episodes. If bupropion is ≥300 mg/day or if there is concern it is tipping you into seizures, your psychiatrist may elect to taper/stop it temporarily while the neurologic work-up proceeds.

6. Sun exposure/photosensitivity: many patients with subclinical lupus notice their lips blister/crack and disease flares after ultraviolet exposure. If that is true for you, mention it. Simple sun block and protective lip balm can sometimes reduce mucosal flares.

7. Sleep study (MSLT) is certainly reasonable if autoimmune and endocrine disease are excluded and hypersomnolence persists, but most physicians would first finish the less costly blood/serology imaging above.

When to seek urgent help

• Any event that progresses to loss of consciousness longer than a minute, respiratory compromise, or status epilepticus (>5 min continuous convulsion).  
• Persistent temperature >38.5 °C (101.3 °F), new rash or rapid joint swelling (possible infection or vasculitis).  
• Sudden vision change, speech difficulty, unilateral weakness—think stroke/TIA, especially if antiphospholipid antibodies are ultimately positive.

Key take-away

A single unifying diagnosis is possible and lupus (± Sjögren / antiphospholipid) is the prime suspect; the missing ANA/dsDNA/complement/APS labs and a contrast MRI are the next most useful tests. Meanwhile, watch the bupropion + THC combination, document all events carefully, and keep pushing for that complete autoimmune panel—an inconclusive work-up so far doesn’t mean the answer isn’t there, it just means the essential tests haven’t been done yet.

54.question: I’m 25 with seizures, been seizure free for about 5 years, I’m on 200mg twice a day medication is lamotrigne, I’m a heavy smoker I’m a female I weigh 139lbs I’m 5’6. Can I take shrooms?
54.answer:
I am not your personal clinician, and what follows is general educational information only.  Do not start, stop or change any treatment (including recreational drug use) without first talking with your own neurologist or other licensed prescriber.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Seizure-related considerations
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Data are sparse, but classic psychedelics (psilocybin, LSD, DMT) are generally believed to lower seizure threshold slightly in susceptible people.  Case reports of seizures during or shortly after psilocybin exist, although they are rare.  
•  Triggers that often accompany a psychedelic session—sleep deprivation, flashing lights, loud music, stimulant use, dehydration, anxiety—can themselves precipitate seizures even if the drug does not.  
•  You have been seizure-free for five years on lamotrigine 200 mg twice daily.  That’s encouraging, yet it does not eliminate risk.  Most neurologists still advise against hallucinogens in anyone with an epilepsy history.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Drug–drug and drug–disease interactions
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Lamotrigine
•  Pharmacokinetic interaction: none known with psilocybin (psilocybin is rapidly de-phosphorylated to psilocin, then cleared mainly by hepatic glucuronidation; it does not significantly induce or inhibit UGT enzymes that handle lamotrigine).  
•  Pharmacodynamic interaction: lamotrigine has mild 5-HT₃ antagonism and may blunt the psychedelic experience, but this does not appear to make it safer.  
•  Net effect: no direct interaction that increases lamotrigine toxicity, but lamotrigine does not “protect” you from a seizure caused by the drug or its setting.

Nicotine / heavy smoking
•  Polycyclic hydrocarbons in smoke induce CYP1A2 and UGT enzymes and may lower lamotrigine plasma levels 10–20 %.  If you already take the maximal or near-maximal lamotrigine dose for your body weight, this could leave you with less seizure protection than you think.  
•  Stimulant effects of nicotine can add sympathetic activation to the psychedelic, increasing heart rate and anxiety.

Other meds / health factors
•  Any antidepressants, stimulants, hormonal contraceptives, alcohol, or cannabis can further complicate risk.  (SSRIs blunt trip intensity; bupropion and stimulants can lower seizure threshold.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Legal and practical issues
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  In most jurisdictions psilocybin remains a Schedule I / controlled substance.  Possession can carry legal penalties.  
•  Products sold on the unregulated market vary wildly in psilocybin content; misidentification of mushrooms is common.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Harm-reduction checklist (if you decide to proceed despite risk)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Again, speak with your neurologist first.  If you still intend to use psilocybin:  
1.  Dose: start very low (e.g., 0.5–1 g dried Psilocybe cubensis, roughly 5–10 mg psilocybin) and wait at least 2 hours before considering more.  
2.  Set & setting: quiet, familiar room; no flashing lights; calm music; avoid crowded festivals or clubs.  
3.  Sitter: have a sober, trusted person present who knows basic seizure first aid and when to call EMS.  
4.  Rest: get a full night’s sleep before the session; plan no all-nighters.  
5.  Hydration & meals: eat normally, stay hydrated, do not fast aggressively.  
6.  Avoid other substances: no alcohol, stimulants, MDMA, DXM, synthetic cannabinoids.  Limit or skip nicotine during the peak.  
7.  Medical supplies: keep your rescue medication (e.g., rectal diazepam or intranasal midazolam, if prescribed) and your phone within reach.  
8.  Post-trip: allow a full night’s sleep afterward.  Maintain lamotrigine on schedule; missing doses post-trip is a known seizure trigger.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Red-flag symptoms that require immediate medical help
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Any generalized convulsion lasting >5 minutes or two seizures without full recovery between them.  
•  Persistent confusion >2 hours past expected trip end.  
•  Severe, crushing headache (possible intracranial event).  
•  Heart rate >130 bpm at rest with chest pain, or temperature >39 °C (102 °F).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Bottom line
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Because you have an epilepsy history, any serotonergic hallucinogen carries a non-zero seizure risk even after five seizure-free years on lamotrigine.  
•  There is no strong evidence that lamotrigine “neutralizes” this risk.  
•  Most neurologists would advise against it; the safest choice is to abstain.  
•  If you choose to proceed, strict harm-reduction measures and an honest discussion with your epilepsy specialist are essential.

Please share this information with your own clinician and make a decision together.

55.question: I am currently a 27yo (white) male (6ft, 150lb) and starting back when I was early 26yo, I started developing epilepsy—frequent episodes of focal-aware seizures. Around that time, I also experienced a few separate occasions of non-trauma-induced, spontaneous compression fractures that would occur in my sleep (I’d wake up with extreme back pain and unable to move, get out of bed, or walk for awhile).I was subsequently discovered to have numerous fresh compression fractures along my thoracic vertebrae (seven thoracic vertebrae fractured to various degrees—some significantly: 50-70% LOH) along with having low bone density that my doctors described as “osteoporosis” (Z-score -2.4).Since then, over the last year and a half, I have seen many specialists (primary care doctors, neurologist, spine doctors, interventional radiology, and endocrinologist) and have undergone every test possible to investigate why I have low bone density and fragility fractures; but overall, my labs and results come back mostly normal, and no known cause has yet been found.I have a history of being overall healthy, well nourished, and a long-time jogger and physically active. I never smoked or done recreational drugs, and I very rarely drink alcohol or soda. Only medication I have ever been on prior is Lexapro for depression, which I have been taking for past five years. I don’t have any family history of bad bones or epilepsy.Your thoughts?
55.answer:
What you describe – multiple atraumatic vertebral compression fractures in a 26-year-old man with a DXA Z-score of –2.4 – is exceedingly uncommon and, by definition, “secondary osteoporosis” until a cause is proved otherwise.  
Below is the framework most metabolic-bone specialists use to work-up and think about a case such as yours, why certain problems are still worth ruling out even when many initial tests are “normal,” and what the next practical steps usually look like.

──────────────────────────────────
1.  Could the epilepsy and the bone problem be parts of the same disease?
──────────────────────────────────
A few single-gene or systemic disorders present with BOTH seizures and low bone mass:

•  Celiac disease / gluten-sensitive enteropathy (malabsorption → osteoporosis; cortical/subcortical calcifications → focal epilepsy).  
•  Mitochondrial disorders (e.g. MELAS).  
•  Hypophosphatasia (ALPL gene, low serum alkaline phosphatase, stress fractures & seizures).  
•  Menkes disease, Wilson disease or other copper disorders.  
•  Homocystinuria (CBS deficiency).  
•  COL1A1/2, WNT1, LRP5 or PLS3 variants (forms of familial early-onset osteoporosis; some pedigrees have epilepsy).  

Because of these overlaps, a completely “clean” neurological imaging study does not entirely exclude a unifying diagnosis.

──────────────────────────────────
2.  Secondary osteoporosis in young men – differential diagnosis & key tests
──────────────────────────────────
Even if the epilepsy turns out to be unrelated, every male under ~50 with fragility fractures should be screened for the following (an asterisk * marks items that are frequently missed the first time around):

 A.  Nutritional / malabsorption
     •  25-OH vitamin D, calcium, phosphorus, PTH  
     •  *Celiac serology (tTG-IgA + total IgA; if IgA-deficient, IgG-based test)  
     •  Stool fat, pancreatic elastase or fecal calprotectin if chronic diarrhea/IBD suspected  

 B.  Endocrine
     •  Total testosterone (+LH, FSH) – early-morning sample  
     •  TSH, free T4  
     •  Prolactin (can suppress gonadal axis)  
     •  *1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression or late-night salivary cortisol for occult Cushing’s  
     •  *IGF-1 (acromegaly can cause both osteoporosis and seizures)  
     •  *Serum insulin-like peptide FGF-23 & phosphate if fasting PO4 is low (tumour-induced osteomalacia / hypophosphataemic syndromes)  

 C.  Renal / acid–base
     •  Creatinine, eGFR  
     •  *Serum bicarbonate and urine pH (distal RTA)  
     •  24-h urine calcium, phosphate, sodium, creatinine  

 D.  Hematologic / oncologic
     •  CBC, ESR, CRP  
     •  SPEP/UPEP with free light chains (myeloma is rare at 27 y but easy to rule out)  
     •  Serum tryptase if mastocytosis suspected  

 E.  Bone turnover and mineralization markers
     •  ALP (total and, if possible, bone-specific)  
     •  Osteocalcin, PINP, CTX  

 F.  Genetic tests – target when there is:
     •  Normal routine work-up, fractures before age 40, and/or family members with low BMD  
     •  Whole-exome “bone panel” (COL1A1/A2, LRP5, WNT1, PLS3, ALPL, etc.) obtainable through commercial labs or research protocols  

 G.  Medication history
     •  Glucocorticoids (even brief high-dose bursts); anti-androgens; PPIs; anticonvulsants that induce CYP-450 (phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital, topiramate); methotrexate; GnRH analogues.  
     •  SSRIs (including Lexapro) – relative-risk of fracture ≈1.3–1.7, but alone they almost never cause seven fresh vertebral fractures.  

──────────────────────────────────
3.  “Everything was normal” – what is commonly missed?
──────────────────────────────────
•  Vitamin D: A level of 20–25 ng/mL is still suboptimal if fragility fractures are present; aim >30–40 ng/mL.  
•  Testosterone: many labs flag “>250 ng/dL” as normal; bone health requires mid-normal range for age (≈500–900 ng/dL).  
•  Cushing’s: a single cortisol can be normal; use a screening test designed for subtle hypercortisolism.  
•  Celiac disease: total IgA deficiency (~1 % of population) makes the common IgA-tTG test falsely negative.  
•  Phosphate: low-normal values (2.5–3.0 mg/dL) are actually abnormal in a 27-year-old male and may point to phosphaturic disorders.  

──────────────────────────────────
4.  Management while the search continues
──────────────────────────────────
1.  Calcium intake 1,200 mg elemental/day (diet + supplements).  
2.  Vitamin D 2,000 IU/day (or more to reach >30 ng/mL).  
3.  Weight-bearing exercise once cleared by spine specialist; avoid heavy axial loading until fractures consolidated.  
4.  Assess need for bone-active drugs: 
    •  In men <50 with multiple vertebral fractures most experts give bisphosphonates or, if turnover is very low, teriparatide or abaloparatide.  
    •  Off-label but endorsed by Endocrine Society when fractures are occurring.  
5.  If kyphosis or pain persists, percutaneous vertebral augmentation (kypho-/vertebroplasty) can be useful, but only after metabolic issues addressed.  
6.  Fall and seizure-injury precautions (foam floor mats near bed, rigid back brace at night until seizure control achieved).  

──────────────────────────────────
5.  Putting it together – a reasonable next step plan
──────────────────────────────────
•  Ask your endocrinologist whether the bolded items above have truly been done; if not, return for a dedicated “secondary osteoporosis” lab panel.  
•  Collect all prior imaging and have them reviewed by a metabolic-bone centre; consider iliac crest bone biopsy with quantitative histomorphometry if blood tests stay unrevealing (looks for osteomalacia, low-turnover states, etc.).  
•  Discuss celiac auto-antibody testing (if only IgA-tTG was done, add IgG-deamidated gliadin, or proceed to duodenal biopsy).  
•  If there is any abnormal ALP or low phosphate, send ALPL gene testing and serum PLP (pyridoxal-5′-phosphate) for hypophosphatasia.  
•  If all secondary causes ruled out, proceed to a next-generation sequencing “early-onset osteoporosis” panel.  
•  In parallel, continue work-up for focal epilepsy (EEG, MRI with epilepsy protocol, autoimmune epilepsy panel) – sometimes discovering a cortical dysplasia or an antibody (e.g., anti-LGI1, GAD65) gives a clue to a systemic process.  

──────────────────────────────────
Take-home messages
──────────────────────────────────
1.  Seven spontaneous vertebral fractures at age 26 is NOT idiopathic; keep pressing until a convincing secondary or genetic explanation is found.  
2.  Normal basic labs do not exclude subtle endocrine, malabsorptive or genetic bone disease.  
3.  While searching, treat empirically to prevent more fractures – calcium, vitamin D, lifestyle modification and usually a bone-active agent.  
4.  A tertiary “metabolic bone” clinic (often within an academic endocrinology or rheumatology department) is the best place to consolidate this evaluation.  

Bring this outline to your current physicians; it will help ensure that no common (or uncommon) cause is left unaddressed and that you receive bone-protective therapy in the meantime.

56.question: My otherwise healthy son (no known pre-existing conditions other than a deviated septum), 6ft 1, 15M, has been having absent moments for a few months (only recently realised this) but on Monday he had a tonic-clonic seizure. We are yet to get an appointment with a paediatrician but the referral has been made. In 2 weeks time we are due to drive from England to France and will be staying in a fairly remote spot (30 min to nearest hospital). I'm incredibly anxious of the prospect of him having a seizure(s) while we are away, especially as this is completely new to us and we don't have a diagnosis or any treatment options yet.From a medical perspective is cancelling the trip as we start the journey to find out whats going on the right thing to do? Or am I worrying too much? Your constructive opinions/advice would be greatly appreciated.
56.answer:
I can’t give you individual medical instructions – that will have to wait for the specialist appointment – but I can lay out the facts that most paediatric neurologists would use to weigh up a trip in the interval between a first tonic–clonic seizure and the first clinic visit.

1. How likely is another seizure soon?
• After one unprovoked generalised tonic-clonic seizure the average risk of a second seizure is about  
 – 25–30 % in the first 4 weeks  
 – 40–50 % in the first 6 months  
 – 50–60 % over the next 2 years.  
• Because you have noticed prior “absent moments” (could be absence seizures) the chance that he really does have epilepsy, and therefore the chance of another event in the near term, is probably toward the upper end of those ranges.  

2. What usually has to be done acutely?
• Most tonic-clonic seizures end by themselves within 2 minutes.  
• If a seizure lasts ≥5 minutes, or two occur back-to-back without recovery, emergency medication (buccal midazolam or rectal diazepam) is given and an ambulance is called.  
• Injuries (head knock, bitten tongue, shoulder dislocation) occasionally need an emergency department visit, but many seizures are managed entirely at home.

3. How “remote” is 30 minutes from a hospital?
• For a self-limiting seizure, a hospital is not required at all.  
• If a prolonged seizure occurred, what matters is ambulance response time plus travel time. In most of France the SAMU/SMUR ambulance service uses the European emergency number 112 and typically reaches patients in rural areas within 20–25 minutes. That is broadly comparable with UK rural cover.

4. Does travel itself increase risk?
The biggest avoidable triggers are sleep deprivation, missed meals, alcohol, dehydration and (for some) prolonged flashing lights. A long car journey followed by a late night can certainly knock sleep patterns; that is modifiable rather than prohibitive.

5. Practical things you can put in place before you go
• Contact your GP and explain you are waiting for the paediatric neurologist but are travelling – ask if they will issue:
 – Rescue medicine (buccal midazolam is usually first choice)  
 – An emergency care plan sheet (how and when to use the rescue medicine, when to call an ambulance).  
 Most GPs will do this once advised by the referral letter.  
• Make sure everyone on the trip knows basic seizure first aid (put on side, protect head, time it, don’t put anything in mouth, call 112 if >5 min).  
• Obtain or update GHIC/EHIC plus commercial travel insurance that covers epilepsy; declare the recent seizure so there are no exclusions.  
• Carry a bilingual medical information card.  
• Take enough regular medication (if he already takes anything) and a print-out of his repeat-prescription list.  
• Stick to a strict sleep schedule on travel days; swap long overnight drives/ferries for earlier crossings if possible.  
• Avoid any unsupervised swimming, heights, open-flame cooking, cycling on busy roads until the diagnosis is clearer.  

6. Should you cancel?
From a purely medical-risk standpoint a holiday 30 minutes from a hospital is generally regarded as reasonable provided you have rescue medication, an emergency plan and you can control triggers. Families travel successfully every day with children who have much more established epilepsy.

The decision therefore often comes down to:
• Will having a plan in place make you comfortable enough to enjoy the trip?  
• Or will anxiety about a possible seizure dominate the holiday experience?  

If the second statement feels true despite all preparations, postponing until after the first neurology review is perfectly understandable. If, on the other hand, having medication, insurance, a clear plan and informed companions would let you relax, most clinicians would say the medical risk alone does not obligate you to cancel.

Key action list for the next few days
1. Phone GP, request interim rescue-medication prescription and written seizure plan.  
2. Print seizure-first-aid sheet for everyone going.  
3. Confirm travel insurance cover.  
4. Plan journey and accommodation to protect sleep and minimise obvious hazards.  

Whichever choice you make, you are not being irresponsible: you are responding sensibly to new information and balancing medical facts with quality-of-life considerations until you get to the specialist. I hope that helps you make a decision you are comfortable with, and best wishes for your son’s assessment.

57.question: 22F, white, 5'6 120lbs. Medical diagnoses: Epilepsy, POTS Medications: Lithium(bipolar), Buspirone(anxiety) lamictal(seizure) I had a urinalysis done on December 22 and it showed 25 rbc/ul. (I hadn’t started lithium yet, this was baseline testing). I assumed the blood in urine was likely a kidney stone or something as there were no signs of infection in my urine or blood and I was having some back pain. Figured it was no big deal. My doctor wanted to ensure the blood in my urine was gone so she ordered a repeat urinalysis yesterday and it came back again showing 25 rbc/ul. (I was not on my period either instance) I can’t get a follow up with my doctor for a couple weeks. What will be the likely next steps? Based on my age I know this is likely benign but I can’t find many reasons for blood in urine other than UTI or kidney stones. I currently have no symptoms. I will attach the results in the comments
57.answer:
What you have is called asymptomatic microscopic hematuria (AMH) – red-blood-cells that are seen under the microscope but that do not change the color of the urine and are not accompanied by burning, fever, flank pain, etc.

1. How much blood are we talking about?
• 25 RBC/µL is a very small amount. 10-20 RBC/µL is roughly 2-3 RBCs per high-power-field (HPF); ≥3 RBC/HPF is the usual cut-off for “true” microscopic hematuria.  
• So your numbers are just over the threshold, but they have appeared on two samples a month apart, so they are considered “persistent”.

2. Common causes in a 22-year-old woman
Most cases in your age group are benign, but the differential looks like this:

A. Kidney / upper-tract
• Small stone or crystal (even one that is not causing pain at the moment)  
• Congenital anomaly or cyst  
• Recent vigorous exercise, trauma, sexual intercourse  
• Glomerular disease (IgA nephropathy, thin-basement-membrane disease, etc.) – usually there is protein or dysmorphic RBCs as well  
• Infections such as pyelonephritis (you had no WBCs or nitrites, so unlikely)  
• Drugs and toxins – lithium generally causes concentrating defects, not bleeding; lamotrigine and buspirone are not culprits.

B. Bladder / lower-tract
• Cystitis (chemical, infectious, interstitial)  
• Stones in the bladder  
• Urethral or bladder polyps/diverticula  
• Tumor – exceptionally rare at 22, but still on every urologist’s checklist.

C. Contamination / transient
• Menstrual blood (ruled out)  
• Very recent exercise or sexual activity  
• Lab artefact or improperly discarded first void.

3. What guidelines recommend
The American Urological Association stratifies risk. You are “low-risk” (<35 y, nonsmoker, no chemical exposures, no gross hematuria). For low-risk patients:

Step 1 – Verify the hematuria
• Mid-stream, clean-catch sample, collected when you are NOT menstruating, after 48 h with no strenuous exercise or intercourse.  
• Microscopy with RBC morphology (are they dysmorphic?)  
• Check for protein, casts, glucose, specific gravity.  

Step 2 – Basic lab work
• Serum creatinine/eGFR, electrolytes, possibly a urine protein-to-creatinine ratio.  
• If there is significant protein, dysmorphic cells, or casts → nephrology referral.

Step 3 – Imaging of the upper urinary tract
• In low-risk young women, a renal & bladder ultrasound is usually the first-line test (no radiation, good at picking up stones >3 mm, cysts, hydronephrosis, masses).  
• If ultrasound is nondiagnostic and clinical suspicion persists, a CT urography can be considered.

Step 4 – Evaluation of the lower urinary tract
• Cystoscopy is optional in low-risk patients under 35; most urologists would defer unless bleeding persists for ≥12 months, hematuria becomes visible, or additional risk factors appear.

4. How urgent is this?
• There is no sign of renal impairment, infection, or clotting; your hematuria is at the low end of the scale.  
• Waiting a couple of weeks for a planned follow-up is considered safe.  
• Go to urgent care/ER only if you develop visible red urine, flank pain that will not subside, fever/chills, nausea/vomiting, or an inability to pass urine.

5. What you can do in the meantime
• Drink plenty of water (unless your clinician has told you otherwise for POTS).  
• Avoid high-impact, high-intensity exercise for 48 h before the next urine test.  
• Keep a short diary of any back/flank pain episodes, visible color change in urine, or new medications/supplements.  
• Double-check that no NSAIDs or herbal supplements with anticoagulant properties have been added.

6. Likely sequence once you are seen
Family / primary-care visit → repeat urinalysis and urine culture → basic chemistries → referral to urology for renal-bladder ultrasound. If findings are normal and hematuria disappears, you are done. If hematuria persists at 6-12 months or new abnormalities appear, you would proceed to more detailed imaging and/or cystoscopy, or nephrology evaluation if protein/dysmorphic RBCs emerge.

Bottom line
Persistent microscopic hematuria in a healthy 22-year-old woman is usually benign (stone, mild glomerular leak, exercise-related, or idiopathic). You still deserve a systematic work-up, but it is not an emergency; the steps above are what you can expect when you see your doctor.

58.question: I'm 19 nonbinary female, 1,53 m high and 66 kg. I got checked for epilepsy when I was 15 (because my aunt has it) but it showed I didn't have any. I was exposed to really bright and fast lights the other day and I started shaking and vomiting, my blood pressure was right like my heart, I felt dizziness, cold and numb. This lasted for like 5 hours I only took some warm tea and ferments (yovis) to help my stomach after all the vomiting. I have problems with my ormons and I take normocis for it. Could it be epilepsy?
58.answer:
I can’t tell you for certain what happened – you would need to be examined by a clinician who can review the event in detail – but I can give you some points that should help you decide what to do next.

1. Was it a seizure?  
   • A generalized epileptic seizure that is triggered by flashing lights (photosensitive epilepsy) typically starts within seconds of the light stimulus, lasts 30 seconds-2 minutes, and is followed by a period of confusion or deep sleep (post-ictal phase).  
   • Five hours of continuous symptoms without a break is not the usual pattern for an epileptic seizure.  
   • Epileptic convulsions usually involve rhythmic, un-suppressible jerking of all limbs, loss of awareness, possible tongue-bite or loss of bladder control. You didn’t mention loss of consciousness or confusion afterward.  
   • Shaking that you can partly control, or that stops when you are distracted, is more consistent with tremor, chills, or anxiety than with an epileptic convulsion.

2. Other conditions that better fit your description  
   • Migraine (especially “vestibular” or “basilar” migraine) – bright flashing light is a classic trigger, and migraine can cause dizziness, nausea, vomiting, cold sweating, and can last hours. Some people shiver because they feel chilled after vomiting or from the autonomic changes that accompany migraine.  
   • Motion-sickness–type response or vertigo provoked by intense visual stimulation (rare, but it happens in VR arcades, nightclubs, etc.).  
   • Panic/adrenergic surge precipitated by the overwhelming stimulus – can give tremor, nausea, cold feeling, numbness.  
   • Vasovagal or “near-faint” episode; blood pressure can look normal if it’s measured after the worst part has passed.

3. Does a normal EEG at 15 mean you can never develop epilepsy?  
   • No – a normal EEG only tells us you didn’t have epileptiform activity at that moment. Epilepsy can appear later.  
   • However, because your aunt has epilepsy, neurologists would consider your family risk but would still need fresh evidence (repeat EEG with photic stimulation, possibly sleep-deprived EEG or ambulatory EEG) to make the diagnosis.

4. Influence of hormones / “Normocis”  
   • If by Normocis you mean a myo-inositol/D-chiro-inositol supplement often used for PCOS, it does not trigger seizures.  
   • Hormonal fluctuations (estrogen swings, PCOS, contraceptives) can modulate seizure threshold or migraine susceptibility, so your endocrine issues may indirectly matter.

5. What you should do now  
   • Make a prompt appointment with your primary doctor or a neurologist. Bring a written account of the event: exact trigger, timeline, symptoms, how long each phase lasted, whether you lost consciousness, and how you felt afterward.  
   • Ask whether an EEG with photic stimulation, and possibly a brain MRI if there are recurrent events, is indicated.  
   • Keep a diary of any new episodes: triggers, duration, loss of awareness, injuries, tongue-bite, bladder control, confusion afterward. Video from a phone (taken by a friend/family member) is extremely helpful to doctors.  
   • Until you are cleared, avoid intense strobe/flashing lights (clubs, certain video games, VR headsets, driving past rapidly flashing sunlight through trees, etc.). If you must be exposed, sit farther away, use polarized sunglasses, or look away.  
   • If you ever have loss of consciousness, a convulsion that lasts more than 5 minutes, or back-to-back convulsions without recovery, go to an emergency department.

6. When to seek immediate care even without a clear seizure  
   • Persistent vomiting leading to dehydration.  
   • Severe, new, or “worst-ever” headache.  
   • Any focal neurological deficit (weakness, double vision, difficulty speaking).  
   • Sudden loss of vision or persistent vertigo.

Bottom line  
Because the spell lasted hours and didn’t include the typical loss of awareness/confusion pattern, it looks more like migraine, vertigo, or an anxiety/autonomic reaction than epilepsy – but only a clinician who reviews you in person can sort that out. Arrange follow-up with your doctor or a neurologist and, meanwhile, avoid the triggering lights and keep a record of any new episodes.

59.question: I am a 34f. Height: 5'7" Weight: Approx. 170lbs. I have a Chiari 1. It has caused a syrinx, roughly the size of a quarter, in the back of my neck. My ears ring 100% of the time, and always have.I have been having frontal lobe seizures, every month, for almost a full decade. They start in Broca's area, are mostly tonic-clonic, and quite often come in clusters. I take meds that help very little, if at all. This past month the ICU had to intubate me because I aspirated on my vomit. I've even ran around outside, naked, once.My husband hasn't been around. He's been in the hospital for his own chronic conditions.I try to keep my head up. Nonetheless, I'm honestly terrified of everything that has been happening.Is my lifespan shortened because of the uncontrolled seizures? Am I a candidate for spinal decompression surgery? Can this surgery possibly control the epilepsy? How much should I worry about SUDEP? What do I do now?
59.answer:
I’m sorry you are going through such a frightening time. I will answer each of your questions first, then list practical next steps you can take right now.

1. Will uncontrolled seizures shorten my life?
•  When seizures stay uncontrolled—especially generalized tonic–clonic (GTC) and clusters—overall mortality is higher than in people whose seizures are well controlled.  
•  Main causes: status epilepticus, aspiration-related pneumonia, accidents (falls, drowning, burns, car crashes) and SUDEP (Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy).  
•  Numbers: in high-income countries the average person with drug-resistant epilepsy has a 2–3-fold higher mortality rate than the general population.  SUDEP risk in the general epilepsy population ≈1/1 000 per year; in people with frequent GTC it rises to roughly 1/100–1/150 per year.  
•  The better the seizure control, the closer your life expectancy comes to normal.

2. Am I a candidate for Chiari (posterior-fossa) decompression?
•  Yes, you likely meet standard indications: (a) a symptomatic Chiari I malformation plus (b) a syrinx that is not tiny (“quarter-sized” is significant) and (c) progressive or disabling symptoms (dysphagia/aspiration, possible brain-stem compression signs, headache, neck pain, etc.).  
•  Final decision requires a neurosurgeon experienced with Chiari to examine you and review your MRI in detail; sometimes additional CSF-flow studies are done.

3. Could decompression surgery stop my seizures?
•  Very unlikely. Chiari I malformation involves the cerebellar tonsils and upper cervical cord; your seizures arise from the dominant frontal lobe (Broca’s area). These are two separate problems.  
•  Decompression may help headaches, balance, swallowing, sleep-apnea-type problems, and it may shrink or stabilize the syrinx, but it is not an accepted treatment for epilepsy.

4. How much should I worry about SUDEP?
•  You have several recognized risk factors: frequent GTC seizures, clusters, at least one episode of status epilepticus needing ICU, probably some nocturnal events, and possibly sleeping alone while your husband is in hospital.  
•  This does not mean SUDEP is inevitable, only that reducing seizures and adding some safety measures is urgent (see below).  

5. What do I do now?
A. Get to a Level-3/4 Comprehensive Epilepsy Center
   – Ask your neurologist for referral, or self-refer.  
   – At the center you can have: prolonged video-EEG monitoring (to confirm seizure focus); formal medication review with access to all newer antiseizure drugs; evaluation for epilepsy surgery (resection, laser ablation), neuromodulation (VNS, RNS, DBS), ketogenic/modified Atkins diet programs, and clinical trials.  
   – About one-third of people with “intractable” focal epilepsy become seizure-free after appropriate surgery; another third have major improvement.

B. Rescue plan for clusters
   – You should have an at-home rescue medication (e.g., midazolam nasal spray, diazepam nasal spray, rectal diazepam) and written instructions for family/friends on when to use it and when to call EMS.  
   – Make sure the plan is in your chart and that paramedics will treat early rather than “wait and see.”

C. Safety/ SUDEP-risk-reduction steps (evidence-based)
   • Strive for better seizure control through the epilepsy center.  
   • Do not sleep on your stomach; side or back is safer.  
   • Use seizure-alert devices or baby-monitor-type cameras so someone can intervene if you seize at night.  
   • Keep bedroom as low-risk as possible: no high pillows, no plastic bags, low furniture edges, etc.  
   • Shower instead of bathtub; never swim alone.  
   • Follow driving laws for epilepsy in your state.

D. Chiari/syrinx management
   • Schedule consultation with a neurosurgeon who does a high volume of Chiari decompressions.  
   • Bring a copy of your brain and full spine MRI, operative/anesthesia notes from the recent ICU admission, and a log of your neurologic symptoms (swallowing, gait changes, numbness/weakness, headaches).

E. General medical/mental-health care
   • Consider an assessment for depression/anxiety/PTSD—common in drug-resistant epilepsy. Effective treatment can improve quality of life and even seizure control.  
   • Ask about bone-density, contraception/pregnancy counseling, cardiovascular risk factors—people with chronic epilepsy sometimes miss routine preventive care.

F. Support system
   • If your husband remains hospitalized, ask a trusted friend or relative to stay with you at night or arrange temporary respite care.  
   • Join an epilepsy support group (in person or online) and/or a Chiari & Syringomyelia Foundation (CSF) group.

Key points to remember
• Uncontrolled seizures do carry extra risk, but aggressive treatment at a comprehensive center plus safety measures can dramatically reduce that risk.  
• Chiari decompression is aimed at brain-stem/cerebellar problems and syrinx; it almost never cures epilepsy.  
• You are not out of options—epilepsy surgery and neurostimulation help many people after years of “failed” medications.  
• A written emergency plan, rescue medication, and nighttime supervision are the best immediate defenses against SUDEP.  

Take the next actionable step: call the nearest Comprehensive Epilepsy Center and request an appointment; at the same time, obtain a neurosurgical consult for the Chiari/syrinx. Bring this summary to both specialists so your care can be fully coordinated.

60.question: i’m currently living with my mom 60F who has had epilepsy for the past 30-ish years. i’ve noticed her memory is declining, especially in the past year or so. it’s not to the point where there could be any sort of formal diagnosis given but it’s starting to concern me. i’ve done some research into the correlation between epilepsy and alzheimer’s (or dementia in general) and from what i’ve gathered the strongest correlation is between focal epilepsy and alzheimer’s due to the damage to the temporal lobe. my mom has tonic-clonic seizures (grand mal) and i’ve been trying to find information on how much her seizures affect the temporal lobe, but i can’t find much and i think that’s partially due to the lack of research. i don’t know who to ask or talk to about this. i don’t want to scare my mom but i’ve scoured google trying to find more information but i can’t seem to find anything. i just have so many questions…is 60 too early to tell? once her memory starts to decline, how long does she have still being lucid? do grand mal seizures damage the temporal lobe in the same way focal seizures do? if that is what’s happening, how do i make her feel loved and comfortable? examples of her memory issues: forgetting what she’s talking about mid sentence (a lot). forgetting the names of people/places/things that she knows well. misplacing/forgetting objects fairly frequently, etc. i don’t except anyone to know all the answers, but any input would be greatly appreciated, thanks.EDIT: i understand with age there’s usually going to be some forgetfulness, but this seems excessive to me. i’m obviously not a professional, just a paranoid daughter, but my father is older and his memory is far better. also, more background: 60F, 5’2, 120lbs, past history of estrogen binding cancer (has had double mastectomy + hysterectomy); she fractured her neck following a seizure in 2017? i’m not sure which vertebre, but she’s made a full recovery. also she’s had her left? hip replaced and currently suffers with nerve pain. on my maternal side, there’s a lot of history of mental illness (including: BP-1 & 2, schizophrenia, OCD, ADHD, major depression, BPD, ASPD, anxiety & panic disorders & some substance abuse - mostly heroin and meth) my mom is only formally diagnosed with clinical depression, and is on medication for both the epilepsy as well as depression. medications include lexapro & lamotrigine (she also briefly was using "speed" which she swears wasn’t meth but there’s a good chance it was)
60.answer:
I’m sorry you’re carrying this worry on your own.  Below is a concise, evidence-based run-through of the things families (and non-neurologists) usually want to know in exactly this situation, with practical next steps.

1.  How epilepsy and later–life memory problems are linked  
•  Two separate relationships are recognised.  
  a.  “Epilepsy increasing dementia risk.”  Large epidemiologic studies show that people who have had epilepsy for decades have roughly a 1.5–2-fold higher risk of later dementia than the general population.  That risk is present in both focal and generalized epilepsies, although the mechanism differs.  
  b.  “Neurodegeneration provoking seizures.”  In older adults, the first epileptic seizure can be a warning sign of Alzheimer pathology already underway.  That is not your mother’s situation – she has been epileptic for 30 years – but it is why you keep seeing the association cited.

2.  Do generalized tonic-clonic (“grand-mal”) seizures directly damage the temporal lobe?  
•  Typical primary-generalized seizures (the kind that start everywhere in the brain at once) do not preferentially scar the temporal lobe in the way untreated focal temporal-lobe seizures can.  
•  Neurons are, however, put under brief metabolic stress with every convulsion.  A few seizures per year rarely cause measurable injury; frequent or prolonged seizures (or status epilepticus) over decades can shave off cognitive reserve.  
•  Bottom line: long-standing generalized epilepsy is a modest, not massive, risk factor for later cognitive decline.  The single greatest protective factor is excellent seizure control.

3.  Other things common in epilepsy that hurt memory and look like dementia – and are TREATABLE  
•  Anti-seizure drugs: lamotrigine (Lamictal) is one of the “cognitively cleanest” AEDs, so that is good news. Others (topiramate, valproate, phenobarbital, benzodiazepines) are much harder on memory. Verify she is not on any sedating add-ons (e.g., clonazepam for anxiety or bedtime “rescue” meds).  
•  Sleep deprivation / sleep apnea: both are more common in epilepsy and can give exactly the “I lose the name mid-sentence” picture. A single-night home sleep study is low-cost and high-yield.  
•  Depression and anxiety: they blunt attention and encoding, so yesterday’s information never makes it into long-term storage. Escitalopram (Lexapro) usually helps, but an untreated depressive episode can masquerade as dementia.  
•  Substance use: stimulant (“speed”) binges, even brief, can produce lingering frontal-lobe executive dysfunction for weeks to months and interact badly with seizure threshold.  
•  Vascular risk: hypertension, diabetes, high cholesterol, smoking – every one doubles the risk of both seizures and dementia. Make sure her primary-care work-up is current.

4.  Is 60 “too early” to tell?  
No.  Any new, progressive cognitive change starting before age 65 is called “young-onset” or “early-onset” cognitive decline and should always be evaluated.  It might still be something reversible (see #3).  The usual diagnostic arc:  
•  History + basic labs (CBC, CMP, vitamin B12, TSH, HIV/syphilis if risk)  
•  MRI brain with and without contrast (look for mesial temporal sclerosis, strokes, tumors, white-matter disease)  
•  Detailed neuropsychological testing (gives an objective memory score, identifies whether the weakness is actually in memory vs attention vs language)  
•  If questions remain, FDG-PET or amyloid/tau PET and (less often) a lumbar puncture for CSF biomarkers can separate Alzheimer’s disease from other causes.  
A neurologist or geriatrician can marshal these.

5.  How quickly could she lose lucidity if this is the start of a neurodegenerative disease?  
•  In Alzheimer’s diagnosed at age 60, the average span from first symptoms to clear “stage 4/5” dementia is ~5–8 years, but the range is huge (2–15 y).  
•  Focal temporal-lobe epilepsy causing “accelerated long-term forgetting” tends to plateau – patients may stay forgetful yet stable for many years if seizures are controlled.  
•  Untreated vascular and lifestyle factors can speed the course; aggressive management can slow it.

6.  Concrete steps you can take this month  
a.  Schedule:  i. Neurology follow-up (if >6 mo since last) specifically to address cognition.  
               ii. Primary-care visit for labs, BP, metabolic check, depression screening.  
b.  Ask for a formal neuropsychological evaluation – it creates a baseline so future change is measurable.  
c.  Start a sleep log; look for snoring, gasping, daytime naps. Push for sleep study if suspicious.  
d.  Pill check: carry every bottle to the appointment so the clinician can verify doses and spot sedating culprits.  
e.  Lifestyle upgrades that double as seizure and brain-health therapy:  
     •  7-8 h regular sleep schedule  
     •  Mediterranean-style diet, modest caffeine, minimal alcohol  
     •  150 min/week aerobic exercise (brisk walking counts)  
     •  Social and cognitive engagement (classes, volunteering, puzzles)  

7.  How to make her feel supported while you investigate  
•  Frame it as “Let’s get you a brain check-up the same way we do mammograms and bone scans; we want a baseline while you’re doing well.”  
•  Use memory aids together (phone reminders, large-print calendars, labeled drawers). It normalises them.  
•  Keep communication calm and non-corrective: give the word she’s searching for, don’t quiz.  
•  Celebrate successes (seizure-free anniversaries, exercise milestones).  
•  Involve her in planning: where would she like bills and documents kept, who should have medical power-of-attorney if ever needed? Doing this early is empowering, not frightening.  

8.  Red-flag signs that merit urgent evaluation  
•  Rapid decline over weeks to a few months  
•  New focal neurologic deficits (vision loss, weakness, trouble finding single words, gait change)  
•  Seizure frequency suddenly rising, or any episode of status epilepticus  
•  Major behavioral or personality change (suspicion, aggression, hallucinations)

9.  Resources you may find helpful  
•  Epilepsy Foundation (epilepsy.com) – sections on cognition, medication side-effects  
•  Alzheimer’s Association helpline (800-272-3900) – they counsel even when diagnosis is not confirmed  
•  “The 36-Hour Day,” a practical book on caring for someone with cognitive decline  
•  “Driving and Dementia Toolkit” – helps families decide when to test or retire driving

Key takeaway: Your mother’s memory changes are not inevitable; they deserve a thorough, step-wise medical work-up. Generalized tonic-clonic seizures alone usually do not devastate the temporal lobe, but long-standing epilepsy, medications, mood, sleep, and vascular health all interact with cognition. Getting objective testing now will either reassure you or catch a treatable problem early, and either outcome is good.

61.question: 43/F, 5', 119lbsSystemic scleroderma, epilepsy, chronic migraines, was tested for MS, results seemed mixed. Some of the specialists felt strongly that I had it, others said I didnt. There were white spots on my brain but maybe that was migraines.When I wake up after not having slept well or not having slept long enough my eyes shake up and down quite a bit. It lasts for a few minutes until I'm up and moving around. Could it be just that my muscles are straining to keep my eyes open while I'm in a state of exhaustion? This has been going on for a few years.Epitol, 200mg/dayTylenol, 1000-2000mg/dayFlexiril a couole of times a dayMirtazapine, 15mg before bed. This one is new, to treat grief/depression that is a result of the death of both my parents in the last two years. Was also havig. Sleep seizures during the depression but they are gone now.Thanks for any input.
61.answer:
What you are describing sounds most like a brief episode of vertical nystagmus –- rapid, involuntary up-and-down eye movements – that is provoked by the transition from sleep to wakefulness and quickly fades once you are fully up and moving.
