A few minutes of “eye shaking” on first opening the eyes is not a normal fatigue phenomenon and is not the same as the eyelid quivering many people feel when they are tired.  While the symptom can be benign in some circumstances, vertical nystagmus is classically a “central” (brain rather than ear) sign and always deserves a formal neurological (or neuro-ophthalmological) evaluation.  Below is an outline of the common causes, how they fit (or don’t fit) your situation, and what to do next.

1.  Possible triggers/causes in your setting  
   •  Sleep deprivation / severe fatigue – can bring out a latent nystagmus or make a subtle one obvious, but usually the eye movements are horizontal and mild.  
   •  Migraine – transient nystagmus can occur during or immediately after a migraine aura; some patients get it on awakening if they slept through an unrecognized nocturnal migraine.  White-matter “spots” on MRI from migraine are well documented.  
   •  Medication effects  
       –  Carbamazepine (Epitol) can cause nystagmus, especially if the blood level is high or if you are particularly sensitive.  Dose is low, but liver-metabolism differences or drug interactions can still push the level up.  
       –  Cyclobenzaprine and mirtazapine rarely produce true nystagmus but can add to sedation, making a fatigue-provoked nystagmus more obvious.  
   •  Multiple sclerosis or another inflammatory/demyelinating process – vertical or multidirectional nystagmus is one of the classic brain-stem/cerebellar eye signs in MS.  The fact that specialists were split on the MS diagnosis makes this possibility worth re-addressing.  
   •  Auto-immune/vascular lesions related to systemic scleroderma – small-vessel ischemic changes in the cerebellum or brain-stem can create exactly this sign.  
   •  Chiari malformation, cerebellar degeneration, stroke, tumor, or other structural changes in the cerebellum/brain-stem – less likely given the intermittent nature, but part of the standard rule-out list for downbeat/upbeat nystagmus.  
   •  Epileptic brain activity – some focal seizures consist only of ocular oscillations, but they usually last seconds, not minutes, and awareness is often altered.

2.  Why it appears only on awakening  
   •  During rapid eye movement (REM) sleep the “gaze-holding” network in the brain stem is temporarily switched off.  If that network is slightly unstable (because of one of the conditions above), the first few minutes after waking can reveal the instability until the cerebellum re-engages normal gaze holding.  
   •  Fatigue lowers the threshold for nystagmus in many central disorders, so it tends to show up after a poor night’s sleep.

3.  What you can do now  
   •  Try to capture a phone-video of the eye movement as soon as you wake.  Vertical nystagmus is unmistakable on replay and tremendously helpful to your doctor.  
   •  Ask your neurologist for:  
       –  A focused neuro-ophthalmologic exam (looking for pursuit deficits, skew deviation, head-shake nystagmus, etc.)  
       –  Serum carbamazepine level (especially since you have recently added other medications).  
       –  A review of the last MRI to see whether any lesions are near the vestibular nuclei/cerebellar flocculus, and consider a repeat MRI with dedicated brain-stem/cerebellar cuts if the last one is more than a year old or was done without contrast.  
       –  Possibly vestibular / ocular-motor testing (ENG/VNG) if the diagnosis remains unclear.  
   •  Optimize sleep hygiene (fixed bedtime, dark cool room, avoid late caffeine or screens) because sleep deprivation magnifies almost every type of nystagmus.  
   •  Keep a log: date/time of event, how long it lasted, whether you had a migraine before bed, whether you took cyclobenzaprine, alcohol, etc., how much you slept.  Patterns often emerge.

4.  Red-flag reasons to seek evaluation sooner rather than later  
   •  Episodes are lasting longer or occurring at other times of day.  
   •  You notice oscillopsia (the visual scene appears to bounce) or blurred vision persisting after the shaking stops.  
   •  New imbalance, dizziness, slurred speech, double vision, or weakness.  
   •  An increase in seizure frequency or a change in seizure type.

Bottom line  
What you are experiencing is most consistent with a brief, fatigue-provoked vertical nystagmus emanating from the brain-stem/cerebellar circuitry that holds the eyes steady.  Several conditions you already carry – migraine, possible demyelination, autoimmune micro-vascular disease, and carbamazepine exposure – can each contribute.  Because vertical nystagmus is nearly always central, documenting it on video and having a neurologist or neuro-ophthalmologist evaluate you is the safest course.

62.question: Bipolar, OCD, TL Epilepsy (I am questioning this, diagnosed with absence seizures but I don’t think this fits) 200mg Topamax 2x daily, 200mg sertraline, 3mg risperidone, 30mg abilify, 1000IU vitamin D, 40mg somac, I was diagnosed with epilepsy when I was around 17-18, but my neurologist just doesn’t really listen to me. He diagnosed me with absence seizures but the problem is I’ve never forgotten a seizure or lost consciousness. Now I’m realising that what he’s called my ‘motor tics’ could be seizures as well. Basically, I have these head jerks where it feels like theres a pulse of electricity in the back of my head usually in the base of my skull on the left side. And my head jerks back and I make a grunting sound, sometimes I jerk back twice. This has been happening for about 10 years but it gets worse when I’m off my meds. But the past week I haven’t really been sleeping and I’ve had the flu and I’ve been unable to twitch and it’s like the feeling is building up in the back of my head and its getting really uncomfortable and making it sometimes hard to breathe. Sometimes painful. The feeling is completely involuntary, kind of like a sneeze, and it feels like when you can’t sneeze. What should I do? My neurologist doesn’t listen to me. I have a GP appointment in 2 days, should I talk to her about it?
62.answer:
I am not able to examine you, review your EEGs or change your prescriptions, so take everything below as general information that you can use when you see your own doctors.  If at any point the jerks become prolonged, occur in rapid succession, are followed by confusion, or you develop trouble breathing or severe neck pain, go to the Emergency Department or call your local emergency number.

1. Why the diagnosis is in doubt  
• Typical absence seizures last 5-20 seconds, you lose awareness, often stare, and have no memory of the episode. What you describe—full awareness, a single jerk of the head, a grunt, and sometimes an urge you can briefly suppress—doesn’t match that pattern.  
• What you describe can fit a number of OTHER possibilities:
  – Chronic motor tics / Tourette’s (urge builds up, relief when it happens, can be held back briefly).  
  – Myoclonic jerks (sudden muscle contractions that can be epileptic or non-epileptic).  
  – Focal motor seizures (usually cannot be voluntarily suppressed and there is no “premonitory” urge).  
  – Medication-induced movement disorders (dystonia, myoclonus or tardive dyskinesia) from risperidone, aripiprazole or the combination.  

2. Why the symptoms worsened this week  
• Sleep deprivation, fever/illness, and missed doses of medicines all lower the seizure threshold AND make tics or medication-induced movements worse.  
• When you consciously stop the jerk, the uncomfortable “pressure” in the back of the head that you describe is classic for tics; people with epileptic myoclonus usually cannot hold them back.

3. Medications worth reviewing  
• It is unusual to be on TWO antipsychotics at full therapeutic doses (risperidone 3 mg + aripiprazole 30 mg). That combination considerably increases the risk of movement disorders.  
• SSRI (sertraline) combined with topiramate has occasionally been associated with myoclonus.  
• Topiramate itself is used to prevent seizures AND can sometimes help tics, but at higher doses it can cause paresthesias or cognitive “fog.”  
• All of the above can interact with each other and with bipolar treatment goals.

4. What you can do before the appointment  
• Make a log: date, time, what the jerk looked like, whether you could stop it, how long, any trigger (fatigue, missed dose, caffeine, alcohol, stress, illness).  
• Ask a friend or family member to video a few episodes on a smartphone (with your permission). A good video is often as useful as an EEG in deciding whether the spell is epileptic or a tic.  
• Write down every medication (with dose and time taken), including over-the-counter products and recreational substances.  
• Note any side-effects: weight gain, tremor elsewhere, restlessness, stiffness, etc.  

5. At the GP visit in two days  
Tell your GP plainly:  
“I was labelled with ‘absence seizures’ but I stay fully aware. I get these head-jerk spells I can sometimes hold back, and I think they might be tics or a different kind of seizure. My neurologist hasn’t addressed this. Could you:  
1. Review whether my current medicine combination might be causing or worsening it?  
2. Refer me for a second opinion to an epileptologist or a movement-disorder specialist who can do a long-term video-EEG or EMU admission?  
3. Consider an MRI (if not done recently) and a repeat EEG while I’m sleep-deprived or during the spell?  
4. Consider whether one antipsychotic can be tapered or changed if the movement disorder risk is high?”  

6. If your GP agrees  
• A referral to a comprehensive epilepsy centre or neurologist who specialises in movement disorders is reasonable.  
• Ask for instructions on how to taper or adjust any psychiatric medicine—DO NOT stop or change doses on your own; abrupt changes can destabilise mood or provoke seizures.  
• If tics are diagnosed, treatments range from behavioural therapy (CBIT), guanfacine/clonidine, to low-dose antipsychotics (which you are already on) or botulinum toxin for focal neck tics.  
• If a medication-induced movement disorder is suspected, dose reduction, switching agents, or adding VMAT-2 inhibitors (e.g., valbenazine) are options.  
• If focal or myoclonic epilepsy is confirmed, anti-seizure medication can be tailored (levetiracetam, lamotrigine, etc.) and safety counselling given.  

7. General safety advice until you’re re-evaluated  
• Take every dose on time; avoid sudden withdrawal.  
• Get consistent sleep, stay hydrated, avoid excess caffeine/alcohol.  
• Do not drive or operate dangerous machinery until a specialist says it is safe.  
• Let someone close know what to do if a spell clusters or lasts >5 minutes.  

Bottom line  
Yes—bring this up with your GP in two days, bring your log and (if possible) video, and explicitly ask for a second-opinion referral and a medication review. The pattern you describe sounds more like tics or a medication-related movement disorder than classic absence epilepsy, but only a direct examination with EEG or video-EEG can resolve the question.

63.question: 25 female, overweight, no smoking, on Jardiance, insulin, Copaxone generic. I feel exhausted all day, doesn't matter how much I sleep. I've been asleep for most of the past 3 days. All of my body hurts and even moving my arm is tiring and painful. I find speaking equally exhausting, too, like, I can't even explain. Using my voice is exhausting, too.I have diabetes, multiple sclerosis, epilepsy, digestive stuff and as of new, undiagnosed liver problems. Have an electromyography and heart tests coming.I can't stay sitting. I need to lie down all the time.Had an overdose couple days ago, if that matters.
63.answer:
I’m really concerned about the group of symptoms you are describing.

Why this is potentially an emergency  
• Extreme, disabling fatigue and generalized muscle pain that came on suddenly and has not improved over several days.  
• You can’t stay awake or sit upright and even speaking feels exhausting.  
• You have type-1 or insulin-dependent diabetes and you are taking an SGLT-2 inhibitor (Jardiance). These drugs can precipitate a “silent” / euglycaemic diabetic keto-acidosis (DKA) in people on insulin; blood glucose may be only mildly elevated or even normal. Severe fatigue, body pain, nausea or abdominal discomfort, rapid breathing, or just feeling “deathly ill” can be the first clues.  
• You mention “liver problems” and that you had an overdose a couple of days ago. An unrecognized acetaminophen (paracetamol) or other drug overdose can lead to acute liver failure and hepatic encephalopathy, which causes profound sleepiness, body aches, confusion, and ultimately coma.  
• Electrolyte disturbances (low sodium, potassium, etc.), rhabdomyolysis, infection, adrenal or thyroid crisis, MS relapse, or cardiac issues are also possible with your history.  

All of these conditions require same-day urgent assessment and lab work.  

What you should do right now  
1. Go to the emergency department or call emergency medical services (911 in the U.S., 112/999 elsewhere) immediately. Tell them:  
   • “I’m a 25-year-old female with diabetes on insulin and Jardiance, MS on glatiramer, epilepsy, recent overdose, and new severe fatigue and body pain. I can’t stay awake.”  
2. If you have home blood-glucose or ketone strips, check them on the way or tell EMTs the last readings. Bring all of your medication bottles (including what you overdosed on, if known).  
3. Do NOT drive yourself; have someone else call or take you.  

What the ER will likely do  
• Vital signs, finger-stick glucose, capillary/serum ketones, venous/arterial blood gas to look for keto-acidosis or lactic acidosis.  
• Comprehensive metabolic panel (electrolytes, kidney, liver), CBC, coagulation profile, serum drug levels (acetaminophen, salicylate, others), CK (rhabdomyolysis), troponin.  
• Ammonia level if liver failure suspected.  
• ECG and possibly chest X-ray.  
• IV fluids, insulin and dextrose if DKA/euglycaemic DKA is confirmed, N-acetylcysteine if acetaminophen toxicity suspected, other targeted treatments as indicated.  

While you are waiting for transport  
• Stop taking Jardiance until a clinician clears you.  
• Sip water or an oral rehydration drink if you can stay awake and swallow safely.  
• Monitor your glucose if you’re able.  
• Have a friend or family member stay with you in case you become less responsive.  

Please do not ignore these symptoms or try to “sleep it off.” With your medical history, multiple serious but treatable conditions are on the table, and the only safe next step is immediate in-person medical evaluation. If you ever feel too weak to call, have someone else make the call for you.

If you have thoughts of harming yourself or feel unsafe, tell the dispatcher or staff right away—help is available (in the U.S. you can also call/text 988).  

Take this seriously and seek care now.

64.question: Age 35, Sex F, Height 5’2”, Weight 135Trying to keep this short and sweet, but can provide infinite additional information/context if requested. I am in good health aside from the growing list of neurological issues I’ve been having after finding a raging enlarged right hilar lymph node this past February. Needle biopsy was negative.I am hanging out on the hospital bed, chillaxing watching tv… and after a few minutes of some kinda medium-mild pain at the top of my spine/base of skull, the following sequence lasted about 2-3 min start to finish, but repeated every few minutes for about an hour:-Right eye involuntarily closes/flutters (~30 seconds) immediately followed by…-Strange ‘out of body/near syncope/like the power is flickering in my brain’ feeling, strong for ~30 seconds, then continues in very brief intermittent waves, immediately followed by…-right leg spasms/shakes/jerks around for ~30 seconds, immediately followed by…-both hands very tingly….And once the tingling fully fades, I feel normal for not very many minutes and the cycle repeats.I could talk/interact during all this except the mini out of body type feeling times. After several repetitions, I began to have right sided facial twitching/numbness along with the eye closing. My speech was affected, I guess because of numbness? Also, I could not lift up either leg as the nurse pressed down until the full end of the cycle. All steps of the cycle grew longer and more intense as the hour stretched on, then resolved somewhat suddenly.Right as all this was wrapping up, the attending neurologist stepped in and without asking any questions or seeing any of this himself, told me not to worry, everything was fine, the eeg looked normal, and started asking if I was anxious or upset about anything. I said no, but what did he think all that was. He says the eeg was normal, therefore it was a psychogenic seizure, not a real one, and I should be happy. I told him that it didn’t really seem like any kind of seizure I’ve ever experienced/heard about, epileptic or not, it seemed like something else entirely and maybe we should try to figure out what? Then he said something about I should mention it to the daytime Dr tomorrow and maybe they could do something on an outpatient basis, but don’t bother him again tonight and if I need anything else, like anxiety medication, ask the nurse. So uh… yeah.Thoughts? Feelings? I briefly caught part of it on video, but have no idea how to post that here.I greatly appreciate any input.
64.answer:
I’m sorry this was handled so abruptly.  Even if a psychogenic‐non-epileptic seizure (PNES) is on the table, it should never be given as a “drive-by” diagnosis; that label should come only after other reasonable neurologic causes have been explored and ruled out.  Let me lay out what a neurologist would usually think through in a situation like yours, why a single normal routine EEG does NOT end the discussion, and what next steps usually make sense.

1.  Could this still be an epileptic seizure?
   • A routine (20- to 40-min) EEG is normal in roughly 30–50 % of patients who truly have epilepsy.  
   • If the spell itself is not captured, the test is basically looking for inter-ictal spikes; it can easily miss mesial‐temporal, insular, deep frontal or occipital foci.  
   • Video-EEG monitoring for 24 h (or ideally 48–72 h) is the gold standard to separate PNES from focal seizures.

   Features in your description that keep a focal (partial) seizure on the list:
   • Reproducible stereotyped sequence (eye → ‘‘power-flicker’’ sensation → unilateral leg jerk → bilateral hand paresthesia).  
   • Progression that sounds almost “Jacksonian” (starting cranially and “marching” down the right side).  
   • Brief post-ictal weakness (nurse could push leg down, you couldn’t lift it).  
   • Preserved awareness except for a short “cloudy” phase (typical of focal aware / focal impaired-awareness seizures).

   Things that argue against—but do not rule out—epilepsy:
   • Cycling every few minutes for an hour is longer than classic focal seizures, though “seizure clusters” can do this.  
   • No tongue bite, incontinence or clear post-ictal exhaustion (but many focal seizures lack those).

2.  Other organic (non-epileptic) possibilities worth excluding
   • Brainstem/cortical TIA or migraine with brainstem aura  
   • Cervical medullary lesion (e.g., demyelination, Chiari, arachnoid cyst) producing position‐triggered spells  
   • Intermittent vertebro-basilar ischemia (vertebral dissection, subclavian steal)  
   • Paraneoplastic or autoimmune encephalitis (especially because of the hilar node and systemic symptoms)  
   • Neurosarcoidosis (bilateral or unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is the classic clue; CSF, MRI & PET can help)  
   • Metabolic/arrhythmic syncope with superimposed myoclonic jerks (needs telemetry, orthostatic vitals, labs)

3.  When does PNES become the leading diagnosis?
   • Only after prolonged video-EEG captures several typical spells with absolutely no electrographic correlate.  
   • By definition the spells must be incompatible with neuroanatomy or physiology, or vary dramatically from event to event.  
   • Even then, PNES and epilepsy can coexist in 10–20 % of patients, so dismissal is unsafe.

4.  What additional work-up usually makes sense now?
   • Admit or arrange for 24–72 h video-EEG monitoring.  
   • MRI brain with and without gadolinium, focused cuts through brainstem and upper cervical cord.  
   • If not already done: MRI cervical spine, MRA head/neck, basic labs (CBC, CMP, Mg, Ca), ESR/CRP.  
   • If sarcoidosis or lymphoma still suspected: chest CT with contrast, possibly PET–CT; serum ACE, lysozyme; consider bronchoscopy or repeat biopsy (needle biopsies miss sarcoid up to 20–30 %).  
   • If paraneoplastic/autoimmune picture persists: serum and CSF autoimmune encephalitis panel (NMDA-R, LGI1, CASPR2, GAD65, etc.), oligoclonal bands, IgG index.  
   • Consider tilt-table or cardiac loop recorder if a syncope variant is credible.

5.  Symptom treatment / safety while the work-up continues
   • Keep seizure precautions until epilepsy is definitively ruled out: no driving, working at heights or swimming alone.  
   • If spells cluster, a rescue med such as intranasal midazolam can be given—whether epileptic or PNES, it often terminates the episode long enough to capture on EEG later.  
   • Document (video on your phone) each spell and jot down precipitating factors, prodrome, duration, recovery.

6.  If PNES is ultimately proven
   • It is not “all in your head” in the pejorative sense; it is a functional neurological disorder usually triggered by physiologic arousal, pain, past trauma, sleep deprivation, etc.  
   • First-line therapy is cognitive-behavioral therapy with a clinician experienced in FND; some patients also benefit from SSRIs/SNRIs.  
   • Clear explanation (“your brain wiring is intact, but the way it’s firing during stress is producing genuine physical spells”) is key—very different from being told to “just calm down.”

Bottom line
A single normal routine EEG plus a brief bedside look is nowhere near enough evidence to declare PNES and shut the door.  The event you describe is sufficiently stereotyped and lateralized that a real neurologic cause—especially a focal seizure—remains very plausible.  Ask for (or insist on) formal video-EEG monitoring and a high-resolution MRI with contrast; make sure any systemic process connected to that hilar node (sarcoid, lymphoma, autoimmune) is fully evaluated.  Until then, keep seizure precautions, record the spells, and don’t hesitate to seek a second neurologic opinion if the current team is unreceptive.

65.question: We have been working with a neurologist about my son. He’s had tremors since he was a baby, but we were always told he would grow out of them. He did have an actual seizure once, but after a 4 hour EEG, they said his brain activity did not look like epilepsy. Lately, he has been closing his eyes and shaking his head, almost like he ate something super sour. Is that normal? What could it be? Teething? Mini seizure?
65.answer:
I can’t tell from a written description exactly what your son is doing, but I can give you a framework you can use when you speak with his neurologist (or with his regular pediatrician if you can get in sooner).  

1. What spells often turn out to be  
• Benign motor tics – quick, repeated movements such as forceful blinking, eye‐squeezing, head shaking, shoulder shrugging, sniffing, throat-clearing, etc. They usually begin between 3-7 years of age, wax and wane, get worse with excitement or fatigue, and disappear during sleep. Children can often suppress them briefly if asked.  
• “Shuddering attacks” (also called infantile shudders) – very brief (1-5 seconds) tremor-like episodes of the head, neck, and upper body without loss of awareness. They are harmless and usually disappear by 2-3 years of age.  
• Benign essential tremor – a fine “action tremor” that appears when the hands are held out or when a child is trying to do something (draw, feed himself). It can run in families.  
• Habit/sensory behaviors – some children shake their heads, roll their eyes, or make faces as a self-stimulatory or soothing maneuver.  
• Discomfort from ears/teeth/reflux – pain or odd sensations can make toddlers grimace, squeeze their eyes shut, or shake their heads, but usually you see other signs of pain (fussiness, ear-pulling, refusing food, drooling, arching, waking at night, etc.).

2. What true seizures usually look like  
• They are stereotyped – every episode is almost identical in appearance and duration.  
• The child is not fully responsive during the spell or is confused afterward.  
• You cannot distract or stop the movement by touching or talking to the child.  
• They may occur out of sleep.  
• They often leave the child tired or briefly confused afterward.  
• A single seizure can happen in any child with fever or illness (febrile seizure) and doesn’t automatically mean epilepsy. A normal 4-hour EEG makes ongoing epilepsy less likely, but occasionally longer video-EEG monitoring is needed if spells persist.

3. Clues that point away from seizure  
• The child stays engaged, follows commands, or can voluntarily stop the movement for a few seconds.  
• The spells are clearly triggered by excitement, anxiety, fatigue, or concentration.  
• They disappear during sleep.  
• They look different from one episode to the next (e.g., sometimes just eye squeezing, other times eye squeezing plus head shake).  
• Your son can do them on purpose if you ask him (“Show me what you were just doing”).

4. What to watch, record, and tell the neurologist  
Try to get one or two episodes on video with your phone (start recording as soon as you notice the first movement, keep filming for a minute after it stops, and talk during the recording—“He’s been awake, it is 2 pm, he can hear me,” etc.).  Write down:  
• Date/time and how long the spell lasted.  
• What he was doing right before (excited, tired, eating, brushing teeth, watching TV).  
• Whether he could respond (look at you, answer, stop) during the spell.  
• Whether he seemed sleepy, confused, or perfectly normal afterward.  
• Any new medicines, illnesses, fevers, exposures, or stressors.  
Bring the video and log to the next visit; they are more useful than an office description.

5. When to call sooner or go to the ER  
• The episode lasts more than 5 minutes or clusters of back-to-back spells run more than 5-10 minutes.  
• There is loss of awareness with bluish color, breathing problems, or loss of muscle tone (falls).  
• He is not himself afterward—confused, weak on one side, vomiting repeatedly, or excessively sleepy.  
• There is a fever and a stiff neck, bad headache, or persistent vomiting.

6. Is it teething?  
Teething can make babies drool, gnaw, wake more, or put their hands in their mouths, but head-shaking with eye-squeezing is not a classic teething sign. Ear infections, dental pain, or reflux can produce more head-shaking than teething itself, so if he also has fever, ear-pulling, night-waking, or feeding problems, have his ears, mouth, and throat checked.

7. Next steps  
• Email or upload a good video clip to the neurologist’s office portal; often they can tell at a glance whether it is a tic or something that needs EEG monitoring.  
• If spells are frequent or changing, ask whether a longer video-EEG (usually 24–48 hours in hospital or at home) is indicated.  
• If they look like tics and your son is school-aged, no treatment may be needed unless they bother him.  
• If there is functional impairment (dropping objects, difficulty writing or eating because of tremor) the neurologist may discuss medicines used for essential tremor.  
• If reflux or ear pain seems plausible, a short trial of reflux medicine or an ENT check may be worthwhile.

Bottom line  
Persistent tremors you’ve noticed since infancy and this new eye-squeezing/head-shaking spell should be reviewed again by his neurologist, but most episodic movements in children turn out to be benign tics or shuddering attacks rather than seizures.  A clear smartphone video and a careful event log are the quickest way to get you and the neurologist on the same page.

66.question: Hi everyone. I'm a male in my 30's, was directed by a neurologist to take brain EEG. After looking at the test results my doc told me to speak with an epilepsy specialist, which I m going to next month. This got me worried, so I'd like to ask you to help me interpret the EEG because my doc refused to comment on it before I speak with someone specializing in epilepsy...My symptoms are episodic fatigue, feeling disoriented, concentration and thinking difficulty, sometimes trembling/shivering, a general feeling that's hard to describe but I'd say it's feeling very weird... I can't put it in words... I was never diagnosed with epilepsy before. Please see the EEG result below. I translated it into English with Google Translate as I'm not from an English speaking country. I would appreciate any help. Examination conditions: 19 (9) convexity electrodes, 24-channel PL-EEG bi- and monopolar, at rest, with HV and under flickering light In peace: Above the posterior regions of the brain there is a moderately pronounced, amplitude-unstable, around 10 c/s background activity with individual, slower, interrupting waves and, in some cases, faster-frequency ß-waves, which spreads to the centroparietal and temporal areas and shows incomplete reactivity to attempts to open and close eyelids. Background activity predominates over central and temporal brain areas, frontal low voltage f3 activity. In addition, discontinuous dysrhythmias are displayed regionally left temporal mid-frontotemporal as well as over the front brain regions (maximum T3-F7, F3-FP1) as well as here again and again isolated rudimentary sharp wave complexes. Under flickering light: No activation signs. Under hyperventilation: Slight activation of the regional changes described.
66.answer:
I am not looking at the original record and I am not your treating physician, but I can translate the “EEG language” into plain English so you have a better idea of why your neurologist wants an epilepsy-specialist opinion.

1. What an EEG normally looks like  
   • When we are awake, relaxed and have our eyes closed, most people show a 8–12 Hz rhythm over the back of the head (“posterior alpha rhythm”).  
   • When we open the eyes the alpha rhythm usually attenuates (“reactivity”).  
   • Superimposed faster ß activity (13–30 Hz) or some slower waves can be normal.  
   • What worries neurologists are so-called epileptiform discharges – spikes or sharp waves – which are brief, pointed waveforms indicating a tendency of the cortex to fire abnormally.

2. What your report says, item by item  

   Background activity  
   • “Around 10 c/s background activity” – a normal alpha rhythm.  
   • “Incomplete reactivity to opening/closing the eyes” – the alpha did not fully disappear when you opened your eyes. That can happen if someone is drowsy, anxious, taking medication, etc. It is not specifically epileptic.

   Additional rhythms  
   • “Frontal low-voltage ß activity” – again often seen in anxiety, after coffee, or with some medicines; not worrisome.

   The key abnormality  
   • “Discontinuous dysrhythmias regionally left temporal mid-frontotemporal … with isolated rudimentary sharp-wave complexes (max. T3-F7, F3-Fp1).”  
     – Translation: In the electrodes over the left temporal lobe and the adjacent frontal area your EEG occasionally shows brief sharp-looking waveforms.  
     – A “sharp wave” is the textbook form of an epileptiform discharge. They last 70–200 ms (longer than a spike but still sharp).  
     – “Rudimentary” means they are small or not fully developed, so the interpreter is cautious in calling them definitively epileptiform.  
     – “Discontinuous” means they do not appear in a continuous train; they pop up here and there.

   Activation procedures  
   • Hyperventilation provoked “slight activation of the regional changes.” When you breathed fast, a few more of those left-temporal discharges appeared. Hyperventilation often activates epileptiform activity, so this supports (but does not prove) an epileptic tendency.  
   • Photic stimulation (flashing light) did not provoke anything – so there is no evidence of photosensitivity.

3. What this pattern usually means  
   • A normal basic rhythm plus occasional left-temporal sharp waves = focal epileptiform activity arising from the left temporal lobe (and possibly the adjacent frontal lobe).  
   • Roughly 80 % of people who show definite sharp waves on an EEG either have epilepsy or will have a seizure at some point. About 20 % never do. Conversely, up to 50 % of patients with proven epilepsy can have a perfectly normal routine EEG. So the EEG alone can neither confirm nor rule out epilepsy.  
   • Your described spells (brief disorientation, “weird” feeling, difficulty thinking, sometimes tremor) are compatible with focal aware or focal impaired-awareness seizures of temporal origin, but they can also be caused by migraine aura, panic attacks, metabolic problems, medication side-effects, etc.

4. Why the referral to an epilepsy specialist  
   The specialist will:  
   • Take a very detailed history of the events (duration, triggers, recovery, automatisms, déjà-vu, smells, lip-smacking, speech arrest, etc.).  
   • Review the actual EEG tracings (not just the typed summary).  
   • Usually order a brain MRI focused on the temporal lobes.  
   • Decide whether a longer (sleep-deprived, ambulatory or video-EEG) recording is needed.  
   • Weigh the risk/benefit of starting an anti-seizure medication; sometimes they prefer to observe first.  
   • Discuss safety issues (driving, heights, swimming) until the picture is clearer.

5. What you can do meanwhile  
   • Keep a “spell diary”: time of day, duration, what you felt, any triggers, how you felt afterwards. Ask anyone who has seen an episode to describe it.  
   • Record an event on your phone if possible (sounds, appearance, speech).  
   • Get adequate sleep, avoid excess alcohol, and limit recreational drugs, since sleep-deprivation and alcohol withdrawal lower the seizure threshold.  
   • Bring a list of all medications and supplements to the appointment – many can influence EEG or provoke spells (e.g., bupropion, tramadol).  
   • If you must drive or operate dangerous machinery, discuss interim safety advice with your current neurologist or primary doctor.

6. Take-home message  
   • Your EEG shows intermittent sharp waves over the left temporal region. That abnormality is why your doctor wants an epilepsy consultation.  
   • It does not automatically mean you have epilepsy, but it is significant enough that it cannot be ignored.  
   • The specialist visit is the right next step and will probably include further testing. In many people with similar EEG findings, treatment dramatically reduces or abolishes the episodes and greatly improves concentration and fatigue.

I hope this demystifies the report and eases some of the worry while you wait for your appointment. Write down any new questions and take them with you to the epilepsy specialist – the more precise information you can provide, the quicker you will get a clear answer.

I’ll break the answer into four parts:  
A. What each drug does on its own (focusing on the “worrisome” properties)  
B. Where the main overlaps really are (seizures, serotonin, QT, blood pressure/heart rate, sedation/orthostasis, pharmacokinetics)  
C. How big the danger is in everyday numbers and which red flags should make you call or go in  
D. Practical ways to lower the risk and some alternative options you and your psychiatrist could kick around

────────────────────────────  
A. SINGLE-DRUG PROFILES (abbreviated to the issues you asked about)

1. Bupropion 150 mg XL/ SR (Wellbutrin)  
   • Mechanism: Norepinephrine + dopamine re-uptake inhibition; essentially no direct serotonin activity.  
   • “Problem” properties:  – Lowers seizure threshold in a clear dose-related fashion (baseline 0.07 %/yr in general pop → ≈0.1 %/yr at 150 mg, ≈0.4 %/yr at 450 mg).  – Potent CYP-2D6 inhibitor (this matters for Adderall).  – Very mild QT-prolongation signal but not usually clinically important.  

2. Trazodone 100 mg qHS  
   • Mechanism: Serotonin 5-HT2 antagonist + weak SSRI + α-1 blocker + antihistamine.  
   • “Problem” properties:  – Can prolong QT.  – Can cause orthostatic hypotension (α-1 block).  – Small increase in seizure risk (0.06–0.1 %/yr at doses ≤150 mg).  – Additive CNS depression with benzos; additive serotonin activity with anything that releases serotonin.  

3. Mixed amphetamine salts 30 mg qAM ± 30 mg qPM (Adderall)  
   • Mechanism: Releases norepinephrine > dopamine > serotonin; also re-uptake inhibition.  
   • “Problem” properties:  – Raises BP/HR; can precipitate tachycardia.  – Very small but real seizure-threshold reduction (mostly in patients who already have epilepsy).  – Mild serotonergic activity → theoretical serotonin-syndrome partner with trazodone.  

4. Clonazepam 1 mg PRN (Klonopin)  
   • Mechanism: Long-acting benzodiazepine (GABA-A positive modulator).  
   • “Problem” properties:  – Additive respiratory/CNS depression with other sedatives.  – Long half-life → daytime carry-over, cognitive dulling, possible tolerance/dependence.  – Makes orthostatic hypotension from trazodone more noticeable because of blunted autonomic responses.  

────────────────────────────  
B. INTERACTION CLUSTERS

1. Seizure-threshold lowering  
   • Additive effect of bupropion + trazodone + amphetamine (and sleep deprivation, stimulants, heavy EtOH use, electrolyte abnormalities).  
   • No one agent here is a “powerhouse pro-convulsant”; risk is cumulative.  

2. Serotonin syndrome potential  
   • Trazodone (weak SSRI) + amphetamine (weak releaser) = theoretical risk.  
   • Bupropion has negligible serotonergic activity, so it does not add to this.  
   • “Serious” red-flag triad: mental-status change (agitation, confusion), autonomic instability (fever, sweating, tachycardia) and neuromuscular findings (clonus, tremor, hyperreflexia).  

3. QT prolongation / arrhythmia  
   • Trazodone is the main QT offender.  
   • Bupropion has a weak signal; amphetamine actually shortens QT a bit via sympathetic tone.  
   • Electrolyte loss (vomiting, diarrhea, dehydration from stimulants or caffeine) magnifies risk.  

4. Blood-pressure / heart-rate elevation  
   • Amphetamine + bupropion (through NET inhibition) raise BP/HR; bupropion’s CYP2D6 inhibition leaves more amphetamine “active.”  
   • Trazodone pulls the other way (α-1 block → orthostasis). The net can be swings from orthostatic drop when you stand to tachycardia when the stimulant peaks.  

5. Sedation and psychomotor impairment  
   • Trazodone + clonazepam are clearly additive.  
   • If you double trazodone or add 1 mg clonazepam after it, you get about the same psychomotor impairment you would with >0.08 % BAC for 2–6 h.  

6. Pharmacokinetic wrinkle  
   • Bupropion (CYP2D6 inhibitor) can raise the d-amphetamine component ≈20–30 % after a few days of co-administration. That is not catastrophic, but it explains why HR/BP and occasional jitter could creep up.  

────────────────────────────  
C. HOW BIG IS “BIG”?  (Data and rules of thumb)

Seizures  
• General population, age 20–30: ≈0.07 %/year.  
• Bupropion 150 mg: ~0.1 %/year.  
• Add trazodone 100 mg: maybe ~0.15–0.18 %/year (data extrapolated).  
• Add therapeutic amphetamine: not clearly additive in studies, but conservatively say ≤0.2 %/year.  
Put differently: about 1 in 500 users per year. Low, but not zero. The biggest real-world triggers are sleep deprivation, heavy alcohol/benzo withdrawal, eating-disorder–related electrolyte losses and huge bupropion doses—all things you can control.

Serotonin syndrome  
• Incidence with SSRI + stimulant combinations in out-patient studies: <0.1 % over 6–12 months.  
• Vast majority are mild; severe/life-threatening cases usually involve an MAOI, MDMA, or overdoses.

QT prolongation / torsades de pointes  
• Therapeutic trazodone rarely produces torsades unless other risk factors (K+ <3.0, Mg++ <1.8, congenital long-QT, other QT drugs).  
• One large insurance-claims study: torsades/ventricular arrhythmia ≈3 per 10,000 patient-years for trazodone monotherapy. Bupropion/amphetamine do not appreciably add to that.

Orthostasis  
• Up to 25–30 % of people on trazodone get a measurable drop ≥20 mmHg systolic; symptomatic light-headedness in ~5–7 %. Risk is higher if you are dehydrated or take benzodiazepines, alcohol, or cannabis.

In short: a) Yes, the drug-interaction checker flashes red, but the absolute risk at the doses you’re on is low; b) most of the risk is modifiable.

────────────────────────────  
D. RISK-REDUCTION CHECKLIST & ALTERNATIVES

1. Seizure-risk hygiene  
   • Stay hydrated, especially when using caffeine, amphetamine, or psychedelics.  
   • Keep alcohol moderate and avoid abrupt heavy-use → zero-use switches (benzo/alcohol withdrawal is a big seizure trigger).  
   • Try not to miss more than one night of sleep in a row; sleep deprivation alone drops the threshold as much as a 300-mg bupropion dose.  
   • Maintain normal electrolytes—eat, don’t crash-diet.  

2. Vitals/ECG surveillance  
   • Baseline ECG once (QTc, rhythm).  
   • BP/HR log at home for two weeks after any dose change; alert if resting HR persistently >110, SBP >160 or symptomatic palpitations occur.  
   • Repeat ECG if you push trazodone much over 150 mg or add any known QT-prolonging drug (macrolide antibiotics, fluoroquinolones, many antipsychotics).

3. “PRN Klonopin for sleep” guardrails  
   • Aim ≤2–3 nights per week, <10 tabs/month to stave off tolerance.  
   • If you find you “need” it 4+ nights/week for more than two weeks, that is the moment to re-evaluate the entire sleep plan (CBT-I, different med, sleep-study to rule out periodic limb movements, etc.).

4. 2D6 interaction mitigation  
   • If afternoon Adderall starts feeling stronger or longer than it used to, consider lowering that second dose to 10–20 mg.  
   • Or re-split: a.m. 20 mg, p.m. 10 mg, etc.  

5. Non-benzo sleep add-ons to discuss  
   • Doxepin 3–6 mg (Silenor)—minimal anticholinergic at low dose, no seizure-risk additive, no tolerance.  
   • Suvorexant (Belsomra) or lemborexant (Dayvigo)—orexin antagonists, also no seizure-risk issue; very little QT effect.  
   • Ramelteon or just 3-5 mg melatonin 2 h before bed.  
   • Gabapentin 300–600 mg at night (if anxiety/pain component and normal renal function).  

6. Consider CBT-I now rather than later  
   • Gold-standard efficacy is equal to or better than hypnotics at 6- and 12-month follow-up.  
   • Freely available apps (e.g., CBT-i Coach) or an 8-week program; most MD students love the structure.

7. Psychedelics / cannabis caveats  
   • Classic psilocybin can transiently raise BP/HR and has 5-HT2 agonism. Wait at least 24 h after last amphetamine dose and skip nightly trazodone that evening to reduce overlapping serotonin drive.  
   • Cannabis and benzos → additive respiratory/CNS depression. Stay away from additional sedatives if you have taken clonazepam that day.

8. “Doubling the dose” advice  
   • Doubling trazodone from 100 to 200 mg for one night is usually harmless, but it adds more α-1 block (dizzy), more QT, and does NOT linearly deepen sleep.  
   • Doubling bupropion or Adderall on your own is where seizure and BP risk really leap. Strongly recommend not exceeding labelled maxes without formal visit.  

────────────────────────────  
BOTTOM LINE

• Your current combination does carry additive seizure-threshold lowering, but at 150 mg bupropion + 100 mg trazodone + therapeutic amphetamine the absolute yearly risk is still well under 1 %.  
• The bigger day-to-day hazards are: (1) orthostatic dizziness/falls when trazodone + clonazepam stack, (2) creeping tachycardia/BP from the 2D6 interaction, (3) tolerance/dependence if clonazepam use drifts upward.  
• Simple steps—baseline ECG, home BP/HR log, firm limits on clonazepam nights, hydration/sleep hygiene—keep the numbers safely low.  
• If insomnia keeps breaking through, consider adding CBT-I or swapping trazodone/benzo for a non-GABAergic hypnotic rather than escalating doses.  
• As always, any new neuro problem (first-time seizure, sustained heart palpitations, fainting, fever + tremor + agitation) = straight to ED.

Bring these points to your psychiatrist; you’re already doing the right thing by taking a systems-level view of the regimen. Good luck in med school, and stay safe.

68.question: I have been diagnosed with Ped Mal seizures since I was young. It has been triggered at times due to various reasons however those reasons have never been gaming. I ran into a game that gave a warning for Photosensitive epilepsy for its intense flashing however I play many games that have intense flashing but haven't had a episode. I am currently on 250MG of LamoTRIgine and I haven't had an episode since iv started the medication. My question is, is it okay to play that game that gives the warning although I play games similar to it and have no side effct.Im 27 and Im a male. I weigh about 290
68.answer:
I am not your personal physician, so use this information only as general education and talk it over with your own neurologist before you decide what to do.

1. What the warning on the game means  
   • “Photosensitive epilepsy” is a form of reflex epilepsy in which rapidly flashing lights, especially in the 3-30 Hz range, and high-contrast patterns (red/blue, black/white) can trigger a generalized seizure.  
   • Only about 3-5 % of all people with epilepsy have this specific sensitivity. The risk is highest in children/teens with generalized seizure syndromes such as juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, but adults can still be affected.  
   • Because companies cannot know each user’s risk, they place a blanket warning on games that contain a lot of strobe-like visual effects.

2. How this relates to “petit mal” (absence) seizures and lamotrigine  
   • Absence seizures belong to the generalized seizure group, which overlaps with the group that can show photosensitivity, though it is still uncommon.  
   • Lamotrigine is very effective at raising your seizure threshold, but it does not make you 100 % immune to triggers. If a flashing stimulus is strong enough and you are tired, under-medicated, or stressed, a breakthrough seizure is still possible.  
   • Many patients with controlled epilepsy play video games without problems. The key is whether you personally have photic sensitivity.

3. Clues to your personal risk  
   • Have you ever had an EEG that included “photic stimulation” (a strobe at different flash rates)? If so, and if no spikes were provoked, your neurologist probably documented you as “non-photosensitive,” which lowers (but does not eliminate) the risk.  
   • A lifetime of playing other flashy games without an event is reassuring, but not an absolute guarantee. Each game’s pattern, color palette, and flash frequency are different.

4. Practical precautions if you decide to try the game  
   • Play the first session with someone else in the room who can help if you have symptoms.  
   • Sit at least 6-8 feet (≈2 m) from the screen, use the smallest screen that is comfortable, and keep the room well lit to reduce contrast.  
   • Lower the screen brightness, turn on any “reduce flashing” or “accessibility” options the game or console offers, and, if available, enable “dark mode.”  
   • Take 10-minute breaks every 30-45 minutes, especially if you start feeling eyestrain, brief blank spells, or headaches.  
   • Avoid playing when you are sleep-deprived, have missed a dose of lamotrigine, are sick, or have been drinking alcohol—anything that already lowers your seizure threshold.  
   • If you ever get warning signs (brief blank stare, eyelid flutter, odd visual aura, sudden nausea), pause immediately and look away from the screen.

5. When to get professional input first  
   • If you have never had a photic-stimulation EEG, or you are unsure of the result.  
   • If you have had breakthroughs from other visual triggers such as police strobes, flickering fluorescent lights, or fireworks.  
   • If your last seizure was less than two years ago or your medications have recently changed.

6. Bottom line  
   Statistically, the odds are low that you will have a flash-induced seizure if you have played similar games for years without trouble and your lamotrigine has kept you seizure-free. Still, “low” is not “zero,” and the only way to be sure is to ask your treating neurologist, especially if you do not know your EEG photic-sensitivity status. If you do try the game, follow the precautions above and stop immediately if anything feels off.

69.question: 18, male, white, 5'11, 81kg, drink occasionally, smoke cigarettes daily, occasional recreational drug use (usually cannabis). Officially diagnosed with ASD and have motor tics. I've noticed "blanking out" spells where i stare off and become completely unresponsive followed by arm and neck twitching and jerking. This most often happens when i'm drinking or when my sleep schedule becomes unhealthy. The first instances of this i can think of must've been a couple years ago and it seems to have been transient since then, but i've noticed it a few times in the past couple months. What especially alarms me is that i know my cousin (blood-related) has had a few instances of grande-mal seizures after drinking, specifically on an empty stomach. I remain conscious during these spells and still aware of my surroundings, albeit less so than typically, however i find that i cannot respond to anything that goes on around me. The twitching and jerking does not last very long (i would say 2 seconds or so). Could it be epilepsy? Am i overthinking?
69.answer:
What you describe could be as harmless as tic-like spells that get worse when you are sleep-deprived or drinking – but it could also be an epileptic seizure or another neurologic “paroxysmal event.”  From the information you’ve given there is no way to say for certain on the internet; the right next step is a formal medical evaluation.  Here’s why, what the doctor will look for, and what you can do in the meantime.

1. How much of this sounds like epilepsy?  
• Sudden start and stop, always looking essentially the same (stereotyped)  
• Brief loss of responsiveness or ability to speak even though you may feel “awake”  
• Involuntary jerks (myoclonus) of the arms/neck that you cannot stop  
• Clear triggers that lower the seizure threshold: alcohol (especially binge drinking or withdrawal), sleep deprivation, some recreational drugs  
• A blood relative with provoked generalized (“grand mal”) seizures  

Those points all raise the suspicion of focal impaired-awareness seizures or brief myoclonic seizures rather than simple tics.  Some epileptic events last only a few seconds and you can still have partial awareness.

2. What else could it be?  
• Worsening motor tics (often seen in ASD, and tics do flare with stress, fatigue, alcohol). Tics are usually preceded by an urge and are partly suppressible; seizures are not.  
• “Absence” or staring spells unrelated to epilepsy (common in ASD or ADHD).  
• Syncope or near-syncope (brief drop in blood pressure).  
• Psychogenic non-epileptic spells (PNES).  
• Very brief dystonic or choreiform movements from medications or drugs.

3. Why see a doctor?  
Only a firsthand neurologic exam plus testing can sort these out.  The usual work-up:  
• Detailed history and physical exam (bring someone who has seen a spell).  
• Routine EEG; sometimes a prolonged video-EEG (24–72 h) is needed.  
• Brain MRI if suspicion remains.  
• Basic labs (electrolytes, liver function, toxicology if indicated).  

4. Safety until you’re seen  
• Arrange an appointment with your primary care provider or directly with a neurologist; ask for an “urgent” or “first-seizure” slot if you can.  
• Keep a diary: date, time, duration, what you were doing, sleep hours, substances used, how you felt before/after.  A phone video of an event is invaluable.  
• Avoid binge drinking; do not drink on an empty stomach; keep sleep regular.  
• Minimise or stop recreational drugs and cut down/quit smoking if possible—nicotine withdrawal or intoxication can also affect the brain.  
• Do not drive, swim alone, climb, or operate heavy machinery until you are cleared; a brief spell could put you or others at risk.  
• Maintain good hydration and nutrition; abrupt drops in blood sugar can mimic seizures.

5. When to seek emergency care right away  
• Any event lasting longer than 5 minutes.  
• Repeated events without full recovery in between.  
• Loss of consciousness with a fall or head injury.  
• Tongue biting, incontinence, or confusion that lasts >10–15 min.  
• Sudden weakness, trouble speaking, or vision changes (possible stroke/TIA).

6. The family angle  
A relative with alcohol-provoked generalized seizures does not guarantee you have epilepsy, but it does suggest a shared genetic susceptibility to lowered seizure threshold.  That makes it even more important to get evaluated and to limit triggers.

Bottom line  
You are not “overthinking.”  The episodes may turn out to be benign tics, but several red flags make epilepsy a real possibility.  Arrange a medical appointment (ideally neurology), bring a description or video of the spells, and practise strict sleep and alcohol moderation until you get a clear answer.
