70.answer:
I can’t diagnose you over the internet, but I can outline what usually raises concern for true epileptic (focal) seizures, what mimics them, and why you should be examined in-person soon.

1. Why focal (partial) seizures are on the table
•  “Warning” feelings (auras) that are brief, stereotyped, and come out of the blue – nausea, a rising chest sensation, sudden fear/anger, odd smells, déjà-vu–like childhood images.  
•  Behavioural arrest or staring with impaired but not absent awareness: you know what’s happening, but answers are slow, fragmented or you can’t move even though you try.  
•  Episodes last seconds to a few minutes, stop abruptly, and leave you tired/confused (post-ictal period).  
•  Temporal relationship with sleep-deprivation / fatty meals / marijuana – common seizure triggers.  
•  No external “gain” or willful control is apparent; most people who truly seize worry they are “faking”, exactly as you describe.

These features are typical of focal-onset seizures from the temporal lobe. They do not prove epilepsy, but they are suspicious enough to justify formal investigation.

2. Migraine aura?
•  Migraine aura usually builds over ≥5 min, lasts 5-60 min, then either resolves or leads into headache.  
•  Auras are often visual (zig-zag lines, blank spots), sensory (pins-and-needles) or language disturbance, but they spread gradually, not suddenly.  
•  Nausea and fatigue can accompany migraine, but an abrupt emotionally-charged “rush” with behavioural arrest is less typical.  
•  You do have headaches and migraines, so migraine aura can’t be ruled out, but the episodes you describe fit seizures better than classic aura.

3. Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (PNES, dissociative events)
•  Very common in people with anxiety/depression and in families where another member has PNES.  
•  Awareness usually fluctuates; movements or vocalisations may be prolonged, dramatic, or triggered by emotional stress; post-ictal confusion is often lengthy.  
•  Your events are brief, stereotyped, and include hard-to-fake neurologic phenomena (sudden speech arrest, déjà-vu, electric “zap”), so PNES is not impossible but less likely than epilepsy.

4. Your medications and lifestyle matter
•  Bupropion is one of the few antidepressants that lowers the seizure threshold; 400 mg/day is near the maximum. Being 120 lb increases risk.  
•  Marijuana can precipitate seizures in some users.  
•  Irregular sleep, missed meals, and rapid weight loss are additional seizure triggers.  
•  Hydroxyzine, buspirone and glycopyrrolate do not themselves provoke seizures but can cloud thinking and complicate the picture.

5. What needs to be done
Make an appointment with your primary care clinician or go directly to a neurologist/epilepsy clinic for:
•  Detailed history from you and your girlfriend (bring written descriptions, times, triggers).  
•  Routine EEG and, ideally, prolonged video-EEG monitoring; this is the gold standard to separate epileptic from non-epileptic events.  
•  Brain MRI to look for a structural focus (especially in the temporal lobe).  
•  Basic labs: electrolytes, glucose, calcium, magnesium, liver/kidney function, thyroid panel, iron studies (weight loss, exercise intolerance), vitamin D replacement.  
•  Medication review: you and your prescriber might lower or switch off bupropion until seizures are ruled out.

6. While waiting
•  Keep a seizure diary: date/time, what you were doing, warning, duration, recovery, possible trigger, whether anyone witnessed it.  
•  Ask your girlfriend to video an episode if it can be done safely.  
•  Ensure adequate sleep, regular meals, hydration, limit/stop marijuana and alcohol.  
•  Do not drive, swim alone, climb heights, or operate heavy machinery until cleared.  
•  Carry a medical ID and let close contacts know what to do if you lose consciousness (>5 min, call 911).

7. Are you “making it up”?
People with both epileptic and non-epileptic seizures often fear they are inventing their symptoms. Objective testing (video-EEG) is the only way to settle the question, and either outcome is legitimate: BOTH conditions are involuntary, real, and treatable.

Bottom line
Your description is concerning for focal seizures, and bupropion plus other triggers increase that risk. The correct next step is a prompt in-person evaluation with EEG/MRI and medication review; don’t try to self-diagnose or downplay it.

71.question: I was recently diagnosed with EA2 after an unexpected hospital stay. Of course I have been researching the condition, and came across 4-AP. I currently take Diamox(500 mg BID) and prednisone(5 mg), which help, but if I begin to have an episode I have to take more and more until it finally stops. My current neurologist won’t really discuss the medication with me, which I was rather surprised by. He has really been pushing for me to come off of the prednisone, even though it is the only thing that really helps me. He wants me to go to a movement clinic first, but the only local one doesn’t take my insurance. Even if I get a PA from my insurance, there is no telling how long it will take before I can get an appointment after. I was really hoping I could get on the 4-AP and come off of the prednisone.
71.answer:
I’m sorry you’re having to navigate this without much guidance.  Below is a summary of what is known about 4-aminopyridine (4-AP), how it is used in Episodic Ataxia Type 2 (EA2), safety points, practical “how-to-get-it” information, and some talking points you can take back to any physician you see.  Use it only as background for a conversation with a clinician who knows your full history.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Quick refresher on EA2 and why 4-AP makes sense
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  EA2 is usually caused by loss-of-function mutations in the calcium-channel gene CACNA1A.  
•  Attacks arise because cerebellar “Pacemaker” cells (Purkinje cells) become electrically unstable.  
•  4-AP is a potassium-channel blocker.  By blocking outward K⁺ current it prolongs the action potential in those neurons, partly restoring the firing pattern.  
•  A series of small but consistent studies (Katz 2004; Strupp 2011; Kalla 2017; Leider 2020, etc.) show roughly a 50–90 % reduction in attack frequency and/or severity in many EA2 patients.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Evidence base at a glance
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Katz et al., 2004 (Neurology): 5 patients with genetically proven EA2 given 4-AP IR 5 mg qid → attacks fell from median 11 → 0.  
•  Strupp et al., 2011 (Lancet Neurology): 10 patients in randomized crossover; attack frequency down 79 % on 4-AP ER 10 mg bid versus placebo.  
•  Multicentre observational series (Kalla 2017, 68 pts): 4-AP responders 84 %; >70 % able to decrease or stop acetazolamide; no serious adverse events when dose ≤30 mg/day.  

Diamox (acetazolamide) remains first-line because it is cheap, well known, and helps about 50–60 % of patients, but when it fails or causes kidney stones, 4-AP is now widely considered the next logical option.

Prednisone is not a standard EA2 therapy.  If you improve on steroids it’s usually taken as an “unspecific stabilizer” rather than disease-specific treatment, and long-term risks (bone loss, diabetes, infection, weight gain, cataracts, adrenal suppression) pile up quickly.  That’s why your neurologist is eager to taper it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Practical prescribing details
--------------------------------------------------------------------
FORMULATIONS  
A.  Extended-release dalfampridine 10 mg tablets (branded Ampyra, generic available in the US). FDA-approved for MS, off-label for EA2.  
B.  Immediate-release 4--AP compounded capsules (usually 5 mg, 7.5 mg, or 10 mg) prepared by a specialty pharmacy.  Much cheaper.

TYPICAL STARTING REGIMEN  
•  ER tablets: 10 mg twice daily, 12 h apart (7 am / 7 pm is common).  
•  Compounded IR: 5 mg 3–4 × daily while awake; after 1–2 weeks can titrate upward to 7.5 mg or 10 mg per dose, max ~30 mg/day in most protocols.  

MONITORING / CONTRAINDICATIONS  
•  Renal function: dalfampridine is renally cleared.  Do not use if creatinine clearance <50 mL/min.  
•  Seizure history: absolute contraindication; risk rises sharply when blood levels exceed those reached at 10 mg bid.  
•  Pregnancy data are limited – usually avoided.  
•  Side-effects: perioral or fingertip tingling, dizziness, insomnia, nausea, anxiety.  They are generally mild and dose-related.  Serious events (seizure) are rare at ≤20 mg/day (ER) or ≤30 mg/day (IR).

RESCUE VS. MAINTENANCE  
Some patients take it continuously and report far fewer attacks.  Others stay on Diamox daily and keep a fast-acting IR 4-AP dose (10–15 mg) to abort a breakthrough episode.  That strategy is published (López-Soto 2016) but needs a physician’s OK because one large IR dose >15 mg can push serum levels into the seizure-risk range.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Obtaining the medication
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Commercial ER (dalfampridine)  
   •  Most neurologists simply e-prescribe “dalfampridine ER 10 mg, 1 tab orally every 12 h” to any retail pharmacy.  
   •  Cash price is high (~$1,500/month) but the manufacturer (Acorda) and several generic companies have discount cards that drop the copay to <$25 for many insured patients.  Medicare patients must use generic + Part D exceptions or move to compounded IR.

2.  Compounded IR 4-AP  
   •  Requires a written prescription to a compounding pharmacy.  Example wording:  
     “4-aminopyridine 5 mg capsules, #90, take 1 capsule by mouth every 6 hours while awake.  May increase in 1-week increments up to 10 mg 3×/day if tolerated.”  
   •  Price: typically $50–90/month.  Some insurance will reimburse with prior authorization; many patients pay out-of-pocket because the price is already lower than a branded copay.

3.  “Research grade” 4-AP powder sold on the Internet is NOT recommended; dosing errors and purity issues are common.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  How to bring this up with a neurologist
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Highlight guideline support:  The International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society (MDS) treatment algorithm (Kalla 2023) lists carbonic-anhydrase inhibitors first, potassium-channel blockers second.  
•  Offer literature: print the Lancet Neurology 2011 randomized trial or the 2017 multi-centre study (PubMed IDs 21208835 and 28259887).  
•  Emphasize safety ceiling: seizure risk is negligible at ≤10 mg ER bid or ≤30 mg/day IR provided eGFR >50 and no epilepsy.  
•  Reassure about monitoring: baseline CMP, follow-up in 4–6 weeks.  No fancy labs needed.  
•  If the issue is insurance logistics, suggest compounded formulation—no prior authorization hoops, same pharmacy can ship to home.  
•  If your current neurologist is still hesitant, you can ask, “Would you be comfortable letting me try a 4-week trial from a compounding pharmacy while we work on a movement-disorders referral?”

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Coming off prednisone
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because you have been on 5 mg chronically AND occasionally escalate the dose, adrenal suppression is possible.  Do not stop it abruptly.  A typical taper once an alternative therapy is in place might be: 5 mg daily 2 weeks → 2.5 mg daily 2 weeks → 2.5 mg every other day 2 weeks → stop, but that must be individualized.  Bone density protection (calcium 1,200 mg, vitamin D 1,000–2,000 IU daily and possibly a DEXA scan) is advised during ANY steroid course longer than 3 months.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  Other tips while you search for the right regimen
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Common attack triggers: psychological stress, sleep deprivation, heat, alcohol, excess caffeine; logging these sometimes reduces frequency more than medication changes.  
•  Gentle, regular aerobic exercise and proprioceptive physical-therapy drills improve baseline steadiness in many EA2 patients.  
•  Rescue options if an attack breaks through: 5–10 mg diazepam or 0.5 mg clonazepam can sometimes abort it (used sparingly).  
•  Migraine prophylaxis doubles as EA2 benefit in some cases (topiramate, verapamil).  
•  Genetic counselling: CACNA1A disorders have ~50 % inheritance; identifying the variant can open genotype-specific trials.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
8.  Key references to print / bookmark
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Strupp M. et al. “Effects of dalfampridine in EA2: a randomized, placebo-controlled crossover trial.” Lancet Neurol 2011;10:462-468.  
•  Kalla R. et al. “4-Aminopyridine in EA2 and other genetic ataxias: a multicentre observational study.” J Neurol 2017;264:984-994.  
•  MDS Evidence-based Clinical Practice Guideline for the Treatment of the Ataxias, 2023.  
•  Acorda Therapeutics. Ampyra (dalfampridine) Prescribing Information, 2023.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
--------------------------------------------------------------------
4-AP has a solid (though still “small-study”) track record for EA2, is relatively safe at the doses used for this condition, and is easier to obtain than many physicians realize—especially through compounding pharmacies.  Presenting the data and a clear plan usually helps a hesitant neurologist feel comfortable giving you a trial.  If that still doesn’t happen, tele-medicine consults with an ataxia specialist (UCLA, Johns Hopkins, Baylor, Mass General, etc.) who can then co-manage the prescription are increasingly accepted by insurers.

I hope this equips you to push for the therapy you need and, ideally, to wean off long-term prednisone.  Best of luck, and feel free to circle back with more questions as you move forward.

72.question: Few nights ago I woke up around 4 am, it happens often to me. What was weird was my consciousness. I was trying to go back to sleep but I had an instinct reaction like when you are drowing that I have to not go back to sleep.As I was getting more awake something felt odd. It was impossible to have a complex thought, thinking was liking trying to hold water with one hand. I was feeling like my ability to think was malfunctioning, like glitching. I was like anable to wake myself more than a kind of pure reaction state.I got up, walked to the living room, trying to wake myself up, nothing. It is hard to describe, it was like my thoughts were erasing as proceeded. Like I was writing on burning paper.I tried to go back to bed thinking going back to sleep would help. I hold my wife to help me calming as I was trying to fall asleep again.The instinct kicks harder, it was like if I was keep going sleeping I would lose that ability to think, my thoughts were getting simplier and simplier, then I noticed that the voice most people hear as they think was completly silent.. a deafning silent.I feel really weird I try to relax, to clear my thinking, I go again in the living room to keep my eyes open, it feels likes my thoughts are not recognized as mine anymore, I do not control my thinking, I lost the ability to, things get chaotic, confused. I try to remind myself memories to keep a thread to reality, it helps. I succeed to get more complex thoughts, I realise that emotions are back as I didn't noticed I kinda lost it for a moment, was it the panic, the fight or flee mode ? I feel flooded by these emotions, I cry.Then it took like 15 minutes to come back to normal, I am in a very confused state and go back to sleep.Any idea what was that ?
72.answer:
What you describe is very reminiscent of a phenomenon doctors call a “confusional arousal” (also nick-named sleep-drunkenness or severe sleep inertia).  
In plain language it means you were partly awake and able to move around, but the higher-order parts of your brain (those that let you think in an organized, self-reflective way) were still stuck in deep-sleep mode.  
Typical features – most of which you mention – are:

• Sudden awakening out of deep (slow-wave/N3) sleep, often in the first half of the night or around the first big slow-wave period (roughly 1–4 a.m.).  
• Marked disorientation or a feeling that “my thoughts won’t stay put,” can’t plan, can’t hold a chain of reasoning.  
• Loss of the normal inner monologue, sense that thoughts are “not mine” or are evaporating.  
• Ability to sit up, get out of bed, even walk, but behaviour is largely automatic or reactive.  
• Emotional flattening at first, then a surge of fear or distress once the cortex finally “comes online.”  
• Duration from a few minutes to ~30 minutes, after which thinking, memory and emotions snap back to normal and the episode is often followed by sleep or intense fatigue.  
• Often precipitated by sleep deprivation, irregular schedule, stress, alcohol, certain medications, or being abruptly awakened (alarm, noise, baby, etc.).  

Why it feels so strange  
During slow-wave sleep, large areas of the frontal and parietal cortex are offline. If you are yanked out of that stage too abruptly, the brain-stem and motor circuits can wake up before the pre-frontal cortex does. You can move and react (the “fight-or-flight” circuitry is already awake) but the networks that create working memory, self-talk, coherent thought, and emotional nuance are still inhibited. As those networks gradually re-activate, you experience a few minutes of extremely patchy consciousness—exactly the “burning paper” or “water slipping through my fingers” you describe.  

Could it be something else?  
• Nocturnal (focal) seizures can produce post-ictal confusion that looks similar, but they usually involve at least a few seconds of abnormal movements, stiffening, automatisms, tongue-biting, incontinence, or complete amnesia for the event.  
• A panic attack on awakening produces intense fear, palpitations, hyperventilation, but thought-blocking or “no inner voice” is less typical.  
• Hypoglycaemia, transient ischaemic attack, or medication/intoxicant effects are possible but would not clear quite so neatly once you fully awaken unless you correct the underlying problem (glucose, blood flow, drug level, etc.).  

Red-flag signs that would warrant prompt medical review  
• Recurrent episodes with injuries, bed-wetting, tongue-biting, or loss of bladder control.  
• Witnessed jerking or stiffening movements.  
• Persistent daytime confusion, headache, or memory gaps.  
• Known diabetes, cardiovascular risk factors, or new neurological deficits (weakness, slurred speech, visual loss).  

What you can do  
1. Prioritise a regular sleep schedule and adequate total sleep time. Sleep-deprivation is the biggest trigger.  
2. Limit abrupt awakenings when possible: gentle alarm tones, dim lights, avoid being startled awake by phone alerts.  
3. Minimise alcohol and sedating medication close to bedtime.  
4. Keep the bedroom cool, dark, quiet; use earplugs or white-noise if noises wake you.  
5. If you do wake confused, sit somewhere safe, turn on a soft light, breathe slowly, give yourself 10–15 minutes; the fog usually clears on its own.  
6. If episodes become frequent, violent, or unclear, keep a sleep diary and see your GP or a sleep-medicine/neurology clinic; they may order an overnight polysomnography or EEG to rule out seizures or other parasomnias.  

Bottom line  
The single episode you outline fits classic “confusional arousal.” It is usually benign, but because other conditions can look similar, monitor for recurrence and any red-flag features. If anything about the story changes, gets more severe, or you simply need reassurance, have it evaluated in person.

73.question: (20F) 5’3” 134lbs Drink/Smoke occasionally, every other day Zyrtec, south asianThis has been a daily issue for ~ a decade. I sleep and wake up about the same times. I pee 2-4 times in the night even if I don’t drink after 9:30pm.Sometimes I can feel myself “shutting down”, or falling asleep and my body starting to paralyze. I hear crazy noises (exploding head syndrome). Mostly 1-3 times i am in a dream and cannot move my body at all. Feels like a magnet is preventing me from moving my head left to right. I’m crying and screaming to lift a finger.It is so exhausting. I wake up fatigued and usually anxious. My brain fools me into thinking I’m free the first time, but then I’m paralyzed again. This is normal dreams + nightmares.I have major depression and anxiety. I heard that epilepsy can make you feel paralyzed in your sleep, and have trouble with memory. I have short-term memory loss past few years. I never have bruises or anything though. Please help!
73.answer:
What you describe sounds frightening but, taken one symptom at a time, there is a fairly clear differential diagnosis and an organized way to have it evaluated.

1. Recurrent “can’t-move, can’t-scream, feel-a-magnet-holding-me” events  
   • This is classic isolated sleep-paralysis: your brain is already in (or still in) REM sleep, when all skeletal muscles are switched off, while your “thinking” consciousness has woken up.  
   • The buzzing/roaring/“exploding-head” sounds, sense of a presence, the feeling you finally move and then are “pulled back,” are all textbook REM-intrusion phenomena.  
   • They are NOT epileptic seizures. Seizures during sleep almost always involve rhythmic jerking, body stiffening, tongue-biting, incontinence or post-event confusion that other people notice. Sleep paralysis is silent and motionless to an observer.  
   • Things that make sleep paralysis more common: sleep deprivation, irregular schedule, anxiety/depression, certain drugs/alcohol, sleeping on your back, untreated obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA), and narcolepsy.

2. Night-time urination (nocturia) 2-4× every night for many years  
   • Common causes in a 20-year-old woman:  
     – Excessive evening fluid or caffeine (you already restrict fluids).  
     – Small bladder capacity / overactive bladder.  
     – Urinary-tract infection or interstitial cystitis.  
     – Diabetes mellitus or diabetes insipidus.  
     – Kidney or electrolyte disorders.  
     – Sleep fragmentation from OSA: every time the airway closes you release atrial natriuretic peptide and make urine. Thin women can still have OSA, especially in some Asian populations with smaller jaws.  
   • A simple first step is a urinalysis, fasting glucose, serum electrolytes, and (ideally) an overnight sleep study, because treating the underlying cause stops the awakenings and will improve the paralysis/nightmares.

3. Fatigue, memory lapses, anxiety/depression  
   • All three are strongly linked to poor-quality, fractured sleep.  
   • Antihistamines such as cetirizine can make you sedated in the day and groggy on waking, so try taking it in the morning instead of night if allergy control allows.  
   • Alcohol and cannabis within 3–4 h of bed suppress deep sleep and REM and rebound later in the night, worsening paralysis and nightmares.

Are these features of narcolepsy?  
– Narcolepsy is defined by irresistible daytime sleep attacks and usually cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness with laughter or emotion). If you have severe daytime sleepiness or cataplexy, ask for a polysomnogram followed by a Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT). Otherwise your picture fits “isolated sleep-paralysis + fragmented sleep.”

Could it still be epilepsy?  
– Very unlikely with your description. A neurologist can still order an EEG if anything about the history changes (injury, bitten tongue, confusion, witnessed jerks).

What you can do now

A. See your primary-care clinician for:  
   • Physical exam, blood pressure, weight, throat/neck assessment.  
   • Urinalysis, serum glucose, kidney panel.  
   • Consider HbA1c, thyroid panel, serum electrolytes & calcium.  
   • Referral to a sleep-medicine clinic for overnight polysomnography ± MSLT.  
   • If nocturnal seizures are a persistent worry, mention it; an extended EEG can be added to the sleep study.

B. Sleep-hygiene & behavioral steps  
   • Aim for a strict 7–9 h sleep window; no catching-up weekends.  
   • Bed only for sleep/sex; if awake >20 min get up, dull activity, then return.  
   • No caffeine after 2 pm, no nicotine/alcohol/cannabis within 4 h of bed.  
   • Shift cetirizine to morning; avoid other sedating antihistamines at night.  
   • Side-sleeping reduces both OSA and sleep paralysis. Wedge a pillow behind your back or try a commercial positional-sleep device.  
   • Wind-down routine: dim lights, screens off 60 min before bed, 10 min of relaxation breathing or progressive muscle relaxation.  
   • Stress/mental-health work: continue or start CBT, mindfulness or medication for anxiety/depression as advised by your physician. Treating mood improves sleep-paralysis frequency dramatically.

C. Managing a paralysis episode  
   • Remind yourself: “This is benign REM sleep; it will pass.”  
   • Try small distal movements (wiggle a toe, move the tongue) rather than large ones; this often breaks the atonia faster.  
   • Regulate breathing—slow, steady exhalations; this reduces panic.  
   • Keep a dim night-light so the room looks the same when the event ends; that helps orientation and calm.

When to seek urgent help  
   • Loss of urine or stool, bitten tongue, injuries, or waking on the floor.  
   • Partner or roommate witnesses repetitive jerking or you stop breathing.  
   • Intense daytime sleep attacks you cannot resist (possible narcolepsy).  
   • Polydipsia, weight loss, or glucose/ketones in urine (possible diabetes).  
   • Mood becomes suicidal or you start hearing voices while fully awake.

Bottom line  
Your symptoms are most consistent with chronic fragmented sleep (possibly from OSA or nocturia) producing isolated sleep paralysis/hypnagogic hallucinations. Epilepsy is unlikely. Start with basic labs and a sleep-medicine referral; improve sleep hygiene and treat depression/anxiety. Most people see a marked drop in sleep-paralysis episodes once underlying sleep disruption is corrected.

74.question: Hey everyone,So my epilepsy meds were changed a few months ago mainly due to my LFT showing very high levels but also because the drug (Tegretol) was no longer working to its potential. So as of now I'm on Keppra and Topamax which means all my AED drugs filter through the Kidneys. Originally I was told I wouldn't need blood tests but at my latest appointment, I was told they definitely will do them. I tried to ask the Specist and NP this in the appointment and they wouldn't really tell me whether there not sure at the moment I don't know. Originally I was getting LFT, CBC or (FBC) and therapeutic drug levels test.My question is with blood testing now likely to continue is it likely they will continue with the LFT and just add on a renal panel? How would this likely play out?
74.answer:
(I’m not your doctor, of course, but this is the usual approach most neurologists and primary-care doctors follow with the two medicines you’re now on.)

1. Why the lab strategy changes  
   • Carbamazepine (Tegretol) is metabolised in the liver and can injure it or affect bone-marrow cells, so people on it typically get:  
     – LFT (liver-function tests)  
     – CBC / FBC (to look for low white cells, platelets, etc.)  
     – Carbamazepine blood level  
   • Levetiracetam (Keppra) and topiramate (Topamax) are cleared mainly by the kidneys, do not usually damage the liver and have blood levels that correlate poorly with clinical benefit, so the monitoring emphasis shifts to kidney function and electrolytes.

2. What is usually checked with Keppra + Topamax  
   Baseline (before or soon after the switch)  
     • Serum creatinine, BUN and calculated eGFR – to be sure kidney function is normal.  
     • Serum bicarbonate / CO₂ – topiramate can cause a chronic, mild metabolic acidosis.  
     • Serum electrolytes (especially sodium, potassium, chloride).  
     • CBC – both drugs can very occasionally lower blood counts.  
     • Urinalysis if the patient has a history of kidney stones (Topamax increases stone risk).  
     • LFT once to confirm that the previously elevated enzymes have come down after stopping carbamazepine.

   Follow-up schedule most centres use  
     • Creatinine/eGFR and electrolytes (including bicarbonate) every 6–12 months, or sooner if dose changes or if you develop symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath, or kidney-stone pain.  
     • CBC yearly or if you feel unusually tired, bruise easily, or have frequent infections.  
     • LFT: many clinicians drop it after the first “post-carbamazepine” normal result; some continue it annually out of habit or if you have other liver risk factors (alcohol use, fatty liver, hepatitis, etc.).  
     • Routine “drug levels” are not usually done for either Keppra or Topamax. They may be ordered only if seizures suddenly break through, if side-effects appear at low doses, or if the kidneys start to fail and the doctor needs to guide dose reduction.

3. Why your team might still draw an LFT panel  
   • Your liver enzymes were elevated before; they’ll want at least one normal value to document recovery.  
   • LFT is bundled into many “general-chemistry” panels, so some laboratories run it automatically when the doctor orders “electrolytes + creatinine,” meaning you might still see AST/ALT on the report even though the focus is really on the renal numbers.

4. Practical takeaway for you  
   • Expect your blood to be checked 1–2 times in the first year after the switch (sooner if doses change), then every 6–12 months.  
   • The panel will almost certainly include creatinine/eGFR, electrolytes and bicarbonate.  
   • A CBC is quite likely.  
   • LFT may or may not remain on the requisition after your enzymes normalise; if it does, it is usually just “extra information” rather than targeted monitoring.  
   • If you get kidney stones, metabolic acidosis symptoms, or worsening kidney function, the testing frequency goes up.

If you’d like exact details, ask the neurologist or the nurse practitioner something like, “For these two medicines, which labs will you be following long-term—kidney, liver, CBC, anything else—and how often?” That usually prompts a clear, step-by-step answer.

75.question: 25 FtMbBipolar 1, TL epilepsy, OCD, ASD 200mg sertraline 200mg topamax 2x 30mg abilify 3mg risperidone 100mcg clonidine2 pumps testogel 40mg somac 1000iu vitamin d 148cm 90kg I have partial seizures (confirmed) and I think myoclonic seizures (not confirmed but this is what I think they are) My left eye has been sticking closed a few times a day for about 10 seconds each time (maybe less time but that’s a general time) I’m just concerned this is a a new epilepsy symptom. Should I see my neurologist or GP about this It’s been happening for about 2 months now, I think I have Blepharospasm in my left eye, could this be related to my epilepsy?
75.answer:
What you describe sounds more like an involuntary spasm of the eyelid muscles (blepharospasm or a hemifacial spasm) than an epileptic event, but only an examination can say for sure.  
Why it is probably not a seizure  
• Focal motor seizures that involve the eyelid usually produce very rapid blinking or fluttering; they seldom keep the lid tightly shut for a full-10-second block of time and then stop.  
• Seizures of the “eyelid myoclonia” type are almost always bilateral and brief, and they are classically triggered by closing the eyes, not by the eye suddenly closing on its own.  
• You stay aware and can describe the event in detail (awareness often, though not always, changes during seizures).

Why a spasm is plausible  
• Blepharospasm can start in one eye, last seconds at a time, and recur many times a day.  
• Aripiprazole (Abilify), risperidone, and even topiramate (Topamax) are all reported to cause dystonias or tardive dyskinesia, whose very first sign may be an intermittent eyelid spasm.  
• Hemifacial spasm (spasm of all the muscles on one side of the face, usually starting with the eye) can also present exactly this way; it is not related to epilepsy and is sometimes precipitated by medications, stress or an irritated facial nerve.

Other possibilities  
• Dry eye/blepharitis can make the lid feel “stuck,” but that is usually relieved by blinking or artificial tears and is not a forceful closure.  
• Migraine aura can occasionally give transient eyelid weakness, but you would usually see other aura symptoms as well.  

What you should do  
1. Don’t stop or change any of your medicines on your own; that can provoke both psychiatric relapse and seizure breakthrough.  
2. Video one or two of the episodes on your phone if you can (close-up of the eye and your face, plus your hand or a pen moving so the examiner can see whether the limb is still during the eye event). A video is enormously helpful to a neurologist.  
3. Arrange an appointment with your neurologist (ideally) or your GP if the neurologist cannot see you quickly. A new focal facial event in someone with epilepsy and on several neuro-active medications deserves a neurologic review.  
   • The neurologist can look for subtle hemifacial spasm, do a brief exam for tardive dyskinesia, and decide whether an EEG or medication adjustment is needed.  
4. At the same time, let the psychiatrist who prescribed Abilify/Risperidone know; if this is a drug-induced dystonia, reducing the dose, adding an anticholinergic medicine, or switching antipsychotics sooner rather than later can keep the problem from becoming permanent.  

When to seek urgent care  
• If the spasm spreads to involve part of the mouth or face and lasts minutes.  
• If you develop any weakness, numbness, double vision, speech change or prolonged confusion with it.  
• If your seizure pattern suddenly changes (more frequent, longer, new loss of awareness, falls).

Bottom line  
A few-seconds-long unilateral lid closure happening many times a day for two months is much more suggestive of blepharospasm/hemifacial spasm or a medication-related dystonia than of a new seizure type. It is still a neurologic issue that should be looked at promptly, so book with your neurologist (and loop in your psychiatrist) rather than simply wait.

76.question: Hi,My six month old son had his first infantile spasm yesterday. Took him to the ER (Canada), they performed an ultrasound which came back clean and booked an EEG for two weeks Tuesday.We are likely going to go over to the states Monday or Tuesday and pay out of pocket to get a quicker EEG as we are terrified of West syndrome and the sooner you can start treatment, the better.Tuberous sclerosis often occurs in tandem with West syndrome and although he doesn't show any signs of it now, it's often not possible to diagnose until later in life.It looks like a genetic mutation is responsible for TS so I'm wondering if this would be called out in a 23andme report? Obviously in theory it could be, just wondering if someone knows for sure.
76.answer:
I’m not a physician, and this is not medical or legal advice.  The following is general information only; you must rely on your son’s treating physicians and (if indicated) a medical geneticist for diagnostic and treatment decisions.

1. 23andMe is not a diagnostic test for tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC).  
   • The health reports that 23andMe is allowed to return by the U-S. FDA cover only a small, pre-approved list of conditions (e.g., certain pharmacogenetic traits, a few recessive-carrier states, late-onset AD diseases such as BRCA-related cancer, APOE/Alzheimer’s risk, etc.).  
   • Tuberous sclerosis is not on that list, so you would not receive a positive or negative “TSC result” in the consumer reports.  
   • The raw data file you can download from 23andMe contains about 600–700 k single-nucleotide positions. That is <1 % of the 3.2 billion bases in the genome and covers only scattered spots within TSC1 and TSC2. Most pathogenic TSC variants are not included in those scattered positions, so a negative 23andMe raw-data “scan” is meaningless for ruling TSC out.  
   • Conversely, if 23andMe happened to genotype a known pathogenic variant at one of its probe locations you might see it in the raw data, but it would appear only as an uninterpreted “A/G” call. You would still need a CLIA-certified, clinically validated test to confirm it. In short, 23andMe cannot be used to diagnose or exclude TSC.

2. How TSC is usually tested.  
   • Clinical exome sequencing or a targeted “epilepsy panel” that fully sequences TSC1 and TSC2 (and dozens of other genes) is the standard genetic work-up when TSC or other monogenic epilepsy disorders are on the differential.  
   • These tests are ordered through a certified medical laboratory and interpreted by a medical geneticist. Turnaround is usually 14–28 days for a stat panel, sometimes faster for a single-gene test.

3. Imaging.  
   • Cranial ultrasound is essentially normal in many infants with TSC; MRI with thin-section T2/FLAIR is more sensitive for cortical tubers and subependymal nodules.  
   • If TSC is suspected clinically, your son’s neurology team will probably recommend a brain MRI, renal ultrasound and cardiac echocardiogram even if the genetic testing is still in progress.

4. Infantile spasms (West syndrome).  
   • You are correct that time to treatment matters; the goal is to start therapy (ACTH, high-dose oral steroids or vigabatrin) as soon as the diagnosis is confirmed on EEG.  
   • In Canada, many centers have an emergency pathway for inpatient EEG if infantile spasms are suspected; if you have not already done so, tell your pediatrician or ER physician that the events looked like spasms and ask if an expedited EEG can be arranged locally.  
   • If you do cross the border for a private EEG, bring a brief, concise referral letter and any smartphone videos of the events; U.S. centers will likely still repeat the EEG or admit for overnight video-EEG monitoring before initiating treatment.

Key takeaway: A consumer test such as 23andMe cannot meaningfully confirm or exclude tuberous sclerosis; a clinically ordered genetic panel or whole-exome sequencing is required, and good pediatric neurology services will handle this as part of the work-up. Continue to press for the earliest possible EEG and specialty evaluation, but spend your resources on clinically validated testing rather than consumer ancestry tests.

77.question: When I woke up yesterday my back was so extremely tight it was hard to move. My head felt really weird, like waves were washing over it from my forehead towards the middle of my head. After that my arms and legs felt tingly the way Restless Leg Syndrome is described. My heart felt super weird (normal EKG last time I went to the ER for this) and I stopped breathing a few times, it was like I had to remember and force myself to breathe again. I got very tired at one point and think I passed out. Woke up what seemed like a few moments later a little confused.This happens every time my cycle comes on but I can usually prevent it by taking ibuprofen before or as soon as cramps start. This time I didn't have any cramps to warn me but I did not have the usual near-constant vomiting so, was able to eat and take ibuprofen. The symptoms subsided about 90% with the tingling still faintly present.I've been to the ER for this, the first time the doctor eventually gave me Ativan which helped like immediately, the second time I had to damn near beg for it. My esophagus tore and I started to vomit blood because nothing else would stop it.Could this be Catamenial Epilepsy? I have no history of Epilepsy in my family.Edit: In past episodes, I have been told I would have bouts of groaning or mumbling but I do not remember 90% of that.
77.answer:
I can’t tell you exactly what is happening to you, but I can give you some context for the term “catamenial epilepsy,” explain why what you describe only partly fits that picture, list some other (more common) possibilities, and outline what sort of follow-up would usually be recommended.

1. What “catamenial epilepsy” actually is  
• It is not a separate disease; it is simply the name neurologists give to the well-known tendency of pre-existing epilepsy to flare around certain points in the menstrual cycle.  
• By definition, the person already has an established seizure disorder; the menses do not “create” epilepsy out of nothing.  
• The usual pattern is an increase in recognizable seizures (generalized convulsions or focal seizures with clear EEG correlates) in the few days before bleeding and/or around ovulation.  
• The vast majority of women who experience catamenial epilepsy have abnormal inter-ictal EEGs when they are NOT having a spell.

Because you have no prior epilepsy diagnosis or abnormal EEG, “catamenial epilepsy” is lower on the list, though new-onset epilepsy is still possible and should be ruled out formally.

2. Do your spells sound like epileptic seizures?  
Typical epileptic events (even focal ones) usually show SOME of the following:
• Sudden, involuntary loss of consciousness or awareness  
• Rhythmic shaking or stiffening of part or all of the body  
• Eyes deviating to one side or rolling back  
• Tongue biting, urinary incontinence  
• Post-ictal confusion that lasts minutes to hours  
• Characteristic changes on an EEG recorded during or shortly after the event

Your description is mixed:
• “Groaning or mumbling” reported by witnesses could be a seizure manifestation—or could just be semi-conscious vocalization during a faint.  
• You do describe a period of confusion after passing out.  
• Tight back, tingling, odd head sensations, awareness that you aren’t breathing, and huge nausea spells are not classic seizure features but can accompany seizures in some patients.

Bottom line: an actual seizure cannot be ruled out from your description alone; only an in-hospital EEG or ambulatory video-EEG during an episode can do that.

3. Other (more common) explanations that can mimic seizures and are very cycle-sensitive  

A. Severe primary dysmenorrhea with vasovagal reactions  
• Intense uterine cramps spike prostaglandins → severe pain + autonomic discharge.  
• Typical autonomic surge: nausea, retching, pallor, tingling in hands/feet (from hypocapnia when breathing changes), light-headedness, fainting.  
• Passing out + brief myoclonic jerks from poor cerebral perfusion often looks seizure-like to observers.  
• Ibuprofen works because it blocks prostaglandin production early in the cascade.

B. Panic / Catecholamine “dump” triggered by hormone shifts  
• Estradiol and progesterone fluctuations the day or two before bleeding increase susceptibility to panic attacks in some people.  
• You feel “waves,” stop breathing or hyperventilate, fingers tingle, heart feels odd, you may briefly lose consciousness.  
• Lorazepam (Ativan) is a rapid, effective anxiolytic—explaining why you felt better almost immediately.

C. Menstrual-related migraine with brainstem or sensory aura (“basilar-type migraine”)  
• Wave-like head sensation, limb tingling, altered level of consciousness, groaning, vomiting, and profound exhaustion are classic for this subtype.  
• Severe migraine aura can include dysarthria or “mumbling” noted by bystanders.  
• NSAIDs often blunt the attack if taken early; benzodiazepines help nausea/anxiety and can abort prolonged aura.

D. Cyclic vomiting syndrome  
• Estrogen/progesterone shifts are one of the best known triggers.  
• Prolonged retching leads to Mallory–Weiss tears and hematemesis (the bleeding episode you mentioned).  
• Again, lorazepam is a mainstay abortive treatment in the ED for CVS.

4. Why lorazepam (Ativan) helped so dramatically  
• It is both an anticonvulsant (raises seizure threshold) AND a potent anxiolytic/antiemetic.  
• The fact that it works does not prove the underlying process is epileptic.

5. Red-flag points that need formal evaluation  
• Recurrent unexplained loss of consciousness—even if brief.  
• Hematemesis from esophageal tears.  
• Subjective episodes of “not breathing.”  
• Any possibility that the heart “felt weird” because of an arrhythmia.

6. Reasonable next steps  
1. Keep a detailed diary for several cycles: date/time of bleeding onset, ALL prodromal symptoms, vital signs if you can get them, medications taken, how long spell lasted, and witness descriptions.  
2. Schedule NON-urgent but prompt appointments with:  
   • Neurology – for an outpatient EEG, and possibly a 24- to 72-hour ambulatory video-EEG if episodes are frequent.  
   • Gynecology – to discuss hormonal suppression (continuous combined oral contraceptives, progestin IUD, depo-provera, or GnRH agonists) if the spells prove to be strictly period-linked.  
   • Gastroenterology – only if vomiting/bleeding persists, to monitor for further esophageal injury.  
3. Discuss a short supply of oral lorazepam or another rescue medication you can take at home when prodrome begins.  
4. Continue using NSAIDs early (your “preventive” strategy clearly works), but take them on schedule rather than waiting for pain.  
5. Make sure basic labs (CBC, ferritin, electrolytes, thyroid, vitamin B12, magnesium) are not low; deficiencies can worsen tingling and palpitations.  
6. If syncope is still suspected, a tilt-table test and/or cardiac monitoring (Holter or event recorder) can rule out arrhythmias or autonomic dysfunction.  

7. When to seek the ER right away  
• Vomiting blood again or black tarry stools  
• Chest pain, sustained irregular heartbeat, or true shortness of breath (not just the “forget to breathe” sensation)  
• Confusion or inability to speak that lasts more than a few minutes  
• A seizure lasting ≥5 minutes or a second seizure without full recovery in between  
• Any head injury from a fall/faint  

Take-home message  
Your spells could represent seizures, but the pattern and response to NSAIDs and Ativan are at least as consistent with severe dysmenorrhea-induced syncope, panic episodes, or menstrual migraine. A structured evaluation—EEG, diary correlation with cycle, and perhaps hormonal suppression—should pin down the diagnosis and prevent further ER visits and complications like esophageal tears. Don’t rely solely on emergency departments; schedule dedicated visits with neurology and gynecology so the work-up can be done under controlled conditions.

78.question: F25, 5’6” 108 lbs.conditions: epilepsy, migraines, endometriosismeds: junel fe 1/20 birth control, pristiq, aptiom (started two weeks ago), and aimovig injection monthly.Yesterday I started feeling pain in my neck and base of the skull on the right side. I could feel a very tender lump right where the occipital lymph node is (thanks google!) I did palpate it a lot, and it is extremely painful today. I was also up all night with an awful migraine (first one in months since I started Aimovig) and it spread to my entire head and it was 8/10 pain. I do not have a fever. My headache is better when upright and has gotten a bit better throughout the day but the very painful bulge is still there. It also hurts at rest in that area. I felt lethargic and drained this morning.Took a covid test. Negative. Worried I have an infection or something but no fever? I have a big, painful and possible infected spit of cystic acne on my right cheek. Not sure if related.I’ve also been having bad muscular pain on the right side of my shoulder after packing and lifting boxes, it kept me up thursday night. But it got better-ish. Not sure if it’s related. Kinda feels worse today.Should I be concerned? It hurts to turn my head/move my head at alland I know that if I lie down my headache would return. If i even brush the lymph node it hurts so much. Was hard to brush my hair.Any insight appreciated. Thanks!TLDR: swollen potential lymph node in the occipital area at the base of skull. very painful. have a headache. concerned about infection but no fever.
78.answer:
I can’t examine you, so use the information below only as general education.  If anything on the “go now” list happens, or your instincts tell you something is wrong, be seen in-person right away.

WHAT THE LUMP COULD BE  
1. Reactive (inflamed) occipital lymph node  
   • Drains the scalp, back of the neck, and part of the ear/face.  
   • Common triggers: an inflamed pimple/cyst, folliculitis, dandruff/dermatitis, insect bite, or a viral URI you don’t feel yet.  
   • Nodes get much more painful after a lot of poking—that repeated palpation alone can keep one sore for 48-72 h.  

2. Occipital neuralgia or a myofascial “knot”  
   • Tight neck muscles or an irritated greater occipital nerve after heavy lifting/packing can feel like a pea-sized lump and be exquisitely tender.  
   • The pain can radiate over the scalp and mimic a migraine.  

3. Epidermoid cyst, lipoma, etc. (usually not this painful unless infected).  

MEDICATIONS  
None of the drugs you list directly cause isolated neck-node swelling. Aimovig, however, can occasionally give new or different headaches; Aptiom occasionally causes dizziness or tiredness but not focal swelling.

WHY THE HEADACHE MAY BE RELATED  
• A reactive node or muscle spasm at the skull base can trigger/“light up” a migraine pathway.  
• The fact that the headache eases when upright argues against high intracranial pressure but is typical of musculoskeletal or vascular headaches.  

RED-FLAG SYMPTOMS (seek ER/urgent care now)  
• Fever >100.4 °F (38 °C) or chills  
• Rapidly enlarging, rock-hard, or reddened lump  
• Stiff neck plus inability to flex chin to chest, photophobia, or confusion (could be meningitis even without fever)  
• “Worst headache of your life,” sudden thunderclap onset, vision loss, new weakness, seizures, or vomiting that won’t stop  
• Night sweats, unexplained weight loss, or more nodes popping up elsewhere  

SELF-CARE FOR THE NEXT 24–48 h (if none of the above apply)  
1. Quit poking it—give it 2–3 days to settle.  
2. Warm compress 10–15 min, 3–4×/day.  
3. OTC anti-inflammatory (ibuprofen, naproxen) if your other medicines/doctor allow.  
4. Gentle neck stretches, massage the surrounding neck muscles (not the node itself).  
5. Treat the cheek acne lesion with warm compresses or topical benzoyl peroxide; keep it clean.  
6. Hydrate, rest, try to keep sleep on schedule; Aimovig works better when migraine triggers (lack of sleep, dehydration) are minimized.  

WHEN TO BOOK A NON-URGENT VISIT (GP or neurology)  
• Node is still >1 cm, tender, or hard after 2 weeks  
• It’s getting larger after the first few days instead of shrinking  
• Recurrent or worsening headaches despite Aimovig  
• You feel a chain of nodes, or nodes in other areas (armpit, groin, supraclavicular)  
• You suspect the acne cyst is becoming an abscess that might need drainage or antibiotics  

BOTTOM LINE  
The single tender lump is most likely a reactive lymph node or a strain/nerve irritation from the heavy lifting and the inflamed cheek cyst. Most settle with time, warmth, NSAIDs, and leaving them alone. Monitor closely; escalate care immediately if any red-flag symptom appears or if the node/headache is not clearly improving over the next couple of days.

79.question: Hi everyone. Just wanting some opinions on this very confusing presentation. My sis in law, 30F, 5'5, smoker, with a suspected eating disorder (binge-purge-restrict cycle) has recently been diagnosed with epilepsy after having 2 seizures within an hour of eachother. She is also on treatment for depression and takes a sleeping tablet daily.The epilepsy diagnosis was confirmed after they ran a few tests. This was a surprise as there's no family history of epilepsy. The neurologist suggested it may be due to the depression meds (an uncommon side effect).Anyway, it has been 3 months since this diagnosis came. Last night, she had a seizure and was groggy and a bit confused for about 2 hours following it. The family understood this to be normal so just followed protocol.Thereafter, she started speaking in 3rd person and with completely different voice. She was not fooling aroud and quite honestly, freaked the hell out of everyone. She kept making degrading comments about herself and said, "Kim is always complaining. Leave her at the back. Leave her at the back". She switched to a different accent and displayed child-like behavior for a few minutes (giggling and kept hugging her pillow).She then spoke normally and complained of feeling dizzy. She had another seizure shortly after. She was taken to hospital where she had another seizure on arrival. At this point, she was completely incoherent and demanded paper and pen. She wrote random words on a page.Currently doing CT scan and blood tests. Will only be seen by a neurologist tomorrow. Any ideas of what could be happening?I initially thought of the possibility of drug use but she has been staying with her parents for 3 months straight and hasn't left the house or received any visitors at all in this period
79.answer:
I’m not in a position to examine or treat your sister-in-law, so take this only as background information you can discuss with her doctors.  
What you’re describing (multiple generalized seizures close together, followed by bizarre behaviour and language changes) can be produced by several different processes.  The ER team is already doing exactly what should be done first: stabilize her, obtain urgent imaging, and run basic chemistries/drug levels.  Here is the differential neurologists usually work through in a case like this:

1. Ongoing or “cluster” seizures / early status epilepticus  
   • When seizures occur back-to-back the brain can stay in a post-ictal (post-seizure) delirium for hours.  
   • Agitation, odd speech, laughter or crying, disinhibition, “child-like” behaviour, writing nonsense, speaking in the third person, or using a different accent can all occur in a post-ictal confusional state or in focal (partial) seizures arising from the temporal lobe.  
   • If the abnormal behaviour is actually another focal seizure, she may not remember it afterward. Continuous EEG monitoring will often be ordered to see whether she’s still seizing without the obvious convulsions (non-convulsive status).

2. Post-ictal psychosis  
   • After a run of seizures, some patients develop a short-lived psychosis that can include hallucinations, paranoid or self-deprecating statements and bizarre speech.  It usually appears after the initial post-ictal confusion starts to clear and can last hours to days.  
   • It is more common in patients with temporal-lobe epilepsy, previous head injury, long seizure duration, or sleep deprivation.

3. Metabolic or toxic causes that both provoke seizures and cause delirium  
   • Electrolyte disturbances: low sodium (especially if she drinks large volumes of water or uses certain antidepressants), low calcium or magnesium, or the hypokalemia often seen in purge-type eating disorders.  
   • Hypoglycaemia from restricted intake, vomiting, or insulin mis-use.  
   • Drug effects: bupropion, venlafaxine, clomipramine and some other antidepressants can lower seizure threshold; sedative-hypnotics (e.g., zolpidem, benzodiazepines) can precipitate seizures if doses are missed or if there is an interaction/overdose.  Serum levels and a urine tox screen are done for this reason.  
   • Alcohol withdrawal can look identical, but you’ve said she does not drink.

4. Central nervous system infection or inflammation  
   • Viral encephalitis (e.g., HSV), autoimmune encephalitis (e.g., anti-NMDA receptor) and other inflammatory conditions can appear with acute psychiatric symptoms plus new-onset seizures.  
   • CT is mainly to rule out bleed or mass; an MRI, spinal tap and autoimmune antibody panels are often added if initial tests are unrevealing and the patient doesn’t improve.

5. Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (PNES) superimposed on true epilepsy  
   • Up to 10–20 % of people with epilepsy also have dissociative (non-epileptic) events.  Dissociation after extreme stress, sleep deprivation or shame (as may accompany an eating disorder) can include speaking in the third person or “different voices.”  
   • Video-EEG monitoring is the gold standard to sort this out, but right now the priority is treating the proven epileptic seizures.

6. Structural brain lesion  
   • Tumour, vascular malformation or cortical dysplasia can cause focal epilepsy and behavioural change, so MRI (with epilepsy protocol) is almost always done even if the initial head CT is “normal.”

Why her background matters  
• Eating-disorder behaviours markedly increase the risk of low electrolytes and vitamin deficiencies (thiamine, B12) that can mimic or worsen seizures/psychosis.  
• Smoking raises the clearance of some antiepileptic drugs; if she recently reduced cigarettes, serum drug levels might rise or fall unpredictably.  
• Sleep-cycle disruption from insomnia tablets and depression itself both reduce seizure threshold.

What usually happens next in hospital  
1. Acute seizure control: IV benzodiazepine, then a loading dose of an antiepileptic (levetiracetam, valproate, fosphenytoin, lacosamide, etc.).  If she keeps seizing or the EEG shows non-convulsive status, they escalate to continuous infusions in ICU.  
2. Labs: CBC, metabolic panel (with calcium, magnesium, phosphate), liver/kidney function, blood glucose, serum antiepileptic and antidepressant levels, tox screen, thyroid panel, ± inflammatory/autoimmune panels.  
3. Imaging: non-contrast CT first; MRI with contrast as soon as she’s stable.  
4. If fever, neck stiffness or suggestive MRI: lumbar puncture for infection/autoimmunity.  
5. Continuous EEG for at least 24 h to catch subclinical seizures and to document any persistent abnormal movements or speech episodes.  
6. Psychiatry / neuropsychiatry consult once she is medically stabilized, because psychiatric adverse effects (post-ictal psychosis, medication-induced mania, dissociation) are very common in this setting.

Red-flag symptoms that demand urgent reassessment  
• Seizures lasting >5 min or ≥2 back-to-back without full recovery.  
• Persistent confusion >12 h beyond the last observed seizure.  
• Focal neurological deficit (e.g., weakness on one side, visual field cut).  
• Fever, stiff neck, new severe headache.  
• Rapidly worsening agitation, autonomic instability, or abnormal movements (could point toward encephalitis or non-convulsive status).

Bottom line  
The combination of genuine epileptic seizures plus the dramatic personality/voice shift is most often explained by:  
(1) post-ictal delirium/psychosis after a cluster of seizures, possibly made worse by metabolic derangement from her eating disorder, medication effects, or sleep deprivation; OR  
(2) focal seizures arising from the temporal lobe that express themselves as alterations in language, affect and behaviour.  

Other aetiologies—autoimmune or infectious encephalitis, toxic exposure, structural lesion—have to be ruled out, and that is exactly what her care team is doing.  As family, the best things you can do now are:  
• Give the doctors a precise medication list (names, doses, time of last dose) and a frank history of any vomiting, laxative use, alcohol/drug intake, recent weight changes, or missed meds.  
• Bring any previous imaging, EEG reports or clinic letters.  
• Keep a time-line (when each seizure or odd behaviour started/ended) and, if possible, video-record any new episodes—this is enormously helpful to neurologists.  
• Ensure she is never left alone in case further seizures or confusion episodes occur.

She is in the right place.  With prompt seizure control, correction of any metabolic abnormalities and careful follow-up by neurology and psychiatry, most patients recover fully from an episode like this.

80.question: 25y/o male, 5ft9, 70kg Since a couple of weeks my partner has been completely intolerant to stimuli (24/7). He can’t tolerate the slightest bit of light (not even his phone or laptop), he can’t tolerate any physical activity such as standing up or walking around, when eating his situation deteriorates as well. And what I mean with situation is the fact that he has a constant headache (stabbing, like knives in the back of the head), is nauseous, vomits, has distorted balance, confusion and this all is at it’s worsed when standing up (it could very rarely be tolerable while lying down but the second he stands up it is intolerable). He also had anisocoria at two seperate moments. He can’t function anymore because of all the combined symptoms. We visited multiple doctors with no diagnosis. He does not take any medication anymore (besides his nitroglycerine dermal patches 5mg/day), he forcebly stopped the rest of his medication because it also profoundly worsened his condition.Sincerest gratitude to any helpVisited multiple internal medicine doctors (gastro-enterology and hepatology), 3 neurologists (who all did not suspect meningitis, thats why we didn’t go to the ER, also I have a little medical background and if I would have suspected it to be meningitis I also wouldn’t have doubted and rushes him to the ER), a lot of general practitioners. They performerd US of the liver, CT of the liver, MRCP of the liver, multiple blood analyses (in blood analyses a couple weeks ago he had ALT and AST were 5x the reference value but since then came back to normal, low ceruloplasmine, low carnitine but supplements were given), EEG (no abnormalities), MRI brains (no abnormalities). On de CT they saw narrow bileducts, but not significant. Still waiting on results of MRCP liver. One neurologist prescribes blood and urinalysis for wilsons disease and porphyria but due to his condition we haven’t been able to go to the lab yet to get them done.
80.answer:
I cannot give you a diagnosis over the internet, but several of the features you describe are “red-flag” findings that justify a prompt emergency-department / hospital evaluation rather than more outpatient visits.  Two problems in particular need to be ruled out quickly because they fit the pattern you report, can be missed on a routine non-contrast MRI, and are treatable:

1.  Spontaneous intracranial hypotension (SIH) from a spinal cerebro-spinal-fluid (CSF) leak  
2.  Cervico-cranial arterial / venous pathology (e.g. carotid or vertebral-artery dissection, cerebral venous-sinus thrombosis)

Why SIH is high on the list  
•  Headache that is clearly posture-dependent – much worse within seconds–minutes of sitting or standing, partly relieved when flat  
•  Associated nausea, vomiting, photophobia, phonophobia, balance problems, cognitive clouding  
•  Occipital or “stabbing in the back of the head” pain is typical  
•  Episodes of transient anisocoria, diplopia or other cranial-nerve disturbances can occur because the brain “sags” when the CSF pressure is low  
•  MRI brain can be completely normal early or if done without gadolinium; the classic pachymeningeal enhancement, “brain sag” or engorged venous sinuses can be missed  
•  The condition often appears abruptly in otherwise healthy young adults and is frequently mistaken for migraine or meningitis

Why arterial / venous problems also need to be ruled out  
•  Vertebral or carotid dissection can present with an occipital headache, unequal pupils, imbalance and vomiting; dissection can coexist with or even cause a CSF leak  
•  Cerebral venous-sinus thrombosis or raised intracranial pressure would usually hurt more when lying flat, but there is overlap and they must be excluded before a lumbar puncture or blood patch is considered

Other possibilities (Wilson disease, porphyria, medication side-effects, POTS, migraine variants, hepatic encephalopathy, etc.) remain on the wider differential but do not explain the dramatic orthostatic component and the anisocoria nearly as well as the entities above.

Recommended next steps – preferably in an emergency / inpatient setting, not piecemeal outpatient:
1.  Full set of orthostatic vitals (BP, HR lying, sitting, standing).  
2.  Complete neurological examination including formal testing of pupils, visual fields, funduscopy for papilloedema.  
3.  MRI brain WITH gadolinium (if not already done with contrast) and an MRV (venous study).  
4.  MRA or CTA of head & neck to look for vertebral / carotid dissection.  
5.  If initial MRI suggests or fails to rule out SIH, proceed to whole-spine MRI with gadolinium, then MR or CT myelography to search for a leak.  
6.  If imaging is unrevealing but clinical suspicion of SIH remains high, a diagnostic lumbar puncture with opening pressure measurement (done only after vascular lesions are excluded) can be decisive.  
7.  Basic and specific labs: CBC, CMP, liver panel, coagulation profile, ESR/CRP, ammonia, thyroid panel, B12/folate, serum ceruloplasmin & 24-h urine copper, urine porphobilinogen & ALA, toxicology screen.  
8.  Hold the nitroglycerin patch for now unless it is absolutely required for a cardiac indication; nitrates can worsen headache and orthostatic symptoms.  
9.  Supportive care: intravenous fluids, caffeine (often helps SIH), anti-emetics, analgesia in a quiet/dark environment to prevent dehydration and malnutrition.

Treatment if SIH is confirmed  
•  Initial: strict bed rest flat, high caffeine intake, aggressive hydration, possible corticosteroids.  
•  Targeted or blind epidural blood patch – cures most spontaneous CSF leaks quickly.  
•  Surgical repair only if a precise leak site is identified and patches fail.

Why urgency matters  
Untreated SIH, vascular dissection, or venous thrombosis can lead to permanent neurological damage.  The episodes of unequal pupils in your partner are especially concerning: they may signal intermittent brain-stem or cranial-nerve traction.  Because ordinary outpatient imaging may already have looked “normal,” you need higher-level imaging and neurology/neurosurgery input straight away.

Bottom line  
Please do not wait for another outpatient appointment or lab draw; take him to an emergency department that has neurology and neuroradiology support, hand them a written summary of the history emphasizing:  
•  Severe orthostatic headache (better flat, unbearable upright)  
•  Two episodes of anisocoria  
•  Constant nausea/vomiting, photophobia, imbalance  
•  Normal routine brain MRI/EEG so far  

Ask specifically: “Could this be a CSF leak / spontaneous intracranial hypotension or arterial dissection?” and request the imaging outlined above.  If SIH is confirmed, an epidural blood patch can be life-changing within hours.

81.question: I 18M have frontal lobe epilepsy and started smoking weed before I was diagnosed but now it's getting a bit boring and im often offered molly and coke and was wondering if it was safe for me to take since I'm fine with weed and booze
81.answer:
I’m going to be very direct, because the stakes are high:

1.  What MDMA (“molly”) and cocaine do to the brain  
   • Both drugs are powerful stimulants that sharply raise the levels of dopamine, nor-epinephrine and (for MDMA) serotonin.  
   • They raise body temperature, heart-rate and blood pressure, disturb electrolytes (especially sodium), and keep people awake for long stretches.  
   • Each of those changes—catecholamine surge, hyper-thermia, hyponatremia, sleep-loss—is a known seizure trigger even in people who DON’T have epilepsy.

2.  Seizure data  
   • Emergency-department reports list seizures in 2–5 % of MDMA-related visits.  
   • Cocaine is so epileptogenic that new-onset seizures in the ER are often screened for recent cocaine use.  
   • In people who already have epilepsy, the risk is several-fold higher, and seizures that do occur tend to be more prolonged or to “cluster.”

3.  Medication interactions  
   • Most antiseizure drugs are metabolized by the same CYP450 enzymes (esp. 3A4, 2C9, 2C19) that handle MDMA and cocaine.  
   • Carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, topiramate, etc. can either speed up or slow down clearance of the street drug (unpredictable potency).  
   • Valproate, lamotrigine and levetiracetam don’t protect against stimulant-induced seizures.

4.  Other, non-seizure risks that are worse when you have epilepsy  
   • Cardiac arrhythmia or stroke → can deprive the brain of oxygen and precipitate status epilepticus.  
   • Hyperthermia & dehydration → can cause breakthrough seizures hours later.  
   • Sleep-loss (“all-nighters”) is one of the strongest triggers for frontal-lobe seizures.

5.  “But I tolerate weed and alcohol fine…”  
   • THC and alcohol act on different receptor systems (GABA, CB1/CB2); tolerance to them tells you nothing about how you’ll respond to catecholamine surges.  
   • Alcohol withdrawal (even after a weekend binge) is itself a seizure trigger.  
   • Only high-CBD, prescription-grade cannabis has evidence of helping epilepsy; recreational THC can actually lower the seizure threshold.

6.  Bottom line on safety  
   • From a neurologist’s standpoint, MDMA and cocaine are two of the least safe recreational drugs for a person with any epilepsy syndrome, including frontal-lobe epilepsy.  
   • “Safe” use cannot be guaranteed; there is no dose proven to be without risk.

7.  If you are going to do it anyway (harm-reduction pointers—not endorsements)  
   • Tell at least one sober friend you have epilepsy; have your rescue med (e.g., intranasal midazolam) on you.  
   • Test the substance with a reagent kit—many “molly” capsules actually contain meth, cathinones or fentanyl analogues (all worse for seizures).  
   • Take the smallest possible dose, and never re-dose the same night.  
   • Stay cool; take breaks from the dance-floor; sip water or sports drink (no more than ~500 mL/hr to avoid hyponatremia).  
   • Get 7–8 h of sleep afterward—no after-parties.  
   • Avoid mixing with alcohol, other stimulants, SSRIs, tramadol or bupropion (all seizure-threshold-lowering).  
   • Wear a medic-alert bracelet.

8.  Talk to your neurologist  
   • They’ve heard it all; you won’t shock them.  
   • Ask specifically about: rescue medication prescription, drug-interaction checks, and whether your last EEG/MRI suggest any extra risks.

9.  Take-home message  
   • Weed and booze feeling “boring” is not a medically sound reason to escalate to two of the most seizure-provoking drugs known.  
   • The safest choice—by a wide margin—is to skip MDMA and cocaine altogether.  
   • If you decide otherwise, reduce harm as much as possible and make sure the people around you know how to help if a seizure occurs.

Stay safe.

82.answer:
I’m very sorry that you, your fiancée and your families are having to go through this.  Super-refractory status epilepticus (SRSE) is one of the most difficult problems we face in neuro-critical care, but it is not hopeless; a meaningful proportion of patients do survive and many of those survivors return to good functional status once the underlying cause is found and treated.  Below is a concise overview of what most major epilepsy centers do, what else can still be considered, what the outcome data actually show, and what you can do as her advocate.  I cannot give personal medical advice, but you can use this as a checklist to discuss with her treating team.

1.  DEFINITIONS & NUMBERS  
• Status epilepticus (SE) = seizure ≥5 min or repeated seizures without recovery.  
• Refractory SE (RSE) = persists after an adequate benzodiazepine dose + one IV antiseizure medicine (ASM).  
• Super-refractory SE (SRSE) = continues or recurs ≥24 h after starting a continuous anesthetic infu­sion or recurs on attempted wean.  
• Mortality for SRSE is roughly 30-40 % overall, but depends heavily on cause; when the cause is treatable (e.g. autoimmune encephalitis) good-outcome rates are >60 %.  Prolonged seizures do not automatically mean permanent brain damage; outcome depends on etiology, systemic com­plications, and how well physiologic parameters are controlled in the ICU.

2.  FIND THE CAUSE – KEEP SEARCHING  
Up to one-third of young adults with new-onset SRSE turn out to have autoimmune encephalitis, most commonly NMDA-receptor antibody disease.  Because antibody panels take days to return, most centers give “empirical” immunotherapy while awaiting results.

Autoimmune / paraneoplastic testing to be sure has been (or can be) sent:  
 • Serum + CSF: NMDA-R, AMPA-R, GABA-B-R, LGI1, CASPR2, DPPX, GAD-65, glycine-R, VGCC, onconeural (Hu, Ma2, etc.).  
 • Screen for occult tumor (especially ovarian teratoma in young women) – pelvic ultrasound or CT if stable enough.  
 • Infectious PCR/antibody CSF/serum: HSV-1/2, VZV, HHV-6, enterovirus, EBV, CMV, West Nile, Lyme, Mycoplasma, Bartonella, HIV, syphilis.  
 • Toxic / metabolic: ammonia, urea, Na, Ca, Mg, glucose, B6 level, serum drug screens (including bupropion, isoniazid, theophylline, cocaine, synthetic cannabinoids).  
 • If no MRI yet with contrast, get one as soon as she can tolerate transport; subtle autoimmune/infectious changes are sometimes only visible on diffusion or FLAIR sequences.

3.  ACUTE TREATMENT LADDER – WHAT MOST CENTERS USE  
(Your fiancée has already received many of these, but you can see where barbiturate coma fits.)

 Benzodiazepine → IV loading ASMs → 1st infusion (propofol or midazolam)  
 → add / cycle additional ASMs (phenytoin/fosphenytoin, valproate, levetiracetam, lacosamide, topiramate, phenobarbital, clobazam, perampanel)  
 → 2nd infusion (ketamine)  
 → 3rd infusion (high-dose barbiturate – pentobarbital) or inhalational agent  
 → non-pharmacologic / rescue measures (see #4)

A true barbiturate coma aims for EEG burst-suppression for 24-48 h, then a very slow wean over days.  Yes, there are complications (hypotension, infection, ileus, immunosuppression), but when SE is the threat to life/brain it is an accepted and often effective step.

4.  OTHER “RESCUE” or ADJUNCTIVE OPTIONS STILL ON THE TABLE  
Most of these have at least case-series evidence of benefit in SRSE; none is a silver bullet, but several can be run in parallel with a barbiturate coma:

A. Immunotherapy (if autoimmune suspected)  
 • Methyl-prednisolone 1 g/day × 5 d – sounds like they have started this.  
 • IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day × 5 d OR plasma-exchange (5–7 exchanges).  
 • If definite or highly suspected autoimmune: rituximab or cyclophosphamide.

B. Ketogenic diet (4:1 fat:carb ratio, enteral formula).  Works in 40-50 % of SRSE children and ~30 % adults.  Can be started through a feeding tube even while sedated; takes 3–5 days to achieve ketosis.

C. Inhalational anesthesia (isoflurane or desflurane) when pentobarbital cannot be used or fails.

D. Hypothermia (32–34 °C for 24–48 h) used by some centers, usually combined with anesthetic infusions.

E. Continuous IV lidocaine (1–3 mg/kg/hr) – modest evidence, low risk.

F. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) 5 g IV once – rarely helps adults but almost no downside.

G. Neuromodulation / surgery (after MRI & PET):
 • Vagus-nerve stimulator (can be implanted bedside in experienced hands).  
 • Responsive neurostimulator (RNS) or focal resection if a single epileptogenic focus is identified.  
 • Corpus callosotomy for generalized convulsive SRSE.

H. Experimental agents
 • Allopregnanolone/Brexanolone (positive GABA-A modulator) – small series, available only through compassionate-use or at study sites.  
 • Ganaxolone (similar).  
 • Cannabidiol (IV formulation in trials).  
 • SAGE-547 (same as allopregnanolone).  
 • Fenfluramine, verapamil, clopidogrel (rare anecdotal reports).

5.  SYSTEMIC/ICU ISSUES THAT AFFECT OUTCOME  
While the team is chasing seizures they also have to:  
 • Keep MAP, oxygenation, glucose, Na, Ca, Mg, temp, pCO₂ in normal-high range.  
 • Prevent aspiration, pneumonia, DVT, pressure ulcers.  
 • Daily eye care, chest physiotherapy, early tracheostomy if prolonged ventilation is expected.  
Excellent general critical-care is a major factor in neuro-cognitive outcome.

6.  PROGNOSIS – THE HARD FACTS BUT ALSO THE HOPE  
Largest modern series (n≈200) of adult SRSE treated in tertiary centers:  
 • Survival to discharge ≈ 60 %.  
 • Good functional outcome (mRS 0-3) ≈ 40 %.  Younger age and treatable cause (autoimmune, infectious) strongly predict recovery.  
 • Duration of SE alone is NOT an independent predictor once you adjust for etiology and systemic complications.

Several documented cases of young adults with 2–4 weeks of coma-level SRSE recovering to independent living, college, work, etc., once the underlying autoimmune encephalitis was treated.

7.  WHAT YOU (FAMILY/ADVOCATE) CAN DO  
• Confirm that a full autoimmune/infectious panel has been sent and that empirical immunotherapy (steroids ± IVIG/PLEX) is under way.  
• Ask whether ketogenic diet, lidocaine infusion, or inhalational anesthesia have been considered.  
• Make sure she is (or can be) in a comprehensive epilepsy center; transfer can be lifesaving if current hospital is not one.  
• Keep a single family spokesperson (you, her parent) in direct contact with the attending neurologist/ intensivist for consistent communication.  
• Take care of yourself; SRSE often runs a marathon, not a sprint.

8.  RESOURCES / REFERENCES FOR YOU AND THE TEAM  
• Neurocritical Care Society guideline: “Guidelines for the Evaluation and Management of Status Epilepticus” (2012, being updated).  
• Rossetti AO & Lowenstein DH. “Management of refractory status epilepticus in adults” – Lancet Neurol 2011.  
• Gaspard N et al. “New-onset refractory status epilepticus” – Epilepsia 2015 (good autoimmune discussion).  
• Sculier C et al. “Long-term outcome of SRSE” – Intensive Care Med 2018.

Bottom line  
Ten days of SRSE is frightening but not unprecedented, and meaningful recovery is still possible, especially in a 24-year-old who was previously healthy.  A barbiturate coma is a standard next step; if that fails, a number of additional options remain.  The single most important factor is identifying and treating the underlying cause, with autoimmune encephalitis high on the list in someone her age who had a viral-like prodrome.  Do not lose hope, but remain an active, informed advocate so all reasonable therapies are considered.

I wish you and your fiancée strength and the best possible outcome.
