Below is an “anatomy-and-radiology glossary” written in plain language and tailored to the phrases that appear in your report.  None of it replaces a discussion with the neurologist or the radiologist who read the scan, but it should make the wording easier to follow when you do talk to them.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Mesial (medial) temporal lobe epilepsy, hippocampus abnormality,
   mesial-temporal sclerosis (MTS)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Hippocampus = a small curved structure deep in each temporal lobe that is
   important for memory and is one of the most seizure-prone parts of the brain.  
•  “Sclerosis” literally means “hardening,” but on MRI it describes scarring
   produced by loss of nerve cells and replacement by supporting (glial) tissue.
•  On the scan the scarred hippocampus looks
   – smaller (volume loss / atrophy) and  
   – brighter on fluid-sensitive sequences such as T2- or FLAIR-weighted images.
•  This pattern is called mesial temporal sclerosis and is the commonest
   structural cause of focal impaired-awareness seizures.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  “Associated regional atrophy of the dorsal right thalamus”
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Thalamus = a relay “hub” that passes information between the cortex and many
   other structures.  The dorsal (upper/back) part receives heavy input from the
   hippocampus.  
•  When the hippocampus shrinks, the fibres that connect it to the thalamus
   also degenerate; the corresponding part of the thalamus then shrinks
   (“secondary or trans-synaptic atrophy”).  It is essentially a knock-on effect
   rather than a separate new disease process.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  “T2-weighted high-signal gliosis within the periventricular white
   matter of the right parietal lobe”
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  MRI “weighting” – T1, T2, FLAIR, etc. – is just the way the machine is tuned
   to highlight different tissue properties.  In T2-weighted or FLAIR images,
   water shows up bright (high signal).  
•  Gliosis = the brain’s version of scar tissue; glial cells proliferate and
   there is extra water, so the area looks bright on T2/FLAIR.
•  Periventricular = next to the lateral ventricles, the normal fluid-filled
   cavities inside the brain.
•  White matter = the bundles of nerve fibres that connect different brain
   regions.
•  Putting it together: the scan sees a patch of long-standing scar tissue in
   the white matter near the ventricle in your right parietal lobe.  The
   radiologist lists two broad possibilities for why the scar is there:
   ‑ Repeated seizure-related injury (excitotoxicity, transient loss of blood
     flow, etc.)  
   ‑ A prior “ischemic or inflammatory insult” (e.g. a small stroke, infection,
     trauma) that long pre-dated the scan.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  “Ex-vacuo dilatation of the ventricular trigone (atrium)”
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Trigone/atrium = the junction where the body, occipital horn and temporal
   horn of each lateral ventricle meet; it lies roughly under the parietal lobe.
•  “Dilatation” just means it looks wider than average.
•  “Ex-vacuo” (Latin “because of a vacuum” or “because something is missing”)
   tells you why it is wider: not because of excess fluid pressure, but because
   the surrounding brain tissue has shrunk.  When neighbouring white matter
   atrophies, the ventricle passively expands to fill the space—like a glove
   inflating if the hand inside it gets thinner.  This is benign in itself; it
   is a marker of the tissue loss already described (gliosis/atrophy), not a
   separate hydrocephalus-type problem.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  “Abnormalities” – a catch-all word
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Radiologists use “abnormality” when what they see differs from what a healthy
structure normally looks like, without yet labelling it as tumour, stroke,
infection, trauma, etc.  
In your context the “abnormalities involving the right hippocampus” refer to:
•  volume loss (atrophy),  
•  high T2/FLAIR signal (water content from gliosis), and  
•  morphological changes typical for mesial temporal sclerosis.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  “Periventricular white matter” – anatomy vs. damage
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Periventricular white matter is simply a location: the large sheets of white
   matter that hug the walls of the lateral ventricles.  Everyone has it.  
•  In many disorders (vascular, inflammatory, demyelinating, post-injury) this
   region is especially susceptible, so radiologists pay close attention to it.
•  In your report only the right parietal periventricular white matter shows a
   lesion; the rest is presumably normal.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Why does any of this matter for epilepsy?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  The combination of right-sided hippocampal sclerosis and the EEG findings
   localises a seizure focus.  
•  Knowing whether there are additional lesions (parietal gliosis, thalamic
   atrophy) helps the epilepsy team predict how seizures spread, how well they
   may respond to medication, and whether surgery, laser ablation or neuromod-
   ulation could be considered.  
•  The extra-hippocampal changes (thalamus, white matter) are typically judged
   “secondary” and usually do not change treatment radically, but they do show
   that the condition has been present for a while.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Key take-home points
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Mesial temporal sclerosis = scarring/shrinkage of the hippocampus—the most
    common structural correlate of focal impaired-awareness seizures.
2.  “High T2 signal gliosis” = MRI appearance of old scar tissue.
3.  “Ex-vacuo dilatation” = ventricle looks bigger only because nearby brain
    tissue is smaller; not the same as pressure build-up hydrocephalus.
4.  Periventricular white matter is normal anatomy; only the specific bright
    patch the radiologist describes is abnormal.
5.  The dorsal thalamic atrophy and ventricular enlargement are downstream
    effects of the primary hippocampal injury, not entirely new problems.

Bring these notes to your next neurology appointment; they can serve as a
starting point for deeper, case-specific questions such as prognosis,
medication options, and (if ever relevant) suitability for epilepsy surgery.

84.answer:
I’m not able to give you a personal diagnosis over the Internet, but I can try to put the pieces together, explain what doctors are usually thinking about when they see a picture like yours, and suggest what the next steps often are.  Take this to your treating physicians, and, if needed, use it as a road map for obtaining a second‐opinion evaluation.  

1.  WHAT CAN SUDDEN, FLUCTUATING EYE MISALIGNMENT MEAN?  
   • Ocular myasthenia gravis (MG) – Classically causes rapidly shifting or fatigable double vision and/or ptosis.  Up to 50 % of purely ocular MG patients are antibody-negative (AChR, MuSK and LRP-4).  Definitive tests are: ice-pack test at the bedside; Tensilon (edrophonium) test; single-fiber EMG of the orbicularis/extra-ocular muscles; or repetitive-nerve-stimulation EMG.  
   • Thyroid (Graves/Hashimoto) eye disease – Hashimoto’s patients can also get restrictive myopathy that produces new strabismus.  Orbital MRI or CT looking at the extra-ocular muscles helps.  
   • Cranial-nerve III, IV or VI palsy – Vascular, infectious, inflammatory or demyelinating lesions along the brain-stem/orbit can do this.  A standard “vestibular” MRI sometimes omits critical orbital and brain-stem cuts with contrast.  
   • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia / brain-stem lesions (for example in multiple sclerosis, stroke, or encephalitis) – produces misalignment plus nystagmus.  Needs high-resolution MRI brain with and without gadolinium.  
   • Drug toxicity – High serum levels of lamotrigine, oxcarbazepine, or antipsychotics can cause diplopia and nystagmus but usually not an isolated large ocular deviation.

2.  WHY THE NYSTAGMUS, OSCILLOPSIA AND VIOLENT VERTIGO?  
   • Unilateral or bilateral vestibular neuritis/labyrinthitis – would not explain fluctuating eye‐movement weakness or seizures.  
   • Cerebellar or brain-stem process – can give upbeat/downbeat/pendular nystagmus, limb tremor, gait ataxia, oscillopsia, vomiting.  MRI must include the posterior fossa with thin cuts.  
   • Lamotrigine, trileptal, Seroquel and Abilify can individually cause nystagmus; together they can amplify it.  A drug-level check and slow taper trial sometimes clarifies this.  
   • Paraneoplastic or autoimmune cerebellitis (anti-GAD, anti-Hu, anti-Yo, anti-Ri, anti-DNER, etc.) – usually subacute; often accompanies seizures or encephalopathy.  
   • Miller-Fisher variant of Guillain–Barré (anti-GQ1b antibodies) – triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia and areflexia; can include autonomic episodes such as flushing and shallow breathing.

3.  HAND/BODY TREMOR, FLUSHING, AUTONOMIC EPISODES  
   • Medication-induced akathisia/tremor (abilify, seroquel, lamotrigine).  
   • Dysautonomia that can be post-viral, autoimmune, or part of MG, Miller-Fisher or brain-stem involvement.  
   • Endocrine causes (thyroid over- or under-replacement, pheochromocytoma) – but TSH on Synthroid usually picks this up.  

4.  NEW-ONSET SEIZURES IN AN ADULT ALREADY ON TWO AEDs  
   • Breakthrough from sleep deprivation, drug interactions or metabolic issues.  
   • Structural or inflammatory brain disease (MS, autoimmune encephalitis, Hashimoto encephalopathy, paraneoplastic process).  Requires MRI brain with and without contrast, CSF, and autoimmune panel if the MRI is unrevealing.

5.  WHAT TESTS ARE USUALLY PURSUED WHEN THE STANDARD MRI AND MG ANTIBODY PANEL ARE NEGATIVE?  
   • High-resolution MRI brain AND orbits with and without contrast (include T1 fat-sat orbit, FIESTA/CISS of the brain-stem, MRA/ MRV).  
   • Complete MG work-up: ice-pack test, Tensilon test (if available), single-fiber EMG, repetitive-nerve-stimulation EMG, AChR-modulating/blocking, MuSK, and LRP-4 antibodies.  
   • Serum and CSF autoimmune/paraneoplastic panels (NMDA-R, LGI1, CASPR2, GAD-65, Hu, Ri, Yo, Ma, DNER, Zic4, amphiphysin, VGKC, GQ1b, etc.).  
   • Comprehensive metabolic and vitamin screen (B-12, copper, folate, thiamine, vitamin E, thyroid, cortisol, calcium, ESR/CRP, ANA, ENA, ACE, Lyme, syphilis, HIV).  
   • Drug levels for lamotrigine and oxcarbazepine.  
   • Formal neuro-ophthalmology examination with eye-movement recordings and Hess/Lancaster plots.  
   • Vestibular testing (video-oculography, rotational chair, vHIT, calorics) to document peripheral vs central nystagmus.  

6.  TREATMENTS THAT CAN BE TRIED WHILE THE WORK-UP IS ONGOING (UNDER PHYSICIAN SUPERVISION)  
   • If ocular MG remains high on the list: continue or restart pyridostigmine (Mestinon) trial; a short (3- to 5-day) course of oral prednisone or IVIG is sometimes used diagnostically.  
   • Drug clean-up: a supervised taper off one antipsychotic at a time (starting with Abilify or Seroquel) to see whether diplopia, tremor and nystagmus improve.  
   • Vestibular suppressants only short-term (meclizine, ondansetron) plus a properly tailored vestibular-rehab program once the emesis is controlled.  
   • Migraine prophylaxis (topiramate, propranolol, verapamil, CGRP inhibitors) can dampen vestibular migraine if that is the driver.  
   • If Hashimoto encephalopathy is suspected: empiric high-dose steroids (e.g., methylpred 1 g IV x 3–5 days) are both diagnostic and therapeutic, provided infection and tumor are ruled out.  

7.  RED FLAGS THAT WARRANT URGENT (SAME-DAY) HOSPITAL OR ED EVALUATION  
   • Worsening or sudden inability to move either eye horizontally or vertically.  
   • Progressive swallowing, speech or breathing difficulty (even intermittent).  
   • New focal weakness, numbness or severe imbalance.  
   • Intractable vomiting with inability to keep medications down.  
   • Anaphylaxis-like flushing episodes with throat swelling.  

8.  WHEN YOUR DOCTOR SAYS “NO MORE TESTS” BUT YOUR SYMPTOMS ARE ESCALATING  
   • Politely request a second-opinion referral: – an academic neuro-ophthalmologist OR – a fellowship-trained neuromuscular specialist experienced in seronegative MG and autoimmune neurologic disease.  
   • Bring a one-page timeline listing each major symptom, its first date, what makes it better/worse, and every test already done.  This prevents duplicated work and often leads to quicker answers.  

BOTTOM LINE  
Your story crosses three subspecialty borders—neuro-ophthalmology (eye misalignment, nystagmus), neuro-immunology (possible seronegative MG or autoimmune brain-stem/cerebellar disease), and vestibular/otoneurology (oscillopsia, vertigo).  A negative standard MG antibody panel and a “normal vestibular MRI” do not exclude the most important diagnoses.  The next practical steps are:

1.  Formal neuro-ophthalmology examination with ocular EMG or ice/Tensilon testing.  
2.  High-resolution MRI brain+orbits with contrast, plus full autoimmune/paraneoplastic CSF and serum panel.  
3.  Drug-level check and rational medication simplification.  
4.  Rapid return to the ED if breathing, swallowing or gait deteriorate.

Take this outline to your neurologist or, if necessary, to a tertiary-care center’s neuromuscular or neuro-ophthalmology clinic for a fresh evaluation.  Prompt, systematic testing is the best way to keep you safe and to arrive at a treatment plan that actually works.

85.question: My wife has very recently, after several extremely trying years, been diagnosed with psychogenic non-epileptic seizures. Some backstory is required before I can pose my question:Originally my wife presented with hallucinations (visual, auditory, and tactile). We naturally sought psychiatric treatment. A slew of medicine was prescribed on the assumption of schizophrenia. I can remember Risperdol, Lamictal, and Effexor, among a few others. This helped her moods and backed the symptoms down a bit for a while.Later on, probably 8-10 months, the hallucinations were getting stronger, accompanied by suicidal tendencies and self-harm, and a new symptom arose that looked a lot like absent seizures. This ultimately culminated in her carving the word "HELP" into her thigh with a pair of scissors, followed by the obvious involuntary commitment, which was spent at the hospital. This led to a new diagnosis, epilepsy. It was explained to us then that hallucinations can be a symptom of epilepsy. This was new info to me. She was prescribed Keppra and sent home. The hallucinations subsided entirely within a few weeks.With the addition of Keppra, she weaned off Risperdol and Lamictal as instructed. What followed after was a marked increase in the absent seizures, now characterized by entirely different symptoms. She would now have standard post-ictal headaches, occasionally some aphasia where she couldn't speak but could still communicate with ASL, and usually some transient amnesia with associated confusion. This would range from forgetting a few days to forgetting several years, sometimes not even recognizing me (we've been together almost four years). These periods of amnesia would last anywhere from 30 minutes to upwards of two hours on bad days.On followup with the neuro who gave the epilepsy diagnosis, a seven day at-home video EEG was ordered. This had to be cut short at day 3 due to a skin reaction she was having, either to the glue or tape, I dunno. The next followup, to go over the test findings, resulted in a diagnosis of PNES as the EEG showed no abnormal brain activity after capturing over a dozen episodes.  Happy to finally have a diagnosis that seemed to cover everything, we followed the neuro's order to ween off Keppra and sought a change in treatment plan at the psychiatrist. This was about one month ago. She came completely off the Keppra about five days ago...And suddenly the hallucinations are back.I'm not smart enough to make heads nor tails of this, despite loads of online research. Getting in with the neuro or the neuropsychologist to which we were referred will take quite some time.The best thing I can come up with is some data suggesting that an estimated 10-25% of individuals with PNES also have epilepsy, which leads me to suspect that the Keppra may have controlled her epilepsy (and the related hallucinations) to a point that the PNES and its symptoms became more obvious.My questions are: Does my theory make sense? If so, is it likely? No other medicines have been added or removed except the Keppra, so why would the hallucinations come back?I'd appreciate any insight or direction that any of you may have to offer.Thank you.
85.answer:
(I am not your wife’s physician; the following is general information that may help you frame the discussion with her treating doctors.)

1. What psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (PNES) are, and what they are not  
• During a PNES spell the brain’s electrical activity remains normal; the event is generated by psychological mechanisms (dissociation, conversion, severe stress, etc.).  
• Because the outward appearance can be very similar to an epileptic seizure, prolonged video-EEG monitoring is required to tell the two apart.  
• Up to 10–30 % of patients who are finally diagnosed with PNES also have “real” epilepsy, so the two disorders can coexist.

2. Hallucinations and epilepsy  
• Certain focal (usually temporal- or occipital-lobe) seizures can produce sensory hallucinations.  
• These ictal hallucinations are usually brief (seconds to a few minutes), stereotyped, and often accompanied by other seizure features (staring, automatisms, change in awareness, post-ictal confusion, etc.).  
• Long-lasting, elaborate auditory-visual hallucinations (hours, days) more often point to a primary psychiatric disorder, a medication effect, or (rarely) a prolonged post-ictal psychosis.

3. What levetiracetam (Keppra) can do besides control seizures  
• Keppra is a broad-spectrum anti-seizure drug.  
• It also has some psychotropic activity: in many patients it has a mild mood-stabilising/anti-anxiety effect; in a minority it can actually provoke irritability, depression, or psychosis.  
• Stopping Keppra is not known to produce a specific “rebound hallucinosis,” but withdrawal of any drug that was quietly suppressing symptoms can allow the underlying condition to re-emerge.

4. Putting your wife’s timeline together  

    a) Initial hallucinations → treated as primary psychosis with risperidone, lamotrigine, etc.  
    b) New “absence-like” spells → presumed epilepsy → Keppra added → hallucinations remit.  
    c) Antipsychotics removed; Keppra continued → hallucinations stay quiet.  
    d) Home video-EEG (only 3 days) captures several spells with no epileptic activity → label changed to PNES → Keppra tapered off.  
    e) Five days after last Keppra dose → hallucinations return.

Two main ways to explain this:

Scenario 1 – Epilepsy + PNES coexist  
• The short home EEG simply failed to catch the true epileptic events (not uncommon).  
• Keppra had been controlling the epileptic part.  
• When it was stopped, genuine focal seizures (with ictal or post-ictal hallucinations) re-emerged.  

Scenario 2 – Primary psychiatric illness + PNES, no epilepsy  
• Your wife’s hallucinations are a manifestation of an underlying psychotic or mood disorder.  
• Keppra happened to have a beneficial psychotropic effect in her case, acting almost like an add-on antipsychotic/mood stabiliser.  
• Once Keppra was withdrawn the psychiatric symptoms resurfaced, independent of any seizure activity.

5. Which scenario is “more likely”?  
Without longer inpatient video-EEG monitoring it is impossible to be sure. Both explanations are medically plausible. Factors pointing one way or the other:

Pro-epilepsy clues  
• Hallucinations shut off completely on a moderate dose of Keppra, despite antipsychotics being tapered.  
• Spells have post-ictal headaches, transient aphasia, focal amnesia – all typical for temporal-lobe seizures.  
• EEG was only three days long; even in proven epilepsy a typical focal seizure may not occur in that window.

Pro-primary-psychosis clues  
• Hallucinations were complex, prolonged, and multimodal – more suggestive of psychiatric illness than of typical ictal phenomena.  
• Keppra can act as a mood stabiliser/antipsychotic in some patients, so its presence might simply have been treating the underlying disorder.

6. What to do now

1. Re-contact the neurologist promptly, tell him/her that the original symptom (hallucinations) has recurred after stopping Keppra.  
2. Ask whether restarting Keppra while awaiting definitive evaluation is reasonable (many neurologists will agree, at least as a therapeutic trial).  
3. Arrange for prolonged inpatient video-EEG monitoring (3–7 days in hospital) if at all possible. This is the gold standard for sorting out PNES ± epilepsy.  
4. Simultaneously re-engage psychiatry. Even if epilepsy is ultimately documented, she still appears to need an antipsychotic or mood-stabilising agent.  
5. Keep a detailed diary (time, description, duration of spells; whether hallucinations occur; any triggers; recovery time). This is invaluable to both specialties.

7. Bottom line  
Yes—your theory that Keppra was suppressing genuine epileptic activity (or, alternatively, acting as her “antipsychotic”) is reasonable and fits the facts. Only a longer video-EEG and careful psychiatric re-assessment can tease the two possibilities apart. Until then, let your wife’s physicians know that her hallucinations have returned so that treatment (either restarting Keppra, reinstating an antipsychotic, or both) can be started sooner rather than later.

86.question: Hi, I bit of back story here I've been diagnostic with NF1 when I was 5 ever since I had to do 2 MRI every year. every time they put a needle in my arm I would faint.So today I just got my blood draw for a schedule MRI in 3 weeks. And like always I fainted but I also started moving my arms and leg uncontrollably lucky the needle was removed before.Anyone know what could cause this or the actual naming?Age: 21 (22 in 3 month)Sex: Male
86.answer:
What probably happened is something called a vasovagal (or “neuro-cardiogenic”) syncope with brief “convulsive” or “myoclonic” movements.

What a vasovagal syncope is  
• Trigger: pain, fear, seeing blood, standing for a long time, etc.  
• Physiology: The brainstem reflex suddenly slows the heart rate and dilates blood vessels → blood pressure drops → not enough blood gets to the brain for a few seconds → you pass out.  
• Why the jerks? When the brain is starved of oxygen for a few seconds it may produce brief, irregular, seizure-like jerks of the arms or legs (anoxic myoclonus). This is called “convulsive syncope” or “anoxic seizure.” It is not epilepsy and usually stops as soon as blood flow returns.

Typical features that fit your story  
• Occurs right after the needle stick (classic trigger).  
• You faint first, jerks start while you are out, and you come around quickly (seconds to a minute).  
• You are usually awake and feel washed-out but otherwise fine within a minute or two.  
• No prolonged confusion, tongue-biting on the sides, or loss of bladder control—features more common in true epileptic seizures.

Why it matters  
• It is common and usually benign, but you can hurt yourself if you fall.  
• Because you have NF-1 (which can be associated with seizures in some people) it’s worth telling your primary doctor or neurologist what happened so they can decide if any further evaluation (e.g., ECG, tilt-table test, or EEG if there is doubt) is needed. Most of the time none is.

What you can do to prevent it next time  
1. Tell the staff you faint—ask to be drawn while lying flat with your legs slightly elevated.  
2. Stay well hydrated and eat something salty before the appointment (unless you have to be fasting for the MRI contrast lab work).  
3. Tense your thigh and buttock muscles (“leg crossing and tensing” maneuver) just before and during the needle stick—this keeps blood pressure up.  
4. Slow deep breaths, look away, distraction (music, talking).  
5. In severe needle phobia some people are given topical anesthetic cream, anti-anxiety medication, or are referred for desensitization therapy.

Names you can mention to clinicians  
• Vasovagal syncope  
• Neurocardiogenic syncope  
• Convulsive syncope / anoxic myoclonus (for the brief jerking part)

Seek urgent care if  
• The spells happen with no obvious trigger, while sitting/lying down, during exercise, or are followed by prolonged confusion.  
• You injure yourself, have chest pain, palpitations, or breathlessness.  
Otherwise, the episode you described is very typical of a vasovagal faint, and many people have the brief jerks you noticed.

87.question: 49YO female with IBS like symptoms due to adhesions choking intestines, non-epileptic seizures due to migraines, deaf, in TCHP chemo for breast cancer, BMX August 1, 2018, no node involvement. 5'6, 220lbs. Effexor for seizure prevention. Bupropion for situational depression related to health challenges. I lost my hair to chemo, so for the first time I noticed I have ridges in my scalp. Googling that, only one thing comes up: Cutis Verticis Gyrata (CVG). My ridges, however, are very mild compared to most images. I can see them in the mirror, but can't find a way to accurately photograph them. They are very much like this in location and "layout", but not quite as deep. This is listed as something different though, related to mental retardation (article's words) from birth. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00105-007-1302-4 I do have a couple of the secondary issues listed, namely non-epileptic seizures and deafness. The former is blamed on migraines that left lesions on the brain and the latter is blamed on the seizures. Should I see an endocrinologist, or is this something else?
87.answer:
What you are seeing is almost certainly NOT a sign of a new, worrisome disease, and in particular it is probably not the classic form of Cutis Verticis Gyrata (CVG) that you found on-line.  
Here is why, what else can cause shallow scalp ridging, and whom to see if you want it looked at:

1. What CVG actually is  
   • True / “classic” CVG is an uncommon condition in which the skin of the scalp becomes thick and forms deep folds and furrows that look like the surface of the brain.  
   • It is divided into three varieties:  
     – Primary essential: just the scalp folds, with no other health problems.  
     – Primary non-essential: folds plus certain neurologic or eye disorders present since birth or childhood (intellectual disability, seizures, strabismus, etc.).  
     – Secondary: folds caused by another disorder that thickens the scalp (acromegaly, thyroid disease, severe inflammatory skin conditions, tumors, long-standing swellings, etc.).  
   • The folds are usually obvious, permanent, and several millimeters to centimeters deep. Most patients (women included) can get striking “canyons” that you can easily photograph.

2. Why the ridges often look worse right after chemo-induced hair loss  
   • Hair hides a lot of subtle topography. When the hair disappears, every little bump, scar, or fold shows.  
   • Partial loss of subcutaneous fat during treatment can unmask natural grooves of the skull.  
   • Because the scalp is now bare and shiny, overhead lighting exaggerates shadows in even shallow furrows.

3. Common, benign causes of shallow scalp grooves  
   • Normal anatomic variation: Almost everyone has a mid-line groove over the sagittal suture and a few transverse lines produced by the attachment of scalp muscles.  
   • Mild cutis verticis gyrata-like changes in people who are overweight: extra soft tissue can sag in faint folds, especially when lying on a pillow. (Your BMI ~35 makes this quite plausible.)  
   • Post-inflammatory thinning or thickening from past mild seborrheic dermatitis or psoriasis.  
   • Age-related skin laxity.  
   • Temporary “pillow lines” that become more visible when the scalp is bare.

4. What would make dermatologists or endocrinologists suspect a pathologic (secondary) CVG  
   • Deep, fixed folds you can put a fingertip into.  
   • Progressive thickening over months to years.  
   • Other stigmata of endocrine disease: enlarged hands/feet, coarse facial features, jaw enlargement (acromegaly); puffy face, brittle hair, constipation (severe hypothyroidism); Cushingoid appearance, etc.  
   • Past or present inflammatory scalp disease, large cysts, tumors, or chronic lymphedema.

5. Your specific history in context  
   • No report of coarse facial changes or enlarged hands/feet to suggest acromegaly.  
   • The seizures and deafness you mention have clear alternative explanations (migraine-related lesions, post-ictal injury) and are not typical of secondary CVG causes.  
   • Chemotherapy itself does not cause CVG. It only unmasks scalp contour.  
   • The ridges are “very mild,” not readily captured on a photo—this alone strongly argues against true CVG. (Dermatologists often call these “physiologic scalp furrows.”)

6. Whom (and whether) to see  
   • Start with your oncologist or your primary care doctor at your next visit; they can look at the scalp quickly and decide if it warrants formal dermatology referral.  
   • If a dermatologist sees definite thick folds or any worrisome skin change, they may do a small punch biopsy or, if endocrine disease is suspected, refer you to an endocrinologist.  
   • Going directly to an endocrinologist is usually unnecessary unless you already have other signs of hormone excess/deficiency.

7. When to make an earlier appointment  
   • Folds are rapidly deepening or new ones are appearing.  
   • You notice scalp thickening, nodules, frequent headaches with visual changes, or new hand/foot enlargement.  
   • The grooves trap debris and cause recurrent infections or odor (uncommon unless folds are deep).

8. What you can safely do now  
   • Keep the scalp clean and moisturized; use a gentle shampoo or scalp wash.  
   • Protect the bare scalp from sun (hats, SPF 30+).  
   • Mention the ridges at your next routine medical visit so someone can lay expert eyes (or fingertips) on them.  
   • Try not to rely on internet images: true CVG cases on the web represent the most dramatic end of the spectrum.

Bottom line  
Mild, newly noticed scalp ridges after hair loss are almost always a normal contour or a benign, weight-related folding of skin, not pathologic CVG. A quick in-person look by your regular doctor or a dermatologist is usually all that is required; an endocrinology visit would only be needed if clear features of an endocrine disorder were present.

88.question: Our son was recently diagnosed with idiopathic epilepsy. We were out of town for 1 week and he started having seizures 1-2 times per day. The episodes were short (20-30 seconds) but essentially he would feel dizzy, sit down confused, occasionally vomit and forget what happenedWent to an out of town hospital (emergency) and had EEG, CT, MRI, MRAs completed with no sign for the cause of the seizures. But the EEG did register slower brain waves indicating epilepsy.Neurologist placed our son on Keppra at 2ml dosage. Since taking the meds he had two very minor episodes during the first week (feels dizzy and needs to sit down but doesn’t lose consciousness or forget what happened). For the past week (2nd week of dosage) he has had no events.We went to see our neurologist today and he would like to increase the dosage from 2ml to 3ml. I’m a little confused since the meds are working at 2ml why up the dosage given all the potential side effects that can happen. I’m not against the meds and fully respect the doctors opinion. The meds are clearly helping and I know that the doctors have his best health in mind but my concern is from a completely laymen’s uniformed perspective it doesn’t make sense to up the dosage unless we don’t see improvement?
88.answer:
I can’t make individual treatment decisions for your son, but I can explain the way pediatric neurologists usually think about levetiracetam (Keppra) dosing and why a dose can be raised even when the medicine already seems to be “working.”

1. “2 mL” is probably a starter dose, not a full-strength dose  
   • The liquid Keppra that most pharmacies dispense is 100 mg/mL.  
   • If your son is getting 2 mL twice a day, that is 200 mg each dose (400 mg/day).  
   • Standard pediatric starting dose: about 20 mg per kilogram of body weight per day, split twice daily.  
   • Common maintenance range: 30–60 mg/kg/day (occasionally higher).  
   • Example: a 25 kg (55 lb) child would start at 500 mg/day and might ultimately land anywhere from 750 mg to 1500 mg/day.  
   In other words, the initial 2 mL was meant to “get the medicine on board” and watch for side-effects, not to reach the full therapeutic dose.

2. The goal is zero seizures, not “fewer” seizures  
   • Even a single brief seizure carries risk (falls, aspiration, motor-vehicle accidents, status epilepticus).  
   • Recurrent seizures can impair school performance, memory consolidation, mood, and in rare cases can lead to SUDEP (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy).  
   • Neurologists therefore aim for complete seizure freedom with the lowest dose that achieves it. If breakthrough events occur (your son’s two dizzy-confused spells likely represent partial seizures or “auras”), the dose is considered sub-therapeutic.

3. Kids grow … and drug levels fall  
   • Weight gain and body-water changes in children steadily lower the “mg/kg” exposure unless the dose is periodically adjusted upward.  
   • Neurologists often write the first follow-up prescription at a dose they already know the child will need in a few weeks or months so that the parents don’t have to scramble for a rapid refill.

4. Keppra is usually titrated in steps to minimize behavioural side-effects  
   • Fast escalation can cause irritability, mood swings, or sleep problems.  
   • A common schedule is: Week 1 – starter dose; Week 2 – moderate dose; Week 3 – target dose (sometimes Week 4 or 5).  
   • If side-effects appear during titration, you can pause at the current step or back down—so the gradual increase gives flexibility.

5. Side-effects are dose-related, but the incidence plateaus  
   • At typical pediatric target doses most children still tolerate Keppra well.  
   • Major blood-work worries (liver/renal toxicity, bone marrow suppression) are extremely rare with levetiracetam, unlike with some older seizure drugs.  
   • Behavioural changes (irritability, mood) occur in ~10–15 % of kids and often settle after the first few weeks even if the dose is kept constant.  
   • Your neurologist balances that risk against the very real risk of more seizures if the dose is left too low.

6. How long will he need it?  
   • For idiopathic generalized or focal epilepsy a common plan is to keep a child on medication until he has been seizure-free for 2 years, then consider a gradual taper.  
   • Early, complete seizure control is associated with a better long-term chance of eventually coming off medicine altogether.

Questions you might ask the neurologist
• What is the exact mg/kg/day target for my child’s weight?  
• Are you planning another step-up after 3 mL, or is that the intended maintenance dose?  
• What specific side-effects should we watch for, and what should we do if we notice them?  
• Under what circumstances should we call you before the next scheduled visit?  
• If my child remains seizure-free at the higher dose, how long will he stay on it before we discuss tapering?

Take-home points
• The first “starter” prescription is usually not the final therapeutic dose.  
• Having even very mild breakthrough spells means the dose is not fully protective.  
• A modest increase now (3 mL) still keeps him in the low end of the normal therapeutic range but adds a safety margin against future seizures.  
• Keppra is generally safe; most side-effects are reversible and can be managed by adjusting the dose again if they appear.

If you remain uncomfortable, share these concerns with your son’s neurologist. They can review the weight-based calculations with you, outline the titration plan, and decide together whether to proceed more slowly or hold at the current dose.

89.question: 48F, 152cm, 70kgGraves' disease in and out of remission for 10 years (remission last 2 years)Stopped carbimazole two weeks agoVery mild temporal lobe epilepsy for 30 yearsLevetiracetam 500mg dailyTetanus vaccination for deep cat scratch five days agoJust finishing a 5-day course of amoxicillin w/ clavulanic acid for same scratchA few days ago, I noticed some swelling above my left clavicle, and I can feel a pea-to-marble sized lump. Immediately, my paranoid brain went to my endocrinologist telling me a couple weeks ago that my lymphocytes have been low for the last two years (0.9) and that one of my liver values is slightly high. My neutrophils, which I understand can be affected by the carbimazole, are normal according to a blood test done just before I stopped taking it.Later, my rational brain kicked in and remembered that I just had a tetanus shot last week in the left arm. I have a doctor's appointment coming up and will certainly mention it, but I guess I'm looking for some reassurance in the meantime. Could it be the tetanus shot that has caused the lymph node swelling? Google results are terrifying for that particular node. Thanks in advance.
89.answer:
I am not your treating physician, but the following points should help you decide how worried you need to be while you wait for your appointment.

1. How likely is a supraclavicular (“above-the-collar-bone”) node to enlarge after a shot in the arm?
• Almost all of the lymph from the skin and muscles of the left arm eventually drains through the left axillary nodes and then into the lower left supraclavicular nodes before it enters the venous blood stream.
• Any brisk immune stimulus in that arm—tetanus-diphtheria booster, COVID shot, shingles shot, significant scratch, etc.—can cause the downstream nodes to become temporarily enlarged and a little tender.
• In vaccine trials, up to 1 – 6 % of adults notice a palpable node in the axilla or supraclavicular fossa after a tetanus-containing shot; the real number is probably higher because most people never check.

2. Your situation contains two separate “triggers”
• Tetanus booster five days ago in the left arm.
• An actual infected cat scratch on the same limb (cat-scratch disease is classically associated with prominent arm/axillary lymph-node swelling, and you have been on an antibiotic active against the usual bacteria).

Either of these alone could produce a pea-to-marble-sized node. Having both in quick succession makes a reactive node even more probable.

3. Features that point toward a harmless, reactive node
• Small size (< 1.5 cm), rubbery, mobile.
• Appeared within a week of a clear local immune stimulus.
• Mild tenderness or “awareness.”
• No systemic “B-symptoms”: fevers, drenching night sweats, unexplained weight loss, severe fatigue.

4. Features that would push your doctor to investigate more aggressively
• Firm, rock-hard or “stony” node, fixed to surrounding tissue.
• Size > 2 cm, or rapid growth over days to weeks.
• Multiple nodal areas involved (both sides of neck, groin, etc.).
• Persistent enlargement beyond 4–6 weeks with no shrinking.
• Abnormal full blood count (especially if neutrophils or platelets start falling).
• Systemic symptoms listed above.

5. What about your low lymphocyte count and mildly raised liver enzyme?
• A lymphocyte count of 0.9 × 10^9/L (900/µL) is only mildly low and quite common in Graves’ disease, chronic stress, infections, and with certain drugs (including carbimazole and, occasionally, levetiracetam). Most people with counts in that range handle infections and vaccines perfectly well.
• A single slightly elevated liver enzyme is nonspecific; recent antibiotics, carbimazole ramp-down, alcohol, weight, and autoimmune thyroid disease itself all can bump liver tests.

6. What will the doctor likely do?
• Physical examination of all lymph-node regions.
• Review your most recent full blood count and liver profile; repeat them if they were drawn before the vaccine.
• If the node is typical of a reactive gland, the usual advice is “watchful waiting”: warm compresses/NSAIDs if tender, no poking/squeezing, re-check in 3–4 weeks.
• If the node is large, atypical, or persists > 4–6 weeks, an ultrasound (+/- fine-needle aspiration) is the next step. This is quick, low-risk, and very good at telling reactive from suspicious nodes.

7. What can you do meantime?
• Mark the outline of the lump with a washable marker and jot down today’s date; that lets you know objectively whether it is shrinking, stable, or growing.
• Note any new symptoms such as fever, night sweats, or weight loss and report them promptly.
• Avoid repeated prodding—this keeps it irritated and may make it seem larger.

Bottom line
Given the timing (cat scratch infection plus tetanus shot in the same arm) and the small, mobile character you describe, a benign reactive lymph node is by far the most likely explanation. The “Virchow’s node” cancer scenario you found on Google usually involves a large, rock-hard, non-tender lump that appears out of the blue without any arm injury or vaccination. Mention it at your appointment, but there is no immediate red-flag warning in what you have described.

90.question: I (22m) currently am on Vimpat and Phenobarbital for epilepsy, which I take twice a day. This morning however, my alarm decided to only vibrate instead of actually going off in order to wake me up to take my meds. So I was 3 hours late in taking them. I know that Vimpat is already pretty much out of your system in 12 hours, which worries me that I took it after 15 hours this morning. I have a bunch of important things to do all this week (some of which involve a lot of driving) and I’m now worried about any breakthrough seizures. So my question is, should I be worried or expect something to happen? And when will I know that I am in the clear and nothing will happen due to me being late on a dose?Side note: I did call my doctor and ask this already, but I’m currently waiting on a call back response, which sometimes takes hours, so I figured I would ask on here as well.
90.answer:
I’m not your treating physician, so use this only as general information until you speak with your own doctor.  
That said, a single dose that is 2-4 h late is very unlikely to undo seizure control for most people taking lacosamide (Vimpat) plus phenobarbital.

Why a 3-hour delay is usually low-risk  
1. Lacosamide’s half-life is ≈13 h. After 12 h you still have ~50 % of the previous dose in your bloodstream; after 15 h you still have ≈40 %. Taking the tablet 3 h late simply tops the level back up, so you never actually go drug-free.  
2. Phenobarbital’s half-life is 60-120 h (2½–5 days). Blood concentrations change so slowly that a few hours makes virtually no difference.  
3. Breakthrough seizures from a single, slightly late dose are uncommon unless you are extremely sensitive to small fluctuations, have frequent seizures despite meds, or have other triggers (sleep-loss, alcohol, illness, flashing lights, etc.) at the same time.

What to do today  
• You already took the missed dose—good.  
• Take tonight’s dose at the normal time. Do NOT shift the whole schedule forward and do NOT take extra to “catch up.”  
• Try to keep the rest of your day as seizure-friendly as possible: adequate sleep tonight, regular meals, good hydration, no alcohol or recreational drugs, and limit extreme stress.

When you’re “in the clear”  
Drug levels will be fully back in their usual steady state after the next scheduled dose—effectively within 12–24 h. If you haven’t had any warning symptoms (auras, unusual twitches, déjà-vu spells) in that window, the risk from this particular delay has essentially passed.

Driving and other important tasks  
Regulations differ by region, but most authorities do not require you to stop driving after a single late dose if you remain seizure-free. Still, use common sense:  
• If you feel “off,” unusually drowsy, or have any aura-like sensations, don’t drive.  
• Make sure someone knows you were late on a dose and can step in if needed.  
• Consider delaying very long solo drives until after you’ve had at least one on-time dose without problems.

When to seek help urgently  
• Any seizure activity, even brief.  
• New or worsening auras, jerks, or confusion.  
• Severe dizziness, double vision, palpitations, or fainting (very uncommon but possible with lacosamide).

How to keep it from happening again  
• Use an alarm that rings AND vibrates; set a backup on another device.  
• Link meds to a daily routine (e.g., toothbrush, breakfast).  
• Pill organizers with built-in alarms, or smartphone apps that keep prompting until you confirm, can help.

Bottom line  
A 3-hour delay is almost never enough to cause breakthrough seizures in someone on lacosamide plus phenobarbital. Take the dose as soon as you remember (as you did), resume the regular schedule, and observe yourself for the rest of the day. After tonight’s normally timed dose you’re effectively “reset.” Always confirm with your own neurologist, but you can be reasonably confident that no major problem will result from this single late dose.

91.question: 28F. 5'8, 250lbs. White. History of epilepsy, asthma and vitamin D & B12 deficiency. Currently on Lamotrigine, Folic acid, Vitamin D, B12 injections.In the last few months I've had some debilitating health issues and, in the process of figuring out what the hell is happening to me, I just learned that my FSH is 122.2 miu/ml. My pcp has ordered estrogen levels to be checked and says we'll have to retest everything in a month to confirm a diagnosis of premature menopause. I just turned 28. I haven't menstruated in 6 months, so what are the chances that my reproductive organs will spontaneously start working again? What could cause this? And is there anything I should be worried about or does this just happen sometimes?
91.answer:
Short answer first  
• A single follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) value of 122 mIU/mL in a woman who has not bled for 6 months is almost always the biochemical picture of ovarian failure/menopause.  
• In a woman under 40 we call this premature-ovarian-insufficiency (POI), not “menopause,” because ovarian activity can come and go; about 5–10 % of women with POI will ovulate again and a few (≈5 %) will conceive spontaneously.  
• The result has to be repeated together with an estradiol level to confirm the diagnosis and to be certain the test was done correctly.  
• Once confirmed, the main issues are (1) looking for a cause, (2) protecting your bones, heart and general health with hormone-replacement therapy, and (3) discussing fertility options if you ever want to be pregnant.

1. Why the level has to be repeated  
• A diagnosis of POI requires TWO FSH measurements ≥40 mIU/mL, at least 4 weeks apart, together with a low estradiol (<30–50 pg/mL), in a woman who has missed her periods ≥4 months.  
• Lab errors occur; pregnancy, combined oral contraceptives or recent high-dose steroids can also confuse interpretation.

2. How likely is it that your ovaries “wake up” again?  
• Roughly 50–75 % of women with POI will have occasional, unpredictable ovarian activity (bleeding or a positive ovulation test).  
• Sustained return of completely normal cycles is uncommon and hard to predict.  
• Lifetime natural-pregnancy rate after a POI diagnosis is around 5–10 %. Because you are very early in the process, your personal chance could be in that range, but you should not rely on it.

3. What can cause POI in a 28-year-old?  
(About half of cases remain “idiopathic,” i.e., no cause is ever found.)  
A. Genetic  
   – X-chromosome abnormalities (Turner mosaic, X-q deletions)  
   – FMR1 premutation (fragile-X carrier)  
   – Rare FSH-receptor or LH-receptor mutations  

B. Auto-immune  
   – Thyroid disease (Hashimoto, Graves)  
   – Adrenal (Addison), type 1 diabetes, celiac disease  
   – Isolated autoimmune oophoritis  
   – Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome  

C. Iatrogenic / environmental  
   – Chemotherapy, pelvic radiation, major pelvic surgery  
   – Pelvic arterial embolization, severe pelvic infection, mumps oophoritis  
   – Cigarette smoking, very high solvent/chemical exposure (rare)  

D. Metabolic/infectious  
   – Classic galactosemia, HIV, severe systemic infection (rare)  

Your current medicines (lamotrigine, folic acid, vit D, B12) are not known to elevate FSH.

4. What tests are usually done after the repeat FSH/estradiol?  
• Pregnancy test (again)  
• Prolactin, TSH  
• LH (usually also high), AMH (very low or undetectable)  
• Karyotype (blood chromosome analysis)  
• FMR1 CGG repeat testing  
• 21-hydroxylase adrenal antibody (screens for Addison’s)  
• Thyroid peroxidase antibody (screens for autoimmune thyroid)  
• Basic metabolic panel, fasting lipids, vitamin D level, celiac panel if symptoms  
• Bone-density scan (DEXA) once diagnosis is confirmed

None of these tests delay the start of treatment—HRT can be begun as soon as the diagnosis looks solid.

5. Why you should care even if you don’t want children right now  
Low estrogen for 20+ years raises the risks of:  
• Osteoporosis and fragility fractures  
• Premature cardiovascular disease  
• Vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes, night sweats)  
• Genito-urinary syndrome (dryness, pain with sex, recurrent UTIs)  
• Mood disorders and cognitive changes

6. Treatment basics  
A. Hormone-replacement therapy (HRT) until at least the average age of natural menopause (≈51):  
   – Either transdermal or oral 17β-estradiol plus a progestin (if you have an intact uterus)  
   – An alternative is a combined oral contraceptive; HRT generally gives steadier physiologic estrogen levels.  
B. Calcium/Vitamin-D (you are already on vit D but make sure 25-OHD stays >30 ng/mL).  
C. Weight-bearing exercise, smoking avoidance, healthy diet, BP and lipid monitoring.  
D. Contraception: even with POI you can ovulate unpredictably; if pregnancy would be a problem, use contraception.  
E. Fertility options: egg/embryo donation IVF has the best success rate; if you still have follicles on ultrasound, experimental approaches or ovarian-tissue banking may be discussed.

7. Things to bring up with your doctor  
• Any family history of early menopause, fragile-X syndrome, autoimmune disease, infertility, or unusual genetic conditions.  
• Prior chemotherapy, pelvic surgery, severe pelvic infections, or radiation exposure.  
• Recurrent mouth ulcers, skin pigment changes, weight loss or low blood pressure spells (possible Addison’s).  
• Mood changes; POI often affects mental health—counseling or support groups help.

8. When to seek immediate attention  
• Sudden severe headaches, visual changes, galactorrhea, which could point to a pituitary process (rare but needs MRI).  
• Flank pain, skin pigmentation, dizziness with low blood pressure—possible Addisonian crisis in autoimmune polyglandular syndrome.

Bottom line  
A repeat set of labs is needed, but an FSH of 122 mIU/mL and 6 months without periods in a 28-year-old almost always means premature ovarian insufficiency. About 1 woman in 10 will still conceive naturally, but you should assume you will need hormone-replacement therapy for long-term health and consider fertility planning if future pregnancy is important to you. Make sure your doctor completes the standard work-up (estradiol, repeat FSH, TSH, prolactin, autoimmune and genetic screening) and start discussing HRT and fertility options promptly.

92.question: A few years back while In the military I had a freak accident until it stopped being that and continued to occur day after day. After some months I was diagnosed with epilepsy.In the beginning I was having 1-3 seizures a day while 2-4 of those were grand mal seizures a month. Medications didn’t work and just seemed to make everything worse so my neurologist made the decision to not give me medications after having tried 5 of them.It’s been a few years now and nowadays I get anywhere from 2-5? Every 4months and about 2 or 3 of those are grand mal seizures. A significant decrease but still ongoing. We never found a cause for the seizures.Well I’m asking because a few months back I started noticing a few things that started worrying me. For example,    a few years back and at the beginning of this I used to be “smart” as in I could write any word no matter how big or small but in recent months I’ve noticed I have a really hard time writing, as in spelling out words. I used to full on turn on autocorrect on my phone but nowadays I find myself almost completely depending on my phones autocorrect and looking up word spellings when even my phone can’t tell what I’m trying to say.    with writing again, for some reason I find myself forgetting or I don’t know, not using simple words such as “the” “of” “to” “and” “from” etc. or sometimes mistaking one word for another when there’s no connection between the two    same thing as above but with speech. I never had any speed impediment or any speech disorder prior but now I find myself getting “stuck” while trying to say a word. It’s to the point where it’ll happen at least once with every full sentence I try to speak. It’s gotten to the point where I’ll see it happening and I’ll try to say the word again and I won’t be able to, I’ll need to dramatically slow down my speech and literally say it in segments    dramatic increase in repeatedly forgetting. I’ll forget my keys, go back and get them, get there and forget what I was going to get or sometimes I’ll forget I forgot. So I’ll go back, then head back out and be like “I went back for my keys and came back without my keys” Male 23 5’11 185lbs first diagnosed at 20. The last neurologist was in the military prior to he being discharged so around 20years of ageEdit: cluster seizures have been very common with me. There’s been about 5x since it started where I’ve stopped breathing, one time in particular it was a really long time.
92.answer:
I’m not your doctor, but based on what you describe several red-flag issues jump out:

1. You remain essentially untreated for an active epilepsy that is still producing generalized tonic-clonic (“grand-mal”) seizures every few months and clusters in which you have actually stopped breathing.
2. You are now noticing progressive problems with language (word-finding, spelling, omitting little connecting words, getting “stuck” mid-sentence) and with short-term memory.

Either of those on its own would justify a prompt re-evaluation; together they make it urgent.

Why this needs attention quickly
•  Recurrent uncontrolled seizures can themselves injure brain tissue, especially in language-dominant temporal and frontal areas, leading to exactly the kinds of word-finding and memory problems you’re noticing.  
•  A structural brain problem (for example a slowly growing tumor, cortical dysplasia, scar tissue, stroke-like lesion, or an autoimmune process) can both cause seizures and progressively affect language.  
•  Repeated episodes in which you “stop breathing” raise your risk of SUDEP (Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy) and make seizure control critical.

Key steps to ask for
1.  Get back under the care of a neurologist—preferably an epileptologist at a Comprehensive Epilepsy Center. If you no longer have military coverage, ask your primary doctor for an urgent referral; most large academic medical centers have such programs.

2.  Update your diagnostic work-up  
   •  High-resolution MRI with an “epilepsy protocol.”  
   •  Video-EEG monitoring to characterize exactly where the seizures start and how often sub-clinical seizures may be occurring.  
   •  Basic labs (electrolytes, liver, kidney, thyroid, B12/folate, inflammatory markers) and possibly an autoimmune / paraneoplastic panel if no cause is found on MRI.  
   •  Formal neuro-psychological testing and speech-language evaluation to document the pattern and severity of the language and memory changes.

3.  Re-visit treatment options  
   •  Medication: More than 20 anti-seizure drugs are available. Failing five does not exhaust the list, and combinations often work when single drugs don’t. Doses and side-effect profiles vary widely. An epileptologist can often find something tolerable.  
   •  Non-pharmacologic therapies: ketogenic or modified Atkins diet, vagus-nerve stimulator (VNS), responsive neuro-stimulation (RNS), or deep-brain stimulator (DBS).  
   •  Epilepsy surgery: If video-EEG and imaging show a removable seizure focus, surgical resection can sometimes cure or dramatically reduce seizures.  
   •  Rescue plan: You should have a prescribed “as-needed” rescue medicine (e.g., intranasal midazolam) that a family member or roommate can give if you go into a prolonged or cluster seizure. Discuss nighttime supervision (monitor, seizure alarm) because of the apnea events.

4.  Manage safety and quality of life right now  
   •  No driving or operation of dangerous machinery until cleared by a neurologist.  
   •  Keep a seizure diary (date, time, type, duration, triggers, recovery).  
   •  Make sure at least one person you live or work with knows basic first-aid for seizures and when to call 911.  
   •  Consider speech-language therapy; it can’t fix an ongoing neurological injury, but it often helps you develop strategies to work around word-finding and memory gaps.

What the language problems may mean
Your description—omitting small connector words, substituting or misspelling words, and needing to slow down to get a word out—sounds like an expressive language (Broca’s) or word-retrieval (anomic) aphasia rather than a simple speech motor problem. That points to involvement of the dominant (usually left) frontal or temporal lobe, regions that also frequently generate focal seizures that can generalize. Whether the seizures are damaging those areas or an underlying lesion there is causing both problems is exactly the question imaging and EEG can answer.

When to treat as an emergency
Go to an emergency department (preferably one with neurology on call) if you have:
•  A seizure lasting longer than 5 minutes or a cluster without full recovery in between.  
•  Any new weakness, numbness, vision loss, or persistent confusion.  
•  A sudden, dramatic worsening of the language problems (can’t produce coherent sentences, profound confusion).  
•  Another episode in which you stop breathing or turn blue.

Bottom line
Progressive language and memory decline in someone with uncontrolled epilepsy is not normal aging, stress, or “just part of seizures.” It needs immediate evaluation. Getting re-connected with a neurologist/epileptologist, repeating imaging and EEG, and aggressively pursuing modern treatment and safety measures is the best way to protect your brain—and your life—going forward.

(I am providing general information, not personal medical advice; please seek in-person care promptly.)

93.question: Age/Sex: 20M Height: 5' 10" Weight: 175 lbs About a month ago I swallowed roughly 42 grams of keppra. I eventually vomited, fell asleep, and woke up feeling pretty normal. I'm curious if there should be any hidden Long-term Health effects caused by my consumption of that much keppra that may not be obvious such as kidney, liver, or brain problems. Additionally, I am curious how likely it is I would have died from consuming that much Keppra and if a death from keppra would be painful.
93.answer:
I’m glad you’re feeling well now.  Below is what is known about levetiracetam (Keppra) overdoses and any possible late-appearing problems after a large, single ingestion.  It is strictly informational and not a substitute for seeing a clinician; if you have any new symptoms or concerns, please get checked.

1.  What happens in a levetiracetam overdose?  
   •  The drug has a very wide safety margin.  In clinical studies, single doses up to 10 g produced only sleepiness, agitation, and dizziness.  
   •  Case reports describe people surviving 20–30 g with only mild, short-lived symptoms, and a handful who survived 50–194 g with supportive hospital care.  
   •  Reported overdose effects: somnolence, agitation/irritability, confusion, dizziness, vomiting, and (rarely) seizures or respiratory depression.  
   •  There are almost no documented deaths in which levetiracetam alone was judged the cause; the few fatalities involved multiple substances or serious underlying illness.

2.  Why is it hard to fatally overdose on Keppra?  
   •  It does not markedly depress breathing or heart function the way opioids or tricyclics do.  
   •  About 66 % of an oral dose is excreted unchanged by the kidneys, and the rest is broken into inactive, non-toxic metabolites.  
   •  It has minimal binding to plasma proteins, so dialysis will remove it if levels become very high.

3.  Would death (if it occurred) be “painful”?  
   •  A toxic dose produces progressive drowsiness, then deep sleep or coma; if death occurred it would most likely be from respiratory failure while unconscious, not from a painful mechanism.

4.  Likelihood of delayed or hidden organ damage after a single 42 g ingestion  
   •  Liver: Levetiracetam is not metabolized through the major liver enzyme systems (it uses esterase hydrolysis), and it is not known to be hepatotoxic.  A one-time overdose has not been shown to cause chronic liver injury.  
   •  Kidneys: Because the drug is cleared renally, pre-existing severe kidney disease can prolong its half-life.  However, a solitary overdose in someone with normal kidneys has not been linked to later renal impairment.  Routine labs a week or two after the event would normally be enough to confirm this.  
   •  Brain/neurologic: The drug binds to the SV2A synaptic protein and then is cleared; it is not known to cause structural brain injury.  What can persist (in about 10–15 % of users even on therapeutic doses) are mood-related side effects—irritability, depression, anxiety.  Those are functional, not structural, and usually resolve when the drug leaves the body, though any mood changes should be followed up.  
   •  Other organs: No reports of delayed cardiotoxicity, marrow toxicity, or endocrine problems from levetiracetam alone.

5.  Practical steps after your event  
   •  If you haven’t already, a basic follow-up exam with routine chemistries (electrolytes, kidney function, liver enzymes) provides reassurance that nothing silent was missed.  
   •  Pay attention over the next weeks to new-onset mood changes, insomnia, irritability, or suicidal thinking—whether they feel related to the drug or not—and seek help promptly if they appear.  
   •  Because large overdoses, even of “safe” drugs, are often associated with emotional distress, it’s wise to talk openly with a trusted physician, counselor, or mental-health professional about what led to the ingestion.

6.  Bottom line  
   •  Based on published data, a one-time 42 g levetiracetam ingestion in an otherwise healthy adult who is currently asymptomatic is unlikely to produce hidden or delayed organ damage.  
   •  The risk of death from that amount alone appears very low, and if it did occur it would typically involve loss of consciousness rather than pain.  
   •  A quick medical check and ongoing attention to mental health are the main recommended follow-ups.

If anything new crops up—fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, persistent mood swings—don’t hesitate to seek care.

94.question: 27F (180cm, 90kg, Austrian) diagnosed with: Crohn's disease (2013), SLE with CNS involvement/Neurolupus(2021), Epilepsy(2021), SFN (2022) medication: Levetiracetam 3000mg/d, Lacosamide 400mg/d, Perampanel 6mg/d, Gabapentin 600mg/d, Hydroxychloroquine 300mg/d, methylprednisolone 10mg/d, pantoprazole 40mg/d, mesalazine 4g/d, Rituximab 375mg/kg twice a year I get red (surrounded) patches on my tongue for about half a year now, 1-3 times per month in 6 different positions, usually just 1 or 2 simultaneously (https://imgur.com/a/LepvOwL). In the picture you see two on my left side, there can be another one on the left tip and the same can be mirrored on the right side. The most I had at the same time were 3 of these. They are painful, especially on contact (when eating); it's a burning sensation most of the time. They start small, get bigger and then develop a white "ring" instead of the red (in the photo), after this state the tongue gets white and the whole mouth has an unpleasant taste. But I would actually say I have good oral hygiene. Could this be related to one of my diseases, or could it be a side effect or something completely unrelated? I've already asked one of my doctors but he had no idea what this could be (out of his field). Which doctor would you suggest visiting, a dermatologist? I'm hoping to find someone here to help me out. I would be thankful for any ideas about what this might be, how to reduce the pain (except for standard painkillers) or to prevent it completely. Compared to my diseases it's not really that bad of course, but another annoying thing that might trigger despair.
94.answer:
What you are describing – and what can be seen on the photograph – corresponds almost perfectly to the condition that oral-medicine specialists call “benign migratory glossitis”, better known as geographic tongue or erythema migrans.

Why this diagnosis fits

• Typical appearance Bright-red, slightly depressed patches with a sharply demarcated, whitish or yellowish rim.

• Typical behaviour A patch enlarges during 1-3 days, then the edge begins to desquamate, another white ring may appear, and after 7-10 days the area re-epithelialises while one or more new foci may start elsewhere (“migration”).

• Symptoms Many people feel nothing, others (like you) complain of burning or stinging, especially with hot, spicy, acidic, salty or alcoholic foods and with tooth-paste foaming agents.

• Frequency of attacks Intermittent, sometimes several times per month, sometimes absent for months.

• Predisposing factors It is more common in people with other inflammatory / auto-immune disorders (Crohn’s disease, psoriasis, atopy, Reiter’s syndrome, SLE, etc.), in people who are iron or B-vitamin deficient, and in people who are chronically stressed or immunosuppressed. Your medical background therefore increases the likelihood.

What it is NOT

• It is not an infection; you cannot “give it” to anyone and it is not dangerous for you.

• It is not oral thrush (candida produces removable white plaques, not migrating red patches with a white rim).

• It is not leucoplakia or oral cancer; those lesions do not migrate and do not clear spontaneously.

Are any of your medicines responsible?

None of the drugs you list are known to induce geographic tongue. Systemic corticosteroids, hydroxychloroquine and rituximab do, however, lower the local immune defence, so secondary candida infection can occasionally complicate things, but that looks different (see above).

What can be done?

Because the condition is harmless, the main goals are comfort and reducing the frequency/severity of flares.

1. Identify and avoid personal triggers  
   – Hot, very spicy, acidic, salty, tomato-based, nutty or rough-textured foods, alcohol, tobacco.  
   – Toothpastes containing sodium-lauryl-sulfate (SLS) or whitening agents.  
   – Stress and overtiredness (keep a short diary – you might discover patterns).

2. Symptomatic relief during a flare  
   – Rinse with cool water or ice chips before eating.  
   – Topical anaesthetic gels/sprays (2 % lidocaine or benzydamine 0.15 % mouth-wash) 5–10 min before meals.  
   – OTC preparations containing sucralfate or a barrier paste (e.g. Orabase).  
   – If burning is intense despite the above: a short (5-7 day) course of a mild topical corticosteroid such as triamcinolone 0.1 % in Orabase, applied thinly 3–4 × daily, often helps. Because you are already on systemic steroids, this would add very little additional risk but should still be prescribed and supervised by a clinician.

3. Check and correct contributory deficiencies  
   – Ask your GP or gastroenterologist to measure ferritin, full blood count, folate, vitamin B12, vitamin B2/B6 and zinc. Crohn’s disease frequently causes subclinical deficiencies that can aggravate glossitis.

4. Good basic oral care  
   – Soft toothbrush; non-alcoholic, non-SLS toothpaste or just a mild kids’ toothpaste; flossing.  
   – If a candidosis is suspected (generalised cottage-cheese-like coating that can be wiped off): a 7- to 14-day course of nystatin or miconazole oral gel quickly clears it.

Which doctor should you see?

• The people who deal with this every day are dentists with an interest in oral medicine/oral pathology, oral & maxillofacial surgeons, or ENT (otolaryngology) specialists. A dermatologist can also help, but many dermatology clinics will refer mouth problems to oral medicine/ENT.

• Take a series of photographs with dates – it is very helpful for the specialist.

When to worry / seek prompt review

– A lesion that stays in exactly the same place for > 2 weeks.  
– Ulcers that penetrate deeply or bleed easily.  
– Indurated (hard) areas, lumps or persistent white patches that cannot be wiped off.  
– Unexplained weight loss, dysphagia, enlarged neck nodes.  
These are NOT typical of geographic tongue and warrant direct evaluation.

Prognosis

Geographic tongue tends to wax and wane for years; some people eventually “outgrow” it, others have lifelong occasional flares. It does not turn into cancer and it does not damage the tongue.

In summary

Everything you describe – appearance, course, symptoms, your underlying diseases – points to benign migratory glossitis (geographic tongue). It is annoying but harmless. Start with trigger-avoidance, topical anaesthetic or mild steroid gel for pain, and have your dentist/ENT/oral-medicine specialist confirm the diagnosis and screen for deficiencies or super-infection.

95.question: TL:DR - Need answers about my 10 year old cousin who is suffering from migraines and seizure like symptoms, yet doctors claim it is not related to epilepsy and cannot find diagnoses.My 10 year old cousin who is probably around 4.3 feet and weights around 75 ibs, Fiona, (not her real name but for privacy’s sake...) has been having this ever since New Year’s Day 2021. It all started when she was having headaches or migraines. She started taking medications, and apparently she was having them per every fours hours.Then on February 15, I got a text from another cousin saying that Fiona was in the hospital due to her passing out, her legs feeling numb, and not being able to move. The doctors say that it’s probably due to the medication being taken too often. She was later sent back home since she got better. She stopped taking the migraine medications anymore, but then things got worse.She then started having some kind of seizure-like episodes. In these episodes she started shaking, twitching, having migraines from light sensitivity, trouble breathing, and that she feels hot. They last over 10 minutes and she has them up to 10 times a day or even more. She also has them in specific time periods such as 6:30 PM.When we called 911 and sent her to the hospital, she had to keep going back-and-forth and that this has happened five times due to doctors not being able to diagnose her (even though they had witnessed her symptoms). They keep saying things that we are sure that it is not true. Here are the things that they said:“ The episodes that she is having are not seizures.“ “It is probably from depression or some psychological problems.” (my cousin has never suffered from depression or anything like that) The first time that I witnessed one of Fiona‘s episodes in real life was during when we were having a welcoming back party for her. This episode lasted 50 minutes due to the fact that we cannot stand having this back-and-forth situation. It is absolutely heartbreaking and frustrating knowing we could not do anything. It has gone to the point that they have to go to Philadelphia (I assume they have better doctors over there), and they still said that it’s probably due to the medication. She is currently back home and still suffering from this. Again, I’m pretty sure that my cousin is not on any harsh medication whatsoever. All she is actually taking is Tylenol, and it is in moderation. So I am concerned as to if symptoms like this can last this long. In the end I know that this forum is not a place to find a diagnosis, but I hope that I can find an answer here. Just a little piece of assumption of what could she is going through can help my family get through this hard time.
95.answer:
I’m sorry your cousin and family are going through such a confusing and frightening experience.  
No one on the internet can tell you exactly what is happening, but I can explain why the doctors may be saying “we don’t think these are epileptic seizures,” outline the most common conditions that can look this way in a 10-year-old, and suggest what evaluations usually clear the picture up.

1. Why “seizure-like” spells are not always epilepsy  
• Epileptic seizures are bursts of abnormal electrical activity in the brain.  
• Many other problems (migraine variants, fainting, metabolic disturbances, certain heart rhythms, and especially psychogenic nonepileptic seizures) can cause shaking, staring, or loss of awareness, yet the EEG remains normal.  
• If the emergency-room EEG done between spells is normal, doctors hesitate to call the events “epilepsy” without catching one on video-EEG.

2. The usual possibilities in a child who already has migraine

A. Complicated / hemiplegic / basilar-type migraine  
 • Children can have attacks with headache, eye pain, light sensitivity, limb weakness, numbness, confusion, or jerking movements that mimic seizures.  
 • Episodes can last 10 min to an hour or more and cluster at roughly the same time of day.  
 • An MRI and sometimes certain migraine-gene panels are done mainly to rule out stroke-like disorders.

B. Medication-overuse (rebound) headache  
 • Acetaminophen (Tylenol) every 4 h for days to weeks easily exceeds the “more than 2–3 days/week” threshold that can set up a vicious cycle: medication → brief relief → withdrawal pain → more medication.  
 • This itself does not cause seizures, but the relentless pain plus caffeine withdrawal, missed meals, or poor sleep can precipitate fainting or stress-induced shaking.

C. Syncope / autonomic instability (e.g., POTS)  
 • In kids, sudden stand-up, dehydration, or pain can drop blood pressure, causing fainting, limb shaking, eye-rolling, and “I feel hot.”  
 • A tilt-table test or simple orthostatic vitals (lying, sitting, standing blood pressure and heart rate) looks for this.

D. Psychogenic Nonepileptic Seizures (PNES) – a kind of Functional Neurologic Disorder  
 • Very common in children with chronic pain.  
 • Movements often last longer than epileptic seizures, happen many times a day, and may stop if the child is distracted. Breathing can be irregular, but pupils remain reactive and there is no post-ictal sleepiness.  
 • PNES is not “faking.”  Stress gets converted into real body symptoms; treatment is counselling plus physical/occupational therapy focused on retraining the spells.

E. Less common but important to exclude  
 • Metabolic (hypoglycaemia, calcium, sodium, magnesium, urea cycle disorders)  
 • Auto-immune encephalitis (anti-NMDA, MOG, etc.)  
 • Cardiac arrhythmias (long QT, SVT)  
 • Infection/inflammation of the brain (EEG, spinal tap, MRI look for this).

3. What usually sorts it out

1. Full paediatric neurology review at a tertiary centre (Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, for example).  
2. In-hospital video-EEG monitoring long enough to capture several of her spells. If the EEG stays normal during a spell, it essentially rules out epilepsy and points to migraine, PNES, or syncope.  
3. Brain MRI with and without contrast (if not yet done).  
4. Basic and, if suggested, extended labs (electrolytes, glucose, liver, renal, calcium/magnesium, thyroid, inflammatory markers, auto-immune panels).  
5. Orthostatic vitals ± tilt-table; ECG ± 24-h Holter if fainting is prominent.  
6. Headache diary: time of onset, duration, possible triggers, foods, sleep, mood, medication taken, and video recordings of the spells on a phone.

4. What the family can do now

• Use as little acute pain medicine as possible (no more than 2 days a week) until a neurologist sets up a proper preventive plan.  
• Hydration, regular meals, strict sleep schedule, and elimination of caffeine drastically reduce paediatric migraine frequency.  
• Record several episodes on a phone—start filming before the shaking if possible; include the child’s face, limbs, and a clock in view.  
• Ask for a referral specifically to a paediatric epileptologist or a “multidisciplinary spells clinic” (neurology + psychology + cardiology) if available.  
• If PNES is eventually diagnosed, early acceptance and engagement with cognitive–behavioural therapy plus physiotherapy gives an excellent chance of stopping the attacks.

5. Red-flag reasons to return to the ED immediately

• New prolonged (>5 min) loss of consciousness that does not stop,  
• One-sided weakness that persists after the spell,  
• Fever, stiff neck, severe vomiting, vision loss, or speech loss,  
• Palpitations or known heart disease.

Bottom line

Headache plus frequent “seizures” is frightening, but in children it is often:
– a complicated migraine variant,  
– medication-overuse worsening the headaches, or  
– psychogenic nonepileptic seizures triggered by stress and pain.

All of these are treatable once the correct team (paediatric neurology, sometimes cardiology and psychology) sees good video-EEG evidence. Keep pushing for that inpatient video-EEG study at a children’s hospital; it is the single most useful test for getting an answer and a proper treatment plan.

96.question: Hi there.My husband underwent surgery 2 years ago to remove an encephalocele in his right temporal lobe that was causing seizures. He had no side effects and no seizures, and received permission from his neuro team to begin weaning off meds. He was completely off by March 2021. Last month I woke up to him having a tonic-clonic seizure in his sleep.Today we recieved the results of his MRI."There has been interval surgical repair of right tegmen mastoideum encephalocele, with new small region of encephalomalacia and gliosis in the adjacent right inferior temporal and parahippocampal gyri. Amygdala and hippocampi are otherwise relatively symmetric with normal signal and configuration.No evidence of mass, suspicious enhancement, or epileptogenic focus elsewhere in the brain."Our next appointment with his neurologist is in a week but it feels like a millenia.
