We are trying to understand so we can prepare ourselves for possible courses of treatment.Is ANY amount of encephalomalacia/gliosis expected following a lesionectomy? Does this result suggest he may just need additional support from pharmaceuticals to control seizures, or are we going to be exploring the possibility of another surgery?  Anything you can offer would help put my mind at ease.Demographics: 34yo male, healthy nonsmoker (6'2, 175lb). Craniosynostosis confirmed (IL11RA variant) and consequently underwent craniofacial reconstructive surgery at age 16. Diagnosed with right temporal lobe epilepsy at age 30. Encephalocele removed from temporal lobe and with medication patient was seizure free for 2 years. July 2021 MRI details new encephalomalacia/glioma near the resection site. Currently on 400mg Vimpat for epilepsy. No other health concerns.
96.answer:
I can’t give individual medical advice, but I can walk you through what the words on the MRI report usually mean, why they show up after a temporal-lobe lesionectomy/encephalocele repair, and what the typical decision-tree looks like when someone has a breakthrough seizure after coming off medicine.

1. What the radiology terms mean  
• Encephalomalacia = “softening” or loss of brain tissue that has already died or been removed. On MRI it looks darker than normal brain and is usually filled with cerebrospinal fluid.  
• Gliosis = the brain’s version of scar formation (a proliferation of support cells called astrocytes) that surrounds any area that has been injured, removed, or deprived of blood supply.  
• The inferior temporal gyrus, parahippocampal gyrus, amygdala and hippocampus are all parts of the medial/right temporal lobe system that can generate seizures.  
• “Relatively symmetric with normal signal” for the amygdala/hippocampus means those deep structures do not show atrophy, sclerosis, or a mass.  
• “No evidence of mass, suspicious enhancement, or epileptogenic focus elsewhere” is reassuring: no tumour, no active infection, no new encephalocele, no area that is obviously lighting up as a new seizure focus on structural imaging.

So the radiologist is basically saying: “I see the expected postoperative changes (the repaired skull base defect, some scar and a tiny area of volume loss) and nothing alarming or unexpected elsewhere.”

2. Is it normal to see encephalomalacia/gliosis two years after surgery?  
Yes. Any time brain tissue is removed, a rim of gliosis forms and small pockets of encephalomalacia can deepen over the first 6–12 months as the cavity remodels. It does not mean there is an active destructive process; it’s the healed footprint of the original procedure. Radiologists sometimes call it “new” only because that exact pocket wasn’t visible on the very first post-op MRI, not because it is a new disease.

3. Can that scarred area provoke seizures?  
Unfortunately, yes. Any structural abnormality—including the scar that cured the original encephalocele—can remain an epileptogenic focus. The fact that he stayed seizure-free for two years tells us the surgery did eliminate a major driver, but the underlying brain still has the circuitry to seize under the right circumstances (sleep deprivation, alcohol, infection, medication withdrawal, etc.). Many centres quote a 60–80 % “seizure-free” rate after resection of a temporal lesion; the remainder may have a late relapse, most often when antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) are tapered.

4. What usually happens after one breakthrough tonic-clonic seizure?  
Typical steps your neurologist/epileptologist will consider:  
a) Resume or increase an AED (you’ve already restarted lacosamide/Vimpat 400 mg). A single breakthrough event, especially after drug withdrawal, is managed medically first.  
b) Order a routine or prolonged EEG to see if there is interictal activity over the right temporal region and to make sure no new zone has emerged.  
c) Review lifestyle seizure triggers (sleep, stress, stimulants, alcohol).  
d) Continue AED therapy for at least another 2–3 years seizure-free before entertaining another taper.

Only if seizures recur despite two appropriately chosen, well-dosed AEDs would they start talking about further surgical or device-based options (repeat resection, laser ablation, RNS, DBS, VNS). One isolated event after coming off meds rarely pushes anyone back to the operating room.

5. Does the MRI show a “glioma”?  
No. Gliosis and glioma sound alike but are very different. The report explicitly says “no suspicious enhancement” and actually calls the finding gliosis; a glioma would enhance or distort architecture, grow over serial scans, and come with a very different radiology description.

6. Practical questions to ask at next week’s visit  
• Do we need a long-term video-EEG to map any residual focus?  
• What dose range of lacosamide is ideal, and should we add a second agent?  
• How long should we remain on medication before another taper is considered?  
• Any lifestyle measures to reduce the chance of sleep-related seizures?  
• What are the driving/work restrictions after a single breakthrough event in our state/province?  
• At what point would you refer us back for surgical reevaluation?

7. Prognosis  
Most patients who have a late seizure after withdrawing medication regain complete control once an AED is reinstated. In published series, only 10–20 % go on to develop medically refractory epilepsy requiring a second intervention. The absence of a new mass, progressive lesion, or hippocampal sclerosis on MRI is a favourable sign.

Bottom line  
• The “small region of encephalomalacia and gliosis” is expected postoperative scarring, not a new tumour or active disease.  
• A single breakthrough seizure months after stopping AEDs is common, and first-line management is simply going back on medication.  
• Further surgery is considered only if seizures become frequent and resistant to at least two well-chosen drugs.  

I hope this helps you go into the appointment with a clearer picture and a shorter list of worries.

97.question: 42 F Lamictal, cymbalta, singulair, levothyroxine, Pepcid, ambien 200lbs (significant weight gain in 3 years after injury to cervical spine - unable to run like I used to so I’m confident that is the main reason why) 3-4 drinks per year, past prescription drug use (all prescribed but over used/abused) no addictive medications for almost 2 years besides ambien but now I’m very careful. Quit smoking cigarettes 1 year ago. Use juul 5% nicotine 1-2 pods per day. History: postpartum psychosis, depression, epilepsy, hashimotos, reynauds, allergy induced asthma, thoracic aneurysm, insomnia Last year I made an appointment with a new family doctor due to a move. I was very open and honest about all past health issues and casually asked about my fainting spells. This is an issue that was ongoing since I was 12. After many tests they determined it is epilepsy. It seems to be well controlled now that I’m medicated and I haven’t had an episode/seizure for 10 months. In those months I’ve noticed I started to “feel things I see”. It’s so bizarre and hard to really explain. When I’m really engrossed in a program or movie and I see someone hug, get hurt, temp changes, even sex, I lightly feel the sensation. If I see certain places (like a national geo program) I can smell and feel the environment. I did ask my neurologist about it and she said that she didn’t think it’s a seizure but it’s strange how it started after they are controlled. My question is about synesthesia and if it’s something that is just pseudoscience or if there is concrete evidence on it? Could this be a mental disorder manifesting that will eventually take a downward turn? I have no complaints about the sensations because they are actually pleasant but it does scare me that they aren’t “normal”. Thanks to all the doctors who visit this sub and offer help!
97.answer:
What you are describing sounds very much like one of the recognized forms of synaesthesia — specifically “mirror-touch” (feeling on your own body what you see happen to someone else) together with a milder cross-modal form (“seeing” a scene and simultaneously getting a faint smell or temperature sensation).

1.  Is synaesthesia real?  
    • Yes.  It has been documented for more than a century and has been studied with modern tools such as functional MRI, magneto-encephalography and trans-cranial magnetic stimulation.  
    • In classic developmental synaesthesia the response is automatic, consistent over time and not under voluntary control; the brain areas that normally process the triggering sense co-activate areas that normally process the second sense.  
    • Roughly 3-5 % of the general population have some form of it; mirror-touch is rarer (≈ 1–2 per 1000).

2.  Acquired synaesthesia can appear in adults  
    It has been reported after:  
    • migraine aura  
    • head injury or stroke  
    • temporal-lobe epilepsy and after epilepsy surgery  
    • certain drugs (e.g. LSD, psilocybin, occasionally after starting or stopping SSRIs / SNRIs)  
    • periods of sensory deprivation (e.g. blindness)  
    The common theme is a change in the balance between brain networks; disinhibition can “unmask” cross-talk that is usually suppressed.

3.  Could it be an epileptic phenomenon?  
    Temporal-lobe seizures can produce complex auras: smells, tastes, déjà-vu, visceral sensations, emotional rushes.  
    Key differences:  
    • Seizure auras are usually brief (seconds–<2 min) and often followed by confusion, automatisms, or overt seizure activity.  
    • Your sensations last as long as you continue to watch the scene, are pleasant, and do not evolve into other seizure signs.  
    • 10 months seizure-free on lamotrigine also argues against ongoing sub-clinical seizure activity, but the only way to be certain would be an EEG while the symptom is provoked (most centres can arrange a short video-EEG session with your trigger clip).

4.  Could it be a psychiatric disorder?  
    • True hallucinations (perceiving something that is not there at all) can occur in psychosis or severe mood disorders.  
    • What you are describing is stimulus-induced, congruent with what you are seeing, and does not include loss of reality-testing. That fits synaesthesia or vivid multimodal imagery, not psychosis.  
    • There is no evidence that synaesthesia in itself progresses to a mental illness.  In fact, people with synaesthesia have rates of anxiety and depression similar to (or slightly lower than) the general population once other factors are controlled for.

5.  Medication factors  
    • Lamotrigine and duloxetine are not classically associated with inducing synaesthesia, but both can heighten sensory imagery in a minority of users.  
    • The fact that the phenomenon appeared after your seizures came under control could reflect removal of frequent abnormal discharges that were “dampening” certain networks. Once the brain settled into a more stable rhythm, the cross-modal links may have become noticeable.

6.  Should you worry?  
    • If the sensations stay pleasant, only occur with an external trigger, and are not accompanied by confusion, loss of awareness, motor twitching, or prolonged after-effects, they are probably benign.  
    • You should seek review if you start to have:  
      – sensations that appear out of the blue without any external stimulus  
      – episodes of blank staring, loss of time, lip-smacking, picking at clothes, or sudden jerks  
      – distressing voices or visions unrelated to reality  
      – sudden change in mood, sleep-wake reversal, or inability to function at work/home

7.  Practical next steps  
    • Keep a brief diary: date/time, what you were watching, exactly what you felt, how long it lasted, and whether anyone else noticed anything odd about you.  
    • Bring that diary to your neurologist.  If there is any doubt they can order a short trigger-based EEG.  
    • A formal neuropsychological assessment can objectively document the cross-modal responses if you want confirmation (there are standard “consistency” tests for synaesthesia).  
    • Continue your current seizure-control regimen unless your neurologist advises otherwise.  
    • Good brain hygiene still matters: regular sleep, steady caffeine and alcohol intake (you already drink very little), healthy diet and cardiovascular exercise that does not strain your cervical spine.

Bottom line  
Synaesthesia is a well-studied, concrete neuro-sensory phenomenon, not pseudoscience and not, by itself, a sign of a deteriorating mental illness. In your situation it is most likely a benign, acquired mirror-touch / cross-modal synaesthesia that surfaced after your epilepsy came under control. Keep a log, mention it at your next neurology follow-up, and seek reassessment only if the experiences start to break free of external triggers or are accompanied by other seizure or psychiatric warning signs.

98.question: Hello! I am a 51M and have had left temporal lobe epilepsy my whole life. I weight 130 pounds and I am 5’6”. I recently had an MRI done as I have had increased migraines and headaches. Here are my medications:    Lamotrigine    Topomax    Propranolol    UbrelvyMy MRI report came back and I have noticed new impressions and findings in it. I was wondering if someone could alleviate some anxiety and explain what these things mean. Specifically, the “Brain” and “Impression” portions of the report.Thank you very much in advance. COMPARISON: MRI brain dated 12/05/2018   TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar, multisequence images were obtained of the brain without administration of intravenous contrast.    FINDINGS:   HEMORRHAGE: No acute parenchymal, subarachnoid or extra-axial hemorrhage.    DWI: No evidence of acute or early subacute infarction.    BRAIN: No mass effect or edema. No significant atrophy or chronic microvascular ischemic changes. Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white matter signal abnormality on the right.    VENTRICLES: Unremarkable. No hydrocephalus.    CALVARIUM: Unremarkable.    PARANASAL SINUSES: Unremarkable.    MASTOID AIR CELLS: Unremarkable.    OTHER FINDINGS: None.    IMPRESSION:   Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white matter signal abnormality on the right which may be related to microvascular ischemic change with demyelinating disease not excluded.
98.answer:
Below is a plain-language walk-through of the sections of the report that usually worry people the most.  Nothing here replaces a face-to-face discussion with your own neurologist, but it should help you understand what the radiologist is saying (and just as important, what he or she is NOT saying).

------------------------------------------------
1.  “BRAIN” SECTION  
   Reported text  
   “No mass effect or edema. No significant atrophy or chronic microvascular ischemic changes. Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white-matter signal abnormality on the right.”

What it means

• No mass effect or edema  
  – There is no tumor, large cyst, abscess, hemorrhage, or swelling that is pushing on or distorting brain tissue.

• No significant atrophy  
  – Your brain volume looks normal for age; tissue is not shrinking more than expected.

• No chronic microvascular ischemic changes  
  – The radiologist does not see the larger, confluent white-matter scars that are often seen in people with long-standing high blood pressure, diabetes, or other vascular risk factors.

• “Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white-matter signal abnormality on the right.”  
  – Translation: A “punctate focus” is a very small spot (literally pinpoint-sized) that shows up bright on certain MRI sequences (T2 and FLAIR).  
  – Location: right-sided white matter (the brain’s wiring).  
  – Number: “few” usually means 1–3 dots.  
  – Size: tiny; radiologists use “punctate” only if each dot is under 3 mm or so.

Why do these dots appear?

The most frequent benign causes at age 51 are:  
  • Migraine (especially if headaches have become more active).  
  • “Microvascular” change—minute changes in the very small blood vessels that nourish the white matter. Hypertension, smoking, high cholesterol, or diabetes accelerate them, but they can appear in perfectly healthy people too.  
  • Prior minor viral illnesses or other non-specific inflammatory events.  

Less common but often mentioned causes the radiologist is obliged to list:  
  • Demyelinating disease (multiple sclerosis, etc.). MS lesions tend to be more numerous, larger, ovoid, often around the ventricles (“Dawson’s fingers”) and in the corpus callosum. Isolated punctate dots, especially on only one side, are not a classic MS pattern, but the disclaimer remains because a non-contrast study cannot completely exclude it.  
  • Vasculitis or other inflammatory disorders (rare; clinical picture usually very different).

------------------------------------------------
2.  “IMPRESSION” SECTION  
   Reported text  
   “Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white-matter signal abnormality on the right which may be related to microvascular ischemic change with demyelinating disease not excluded.”

What it means

• The radiologist’s bottom-line: “I see a few tiny bright dots. Most likely they reflect microvascular change. In the absence of contrast and without clinical information, I cannot 100 % rule out an early demyelinating process such as MS, but nothing on this scan forces that conclusion.”  
• In radiology-speak, “not excluded” means “I can’t say zero—but I see no strong evidence for it.”

------------------------------------------------
3.  COMPARISON WITH YOUR 2018 SCAN

The report does not mention “interval progression” or “new lesions,” which suggests either:  
  • The tiny spots were already present in 2018 and look unchanged; or  
  • They are new but so few and small that the radiologist does not consider the change clinically significant.  

If your 2018 report is handy, look for mention of “white-matter hyperintensities”; if they were there then, this is likely a stable picture.

------------------------------------------------
4.  How worried should you be?

Most neurologists would summarise your scan as “essentially normal for a 51-year-old with migraines/epilepsy.”  
• These findings do NOT explain seizures; they do NOT mean an impending stroke or dementia.  
• They are extremely unlikely to require surgery, additional medicines, or an urgent change in your epilepsy treatment.  
• Given your migraine history, many specialists call these dots “migraine spots.” They rarely change a headache treatment plan.

------------------------------------------------
5.  Common next steps

Because the MRI is essentially reassuring, many neurologists would:  
1. Correlate with your exam. If you have no objective neurologic deficits (weakness, sensory loss, visual field cut, etc.), observation is typical.  
2. Address modifiable vascular risks: blood pressure, lipids, weight, exercise, smoking, sleep apnea, etc. Even if microvascular changes are mild, keeping them mild is worthwhile.  
3. If MS or another demyelinating disease is a clinical possibility (for example, you’ve had unexplained spells of numbness, visual loss, or problems walking separate from your seizures), they may order:  
   • MRI with gadolinium contrast (shows active inflammation)  
   • Cervical/thoracic spine MRI  
   • Blood tests or, rarely, a lumbar puncture.  
   In the absence of such symptoms, most docs stop here.  
4. Follow-up MRI in 12–24 months if there is any clinical change, or sooner if new symptoms arise.

------------------------------------------------
6.  Practical tips for the appointment with your neurologist

Bring:  
• This report plus the 2018 report (or a CD/USB of the images).  
• A concise timeline of migraine frequency/intensity, seizure control, medication changes, and any new neurologic symptoms.  
Ask:  
• “Do these white-matter spots require additional tests or treatment?”  
• “Are they consistent with my migraine history? With my seizure history?”  
• “Should any of my medications be adjusted in light of these MRI findings?”  
• “When should we repeat imaging?”  

------------------------------------------------
7.  Reassurance in one sentence

Tiny white-matter spots are common, usually benign, and—based on the wording of this report—nothing alarming or urgently actionable has been found.

------------------------------------------------
Bottom line

Your scan shows no tumor, no bleed, no stroke, no worrisome atrophy, and only a few minute white-matter spots that most often accompany migraines or tiny vessel changes seen in people over 50. Your neurologist will likely integrate this with your clinical picture, optimise migraine/vascular risk factors, and continue routine follow-up.

99.question: 23M, 6’5 and wondering if liquid nytol is okay to use with a very mild form of epilepsy (no seizures) that is triggered by light.On no other medications but have ADHD and anxiety and can’t sleep anymore
99.answer:
Short answer  
Liquid Nytol contains the sedating antihistamine diphenhydramine.  In people with a history of epilepsy it is not an absolute “never-use”, but every formulary (e.g. British National Formulary, U.S. Epilepsy Foundation, etc.) lists “use with caution / may lower seizure threshold”.  Because you do carry a diagnosis of epilepsy—even though your seizures are only light-triggered—you should clear any diphenhydramine-containing sleep aid with your own GP / neurologist before using it.

Why the caution?  
• Diphenhydramine readily crosses the blood–brain barrier and has mild pro-convulsant properties.  
• At therapeutic doses the risk is small, but seizures are a known feature of overdose and of anticholinergic toxicity.  
• In people who already have an abnormally low seizure threshold (epilepsy, sleep-deprivation, anxiety, ADHD, alcohol, etc.) the extra push from diphenhydramine can occasionally be enough to precipitate a breakthrough event.  
• If you eventually need a stimulant for ADHD, taking an anticholinergic sedative at night and a stimulant by day can complicate both seizure risk and sleep quality.

Other practical issues with liquid Nytol  
• Next-day grogginess and impaired concentration (problematic for ADHD).  
• Rapid tolerance—after a week or two it often stops working and people escalate the dose, raising seizure and anticholinergic-delirium risk.  
• Anticholinergic side-effects: dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, urinary hesitancy.  
• If you have to discontinue abruptly after nightly use, “rebound insomnia” is common.

Safer first-line options you can discuss with your doctor  
1. Non-drug measures (strongly recommended before any medication)  
   – Strict sleep schedule, out of bed at the same time every day  
   – Keep the room dark and cool; remove flashing electronics (important for photosensitive epilepsy)  
   – Blue-light filters / glasses after dusk  
   – 30-min wind-down without screens, caffeinated drinks stopped ≥6 h before bed  
   – Relaxation techniques, diaphragmatic breathing, progressive muscle relaxation  
   – Regular daytime exercise, preferably outdoors early in the day  
   – CBT-I (cognitive-behavioural therapy for insomnia) — best long-term evidence

2. Melatonin 1–3 mg 1–2 h before bedtime  
   – Improves both sleep onset and, in some studies, seizure control  
   – Minimal side-effects; does not reduce next-day alertness  
   – Prescription-only in the UK but widely used

3. If a medication is still needed  
   – Low-dose doxepin (3–6 mg)  
   – Trazodone 25–50 mg  
   – Gabapentin or pregabalin (helpful for both anxiety and sleep, anti-seizure properties)  
   These have to be prescribed and monitored but do not lower the seizure threshold the way diphenhydramine can.

4. Treat the underlying ADHD/anxiety  
   – Properly dosed stimulants or non-stimulants (atomoxetine, guanfacine) often improve the circadian rhythm once daytime symptoms are controlled.  
   – CBT or other therapy for anxiety.

If you still decide to try liquid Nytol while waiting to see a doctor  
• Use the lowest effective dose, no more than 7 consecutive nights.  
• Avoid alcohol, cannabis, or other CNS depressants.  
• Have another adult in the household who knows you might seize.  
• Stop immediately if you notice twitching, jerks, visual auras, or paradoxical agitation.  
• Re-discuss with a clinician if insomnia persists beyond a week.

Bottom line  
Because you have an epilepsy diagnosis, even if seizures are only light-triggered, the safest course is to check with your GP/neurologist before starting diphenhydramine (liquid Nytol).  Non-drug measures and alternatives such as melatonin or a prescription agent that does not lower the seizure threshold are preferable.

100.question: 50F in Australia, on carbimazole and levetiracetam for Graves’ and epilepsy, respectively. FOOSH injury of the wrist.I tripped over some uneven pavement while running last night and fell on my hands. I got some road rash on one hand, and both instantly went numb. As the numbness wore off, one had was fine, but the other has pain. It hurts to grip things, and most of the pain is near the base of my thumb. Some pain radiates down the inside of my wrist. It’s not horribly painful but was enough to disrupt my sleep a lot last night, because I couldn’t find a comfortable position for my wrist. It also sent a shooting pain when I tried to use my thumb to press the button on my electric toothbrush.I’ve called a local medical centre, and their radiology office is closed for the weekend. They recommended going to the ED if I want an X-ray, but I’m not convinced it’s that urgent. It’s Saturday here now. Is it ok to wait for Monday, or is there any reason I should get it imaged right away?Here’s the damage to the palm of my hand.
100.answer:
I cannot examine you, so use the information below as general guidance only.  If anything you read here conflicts with advice you receive from an Australian-registered clinician who has actually seen you, follow them.

1.  Why the base-of-thumb pain matters  
•  A fall on an out-stretched hand (FOOSH) that leaves you tender in or just distal to the “anatomical snuff-box” (the hollow between the tendons at the base of the thumb when you make a thumbs-up) is treated as a presumptive scaphoid fracture until proven otherwise.  
•  Scaphoid fractures may not show on the first X-ray; nevertheless, early immobilisation (thumb-spica) is started right away because a missed fracture can go on to non-union or avascular necrosis.  
•  Other structures that can be injured the same way – distal radius, base of 1st metacarpal (Bennett/Rolando fractures), scapho-lunate ligament – are also best dealt with early.

2.  Is this an emergency?  
Go to an Emergency Department today if you notice any of the following:  
•  Visible deformity or step in the wrist/thumb  
•  Progressive swelling that makes the skin shiny or tense  
•  Cool, pale or blue fingers, capillary refill >2 s, or you cannot fully move/feel the digits  
•  Severe pain not settling with paracetamol/ibuprofen (if you can take them)  
•  Wound that is very dirty or looks infected (increasing redness, pus, red streaks, fever)  
•  You need a medical certificate / strong analgesia tonight and can’t get either elsewhere

If none of those are present, most centres would be happy for you to:  
   – Splint the wrist and thumb yourself (see below)  
   – Use simple analgesia and elevation  
   – Arrange imaging within the next 24-48 h

3.  Why sooner rather than “whenever next week”  
•  You are 50 and have Graves’ disease. Prolonged periods of hyper-thyroidism increase bone turnover, so even if you are currently euthyroid, you have a mildly higher fracture risk.  
•  Antiepileptic drugs in general, and possibly levetiracetam, are associated with reduced bone mineral density over time.  
These factors don’t make tonight life-threatening, but they do nudge the needle toward getting an X-ray promptly (by Monday at the latest) and being diligent about immobilisation in the meantime.

4.  What to do until you’re seen  
•  Immobilise: A chemist-bought rigid wrist/thumb splint is ideal.  Second choice: piece of cardboard or magazine on the palmar side, wrist in neutral, thumb in “holding-a-can” position, wrapped with crepe bandage or tape (not tight).  
•  Ice 15-20 min each hour while awake for the first 24 h, then as needed.  
•  Elevate on pillows when resting.  
•  Analgesia: paracetamol ± NSAID if no contraindication (normal kidneys, no peptic ulcer, no NSAID allergy, etc.).  
•  Clean the road rash with warm soapy water; apply a non-stick dressing and change daily or if soaked.  Thin antibiotic ointment can be used if the wound is dirty but is optional if it looks clean.  
•  Avoid lifting, gripping or weight-bearing with that hand.

5.  Getting the imaging  
Option A – Emergency Department today: immediate X-ray, splint, and referral to fracture clinic if needed.  
Option B – Present to a walk-in injury clinic / urgent care centre Sunday if one is open.  
Option C – Book GP or fracture clinic first thing Monday.  Tell the receptionist it is a possible scaphoid fracture so they reserve an X-ray slot the same visit.

6.  After the X-ray  
•  If the initial films are negative but clinical suspicion remains, you will usually stay in the splint and have repeat imaging or advanced imaging (CT/MRI/Bone scan) at 7–10 days.  
•  Confirmed scaphoid or distal-radius fractures are normally put in a plaster splint or cast and followed by orthopaedics or a fracture clinic.  
•  Ligament or base-of-thumb injuries may need different management (e.g., operative fixation, hand therapy).

Bottom line  
Given your description—FOOSH, ongoing pain at the base of the thumb—this deserves imaging and splinting within 24–48 h.  It does not sound limb-threatening tonight, so it is reasonable to wait until morning/Monday provided you splint the hand, the pain is controllable, and there is no worsening numbness, colour change, or deformity.  If any of those appear, or if you simply cannot immobilise it adequately yourself, head to the ED now.

101.question: Epilepsy and lamictal 44 year old female. 215 pounds. Non smoker. Epilepsy. I’ve been diagnosed with epilepsy, juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, since my early 20’s. I would have one maybe a year or so. I started lamictal xr 200mg. First time on meds. Things got better but I still had them. Fast forward to 2019 October I had three in one month. I had my blood levels checked by pcp and neuro. At that point I was on lamictal xr 400mg. My levels have always been around 9ish. These 3 were checked the same time of day. 8/29/19 7.1 10/31/19 6.3 After I changed to newer bottles it was 11/22/19 9.2 These levels were checked because I pushed it. I had this history of always having these pinching headaches in the morning only. I addressed it with my regular neuro that was self pay, 2 others that were through my insurance. All shrugged their shoulders and said it’s fine. When I saw that the 10/31 dropped to 6.3 I for fun decided to start my lamictal bottles that had a later expiration date. The ones I was taking were expiring in 6 months so I went to ones that expiring in 2 years from them. The second opinion neuro said they are actually still good 6 months after expiry. I’m doing better after I changed my bottles out. My regular neuro said that even though expiry date has not passed and that it was older bottles to toss all those and use the newer ones. He used to write double dosage due to saving money so I had a bunch. He had wanted me to increase to 600mg xr but I didn’t because I was scared of making things worse. In April 2020 I finally did and I was in heaven. Morning headaches went away and I was so happy. My neuro shrugged his shoulders and said ok. I thought I was in the clear but I had one in October 2020 most likely due to my recklessly getting less sleep and being under marital stress. I thought great it’s been a year and due to my issues I won’t let it happen again. Now fast forward to June 2021 I had another one. I’m back to bad sleep and marital stress again. I have not had my levels checked but now after that seizure I’m starting to have headaches in the morning. Maybe it’s because I’m stressed again of it happening again maybe because my problems In life haven’t gotten better. My current meds expire a year from now. August 2022. My neuro had explained back then that even though when they were 6 months from expiry it’s possible that there is a somewhat of a decrease in the lamictal that for me it’s pushed me to the edge of it not being as effective for me. So basically my thoughts are is it possible I need to throw out the ones that are one year from expiry? My new ones are June 2023 and I haven’t started those yet. At the nov 2019 visit he first said maybe it’s time of day or fluke but when I told him what I did with newer bottles he then seemed to think the 6 months from expiry were ones that I should throw out even though technically they should be still ok to use. He said let’s say they were manufactured 5 years from expiry that the effectiveness for me is not as good anymore compared to the newer bottles. I haven’t contacted my neuro yet but will be this week. Will see if he’s changed his thoughts on that and maybe he will say one year should be ok and maybe it’s a me thing and nothing to do with my meds. To save money I was trying to finish the ones that expire next year but I would throw those out if a doc thought I should and start new ones. Also odd question. I take xr600 mg a day. Three 200mg pills a day. The new ones will be two xr300mg a day. Would this have any effect blood levels because they are xr and the coating melts at different rate. If they weren’t xr I wouldn’t be asking this question. I haven’t swapped them out to see if the headaches will go away because I was thinking I shouldn’t change the way the dosage is delivered. I just think it was odd. I have 3 seizures in one month and levels dropped. I change to newer bottles and levels go back up again. Also when I started the 600mg dose last year my levels were checked once and they were 12. After this long post my question is should I throw the ones out that expire next year? I won’t be able to get my levels checked anytime soon to see if they have dropped. If you’ve made it this far thanks for reading. Edit the bottles were stored in my dresser. And they were in original manufacture bottle from galxosmithklein gsk
101.answer:
I am not your treating physician, so use the information below only as background for the conversation you are going to have with your own neurologist or epilepsy team.

1.  Lamotrigine (Lamictal) blood-level facts  
   •  In adults who are not taking enzyme-inducing or ‑inhibiting drugs, the “usual” trough (just-before-next-dose) concentration that controls generalized seizures is roughly 3–14 µg/mL. Many patients do fine at 4–6; some need 10-15.   
   •  The assay itself has a ±10 % analytic variance, and day-to-day biologic variance adds another 10–15 %. A reported change from 9.2 to 7.1 to 6.3 µg/mL can therefore be partly—or even largely—normal laboratory scatter.  
   •  With Lamictal XR the difference between a peak sample (3–6 h after the dose) and a trough sample (≈24 h after the dose) is usually <20 %. If samples are not taken at exactly the same time after the dose they can look “different” even when exposure is identical.

2.  Does nearing the expiration date really drop the strength that much?  
   •  Lamotrigine is chemically very stable at room temperature. When stored in the manufacturer’s bottle below 86 °F (30 °C) the U.S. Pharmacopeia allows no more than a 10 % loss of potency at the printed expiration date—usually 4–5 years after manufacture.  
   •  The loss is gradual. A tablet that still has 90 % of labeled drug after 5 years would still have ~95-98 % at one year before the date. That small difference would not move a blood level from 9 to 6 µg/mL.  
   •  Practical point: Unless tablets have been exposed to excessive heat/humidity (kept in a car, bathroom medicine cabinet, etc.) they are considered full-strength up to the stamped date and very likely for many months beyond.  

3.  Why did your level seem to go back up when you opened a “newer” bottle?  
   •  Coincidence and natural variability are the most probable explanations.  
   •  Another possibility is unintentional non-adherence (a missed or late dose here and there). Starting a fresh bottle often makes people more attentive to dosing times.  
   •  Lab timing can also explain it (see Section 1).

4.  3 × 200 mg XR tablets vs 2 × 300 mg XR tablets  
   •  Lamictal XR uses a diffusion-controlled polymer shell; each strength (50, 100, 200, 250, 300 mg) is engineered so the 24-h area-under-the-curve (AUC) is proportional to the dose.  
   •  Pharmacokinetic studies submitted to the FDA show that 3 × 200 mg and 2 × 300 mg give essentially identical daily exposure (Cmax, Cmin, AUC). In ordinary clinical use no dose adjustment is required when switching.  
   •  A small minority of patients report that a different tablet strength “feels” different (probably because of a different pill burden, timing, or simply expectation). If you switch and notice a change, ask for a trough level 5–7 days after the change to document what is really happening.

5.  Morning “pinching” headaches  
   •  Lamotrigine can cause mild morning headaches in some people, but in epilepsy the commonest reasons are inadequate sleep, medication rebound if a dose was missed or delayed, or a subtle nocturnal seizure/myoclonus.  
   •  Keeping a strict sleep schedule and using a smartwatch/fitness tracker or overnight video can help your neurologist see whether the headaches correlate with nocturnal events.

6.  Stress and sleep deprivation  
   •  For juvenile-myoclonic epilepsy, sleep loss is one of the strongest seizure triggers. Marital stress further fragments sleep and raises cortical excitability through cortisol and catecholamine release.  
   •  When breakthrough seizures line up with periods of poor sleep or intense stress, restoring sleep hygiene often does more than a milligram-for-milligram drug increase.

7.  Weight and dose  
   •  You weigh ≈215 lb (≈98 kg). For generalized epilepsy, lamotrigine is often titrated up to 8–10 mg/kg/day when it is the only antiseizure medicine. A 600 mg once-daily dose is right in that ballpark for your body weight.  
   •  If trough levels at 600 mg are only 6 µg/mL and you are still having seizures, some clinicians aim for 10–12 µg/mL by increasing to 700–800 mg/day or by adding a synergistic drug (for example, valproate, topiramate, or levetiracetam). The decision is individualized.

8.  So, should you throw away the tablets that expire in August 2022?  
   •  From a potency and safety standpoint: No. Science says they are still ≥95 % potent, provided they were stored <86 °F and kept dry.  
   •  From a psychological standpoint: If you will constantly worry that “maybe these older tablets aren’t working,” that anxiety itself can steal sleep, raise stress hormones, and raise your seizure risk. In that case it can be reasonable to discard them, even though chemistry says you don’t have to.  
   •  What many patients do is keep the 2022 tablets as a back-up supply (for travel, emergencies, natural disasters) and use the 2023 lot for day-to-day dosing.

9.  Action plan to discuss with your neurologist this week  
   •  Get a trough lamotrigine level (blood drawn ≤1 h before your usual daily dose) while on your current tablets.  
   •  If level is <8–9 µg/mL, discuss increasing to 700–800 mg/day OR switching the timing (e.g., split XR 400 mg AM + IR 200 mg PM) OR adding a second agent.  
   •  Re-emphasize strict sleep hygiene: same bedtime, 7–8 h minimum, no all-nighters, limit blue-light devices after 10 p.m.  
   •  Consider cognitive-behavioral therapy, couples counseling, or other stress-management tools—treating the trigger can be as important as treating the epilepsy.  
   •  Keep a seizure and headache diary including total hours slept, stress level (0-10), menstrual cycle data if relevant, and any missed or late doses.

Key take-home points  
•  Lamotrigine remains close to full potency until the stamped expiration date, so your 2022 tablets are almost certainly fine.  
•  The 3 × 200 mg XR and 2 × 300 mg XR regimens deliver the same total daily exposure for almost everyone.  
•  Small fluctuations in blood level are expected; a drop from 9 to 6 µg/mL can occur from lab timing, assay variability, or missed doses rather than from tablet age.  
•  Sleep loss and stress are potent seizure triggers in juvenile-myoclonic epilepsy; controlling them may help more than discarding “older” tablets.  
•  Get a new trough level, share a detailed seizure/sleep diary with your neurologist, and decide together whether a dose adjustment, add-on drug, or lifestyle change is the next best step.

102.question: My friend's brother just had a baby several days ago. The mom is in her mid 30s, third time mom, healthy. They have 2 completely healthy kids. The pregnancy was good, although the baby was born about a week after due date. The mom was in hospital during that period as she had contractions periodically but they said there wasn't a need to induce her. She delivered a (seemingly) healthy girl on june 27th (due date was june 19th).While she was in hospital, everything seemed great. When my friend and her brother went to pick the mom and baby up from the hospital yesterday, the baby had a mild seizure while the nurses were doing the final check-up. However, it was dismissed and the baby was allowed to go.Just mere hours after the baby got home, she had two more seizures in the span of 3 hours. The first was around 5pm and the second was around 8pm, after which they took the baby to the hospital. They ran some tests and decided to keep her for the night. She had another seizure in the morning, a stronger one, and it was witnessed by a doctor. The doctor was pretty concerned and ordered some other tests. The brain scan and reflexes were good, brain activity was good. They decided to keep her anyway, just to keep an eye on her. The baby was finally seen by a neurologist this afternoon. The neurologist is an older woman, they say she's very experienced in neonatal care. She basically said that it's nothing, that it happens all the time, that the mom was probably hungry, cold and/or scared so she was shaking during delivery which somehow transfered the shakiness to the baby and it manifested as a seizure (3 days later?). Now, I'm absolutely NOT a doctor, much less an experienced neurologist, but this honestly smells like BS. I also don't have kids and have never given birth. Is this possible? My friend and her family are holding onto what this woman said and I definitely don't want to be skeptical, but I really can't help it. It just sounds so impossible to me and the fact that it happened 3 times in the 24 hours the baby was released just makes me believe that the hospital is trying to save itself from a lawsuit.  Can any doctor, nurse, mother, anyone who had or has heard of a similar experience tell me their opinion? Because I truly wish I could believe it, but I simply don't. Even though the test results are good so far.
102.answer:
(I’m not your child’s doctor and I haven’t examined the baby, so please regard this as general information only.  If at any time the parents feel something is being missed they should not hesitate to ask for another opinion or to request transfer to a children’s hospital with a neonatal neurologist.)

1.  Can the mother’s “shakiness” during labor make a baby seize days later?  
No.  A contraction-ridden or shivering mother may influence fetal heart rate or blood-flow while the baby is still attached to the placenta, but once the umbilical cord is cut there is no lingering physiologic “tremor” that can be transferred to the infant.  Maternal hunger, cold or anxiety during labor do not cause neonatal seizures several days later.  So that explanation, taken literally, is not medically plausible.

2.  Could the episodes have been something other than seizures?  
Yes.  Two benign conditions are commonly mistaken for seizures by staff and families:

   • Jitteriness (“tremors”): rapid, low-amplitude shaking that is stimulus-sensitive (starts when the baby is handled, stops when the limb is held).  There is no eye-rolling, no color change, no apnea.  It is common in hungry, cold or overstimulated babies and in the vast majority of cases has no pathologic meaning.  

   • Benign neonatal sleep myoclonus: brief jerks that occur only while the infant is asleep, disappear on awakening, and are associated with a normal EEG.  

If the neurologist actually witnessed an event and decided it was one of these benign phenomena, then her reassurance may be reasonable—although the “because Mom was hungry” phrasing is unusual.

3.  How do professionals decide whether a newborn’s movements are seizures?  
Clues that favor a true seizure:  
   – stereotyped, rhythmic jerking or stiffening that does NOT stop when the limb is held  
   – eye deviation, lip smacking or bicycling movements  
   – associated color change, apnea, or tachycardia  
   – occurs while the baby is quiet or sleeping, not just when crying/handled  
   – abnormal electrical discharges on an EEG recorded during or immediately after the spell  

Because seizures can be subtle in neonates, many units perform a video EEG if there is any doubt.

4.  If they are seizures, is this “nothing to worry about”?  
Any confirmed seizure in the first month of life is considered abnormal and warrants a full work-up, because the differential diagnosis ranges from benign genetic syndromes to treatable metabolic disorders to life-threatening infection or stroke.  Standard evaluation at term includes:  
   • Bedside glucose (hypoglycemia is the commonest cause and easy to miss)  
   • Serum calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium, phosphate  
   • CBC, CRP and blood culture; lumbar puncture if infection suspected  
   • Head ultrasound ± MRI looking for hemorrhage or stroke  
   • EEG  
   • Consideration of inborn errors of metabolism, drug withdrawal, pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy, etc.  

Unless a clearly benign explanation is documented, most neonatologists start phenobarbital or levetiracetam while the work-up is proceeding.

5.  Where does your friend’s family stand now?  
You said:  
   – events happened on day 4 of life  
   – “brain scan and reflexes were good; brain activity was good”  
   – a neurologist was “not worried”.

What remains unclear from your description:  
   • Were serum glucose, calcium, magnesium checked at the time of each event?  
   • Was a full EEG (not just a quick “brain scan”) done?  
   • Did the neurologist actually watch one of the spells on video or at the bedside?  
   • Did the movements stop when the limb was held? Did the baby color-change or stop breathing?  

If the answers all line up with “benign jitteriness” or “benign sleep myoclonus” and the labs/imaging are normal, then it is perfectly reasonable to discharge the infant with routine follow-up.

If any of the answers are “we don’t know,” or if the parents keep seeing events at home, they should document them on video and bring the baby back immediately.  A second opinion from a pediatric neurologist at a tertiary care children’s hospital is never out of place when the issue is neonatal seizures.

Bottom line  
• Maternal shivering does not cause neonatal seizures days later.  
• Jitteriness and benign sleep myoclonus are common and harmless but must be distinguished from true seizures by exam, lab tests and (ideally) EEG.  
• If the episodes were verified seizures, they are not “nothing”—they merit a full neonatal seizure evaluation and, in most centers, treatment.  
• If the family remains uneasy, the safest step is to seek another pediatric neurology opinion and/or arrange for video-EEG monitoring.

103.question: So I'm an 18 yr old Caucasian male (62kg,180cm). Since some months ago, I have constant depersonalization/dereaalization and periods of confusion that really bother me. I went to a neurologist and had an MRI scan(which turned out fine, except for some normal anatomical variants) and I was wondering if my confusion and dpdr can be the result of epilepsy ?(non-convulsive seizures). Thanks!
103.answer:
I’m not able to diagnose you over the Internet, but I can give you some facts that may help you frame the discussion with your own doctor.

1. What “non-convulsive” (focal) epileptic seizures usually look like  
   • Most last seconds to a few minutes.  
   • They are paroxysmal (come and go suddenly), not continuous all day.  
   • Typical subjective symptoms can include déjà vu, jamais vu, a rushing “wave” of fear, smells, tastes, a feeling of being “out of body,” or brief confusion.  
   • After a seizure there may be a post-ictal period of grogginess or disorientation that generally wears off within minutes to a few hours.

   Continuous depersonalization/derealization (DP/DR) day after day is therefore uncharacteristic of epilepsy. It doesn’t completely rule epilepsy out—people can have many brief seizures in a day so that they blur together—but it makes it less likely that epilepsy is the sole explanation.

2. MRI vs. EEG  
   • An MRI mainly looks for structural lesions (tumors, malformations, scars). A normal MRI is common in people who still do have epilepsy.  
   • The key test for epilepsy is an electroencephalogram (EEG); sometimes a routine 20-minute EEG is enough, but often longer ambulatory or video-EEG monitoring is needed to capture an event. If you have not had an EEG, ask your neurologist whether one is warranted.

3. Other medical problems that can mimic what you feel  
   • Migraine aura (with or without headache) can cause DP/DR-like sensations.  
   • Metabolic derangements (low blood sugar, thyroid problems, B-vitamin deficiencies, anemia).  
   • Sleep disorders (sleep deprivation, narcolepsy).  
   • Medication or drug effects (cannabis and some antidepressants can trigger persistent DP/DR in susceptible people).  
   • Anxiety, panic disorder, major depression, PTSD, or a primary depersonalization/dissociation disorder. These are the most common causes of chronic DP/DR in an otherwise healthy young adult.

4. Red-flag features that should prompt urgent neurological reassessment  
   • Sudden worsening of confusion, loss of memory for intervals of time, or episodes witnessed by others in which you stare, stop responding, or exhibit automatic behaviors (lip-smacking, picking at clothes).  
   • New focal neurologic deficits (weakness, speech problems, vision loss).  
   • Severe headaches, especially with vomiting or visual changes.  
   • Any loss of consciousness or convulsive activity.

5. What to do next  
   • Keep a diary. Note exact clock time, duration, triggers, accompanying sensations, and what observers notice. This is extremely helpful for neurologists.  
   • If you have not had at least a screening EEG, ask for one. If the first EEG is normal but suspicion remains, prolonged ambulatory or video-EEG monitoring can be ordered.  
   • Parallel psychiatric evaluation is wise. Even if epilepsy is ruled out, treating anxiety, depression, or a primary dissociative disorder can markedly improve DP/DR symptoms.  
   • Lifestyle: strict sleep schedule, no recreational drugs, limited alcohol/caffeine, regular meals, stress-management techniques, and aerobic exercise—all lower the threshold for both seizures and DP/DR.

Bottom line  
Constant, months-long depersonalization/derealization with intermittent “confusion” is more often psychiatric (or migraine/sleep/anxiety related) than epileptic, but focal seizures can produce brief, recurring DP/DR-like episodes. A normal MRI does not exclude epilepsy. Only an EEG (sometimes prolonged) plus a detailed clinical history can settle the question, so following up with your neurologist (and possibly a mental-health professional) is the next logical step.

This information is educational and not a substitute for in-person medical care. If your symptoms change or you develop any of the red-flag signs above, seek medical attention promptly.

104.question: What would cause a 31 year old Caucasian female w/east European and french-canadian decent who is 5'3 110lbs to have;-Seizures (family history epilepsy, personal history TBI) w/seizure onset being 26.-Chronic low potassium-Chronic borderline and sometimes full anemia-POS ANA 1:320 that had been POS ANA 1:160 for several year but recently has risen-GFR swings on and off from 90 to 70 to as low as 50 in one year and cycling this patten indefinitely-Difficulty w/low glucose however repeat testing and dr deny Diabetic as an option-upon seizure onset new symptoms of small blood clots and bruising. Significant pain in locations followed by relief and brusing in the location.-female doesn't drink (at all) or smoke had been working out regularly last decade until onset of symptoms came with intense fatigue.-Has had 1 child, only complications was significant post birth hemorrhage.-upon seizure onset development of seeing black lines in vision that come and go.-potential stroke upon onset of all above resulting in drop foot right side, eye palsy right side, neuropathy of right side-chronic borderline high MCH-positive Raynauds-Bouts of unprovoked tachycardia with PVC  -aphasia and dysphagia-swelling of joints but negative RA factorTests negative for- -Sjorgens specific -Lupus has been consider however initial workup showed stable c3 and c4 and was dismissed year of all onset. Hasn't had lupus specific retesting since then.Differental offered was MS but cleared on MRIs.
104.answer:
Putting every item that is on your list side-by-side and asking “what unifying process could make all of them happen in a 31-year-old woman?” pushes one very strongly toward a systemic autoimmune connective-tissue disease – in particular systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with secondary antiphospholipid-antibody syndrome (APS) and a lupus/Sjögren-related distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA).

Why this diagnosis ties virtually every feature together

1. Positive ANA that is rising  
   • ANA 1 : 320 is abnormal for any laboratory. 90-plus % of patients with SLE are ANA-positive; the titre commonly climbs when the disease becomes more active.

2. Seizures, stroke-like episode, aphasia, dysphagia, visual field disturbance  
   • Seizure is one of the 19 “neuro-psychiatric SLE” criteria.  
   • APS, which accompanies SLE in ~30–40 % of patients, produces arterial and venous thromboses and can give stroke, TIA, chorea, transient visual loss or scotomas (“black lines”).  
   • Drop-foot and eye palsy on the right side fit either an ischemic lacunar stroke or a focal demyelinating event of neuro-SLE.

3. Fluctuating GFR 90 → 50 mL/min  
   • Early lupus nephritis often begins with subtle falls in GFR that wax and wane.  
   • Alternatively, dRTA (seen in both SLE and primary/seronegative Sjögren’s) causes renal potassium wasting and chronic tubulo-interstitial injury that makes creatinine clearance drift downwards.

4. Chronic hypokalaemia  
   • Distal (type I) RTA is classically caused by Sjögren’s or SLE.  Potassium is lost in the urine; serum CO₂/bicarbonate is low (non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis).  
   • Hypokalaemia produces muscle pain and, when severe, can precipitate arrhythmias and even seizures.

5. Anaemia with high MCH  
   • Anaemia of chronic inflammation and/or autoimmune haemolysis are both common in SLE. Haemolytic anaemia often gives a borderline macrocytosis (high MCH).  Chronic dRTA may also cause mild B-12 or folate deficiency by malabsorption.

6. Unprovoked tachycardia / PVCs  
   • Electrolyte loss (K⁺, Mg²⁺) and autonomic dysfunction of SLE/APS explain this.  Libman-Sacks endocarditis or myocarditis of SLE may also give arrhythmias.

7. Recurrent bruising, “small clots”, Raynaud’s, post-partum haemorrhage  
   • Micro- and macro-thromboses are hallmarks of APS.  
   • Raynaud’s phenomenon appears in ~30 % of SLE/overlap cases.  
   • Thrombocytopenia (immune or APS-related) predisposes both to bruising and to post-partum haemorrhage.

8. Borderline-low glucose spells (but not diabetes)  
   • True autoimmune hypoglycaemia exists (anti-insulin receptor antibodies); more often patients with systemic inflammation have reactive hypoglycaemia when they finally eat after long fatigue-related fasts.  Cortisol deficiency is unlikely because your potassium is low, not high.

9. Joint swelling but seronegative for rheumatoid factor  
   • Non-erosive, seronegative, migratory arthritis/arthralgia is one of the inaugural SLE criteria.

10. Family history of epilepsy and personal TBI  
    • These factors may lower seizure threshold but are insufficient to explain the whole multi-system picture.

What has already been ruled out

• Normal brain/cord MRI makes MS unlikely.  
• Negative anti-Ro/La (SSA/SSB) lowers, but does not eliminate, primary Sjögren’s – 30–40 % of biopsy-proven Sjögren’s patients are seronegative.  
• A chronic vasculitis such as ANCA-associated disease generally produces a strongly positive ANCA rather than a high-titre ANA, and classically causes purpuric skin lesions rather than widespread bruising.

Key investigations still missing (and urgently needed)

1. Full lupus/overlap panel  
   • Anti-dsDNA (highly specific, correlates with renal activity)  
   • Anti-Smith, anti-RNP, anti-chromatin, anti-ribosomal-P  
   • Repeat C3, C4, CH50 (levels fall during active disease)

2. Antiphospholipid antibody panel (twice, ≥12 wk apart for diagnosis)  
   • Lupus anticoagulant (dRVVT and/or aPTT mixing study)  
   • Anti-cardiolipin IgG & IgM  
   • Anti-β2-glycoprotein-I IgG & IgM

3. Renal work-up  
   • Spot urine protein/creatinine and microscopic exam (RBC casts?)  
   • 24-h protein or albumin:creatinine ratio  
   • Serum electrolytes + arterial/venous blood gas to confirm distal RTA (non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis, urine pH >5.5 despite systemic acidosis)

4. CBC with reticulocyte count, haptoglobin, LDH, Coombs test (haemolysis?)  
5. Echocardiogram to look for Libman-Sacks vegetations / myocarditis  
6. Ophthalmologic exam for retinal vasculitis  
7. B-12, folate, ferritin, Mg²⁺ to complete the anaemia/electrolyte picture

If the above panels confirm SLE ± APS

• Induction therapy for active lupus (mycophenolate, tacrolimus or cyclophosphamide + high-dose corticosteroid) is started when renal, neuro or haematologic criteria are met.  
• Lifelong anticoagulation (warfarin or DOAC if no lupus anticoagulant interference) is indicated for definite APS with thrombosis.  
• dRTA is treated with oral bicarbonate/citrate and aggressive K⁺/Mg²⁺ replacement; correcting acidosis often stabilises GFR.  
• Hydroxychloroquine 200–400 mg daily reduces flares, thrombosis and dyslipidaemia.  
• Seizure control with levetiracetam or similar continues; some neuro-SLE patients stop seizing once immunosuppression is effective.  
• Regular monitoring by rheumatology, nephrology and neurology is mandatory.

Alternate, but less likely, single-disease explanations

• Mixed connective-tissue disease (anti-RNP positive) – would still be treated similarly.  
• Seronegative Sjögren’s with APS overlap – harder to fit the stroke and rising ANA without invoking lupus.  
• Mitochondrial disorder (MELAS) – would not explain ANA-positivity, Raynaud’s or hypokalaemic RTA.  
• Paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria – causes anaemia and thrombosis but not ANA, Raynaud’s, seizures or low K⁺.

Bottom line

The combination of a high-titre ANA, neuro events, fluctuating renal function, chronic hypokalaemia, Raynaud’s, clotting/bruising episodes, borderline anaemia and arrhythmias is most parsimoniously explained by systemic lupus erythematosus with antiphospholipid syndrome and distal renal tubular acidosis.  A focused rheumatologic work-up as outlined above is the next critical step; if confirmed, timely immunosuppression and anticoagulation can prevent irreversible organ damage.

105.question: My mum (45F, 165cm, 80kg, non drinker, non smoker) moved from India to Australia in 2006. She had her first seizure (tonic-clonic) in 2009 and was diagnosed with Epilepsy which has been reasonably controlled (rarely any tonic-clonic seizures and isolated absent seizures) with Keppara and Trileptal on varying doses over the last 10 years. Her current dose is Trileptal 750mg bd and Keppara 1000mg bd. She also has medications for high blood pressure and high cholesterol. Mum recently went to India for 6 months and after returning, has been dealing with multiple absent seizures a day where she will have a lapse of attention and mental confusion/unable to pay attention. There are also lip smacking and chewing motions also. She has accidentally injured herself during the absent seizures and they seem to occur in periods of stress/anxiety. As a result, the docs are saying there might be a psychological aspect to her epilepsy. She has most of her family overseas so has always dealt with feeling isolated and may be feeling more so since coming back from India. We are getting her in with a pyschologist in the New Year but really want to know if anyone on here can offer any advice on why the medications are no longer controlling the absent seizures and if there might be something we are missing. It has impacted her lifestyle/QoL immensely over the last decade and it is getting worse so if anyone has advice on different ways we can manage this, we would be grateful. Whether it is seeing a different medical specialist, allied health practitioners or things we can implement to ensure her safety. Thank you.
105.answer:
I realise the family is looking for something very concrete to do while you wait for the psychology appointment, so the outline below is designed to be as practical as possible.  Think of it in three steps:

(1)  Confirm what is really happening.  
(2)  Look for—and fix—any new “provokers.”  
(3)  Optimise treatment and safety.

────────────────────────────────
1.  Make sure the events really are epileptic
────────────────────────────────
• What you describe – sudden loss of contact, lip-smacking, chewing, confusion afterwards – sounds more like focal-impaired-awareness (temporal-lobe) seizures than classical “absence” seizures, which are brief, no-warning lapses more typical in children.  
• Psychogenic non-epileptic events (PNES) can look similar and are common when stress is high; giving more anti-seizure drug does not help PNES.

The only reliable way to separate the two is video-EEG recording.  
Ask the neurologist for:  
 – Routine EEG first (may show new epileptic discharges).  
 – If ordinary EEG is unrevealing, a 24-72 h ambulatory or in-hospital VIDEO-EEG.

(If your public hospital queue is long, most Australian capital cities have private long-term video-EEG labs that can be accessed with a GP or neurologist referral; cost is often partly covered by Medicare/private cover.)

────────────────────────────────
2.  Systematically look for new seizure “triggers”
────────────────────────────────
A single change is often enough to break previously good control.

Drug factors  
• Brand / formulation switch in India? Different generic levetiracetam or oxcarbazepine can alter blood levels.  
• Missed doses or irregular timing while travelling?  
• Weight has crept up (now 80 kg) – both drugs are dosed on weight; she may simply be under-dosed.  
• Interactions: some antihypertensives (hydrochlorothiazide), some statins, stomach remedies (omeprazole) can lower sodium or change drug metabolism.  
• Measure serum Na⁺ (oxcarbazepine commonly causes hyponatraemia, which in turn provokes seizures).  
• Check eGFR; levetiracetam is renally cleared—impaired kidney function can give fluctuating levels.

Medical / metabolic factors  
• Perimenopause: falling oestrogen sometimes increases seizures.  
• Thyroid dysfunction, infection, new structural brain lesion (request a repeat MRI if none done in the last 3–4 y).  
• Sleep deprivation, jet-lag after long flights.  
• Alcohol is not an issue for her, but dehydrating summer heat and fasting can be.

Laboratory bundle worth ordering through the GP now  
 FBC, U&E (especially sodium), LFT, eGFR, thyroid panel, fasting glucose, lipids (already on record), CRP, and, if affordable, an “AED level” for levetiracetam to see whether she is in therapeutic range (oxcarbazepine levels are less useful).

────────────────────────────────
3.  Optimise treatment and safety
────────────────────────────────
A. Medication strategy (to discuss with her neurologist/epileptologist)

Typical adult “ceiling” doses are higher than she is on:  
 Levetiracetam up to 1.5 g twice daily (3 g/day)  
 Oxcarbazepine 600–900 mg twice daily (1.2–1.8 g/day)  

Options:  
1. Simply stepwise-increase levetiracetam (250 mg every 5–7 days) while monitoring mood.  
2. If hyponatraemia or side-effects appear, drop oxcarbazepine and substitute:  
 • Lacosamide 100 mg bid    • Lamotrigine slow titration (good for focal ± absence)  
 • Topiramate, perampanel or clobazam as add-on.  
3. If clear focal-temporal pattern, many Australian centres will consider:  
 • Sodium-valproate (very effective for mixed generalised/focal but watch weight and lipids)  
 • Vagus-Nerve Stimulator or Responsive NeuroStimulator (RNS) for drug-refractory cases.  
4. Dietary therapies (modified ketogenic / low-glycaemic), particularly if weight loss is also desired—requires dietitian familiar with epilepsy.

B. Psychological / behavioural adjuncts

Even if events turn out to be purely epileptic, stress clearly lowers seizure threshold.  
• Formal cognitive-behavioural therapy or ACT with a psychologist (already booked).  
• Mindfulness apps, yoga, gentle exercise programme—ideally something social to fight isolation.  
• If levetiracetam is fuelling irritability or low mood (“Kepp-rage”), switching to brivaracetam or lamotrigine often helps.

C. Safety checklist you can implement tomorrow

Home  
 – Shower, not bath; non-slip mat.  
 – Cook on rear burners, use microwave / air-fryer more, buy cut-resistant gloves.  
 – Bedside seizure mat or low bed if night-time events occur.  
 – Chair rather than standing to iron / chop.  
 – No climbing ladders, no swimming alone.

Outside  
 – Medical-ID bracelet with “Epilepsy – Takes levetiracetam & oxcarbazepine.”  
 – Phone app that detects prolonged non-movement (e.g. SeizAlarm, EpiWatch) and alerts family.  
 – Driving: Australian national guideline is seizure-free ≥6 months (private licence) – discuss with doctor; you are legally obliged to notify the licence authority.

Medication adherence  
 – Weekly pill organiser, phone alarms.  
 – Replace any tablets brought from India with Australian pharmacy supply to eliminate potency doubts.

Develop a one-page “Seizure Action Plan”  
• What her seizures look like.  
• When an ambulance should be called (≥5 minutes, injury, cluster >3 in an hour, breathing trouble).  
• List rescue medicine if prescribed (e.g. 10 mg buccal midazolam).

────────────────────────────────
Which specialists and services?

1.  Epileptologist (neurologist sub-specialised in epilepsy) at a Comprehensive Epilepsy Centre – request referral now; waiting lists can be months.  
2.  Video-EEG unit (public or private) for diagnostic clarification.  
3.  Epilepsy nurse-educator – many hospitals and Epilepsy Foundation (Vic/NSW/QLD) offer free sessions.  
4.  Accredited practising dietitian experienced in ketogenic / low-GI diet, if considering dietary therapy.  
5.  Neuropsychologist if memory/cognition are major issues.

────────────────────────────────
Bottom line

Sudden loss of previously stable control nearly always has an identifiable reason: under-dosing, metabolic derangement, brand switch, new brain pathology, or the events are not epileptic at all.  Start with a lab screen, video-EEG, medication review and mental-health support; meanwhile, tighten daily routines and household safety.  Escalate to an epilepsy centre if she is still having seizures after two adequately tried drugs at therapeutic doses.

106.question: Ever since I was a little kid, every few months I get hit with absolutely insatiable vinegar cravings. I will straight up drink it from the bottle and still want more. I also get cravings like this for things that are quite acidic in nature, such as lemons, hot sauce, or tomatoes. As a kid my parents would have to literally cut me off because I would eat so much my lips would turn white, and I’d still want more. I’ll sit down and eat an entire head of lettuce, bundle of celery, full size cucumber, etc with vinegar on it. (Idk if this is important, but I hate apple cider vinegar. My go to is red wine vinegar, but white vinegar or balsamic will also do the trick.) I do imbibe on occasion and have noticed that the last two days after I did get these vinegar cravings, but other than that, I can’t pinpoint any specific triggers.I’m a healthy weight and eat a fairly varied diet, and the only oddities in my bloodwork are low white blood cell counts.I’ve heard that sometimes intense cravings can signal some sort of biological clue for a nutrient that is missing. Could that be something that is going on? I was just curious! This doesn’t really negatively impact my life, it just causes me to get some weird looks sometimes.Details: 23F, 5 ft 3 inches, 130 lbs, Caucasian, acid cravings, existing medical issues (Migraines, IST, mitral and tricuspid valve regurgitation), medications (verapamil and singulair), no drugs, sparingly drink, no smoking.
106.answer:
What science actually knows about “vinegar / sour food cravings” is pretty limited.  That said, the few things that can make people repeatedly seek out very acidic foods fall into four broad categories.  You can use the list as a quick check-list with your own doctor, but the bottom line is that in most otherwise-healthy people this turns out to be a harmless taste preference rather than a sign of a dangerous deficiency.

────────────────────────────────────────
1. Iron-deficiency–related pica or “acidophagia”
────────────────────────────────────────
•  Pica is the umbrella term for recurring, hard-to-resist cravings for substances that don’t usually count as normal food (ice, chalk, starch, dirt, etc.).  
•  A less common variant, sometimes called acidophagia, is a powerful desire for very sour/acidic items—pickles, lemon slices, straight vinegar.  
•  Roughly 1 in 3 people with iron-deficiency anaemia develop some kind of pica.  Case reports show the acid craving can disappear once iron stores (ferritin) are re-filled.  
•  Worthwhile lab tests: CBC with indices, ferritin, serum iron, transferrin saturation.  (A normal haemoglobin does not exclude low ferritin.)

────────────────────────────────────────
2. Low or fluctuating stomach acid (hypochlorhydria/achlorhydria)
────────────────────────────────────────
•  When the stomach is producing too little acid, some people notice they digest meat poorly or feel unusually full; they may start adding vinegar, lemon juice, or hot sauce to “help things along.”  
•  Causes include Helicobacter pylori infection, long-term acid-suppressing drugs, autoimmune gastritis, and (rare at your age) pernicious anaemia.  
•  If you also have early satiety, bloating, or unusual belching after meals, mention this to your physician.  Simple tests: serum B12, gastric pH during endoscopy, or a urea breath test for H. pylori.

────────────────────────────────────────
3. Learned or behavioural factors
────────────────────────────────────────
•  Highly acidic food stimulates the trigeminal nerve and gives a quick sensory “jolt,” which some people find soothing or even mildly addictive—similar to the kick from very spicy food.  
•  Sourness also increases salivation and can transiently reduce nausea; some migraine and dysautonomia patients discover this by trial and error and then start to crave it cyclically.  
•  Alcohol intake can temporarily blunt taste buds, making strong flavours (including acidity) more appealing for a day or two—which fits what you noticed after drinking.

────────────────────────────────────────
4. Miscellaneous metabolic triggers
────────────────────────────────────────
•  Pregnancy (not applicable here), chronic dehydration (vinegar itself is not high in sodium but pickled foods are), or endocrine conditions such as Addison’s disease more typically cause SALT cravings but occasionally overlap with sour cravings.  
•  Zinc deficiency and, less commonly, vitamin C deficiency can alter taste perception, but they usually cause a DULLING of taste rather than a specific sour craving.

────────────────────────────────────────
Practical advice
────────────────────────────────────────
1. Bring it up at your next physical so your PCP can at least run a ferritin and CBC; it is quick, cheap, and will settle the iron-deficiency question.  
2. Because you already show leukopenia, your doctor may want to look at the rest of the blood count and iron studies anyway.  
3. Protect your teeth: straight vinegar (pH ~2–3) erodes enamel quickly.  Dilute it in water, use a straw, and rinse your mouth with plain water right after.  Don’t brush for at least 30 min (brushing immediately spreads the softened enamel).  
4. Watch for reflux, throat irritation, and changes in potassium (very large amounts of acid can very rarely provoke metabolic disturbances).  
5. If iron tests come back normal and you have no GI symptoms, you can safely chalk this up to a personal palate quirk.  Lots of people have strong “umami” or “spicy” drives—yours just happens to be “sour.”

When to get seen sooner:
• New fatigue, pallor, shortness of breath, brittle nails (signs of iron deficiency)  
• Heartburn, unintended weight loss, black stools, or persistent abdominal pain (to rule out an ulcer or other GI pathology)  
• Mouth sores or dental pain from the acid

Otherwise, enjoy your salads—but maybe keep a travel bottle of diluted red-wine vinegar instead of sipping the straight stuff!

107.question: I’m 19F about 5’3” not sure about my weight but quite small from the UK.So, in the past, I’ve had what I believe to be 3 tonic-clonic seizures. I never actually got medical advice for these because 2 happened after smoking weed and one when my (untrained) friend pierced my nose and I didn’t want my parents to find out about any of these with a trip to the doctors (when they did ever find out they just thought I fainted because it was a hot day etc) These were years ago so I haven’t thought about them much. An hour or so ago my boyfriend was having a normal conversation with me and I started panicking for no reason at all and from past experience felt like I was going to have or had just had a seizure. I got really hot, dizzy, panicky, shaky and just didn’t feel right overall. I felt kind of disconnected if that makes any sense. I thought this might be a focal seizure. A while afterwards though I still didn’t feel normal, I’ve been staring at my room for about 20 minutes just looking around and closed my eyes for 10 minutes with my knees to my chest rocking side to side. I just don’t feel quite normal at the moment and I’m not sure if I could have epilepsy or it could just be my mental health (I have depression, anxiety and occasionally worry I have schizophrenia) but I thought I was doing alright mentally at the moment.Sorry for the long post, as I say it’s my first ever post on Reddit and I’m just very confused about what’s going on at the moment.Any ideas or advice would be great!
107.answer:
I’m not a substitute for a face-to-face examination, but what you describe is important enough that you really do need to be assessed by a doctor soon – ideally within the next few days, or sooner if anything similar happens again.  Below is some context that may help you decide what to do next.

1.  Why you should be seen now  
   •  Three episodes that sound like possible tonic–clonic seizures, even if they were “provoked” by cannabis or pain, are reason enough for a work-up.  
   •  Today’s spell (heat, panic, dizziness, “disconnected” feeling, needing to curl up and rock) could be:  
        – a focal seizure with impaired awareness that didn’t generalise  
        – a vasovagal faint (especially if you were hot/dehydrated)  
        – a panic attack or dissociative episode  
        – something metabolic (low blood sugar, blood-pressure drop, etc.)  
     No one can tell which without proper assessment (history, examination, possibly an EEG, blood tests and sometimes a brain scan).  
   •  If you did have three true seizures on separate days, by definition you may meet criteria for epilepsy, and in the UK that has implications for driving, safety at work, contraception choices, etc.

2.  What to do if it happens again  
   •  If you lose consciousness, have uncontrolled jerking, or remain confused for more than 5–10 minutes, someone should phone 999.  
   •  If it’s “just” the panicky/disconnected feeling but you remain aware, call NHS 111 for real-time advice, or go to A&E if you do not quickly return to normal.

3.  How to prepare for a medical appointment  
   •  Write down a timeline of every episode you can remember: date, time of day, what you were doing, any triggers (weed, pain, heat, lack of sleep), how long it lasted, how you felt afterwards.  
   •  Ask your boyfriend or any witness to describe exactly what they saw (jerking, eye deviation, sounds you made, breathing, skin colour, how long you were “out”). Phone-video evidence is very useful.  
   •  List all medicines, supplements, alcohol/drug use and any family history of seizures, migraines, heart problems or mental illness.

4.  Safety until you’re seen  
   •  No driving (DVLA requires you to be seizure-free and cleared by a doctor).  
   •  Don’t swim, climb, bathe alone or operate machinery that could injure you if you black out. Shower rather than bathe.  
   •  Try to get regular sleep, eat regularly and stay hydrated; sleep deprivation and low blood sugar lower seizure threshold.  
   •  Avoid recreational drugs and keep alcohol low – both can provoke seizures directly or through sleep loss.

5.  Mental-health overlap  
   •  Anxiety, panic and dissociation can mimic some seizure sensations (“aura”, derealisation).  
   •  People with epilepsy have higher rates of depression/anxiety, and vice-versa; it’s not either-or.  
   •  Mention your existing mental-health history to the GP; you might need parallel help from psychological services even if the events turn out to be non-epileptic.

6.  Who to contact  
   •  Book an urgent GP appointment and tell reception you have had possible seizures – they should prioritise you.  
   •  If the GP suspects epilepsy you’ll be referred to a neurologist or an epilepsy clinic for EEG ± MRI. Waiting times vary, but a clear referral marked “possible first seizure” or “recurrent seizures” usually shortens the queue.  
   •  If you can’t get a timely GP slot and you feel unwell or have another event, go to A&E.

7.  What not to worry about right now  
   •  One or two weed-related seizures years ago don’t automatically mean you have lifelong epilepsy – but they still matter because they show your brain can seize under the right conditions.  
   •  The strange half-hour you spent staring/rocking does not on its own confirm schizophrenia. The priority is to rule out physical causes first.

Bottom line
