You have had several episodes that need proper medical evaluation.  Call your GP (or NHS 111 for advice tonight), arrange to be seen, and keep yourself safe in the meantime.  Taking that step is far better than trying to guess whether this is “just” anxiety or true epilepsy.

108.question: Age 33 Sex M Height 5’ 9” Weight 170 Race Caucasian Duration of complaint 3 Weeks Location Distal Tibia/Ankle Any existing relevant medical issues Epilepsy Current medications KeppraI’m about 3 weeks post skateboarding injury and I have this lump on my distal tibia. Seems like it’s off the bone on the medial side. As a skateboarder it’s common to take repetitive shots to the ankle, so I’m not overly concerned. The lump happened to appear after the injury. It wasn’t super painful so I kept on skating after a few more incidents to the same area I decided to take a break. I’m about a week removed from skating and haven’t seen a noticeable improvement. No pain. Just sensitive to the touch. Thanks in advance
108.answer:
I’m not in a position to diagnose you over the internet, but I can lay out the common things we think about after a direct-impact ankle/shin injury and when it’s time to get it looked at in person.

What the lump is most likely to be

1. Localized contusion/hematoma  
   • A direct blow can rupture small vessels under the periosteum (the thin sleeve that covers bone).  
   • Blood collects, forms a firm “goose egg,” then gradually organizes and is re-absorbed over 4–8 weeks.  
   • It can feel like it’s “on” the bone but actually be under the skin or just beneath the periosteum.  
   • Still tender to poke, but generally non-painful with walking, and not getting bigger.

2. Periosteal reaction or small cortical chip (“bone bruise”)  
   • Repetitive hits can lift the periosteum slightly or chip a sliver of bone.  
   • The body quickly lays down new bone (callus), producing a hard nodule that can stick around for months.  
   • Usually doesn’t hurt much once it’s formed, but it’s sensitive to taps.

3. Myositis ossificans (less common in the ankle)  
   • A deeper muscle bruise occasionally calcifies, creating a hard lump that feels like bone.  
   • More typical in thighs/arms, but possible anywhere there’s repeated trauma.

Things we worry about (much less common, but good to be aware of)

• Stress or occult fracture – would usually hurt with weight-bearing or jumping.  
• Local infection (abscess, osteomyelitis) – lump would get red, hot, increasingly painful, maybe fevers.  
• Cyst or tumor coincidentally noticed after trauma – usually painless at first but keeps growing.

Why it may still be there after 3 weeks

Soft-tissue hematomas can take a frustratingly long time to flatten—4, 6, even 8 weeks isn’t unusual, especially if you keep banging the same spot. Callus from a periosteal injury can remain palpable indefinitely (though it should stop enlarging).

What you can do at home

• Relative rest: give it a couple more weeks without direct impacts.  
• Protect: skate-specific shin/ankle padding or a neoprene sleeve when you return.  
• Warm compress or gentle massage after the first few days can speed resorption.  
• NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) short-term for tenderness if your stomach/kidneys allow.  
• Observation: mark the outline with a pen; if it grows outside the line within a week or two, get re-checked.

When to get evaluated in person (X-ray or ultrasound is quick, inexpensive, and definitive)

• Lump is enlarging, changing shape, or still prominent after 6–8 weeks.  
• New or increasing pain, redness, warmth, bruising, or numbness/tingling.  
• Pain with hopping or twisting that wasn’t there before (possible occult fracture).  
• Any systemic signs (fever, chills).  
• You simply want reassurance before going back to skating hard—totally reasonable.

Why imaging might be useful

• Plain X-ray: will show a healing cortical chip, periosteal reaction, or heterotopic ossification.  
• Ultrasound: great for seeing fluid versus solid mass and guiding aspiration if a large hematoma needs draining.  
• MRI/CT: rarely necessary unless symptoms don’t match initial studies.

Special note about epilepsy/Keppra

Keppra doesn’t meaningfully reduce bone density the way some older anti-seizure drugs do, but any chronic anticonvulsant therapy puts you at slightly higher fracture risk. All the more reason to pad and protect bony prominences.

Bottom line

Three weeks is still within the normal window for a post-traumatic “bump” to hang around, but because repeated knocks can convert a simple bruise into a hard mass or hide a small chip fracture, consider letting a clinician lay hands on it—especially if it hasn’t started to shrink by the 6-week mark. In the meantime, rest, protect, and monitor for any change.

109.question: Hello, my relative started falling unconscious out of nowhere a year ago. She has been diagnosed with epilepsy due to one shaking seizure. After some time and different pill combinations she is still fainting seemingly randomly but mostly before her period ( she said she noticed fainting every 2 weeks but take it with a grain of salt ). After multiple MR scans and 2 different hospitals in two different towns neurologist said she might have MS and gave her corticosteroids which after about a month they withdrew and said she might not have MS. We are completely lost on what to do and its making her life a living hell as she cant keep a job or/and is dangerous to have one as she hit her head multiple times already. Recently she didnt fall unconscious but sort of lost memory of what she was doing at the moment kind of being on autopilot for a few seconds. Please any help is kindly accepted and feel free to ask away any questions I am happy to answer.Age: 22 Female
109.answer:
I’m sorry your relative is going through this.  Recurrent, unpredictable loss of consciousness is frightening and can be hard to sort out because many different disorders look similar on the surface.  Below is a road map you can take to the next neurology (and possibly cardiology) appointment.  It is long, but I want to give you enough detail to help you ask the right questions and understand why each test or consultation might be suggested.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
1.   First: make sure it’s really a “seizure” and not something else
-------------------------------------------------------------------
“Passing out,” “fainting,” “black-outs,” or a few seconds of “blank staring” can be:
• Epileptic seizures (electrical bursts from the brain).
• Syncope (brain shuts off for a few seconds because blood pressure or heart rhythm suddenly drops).
• Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (PNES or “dissociative attacks,” not voluntary, but no abnormal brain electricity).
• Very short “absence” seizures (brief staring, often <15 s) in genetic generalized epilepsy.
• Migraine variants, narcolepsy/cataplexy, metabolic problems, etc.

Why it matters:  
Anti-seizure medicines help epilepsy but do nothing for syncope or PNES; heart drugs or a pacer help arrhythmias but not epilepsy; psychotherapy helps PNES; treating catamenial (period-related) hormones sometimes helps epileptic seizures.

Key questions a doctor will ask (and you can start writing down):

1. What happens **just before** the spell?  (Warning aura?  Dizziness?  Palpitations?  Chest pain?  Visual change?  Epigastric rising feeling?)  
2. **During** the spell?  (Eyes open or closed?  Any stiffening, jerking, shaking, bicycling legs?  Color change—blue, pale?  Sweating?  Breathing noise?  Tongue-bites?  Incontinence?)  
3. **After** the spell?  (Confused for minutes-hours?  Or fine within seconds once upright?)  
4. How long from start to full recovery?  >5–10 min strongly favors epileptic seizure; <1–2 min favors syncope/PNES.  
5. **Triggers**?  Standing up suddenly, pain, seeing blood, hot shower (syncope) vs. sleep deprivation, flashing lights, stress (seizure) vs. arguments or emotional stress (PNES).  
6. **Timing with menstrual cycle**?  Catamenial epilepsy = clusters in the days around periods when progesterone falls.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
2.   Objective testing that usually sorts it out
-------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Video-EEG monitoring (the “gold standard”)  
• Patient is admitted to an Epilepsy Monitoring Unit (EMU) for 3-7 days.  
• Continuous EEG and a video camera run 24 h.  When a spell happens, doctors look at the brain waves and the body movements at the same time.  
• If the EEG shows a clear epileptic discharge → epilepsy.  
• If the spell looks dramatic but the EEG stays normal → most often PNES or syncope.

B. Cardiac evaluation  
1. 12-lead ECG (look for Wolff-Parkinson-White, long QT, Brugada, etc.).  
2. 24-h Holter monitor or 2-week event monitor.  
3. If still unexplained and dangerous blackouts continue → consider implantable loop recorder (ILR).  
4. Tilt-table test if history suggests neurally mediated syncope (fainting with prolonged standing, heat, pain, etc.).

C. Brain MRI (already done)  
• The MS question:  To diagnose multiple sclerosis you need:  
  – ≥2 episodes in time AND  
  – ≥2 lesions in typical locations (periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, spinal cord) OR oligoclonal bands in spinal fluid.  
• Corticosteroids help acute MS relapses; if MRI + spinal tap do not fit MS, steroids should be stopped (sounds like what happened).

D. Basic blood panel if not already done  
CBC, electrolytes, glucose, calcium, magnesium, liver/kidney function, thyroid, B12, cortisol if suspicion of adrenal insufficiency.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
3.   Why episodes cluster around periods
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Catamenial epilepsy = seizures worsen when estrogen (“pro-seizure”) peaks or progesterone (“anti-seizure”) plummets, usually:  
Pattern C1: Days –3 to +3 of menstruation.  
Pattern C2: At ovulation.  
Management options (only if EEG proves epilepsy):  
• Keep a seizure-menstrual diary for 3 full cycles.  
• Adjust antiseizure drug (ASD) dose upward for 7–10 days around the vulnerable window.  
• Add short-term benzodiazepine (e.g., clobazam) only those days.  
• Cyclic oral progesterone or depot medroxy-progesterone.  
• Continuous combined hormonal contraception or IUD to flatten hormone fluctuations.  
(These should be discussed with both neurology & gynecology.)

-------------------------------------------------------------------
4.   When the MRI shows white spots but doctors pull back on MS
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Many young adults have small nonspecific white-matter spots (migraine, hypertension, previous viral illness).  If they’re not in the classic MS locations, or no new lesions appear over time, MS criteria are not met.  
Bottom line: Unexplained spells are rarely the first and only symptom of MS.  Epilepsy can occur in MS, but usually after other classic symptoms (optic neuritis, spinal cord episode, etc.).

-------------------------------------------------------------------
5.   What to do while you are still searching for the cause
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Safety first:  
• No driving until episodes are under good control (laws vary by region).  
• Shower instead of bath; sit on a stool if possible.  
• Cook on back burners, use microwave rather than open flame.  
• Sleep on a low bed; avoid bunk beds.  
• Supervise swimming; avoid heights, heavy machinery.  
• Simple protective headgear in risky settings if frequent falls.  
• Medical alert bracelet stating “Seizure disorder / episodes of loss of consciousness.”

Keep a detailed diary:  
Date, time, relation to period, food/alcohol/caffeine, sleep hours, stressors, position (lying/standing), preceding symptoms, duration, injuries, recovery time.  Bring to every appointment.

Medication adherence:  
Missing even a single dose of ASD, especially lamotrigine, levetiracetam, carbamazepine, can precipitate breakthrough seizures.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
6.   Who should be on the team?
-------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Board-certified neurologist with subspecialty in Epilepsy or Clinical Neurophysiology (often at a tertiary “Level 4” Epilepsy Center).  
2. Cardiology / Electrophysiology if syncope or arrhythmia suspected.  
3. Sometimes Psychiatry or Psychologist experienced in PNES.  
4. Gynecologist/endocrinologist if catamenial pattern confirmed.  
If one hospital has only basic EEG, ask for referral to an EMU.  Many patients finally get the right diagnosis there, even after years.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
7.   Questions to take to the next appointment
-------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Can you refer me for inpatient video-EEG monitoring?  
2. Should we order a loop recorder or tilt-table test to rule out cardiac syncope?  
3. Does my MRI meet McDonald criteria for MS?  Do we need spinal fluid oligoclonal band testing?  
4. If we confirm epilepsy, what is the likely syndrome (focal vs generalized)?  
5. Are my episodes related to my menstrual cycle?  Would cyclic progesterone or perimenstrual ASD “pulse-dosing” make sense?  
6. Could these be psychogenic non-epileptic seizures, and if so can you refer me to a psychologist trained in CBT for PNES?

-------------------------------------------------------------------
8.   Bottom line
-------------------------------------------------------------------
• Don’t give up—roughly 20–30 % of people sent to epilepsy clinics for “medication-resistant seizures” actually turn out to have something other than epilepsy, and once the right diagnosis is made, most improve quickly.  
• The single test with the highest diagnostic yield is prolonged video-EEG monitoring.  
• Until then, focus on meticulous seizure/syncope precautions and a detailed diary.  
• Press for a structured evaluation pathway rather than trial-and-error drug changes.

I hope this gives you a clear set of next steps and questions.  Print it out, add your own notes, and bring it to the next visit.  Best of luck to your relative, and please seek emergency care immediately if spells become prolonged, she injures herself, or develops new neurological symptoms (weakness, vision loss, difficulty speaking).

110.question: 25F white JME keppra 1gMy epilepsy seems very well controlled with keppra. No complaints.Lately I've been feeling really tired, but I'm getting good sleep. I don't have any signs of seizures when I wake up. It's always been hard to wake up in the mornings, but lately it's been awful. It feels like I didn't sleep at all.I was working today. I closed my eyes to blink, and everything was kinda dizzy, but it went away quick. It's hard to describe, it's kinda like dizziness, but also like everything's... dropping? Melting?It feels like my brain is tripping up just like with a myoclonic jerks, but there's no myclonic jerk. Weird right?I've just been trying to shake it off. I been on keppra for 3 or 4 years. Can it wear off?
110.answer:
Short answer – Keppra (levetiracetam) does not “wear off” or become tolerant in the way some pain-killers or benzodiazepines do, but several things can still make you feel as if it has:

1. The drug level can dip (e.g., if it’s taken once a day instead of every 12 h, if a dose is late, if you have gained weight, or if kidney function has changed).
2. Your epilepsy pattern can evolve, so you may start having brief, subtle seizures that you didn’t have before (for instance very short absence seizures or “negative myoclonus” that feels like the floor drops but there is no visible jerk).
3. Keppra itself, or a vitamin/hematologic issue it unmasked, can cause fatigue.
4. Something totally unrelated to epilepsy (thyroid, anemia, sleep-disordered breathing, mood, infection, etc.) can make you exhausted and light-headed.

What your description could be
• “Brain tripping up / dropping / melting” for 1–2 s with no visible jerk – In JME that can be a micro-absence or a motor-negative myoclonic event. Quite a few patients describe an internal “jolt” with no outward movement.  
• Morning worsening – If you take the whole 1000 mg at night, the level may be its lowest just before the morning dose.  
• Fatigue – Common with levetiracetam, especially if dose was recently increased, vitamin B6 low, or you’re slightly anemic.

Things to check/try (straight-forward and safe):

1. Dose timing  
   • Make sure you are on 500 mg every 12 h, not 1000 mg once daily.  
   • If you already split doses, try moving the evening dose a bit later (e.g., 10 p.m. instead of 7 p.m.).

2. Seizure diary  
   • Note each of these “dizzy/drop/melting” spells with date, time, duration, what you were doing, sleep the night before, caffeine/alcohol, menstrual cycle day. Bring to your neurologist.

3. Lab work (simple blood tests)  
   • CBC (look for leukopenia or anemia)  
   • CMP (renal function; Keppra is renally cleared)  
   • Thyroid panel  
   • B12, folate, ferritin  
   • Consider vitamin B6 level or an empiric 25–50 mg/d supplement (ask your doctor first).

4. Sleep hygiene screen  
   • Good sleep yet still exhausted can be sleep apnea or periodic limb movements—worth asking about a sleep study if you snore, gasp, or feel unrefreshed.

5. Mood screen  
   • Keppra can trigger depression or irritability (“Kepp-rage”). Subtle mood changes often feel like fatigue.

6. Neurology review & EEG  
   • A routine or even an ambulatory EEG can see if these brief spells correspond to generalized 3 Hz spikes or polyspike-waves.  
   • If they are seizures, your neurologist may raise Keppra, add valproate, lamotrigine, or switch drugs.

When to call sooner (today / tonight):

• Spells lengthen, cluster, or you start losing awareness.  
• You have any generalized convulsion or fall/injury.  
• You develop new focal weakness, speech trouble, vision changes, or severe headache.

Bottom line  
No, Keppra itself doesn’t become ineffective just because you’ve taken it for years, but dose timing, blood levels, subtle new seizure types, or other medical problems can make it feel as if it has. Keep a diary of these events and fatigue, arrange basic labs, and schedule a prompt visit (or phone call) with your neurologist. Most of the time a tweak in dose, adding a morning dose of medication, treating a vitamin/thyroid problem, or addressing sleep quality solves the issue.

111.question: Hello, my relative started falling unconscious out of nowhere a year ago. She has been diagnosed with epilepsy due to one shaking seizure. After some time and different pill combinations she is still fainting seemingly randomly but mostly before her period ( she said she noticed fainting every 2 weeks but take it with a grain of salt ). After multiple MR scans and 2 different hospitals in two different towns neurologist said she might have MS and gave her corticosteroids which after about a month they withdrew and said she might not have MS. We are completely lost on what to do and its making her life a living hell as she cant keep a job or/and is dangerous to have one as she hit her head multiple times already. Recently she didnt fall unconscious but sort of lost memory of what she was doing at the moment kind of being on autopilot for a few seconds. Please any help is kindly accepted and feel free to ask away any questions I am happy to answer.Age: 22 Female 5,5 Ft, 160 Lbs Non smoker
111.answer:
I’m very sorry your relative is going through this.  Because all of the “spells” look the same to observers, it often takes time – and repeated testing – to sort out whether someone is having 1) epileptic seizures, 2) fainting/syncope from cardiovascular or autonomic causes, 3) psychogenic-nonepileptic seizures (PNES), or 4) some combination.   
Below is an outline of the major possibilities, the tests that usually clarify things, and practical next steps you can take right now with her doctors.  (This is general information, not a substitute for medical care.)

1.  What has to be ruled in / ruled out  
   • Epileptic seizures (especially “catamenial” – triggered by the hormonal shift around menses)  
   • Cardiogenic syncope (dangerous heart rhythm or structural heart problem)  
   • Neurally mediated/vasovagal syncope or POTS (autonomic dysregulation – often seen in young women)  
   • Psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (spells that look like seizures but do not come from abnormal firing in the brain)  
   • Metabolic / endocrine causes (hypoglycaemia, adrenal, thyroid)  
   • “Drop attacks” from rare neurologic disorders (much lower on the list given her age and normal MRI)

2.  Why the current picture causes confusion  
   • She has had at least one “generalised tonic-clonic” event (shaking), which pushes physicians toward the epilepsy pathway.  
   • BUT MRI scans apparently show no convincing multiple-sclerosis-type lesions, and antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) have not stopped the events – that raises the possibility it is not epilepsy, or not just epilepsy.  
   • The clear menstrual clustering is a red flag for catamenial epilepsy, but cyclical fainting from vasovagal triggers or volume depletion around menses also occurs.  
   • Brief “autopilot” episodes can be focal impaired-awareness seizures, transient arrhythmias, or dissociative/PNES episodes – without good EEG/ECG data it is impossible to be sure.

3.  Key tests that usually settle the question  

   Neurology / Epilepsy  
   • 24-hr or, preferably, multi-day VIDEO-EEG monitoring in an epilepsy monitoring unit (EMU). The goal is to capture a typical event on both video and EEG. That single test often eliminates months of guesswork.  
   • Ambulatory EEG for up to 72 h if EMU not immediately available.  
   • Blood work: electrolytes, calcium, magnesium, glucose, CBC, liver panel, hormonal profile if catamenial epilepsy suspected.  
   Cardiology / Autonomic  
   • 12-lead ECG and echocardiogram (these are usually done early; make sure they were).  
   • At least 24-h Holter; many centres now use 2-week event monitors or implantable loop recorders to catch intermittent arrhythmias.  
   • Tilt-table test and orthostatic vitals to look for vasovagal syncope or POTS.  
   Other  
   • Serum β-hCG (pregnancy), thyroid panel, morning cortisol, fasting glucose if not already done.

4.  Why MS was mentioned and then dropped  
   Small non-specific white-matter spots can appear on MRI and raise the spectre of demyelinating disease, but if they do not follow typical MS patterns (location, shape, enhancement) and spinal tap/evoked potentials are negative, neurologists usually back away from that diagnosis – apparently what happened here.

5.  Catamenial epilepsy in a nutshell  
   • Roughly one-third of women with refractory seizures notice clustering around their period.  
   • Oestrogen tends to be pro-convulsant; progesterone is anti-convulsant. The sudden fall in progesterone just before menstruation is a common trigger.  
   • Management options your neurologist can discuss:  
     – Increase the dose of the existing AED for 7–10 days around menses.  
     – Short course of clobazam or acetazolamide during that window.  
     – Continuous-cycle oral contraceptive pill, progesterone-only pill, depot progesterone, Mirena IUD, or (rarely) GnRH analogues to suppress cycles.  
     – Keep a detailed seizure-menstrual diary (paper or phone app) – indispensable for tailoring therapy.

6.  If it turns out NOT to be epilepsy  
   • Cardiogenic: An implantable loop recorder often clinches intermittent arrhythmias (e.g., long-QT, AV block, tachy-brady). Definitive rhythm control or pacemaker/ICD can be life-saving.  
   • Vasovagal / POTS: High-fluid/high-salt regimen, compression stockings, slow postural changes, β-blocker or fludrocortisone/midodrine as needed.  
   • PNES: Referral to a psychologist/psychiatrist familiar with functional neurological symptom disorder; cognitive-behavioural therapy is first-line.

7.  Practical things to do now  
   • Ask her current neurologist for a referral to a Comprehensive Epilepsy Center (usually at a university hospital) for video-EEG monitoring. Waiting lists exist, so start the process.  
   • If she has not seen a cardiologist, request one; get at least a 14-day event monitor.  
   • Start (or continue) a diary: date/time of each spell, description (convulsive? fall? eyes open/closed? colour change?), how long unconscious, confusion afterwards, injuries, medications taken, caffeine/alcohol, sleep hours, and day of menstrual cycle.  
   • Review medication adherence and serum drug levels (especially if she is on lamotrigine, levetiracetam, valproate, carbamazepine, etc.). Missing even one dose can provoke a seizure.  
   • Safety: no driving; avoid heights, swimming alone, operating heavy machinery; consider a protective helmet if falls are frequent; shower rather than bath.  
   • Identify witnesses who can film an event on a phone – enormously helpful to clinicians.  
   • Ensure she has a rescue plan (e.g., clonazepam or intranasal midazolam) and loved ones know when and how to use it.

8.  Questions to take to the next appointment  
   1. Can we schedule inpatient video-EEG monitoring?  
   2. Has a tilt-table test or prolonged cardiac monitoring been done?  
   3. Do her EEGs show any epileptiform discharges? If not, what is the differential?  
   4. Could this be catamenial epilepsy, and how would you adjust treatment for that?  
   5. Would hormonal therapy or cycle suppression be appropriate?  
   6. If medication trials fail, what is the plan – diet therapy, neuro-stimulator, referral for epilepsy surgery evaluation?  
   7. If spells are nonepileptic, how do we arrange psychologic/autonomic follow-up?

9.  Bottom line  
   • At 22 years old with repeated unexplained loss of consciousness, she needs a systematic, multidisciplinary work-up.  
   • The single most decisive test in this setting is usually prolonged video-EEG, ideally capturing more than one event.  
   • Do not dismiss cardiac causes; they can mimic seizures and be lethal.  
   • If events clearly cluster around menstruation, catamenial epilepsy management strategies often help, but only after epileptic vs. nonepileptic origin is confirmed.  
   • Until a firm diagnosis is reached, strict safety precautions and a detailed event diary are essential.

I hope this gives you a roadmap. Push (politely but firmly) for comprehensive monitoring; it is the fastest way to stop the guessing and let her life get back on track. Best wishes to both of you.

112.question: 28F 5’6” 225lbs non smokerA little less than a month ago, I had two seizures in the span of 24 hours due to postpartum eclampsia. I have never had a seizure before, and from what I understand, I shouldn’t have one again because it was due to the high blood pressure caused by the eclampsia.The neurologist at the hospital put me on Keppra for a month just to be safe and prevent more seizures while my body recovered from the eclampsia. 1000mg twice a day.Well, I am off all blood pressure medications and have stabilized from the eclampsia, and now it’s getting to be time to come off the Keppra and I am worried about what it will be like coming off.I’ve read things about Keppra causing a lot of side effects when you come off it, which is very scary to me seeing as a lot of the day I am alone with my newborn and I cannot be in an unfit state during that time.I don’t think I’m at risk for going off the Keppra triggering a seizure, right? Because it was a one time thing caused by high blood pressure? And my blood pressure is now under control? That’s what scares me the most. Being alone with my newborn and having another seizure because I got off the meds. Should I ween off the meds or have I been in them a short enough time and the fact that I’m not epileptic makes it safe to come off them without risking serious side effects?I am talking with the neurologist I saw at the hospital who prescribed me the Keppra, but he’s been very nonchalant, not really getting back to me, and doesn’t seem to understand my really big concerns because I am alone with a newborn for a lot of the day and I need to be 100% certain that coming off Keppra will not interfere with my ability to care for him.
112.answer:
I understand why this feels frightening—nobody wants even a tiny chance of having a seizure while home alone with a new baby. Let me walk you through the facts we rely on when advising women who have had eclamptic seizures and were placed on levetiracetam (Keppra) “just in case.”

1. Was the seizure really “one-time only”?  
   • Eclampsia is a hypertensive/vascular problem of pregnancy, not epilepsy.  
   • Over 90 % of eclamptic seizures occur before delivery or within the first 48 h postpartum. Fewer than 1 % present after 4 weeks.  
   • Once blood pressure, kidney/liver labs, and neuro exam have returned to normal, the risk of a late, new seizure related to eclampsia is extremely small (essentially the same as the general population’s risk).

2. Why were you given Keppra at all?  
   • In the acute setting it was meant only as “belt-and-suspenders” protection while doctors were sure the hypertension had settled.  
   • Standard obstetric guidelines use magnesium sulfate for 24 h; long-term anti-seizure drugs are *not* routine. Some neurologists pick an oral agent for a few weeks out of extra caution.

3. Is there a withdrawal syndrome with Keppra?  
   • Keppra does *not* cause physical dependence (no rebound tachycardia, sweating, nausea, etc.).  
   • The only clinically significant “withdrawal” is the theoretical risk of precipitating seizures in someone who has an underlying seizure disorder—something you don’t have.  
   • People sometimes notice the side-effects they had on the drug (fatigue, mood change) simply fade away.

4. Do we taper or stop abruptly?  
   • After only a month of therapy, most neurologists would taper over 3–7 days purely for “good form.”  
   • Example taper (many variations are fine):  
     – Days 1-3: 750 mg twice daily  
     – Days 4-6: 500 mg twice daily  
     – Day 7-9: 250 mg twice daily, then stop  
   • A slower taper is not harmful if it makes you feel safer.

5. What is the real risk of a new seizure once Keppra is gone?  
   • Published series put the recurrence risk after resolved eclampsia at <1 %.  
   • That tiny risk is not changed in any meaningful way by staying on or coming off Keppra once blood pressure and labs are normal.  
   • The bigger things that *can* lower your seizure threshold (for anyone) are extreme sleep deprivation, dehydration, and abrupt spikes in blood pressure. Try to protect your sleep, stay well-hydrated, and keep a home BP cuff if recommended.

6. Practical safety tips while you taper/stop:  
   • Schedule the taper for a week when another adult can be in the home for at least a few hours a day, even if just by video check-ins.  
   • Continue home BP monitoring for the next couple of weeks.  
   • Avoid driving until you are completely off the medication and feel baseline for 24–48 h (a conservative but reasonable rule).  
   • Keep a phone or smart watch on you and doors unlocked while you’re alone with the baby.

7. When to call the doctor or 911:  
   • Any sudden spike in blood pressure (e.g., systolic >160 mmHg) with headache or visual changes.  
   • Obvious seizure aura: déjà vu, flashing lights, sudden confusion (unlikely in someone without epilepsy, but worth mentioning).  
   • New, severe headache unlike the postpartum milder “sleep-deprivation” headaches.

8. Follow-up:  
   • One visit with either your obstetrician or primary doctor about 2-4 weeks after stopping Keppra is standard; a repeat neurologic visit is optional unless you develop symptoms.  
   • There is *no* requirement for lifeline anticonvulsant therapy, EEG, or driving restrictions once you have been seizure-free for 30 days and the neurologist documents it was eclampsia-related.

Key take-away: The evidence, plus decades of obstetric-neurology experience, tells us you can safely come off Keppra after a short taper, and your risk of another seizure once blood pressure is normal is extraordinarily low. Run the exact taper schedule you prefer by your neurologist (or, if responsiveness is still an issue, your OB or family doctor), but you can feel confident that caring for your newborn will not be jeopardized by stopping the medication.

113.question: Prefacing with comorbidities: obese, diabetic, hypertension 75 inches, 300lbs Early March, I had an episode where I felt what was almost like an electric shock in my right hand, followed by a similar sensation on the left side of my head. I fell unconscious, and the next thing I know, the EMTs are at my house. My wife states that I was convulsing, and, at one point, not breathing during the attack. After standard workups, they found a 8mm lesion on my brain. televisit Neurologist told me that it didn't look like cancer and that 'no neurosurgeon is going to operate on this.' Either way, I was scared. Went to a well-reputed hospital, and saw a neuro-oncologist. He felt this was serious, and ordered a functional MRI as well as a Stealth MRI. I was really happy to receive the results that this was not brain cancer, and was in fact vascular in nature (literally, anything but brain cancer, right?). I was referred to a neurosurgeon who deals with things more vascular in nature. He's ordered a diagnostic cerebral angiogram, which I'm getting tomorrow. CTA showed a narrowing of my carotid artery, and he suspects it was a dissection. Either way, I'm simultaneously being treated by a neurologist at the same hospital as the aforementioned neurosurgeons in case this was a seizure (my initial diagnosis). I did not tolerate keppra well (rage), and am now on Vimpat. Almost every night, I have these episodes where I have this 'pit of my stomach' that I recognize as how I felt right before I had my initial attack. Questions: Are these seizures, or could this issue completely vascular in nature? Can a dissection/TIA cause seizures? What about the initial attack? Looking up TIA online, I'm not seeing it presenting in this manner. Will I be on these seizure meds forever (They make me feel awful, with brain fog, etc.)? Did I develop Epilepsy at age 35?
113.answer:
I can’t give you a personal medical diagnosis over the Internet, but I can walk you through how neurologists think about situations like yours and what the various pieces of information probably mean.

1.  Was the spell you had in March a seizure?  
   •  The description (electric-shock sensation → loss of consciousness → generalized shaking → not breathing briefly → confusion when you woke up) is classic for a generalized tonic–clonic seizure.  
   •  EMTs/ER staff apparently agreed, because you were started on an antiseizure drug (Keppra).  
   •  A transient-ischemic attack (TIA) almost never produces full-blown convulsions. A TIA usually causes negative neurologic symptoms (loss of strength, loss of vision, loss of speech) that come on suddenly, last minutes, then resolve. Generalized shaking and post-ictal confusion point much more to seizure than to TIA.  
   Bottom line: the March event was almost certainly a seizure.

2.  Can vascular problems cause seizures?  
   Yes. Anything that irritates or injures the cerebral cortex can provoke seizures. Common vascular culprits are:  
   •  Small cortical strokes or bleeds (including those caused by a carotid-artery dissection)  
   •  Aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) that bleed microscopically or simply “irritate” nearby brain tissue  
   •  Cavernous malformations (“cavernomas”) that ooze small amounts of blood  

   Your MRI shows an 8-mm vascular-appearing lesion. That in itself is a potential seizure focus, even if it never turns into a big hemorrhage or a frank stroke.

3.  Where does the carotid dissection fit in?  
   •  A dissection is a tear in the inner wall of the artery; it narrows the lumen and can throw clots to the brain.  
   •  The narrowing seen on CTA makes the doctors suspicious, and the cerebral angiogram you are having will nail down whether that is truly a dissection, how big it is, and whether it needs treatment.  
   •  A dissection can certainly cause a cortical stroke, and a cortical stroke can present with an early seizure. That would link the vascular issue to the March seizure.  
   •  If the angiogram does confirm a dissection, you will also be given either an antiplatelet drug (aspirin, clopidogrel) or an anticoagulant for several months to prevent further emboli.

4.  What are the nightly “pit-of-the-stomach” sensations?  
   •  Many patients with temporal-lobe epilepsy describe an “epigastric rising” feeling, dread, déjà vu, or a rush just before a larger seizure.  
   •  Those episodes can occur in isolation as very brief “focal aware” (aura-only) seizures.  
   •  An EEG—preferably a prolonged ambulatory or inpatient video-EEG—can show whether these spells are epileptic discharges or simply anxiety/panic phenomena.  
   Make sure you tell your neurologist about the nightly events; they may want to capture one on EEG or adjust medication.

5.  Will you need antiseizure medication forever?  
   •  By strict definition you now have epilepsy (one unprovoked seizure plus an identifiable brain lesion that confers a high risk of recurrence).  
   •  Standard practice is to stay on medication at least 2 – 3 years seizure-free before considering a taper—longer if the structural lesion remains.  
   •  If the vascular lesion can be completely eliminated (e.g., an AVM that is surgically removed or a dissection that heals without leaving scar tissue in brain), your doctor might attempt a taper earlier.  
   •  If the lesion cannot be removed and continues to irritate cortex, many neurologists would advise lifelong therapy because the risk of another seizure (and sudden loss of consciousness while driving, swimming, on a ladder, etc.) never goes to zero.

6.  Do the side-effects have to be this bad?  
   •  Levetiracetam (Keppra) commonly causes irritability or rage. That problem often improves with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation or by switching drugs, which your doctors have done.  
   •  Lacosamide (Vimpat) can cause brain fog, imbalance, or fatigue in some people. It does not work for everyone.  
   •  There are many other agents (lamotrigine, brivaracetam, oxcarbazepine, topiramate, zonisamide, etc.) and combinations. If Vimpat continues to make you miserable, tell your neurologist; most of us keep trying until we find a regimen you tolerate.  
   •  Good sleep, avoidance of alcohol/binge glucose swings, and control of blood pressure and diabetes also improve seizure control and let you use the lowest effective drug dose.

7.  “Did I just develop epilepsy at age 35?”  
   Unfortunately, yes—epilepsy can begin at any age. Roughly 1 person in 26 will have epilepsy during their lifetime; the peaks are childhood and after age 60, but plenty of people present in mid-adulthood, usually because of a structural lesion (tumor, scar, vascular malformation, prior head trauma, etc.).

Action items / what to discuss with your team
•  Complete the catheter angiogram; it will tell whether the carotid narrowing is a dissection, whether the 8 mm lesion is an AVM/aneurysm/cavernoma, and whether either can or should be treated surgically or endovascularly.  
•  Ask whether an inpatient video-EEG (24–72 h) is warranted to document the nightly spells.  
•  Tell the neurologist clearly how much the current medication affects you; ask for alternative drugs or dose adjustments if the side-effects are unacceptable.  
•  Clarify driving restrictions: most states require a seizure-free interval (3–12 months) before driving.  
•  Optimize vascular risk factors—blood-pressure control, diabetes management, weight loss, and smoking cessation (if applicable)—because they influence both stroke and seizure risk.

If you get through the angiogram without complications, get better seizure control on a better-tolerated drug, and no new events occur for a couple of years, your doctors may re-evaluate the need for lifelong medication. Until then, the safest assumption is that you have a seizure disorder provoked by a vascular brain lesion, and treatment is aimed at both problems.

114.question: Why does my head feel like it’s slightly shaking when I put my hands on my forehead and press them down into my pillow ? I am 21M, I am 21 and a male, 5’9 roughly in height, I weight roughly 60 KG, I take epilepsy medication called Epilim 6 tablets per day in the morning and the evening, I’m a non smoker, I am white/ Caucasian, I don’t use drugs, my issue is twitching problems, this issue started on the 27th of September and has lasted till this day, it has happened in Leeds the United Kingdom. I have only had absence seizures before which nobody ever noticed, the neurologist that I saw in Poland this summer said it’s very likely that I will only have absence seizures my whole life. 5 days ago I noticed that my leg started slightly twitching, I noticed this physically and I don’t feel it unless I see it, 2-3 days ago I felt my left arm slightly twitching. When I put my head into my pillow in a certain position or against my bed I feel like it’s slightly shaking, other wise I get no other feeling from my head. 5 days ago I started getting small weird twitches in my left upper arm and right leg nowhere else in my body, the doctors that I saw today and yesterday said that Yesterday when I was sleeping I felt that a weird shaking feeling in my body at night but honestly unlike the other feelings this might have not even happened, I’m not sure that it did happen. I saw two doctors about this yesterday and both said it’s probably from stress and the doctor yesterday said it’s the fasciculation of muscle from stress. They booked me in with a neurologist but it might take 3 week. What’s wrong with me ?
114.answer:
I’m not examining you in person, so I can’t give a personal diagnosis, but I can run through the most common explanations for what you describe, why the doctors you have already seen think it is benign, what “red-flag” features would make it more urgent, and what usually happens next with the neurologist referral.

──────────────────
1. What you are feeling/seeing
──────────────────
• Small visible ripples of a muscle without any actual movement of the joint = fasciculations.  
  – They usually look like a “bag of worms” under the skin.  
  – Most people do not actually feel them; they only see them.

• Fine, high-frequency shaking that is most obvious when a muscle is held against resistance or when you press your head into the pillow = physiological or drug-induced tremor.  
  – It is often amplified the harder you press or the more you pay attention to it.

• A sudden single jerk that moves the limb or wakes you at night = myoclonus.  
  – Everyone gets occasional “sleep starts,” but if they repeat frequently they can be pathologic.

Your description (brief, visible twitch in upper arm or thigh, not really felt; a sense of fine vibration in the head only when you push it into the pillow) is most consistent with fasciculations plus a mild postural/physiological tremor.

──────────────────
2. Likely causes in your situation
──────────────────
A. Benign fasciculation syndrome (BFS)  
   • Very common in young, healthy, often anxious men.  
   • Triggered or worsened by lack of sleep, caffeine/energy drinks, alcohol, stress, exercise, viral illness.  
   • Neurological exam is otherwise normal (strength, reflexes, coordination).  
   • Does not turn into any serious disease in the vast majority of cases.

B. Sodium valproate (Epilim) side effect  
   • Tremor is one of the most frequent dose-related side effects (up to 20 % of users).  
   • It is usually fine, postural, and maximal when trying to hold something still or when pressing against a surface.  
   • Fasciculations can occur but are less common.

C. Physiological tremor that you are suddenly aware of  
   • Everyone has a tiny “baseline” tremor produced by the heartbeat and normal nerve firing.  
   • When you lie with your head or limb firmly pressed against something, that vibration can be transmitted back to you, making it feel stronger.

D. Stress/anxiety and hyper-alertness  
   • Stress hormones make muscle spindles fire more often and lower the threshold for fasciculations.  
   • The more you look for them, the more you notice them.

E. Less common but still benign: electrolyte imbalance (low magnesium, potassium), caffeine excess, thyroid over-activity.

──────────────────
3. Red flags that would need faster review
──────────────────
Seek urgent evaluation (same day) if you develop any of the following:
• Progressive true weakness (can’t lift toes/foot, can’t grip, slurred speech) rather than just twitching.  
• Muscle wasting (noticeable thinning of a muscle over weeks).  
• New seizures or change in seizure type/frequency.  
• Tremor so violent you cannot feed or dress yourself.  
• Accompanying fever, weight loss, or other systemic illness.

You do NOT list any of those red-flag features.

──────────────────
4. What the neurologist will usually do
──────────────────
1. Detailed neuro exam again.  
2. Check for any focal weakness or sensory loss.  
3. Possibly order:  
   • Serum electrolytes, calcium, magnesium, thyroid function.  
   • Valproate level (to see if you’re at the high end of the therapeutic range).  
   • If still doubtful: EMG (electromyography) to record the twitches.  
In most patients with the pattern you have, the EMG is normal or shows only benign fasciculations.

──────────────────
5. What you can do while you wait
──────────────────
• Review your valproate dose with your family doctor or epilepsy clinic; sometimes splitting the dose more evenly or lowering it slightly can reduce tremor without losing seizure control. Never stop it abruptly.  
• Reduce caffeine, energy drinks, nicotine, alcohol.  
• Ensure 7–9 h of sleep, keep a regular schedule.  
• Stay hydrated; consider a balanced multivitamin or magnesium supplement if diet is poor (but clear it with your GP).  
• Light regular exercise and stretching can calm fasciculations.  
• Try not to keep checking/watching the muscles; “symptom scanning” feeds the anxiety loop.

──────────────────
6. Bottom line
──────────────────
Everything you describe fits well with benign fasciculations and/or a mild valproate-related tremor, both of which are common, non-dangerous, and often worsened by stress. Your normal neurological examinations so far and the absence of weakness or other neurologic deficits are reassuring. A routine neurology appointment in a few weeks is appropriate. If any of the red-flag signs appear before then, seek care sooner.

I hope this helps you feel clearer about what is most likely happening and why the doctors felt it was safe to wait for the neurology review.

115.question: About a month ago i smoked a little weed with my friends at a pool and when i got out i started feeling extremely light headed so i went to go sit down on a lounge chair next thing i knew i was on the ground everything was completely black and i couldn't see or hear anything all i could feel was my body flopping around uncontrollably and i couldn't stop it. The whole experience only lasted about 15 seconds but it felt like 15 minutes then out of nowhere i was able to stand up and my vision cleared and i was fine if anyone has any experience with or knows why this happened please help me im scared there could be underlying health issues i never knew about (i smoke fairly frequently and it never happened prior to this incident or after any help would be greatly appreciated)Edit: mods removed my first post for not adding this so age and gender 16m weight 132lbs height 6'3 no medical issues aside from psychological and im on no medications
115.answer:
I’m not your doctor and this isn’t a substitute for an in-person evaluation, but here’s what usually makes sense in a situation like the one you describe and why it’s still worth getting checked.

WHAT MOST LIKELY HAPPENED  
Everything you describe fits much better with a brief faint (syncope) that had some “convulsive” movements than with a true epileptic seizure.

1. Typical triggers  
   • Standing up quickly after being in a warm pool → blood vessels are still dilated from the heat, more blood pools in the legs, less blood reaches the brain.  
   • Cannabis can further dilate blood vessels and drop blood pressure.  
   • Possible mild dehydration (pool + summer + smoking) makes it worse.

2. Typical prodrome and course  
   • Sudden light-headedness, tunnel vision, hearing dimming → brain not getting enough blood/oxygen.  
   • You pass out; while out you may have a few seconds of whole-body jerking (called “convulsive syncope”). That jerking looks scary but is just the brain’s response to lack of oxygen, not epilepsy.  
   • You recover quickly (10–30 s) once you’re horizontal because blood flow to the brain returns.  
   • Little or no confusion afterward; you can stand and feel basically normal within a minute or two.

That’s exactly the timeline you describe.

WHY IT SHOULD STILL BE CHECKED ONCE  
Most healthy teenagers who faint in a hot environment with weed on board have nothing dangerous going on, but syncope can occasionally be the first sign of a heart-rhythm problem, anemia, or other treatable issues. Because you had loss of consciousness and uncontrolled movements, guidelines say you should have at least one medical evaluation that includes:  
• A good history and physical exam.  
• Blood pressure sitting and standing.  
• A simple ECG (electrocardiogram).  
These are quick, cheap, and often totally normal, but they rule out the rare bad causes.

RED FLAGS THAT WOULD MAKE IT MORE URGENT  
• Fainting during exercise or stress rather than after getting up.  
• Family history of sudden cardiac death at a young age.  
• Fainting with chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath.  
• Taking longer than a minute or two to wake up or being very confused afterward.  
If any of those apply, see a physician promptly (today or tomorrow).

HOW TO AVOID A REPEAT EPISODE  
• Hydrate well, especially if you’ll be in heat or swimming.  
• Stand up slowly after you’ve been sitting or lying in a warm place.  
• Tense your leg muscles or cross your legs and squeeze if you feel woozy (pumps blood back to your brain).  
• If you choose to keep using cannabis, be aware that it lowers blood pressure; combine that with heat, dehydration, or prolonged standing and you’re more likely to faint.  
• Eat something salty if you tend to run low blood pressure.

SEIZURE VS. FAINTING QUICK CHECK  
Fainting: brief (<30 s), happens after standing, quick recovery, maybe a few jerks.  
Seizure: often >60 s, can happen in any position, tongue biting/incontinence common, longer confusion after.  
Your story is the former.

BOTTOM LINE  
The episode sounds like a classic heat/dehydration/cannabis-related faint with a few seconds of convulsive activity. It’s unlikely to signal a major problem, but a one-time checkup with an ECG is the safe and standard thing to do. In the meantime, hydrate, get up slowly, and be cautious with weed and hot environments.

116.question: Today the mathematics docent in my university, who is approximately 60 years old, froze for some 20 sec leaning on his desk, then his face's right half made something like a smile, and he turned his head slightly rightwards, for some 15 sec, and as we were just realizing something's wrong, he burst out in short unnatural laughter, moving his hands away from the desk, then stiffened and fell back. He hit his head at the board; of course, we called ambulance. I was out to wait for it, but after accounts of my colleagues who stayed with the docent, he was unconscious for 5-7 minutes, foam from his mouth, and as I could myself see, blood had run from within his left ear (the medics who came commented than it could be that he got a skull fracture from the hit in the board rim which is metallic; his skin on the front left of his head where he apparently hit the board was reddish, scratched from the rub; although it appeared to me that he must rather hit the board with the rare of his head). He was desoriented, not sure how much he understood, but he answered negatively when they asked him if he had epilepsy. I read this whole afternoon about strokes and epilepsy but none of the various descriptions seems to match what I witnessed (esp. the disturbing laughter). Some idea?
116.answer:
What you describe fits best with a focal‐onset epileptic seizure that secondarily generalised into a tonic-clonic seizure.  
Sequence of events and how they are interpreted by neurologists:

1. “Freezing” for ±20 s while leaning on the desk  
   • Very typical of the beginning of a focal aware seizure (the old term was “simple partial seizure”).  
   • The patient feels an internal change (aura) and may stop talking or moving.

2. Contraction of the right half of the face and slow head deviation to the right for ±15 s  
   • Tonic (sustained) contraction of facial muscles on one side and “versive” head turning are classic signs that the seizure focus is in the *contralateral* frontal lobe motor cortex (here very probably the left frontal lobe, which controls the right facial muscles and head/neck muscles).

3. Sudden short “unnatural” laughter  
   • Laughter occurring as part of a seizure is called a *gelastic* seizure.  
   • It is most often produced by discharges in frontal or temporal cortex, occasionally from a deep hypothalamic focus. In adults it is almost always of frontal-temporal cortical origin.

4. Loss of posture, stiffening, fall, foaming at the mouth, 5–7 min unresponsiveness  
   • The focal seizure has generalised into a tonic-clonic seizure.  
   • Frothing/foaming and a postictal (after-seizure) period of confusion or unresponsiveness for minutes are typical.

5. Bleeding from the ear  
   • Very likely a traumatic laceration of the external ear canal or a basal skull fracture caused by the violent fall and the head hitting the board. (The bleed did **not** cause the seizure; it is a consequence.)  
   • Needs imaging (CT) to rule out skull-base fracture and intracranial bleeding.

Why it is unlikely to have been a stroke or transient ischaemic attack  
• Strokes rarely produce a sequence of tonic contraction → forced head turn → sudden laughter → generalised convulsion.  
• In stroke the facial change would be a *droop* from weakness, not a tonic smile.  
• Stroke does not usually produce foaming at the mouth or minutes of post-event unresponsiveness followed by gradual recovery.  
• The laughter phenomenon can occur in some strokes (“facioplegia-agrypnia”), but it is rare and would not be followed by a bilateral tonic-clonic event.

Why it may not have been “just” syncope (faint) with convulsive movements  
• Convulsive syncope usually begins with pallor, sweating and a limp collapse, not with focal tonic movements and forced head/eye deviation.  
• There is seldom a gelastic component.

What happens next / what the doctors will do  
1. Neuro-imaging (CT or MRI) to look for:  
   • Acute haemorrhage from the fall  
   • A pre-existing structural lesion that might have triggered the seizure (e.g., small stroke, tumour, cortical scar).  
2. Baseline laboratory tests (electrolytes, glucose, infection markers).  
3. EEG to confirm epileptiform activity and localise the focus.  
4. If this is a first unprovoked seizure at ≥60 yr, the chance of an underlying structural brain lesion is high (≈60 %).  
5. Antiseizure medication is usually started after one unprovoked seizure in this age group, once acute precipitants have been excluded.

Key take-home points for witnesses of such an event  
• Lay the person on the floor on their side if possible, loosen tie/neckwear, *do not* put anything in the mouth, and time the event.  
• Call emergency services if the convulsion lasts >5 min, if there is a second seizure without recovery, if it is a first seizure, or if there is injury.  
• After the seizure the person will often be confused and need reassurance.

In short, the most plausible explanation is a focal (likely left frontal) epileptic seizure with gelastic features that generalised, followed by a traumatic head injury on falling. The emergency team’s evaluation and subsequent neurological work-up will determine the exact cause and long-term management.

117.question: So I am a 26 y/o male and I was just diagnosed with epilepsy about a year ago.  went to my current neurologist and he prescribed me Lamotrigine tablets for the seizures. He only prescribed them in 6 month increments and will not renew the prescription until I come in for another appointment. Currently I am on my last month of the prescription and had not scheduled an appointment yet. I tried to renew the prescription through my pharmacy, but the Dr declined the renewal request. I was able to make a last minute appointment for tomorrow but that seems a little wrong of him to do that. What if I was unable to schedule an appointment before my prescription ran out? I know it’s on me to reschedule the appointments but this is potentially life saving medication for me. These are not opiates or amphetamines. I just didn’t know if this was the norm or if the Dr is being unnecessarily difficult. Thank you for any clarification on this.
117.answer:
(I’m not your doctor, so this is general information only.)

Is it “normal” for a neurologist to refuse a refill on lamotrigine unless you’ve been seen recently?  
Yes—this is actually very common practice, and it’s based much more on safety than on any concern about abuse (lamotrigine is not a controlled substance).

Why neurologists usually want a visit every 3–12 months before renewing an anti-seizure drug  
• Effectiveness.  Are you still seizure-free?  If not, the plan may need to change (dose adjustment, add-on drug, imaging, driving advice, etc.).  
• Safety / adverse effects.  Lamotrigine can cause rash, mood changes, bone-marrow/LFT abnormalities, interactions with new meds, etc.  These are easier to catch in person (and sometimes labs are ordered).  
• Compliance.  If pills have been missed, the titration might have to be repeated to avoid the rare but dangerous rash with re-escalation.  
• Documentation / liability.  In most U.S. states an Rx for a NON-controlled medication is legally valid for up to 1 year.  Many specialists, though, shorten that to 3–6 months so the chart shows ongoing follow-up.  Malpractice carriers often recommend that interval for epilepsy patients.  
• Insurance / “prior auth” issues.  Some payers won’t honor a 12-month lamotrigine refill unless the prescriber’s last note is <6 months old.

What if you can’t get in before the pills run out?  
• Call the office, not just the pharmacy.  Most neurologists will call in a “bridge” script for 7–30 days if you already have a follow-up booked.  
• Many U.S. states allow a pharmacist to give an emergency 72-hour supply of a maintenance drug if they can’t reach the prescriber (rules vary).  
• Telehealth often counts as an adequate visit; ask whether a virtual appointment is available sooner.  
• Set reminders: When you pick up the second-to-last refill, schedule the next appointment right then.

Could abruptly stopping lamotrigine harm you?  
You might not seize immediately, but the seizure threshold can fall within days, and stopping suddenly after months of therapy can trigger status epilepticus in some patients.  Restarting also requires a slow retitration to avoid the serious rash.  So continuing the medicine without gaps is important.

Bottom line  
Your neurologist’s six-month policy is well within standard practice.  It isn’t meant to be punitive; it’s meant to keep your treatment safe and documented.  Going forward, just book the next appointment before you leave the office (or set a calendar alert) so you’re never down to your last month of pills without a visit on the calendar.

118.question: I was recently diagnosed by a neurologist with partial epilepsy. the symptoms I had were burning sensation in the back of my head and neck and my back, memory and concentration problems and tightness inside of my head, I felt it in the beginning in the top of my head back in 2017, and starting from 2018 it transferred to the bottom inside of my head. I got prescribed Zeptol 200mg (Carbamazepine) and one for memory and concentration and another for something else (I'll update this with the other prescriptions, I'm writing this from work because I'm on the verge of quitting). I previously thought that I had a problem with my neck or something that has to do with my spine. I have gone to several neurologists and this is the only one that mentioned partial epilepsy. The previous ones all said it was nothing to worry about. I, today have dementia. I have trouble following courses or job meetings or anything. Sometimes I forget the name of people around me. I should mention as well that I feel something really tight in the bottom back of my head. After some research I found that a part of the brain called hippocampus is the one responsible for short term memory processing. It's been a week and a half using Zeptol (200mg). I started with one a day for a week. Now the second week I increased it to two, just as my neurologist said. I still don't feel the benefit that I wanted, to gain back my short term memory. Is the damage done to my short term memory reversible, or am I gonna be like this for the rest of my life?eventually having Alzheimer in my 30s?
118.answer:
I’m not in a position to make or change a diagnosis for you, but I can try to put what you’ve been told into context and answer the questions you asked most often in the clinic:

1. What is “partial” (now called “focal”) epilepsy?  
   •  In focal epilepsy the seizures arise from one limited area of cortex.  
   •  Depending on where that focus is, the first symptoms can be sensory (burning, tightness, déjà-vu, strange smells, sudden emotions), motor, autonomic, or cognitive.  
   •  If the focus is in or next to the temporal lobe/hippocampus, short-term (working) memory is often disturbed because the hippocampus is a key relay for making new memories.

2. Can focal seizures really feel like a tight/burning sensation in the head/neck/back?  
   •  Yes.  A focal sensory seizure coming from the parietal or posterior temporal cortex can be felt as a burning, tingling, “pressure,” or “tightness” in a circumscribed part of the body or even “inside the head.”  
   •  Episodes may be brief (seconds to a few minutes) and may leave you tired or foggy afterwards (a “post-ictal” period).  If these events occur dozens or hundreds of times a day you can feel foggy almost all the time.

3. Why the sudden worry about memory?  Am I developing dementia?  
   •  Transient memory and concentration loss are very common in active epilepsy for two reasons:  
     – each actual seizure temporarily blocks information from being stored;  
     – even between seizures, frequent abnormal discharges on EEG can disrupt attention.  
   •  Once seizure activity is under control, many patients experience a noticeable improvement over weeks to months.  
   •  True Alzheimer’s disease in the 30-year-age range is extremely rare.  Epilepsy itself does not “turn into” Alzheimer’s.  
   •  A structural lesion such as hippocampal sclerosis can produce more persistent memory difficulty, but even then controlling seizures prevents further damage and preserves remaining function.

4. How quickly should I expect benefit from carbamazepine (Zeptol) 200 mg?  
   •  Carbamazepine is usually started low and raised every 1–2 weeks until seizures stop or side-effects appear.  Typical adult maintenance dose is 400–1200 mg/day in two or three divided doses.  Two 200-mg tablets a day (400 mg) is still on the low side for many adults, so you may not yet be at a fully therapeutic level.  
   •  Blood levels reach steady state about 5–7 days after each dose increase, and the brain may need several additional weeks of stable seizure control before cognitive benefits are obvious.  
   •  Paradoxically, early in treatment carbamazepine can make some people groggy or slow; this usually settles after a week or two at each dose step.

5. Is any memory damage permanent?  
   •  If your only problem is seizure activity, memory generally improves once the abnormal firing is suppressed; the brain is remarkably plastic.  
   •  If MRI shows established hippocampal atrophy or another structural injury, the loss from that lesion will not come back, but further decline can often be stopped, and other brain areas can be trained to compensate partly (cognitive rehabilitation therapy).  
   •  The sooner good seizure control is achieved, the better the outlook.

6. What else should be done?  
   •  Objective testing: a high-resolution MRI focused on the temporal lobes and a long-term EEG (or inpatient video-EEG) to confirm the diagnosis and look for hippocampal sclerosis or other lesions.  
   •  Baseline neuropsychological testing to measure memory and attention now; this lets you and your doctors track change over time and guides rehabilitation.  
   •  Review of medications: some antiseizure drugs (e.g., topiramate) worsen cognition, others (e.g., lamotrigine, levetiracetam) tend to be “cognitively neutral” or even slightly helpful.  If carbamazepine alone does not stop seizures or if side-effects remain bothersome, alternatives or add-ons exist.  
   •  General brain-health measures—adequate sleep, regular aerobic exercise, treatment of anxiety/depression, avoidance of alcohol/drugs, and good control of cardiovascular risk factors—improve day-to-day cognition and may protect long-term memory.  
   •  If seizures remain focal despite two appropriately chosen antiseizure medications, referral to an epilepsy center for evaluation of surgery, laser ablation, neuromodulation, or diet therapy is standard.

7. When to seek help immediately  
   •  Worsening confusion, new neurological deficits (double vision, weakness, imbalance), severe rash or fever on carbamazepine, suicidal thoughts, or seizures that cluster or last longer than 5 minutes all require urgent medical attention.

Key points to take home:
•  Your profile (burning/tight sensory episodes, short-term memory trouble, normal structural imaging so far) fits a not-uncommon form of focal epilepsy, often temporal-lobe related.  
•  One to two weeks on a low starting dose of carbamazepine is much too early to judge the final result.  Dose adjustments and sometimes a change of drug are needed.  
•  Most memory and concentration problems in epilepsy improve once the seizures are controlled; this is not the same as early-onset Alzheimer’s.  
•  Close follow-up with your neurologist (or an epileptologist), proper diagnostic work-up, and possibly a neuropsychology referral will give you a clearer prognosis and plan.

Because your symptoms are affecting work and quality of life, do stick with follow-up appointments and don’t hesitate to seek a second opinion at a comprehensive epilepsy center if you still feel unsure about the diagnosis or treatment plan.

119.question: Yet another EDIT: I fainted today on my way to the store and was brought into the hospital. They did a bunch of tests, and realized I was having from 6-10 "silent" seizures a day. I probably had them when I was younger too and they just went away, and came back due to my lack of sleep in the past couple of weeks and anxiety. I honestly didn't even know that was a thing until yesterday, so thank you all. They also did a GI and said that I might have gastroparesis, which would explain pretty much all my symptoms when it comes to weight-loss, and I have an appointment for a gastric emptying study in 2 weeks from now. Thank you all!EDIT: I've called them brain zaps my whole life, but I didn't know that was an actual medical term for something completely different. Its not the withdrawal kinda zaps, it's like a loss of consciousness that I get, but still stay standing up.EDIT 2: No, I don't have an eating disorder. Doctors have no idea why I lost my appetite and can't keep food downSo I really don't know how to explain this without sounding absolutely insane.
119.answer:
I’m glad you were seen urgently and that some answers are beginning to come together. Below is an overview written in plain language that ties together what the doctors have already told you, what the next steps usually look like, and what you can do in the meantime. It is not a substitute for care from your own clinicians, but it should help you understand the pieces of the puzzle and prepare good questions for your follow-ups.

────────────────────
1. “Silent” (Non-Convulsive) Seizures
────────────────────
What they are  
• In many people a seizure is not the shaking (“tonic-clonic”) most of us picture.  
• Absence seizures and focal impaired-awareness seizures can last a few seconds to a couple of minutes. You may stare, pause mid-sentence, lose track of what you’re doing, or have tiny automatisms (lip smacking, picking at clothes) but remain standing.  
• Because there is no dramatic collapse, they’re easy to miss—patients often describe them as “spacing out,” “brain zaps,” or “glitches.”  
• Having 6-10 a day, exactly as your EEG showed, is typical for uncontrolled absence or focal seizures.

Why they showed up again  
• Sleep deprivation is one of the strongest seizure triggers.  
• Anxiety, flashing lights, illness, alcohol, fever, certain medications, and hormonal changes can all lower the seizure threshold.  
• You may have had the tendency since childhood; many kids “grow out” of absence seizures only to have them re-emerge under stress later.

Testing and treatment  
• The gold-standard work-up is a detailed history + MRI of the brain + extended EEG (sometimes inpatient video-EEG).  
• First-line medicines depend on the seizure type (ethosuximide if pure absence; valproate, lamotrigine, levetiracetam, topiramate, etc. if focal or mixed).  
• Nearly everyone with recurrent seizures is advised to:  
  – Get 7–9 h of consistent sleep every night.  
  – Limit/avoid alcohol and recreational drugs.  
  – Take medicines at the same time daily and never stop suddenly.  
  – Keep a seizure log (time, duration, triggers).  
  – Discuss seizure-safe driving rules (varies by region).  
• If medication fails, other options include ketogenic diet, vagus-nerve stimulator, or epilepsy surgery—but <30 % of patients need those.

Key questions for your neurologist  
• “Are my events absence or focal impaired-awareness?”  
• “What did my EEG show about the focus and pattern?”  
• “Which medications fit best with my age, sex, other health issues, and pregnancy plans?”  
• “When am I cleared to drive/work/operate machinery again?”  

────────────────────
2. Gastroparesis
────────────────────
What it is  
• Literally “stomach paralysis.” The stomach muscles and/or the vagus nerve that coordinates them are sluggish, so food empties into the intestine very slowly.  
• Classic symptoms: early fullness, bloating, nausea, vomiting undigested food hours later, and unintentional weight loss.  

Why it happens  
• Diabetes is the most common cause, but many cases are “idiopathic” (no clear cause), post-viral, medication-induced (opioids, some antidepressants, GLP-1 agonists), or part of a broader neurologic/autonomic disorder.  
• A minority of epilepsy patients share an underlying autonomic or autoimmune problem that can involve gut motility, so the coincidence is not impossible—but often they’re two separate issues.

The gastric emptying study  
• You eat a standard radio-labeled meal; a scanner tracks how much remains in the stomach at 1, 2, 3, and 4 h.  
• >10 % retention at 4 h or >60 % at 2 h usually confirms gastroparesis.  

Treatment ladder  
1. Dietary: 4–6 small meals/day, low-fat, low-fiber, chew thoroughly, add liquid calories (smoothies, broths) so less residue sits in the stomach.  
2. Prokinetics: metoclopramide*, domperidone, erythromycin, prucalopride—each has pros/cons and regional availability.  
3. Antiemetics: ondansetron, promethazine, etc. for breakthrough nausea.  
4. Endoscopic or surgical: pyloric botox, G-POEM, gastric electrical stimulator, jejunostomy tube feeding if weight loss becomes severe.  

(*Metoclopramide carries a small risk of tardive dyskinesia—use lowest effective dose and limit lifetime exposure if possible.)

Things you can do right now  
• Stay hydrated: try oral rehydration solutions or water + a pinch of salt and sugar.  
• Liquid nutritional supplements (Boost, Ensure, Kate Farms, Orgain, etc.) often slip through better than solids.  
• Keep a food/symptom diary to show the GI specialist.  
• Ask whether any current meds could be slowing your gut and whether they can be adjusted.  

────────────────────
3. How (or whether) the two conditions connect
────────────────────
• The vagus nerve is involved in both brain and gut function. Some inflammatory or autoimmune processes (e.g., autoimmune encephalitis, paraneoplastic syndromes) can present with both seizures and dysmotility, but they are rare.  
• More commonly, they are unrelated parallel problems that surfaced together because you were under tremendous physiologic stress (poor sleep, weight loss, anxiety).  
• Your care team will rule out systemic causes with basic bloodwork (glucose, thyroid, B12, ANA, ESR/CRP) and imaging; if red flags appear they may order antibody panels or refer to an autonomic specialist.

────────────────────
4. Practical Tips While You Await Further Work-up
────────────────────
1. Seizure diary: date/time, what you were doing, duration, trigger, how you felt after.  
2. Medical ID: bracelet or phone lock-screen stating “Epilepsy – non-convulsive seizures” and emergency contact.  
3. Sleep hygiene: same bedtime/waketime, dark room, limit screens 1 h before bed, caffeine only before noon.  
4. Stress reduction: CBT, mindfulness apps, gentle exercise like walking or yoga as tolerated.  
5. Medication adherence: set alarms or use blister packs.  
6. Bring someone to appointments: an extra set of ears helps when lots of information is flying around.  
7. Prepare written questions: you’ll be amazed how many get forgotten once you’re in the room.

────────────────────
5. Red-Flag Reasons to Seek Care Immediately
────────────────────
• New seizure lasting >5 min or clusters without recovery in between (status epilepticus).  
• Severe vomiting with signs of dehydration (no urine >8 h, dizziness when standing, very dry mouth).  
• Black/tarry or bloody vomit or stools.  
• Sudden severe headache, weakness, vision or speech changes (rule out stroke).  
• Rapid, unintentional weight loss >2 lb/1 kg per week despite attempts to eat.  

────────────────────
Bottom Line
────────────────────
You’ve already made the single most important step: you were evaluated and now have an evidence-based explanation (non-convulsive seizures) plus a good lead on the GI symptoms (suspected gastroparesis). With the right seizure medication, consistent sleep, and targeted treatment for gastric emptying, most patients get major relief and regain weight.

Bring this summary to your neurologist and gastroenterologist, keep asking questions, and don’t hesitate to lean on dietitians, psychologists, epilepsy nurses, or support groups—they’re part of the team too.

Best of luck, and congratulations on advocating for yourself until someone listened. It really does make a difference.

120.question: Age:18 Sex:F Weight:46 kg Height:1.61 cm So i have had histories of deja vu, it usually doesn’t last long. I don’t have them a lot, sometimes more sometime less. I have a huge fear of brain tumor/epilepsy so i am always looking out for symptoms. I also randomly get dream flashbacks. Sometimes at night, doesn’t happen that often, i get like weird head/body vibrations/buzzing and then i try to go to sleep, i start having nonsense thoughts and i can’t sleep. My ears are buzzing right now and so is my head. My heart sometimes gets on a higher rate and i wake up from this mildly depersonalized. I fear that this mighr turn into a grand mal seizure. I have had no history of seizures before. I am so scared to sleep right now fearing that something might happen. It’s probably about a year that this situation while i am trying to sleep happens. Wold really love to have an EEG bit when i went to the neurologist a year ago he only diagnosed me with anxiety combined with elements of OCD. He did some reflex/eyesight tests and all came back with no neurological deficit. I’d get an EEG but i am literally such a hypochondriac that my parents are concerned and i just went through blood tests and i don’t want to worry them again! If anyone has any idea i’d be so glad :)
120.answer:
I’m not in a position to diagnose you over the internet, but I can walk you through the possibilities, point out the warning signs that really do need medical review, and suggest some practical next steps. Read this slowly and keep it for reference when you talk to your own doctor.

1. How common are the sensations you describe?
 • Déjà-vu: More than 60 % of healthy people experience it occasionally. It is especially common in teenagers and young adults and becomes more frequent with stress, lack of sleep, stimulants (caffeine, energy drinks), or anxiety.
 • “Dream flash-backs,” buzzing in the head or ears, body vibrations, and nonsense thoughts while falling asleep: These are classic hypnagogic phenomena (the half-awake/half-asleep state). People can experience vivid images, sounds, or body sensations just as the brain is switching sleep stages. They are harmless but can feel strange or frightening if you do not know what they are.
 • Racing heart, depersonalization, and fear: These fit well with panic or anxiety attacks. When the fight-or-flight system turns on, you can feel heart pounding, ear ringing (from sudden changes in blood flow), inner “vibrations,” and a sense of unreality.

2. Could this be epilepsy?
Temporal-lobe (focal aware) seizures can produce déjà-vu, a rising stomach sensation, buzzing, fear or depersonalization that lasts 5–60 s and is completely stereotyped (same every time). They usually occur out of the blue, not only at sleep onset, and people often cannot speak or respond normally during them. They may progress to a loss of awareness or a convulsion in roughly one-third of patients.

What you have described so far argues more for anxiety‐related states than for epilepsy:
 • You remain fully aware and can recall what happened.
 • Episodes vary in content, duration, and context.
 • They occur mainly as you fall asleep or when you are very anxious.
 • You have never had a convulsion, tongue bite, incontinence, or post-event confusion.

BUT: No internet post can definitively rule epilepsy in or out. If you ever develop events that are
 – stereotyped and brief,
 – associated with blank staring, loss of speech, or unresponsiveness,
 – followed by confusion,
 – or end in a full-body convulsion,
then you must be re-evaluated promptly (ideally with an EEG and possibly MRI).

3. Could it be a brain tumour?
