Keep an open, organized line of communication with your new neurologist; bringing a concise diary and this kind of structured problem list to each visit often speeds the path to clearer answers and better control.

132.question: An MRI with Neuroquant showed these normative percentiles: Hippocampal Occupancy Score – 32 Hippocampi – 72 Superior Lateral Ventricles – 94 Inferior Lateral Ventricles - 74 The hippocampal volume seems normal but the hippocampal occupancy score is very low. What does this mean, and what do you think the prognosis could be? I've been experiencing memory loss, depersonalization, reduced consciousness, and depression since getting COVID and having a vaccine reaction earlier this year. However, I also used CBD oil for three months the year before to ill effect (it caused depersonalization and amnesia) and was diagnosed with depression in the past, which may or may not contribute. Things really worsened after I had an mRNA vaccine, so I think that the virus could've been near the hippocampus and gotten attacked afterward. My information: 24F, 110 pounds, conditions: epilepsy, history of COVID, history of vaccine reaction, medications: Trileptal, location of problem: brain, duration: 9 months
132.answer:
What the numbers actually represent  

1. How NeuroQuant works  
   • The software measures the volume of a structure (e.g., the hippocampus) and the volume of the immediately adjacent inferior-lateral ventricle.  
   • It then compares those volumes with a large reference data set of healthy people matched for age and head size and expresses the result as a percentile.  
   • 50th percentile is the statistical “average”; values between about the 5th and 95th percentile are usually regarded as within the normal range.

2. Hippocampal Occupancy Score (HOC)  
   HOC = hippocampal volume ÷ (hippocampal volume + inferior-lateral ventricular volume) × 100.  
   A high ventricle volume (or a low hippocampal volume) drives the ratio down. It is used chiefly in people >55 yr to screen for early Alzheimer-type atrophy.

3. What your numbers mean (24-year-old female)  
   • Hippocampal volume: 72nd percentile – larger than average for your age/sex.  
   • Inferior-lateral ventricles: 74th percentile – those small side pockets of CSF are also somewhat larger than average.  
   • HOC: 32nd percentile – because both numbers are on the large side, the ratio shifts downward.

   Important points:  
   • 32nd percentile is still inside the normal distribution; it is not the “bottom 5 %” red-flag zone most neuroradiologists worry about.  
   • The HOC has been validated mainly in older adults; in a 24-year-old the clinical meaning is far less certain.  
   • A single MRI can show congenital or developmental size differences that have nothing to do with current symptoms.

Do the imaging findings explain your symptoms?  

Probably not by themselves.  In a young adult with normal-sized hippocampi, a mildly low HOC is much less likely to be the cause of recent-onset memory problems than the conditions you already list:

• Epilepsy and seizures (especially temporal-lobe seizures) can produce transient memory loss and depersonalisation.  
• Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal) may cause fatigue, slowed thinking, or hyponatraemia, which in turn worsens cognition.  
• Post-COVID or post-vaccination syndromes can include “brain fog,” mood change, and derealisation, usually with normal structural MRIs.  
• Major depression itself impairs memory, concentration, and the sense of “conscious presence” and can mimic early dementia.  
• Prior cannabis/CBD exposure can trigger or unmask depersonalisation, but its structural MRI footprint is typically nil and its effects fade once the drug is stopped.

Prognosis  

Because there is no clear structural loss of hippocampal tissue, the picture is more consistent with potentially reversible functional impairment than with a progressive neuro-degenerative disease. In other words, the outlook depends largely on how well the underlying, treatable conditions are managed:

1. Epilepsy – Good seizure control, sodium checks (for Trileptal), routine follow-up EEG.  
2. Mood/disassociation – Evidence-based depression treatment (SSRIs, psychotherapy, CBT, structured exercise).  
3. Post-COVID cognitive issues – Sleep normalisation, graded aerobic activity, occupational/neuro-cognitive therapy if needed.  
4. Lifestyle – Avoid cannabis/CBD for now, maintain adequate sleep, hydration, B-vitamins, iron, thyroid balance, etc.  
5. Re-imaging – If symptoms progress, a repeat MRI with volumetrics in 12-18 months can show whether the structures are truly changing.

When to seek urgent evaluation  

• New focal neurologic deficits, worsening seizures, or confusion  
• Rapidly progressive memory loss over weeks  
• Severe depression with suicidal thoughts  

Key take-aways  

• Your hippocampi are not shrunken; the HOC looks “low” only because the nearby ventricles are a bit roomy.  
• In a 24-year-old that finding is almost always a normal variant, not an omen of Alzheimer’s.  
• The symptoms you describe have many better-documented, potentially reversible causes.  
• Work closely with your neurologist and a mental-health professional; most young patients improve with a tailored plan that addresses seizures, mood, sleep, and physical conditioning.

This explanation cannot replace direct medical advice; use it as a guide for a focused discussion with your treating physician.

133.question: I have epilepsy(taking Keppra/Lamictal)Age: 39M Height: 6’0 Weight: 235 Non smoker/drinker I have epilepsy(controlled by meds) and have typically avoided flu vaccines due to GBS(albeit rare). Has anyone heard of any data related to the Covid vaccine and GBS and/or is there a better choice when choosing between brands.
133.answer:
Key points up-front  
• Having epilepsy and taking levetiracetam (Keppra) or lamotrigine (Lamictal) is NOT a contraindication to any of the COVID-19 vaccines.  
• The only vaccine platform that has shown a measurable increase in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is the adenovirus-vector vaccines (Janssen/J&J in the U.S., AstraZeneca elsewhere).  
• The mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna) and the protein-subunit vaccine (Novavax) have not shown any increased risk of GBS in the large post-marketing safety databases.  
• The risk of developing GBS after a SARS-CoV-2 infection is several-fold higher than the risk after vaccination with any product.  

1. GBS background and the influenza-vaccine experience  
• Baseline incidence of GBS: ~1–2 cases per 100,000 people per year.  
• The 1976 “swine-flu” shot produced an excess of about 8–10 cases per million. Since then, modern flu shots have shown either no increase or ~1–2 excess cases per million doses—still very rare.  

2. What the safety data show for COVID-19 vaccines  

a) mRNA vaccines (Pfizer, Moderna)  
   – U.S. Vaccine Safety Datalink (VSD, >12 million doses through 2022): no safety signal for GBS (rate ratio 1.1; 95 % CI crosses 1).  
   – UK and EU pharmacovigilance data: no excess GBS over background.  
   – CDC statement: “People with a history of GBS may receive an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine.”  

b) Protein-subunit vaccine (Novavax)  
   – Clinical trials (~40,000 participants) reported 1 GBS case in vaccine arm vs 0 in placebo; difference not statistically significant.  
   – Post-authorization data so far show no signal, but numbers are smaller than for mRNA vaccines.  

c) Adenovirus-vector vaccines (J&J/Janssen, AstraZeneca)  
   – U.S. VAERS thru Feb 2022: ≈ 21 confirmed GBS cases per 100,000 Janssen doses in the 42 days post-vaccination (about 7–8× background). Absolute risk ≈ 9–10 per million doses.  
   – UK study (AstraZeneca): ≈ 5–6 excess cases per million doses.  
   – Because of this, the CDC recommends using mRNA vaccines preferentially; J&J is limited to people who cannot or will not take an mRNA product.  

d) COVID-19 infection itself  
   – Studies in the U.S. and UK: 15–20 excess GBS cases per million SARS-CoV-2 infections—significantly higher than after ANY vaccine platform.  

3. Epilepsy-specific considerations  
• Fever can lower seizure threshold. Moderna tends to cause slightly more post-shot fever/chills than Pfizer, so many neurologists suggest Pfizer if a patient wants the least reactogenic option.  
• Prophylactic acetaminophen/ibuprofen (starting when the arm becomes sore) is reasonable and does not blunt antibody response.  
• No pharmacokinetic interaction between mRNA vaccines and levetiracetam or lamotrigine. Continue your meds as scheduled.  

4. Practical advice for someone with a GBS concern  
1. Discuss your specific history with your neurologist, especially if you personally have had GBS before (the CDC’s caution mainly applies to patients who developed GBS within 6 weeks of a prior dose of an adenovirus-vector COVID vaccine).  
2. If you decide to vaccinate (recommended):  
   • Prefer an mRNA vaccine (Pfizer or Moderna) or Novavax if available.  
   • Stay well-hydrated, keep seizure meds on time, and use acetaminophen/ibuprofen for fever or myalgias.  
   • Observe the usual 15-minute post-shot waiting period (30 minutes if you have a history of severe allergies).  
3. If a booster is due, the same hierarchy applies—mRNA > Novavax >> J&J.  

Bottom line  
The adenovirus-vector vaccines have a small but measurable GBS signal; the mRNA and protein-subunit vaccines do not. For someone worried about GBS, an mRNA product (Pfizer or Moderna) is the safest and is fully compatible with your epilepsy medications. The overall benefit of vaccination still far outweighs the very small potential risk, especially given that COVID-19 infection itself carries a higher risk of triggering GBS. Always run the plan by your treating neurologist or primary physician, but current data support proceeding with an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine.

134.question: About June of 22 I suffered an event which felt like a lightning bolt across my chest not soon after starting experiencing numbness in arms and legs, constant bouts of extreme fatigue and muscle spasms/ cramps…neurology ruled out epilepsy and PNES, they are still stumped on ms or lyme possibly…the only confusing part is reoccurring rhabdomyolysis and extreme heat intolerance…the numbness has turned into more of a burning feeling down arms and legs and seems to be spreading used to only start in finger tips and toes…the muscle spasms in legs seems to be getting worse…neuro could only find. Low testosterone symptoms, was referred to endocrinologist and put on test replacement…exercise and diet seem to help temporarily but then I hit the reoccurring course of over heating and then my CK levels spike was at 16000 recently but after aggresive flushing they went back down, we’re kind of at a cross road was wondering if anyone had insight on what to do next? Neurology only wants to repeat an mri once per year to rule out ms
134.answer:
I’m not your physician, but the combination of  
• recurrent, very‐high CK / true rhabdomyolysis (16 000 U/L) that is precipitated by heat or exertion  
• progressive burning dysesthesias in the hands and feet that are now ascending (small-fiber-type neuropathy)  
• muscle cramps/spasms and profound exercise-induced fatigue  
• marked heat intolerance  

is unusual for multiple sclerosis and, by itself, does not fit the typical post-treatment course of Lyme disease.  To keep the diagnostic process moving you will usually need a neuromuscular-disease work-up rather than a “general” neurology follow-up once a year.  Below is a practical road map you can take to your physicians (or to a major academic neuromuscular center for a second opinion).

1.  Make sure it really is rhabdomyolysis  
   • A CK > 5 × upper limit (often >1000 U/L) plus dark urine or myoglobin in serum/urine confirms it.  
   • Get a copy of every CK result, urine myoglobin, creatinine and electrolytes drawn so far.  Plot them vs. time and triggers (exercise, heat index, infection, medication changes).  A pattern often emerges.

2.  Rule out common, reversible precipitants  
   • Drugs / toxins: statins, fibrates, antipsychotics, SSRIs/SNRIs, colchicine, alcohol, cocaine/amphetamines, supplements such as ephedra or synephrine, anabolic steroids, ketones.  
   • Endocrine / metabolic: hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, adrenal crisis, severe hypokalemia or hyponatremia, uncontrolled diabetes, severe vitamin D deficiency.  
   • Infections (EBV, CMV, influenza, COVID-19, HIV, coxsackie, etc.).  
   • Heat illness / dehydration.  (You already noticed this one, but document wet-bulb temperature and hydration status.)

3.  If the above are negative, the differential narrows to six big categories  

   A. Metabolic / genetic exertional myopathies (often give exactly the “feel fine, then overheat, then CK explodes” story)  
      – Glycogenosis (McArdle – PYGM), phosphofructokinase (PFKM), debrancher (AGL), etc.  
      – Lipid oxidation defects (CPT-II, VLCAD, carnitine transporter, LPIN1, RAB3GAP2, etc.).  
      – Mitochondrial cytopathies (multiple genes; often add multisystem fatigue, dysautonomia).  
      – RYR1- or CACNA1S-related malignant hyperthermia/exertional heat injury.  
      – Dystrophinopathies / sarcoglycanopathies (less likely in your age group but can present with rhabdo).  

   B. Immune-mediated necrotizing myopathies / myositis  
      – Anti-HMGCR, anti-SRP, antisynthetase antibodies.  
      – Can also cause neuropathic pain (small-fiber involvement).  
      – Responds to steroids/IVIG/other immunotherapy if caught early.

   C. Channelopathies / periodic paralysis variants  
      – SCN4A/RYR1/ATP2A1; often have heat sensitivity, cramps and occasionally rhabdo.  

   D. Autoimmune / systemic inflammatory disease with overlap neuropathy + myositis  
      – Sarcoidosis, Sjögren, vasculitis, eosinophilic fasciitis, lupus, mixed connective tissue disease.  

   E. Infiltrative / storage disorders  
      – Fabry (neuropathic burning, heat intolerance, high CK after exertion).  
      – Amyloidosis.  

   F. Toxic mitochondrial or metabolic injury due to an occult exposure.

4.  Focused testing that a neuromuscular clinic will often do up front  
   (You can ask your current doctor to order many of these or request referral to an academic neuromuscular specialist.)  

   • Repeat CK, aldolase, AST/ALT, LDH, ESR, CRP when asymptomatic and again during a flare.  
   • Comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid panel, morning cortisol, HbA1c, vitamin D, B12, folate, copper.  
   • Serum & urine myoglobin.  
   • Autoimmune/myositis panel: ANA, anti-HMGCR, anti-SRP, Jo-1, PL-7, PL-12, EJ, OJ, Mi-2, TIF1-γ, MDA5, NXP-2, SAE.  
   • Infectious serologies: Lyme ELISA/Western blot, syphilis, HIV, hepatitis B & C, COVID-19 nucleocapsid if not already immune.  
   • Electrodiagnostics: EMG/NCS during asymptomatic period (looks at myopathy vs neuropathy).  
   • Skin punch biopsy for intra-epidermal nerve fiber density (small-fiber neuropathy).  
   • Autonomic testing (QSART, tilt-table) for dysautonomia causing heat intolerance.  
   • If EMG shows active myopathy OR CK >5000 persists → consider MRI of thighs & calves with STIR to locate inflamed muscle, then ultrasound-guided muscle biopsy.  
   • Next-generation sequencing myopathy panel (covers CPT2, RYR1, LPIN1, PYGM etc.) or whole-exome if initial targeted panel is negative.  
   • If Fabry suspected: α-galactosidase A activity ± GLA gene sequencing; urine globotriaosylceramide.  
   • Mito work-up: resting venous lactate/pyruvate, then forearm ischemic exercise test; muscle biopsy with COX/Succinate dehydrogenase staining and mtDNA sequencing if needed.

5.  While testing is in progress – practical management  

   Heat / exertion  
   • Absolutely avoid exercising in >80 °F (>27 °C) environments until you have a firm diagnosis.  
   • Pre-cool (ice vests, cool shower), frequent cooling breaks, maintain urine output >1 ml/kg/hr.  
   • Keep oral rehydration solution with 3–4 g NaCl per liter if you sweat heavily.  
   • At the first sign of cola-colored urine or muscle swelling, go to ER (fluids, renal monitoring).

   Cramps / spasms  
   • Magnesium glycinate 300–400 mg at night (if renal function normal).  
   • Trial of mexiletine 150 mg bid or carbamazepine 100–200 mg bid can be considered by your physician in proven sodium-channel myotonia.  
   • Stretching, nocturnal slow-release potassium (20 mEq) if labs allow.

   Neuropathic pain  
   • First-line: gabapentin, pregabalin, duloxetine or low-dose amitriptyline; topical 8% capsaicin or 5% lidocaine patches.  
   • If small-fiber neuropathy is proven and autoimmune markers are present, IVIG 2 g/kg loading then monthly often helps pain and sometimes stops progression.

   Testosterone replacement  
   • Monitor hematocrit, estradiol, PSA (if >40 y).  TRT itself rarely causes rhabdo, but supraphysiologic dosing can accentuate heat illness.

6.  When to escalate immediately  

   • Dark urine or CK >5000 U/L after minimal exertion or at rest.  
   • New weakness that is more than post-rhabdo soreness (trouble climbing stairs, lifting head, swallowing, breathing).  
   • Fever >101 °F with muscle pain (could be malignant hyperthermia-like crisis, infection or immune flare).  
   • Decline in kidney function (creatinine rising, decreased urine).

7.  Getting the right team  

   • Ask your PCP to refer you specifically to a neuromuscular specialist (not just “neurology”).  Academic centers often run a combined “Rhabdomyolysis / Metabolic Myopathy” clinic.  
   • If inflammatory myopathy or systemic autoimmune disease is suspected, enlist rheumatology early—treatment delay >6 months worsens long-term outcome.  
   • Genetics department if first-tier metabolic panel is nondiagnostic.  
   • Physical medicine & rehab for a paced, safe re-conditioning program once your baseline CK stays <1000.

8.  Why an annual “MRI for MS” is not enough  

   MS almost never produces 16 000 U/L CK or frank rhabdomyolysis.  Waiting a year risks repeated renal hits and permanent muscle damage.  A focused neuromuscular evaluation usually reaches a working diagnosis (or at least a safe management plan) within 2–3 months.

Bottom line  
1. Document every episode (date, ambient temperature, activity, meds, CK, kidney tests).  
2. Push for a comprehensive neuromuscular/myopathy evaluation—including genetic and autoimmune panels, EMG, muscle/nerve biopsy if needed.  
3. In the meantime avoid heat, stay aggressively hydrated, use neuropathic-pain meds, and keep testosterone in the physiologic range.  
4. Escalate to the ER for any new rhabdo flare or neurologic deficit.  

Take this outline to your current doctors.  If they are uncomfortable pursuing it, ask for referral to a tertiary center (Mayo, Johns Hopkins, Cleveland Clinic, UCSF, WashU, Duke, etc.) where recurrent unexplained rhabdomyolysis and small-fiber neuropathy are seen frequently.

135.question: Hong Kong,18M On 27 August I had my first seizure, it happened at a restaurant which go for lunch nearly every day. The waiter there told me she saw me fell suddenly and seizing on the ground. After I ‘woke up’ I found my self yelling and struggle to leave the restaurant. Then slowly regain consciousness and paramedics asked me to unlock my phone in order to contact my parents. They also me that they called the police for help.I have no idea about what I did during that time... It makes me feel so ashamed.... After one day of hospitalization I was discharged with no medication given. I was also given a discharge slip mentioning the diagnosis was epilepsy Just a few days my second seizure occurred, while I was sleeping. When I woke up, I saw paramedics standing in front of my bed. Then nothing else. Then the next thing I could remember was , I am inside a ambulance. I can feel my brain like a computer lagging. It took me around 20-30s to recall why I was in an ambulance. After one day of hospitalisation, I discharged with Lamictal prescribed. After gradually increasing the dose, now I have to take medication two times per day, 100mg in total. I can start to feel the side effects. It makes me memory decline.. It makes me feel so frustrated. I did not want my friends to know. So I talked about my feelings on other forums anonymously. The reply I got was, are sure you are suffering from epilepsy? (That person)I have the same experience before too! Turns out he was diagnosed vasovagal episode. So now I am doubting if I am suffering from epilepsy or not? I really hate taking that Lamictal and wish to get rid off it..
135.answer:
I’m sorry this has happened to you – having a first seizure (let alone two in one week) is frightening and confusing. Below is a detailed, step-by-step explanation of what usually happens after a first seizure, why your doctors treated you as an epileptic, what Lamictal (lamotrigine) is expected to do, what side-effects are typical, and what options you have if you feel the diagnosis is wrong or the medicine is intolerable.

1. How doctors decide whether it is “epilepsy” or something else  
   A single convulsion can be caused by many things (low blood sugar, fainting, drug/alcohol withdrawal, infection, head injury, etc.).  Doctors switch from the term “seizure” to “epilepsy” only when the risk of another unprovoked seizure is thought to be high.  The usual criteria are:  
   • Two unprovoked seizures more than 24 h apart, or  
   • One unprovoked seizure and a brain scan/EEG that shows a high chance of recurrence.  
   You already meet the first criterion (two unprovoked events within a few days), so it is reasonable they wrote “epilepsy” on the discharge form.

2. Why people sometimes confuse seizures with vasovagal syncope (“fainting”)  
   Vasovagal fainting can occasionally produce brief jerks or stiffening; this is called “convulsive syncope.”  However, there are key differences:  
   • Triggers.  Vasovagal episodes are often set off by prolonged standing, heat, pain, emotional stress, or seeing blood.  Epileptic seizures can appear out of the blue, during sleep, during eating, etc.  
   • Colour.  In fainting the person is usually pale; in seizures they can be flushed or bluish.  
   • Tongue-biting.  A bite on the side of the tongue strongly points to epilepsy; tip-of-the-tongue bites can happen in fainting.  
   • Post-event confusion.  A true seizure is usually followed by minutes to hours of confusion, tiredness, headache or “brain lag.”  After simple fainting, recovery is rapid (within seconds to a minute).  
   • Witness description.  True seizures have rhythmic jerking of limbs, forced eye deviation, clenched jaw, and often loss of bladder control.  
   In your first event you had sudden collapse, rhythmic seizing, and a prolonged confused/agitated period (yelling, trying to leave, paramedics had to calm you).  In the second, you had a nocturnal event (very rare for vasovagal), and a post-ictal period where you could not remember why you were in an ambulance.  Those features are classic for epileptic generalized tonic–clonic seizures.

3. Tests that usually follow a first seizure  
   • Routine labs (sugar, calcium, electrolytes, CBC) – probably done in the ER.  
   • Brain MRI – looks for structural causes.  
   • EEG – looks for epileptic discharges.  
   Even if MRI/EEG are normal, about 30 % of people still have epilepsy on clinical grounds alone; normal tests do not rule it out.

4. Why start medication so quickly?  
   After two unprovoked seizures, the chance of another one in the next 1–2 years is roughly 60–80 %.  Antiseizure medication cuts that risk by roughly two-thirds.  Hong Kong guidelines (similar to UK/NICE) recommend offering treatment after the second event.  Early control matters because every seizure carries small but real dangers: head injury, burns, drowning, sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP).

5. Lamictal (lamotrigine) – benefits and side-effects  
   • Pros: Broad-spectrum (works for most generalized and focal epilepsies), low sedation, minimal weight gain, rarely causes cognitive slowing compared with many other drugs.  It is a common first-line medicine for young adults.  
   • Cons/side-effects: Rash (1–3 %, serious 1/3,000), insomnia, vivid dreams, mild dizziness, mild memory/attention problems.  Most cognitive complaints settle after 4–6 weeks at the target dose.  
   • Dose: The slow build-up (e.g., 25 mg for 2 weeks, 50 mg for 2 weeks, then 100 mg daily, then 50 mg twice daily) is meant to prevent the rare serious rash called Stevens-Johnson syndrome.  

   What you describe (“my brain feels slow, memory worse”) can come from:  
   a) Post-ictal effects – every generalized seizure can temporarily affect memory for days-to-weeks.  
   b) Sleep disruption (common after hospital stays and anxiety).  
   c) Lamotrigine itself (usually mild; keeping the evening dose earlier in the night and good hydration often help).  
   If in a few more weeks you truly feel Lamictal is clouding you, your neurologist can:  
   • Check lamotrigine blood level (sometimes “normal” doses give high levels in fast-absorbers).  
   • Reduce by 25 mg steps and re-judge seizure control.  
   • Switch to another drug (e.g., levetiracetam, brivaracetam, topiramate, valproate – each has its own pluses/minuses).  

6. Stopping medication – why doctors resist unless you are seizure-free for years  
   Hong Kong and international practice is to continue medication until you have been seizure-free at least two years (for generalized epilepsy) or even longer (some focal epilepsies).  Stopping earlier carries a ~40 % relapse risk, and if you relapse you must restart at the bottom of the dose ladder.

7. What you can do now  
   • Make sure you have a follow-up appointment with a neurologist or epilepsy clinic (within 4–6 weeks of discharge is typical).  Bring a written list of all questions, including: “Could this be syncope?”, “Can we do an EEG/MRI if not already done?”, “What are my driving/physical activity restrictions?”, “How long do I need to be on Lamictal?”  
   • Keep a seizure diary: date, time, what you were doing, how long the event lasted (ask witnesses), how long until you felt normal again, possible triggers (sleep deprivation, stress, alcohol, flashing lights, infections).  
   • Sleep: 7–9 h every night is one of the best seizure preventers.  
   • Limit alcohol (binge drinking is a strong trigger) and stay well hydrated.  
   • Do not suddenly stop Lamictal – that alone can provoke seizures.  Any change should be gradual under medical advice.  
   • Consider sharing at least with one trusted friend or relative who can help if a seizure occurs.  Epilepsy is common (about 1 in 100 people) and nothing to be ashamed of.  
   • Psychological support.  A sudden epilepsy diagnosis often produces anxiety or depression.  Hong Kong has Epilepsy Concern HK (3679-0900) and Caritas Family Crisis Support Centre (18288) for counselling.  Online peer forums (r/epilepsy on Reddit, Epilepsy Foundation forums) are also helpful.

8. Quick answers to common worries  
   • “Will seizures harm my IQ?”  Repeated, uncontrolled generalized seizures can affect memory, but with medication and good sleep most people lead full academic/professional lives.  
   • “Will friends find out?”  They will not know unless you or witnesses tell them.  However, letting roommates or sports partners know what to do (turn you on your side, time the seizure, call an ambulance if it lasts >5 min) can literally save your life.  
   • “Can I exercise?”  Yes – regular exercise is encouraged.  Avoid swimming alone or climbing heights without supervision.  
   • “Driving?”  Transport Department usually requires 12 months seizure-free before re-issuing a licence; check exact HK regulations.

Bottom line  
Two witnessed, unprovoked events with prolonged confusion afterward and one occurring out of sleep make epilepsy far more likely than vasovagal fainting.  Lamotrigine is a sensible first choice; its cognitive side-effects are generally mild and often improve after your brain has a few weeks of stable levels.  Do not stop it on your own.  Schedule follow-up with a neurologist, get (or confirm results of) an EEG and MRI, and discuss any lingering doubts or side-effects.  With proper care, most young people with new-onset epilepsy achieve full seizure control and normal life.

136.question: 24 F USA Asthma, epilepsy, hypothyroidismI have laryngeal candidiasis (unknown cause but thought to be from Breo and prednisone?) and it isn't responding much to fluconazole. The next step is amphotericin b and I'm kinda nervous. What should I expect realistically?
136.answer:
I’m not your physician, but I can walk you through the usual approach so you know the kinds of questions to ask and what to expect.

1. Why amphotericin-B is being suggested  
• Refractory Candida. If fluconazole hasn’t worked, the organism may be intrinsically resistant (e.g., C. glabrata, C. krusei) or have acquired resistance.  
• Deep-seated site. The larynx is tougher to reach than the mouth, so “topical” agents such as nystatin or clotrimazole don’t penetrate well.  
• Guidelines. IDSA guidelines list amphotericin-B or an echinocandin (caspofungin, micafungin, anidulafungin) as next-line choices after an azole failure for mucosal candidiasis.

2. Which formulation are they planning?  
Ask whether you’ll receive:  
• Conventional amphotericin-B deoxycholate (often simply called “Ampho-B”).  
• A lipid formulation (liposomal amphotericin-B [Ambisome], amphotericin-B lipid complex [Abelcet], or cholesteryl-sulfate complex).  
The lipid products are far less kidney-toxic and cause fewer chills/fevers, but they cost more, so some insurers require special approval. Your consent form or the pharmacy label will tell you which one.

3. How it is given  
• Almost always IV, through a peripheral or (preferably) a central line.  
• Infusion time: 2–4 h.  
• Setting: hospital admission or an outpatient infusion center. A short course (7–14 days) can sometimes be finished entirely as an outpatient.

4. Monitoring you can expect  
Baseline and then at least twice a week (sometimes daily):  
• Serum creatinine and BUN (kidney function).  
• Electrolytes, especially potassium and magnesium.  
• CBC (amphotericin-B can cause mild anemia).  
• Vital signs during the infusion (looking for fever, rigors, hypotension).  
• Weight and fluid balance (if inpatient).  
Because you have epilepsy, ask them to keep a close eye on magnesium and sodium—large drops can make seizures more likely.

5. Common side-effects and how they’re managed  
A. Infusion-related “shake and bake” (fever, chills, rigors, headache, nausea)  
 • More common with conventional formulation than with liposomal.  
 • Usually starts 30 – 90 min after the infusion begins; lasts 1–3 h.  
 • Prevented/treated with “premeds”: acetaminophen 650 mg, diphenhydramine 25–50 mg, sometimes hydrocortisone 25–50 mg IV, and meperidine 25–50 mg IV/IM if rigors occur.  
B. Kidney toxicity (rise in creatinine, drop in urine output)  
 • Risk goes up with cumulative dose and if you’re already dehydrated or on other nephrotoxic drugs (e.g., NSAIDs).  
 • Pre-hydration with 500–1000 mL normal saline before the infusion protects the kidneys and is standard practice.  
 • If creatinine climbs, the dose is reduced, spaced out, or switched to a lipid product. Damage is usually reversible if caught early.  
C. Electrolyte wasting (low K+, low Mg++)  
 • Can lead to muscle cramps, palpitations, or, rarely, arrhythmias or seizures.  
 • Often requires daily oral or IV supplements.  
D. Anemia (over longer courses).  
E. Thrombophlebitis at the IV site (use of a central line or rotating peripheral sites helps).

6. Less common/serious adverse events  
• Severe allergic reaction—rare, but you’ll be observed during the first doses.  
• Cardiac arrhythmias—from electrolyte shifts; why monitoring is important.  
• Liver enzyme elevation—uncommon, but LFTs may be checked weekly.

7. Typical dosage & length for mucosal/laryngeal disease  
Conventional: 0.3–0.7 mg/kg/day IV.  
Liposomal: 3–5 mg/kg/day IV.  
Duration: usually 7–14 days, occasionally up to 21 days if response is slow. Improvement in pain/hoarseness generally begins within 3–5 days.

8. What happens if you can’t tolerate it?  
• Switch to a lipid formulation (if you started on conventional).  
• Change to an echinocandin—these are IV as well but have minimal kidney toxicity and almost no infusion-related rigors.  
In practice many clinicians actually try an echinocandin before conventional Ampho-B unless there’s a specific reason to use Ampho-B, so you could ask whether an echinocandin is an option.

9. Things you can do to lower the chance of needing more antifungal therapy later  
• Asthma inhalers: Use a spacer, rinse/gargle and spit after each dose of Breo, and discuss whether your steroid dose can be stepped down once the infection is gone.  
• Systemic steroids: stay on the lowest effective dose and taper off if possible.  
• Good oral hygiene; treat any denture problems, reflux, or xerostomia that can predispose to Candida.  
• Keep follow-up with ENT or ID to be sure the infection fully resolves (repeat laryngoscopy if they used it for diagnosis).

10. Questions to ask your team  
• Which formulation of amphotericin-B will I get?  
• Can we consider an echinocandin first?  
• Where will the infusions happen—do I need admission?  
• What pre-medications and kidney-protection plan will you use?  
• Who will be checking my labs and how often?  
• How long is the planned course, and what milestones tell us it’s working?  
• What can I do about the steroid inhaler so this doesn’t recur?

Bottom line  
Amphotericin-B is a powerful drug with a scary reputation, but with modern monitoring, pre-hydration, and the availability of lipid formulations, most people complete a short course without lasting problems. The two issues you are most likely to notice are infusion-related chills/fever (manageable with pre-meds) and low potassium/magnesium (managed with supplements). Permanent kidney damage and serious reactions are now uncommon, especially if a lipid formulation is used and labs are watched closely.

Bring this list of questions to your next visit, clarify which exact product you’ll receive, and be sure your neurologist knows about the plan so seizure medications and electrolytes can be adjusted if needed. Best wishes for a smooth, uneventful course and a quick resolution of the infection.

137.question: For a bit longer than a year, I've got random cramps in my sleep, I don't have any memories from that event afterwards and I also don't know what happens while it happens (seemingly like still being asleep). The only person that has observed the seizures/attacks is my girlfriend.Also I only get those cramps/seizures/attacks at night in my sleep and I know that I don't have photosensitive epilepsy.She furthermore described the attacks and mentioned that I seem to have trouble breathing and I seem to make weird noises.I was at a neurologist and he prescribed me Antelepsin at first and then Levetiracetam (up to now), which are both a medical substance that I have to take before going to bed. It does help, but it doesn't cure my state.I'm smoking tobacco on a daily basis, drink alcohol sometimes, smoking cannabis on weekends, and very rarely I take LSD in moderate dosages.As of yet I didn't get a real Diagnose, so I wanted to ask the reddit community, because why not giving it a shot right?I really hope someone can help me, mostly because I don't want to cause any more trouble and anxiety to my girlfriend.
137.answer:
I’m not in a position to give you a formal diagnosis, but I can outline the possibilities your neurologist is probably weighing, why the medicines you’ve been given were chosen, what else can be done diagnostically, and what day-to-day steps may help while you’re waiting for clearer answers.  Use this as background information only and keep working with your own doctor.

1. What the attacks sound like  
• Nocturnal generalized tonic-clonic seizures (the classic “grand-mal” type) – Loss of tone or stiffening, rhythmic jerks, breathing changes, grunting sounds, no memory afterward, and only happening during sleep all fit.  
• Sleep-related focal (often frontal-lobe) epilepsy – These can appear as brief, violent “cramps,” thrashing, or bizarre movements in sleep and are sometimes mistaken for parasomnias.  
• Parasomnias (night terrors, REM-behavior disorder, etc.) – These can also look dramatic, but usually the person can be aroused more easily, and full-body convulsions are less common.  
• Convulsive syncope from severe obstructive sleep-apnea – People can briefly convulse if they stop breathing for long enough; the “trouble breathing” your girlfriend sees makes this worth ruling out.

2. Why you were put on antiseizure drugs  
• “Antelepsin” is most often a trade name for carbamazepine. Levetiracetam (Keppra) is another first-line drug. Starting one, then switching, is typical if the first is only partly effective or causes side-effects.  
• Partial benefit but not complete control is common; ~30 % of people with epilepsy need adjustments, combination therapy, or a different drug class before they become seizure-free.

3. What tests usually come next  
• EEG with sleep deprivation or an overnight video-EEG. A short, routine EEG can miss purely nocturnal epilepsy; recording an entire night raises the diagnostic yield a lot.  
• Brain MRI (if not already done) looking for structural lesions.  
• If sleep apnea is suspected: polysomnography (formal sleep study).  
• Smartphone video: have your girlfriend film an event if she can do it safely. A clear recording is often as useful as a lab study in steering the work-up.

4. Read-through of your triggers/drug use  
Tobacco: not a major seizure trigger, but nicotine can speed up the liver enzymes that metabolize many antiseizure medicines, sometimes lowering drug levels.  
Alcohol: heavy use or even single-night binge drinking followed by the “post-drinking” sleep period is a well-known trigger. Withdrawal the next morning is an even bigger risk.  
Cannabis: data are mixed, but THC generally lowers the seizure threshold in susceptible people and can interfere with some meds’ metabolism.  
LSD and other psychedelics: documented to precipitate seizures in predisposed people; even “moderate” doses can do so unpredictably.  
Bottom line: Anything that disturbs sleep architecture, causes dehydration, rapid temperature swings, or interacts with hepatic enzymes can increase night-time seizures. Cutting back or eliminating these substances—especially while you’re still having events—often improves control.

5. Practical steps while seeking a firmer diagnosis  
• Take Levetiracetam exactly as prescribed, at the same times every day (missing night-time doses is a frequent cause of break-through attacks).  
• Consistent sleep schedule: same bedtime, same wake-time, enough total hours.  
• Avoid alcohol within 4–6 h of bedtime and consider abstaining completely until your seizures are controlled.  
• If you continue to use cannabis or psychedelics, let your neurologist know; they need to interpret drug levels and seizure frequency in that context.  
• Keep a seizure diary (date, approximate time, any triggers, length if known, how you felt afterward) and have your girlfriend add her observations.  
• Make the bedroom as safe as possible: move hard furniture away from the bed, don’t sleep on the top bunk, use a low pillow or none if you tend to end up face-down, and consider a seizure alarm or baby monitor so your girlfriend can respond quickly.  
• Medical ID bracelet or phone lock-screen information stating “Seizure disorder / Takes Levetiracetam.”

6. When to call the doctor or go to the ED  
• Any seizure lasting longer than ~5 minutes, or repeated seizures with no full awakening between them (status epilepticus).  
• A much more forceful or different-looking seizure than usual.  
• Serious injury, head strike, or suspicion of breathing not resuming promptly after a convulsion.

7. Questions to raise at your next neurology visit  
• Do I need an overnight video-EEG or inpatient monitoring?  
• Have I had an adequate trial at the current Keppra dose, or should the dose be pushed up / a second medicine added?  
• Do you suspect sleep-apnea; should I get a polysomnography?  
• Would a rescue medication (orally dissolving clonazepam tablet, intranasal midazolam, etc.) be appropriate for prolonged events?  
• Is it safe for me to continue driving / working at heights, etc.?

8. Why it matters to get control  
Night-time convulsive seizures can carry a higher risk of SUDEP (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy) when uncontrolled. Full seizure freedom—or at least a marked reduction—is the single best way to lower that risk, so aggressive follow-up is worth it.

Key take-away  
You most likely do have a form of sleep-related epilepsy; the basic treatment you’re on is appropriate, but you and your neurologist haven’t yet reached the “right drug and right dose” or ruled out other contributing sleep disorders. The next steps are better documentation (video-EEG, sleep study, seizure diary), possible medication adjustment, and minimizing lifestyle triggers (especially alcohol and psychedelics). Keep your neurologist in the loop and push for a clear plan—epilepsy can almost always be brought under much better control with systematic follow-up.

Good luck, and take care.

138.question: My boyfriend (82kg, about 176cm tall) has had panic attacks that look like seizures since he was 16. He is now 31. During those attacks, which are primarily triggered by his fear of needles and medicinal procedures, he loses consciousness. He describes it as "the light going further and further away until I'm in a black void and there is a hammering noise in my head". He also told me that sometimes he kicks around and trembles and shakes while he is out of consciousness. He was tested for epilepsy twice, has had several blood tests. His attacks only happen when he is in an anxious situation.He did take drugs like weed and speed as a teenager, he quit smoking in January this year. He has depression and anxiety officially diagnosed as well as panic disorder.A few weeks ago I witnessed such an attack for the first time ever. And I thought I was prepared. But suddenly his face turned purple. So I called an ambulance. He was brought to the hospital and they gave him medicine to calm him down ( I think it was opioids) so they could test his blood and stuff and it all came back normal, there is also still no sign for epilepsy. He is sleeping well, he is eating well, he is drinking well. Therapy and medicine have already been recommended to him many times. He's had CBT, but they never really did any confrontation therapy with him aside from drawing blood from him with a needle, which went well.
138.answer:
What you are describing sounds much more like “reflex (vasovagal) syncope with convulsive movements” than an epileptic seizure or an ordinary panic attack.

1. What is reflex / vasovagal syncope?  
   • A sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure produced by a reflex of the autonomic nervous system.  
   • Typical triggers are fear, pain, needles, seeing blood, medical procedures, standing for a long time, heat, emotional distress.  
   • Immediately before the loss of consciousness people often notice tunnel vision, dimming or “the light going away,” roaring or pounding in the ears, nausea, sweating – exactly what he describes.  
   • Because the brain is briefly starved of blood and oxygen, the body may show brief jerks or “convulsive” movements that can look like a seizure. This is called “convulsive syncope.”  
   • Colour changes can occur: first very pale, then sometimes a dusky / purplish colour if breathing is shallow or the airway is partly blocked while he is limp.

2. How is it different from epilepsy?  
   • Always has an obvious trigger (needle, medical procedure, intense anxiety) – epilepsy does not.  
   • Usually preceded by the typical fainting prodrome described above.  
   • Eyes are often closed in syncope; in epilepsy they are usually open.  
   • Body stiffening is brief or absent; movements tend to be brief, irregular myoclonic jerks rather than the prolonged tonic-clonic shaking of a generalized seizure.  
   • People recover very quickly (seconds to a couple of minutes) and have little or no post-event confusion.  
   • Normal EEGs and normal neurological examinations between events, as he has had.

3. Why does it happen only “when he’s anxious?”  
   He likely has a “blood-injury-injection” (BII) type phobia – a well-known phobia in which the body’s reflex actually produces fainting. So the faint IS the panic response in this particular phobia. Ordinary CBT that focuses on “thinking” about anxiety often helps the fear part, but without specific “applied tension” training or graduated exposure it seldom stops the fainting spells.

4. What to do during an episode  
   • Lay him flat on his back immediately and raise his legs (gravity helps blood return to the brain).  
   • Loosen tight clothing around neck / waist.  
   • Ensure the airway is open. Turning the head to the side if he is very limp prevents saliva from pooling at the back of the throat.  
   • Do NOT try to hold the limbs down; do NOT put anything in the mouth.  
   • Usually consciousness returns within 20–60 seconds once he is lying flat.  
   • If he is cyanotic (purple) or not breathing for more than ~10-15 sec, call emergency services as you did – rare, but better safe than sorry.  
   • After recovery keep him supine for several minutes, then sit, then stand with support; give cool water.

5. When does he need more medical work-up?  
   • If episodes start happening without clear triggers, while lying down, or during exertion;  
   • If they last more than 1–2 min before recovery;  
   • If there is chest pain, palpitations, family history of sudden cardiac death;  
   • Abnormal ECG, structural heart disease, anaemia, diabetes, etc.  
   A primary-care doctor or cardiologist can arrange ECG, echocardiogram, Holter monitor or a tilt-table test. Two negative EEGs plus the clear trigger history make epilepsy extremely unlikely, but a cardiovascular screen once is still good medical practice.

6. Long-term management

A. Behavioural  
   • “Applied tension” (AT) training – repeatedly tensing the large muscles of arms, legs, core for 10–15 sec then relaxing – raises blood pressure and prevents fainting. He practises several times a day, then uses it as soon as prodrome starts. AT is the gold-standard behavioural technique for BII phobia.  
   • Graduated exposure / systematic desensitization with a therapist who specialises in BII. This often starts with looking at drawings of needles, then photos, then videos, then being in a clinic, then having a sham needle nearby, then a real needle, all while using applied tension.  
   • Some find success with virtual-reality exposure programmes.

B. Medications  
   • SSRIs (e.g. sertraline, escitalopram) can reduce overall anxiety and the anticipatory dread.  
   • A low-dose benzodiazepine (e.g. 0.25 mg clonazepam) taken 30 min before a medical procedure can blunt the initial fear, though it does not remove the vasovagal reflex itself and must be used sparingly to avoid dependence.  
   • Beta-blockers are sometimes tried but usually not useful in pure vasovagal syncope triggered by BII.  
   Opioids were probably used in the emergency department only to sedate him temporarily so staff could take blood without re-triggering the episode.

C. Lifestyle / safety  
   • Good hydration and salt intake on days he expects a trigger. Dehydration lowers blood pressure and makes fainting easier.  
   • Sleep, regular exercise and avoidance of stimulants / alcohol binges all improve autonomic stability.  
   • When he must have blood drawn, he should be lying down ahead of time, stay down for a few minutes afterwards, and use applied tension continuously. Let staff know he faints. Most clinics are familiar with BII protocols.

7. Why CBT “didn’t work” so far  
   Many counsellors who say they do CBT never learned the specific protocol for BII phobia (which is quite different from CBT for social anxiety or generalized panic). A referral to someone who explicitly advertises experience in “blood-injury-injection phobia, applied tension, or syncope management” is worth pursuing. These programmes typically run for 6–10 weekly sessions and have success rates of 70-80 % in preventing fainting.

8. What you can do as a partner  
   • Learn the simple faint-response steps (lay flat, legs up, airway) so you feel confident and won’t panic yourself.  
   • Encourage (but don’t force) him to practise applied tension daily.  
   • Help him schedule a proper BII-phobia therapist or clinic.  
   • At appointments be his advocate: insist he be allowed to lie down, have time, and not be rushed.

Bottom line  
Everything you describe fits reflex vasovagal syncope with convulsive movements triggered by a blood-injury-injection phobia, not epilepsy. It is frightening to watch but rarely dangerous once you know how to manage the faint. A cardiovascular screen once, plus specialised behavioural treatment (applied tension with graduated exposure), is the most effective long-term solution.

139.question: A few days ago I noticed brain zaps when falling asleep (starts in brain and shocks the rest of my body, then spreads to my tongue and leaves it numb for a few seconds).I thought it was from my medication (Straterra) because I was bad about taking it daily for a couple of months but finally got into a routine (I have been taking Straterra for 5 years). My primary doctor told me this was unusual and shouldn’t be because of my medications so she told me to get an MRI on my brain.I have gotten an MRI on my brain when I was 14 and they found nothing unusual.I also have some neurological disorders, such as ADHD, OCD, Misophonia, and I also had a tic disorder in the past and have occasionally had mild non-epileptic seizures. I’ve never experienced this before.I’m wondering if anyone has any idea what this could be and if it sounds seriousSex: Female, age: 21, height: 5’3, weight: 109 lbs
139.answer:
I’m not able to examine you, review the MRI images or take a full history, so view the following as general educational information rather than a personal medical diagnosis.  Anything new or worrisome should be discussed again with your own clinician, and a visit with a neurologist is reasonable.  That said, the combination of “electric-shock” sensations in the head with a sudden full-body jolt just as you are drifting off is most often explained by one of three benign phenomena:

1. Sleep-onset (hypnic) jerks  
   • Very common (up to 70 % of people experience them at some point).  
   • Typically occur in the seconds or minutes after you start to fall asleep.  
   • Felt as a single “zap” or “falling” sensation that can involve the whole body or only part of it.  
   • Often brought on or worsened by sleep deprivation, caffeine, stimulant medications, anxiety or irregular sleep schedules—all things that can also be present in someone treated for ADHD.

2. “Brain zaps” related to medications that manipulate serotonin/norepinephrine  
   • Atomoxetine (Strattera) is a selective norepinephrine re-uptake inhibitor and, to a lesser degree, affects serotonin. Intermittent dosing, abrupt stopping/starting, or dose changes can trigger transient head-shock sensations, tingling, or buzzing that people often describe as “brain zaps.”  
   • They usually resolve once the blood level of the drug stabilizes (typically days to a few weeks).  
   • SSRI/SNRI withdrawal is the classic scenario, but the same chemistry applies to atomoxetine.

3. Exploding Head Syndrome (EHS)  
   • A parasomnia in which a person hears or feels a loud bang, zap, or flash inside the head at sleep onset or on awakening.  
   • It can be startling but is harmless; no seizure activity or structural brain problem is present on EEG/MRI.  
   • Stress, fatigue, and certain medications can make it more frequent.

Features that point toward a benign sleep-related process  
• Only happens at the moment you fall asleep.  
• Lasts seconds; you are fully alert right after.  
• No loss of consciousness, confusion, tongue-biting, urinary incontinence, or prolonged weakness.  
• Completely normal neurologic exam when you are awake (aside from pre-existing tics/OCD).  

Features that would make neurologists look harder  
• Events occurring while fully awake or several times through the night.  
• Associated loss of awareness or confused speech afterward (possible focal seizures).  
• A stereotyped electric shock travelling down the spine when you bend your neck forward (possible Lhermitte sign in multiple sclerosis or cervical cord disease).  
• Persistent numbness or weakness that lasts minutes to hours.

Why your doctor ordered an MRI  
Although your description sounds most compatible with a benign sleep-related jerk or medication-related “zap,” MRI is the standard first look to rule out structural brain causes (tumor, demyelination, vascular malformation), especially when someone reports new neurologic symptoms.  A normal MRI is reassuring but doesn’t capture everything (for example, it doesn’t diagnose seizures—that’s done with EEG).

What you can do while waiting for the MRI / neurology visit  
1. Keep a log: time you go to bed, whether you took atomoxetine that day and at what hour, caffeine/alcohol use, stress level, number and severity of zaps/jerks. Patterns often become obvious.  
2. Aim for strict sleep hygiene: same bedtime/wake time every day, dark/cool/quiet room, no screens 30 min before bed.  
3. Avoid caffeine and other stimulants after mid-afternoon.  
4. Take atomoxetine exactly as prescribed every day at the same hour.  If doses were missed recently, do not double up—resume the usual daily dose unless your prescriber says otherwise.  
5. Manage anxiety: deep-breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, mindfulness apps, or short cognitive-behavioral exercises before bed.  
6. Limit recreational drugs, nicotine and heavy exercise right before sleep.  
7. Note any additional neurologic symptoms (daytime spells, focal numbness/weakness, vision changes).  If any appear, call your doctor promptly.

Red-flag reasons to seek same-day medical attention  
• A prolonged seizure, or repeated jerks that prevent you from speaking or responding.  
• New weakness, loss of balance, slurred speech or double vision lasting more than a few minutes.  
• Severe, worst-ever headache.  
• Unable to swallow or breathe normally after an episode.  

Bottom line  
The brief “shock-then-numb-tongue” you feel at sleep onset most likely falls under hypnic jerks/brain zaps, which are benign and often triggered or worsened by inconsistent use of atomoxetine, stress or poor sleep.  Your doctor is rightly being cautious by ordering an MRI; if this and a neurologic exam are normal, reassurance plus good sleep hygiene and regular dosing of your medication usually make the problem fade over the next few weeks.  If anything changes in character or frequency, or you develop new neurologic deficits, follow up promptly with your physician or a neurologist.

140.question: Age 23 Sex M Hypertension, Hypothyroid, pre-diabetes, ADHD, Anxiety Disorder and panic attacksOkay so my MRI's report is normal, here:https://imgur.com/a/OiCEZ3N I get these body jerks so the doctor was thinking it's Myoclonic Epilepsy or Motor Tics. But the Motor Tics medicine isn't doing any good to me so the doc was thinking about Myoclonic Epilepsy. But my MRI report is fine? Do i still need to worry? I have ADHD, Panic attacks and Anxiety Disorder problems and even normal MRI is killing me inside why am i having those jerks!?
140.answer:
Key points up-front  
• A normal brain MRI does NOT rule-out epileptic disorders or other causes of myoclonus.  
• Myoclonic jerks, tics, medication-related movements, anxiety-related startle, benign sleep jerks and several metabolic problems can all look similar.  
• The study that usually settles whether the jerks are epileptic is an EEG, ideally a prolonged or video-EEG.  
• The fact that the MRI is normal is reassuring – it means there is no tumour, stroke, malformation, MS plaque, etc. – but it does not by itself tell us why you jerk.  
• Continue working with your neurologist; if you have not yet had an EEG (or if it was a routine 20-minute EEG only), ask about a longer video-EEG and about medication review.  

1. What the normal MRI means  
MRI is a structural picture. Many seizure syndromes (especially the idiopathic generalized epilepsies that include juvenile myoclonic epilepsy) show a completely normal MRI because the brain structure is intact; the problem is electrical. Therefore a normal scan neither proves nor disproves epilepsy, it simply shows there is no scar, tumour, bleed, etc.

2. How myoclonic epilepsy is diagnosed  
• History – very brief, shock-like jerks, often in both arms, worse in the morning or when sleep-deprived, sometimes aggravated by alcohol, flashing lights or stress.  
• EEG – typical generalized 3–6 Hz spike-wave or poly-spike-wave discharges that correlate with a jerk on the video. A routine 20-minute EEG can miss this; a sleep-deprived EEG or 24-hour video-EEG increases the pick-up rate.  
• Response to anti-seizure medicines such as levetiracetam, valproate, lamotrigine or clonazepam.

3. How motor tics differ  
• Usually preceded by an inner urge or “premonitory sensation.”  
• Person can suppress them for seconds to minutes but feels mounting tension.  
• Often change over weeks, migrate to different muscle groups, and come in bouts.  
• EEG is normal.  
Medication tried for tics (often antipsychotics like risperidone or tetrabenazine) would not help epileptic myoclonus.

4. Other common mimics  
• Benign sleep (hypnic) jerks – single jolts as you are falling asleep.  
• Anxiety / panic induced startle or “body surges.”  
• Medication side-effects or withdrawal – stimulants for ADHD, SSRIs/SNRIs, bupropion, tramadol, opioids, certain antibiotics (quinolones) can all produce myoclonus.  
• Metabolic – hypothyroidism (if under-treated), kidney or liver dysfunction, electrolyte imbalance, B-12 deficiency.  
• Caffeine or energy-drink over-use; sleep deprivation.  
These possibilities can be screened with blood tests, medication review and sleep / caffeine diary.

5. Action plan to clarify the diagnosis  
a. Make sure you have (or schedule) a video-EEG. Bring a companion or video clips of the jerks if possible; seeing the movement helps the neurophysiologist correlate clinical and electrical events.  
b. Thorough medication review with both your neurologist and the doctor treating your ADHD/anxiety. Ask specifically: Could any of my current medicines or supplements provoke jerks?  
c. Check thyroid panel (TSH, free T4), basic metabolic panel, liver/kidney function, B-12, fasting glucose/HbA1c (already pre-diabetic), and, if clinically suggested, serum copper/ceruloplasmin.  
d. Sleep hygiene: 7-9 h nightly, limit caffeine after noon, avoid flashing screens in the dark. Lack of sleep worsens both tics and epileptic myoclonus.  
e. Stress/anxiety management: CBT, mindfulness, regular aerobic exercise. Lowering baseline anxiety often decreases jerk frequency even when they are neurological.  

6. Should you “worry”?  
Be concerned enough to pursue proper evaluation, but not panicked. Most causes of myoclonus/tics are manageable once properly identified, and a normal MRI rules out many dangerous structural problems. Untreated generalized epilepsies respond well to modern anti-seizure medications, and non-epileptic tics or anxiety-related jerks improve with the right behavioural and/or pharmacologic therapy.

7. When to seek urgent care  
• Jerks that progress to sustained shaking with loss of awareness.  
• Repetitive jerks lasting >5 min without recovery.  
• New focal weakness, speech difficulty, or vision loss.  
• Head injury or severe tongue biting during an episode.

Bottom line  
Your normal MRI is good news but does not answer the whole question. Ask your neurologist about a prolonged video-EEG, review all medications and lab work, and continue anxiety management. With systematic evaluation most patients arrive at a clear diagnosis and effective treatment.

141.question: The other day I didn't use the dosage cup and just swallowed some Pepto-Bismol Max. I guess it was maybe a mouthful? I don't know how much that is but it felt like a "large swallow". Maybe as much as the max daily dosage of 120mL. That was all I had for at least 24 hours in either direction.I don't think I feel any symptoms different than what I usually feel. I read that toxicity can cause confusion and ringing in the ears. But I always seem to have ringing in the ears from time to time, and I have epilepsy so I'm always a little tired and confused (I take carbamazapine 300mg 2x).How concerned should I be? 28 year old white male. About 160lbs and 5'6
141.answer:
Short answer  
What you probably swallowed is no more than the manufacturer-recommended “maximum daily dose.”  Taken once, in an otherwise healthy adult of your size, that amount is very unlikely to cause salicylate (aspirin) toxicity.  If you are not experiencing new, worsening, or progressive symptoms (persistent ringing that gets louder, rapid breathing, dizziness, vomiting, marked confusion, severe headache, etc.) there is very little reason for concern and no specific treatment is needed.

Why that is so  
1. What’s in the bottle?  
   Pepto-Bismol Max Strength = bismuth subsalicylate 525 mg per 15 mL.

2. How much did you probably get?  
   • One “mouthful/large swallow” usually holds 20–40 mL.  
   • Even if it was a very large swallow—say 120 mL—that equals 8 × 15 mL doses.  
   • 8 doses × 525 mg = 4 200 mg of salicylate.

3. Toxicity thresholds (single ingestion)  
   • Mild salicylate effects: ≈ 150 mg/kg.  
   • Moderate: ≈ 300 mg/kg.  
   • Severe / potentially lethal: > 500 mg/kg.  
   You weigh ~73 kg.  
   • Mild-effect threshold for you ≈ 11 000 mg.  
   • Your worst-case dose = 4 200 mg, only ~ 60 mg/kg, well below levels that normally cause clinically significant toxicity.

4. What might you notice at that dose?  
   • Temporarily darker (almost black) stools or tongue – harmless.  
   • Maybe mild, short-lived tinnitus if you are sensitive.  
   • Most people feel nothing at all.

5. Red-flag symptoms that WOULD merit a call to Poison Control (1-800-222-1222 in the U.S.) or urgent medical evaluation:  
   • Persistent, worsening, or high-pitched ringing in the ears.  
   • Rapid breathing, shortness of breath.  
   • Nausea/vomiting, especially if it looks bloody.  
   • Severe abdominal pain.  
   • Marked dizziness, agitation, confusion, or seizures beyond your usual baseline.  
   • Unusual bruising or bleeding.  
   • New rash, swelling, or itching (possible allergy).

Drug-interaction note  
Your carbamazepine does not significantly interact with a single normal-to-high dose of bismuth subsalicylate.  The combination is generally considered safe.

Bottom line  
A one-time “big gulp” of Pepto-Bismol Max is still within the labeled maximum for a 24-hour period.  If you feel the same as usual, you can simply return to the directed dosing schedule.  Use the measuring cup next time so you do not exceed the daily limit, and call your clinician or Poison Control if any of the warning symptoms above develop.

(This information is for general education and is not a substitute for personalized medical advice.  If you are ever in doubt, phone your local Poison Control Center or seek medical attention.)

142.question: My girlfriend and I are at the end of our rope. Age: 24, height: 171 cm, weight: 50 kg She was vaccinated with Biontech for the first time in August. She passed out in the waiting room after 15 minutes, so she fainted. 3 weeks later it happened again. Ambulance was called, but in the hospital no cause could be found.Not thinking much of it at the time, she had a second vaccination in September, again Biontech. Since then - and I am not exaggerating here - she keels over several times a day, uncontrolled and absolutely randomized, and is unconscious between 10 and 30 minutes.During her unconsciousness she hyperventilates, unconsciously of course. In addition, she convulses at times, but very tentatively. For example, within 15 minutes she convulses 3 times for about 3 seconds at a time. The hyperventilating goes on for several minutes. If I keep up the same breathing speed during this, I have the feeling of suffocating.She was already 2 times over more than a week in the hospital, where the heart and the brain were examined (MRI, CT,...). Both times nothing was found. I suppose that an examination during an attack would be useful, but somehow the doctors don't seem to think so.  We have been to neurologists and family doctors besides the hospital. Even a "systematic" family doctor who prescribed some homeopathic thing.No remedy let alone diagnosis has been found yet, neither epilepsy nor narcolepsy. Nothing.Now for other aspects: - She has a headache almost continuously, but before the attacks it gets stronger - Her vision on both eyes gets worse before the attacks - She feels the left side of her body less, including her arms and legs before the attacks. - She gets dizzy before attacksShe can minimally fight it, but not for long. It can happen while lying down or standing up. But especially when she is physically exerting herself. If she lies down one evening, it is less likely to happen. If she fights it during the day, the attacks are longer and more severe in the evening.Sometimes it is right after eating or drinking - she also can no longer drink and eat large amounts at the same time. As a result, she consumes very few calories and continues to lose weight - she is already extremely thin and really should not lose any more weight.She can hardly concentrate on her studies. She can't go out by herself anymore because she could fall over at any time. The whole everyday life is insanely restricted. In principle, the disease currently dominates everything.She reacts extremely badly to medication. She can't take headache pills because they make her fall over. Even things prescribed by doctors make her faint right away. I bought carbohydrate powder - she passes out from that too.She has no mental illnesses. She is not depressed, has no anxiety, and has no mental issues with her weight or anything like that. I really can't imagine that this is psychosomatic based - especially because the connection with vaccination is so clear.  We are both absolutely not anti-vaccination and don't believe that there was anything weird in it. She even wanted to get boostered, but we are too afraid that it would get worse.We had hoped that the attacks would lessen as the vaccine effect wore off. But it seems more likely to get even worse over time.This is psychologically very stressful and also makes me afraid to go out with her because I never know in which situation I have to intervene right away. Partly she has already hit the ground while standing unchecked.We really don't know what to do. Is there anyone with experience reports on this or any kind of clue what else we could do? Any doctor, any diagnosis, any kind of remedy?She and I are both 100% aware that it can't go on like this in the long run. And she would also commit suicide at some point if it doesn't get better. And I can absolutely understand that. A normal life is impossible like that.tldr: Friend keeps keeling over uncontrolled and randomized since vaccination. After 6 months still no doctor knows why and we suffer extremely. Especially for her a normal life is no longer possible
142.answer:
I can’t examine or test your girlfriend, so I can’t tell you what the diagnosis is, but I can outline the problems that still have to be ruled in / out, the kinds of tests that usually answer them, and the specialists/centres that do that work every day. Take this list to the next physician; if the local hospital cannot do the studies, ask for a referral to a tertiary-care (university) “syncope / autonomic / epilepsy” unit.  

1. Separate the possibilities  
   a. Cardiac syncope (arrhythmias, long-QT, structural heart disease, autonomic failure)  
   b. Neurovascular syncope (vasovagal, POTS, orthostatic hypotension, autonomic neuropathy, basilar-type migraine)  
   c. Epileptic seizures (focal or generalized)  
   d. Psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (PNES) / functional neurological disorder  
   e. Metabolic/toxic causes (hypoglycaemia, adrenal insufficiency, electrolytes, anaemia, thyroid, etc.)  
   f. Very rare post-vaccination immune phenomena (autoimmune autonomic ganglionopathy, small-fiber neuropathy, cerebral venous thrombosis, etc.)  

2. Tests that actually distinguish those causes  
   •  Prolonged ambulatory ECG (Holter 48 h, or an event recorder/implantable loop recorder if events are less frequent).  
   •  Tilt-table test with beat-to-beat blood-pressure and ECG recording. This is the single best test for vasovagal syncope and POTS.  
   •  24–72 h VIDEO-EEG monitoring in an epilepsy monitoring unit. The aim is to capture one of her typical attacks on camera while the EEG is running. Normal brain MRI and CT do not rule out epilepsy; only a recorded EEG during the spell does.  
   •  Orthostatic vital-signs chart (supine vs standing HR/BP repeatedly at home or clinic).  
   •  Basic and extended blood work: CBC, ESR/CRP, fasting and post-prandial glucose, electrolytes, renal/liver function, thyroid panel, cortisol, ferritin, B-12/folate, pregnancy test, serum tryptase if allergic component suspected.  
   •  If autoimmune dysautonomia suspected: serum ganglionic ACh-receptor, N-type Ca-channel, adrenergic & muscarinic receptor antibodies, and small-fiber skin biopsy. These are usually done only after the commoner causes above are excluded.  

3. Why her description fits some conditions better than others  
   •  Hyperventilation, light-headedness, blurred vision, left-sided numbness, precipitation by upright posture/exertion/after meals, and improvement when lying down are classic for neurally-mediated syncope and for POTS. Many patients with chronic POTS faint several times a day and lose weight because eating larger meals worsens the pooling of blood in the gut (“post-prandial hypotension”).  
   •  Convulsive movements lasting only 2–3 s in a person who is otherwise flaccid and pale are usually anoxic myoclonic jerks due to transient loss of cerebral perfusion—not epileptic seizures. True epileptic convulsions are typically rhythmic, longer, and followed by minutes of deep sleep (post-ictal).  
   •  The fact that it first happened immediately after vaccination does not prove causation, but vaccines (and, more often, viral infections) can trigger or unmask dysautonomia or functional neurological disorders. It is NOT a reason to avoid further medical care or vaccinations; it is a reason to get a precise diagnosis first.  

4. What helps meanwhile (if orthostatic intolerance/POTS proves to be the culprit)  
   •  Aggressive fluid (2.5–3 L/day) and salt (8–10 g/day) intake, if kidneys and BP permit.  
   •  Compression stockings or full abdominal binder.  
   •  Gradual recumbent exercise programme (rower, recumbent bike) to re-condition the autonomic nervous system.  
   •  Pharmacologic options under a physician’s supervision: fludrocortisone, midodrine, low-dose propranolol, pyridostigmine, or ivabradine. Every patient is different; some need none, some need several.  
   •  Small, frequent, low-carbohydrate meals to avoid post-prandial pooling.  
   •  If video-EEG shows psychogenic seizures, cognitive-behavioural therapy in a centre that specialises in functional neurological disorders dramatically reduces events in >50 % of patients.  

5. Danger signs that require ED attendance every time  
   •  Syncope associated with chest pain, sustained racing heart, or occurring while lying flat.  
   •  Prolonged loss of consciousness (>5 min) or cyanosis.  
   •  Any injury (head strike, fractures) during the fall.  
   •  Blood glucose <3 mmol/L (54 mg/dL) or >15 mmol/L (270 mg/dL).  

6. Practical tips for the next appointment  
   •  Keep a diary: time of day, posture, activity, food intake, prodrome, duration, colour (pale? blue?), movements, recovery time, HR/BP if you can get them, and a smartphone video of an episode. Doctors take video evidence very seriously.  
   •  Ask explicitly for “tilt-table testing” and “video-EEG monitoring”; if the local hospital declines, request referral to the nearest university hospital with an “autonomic disorders” or “comprehensive epilepsy” programme.  
   •  Mention the weight loss, inability to eat, and suicidal thoughts. That combination calls for urgent multidisciplinary care (neurology, cardiology, autonomic clinic, clinical psychology, nutrition).  

7. Mental-health support is not optional  
   Chronic unexplained blackouts are among the top precipitants of depression. Suicidal thoughts mean she needs a mental-health professional on the team now, in parallel with the medical work-up. Asking for that help will make physicians MORE, not less, willing to pursue the physical diagnosis, because it shows you are addressing every component.  

Bottom line  
The work-up so far has ruled out gross brain and heart structure problems, but that is only the first step. The next step is to CAPTURE an event with continuous EEG and beat-to-beat BP/ECG—or, at minimum, a tilt-table test—so that the pattern of cerebral blood flow, heart rhythm, and brain electrical activity during a faint can be seen. That usually differentiates vasovagal/POTS, epileptic seizures, and psychogenic events. Almost every tertiary-care hospital has such a unit; keep knocking until one of them books her.  

If you feel the current team is brushing you off, ask directly, “Where is the nearest autonomic disorders clinic or epilepsy monitoring unit? Please refer us.” Persistence pays off, and a correct diagnosis is the first step toward getting her life back.

143.question: I’m a 23 year old female. I have recently been getting very dizzy, my body gets hot and seeing stars until my vision disappears completely and I can’t see at all and it doesn’t go away until I lay down or sit. I have never had a problem like this ever but it’s starting to interfere with my life because I’m always having to sit. I’m 5”3 and I weigh around a 100 pounds. My weight does fluctuate a lot (+ or - 5 pounds every week) I try to eat healthy but I also sometimes can’t get myself to eat because I feel anxiety and my heart starts beating weird. I also have epilepsy and I am on Keppra and have been on it for almost 3 years so I don’t think that’s the problem but I try to take it on time, I take 500mg in the morning and 500mg at night. This problem has started only around a month ago but it happens almost every other day. I don’t know What is going on , should I be concerned?Edit: I do want to add that I do eat a lot of salt in my diet and I have been like this for long time. I add a lot of salt on my food, I eat a lot of olives and a lot of pickles, sometimes I will individually season spoonfuls or food before putting them in my mouth because it’s what tastes good to me (if that is of any significance)And I do drink alcohol about 3 times a week
143.answer:
What you are describing sounds like “pre-syncope” – a spell in which blood flow to the brain suddenly falls so you begin to see spots, feel hot, dizzy or light-headed, and may pass out unless you lie or sit down.  There are many possible reasons for this, and several of them can be serious.  Because the spells are now frequent and are interfering with daily life, you should be checked by a physician as soon as you can get in (urgent-care or ED if an appointment is not available promptly, or immediately if you actually lose consciousness, injure yourself, have chest pain, shortness of breath, or a seizure).

WHY IT NEEDS TO BE EVALUATED  
1. Orthostatic (postural) hypotension – blood pressure drops when you stand up.  Causes include dehydration, low overall blood volume from inadequate food/fluid intake, rapid weight swings, alcohol use, certain medications, or endocrine problems such as adrenal insufficiency (salt craving is a classic clue).  
2. Vasovagal/neurally mediated syncope – a reflex causing sudden slowing of the heart and widening of blood vessels.  
3. POTS (postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome) – often seen in young women with similar symptoms.  
4. Cardiac rhythm problems – fast or very slow heartbeats can cause abrupt dizziness/vision loss.  
5. Anemia or low blood sugar – common in people who are underweight or eating poorly.  
6. Electrolyte disturbances – especially if intake is erratic or alcohol use is significant.  
7. Endocrine/metabolic conditions – thyroid disease, adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s), pregnancy, etc.  
8. Medication effects – Keppra usually does not cause this after years of use, but doses, timing, other drugs, and alcohol together can matter.

WHAT THE DOCTOR WILL PROBABLY DO  
• Full history (exact circumstances of each spell, triggers, diet, alcohol, fluids, medications, menstrual history, seizure control).  
• Physical exam with orthostatic vital signs (BP/HR lying, sitting, standing).  
• ECG and possibly a Holter/event monitor.  
• Basic labs: CBC (anemia), BMP/electrolytes, glucose, thyroid tests, ferritin/iron, morning cortisol (for adrenal function), possibly pregnancy test.  
• If warranted: tilt-table testing, echocardiogram, or referral to cardiology/neurology.

SAFETY MEASURES UNTIL YOU ARE SEEN  
• Do not drive, swim alone, climb, or operate machinery until spells are explained.  
• Stand up slowly; wiggle feet/calves before rising.  If you feel an episode coming, sit or lie down immediately and elevate legs if possible.  
• Stay well hydrated; alcohol dehydrates and drops blood pressure, so cut back or stop for now.  
• Eat small, regular meals with a mix of protein and complex carbohydrates to avoid hypoglycemia.  
• If you are often dehydrated, an oral rehydration solution (water + small amounts of salt and sugar) may help, but you are already taking in large amounts of salt, so do this only after guidance from your doctor.  
• Keep a diary: time of day, what you were doing, food/fluid intake, medication timing, heart rate if you can check it, and how long recovery took.  This makes the office visit much more productive.

RED-FLAG SYMPTOMS THAT REQUIRE EMERGENCY CARE  
• Actual loss of consciousness, especially if you cannot be woken quickly.  
• Chest pain, palpitations that don’t stop, severe shortness of breath.  
• New seizure activity or prolonged post-ictal state.  
• Severe, persistent vomiting, inability to keep fluids down, or signs of dehydration (very dark urine, no urine for >8 h).  
• Any injury sustained during a spell.

BOTTOM LINE  
Yes, you should be concerned enough to get prompt medical evaluation.  The problem is very unlikely to be “just anxiety,” and while it may turn out to be a relatively benign orthostatic problem that can be managed with lifestyle changes, you first need to be sure there is no underlying cardiac, neurologic, hematologic, or endocrine disorder.
