144.question: 25f 110ish lbs Everyday smoker Cannabis use Non drinker 200mg lamotrigine 2x daily 400mg zonsimide 2x daily Refractory epilepsy of unknown origin(possibly localized but won't know until I go in for my EMU)Hello so as you can see I have refractory epilepsy and my specialist and I are talking about me begining the steps towards a surgical approach as I'm still having breakthrough seizures. I have modified my doet and lifestyle in the hopes this would stop my seizures, but I'm still having breakthrough seizures about every other month or so. I was wondering if anyone out there has heard of other options I could try besides jumping to laser surgery or the VNS?Several people have mentioned chiropractic treatment and or acupuncture to me and it honestly sounds like a crock, but maybe they know something I don't???Please I'm open to suggestions
144.answer:
I’m glad you’re working closely with an epilepsy‐specialist and getting a full presurgical evaluation; that really is the right next step when you still have breakthrough seizures on two appropriate antiseizure medicines (ASM) at tolerated doses.  
Below is a broad, evidence-based “check-list” of things people with drug-resistant focal epilepsy usually run through before (or in parallel with) decisions about resection, laser ablation, VNS, RNS, DBS, etc.  Use it as a framework for discussion with your epileptologist.  It is not personal medical advice.

1. Make sure the basics are truly optimized  
   • Confirm the seizures are epileptic (nonepileptic spells can mimic epilepsy).  
   • Verify you’re on maximal tolerated doses/levels of each ASM and that the combination is rational (e.g., lamotrigine pairs well with levetiracetam or valproate, but lamotrigine + zonisamide is sometimes metabolically redundant).  
     – 400 mg/day lamotrigine is in the upper half of the usual dose range for a 50-kg adult, but serum levels vary widely—checking one can tell whether there is room to go up.  
     – 800 mg/day zonisamide is the top of the usual adult range; if you still seize on that, your doctor will often swap rather than continue to push.  
   • Adherence: take every dose, same clock times, with food/water if the prescriber recommends; use phone alarms or blister packs.  
   • Drug interactions: daily cannabis can induce or inhibit liver enzymes inconsistently and can lower lamotrigine levels in some people; get levels checked if you keep using.  
   • Rescue plan: intranasal midazolam or diazepam when a seizure clusters—prevents ER visits and status epilepticus.

2. Try at least one more reasonably chosen medication or combination  
   Roughly one-third of patients who have failed two agents will still get worthwhile control by adding or swapping another drug.  Modern options you haven’t yet tried include: brivaracetam, cenobamate (high responder rate), clobazam, lacosamide, perampanel, felbamate (last-line), etc.  Choice depends on seizure type, comorbidities, adverse-effect profile, insurance, and enzyme interactions.  Your weight makes side-effect monitoring (somnolence, mood, kidney stones with zonisamide, etc.) crucial.

3. Metabolic / dietary therapies  
   • Classical ketogenic diet (4:1 fat-to-carb/protein) – best evidence in kids but still used in adults; requires dietitian, labs, supplements.  
   • Modified Atkins (≈20 g net carbs/day) – easier to follow; ~30–40 % of adults get ≥50 % seizure reduction; median time to benefit 3–6 months.  
   • Low-glycemic-index treatment – less restrictive, focuses on low-GI carbs.  
   • **Important**: must be physician-monitored when you take zonisamide (risk of acidosis, kidney stones) and if you are already low BMI.

4. Neurostimulation (implantable but not resective)  
   • VNS (vagus-nerve stimulation) – you already mentioned; 50–60 % of patients reach ≥50 % reduction over 1–3 yrs.  Outpatient surgery, minimal imaging requirements; helpful if multifocal or unknown focus.  
   • RNS (responsive neurostimulation) – requires localization of ≤2 seizure foci; can record and stimulate in real time; ~70 % median seizure reduction at 9 yrs; battery replacement q9-12 yrs.  
   • DBS (deep-brain stimulation of anterior thalamus) – FDA-approved for adults with focal drug-resistant epilepsy; 69 % median reduction at 5 yrs.  

5. Evidence-based complementary / “alternative” options  
   • Acupuncture – Systematic reviews show no clear, reproducible benefit beyond placebo; generally regarded as safe if needles are sterile, but it is NOT a substitute for ASMs or surgical therapy.  If you enjoy it for relaxation and are willing to pay out of pocket, it probably won’t hurt—just don’t expect seizure control.  
   • Chiropractic cervical manipulation – No plausible mechanism and no data showing seizure reduction; rare but serious risk of vertebral-artery dissection → stroke.  Not recommended.  
   • Mindfulness-based stress reduction, CBT for stress or anxiety, yoga, biofeedback – useful for quality of life and possibly for seizure threshold through sleep and stress regulation; evidence moderate but supportive as adjuncts.  
   • Cannabidiol (Epidiolex) – Proven for Dravet, LGS, TSC; many centers give off-label for focal epilepsy.  Typical adult dose 10–20 mg/kg/day (about 500–1,000 mg for you) of purified CBD, not smoked cannabis; needs LFT and ASM level monitoring (raises clobazam and valproate levels, lowers lamotrigine in some).  Smoked/vaped THC-rich cannabis can sometimes worsen seizures and clouds EEG interpretation.

6. Ongoing medical “housekeeping”  
   • Sleep: 7–9 h nightly, no all-nighters.  
   • Female hormones: some women have catamenial epilepsy; keeping a seizure-period calendar with menstrual cycle helps determine if cyclic progesterone or birth-control adjustment is worthwhile.  
   • Vitamin / metabolic screens: sodium, calcium, magnesium, glucose, liver/kidney function, B-12, folate; bone density (lamotrigine is bone-neutral, zonisamide mildly demineralizing).  
   • Mood screening: depression and anxiety are common and themselves lower seizure threshold.

7. Experimental / investigational therapies (usually via clinical trials)  
   • Transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) and transcranial direct-current stimulation (tDCS) – early data; effects modest and transient; still research-only.  
   • Gene or cell therapies for specific monogenic epilepsies (e.g., SCN1A) – highly experimental.  
   • Focused ultrasound ablation – in development.

8. The presurgical evaluation you’re about to undergo  
   Video-EEG monitoring, 3 T MRI with epilepsy protocol, PET/SPECT, neuropsychological testing, possibly MEG.  If seizures localize cleanly to eloquent-sparing cortex, traditional resection or LITT offers the highest chance of seizure freedom (40–80 %, site-dependent).  Going through the EMU doesn’t commit you to surgery; it just gives you and your team the data to make an informed choice.

9. Safety pearls while you’re still seizing  
   • Back-sleep to reduce SUDEP risk; consider an alert device if you have nocturnal generalized convulsions.  
   • Shower instead of bath; cook on back burners; avoid heights and open water alone.  
   • Don’t drive until state law seizure-free interval is met (often 6–12 months).

Bottom line  
After failing two appropriate ASMs you are already in the “drug-resistant” category, so it’s entirely appropriate that your team is discussing surgical and neurostimulation options.  Before (or alongside) those, it is still worth:

1. Double-checking medication blood levels and considering a newer agent or combination.  
2. Trying a diet therapy under supervision if feasible.  
3. Looking at neurostimulation (VNS, RNS, DBS) as “in-between” steps—not necessarily an either/or with laser ablation.

Chiropractic manipulation has no supporting evidence and real risks; acupuncture has weak evidence but is generally harmless as a relaxation tool.  Keep your epileptologist in the loop about anything you add, especially substances that can interact with lamotrigine or zonisamide.

Take this outline to your next appointment and work through each item together—your care really needs to stay individualized.  Wishing you the best as you move through the EMU and decide on the safest, most effective plan for long-term seizure control.

145.question: I've been receiving electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) in two session, I stopped the first time due to cognitive side effects. However I started it again and I'm perplexed. I've always had intense headaches post ECT and during the first session I had intense deja vu experiences 2-10 times per day, this after about 1,5 months lowered to 3 times per week but up to 10 times a day. With this I developed difficulties placing people I've recently met, when I had gotten to know a face something in me just told me that I had known them since long. This time around, everyone I meet I recognise. Yesterday I was hours away from my hometown, and somehow I only met people I knew...but no one said hello...Anyone know information about this occurrence and whether it's a neurological concern or just a temporary side effect? My ECT-nurse had never heard of it before.Info: Male, 24 y/o, Caucasian, mucho depressed, no medications only ECT.
145.answer:
What you are describing –  

• brief, striking attacks of déjà vu (a powerful feeling that a present situation has already been experienced) and  
• a pronounced, sometimes almost comic, sense that every face you see is “familiar” even though you realise intellectually that you have never met the person –  

belongs to a group of phenomena neurologists and neuropsychologists call paramnesias (literally “distorted memories”).  They are well-recognised, although not very common, side-effects of electro-convulsive therapy.

Why can ECT do this?  
1. What ECT actually does is produce a short, generalised seizure. During the seizure a burst of electrical activity sweeps through the temporal lobes, hippocampi and parahippocampal cortex – the parts of the brain that tag events as “new” or “familiar” and store autobiographical memory.  
2. Immediately after a seizure those circuits are in a transiently excited / fatigued state.  For many patients the result is the expected anterograde and retrograde amnesia (trouble forming new memories and gaps in older ones).  
3. A smaller proportion experience the opposite error signal: everything is flagged as “already stored”, so faces, places or conversations feel uncannily familiar.

Relevant literature (if you want to show your team)  
• O’Connor & Moulin.  “Recognition without identification after electroconvulsive therapy.” Cognitive Neuropsychiatry 2006.  
• Roques-Carmes et al.  “Déjà vu after ECT: a transient paramnesic syndrome.” Journal of ECT 2014.  
• Conway et al.  “False familiarity and temporal lobe dysfunction following ECT.” Neuropsychologia 2001.  

Other points that fit your story  
• Headache after ECT is common (up to 45 % in large series).  
• Déjà-vu–style paramnesias usually begin within the first 2–3 weeks of a course, peak around session 6-10 and fade over several weeks after the last treatment.  
• They are more often reported with bilateral than right-unilateral placement and where the stimulus energy is high for the individual’s seizure threshold.

When can it be more than a benign, self-limiting side-effect?  
The same symptom cluster (déjà vu + headache) can also appear as:  
• auras of temporal-lobe epilepsy,  
• migraine aura,  
• medication toxicity (e.g. bupropion), or  
• in very rare cases a structural lesion of the right temporal lobe.  

Red-flag features that would justify a formal neurological review / EEG:  
• Episodes lasting more than a minute or progressing to frank loss of awareness.  
• Motor manifestations (chewing, lip-smacking, automatisms).  
• Persistent confusion lasting hours.  
• Worsening, unilateral or thunderclap headaches.  
• Focal neurological signs, visual field defects, speech arrest, etc.  

What you can discuss with your ECT psychiatrist / anaesthetist now  
1. Electrode position – switching from bilateral to right unilateral or to bifrontal often reduces cognitive side-effects.  
2. Stimulus dose – many centres titrate to just above seizure threshold to minimise after-effects.  
3. Treatment spacing – going from 3/week to 2/week or weekly “maintenance” can give memory circuits more recovery time.  
4. Simple headache prophylaxis – paracetamol, NSAID or low-dose gabapentin pre-ECT if not contraindicated.  
5. Baseline and follow-up cognitive screening (e.g. MOCA) to document recovery.  

Bottom line  
What you are feeling is almost certainly a transient paramnesic phenomenon caused by the way ECT temporarily disrupts the brain’s “familiar / unfamiliar” tagging system.  In most patients it fades gradually once treatments stop or are spaced further apart.  Nevertheless, because déjà-vu–plus-headache can occasionally herald spontaneous temporal-lobe seizures, it is sensible to:  
• tell your treating psychiatrist exactly what is happening,  
• request at least a screening neurological assessment, and  
• avoid driving or working at heights / with machinery until the episodes have settled.

If any of the red-flag features above occur, or if the déjà-vu spells are still present several weeks after finishing ECT, insist on a formal neurology referral.

Hope this clarifies what is going on and how to handle it with your care team.

146.question: 35 yo female with history of migraines as a child. MRI, ekg totally clear.Fainted a few times which caused a visit to a neurologist who was quick to diagnose with epilepsy. No longer loosing consciousness but symptoms are still present.    Wave of “feeling ill” usually nauseous    Followed by involuntary grimacing (as if I sucked on a lemon)    Slurred or slow speech 80% of the time    Feels like my brain is swollen - but only the part of my forehead    Sometimes itchy scalp    After the episode I feel like I was hit by a truck for the next few hoursDoes this sound like a seizure? Could it be something else?I refuse to take anti seizure meds without being confident and the lack of proof makes me weary of doctors who are quick to prescribe such strong meds.
146.answer:
I’m not in a position to tell you definitively what the spells are, but I can outline why a neurologist might think “epilepsy,” what other conditions can look similar, and what tests usually help sort it out so you can make an informed decision about medication.

1. Why seizures are on the table  
   • The episodes are stereotyped – each spell follows the same sequence: sudden queasy feeling → facial grimace → speech abnormality → exhaustion. Stereotyped, recurrent events lasting seconds-to-minutes are classic for focal seizures.  
   • Grimacing, facial twitching or tonic posturing, and speech arrest/garbling often arise from seizures that start in the frontal or temporal lobe.  
   • The post-event “hit-by-a-truck” fatigue is analogous to a post-ictal state.  
   • Loss of awareness is not required; many focal seizures occur with preserved consciousness (focal-aware seizures) or only brief impairment.  
   • Normal MRI and EKG do not rule out epilepsy; most people with focal epilepsy have a normal MRI.

2. Clues that point away from seizures (or at least demand broader thinking)  
   • Nausea and a “wave of feeling ill” are common in migraine aura, panic attacks, dysautonomia, vestibular disorders, and low blood-pressure spells.  
   • Childhood history of migraine can evolve into atypical migraine aura in adulthood, sometimes without a headache (“acephalgic” or “silent” migraine). Facial tingling, speech disturbance (dysphasic aura), and exhaustion afterwards are well-described.  
   • Recurrent fainting (syncope) can cause brief convulsive movements and post-event fatigue that mimic seizures.  
   • Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) usually don’t repeat in exactly the same way and are rare in a healthy 35-year-old, but speech disturbance always prompts us to exclude vascular causes.  
   • Anxiety/panic or functional neurological (psychogenic) spells can present with facial tension (“grimacing”) and speech changes.

3. How doctors normally nail down the diagnosis  
   a. Detailed eyewitness history and video of an event (smart-phone video is invaluable).  
   b. Routine EEG: picks up interictal spikes in only ~50% of people with epilepsy, so a normal result doesn’t settle the question.  
   c. Extended or ambulatory video-EEG (24–72 h or longer): gold-standard; captures an actual spell while recording brain waves and your behavior. If the EEG shows an epileptic rhythm that matches the clinical spell, the diagnosis is firm. If spells occur with a normal EEG, epilepsy is very unlikely.  
   d. Tilt-table test, Holter monitor, echocardiogram: if fainting or arrhythmia is suspected.  
   e. Migraine work-up is clinical; sometimes trial of migraine-preventive medication or lifestyle measures helps clarify the picture.

4. Weighing the risk of “watchful waiting”  
   • If the spells are seizures, the main risks are: injury, sudden loss of consciousness at dangerous moments (driving, swimming, heights), and (rarely) SUDEP (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy).  
   • Most neurologists recommend treatment after two unprovoked seizures or even after one if EEG/MRI show definite epileptic abnormalities.  
   • Conversely, anti-seizure drugs do have side-effects; starting them without a firm diagnosis is not ideal.

5. Practical steps you can take now  
   • Request (or self-refer to) an epilepsy monitoring unit for inpatient video-EEG, or ask for a 3- to 14-day ambulatory video-EEG you wear at home. This is the single most useful study.  
   • Keep a seizure-/spell-diary: date, time, triggers, body sensations, duration, recovery time, menstrual cycle, meals, sleep deprivation, stress, new meds.  
   • Record an episode on video if possible.  
   • Ask for copies of your MRI and EEG reports and bring them for a second opinion at a comprehensive epilepsy center or a headache specialist, depending on which way the evidence is pointing.  
   • Meanwhile, practice basic safety: avoid driving if a spell could impair awareness, shower instead of bathe, don’t climb ladders, sleep on your side if spells occur at night.

6. Questions to ask your neurologist  
   • What specifically on history or exam made you diagnose epilepsy?  
   • Was my routine EEG normal or were there epileptiform discharges?  
   • Would you order a prolonged video-EEG or ambulatory EEG before starting medication?  
   • Could this be migraine aura, syncope, or something else? What work-up rules those out?  
   • If medication is advised, which drug, why, and what are its common side-effects?

Bottom line  
Your description could indeed fit focal seizures, but migraine aura, syncope, and other mimics are legitimate alternatives. The diagnosis almost always rests on capturing a typical spell on video-EEG. If that has not been done, it is entirely reasonable to push for it—or to seek a second opinion—before committing to long-term anti-seizure therapy.

147.question: i’m 18 years old, 5’3, i don’t take any medications, i vape and smoke weed. i do cocaine, so i was driving and i felt a weird like strain in my neck on the left side, then the left side of my face went numb. my tongue went numb and my left eye felt weird. my arm went numb too. then i pulled over and my hearing started to fade. my vision started to go black and i passed out. when i was unconscious it felt very euphoric and safe, it felt like i died. and then i woke up suddenly and took a breath and i had pissed myself. my friend with me said it looked like i was having a seizure but i had never had a seizure before. while i was at the doctor my blood sugar was normal but my blood pressure was low, my ekg was normal, the doctors took blood and said nothing was wrong. what do you guys think is wrong with me
147.answer:
I can’t give you a formal diagnosis over the Internet, but what you describe is NOT “just nothing.”  A single episode that includes:

• Sudden one-sided facial, tongue, eye and arm numbness  
• Temporary loss of vision and hearing  
• Loss of consciousness while sitting up, followed by urinary incontinence  
• A witness description of “seizure-like” activity  
• Cocaine use only hours beforehand  

…has a short list of possibilities, all of which are serious enough to justify an urgent, thorough work-up by a hospital that can do advanced brain and heart imaging.  The normal EKG and basic blood work you already had are reassuring but nowhere near enough to rule out the most dangerous causes.

Why something this dramatic can happen at 18

1. Cocaine effects
   • Spasm or “clamping down” of brain or neck arteries → transient ischemia (mini-stroke/TIA) → seizure or faint.  
   • Direct lowering of the seizure threshold.  
   • Sudden heart-rhythm disturbances → brief loss of blood flow to the brain (convulsive syncope).

2. Artery injury in the neck (carotid or vertebral dissection)  
   Turning your neck or straining can tear the inside lining of these arteries; cocaine raises the risk. First symptom is often one-sided face/arm numbness or pain, then stroke or seizure.

3. Primary seizure disorder  
   Generalized tonic–clonic seizures often cause tongue/facial tingling (an aura) and post-event incontinence.

4. Severe vasovagal syncope or orthostatic hypotension  
   These can produce convulsive movements, but they usually are NOT preceded by focal (one-sided) neurologic symptoms.

5. Migraine with brain-stem aura (rare at your age)  
   Could resemble your symptoms but would not explain the incontinence and witnessed convulsions.

What a complete evaluation should include

• Brain imaging: MRI/MRA (or CT/CTA) of brain AND neck arteries to look for stroke, hemorrhage, or dissection.  
• Continuous heart monitoring (telemetry, possible Holter) to look for rhythm disturbances triggered by stimulants.  
• EEG to look for seizure activity.  
• Repeat vital signs, orthostatic blood pressures, full metabolic panel, toxicology, pregnancy test if relevant.  
• Possible echocardiogram (to rule out heart structural issues that can throw clots or cause arrhythmias).

Red-flag symptoms that mean “call 911 right now”

• Re-appearance of any face, arm, or leg weakness or numbness  
• Trouble speaking, seeing, or walking  
• Severe “worst ever” headache or neck pain  
• Chest pain, pounding heartbeat, or palpitations  
• Another blackout or seizure

What you should do now

1. Do NOT drive until a doctor clears you.  
2. Go (or go back) to an emergency department that has neurology and stroke capabilities and tell them exactly what happened, including the cocaine use and the witnessed “seizure.”  
3. Stop all cocaine and vaping immediately; both raise the risk of repeats and permanent damage.  
4. Arrange follow-up with a neurologist even if today’s imaging is normal; sometimes dissections and small strokes are missed in the first hours.  
5. If the episode is confirmed as a seizure, you’ll need counseling about seizure precautions (no driving, swimming alone, heights, etc.) until seizure-free for a specific period on or off medication as advised by a neurologist.

Bottom line

You had either a seizure, a transient stroke-like event, or both, possibly triggered by cocaine and neck strain. All of those are medical emergencies that can recur and become life-threatening. Please seek full emergency evaluation right away and avoid driving or further stimulant use until you have answers.

148.question: 18M I think it might be a form of seizure or epilepsy... I will try to be conecentrating on something and then all of a sudden i lose concentration, and when i realize and try to focus again my whole body will twitch. The twitch lasts just a second. Let me inform you that this has led to a seizure only once before (for the last 10 years) and the doctors said it was from dehydration. But the twitching won't stop, any clue what it is? It doesn't cause any pain or fatigue afterwards, just a little stress that it could have been a serious seizure like before. I don't know its happening until afterwards, and it happens everytime i try to re-focus.
148.answer:
I’m not able to diagnose you over the internet, but I can give you some perspective on what can cause the kind of brief, whole-body “jerks” you’re describing and why it would be wise to let a clinician sort it out.  

1. What could be going on?

   • Benign myoclonus (sudden, single muscle jerks)  
     – Common in healthy people when they’re falling asleep (hypnic jerks) or when they’re startled, tired, stressed, or using a lot of caffeine.  
     – Can sometimes be “action-myoclonus,” triggered when you purposely do something (such as re-focusing).  

   • Tics / startle responses  
     – Rapid twitches that can involve many muscles at once; usually people feel an urge or notice a pattern.  

   • Focal or generalized seizures  
     – Myoclonic seizures are often very brief (milliseconds to 1–2 s) and can occur many times a day.  
     – Typical epileptic myoclonus is more likely in the morning, may throw objects from the hands, or can evolve into a larger seizure.  

   • Metabolic causes  
     – Low blood sugar, electrolyte shifts, stimulant drugs, dehydration, sleep deprivation, etc., can all lower the “seizure threshold” or provoke muscle jerks.  

2. Red flags that suggest seeing a neurologist promptly

   • Jerks are getting more frequent, occur in clusters, or happen soon after waking.  
   • You ever black out, lose bladder control, bite your tongue, or wake up confused.  
   • There is any memory gap around the event.  
   • Family history of epilepsy.  
   • Head injury, new medication, drug or alcohol use, or any other new neurological symptoms (vision change, weakness, numbness).  

3. What a doctor might do

   • Detailed history and physical / neuro exam.  
   • Basic labs: glucose, electrolytes, kidney, liver, thyroid.  
   • EEG (looks for epileptic electrical patterns).  
   • MRI or CT if there’s any concern for structural brain problems.  
   • Consideration of trial anti-seizure medication if epilepsy seems likely.  

4. Practical measures while you wait for an appointment

   • Keep a diary: date/time, what you were doing, how long it lasted, any triggers (sleep loss, stress, caffeine, alcohol, dehydration, illness).  
   • Stay well-hydrated, keep regular sleep hours, limit energy drinks/caffeine, avoid recreational drugs.  
   • Let a friend or family member know what’s happening so they can describe what they see if an event lasts longer or looks more involved.  
   • If you ever have a prolonged episode (>5 min), repeated episodes without recovery, or any injury/loss of consciousness, seek emergency care.  

Bottom line  
Isolated body jerks can be completely benign, but they can also be a form of myoclonic seizure. Because you’ve had one definite seizure in the past and these jerks keep recurring, the safest course is to ask your primary-care doctor for a referral to a neurologist (or go directly if you can) to get an EEG and formal evaluation. It may turn out to be nothing serious, but ruling out epilepsy now will spare you a lot of worry later.

149.question: My daughter is 7F, in Canada, recently diagnosed ADHD-C but not on meds yet. All vaccines up to date. She is in therapy for ADHD & anxiety management at a local kid's multidisciplinary clinic (occupational therapists, speech language pathologists, counsellors, that sort of thing.)Sleep history: she had night terrors maybe 3-4 times total during her toddler years, nothing else of note.So, after years and years of no sleep issues, my daughter has had 4 very similar "episodes" within the past 4 weeks. Here's what they look like:-episodes start <2 hours after sleep onset and seem to have distinct "phases"-phase 1: she screams for me-phase 2: she gets into a crawling position on the bed and starts violently rocking forward/back and slapping or clawing at the mattress. She'll vocalize 1-2 words or sounds as if she's trying to communicate something to me, then make a tongue clicking sound, then try again, over and over. This lasts about 1-2 minutes. She seems to be aware of my presence but can't express herself. -phase 3: she starts running to her doorway as if she's looking for something, then returning to the bed to rock and click again, though she seems more "in control" of herself than in phase 2. This lasts longer, maybe 3-5 minutes. Again, she's aware of my presence and will even talk to me sometimes.-phase 4: she stops rocking and makes a very urgent, specific, and clearly spoken request. One time, for example, it was that she desperately needed a blue marker, which she used to write "BACKE" on a poster on her wall. Another time she needed to put her blanket in the corner in the shape of a pyramid.-phase 5: once the task is completed, she is very visibly relieved, and speaking normally. She lays down again and is very twitchy/shaky. It takes her about 5 minutes to stop twitching, and then she suddenly drops asleep.-she always remembers these episodes in perfect detail the next morning. She explains it as getting a "weird" feeling in the centre of her forehead, and then she sees something in the room that isn't right, like the door frame being too small or a clone of herself standing in the room.These episodes started suddenly a few days after we returned from a trip across the country to visit family. During that visit, she had a UTI and was on 10 days of cefixime, in case that's relevant. She was always accompanied by at least one parent at all times during the trip and we didn't notice any oddness in her behaviour.Daytime behaviour is mostly normal, though she is sometimes very tired when she wakes up, and that doesn't seem connected to these episodes.We've been treating this like some sort of sleepwalking manifestation of anxiety, but I'm starting to question myself. Does this description raise any flags that suggest we should be looking into other possibilities or getting her in to see a doctor?
149.answer:
What you are seeing could still be a benign N-REM “arousal parasomnia” (confusional arousal / sleep-walking variant), but several details you describe overlap with nocturnal focal seizures—particularly the syndrome now called Sleep-related Hypermotor Epilepsy (SHE, formerly “nocturnal frontal-lobe epilepsy”).  
Because the two conditions can look almost identical to a parent in the dark, the only reliable way to separate them is by a formal sleep study with prolonged video-EEG.  For that reason the safest next step is to involve your daughter’s physician and request referral to a paediatric sleep/neurology service.

Why the episodes resemble an arousal parasomnia  
• Occur in the first 1–2 h of the night, when deep (N3) sleep is most abundant.  
• Begin with a sudden cry and apparent confusion.  
• Last a few minutes and end with an abrupt return to sleep.  
• She is difficult to engage at first.  
• You travelled recently and her schedule/stress level changed—common precipitants for parasomnias in children.

Why they raise seizure “red flags”  
1. Stereotyped, repetitive motor pattern each time (crawling → rocking → clicking → door-running).  
2. Prominent oral automatisms (tongue clicking) and hand automatisms (clawing).  
3. Relatively brief (1–2 min “active” phase) with sudden, clear end.  
4. Full recollection the next morning—unusual for N-REM parasomnias, although not impossible.  
5. Described internal “weird feeling in the middle of my forehead” (an aura).  
6. Visual distortions/illusions (door frame too small, clone of herself) are common in focal seizures.  
7. Post-event twitchiness/shakiness can represent a post-ictal phase.  
8. Lack of prior lifelong history of sleepwalking/terrors but new-onset cluster of identical events.

Points that do NOT exclude seizures  
• She can answer simple questions or carry out a complex request.  Partial awareness is common in focal seizures.  
• Frequency of only four events; SHE can be nightly but may also appear sporadically at first.

Other considerations that usually can be ruled out once EEG is done  
• REM sleep behaviour disorder (rare in children, events later in night).  
• Panic attacks on falling asleep (would require full wakefulness and recall of fear).  
• Drug-induced phenomena (cefixime is not known to cause this once the course is finished).

What to do now  
1. Make an appointment with her primary care physician and bring a detailed written log plus any videos you can capture (phone on night-stand often suffices).  
2. Ask for referral to:  
   • Paediatric sleep laboratory for an overnight video-polysomnography with expanded EEG leads, OR  
   • Paediatric neurologist who can order prolonged video-EEG monitoring.  
3. Until she is seen:  
   • Keep a strict, regular sleep schedule; avoid sleep deprivation.  
   • Ensure a safe sleep environment (floor mattress, clear path, door alarm if needed).  
   • Limit evening screen time/stimulants; continue anxiety strategies already taught in therapy.  
4. If an event lasts >5 min, clusters repeatedly in one night, or is followed by prolonged confusion, breathing difficulty, or unilateral weakness, treat it as a possible seizure and seek urgent care (call EMS).

Prognosis  
• If EEG proves it is an arousal parasomnia, behavioural measures usually suffice and children outgrow it.  
• If SHE or another focal epilepsy is confirmed, seizure control with low-dose medication is usually excellent and most children maintain normal cognition and activities.

Bottom line  
These episodes are uncommon but not rare, and the only way to be sure they are not seizures is objective recording.  Call her doctor, share the description above, and ask for a video-EEG sleep study.

150.question: 26F I'm currently talking 30mg citalopram for depression and anxiety, it definitely helps with anxiety but my depression is just getting worse. At first I thought it was due to my other health issues but I think it's from increasing dose of citalopram?? Can SSRIs make you more depressed? I've been taking it for around 4-6 months.I've been trying to get a GP appointment for a week but they're always booked up (I'm in the UK) so I'm tempted to just stop taking it until I can get one and change meds but not sure if this is safe? Maybe more safe than slowly becoming suicidalAlso I'm not sure what antidepressants to try next, I'm currently taking topirimate 50mg bidaily (hoping to increase this or might be swapping to another epilepsy med for my myoclonic jerks) so any med that has twitching as a possible side effect is a no. Also want to avoid anything that will make me tired, I have fatigue.I've tried Sertraline and fluoxetine in the past, I tried mirtazapine. Would amitripyline be a bad combo with topirimate cause I know they're both used for migraines too?
150.answer:
I’m not your prescriber, but I can give you the general information UK GPs and psychiatrists use when decisions like this are made.

1. Can an SSRI make depression feel worse?
• Very early in treatment (first 2–4 weeks) some people get an increase in agitation or suicidal thoughts before mood lifts.  
• After several months, true “worsening” caused by the drug is uncommon.  What is more likely is:  
  – The medicine simply isn’t treating the depression strongly enough (partial or non-response).  
  – You are experiencing “emotional blunting / apathy”, a recognised SSRI side-effect that feels like flat, joyless, unmotivated depression.  
Either way, if you feel you are sliding into suicidal territory the treatment plan needs changing.

2. Is it safe just to stop citalopram?
• Citalopram has a short half-life. Stopping suddenly often causes a discontinuation syndrome: flu-like aches, dizziness, “brain-zaps”, nausea, insomnia and rebound anxiety/low mood that can last 1–2 weeks.  
• The symptoms are rarely dangerous, but they are unpleasant and can make suicidal thoughts worse.  
• Standard advice is a taper of 5–10 mg every 1–2 weeks.  
→ The safest course is to speak to a clinician first. If you cannot get a routine appointment, you are entitled in the UK to:
  – Phone the surgery and request a same-day urgent call-back for mental-health deterioration.  
  – Telephone NHS 111 (or 999/A&E if you feel unsafe with your thoughts).  
  – Ask for your local crisis team number (often printed on your GP’s out-of-hours message).  
  – Samaritans 116 123, 24 h.

3. What could be tried next?
(Must keep in mind: you have myoclonic epilepsy treated with topiramate; you want to avoid sedation and drugs that worsen jerks).

   Probably reasonable options
   • Venlafaxine (SNRI) – evidence-based after SSRI failure; tends to be more activating than sedating; seizure risk is low at usual doses.  
   • Duloxetine (SNRI) – similar, also helps some pain/fatigue syndromes.  
   • Vortioxetine – newer serotonergic modulator; relatively activating, low weight gain, minimal sexual dysfunction; neutral for seizures.  
   • Agomelatine – melatonin receptor agonist/5-HT2C antagonist; not sedating in daytime; no seizure signal, but LFTs must be checked.  
   • Augmentation rather than switch: adding low-dose aripiprazole or lithium sometimes used, but both must be weighed carefully in epilepsy.

   Drugs to avoid or use with caution
   • Bupropion – relatively activating but significantly lowers seizure threshold; generally avoided in anyone with a history of seizures.  
   • Tricyclics (amitriptyline, nortriptyline) – lower seizure threshold at moderate–high doses, anticholinergic side-effects, quite sedating. Small doses (10–25 mg) often used for migraine or insomnia, but they are unlikely to treat major depression on their own.  
   • Mirtazapine – you’ve tried this; it can be sedating and increase appetite/weight.  
   • MAOIs – effective but complicated diet/drug interactions; usually reserved for specialist use.

   Interactions with topiramate
   • No serious pharmacokinetic interactions with SNRIs, vortioxetine or agomelatine.  
   • Amitriptyline levels can be reduced by topiramate (more of the drug is broken down). If you used it you would need slow upward titration and close monitoring; seizure threshold issue still applies.  
   • Lamotrigine can be a useful mood-stabilising add-on and an anti-seizure medicine, but needs specialist dosing if combined with other anti-epileptic drugs.

4. Practical next steps
a. Contact your GP surgery today, explain you are deteriorating and need an urgent same-day telephone slot.  
b. While waiting, list: current medicines, what doses you have tried, how long you stayed on each, side-effects, family history, therapies tried. This helps the clinician decide rapidly whether to increase, switch or refer.  
c. If no GP appointment is available, ring NHS 111; they can arrange an out-of-hours GP or crisis assessment.  
d. Do not run out of tablets. If supply is the only issue, most UK pharmacies can give an emergency 5-day SSRI supply if they speak to your surgery/111.  
e. If you feel you might act on suicidal thoughts, go to A&E or call 999.

5. Non-drug support
Even when medication changes are necessary, combining them with psychological therapy (CBT, ACT, interpersonal therapy), regular exercise (when possible with fatigue), consistent sleep pattern and a structured day improves the odds of recovery and can reduce reliance on higher doses.

Bottom line
• Yes, an SSRI can leave you feeling worse if it isn’t the right drug or dose, but abrupt stopping is likely to make you feel even rougher.  
• Book (or insist on) an urgent review; you have several non-sedating alternatives that are compatible with topiramate and low seizure risk.  
• Seek immediate help if suicidal thoughts escalate—there is always 24-hour support available while you wait for a formal medication review.

151.question: Age 5 Sex male Height 40” Weight40lb Racewhite Duration of complaint 20 months Location Colorado, USA Any existing relevant medical issues CP, epilepsy Current medications Generic keppra 2.5mg/ml 2x daily My 5 yo son with CP and epilepsy My kid is amazing and funny and smart. We learned of a perinatal stroke he had between 28-32 weeks. He was born at 33 weeks, 3 days (twin A). He has left hemiplegia, is legally blind, ambulatory, talks, etc.On 4/30/19, he had a blow out focal seizure that generalized. He was stabilized by EMS with Versed and is now on a daily generic Keppra dose that is controlling seizure activity and is doing great. He’s wonderful. I’m so proud of him. He’s such an incredible human being. The thing is, I can’t seem to get over this looming threat of another generalized seizure. I have rescue meds, I’m with he and his his twin sister all the time, but I’ve lost all sense of calm since this event. I can’t sleep through the night without checking on him repeatedly (he’s actually sleeping in our room since it happened). I have motion and sound activated cameras all over my home, as he isn’t a great fit for most seizure detecting devices. I am so worried I’m ruining his life by being so caught up in this FEAR of another big seizure. I am scared all the time. I want him to be happy. I don’t want him to stop speaking to me when he turns 18 because I am such an annoying, overbearing mom. I want him to have privacy. With COVID, I’ve gotten even more protective. We really don’t go anywhere anymore. We’ve ceased all in person therapies and remotely attend school, as I’m so scared of a fever triggering a seizure. We were hiking a lot this summer, but all the trails in my area are very busy, and we just couldn’t continue risking it. Any ped neuros/epileptologists out here, please give me some feedback. What is the likelihood of him having a breakthrough seizure out of nowhere? How can I get past this and let him just be a kid? If the seizure occurred because of his brain injury from the stroke, will it always remain controlled with the Keppra, or can that change, too? FWIW, his twin sister is also incredible and hilarious, kind and wondrous.
151.answer:
I’m not your son’s doctor, so please view everything below as general education that you can take back to his own neurologist and pediatrician.  I’ve tried to address the questions that come up most often from parents in your exact situation—children who have epilepsy secondary to a perinatal stroke, who are presently doing well on levetiracetam (Keppra), but whose parents are living with a constant sense of dread.

1. How common are “break-through” seizures once a child is well-controlled?
• In children whose seizures are due to a structural injury (such as a focal perinatal stroke) and who become seizure-free on the first medication, roughly 60–70 % will remain seizure-free on that medication long term.  
• That leaves about 30–40 % who experience at least one breakthrough seizure over the next several years.  For many of those children the event is triggered by something obvious—missed/late doses, a growth spurt without a dose adjustment, significant sleep loss, high fever, or another illness—and seizures re-stabilise once the trigger is removed or the dose is raised.  
• If he has now gone 20 months without another event, his individual odds of staying controlled are better than the group statistics above.  The risk of a recurrence is highest in the first 6–12 months and steadily drops thereafter.  

2. What specific things make a seizure more likely even when he’s on medicine?
• Missed or late doses (set two alarms, keep an emergency dose in the car or your bag).  
• Growth without dose adjustment.  Levetiracetam is usually dosed at 20–60 mg/kg/day.  A 40 lb (≈18 kg) child often needs 360–900 mg a day; most kids outgrow their original dose every 4–6 months.  
• High fever, especially with viral illnesses.  Aggressive fever management (acetaminophen/ibuprofen early, fluids, rest) really does help.  
• Major sleep deprivation.  Many photosensitive or other specific triggers don’t apply to stroke-related epilepsy.  

3. Could his epilepsy suddenly stop responding to Keppra?
That’s uncommon.  Once a focal-structural epilepsy proves sensitive to a particular anti-seizure medicine, loss of effect years later is rare unless (a) doses can’t keep up with growth, or (b) new brain injury or scarring develops (not expected in a remote, stable stroke).  Of course, about 1 child in 4–5 ultimately needs a second medication or a higher dose over the years, but that is usually a slow evolution picked up at clinic visits, not an abrupt failure out of the blue.

4. Long-term roadmap
• If he reaches 2–4 years seizure-free and his EEG looks quiet, some neurologists will consider a slow taper off medicine, even with a structural lesion.  Others prefer lifelong treatment because the lesion is permanent.  It’s an individual call.  
• Risk of SUDEP (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy) in children with well-controlled focal seizures is <1 per 4,000–5,000 patient-years—very rare, and mostly confined to people with frequent uncontrolled convulsions.  Good seizure control plus nighttime supervision already puts him in a very low-risk category.  

5. Letting him be a kid while staying prepared
Practical measures that protect him AND allow you to exhale:
• Keep a written seizure action plan and a pre-drawn intranasal midazolam or diazepam syringe in the house, car, and school bag.  Knowing you can treat within a minute is the single biggest anxiety-reducer for many parents.  
• Schedule—and actually take—“growth check” phone calls with neurology every 4–6 months so the dose never lags behind his weight.  
• Teach a short “seizure first aid” script to grandparents, teachers, babysitters, even his twin sister in kid-friendly form (“roll him on his side, don’t put anything in his mouth, call Mom”).  Spreading the responsibility lessens the sense that only you can keep him safe.  
• Re-introduce activities in layers.  Example: Start with a quiet weekday trail, carry the rescue med, hike 30 min, turn around.  Next time stay longer or try a slightly busier trail.  The repeated safe experiences slowly retrain your fight-or-flight reflex.  
• Re-set nighttime monitoring goals.  Many parents transition from “eyes-on” to (a) a wide-angle video baby monitor pointed at his bed and (b) one scheduled visual check before you go to sleep.  If he stays on his current streak, consider dropping the overnight checks altogether in 3-6 months.  

6. Your own (completely understandable) anxiety
Parents of children with chronic illnesses can develop the physiologic equivalent of PTSD.  The hyper-vigilance feels protective, but it gradually erodes sleep, mood, and ultimately parenting quality.  Things that do help:
• A short course of cognitive-behavioural therapy focused on health anxiety/PTSD.  Evidence-based, usually 6–10 sessions, and available via telehealth during COVID.  
• Peer support: the Epilepsy Foundation of Colorado runs parent Zoom groups that many families find invaluable.  
• Scheduled respite: trade off overnight duty with a partner or relative once a week, even if you are all sleeping under the same roof.  One full night’s sleep is therapeutic.  
• An honest conversation with his neurologist.  Most clinicians are relieved when a parent says, “We’re doing great seizure-wise, but I’m falling apart,” because that’s a fixable problem.  They can steer you to mental-health resources and give you concrete statistics—often more reassuring in person than anything you read online.  

7. COVID-specific concerns
Fever is a potential trigger, but the neurologic community has not seen a surge of seizure relapses purely from SARS-CoV-2 infection in children.  Standard public-health precautions (masks, distancing, outdoor settings) make everyday activities like PT sessions or uncrowded hikes reasonably safe, and the developmental/social upside of getting back to therapy is large.  Many centres now offer one-parent/one-child in-person sessions with stringent screening protocols.  Discuss this risk-benefit balance with each therapy provider—most are ready to individualise plans for medically fragile kids.

Key take-home points
• After 20 months seizure-free your son’s outlook is very good; odds favour continuing control, not sudden relapse.  
• Breakthrough seizures usually have a fixable trigger; few come “out of nowhere.”  
• Levetiracetam’s effectiveness rarely disappears unless the dose falls behind growth.  
• Reasonable precautions (rescue med, seizure plan, dose checks) provide safety without 24/7 surveillance.  
• Parental hyper-vigilance is common, treatable, and worth treating—for your sake and his.  

Your little guy—and his sister—already have the most important protective factor there is: a parent who is informed, prepared, and deeply invested in their well-being.  Keep working with his neurology team, keep adjusting his dose as he grows, and take concrete steps to reclaim some normalcy for all of you.  You’re not ruining his life; you’re building the framework that will let him live it.

152.question: I’m an 18 year-old male senior in high school (155 lbs, 6’0”) that has been dealing with a life-altering medical condition for what I presume to be most of my life.I’m not sure exactly when it started, but the best way I thought I could explain what I have endured and my journey through it would be starting with my symptoms. Every couple of seconds, I presume in conjunction with blood flow to my head, I get a sensation of “blanking out” almost like the entirety of my brain shuts down for a split second. If I were to look at an object for an extended period of time, every couple of seconds I would slightly lose focus of it and have to reorient myself to it, which when applied in a broader sense makes everything from my perspective seem less grounded and real. I’ve had people watch my eyes and tell me that they don’t move, so I don’t know exactly where this is coming from. Additionally, it’s almost like I cant keep track of too much at the same time because I feel like I am constantly losing focus. This affliction has affected nearly every aspect of my life, from academics, socializing, and self-acceptance in ways that you can’t imagine. It feels as if I am a fragmented version of my true self, which is just awful.I’m an effort to resolve this issue, I’ve tried nearly everything that I could think of. First I tried changing my diet. Nothing. Then my sleep and exercise habits. Nothing. Then ensuring I get every single possible vitamin or mineral that I could possibly be deficient in. Nothing. Then I went to a chiropractor for speculation that it could be an issue related to my neck. Nothing. My parents put me on anti depressants and ADD medications because as a result of my issue I exhibit some symptoms of ADD. They made me feel a little funky, but didn’t fix or change the issue at all. I went to a psychiatrist who just dismissed what I had was all in my head, and a therapist who was helpful for other aspects of life but could not offer any advice for my affliction. I convinced my parents to let me go see another chiropractor that specialized in upper cervical adjustments, as that’s what I thought could be the underlying key after all this time. After half a year of doing that, the best that it could offer was inconsistent slight alleviation of my symptoms. From this I thought that maybe I could get at least some relief from self massage and muscle release of my upper neck and head area, so I attempted probably hundreds of different stretches and exercises from every corner of the web to release any possible muscle tension or tightness that could be leading to this. Nothing. That is until about a week ago, when I noticed something peculiar when messing around with my tmj joint. If I open my jaw wide, go behind the joint right on the front of my left ear, move up to where I feel two bones connect, and push in to try to separate them for about a minute, I get a moderate amount of temporary relief. When I do this, I also get a strange warm and liquidy sensation in that joint, as well as being able to feel the blood flow from some blood vessel connected there to the inside of my head near the left far end of my mouth. The relief only lasts around 15-45 minutes, and sometimes if I push too hard my cheeks feel worse and my mental state becomes even weirder, but for some reason out of every single thing that I’ve tried this is the only maneuver that works consistently.Throughout the years I have gotten an MRI of my head, an MRA of my head, and an MRI of my cervical spine that have all supposedly come back normal, which makes no sense to me because my symptoms and sensations are reality.I’m wondering if I could possibly have an issue with a subdued artery that runs near my tmj joint that could be doing weird things to blood flow to my brain, because honestly that’s what it feels like is happening. The constant change and fluctuation in my mental status and capabilities has nearly driven me to the edge, and that coupled with what I know I could be capable of if I didn’t have such an affliction makes me horribly depressed and dare I say slightly suicidal.I know this is quite a handful and seems outright crazy and confusing from an outside perspective, but I am going again to a doctor this week to describe in detail my symptoms and how I can partially remedy them, so any insight or advice from a doctor on here on what could possibly be the cause of this or what to bring up with her would be highly appreciated. EDIT: Thank you guys for all your responses, I’ll make sure to bring up a lot of the possibilities with my physician. Even though I still don’t know the exact root cause it is incredibly relieving to know that other people are willing to offer their ideas and help after it feeling like me against the world for so long.
152.answer:
I cannot examine you and can only speak in general terms, but the history you give raises several problems that have NOT yet been ruled out by the tests and therapies you have already tried.  When you see your doctor this week it will help to go in with a short, focused list of questions and requests.  Below is the way most neurologists or neuro-ophthalmologists would approach the story you have told.  Use it as a checklist, not as a diagnosis.

1.  Rule-out brief seizures (“staring spells”)  
   • Why it fits:  Absence-type or focal impaired-awareness seizures are usually only ½–3 seconds long, come many times a day, and are described by patients as “blanking out,” “momentary loss of contact,” or “my brain flicks off.”  During the spell the eyes may appear normal to an observer, or there may be only a subtle pause in blinking.  
   • MRI can be normal; the key test is an EEG or, even better, a 24- or 48-hour video-EEG.  
   • What to ask your doctor:  “Can you order an EEG, and if it is nondiagnostic, consider an ambulatory or in-hospital video-EEG to look for generalized 3-Hz spike-wave or focal discharges?”

2.  Neuro-ophthalmic/vestibular causes of transient blur  
   • Convergence insufficiency, ocular flutter/opsoclonus, or small-amplitude nystagmus can make a stationary object go in and out of focus every few seconds, yet be subtle enough that a casual observer does not notice eye movement.  
   • Formal eye-movement recording or examination by a neuro-ophthalmologist is the gold standard.  
   • Request:  Referral to a neuro-ophthalmologist or vestibular specialist with eye-movement recording capability.

3.  Dysautonomia (orthostatic intolerance, POTS)  
   • Moment-to-moment cerebral blood-flow changes can produce brief light-headed “grey-outs” that improve when you bend the neck, massage vessels, or change posture.  
   • Simple in-office orthostatic vitals and a tilt-table test screen for this.  
   • Ask:  “Can we check orthostatic vitals and, if abnormal, arrange tilt-table testing?”

4.  Narcolepsy / microsleeps from a sleep disorder  
   • Split-second sleep intrusions can mimic what you describe, sometimes beginning in childhood and persisting into the teen years.  
   • A formal overnight polysomnogram with next-day MSLT (multiple sleep-latency test) rules it in or out.  
   • Ask:  “Should I be referred to a sleep-medicine specialist for a polysomnogram and MSLT?”

5.  TMJ or upper-cervical sensory feedback as a distraction, not the cause  
   • The fact that pressure on the left TMJ brings temporary relief makes many people suspect a “blocked artery,” but anatomically there is no major cerebral artery you can occlude or open with your thumb.  A more likely explanation is that intense sensory input from the jaw temporarily overrides the uncomfortable sensation coming from whatever the real generator is (similar to rubbing your elbow after you bump it).  It is a clue, but not proof.  
   • A dental TMJ specialist can still evaluate occlusion and joint imaging, but do not let this delay the neurologic work-up.

6.  Mental-health overlay vs. primary cause  
   • Anxiety, depersonalization/derealization disorder, and ADHD certainly can coexist with neurologic conditions.  The fact that stimulant or antidepressant trials did not help does NOT disprove a psychiatric component, but the presence of objective, rhythmic episodes every few seconds should keep the neurologic search front and center.  
   • Because you mention occasional suicidal thoughts, make sure you and your parents tell the physician this explicitly—help is available and should run in parallel with the medical work-up.

Practical steps to take to this week’s visit  

A. Prepare a one-page timeline.  Include:
   – When you first noticed the spells.  
   – Exactly how long each “blank” lasts (count “one-one-thousand” in your head during an episode).  
   – How often they come (per minute, per hour, all day, only when reading, etc.).  
   – Any triggers (fatigue, lights, posture, stress).  
   – Any associated symptoms (sound fades, head drops, eyelids flutter, heart pounds, etc.).  

B. Bring a short video if you can capture an episode on a phone.  Even if eye movement is minimal, neurologists glean a lot from video.

C. Ask specifically for:  
   1. EEG (and, if unrevealing, longer video-EEG monitoring).  
   2. Neuro-ophthalmology referral with eye-movement recording.  
   3. Orthostatic vitals / tilt-table screening.  
   4. Sleep study referral if history fits.  
   5. Continued mental-health support for depression and suicidality.

D. If you feel unsafe with suicidal thoughts, tell someone immediately (parent, physician, counselor, or call 988 in the U.S.).  Getting to the bottom of a neurologic problem and taking care of mood symptoms are not mutually exclusive—you deserve both.

Bottom line  
You have done a lot of reasonable things already, but you have NOT yet had the tests that can actually catch brief seizures, subtle eye-movement disorders, or dysautonomia.  Go to the appointment with a concise description and specific requests for EEG, neuro-ophthalmology, autonomic testing, and sleep evaluation.  Most of the conditions on the list are very treatable once identified, so do not give up.  Good luck, and take someone with you to the appointment so everything gets written down and acted on.

153.question: Female, 40, has a history of seizures but not since 2011, after surgery,  Can you feel a seizure in your head? Google says it goes from your head to other parts of your body, but could someone feel it happen inside their head? Why don't all seizures show up on eeg? Is it possible to not notice or feel having a seizure but suddenly have the feeling like you had one? If there is an article that explains all this, I would love to read it. Thanks in advance!
153.answer:
I am not your personal physician, and nothing below substitutes for an in-person evaluation, but I can give you the general neurologic “rules of thumb” that specialists use when they discuss how seizures are perceived, why they sometimes evade the EEG, and how someone can be unaware a seizure even took place.

1. Can you “feel” a seizure happening only in your head?  
• Yes—especially if the discharge stays confined to a small area (a focal-aware seizure, formerly called a “simple partial” seizure).  
• Typical head-only sensations people describe: a sudden electric “buzz,” rushing, tingling, pressure, déjà-vu, jamais-vu, a rising epigastric “lift,” sudden fear, or an odd smell/taste.  
• If the abnormal firing spreads to the motor cortex or nearby networks, physical jerking, speech arrest, or loss of awareness can follow. When it stays in a sensory area, you may never get visible body movements.

2. Why does Google say it “goes from your head to the rest of your body”?  
Because that is what generalized tonic-clonic (“grand mal”) seizures do; the discharge rapidly engages networks on both hemispheres, recruiting many muscle groups. But focal seizures do not have to generalize. Roughly 60 % of adult epilepsies are focal.

3. Why don’t all seizures show up on a scalp EEG?  
• Timing: Routine office EEGs last 20–40 minutes. If you don’t have a discharge during that window the study is “normal.”  
• Depth: Electrodes on the scalp are ~1 cm from cortex; electrical potentials generated deep in medial temporal or frontal lobe may be attenuated before reaching the scalp.  
• Location: Small cortical patches (“micro-seizures”) are sometimes too focal or oriented tangentially to be recorded.  
• Noise & artifacts: Muscle, eye, and movement artifacts can mask low-voltage discharges.  
Sensitivity of a single routine EEG is about 50 %. Yield climbs with sleep deprivation, longer (24-72 h) ambulatory or inpatient video-EEG, or implantation of intracranial electrodes.

4. Is it possible not to notice the seizure itself, yet later “feel as if I must have had one”?  
Absolutely. There are two main scenarios:  
a. Focal-impaired-awareness seizure (formerly “complex partial”)—consciousness is clouded for 30–120 s, the person may stare, make chewing or picking motions, keep talking but nonsense words, then “come to” confused. They often remember nothing but feel wiped out, headachy, or “off.”  
b. Nocturnal or absence seizures—occur during sleep or are so brief (<15 s) that the patient thinks they “blanked out” momentarily. Postictal fatigue, sore tongue, muscle aches, or bitten cheek are clues something happened.

5. Post-ictal sensations often reported  
• Heavy fatigue, “drained” feeling  
• Frontal or global headache  
• Localized pain where muscles contracted (neck, shoulders, jaw, limbs)  
• Short-term memory lapses (“lost a few minutes”)  
Those symptoms can be the only hint to the patient that a seizure occurred.

6. What to do if you suspect breakthrough seizures after years of remission  
• Keep a dated diary of every spell or “funny feeling.” Note time of day, triggers (sleep loss, alcohol, stress, flashing lights), and anything witnesses saw.  
• Ask your neurologist whether to repeat imaging, adjust medication doses, or order a longer video-EEG.  
• Avoid high-risk activities (driving, swimming alone, operating heavy machinery) until you and your physician are confident nothing risky is happening.  
• Maintain scrupulous sleep hygiene and medication adherence—breakthrough seizures after long remission are often related to missed doses or sleep deprivation.

7. Good lay-level resources  
• Epilepsy Foundation (www.epilepsy.com) – “Types of Seizures,” “What is an Aura?”  
• Mayo Clinic – “Epilepsy: Diagnosis and Tests” (explains EEG sensitivity)  
• Johns Hopkins Epilepsy Center – Patient guides on focal seizures and EEG monitoring

Open-access medical reviews if you want more detail  
• Jobst BC & Cascino GD. “Current concepts: Seizures and epilepsy.” N Engl J Med 2015; 373:1643-1651.  
• Binnie CD & Stefan H. “Modern electroencephalography: its role in epilepsy management.” Epilepsia 2019; 60(9): 1809-1825.  
• Panayiotopoulos CP. “A clinical guide to epileptic syndromes and their treatment,” 2nd ed. (Chapters 3–5 cover focal symptoms and EEG pitfalls).

Bottom line  
You can indeed experience a seizure purely as an internal head sensation; many do not produce visible shaking. A normal routine EEG never rules epilepsy in or out—it only says “no abnormal firing was captured today.” And yes, people frequently discover they probably had a seizure only because of the way they feel afterward. If you have any suspicion your seizures may be returning, it is worth re-engaging with a neurologist for updated assessment.

154.question: Hey all, I am a 30 yo white male. I am currently 270 pounds and 5'9. Active and fairly healthy. Meds: Keppra (1000mg x2 daily, Prozac 40mg 1x Daily, Clonazepam .5mg x2 daily, Meloxicam 15mg 1x daily, Fish Oil, Vitamin D, Vitamin C Supplements) I had mono when i was 17 that developed into GBS. I had weakness, druken gate, and slurred speech and my main symptoms. Symptoms resolved in approx. 6 months and i was going back to normal. Shortly there after i started with seizures, one in November 2009, again in February 2010. I have been on Keppra since and been seizure free. I also have auto immune disease. One diagnosed, Hidradenitis Supperativa (doing well), and one undiagnosed. The undiagnosed one is more recently been bothering me.. i have Episcleritis and joint pain.. High ESR and CRP in the blood. I am worried about covid and want the vax but am afraid because i had a neurological reaction to the flu shot after my GBS. My Neurologist is insisting i get the vax and im talking to my Rheumi tomorrow. Is there anybody who can give me insight on what i should consider? Thank you!
154.answer:
I’m not your physician, but I can give you the up-to-date facts doctors use when counseling someone with your history.  Take this to your neurologist/rheumatologist and work through it point-by-point.

1.  Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) and COVID-19 vaccines  
   •  Baseline risk: In the U.S. about 1–2 people per 100,000 develop GBS each year, most after infections (Campylobacter, EBV, CMV, influenza, etc.).  
   •  mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna):  Large post-marketing surveillance (>400 million doses) has NOT shown an excess of GBS above background.  
   •  Adenoviral-vector vaccine (J&J):  About 8–10 extra GBS cases per million doses; the CDC now lists “history of GBS within 6 weeks of any vaccine” as a precaution, and strongly prefers an mRNA product in that circumstance.  
   •  SARS-CoV-2 infection itself:  Multiple cohort studies show COVID infection raises GBS risk to roughly 5–7 times baseline—clearly higher than any vaccine signal.

   Bottom line: If you had GBS after an influenza shot it is still considered safe to receive an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine.  You would be observed 30 minutes instead of 15.

2.  Seizure disorder on levetiracetam (Keppra)  
   •  Neither the clinical trials nor pharmacovigilance data show vaccines triggering seizures in people whose epilepsy is well-controlled.  
   •  Fever can lower seizure threshold, so take acetaminophen if you develop ≥38 °C (100.4 °F).  Continue Keppra on schedule.

3.  Autoimmune/inflammatory problems (hidradenitis suppurativa, episcleritis, seronegative arthritis?)  
   •  You are not on high-dose steroids, MTX, biologics, or other immunosuppressants, so vaccine efficacy should be good.  
   •  Flares after mRNA shots are uncommon and, when they occur, mild and self-limited (1–2 weeks, treatable with NSAIDs or short steroid taper).  
   •  COVID infection itself can provoke intense immune activation and has triggered new autoimmune diseases; preventing infection generally trumps the small flare risk.

4.  Practical points to discuss with your doctors  
   •  Choose an mRNA vaccine (Pfizer or Moderna).  
   •  Schedule it when your joint/eye symptoms are relatively quiet, if possible.  
   •  Hold meloxicam the day of and the day after the shot only if your rheumatologist wants the very best antibody response; otherwise you may keep taking it.  
   •  Plan for 24–48 h of arm soreness, fatigue, maybe low-grade fever.  Use acetaminophen; avoid ibuprofen 6 h before and 6 h after the shot if you want maximal immune response.  
   •  Ask to be observed 30 minutes post-injection for extra caution (history of neurologic event).  
   •  Report any new limb weakness or tingling that progresses over hours to days—worrisome for recurrent GBS—immediately.

5.  Why the benefit outweighs the risk for you  
   •  At 270 lb/5′9″ your BMI is ~40: obesity doubles to triples hospitalization/ICU risk from COVID even in young adults.  
   •  Autoimmune and inflammatory disorders (high ESR/CRP) correlate with worse COVID outcomes.  
   •  Vaccine-preventable serious side-effects (GBS, myocarditis, etc.) remain on the order of 1 in 100,000 to 1 in a million; serious COVID complications in unvaccinated people with your profile are orders of magnitude more common.

6.  What would make your doctors hesitate?  
   •  Active, progressive GBS within the past 6 weeks.  
   •  Anaphylaxis to a vaccine component (polyethylene glycol for mRNA products).  
   •  Current high-dose immunosuppression that would make the shot ineffective (not your case).

Take-home sentence to discuss with your specialists:  
“For someone who had GBS 13 years ago, is seizure-free on Keppra, and has inflammatory joint/eye disease but is otherwise immunocompetent, the CDC and neurology/rheumatology societies all recommend an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine with 30-minute observation; the benefit clearly exceeds the small theoretical risk of recurrence.”

Bring this summary, listen to your neurologist and rheumatologist, and you should be able to make an informed choice.

155.question: Medical professionals are calling my bf's symptoms panic attacks, but I'm convinced he needs a neurologist. I'm a research scientist in mental health (i.e. not a doctor), and my gut keeps telling me something is very wrong. What do you think?Bf is currently experiencing “panic attacks” that he barely remembers after they finish. They last 3-6 hours, occur on more than half of the days in a week, and are characterized by extreme anxiety and neurological symptoms such as loss of balance, slurred and slowed speech, mental confusion, memory loss, rapid eye saccades side to side, fainting, and vomiting.Background: He has a history of childhood abuse and neglect and in general hasn't seen doctors in his lifetime. Before this started, he had no known conditions but did have a history of anxios and depressive symptoms since adolescence. He's of south asian descent, 5'10, aprox 150lbs, is on 100mg of lyrica, smokes nicotine (~10 cigarettes a day), 4-7 drinks a week, no other drug use. Early 2021 - Symptoms begin: He started losing his balance and slurring his speech in the last year, usually either after something extremely stressful (covid and unemployment really got to him) combined with having a beer or two. I thought it was his alcohol tolerance changing with age, so I wasn't too worried. He had several bad falls because of this, broke his glasses twice, needed stitches, etc... stressful but not concerning.  June 2021 - Symptoms worsen: He finally got a job in April, he was super happy. It was a bit stressful and outside his field and had a huge learning curve, but he loved it. But he started losing his balance and slurring his speech more often, even when he hadn't had a drop of alcohol. He also started having full blown panic attacks, where he couldn't breathe, would vomit repeatedly, thought he was dying... I used grounding and breathing techniques to help him through July 2021 - Psychiatric emergency room: In early July, he couldn't keep food down for 6 days straight and alternated crying and panic attacks. The slurred speech and loss of balance continued. I took him to psychiatric emergency in my city where he was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder and put on a low dose (25mg) of seroquel/quetiapine. He was put on sick leave from his job. He was matched with a local psychiatrist, so switched him from seroquel to 50 mg lyrica (gabapentin pregabalin~~)~~ that eventually increased to 150mg. August 2021 - Regular emergency room: Worst night. After feeling suicidal for the first time in years, he suddenly crashed face first into our shoe rack. Busted his nose open, black eye, full shebang. He was on his back and semi conscious, and couldn't speak. No asymmetry in smile etc but 911 operator and ambulance both suspected a stroke. He got carried out on a stretcher, down the stairs, rushed to ER, and kept for 2 days. He doesn't remember any of this except waking up in the hospital (but he was conscious and speaking/attempting to speak). MRI negative for stroke, EEG negative for seizure, bloodwork normal. Given one dose of ativan, discharged, told it was "bad anxiety", and to keep seeing his psychiatrist. Sept 2021-present: medical incompetence??? : He saw his psychiatrist 3 days after he was released from the ER. Doc kept him on Lyrica 150 and said ER wasn't concerning since all tests were normal. Asks why bf doesn't want to go back to work yet/is reluctant to extend sick note. Doc refuses to put him on waitlists for therapy, other modalities at the psychiatric hospital, etc... because it's "not that bad". My bf quit his job last week, since he faints at least weekly, vomits 2-3 times a week, and gets these "panic attacks" every other day at least (we're currently on day 4 of a long storm). Second appointment was Tuesday. Doc decided to lower lyrica to 100mg (???) and prescribed Silexan, a lavender oil extract(?!?!?!) available from natural food stores. Not available to buy in my country. No pharmacist near us has heard of it. Doc still refuses to do anything else and outright refused ativan when my bf asked for it because it's "not serious enough". Next appointment is in over a month. Bf was on the floor half an hour ago and unable to get up. Where I'm stuck: We're stuck in a loop of "well, he has a doctor, so go see him" whenever we consult a nurse, ER, clinic, etc... and a doctor that isn't taking this seriously. We're in Canada (Quebec) with no family doctor and current doc and er won't refer to a neurologist. We've tried putting in a doctor change request but in a strained system it's not going through. I've reached out to work colleagues within mental health research and they can't help/shuttle him in anywhere. Bf is struggling with feeling suicidal/like a burden and I'm scared all the time
155.answer:
I’m not in a position to diagnose your boyfriend, but what you are describing is NOT a typical panic-attack picture and it deserves to be worked‐up as a possible neurological or medical problem, not just a psychiatric one.  The single most important message is: keep taking him back to an emergency department (preferably a large tertiary-care hospital) while the symptoms are actually happening and insist on a neurology review.  Document an episode on your phone so staff can see the eye movements, speech, gait, fainting, etc.

Why the story doesn’t fit ordinary panic attacks  
•  Panic attacks peak in 10-20 min and usually resolve within an hour. These episodes last 3-6 h.  
•  Panic does not produce objective focal signs such as clearly slurred speech, true loss of balance/ataxia, rapid horizontal eye “beating” (nystagmus/saccades), or prolonged amnesia.  
•  Recurrent fainting, vomiting, black-outs, and injuries are red-flag “can’t miss” symptoms in neurology and emergency medicine.  

Key possibilities that need to be ruled out (non-exhaustive)  
1.  Posterior-circulation (brain-stem or cerebellar) TIA / stroke / vascular malformation.  
2.  Seizure variants, incl. non-convulsive status or focal-impaired-awareness seizures.  
3.  Basilar/vestibular migraine or episodic ataxia.  
4.  Drug- or toxin-related: pregabalin can cause ataxia, nystagmus and dysarthria, and it potentiates alcohol. Dose may be “low” but sensitivity varies.  
5.  Metabolic or nutritional: thiamine deficiency, B12 deficiency, hypoglycaemia, hyponatraemia.  
6.  Inflammatory/demyelinating disease (multiple sclerosis, autoimmune encephalitis).  
7.  Cardiac arrhythmia with cerebral hypoperfusion leading to syncope/confusion.  
8.  Functional neurological disorder/psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (possible, but only after the above are ruled out).  

Reasonable minimum work-up  
•  Repeat MRI brain WITH attention to posterior fossa ± MR angiography/venography.  
•  Long-term (24-48 h) video-EEG monitoring.  
•  Complete metabolic panel (CBC, renal, liver, glucose, calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium).  
•  Thyroid, vitamin B12, folate, thiamine.  
•  ECG and 24-h Holter; consider echocardiogram or tilt-table if syncope persists.  
•  Formal bedside and vestibular neuro-exam by a neurologist or ENT.  

Practical steps in Québec’s system  
1.  Call 911 or go to a large ER (e.g., Montreal Neurological Hospital, Jewish General, CHUM). Tell triage “recurrent episodes of ataxia, slurred speech, possible brain-stem TIA/seizure” – not “panic.”  
2.  Bring written timeline, medication list, and phone video of an attack. That prevents the “looks fine right now” dismissal.  
3.  If they try to shunt him back to psychiatry, calmly repeat that the episodes have objective neurological signs and that stroke, seizure and arrhythmia have not been excluded. Ask to be seen by the neurologist on call.  
4.  During any admission ask the attending physician to place a formal neurology outpatient referral if the inpatient work-up is incomplete.  
5.  Use the hospital’s “Patient Representative / Complaints Commissioner” if necessary—you have that right under Québec law.  
6.  If you can’t get traction locally, present to another ER or call an ambulance during an actual spell: paramedic documentation of slurred speech, nystagmus and ataxia carries weight.  

Things you can do meanwhile  
•  Taper alcohol to zero; avoid taking pregabalin within 8 h of any drink.  
•  Consider discussing a slow taper or temporary stop of pregabalin with a pharmacist or another physician—in a minority of patients it paradoxically worsens dizziness and disequilibrium. Never stop abruptly.  
•  Maintain hydration and regular meals; give a daily multivitamin or at least B-complex with thiamine.  
•  Remove tripping hazards, keep a mattress or gym mat where he often falls, and have him sit on the floor the moment disequilibrium starts.  
•  If suicidal thoughts return, call Québec’s crisis line (1-866-APPELLE / 1-866-277-3553) or go to the nearest ER; tell staff explicitly “active suicidal ideation.”  

Bottom line  
Your instincts are correct: episodes that include ataxia, dysarthria, nystagmus, prolonged amnesia and syncope are neurological until proven otherwise.  Keep insisting on a full medical work-up and do not accept “just anxiety” as the final answer until objective causes have been excluded by a neurologist with the appropriate investigations.

156.question: My son- 2.5 year old M, 3 feet tall, 35 lbs, takes 1.5ml Keppra 2x/day- diagnosed with generalized epilepsy in December and taking keppra since then- had mri under sedation in Feb and found a significant Chiari malformation (normal cerebellar tonsils are 3-5 mm, his are 15)- they say the chiari and epilepsy are not related though it seems like quite a coincidence to me. Thoughts??
156.answer:
I am not part of your child’s care team, so everything below is general information, not personal medical advice.  Use it only to help you frame questions for the neurologist and neurosurgeon who know his exact history, MRI images and examination results.

------------------------------------------------
1.  A QUICK REVIEW OF THE TWO DIAGNOSES  
------------------------------------------------
•  Epilepsy
