  – “Generalized epilepsy” means the abnormal electrical discharges seem to involve both hemispheres of the cerebral cortex at once.  
  – The cortex (gray matter on the surface of the brain) is the structure that generates seizures.  
  – Keppra (levetiracetam) is commonly used; typical pediatric doses are 20–60 mg/kg/day in two divided doses.  (1.5 mL of the usual 100 mg/mL solution twice daily = 300 mg/day.  At 35 lb ≈ 16 kg, that is ~19 mg/kg/day – a fairly low starting dose.)  

•  Chiari I malformation  
  – In Chiari I the lower part of the cerebellum (“tonsils”) herniate downward through the foramen magnum.  
  – Tonsils 3–5 mm below the foramen are often called “low‐lying” and may be asymptomatic;  >5 mm meets most radiologic criteria for Chiari I.  Your son’s 15 mm descent is certainly significant.  
  – Symptoms (if any) arise from pressure on the brain-stem/spinal cord or obstruction of cerebrospinal-fluid (CSF) flow: headaches (often with coughing/straining), neck pain, balance/coordination problems, sleep-apnea, syringomyelia, etc.  

------------------------------------------------
2.  ARE CHIARI AND EPILEPSY USUALLY RELATED?  
------------------------------------------------
Short answer:  In most children, no—you can have either one without the other, and most specialists do not consider Chiari I a typical cause of generalized epilepsy.

Why?

1. Anatomical reason  
   • Seizures start in cerebral cortex.  
   • Chiari I involves the cerebellum/brain-stem, structures that usually modulate movement and autonomic functions, not cortical electrical activity.

2. What the literature says  
   • Large case series of Chiari I (hundreds of patients) report headaches, neck pain, sensory changes, syringomyelia, scoliosis, etc., but seizures are uncommon (≈1–3 %).  
   • Likewise, among thousands of children with epilepsy who undergo MRI, the prevalence of Chiari I is only slightly higher than in the general population, and many of those cases are judged incidental.  
   • There are scattered case reports of seizures improving after Chiari decompression, but they almost always involve additional factors (hydrocephalus, cortical migration disorder, or a syrinx) that can secondarily irritate the cortex.  

3. Population statistics (back-of-envelope)  
   • Lifetime prevalence of epilepsy ≈1 %.  
   • Incidental Chiari I on MRI in children ≈0.5–1 %.  
   • If the two were completely independent, the chance of an individual having both is roughly 1 in 10 000 to 1 in 20 000—a low number, but not so rare that a large children’s hospital would never see it.  

Because of these points, most pediatric neurologists will tell families, “Your child has two separate conditions we happened to discover.”

------------------------------------------------
3.  COULD THEY EVER BE LINKED IN A SPECIFIC PATIENT?  
------------------------------------------------
Possibly, if the Chiari is causing secondary problems that DO affect cortex:

•  Hydrocephalus (ventricular enlargement) from CSF blockage can cause seizures.  
•  Chronic brain-stem compression can disrupt respirations, leading to hypoxia that lowers seizure threshold.  
•  Syringomyelia extending upward into the brain-stem can, on rare occasions, irritate cortical connections.  

If the MRI (and physical exam) show none of these complications, the odds that the Chiari is driving the epilepsy drop further.

------------------------------------------------
4.  WHAT TO ASK YOUR SON’S TEAM  
------------------------------------------------
1.  “Do you see any signs of hydrocephalus, syringomyelia, or cortical malformations on the MRI?”  
2.  “Does his exam show brain-stem signs (abnormal reflexes, nystagmus, swallowing or breathing issues)?”  
3.  “How will you decide whether decompression surgery is needed?  What symptoms, if any, will you be watching for?”  
4.  “If we eventually operate, would you expect any change in the seizures, or will his epilepsy plan stay the same?”  
5.  “Is his Keppra dose adequate for the seizure type and frequency we’re seeing?”  

------------------------------------------------
5.  WHEN DOES A CHIARI NEED SURGERY?  
------------------------------------------------
•  Definite indications: progressive neurologic deficit, symptomatic syringomyelia, obstructive hydrocephalus, central sleep-apnea attributed to Chiari.  
•  Relative indications: frequent Chiari-type headaches, severe Valsalva-triggered pain, significant balance/coordination problems.  
•  Asymptomatic Chiari I (even with 15 mm descent) is sometimes just monitored, especially in toddlers who cannot reliably describe headaches.  
Decision is individualized; many centers repeat MRI and do a thorough symptom review every 6–12 months if observation is chosen.

------------------------------------------------
6.  TAKE-HOME POINTS  
------------------------------------------------
•  Epilepsy originates in cortex; Chiari involves cerebellum/brain-stem, so a causal link is uncommon.  
•  Nevertheless, both conditions can coexist by chance; the probabilities, while low, are not astronomically low.  
•  Ask the treating team to rule out secondary effects of Chiari (hydrocephalus, syrinx) that could lower seizure threshold.  
•  If none are present, treating each problem on its own—Keppra for epilepsy, watchful waiting or decompression for Chiari—makes sense.  

------------------------------------------------
7.  FOLLOW-UP AND SUPPORT  
------------------------------------------------
•  Keep a seizure diary (date, time, description, precipitating factors) to gauge medication effectiveness.  
•  Note any signs that might indicate symptomatic Chiari:  
     – New headaches, especially with coughing/straining  
     – Change in gait, balance or coordination  
     – Neck pain or stiffness  
     – Swallowing or breathing pauses during sleep  
     – Weakness, numbness or scoliosis developing  
•  Consider a genetics consultation if other findings emerge; some connective-tissue or developmental syndromes can feature both Chiari and epilepsy.  
•  Reach out to reputable groups (e.g., the American Epilepsy Society, the Chiari & Syringomyelia Foundation) for educational material and parent networks.  

I hope this gives you a clearer framework for discussing your son’s situation with his doctors and helps make the “coincidence” they’re describing a bit more understandable.  Best wishes for straightforward management of both conditions and an uneventful path forward.

157.question: This is going to be a long post, I also copy pasted it from my previous post on a different forum which I used because I thought this forum was taken down. Im not sure if that's ok.I (m24) have had episodes of sudden double vision which lasts approximately 40 minutes each time for 5 years. I am responsive and coherent during episodes. They are usually a few grouped together within 2 weeks of each other and no more than 10 'episodes' a year.This is something I have seen many doctors, including neurologists, for ever since it began and have never gotten solid answers.Things ruled out by medical professionals and lab tests are: epilepsy  migraines   vertigo    brain masses  scar tissue in brain  eye diseases  blood sugar problems  blood pressure   medication levels Through my own observations by recording and testing things during episodes I have also found that it has no correlation with dehydration  eye appearance (pupil size, placement and no involuntary eye movement)  blood sugar  temperatures  foods or caffeine time of day   medications  body position (standing, sitting, laying down, walking)    eye fatigue smoking (happened both before I started smoking and after) finally realized I will start feeling slightly disoriented about 5-10 minutes before it starts. When the double vision starts, moving around promotes more dizziness but only because my eyes can't focus. If I am sitting down or keeping my head level there will still be feeling of mild disorientation and double vision but no dizziness. These episodes last almost exactly 40 minutes every time (I set a stopwatch when they start.) with the longest edging closer to an hour.  I started having peripheral neuropathy involving both arms and both legs early this year but after blood tests we found out I had severe vitamin D deficiency. After high doses of Vitamin D this completely went away and I was hoping the double vision would also go away (because most of the episodes happen between september and april, lower light months). But unfortunately it's still happening.Again I am left anxious and concerned because the episodes just came back. A notable episode happened recently when the double vision was significantly worse than ever before and went away when I used only one eye (it used to happen no matter which eye I looked through or if I used both.). It made the double vision go from a noticeable but slight 'distance' between the two versions I see, to double vision that showed stuff separate up to 3 inches apart. I don't drive so it's no danger to myself or others but when I'm walking it makes it hard to make out things like stoplights or to be able to look side to side to check for cars without feeling like I will fall. Just knowing it might start at any moment is so terrible.I have looked this up and talked to doctors about it so much over the past 5 years and I just want to know if there are any other reasons these might be happening or advice about what to do.I forgot to mention I did have a few minor concussions as a kid. 3 notable ones were when i broke my nose falling directly on my face with some confusion, the back of my head going through drywall and a hit against the back of my head where i may have blacked out for a second. No puking or memory loss after any and no need to see a doctor. and A benzo overdose a year before first episode with no short memory for 3 days (i was medically cleared afterwards and it caused no other issues) Thats why they were looking for possible scar tissue in my brain.The peripheral neuropathy mentioned came back. My vitamin D levels came back normal and my doctor checked my parathyroid hormone levels because of it and those also came back normal. She's suggesting neuro again but I probably won't schedule unless something gets worse or something new happens bc specialty appointments are expensive.
157.answer:
I am not your doctor and can’t diagnose you on-line, but I can tell you how physicians usually approach a complaint of brief, recurrent double vision and why it has been so hard to pin down.  Read this, keep a diary of the next few attacks and take it to the next specialist (ideally a neuro-ophthalmologist).  



1.  First question every doctor asks  
   ───────────────────────────────  
   “Is the diplopia monocular or binocular?”  

   • Cover one eye during an attack.  
     – If the objects are still doubled, it is MONOCULAR (almost always an eye/optics problem – cornea, lens, dry eye, uncorrected astigmatism, etc.).  
     – If the doubling disappears when either eye is covered it is BINOCULAR (the eyes are mis-aligned for some reason – nerve, muscle or brain-stem control).  

   Your earlier description (“happened no matter which eye I looked through”) sounded monocular, but the latest attack was abolished by closing one eye, i.e. binocular.  Clarifying this point with a simple cover test (ideally filmed on your phone) will instantly narrow the field for the next doctor.  



2.  Causes of very short-lived (minutes-to-hour) BINOCULAR diplopia  
   ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  
   a. Migraine aura involving the brain-stem (“migraine with brain-stem aura”, formerly basilar-type).  
      • Fits the 5–60-min duration almost perfectly.  
      • Often comes in clusters and may occur without any headache.  
      • Can be preceded by a vague “off” feeling.  
      • Mild dizziness when you move your head is common.  

   b. Ocular myasthenia gravis.  
      • Diplopia fluctuates, worsens with sustained up-gaze/reading, improves after rest or an ice-pack.  
      • Episodes can be minutes to hours.  
      • Blood tests (AChR and MuSK antibodies) ± Tensilon/ice-pack tests pick this up.  

   c. Intermittent de-compensated phoria / convergence spasm.  
      • Harmless but annoying mis-alignment brought on by fatigue, stress, prolonged near work.  
      • Eye-muscle exam during an attack shows a large phoria/tropia that vanishes between attacks.  

   d. Very transient cranial-nerve palsy from vasospasm or “TIA-like” phenomena of the vertebro-basilar artery.  
      • Important mainly because it has to be ruled out, even though it is uncommon at your age.  

   e. (Much less likely given the short duration) earliest attacks of demyelinating disease such as multiple sclerosis – usually the diplopia lasts days, not minutes.  



3.  Causes of episodic MONOCULAR diplopia  
   ──────────────────────────────────────  
   Unstable tear film, corneal irregularities, lens changes, refractive issues or even posterior vitreous detachment can all cause transient “ghosting,” but these do not improve when either eye is covered.  Again, clarifying the cover-test answer is essential.  



4.  Tests most neuro-ophthalmologists order if the history fits  
   ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  
   • MRI brain and orbits with contrast + MRA of the vertebro-basilar circulation.  
   • Formal eye-movement exam (prism cover test, Hess or Lancaster).  
   • Acetylcholine-receptor and MuSK antibodies (for myasthenia).  
   • Thyroid function (thyroid eye disease can give intermittent diplopia).  
   • Basic autoimmune/vasculitis panel if indicated.  

   During an actual spell, a quick video of your eyes trying to look left, right, up and down is often more helpful than any scan.  



5.  Why “migraine” may have been dismissed too quickly  
   ───────────────────────────────────────────────────  
   Many non-specialists equate migraine with headache.  The International Headache Society recognises “migraine aura without headache” and “migraine with brain-stem aura,” both of which can present exactly as you describe.  If your diary shows:  
   • attacks lasting 5–60 min,  
   • at least two similar attacks,  
   • fully reversible neuro symptoms (diplopia, vertigo, disorientation, etc.),  
   a migraine mechanism should be reconsidered even if you never get head pain.  Management is simply standard migraine lifestyle plus, if frequent, prophylactic medication.  



6.  When to seek care quickly  
   ──────────────────────────  
   • Attack lasting >1 h or leaving residual weakness/numbness.  
   • New speech difficulty or facial droop.  
   • Constant (not episodic) double vision.  
   • Severe eye pain, proptosis or sudden loss of vision.  



7.  Practical steps you can take now  
   ─────────────────────────────────  
   • Keep a dated log: time started, duration, cover-test result, what you were doing, food, sleep, stress, any later headache.  
   • Film your eyes during an attack.  
   • Make sure your basic labs stay normal: B-12, thyroid panel, HbA1c, inflammatory markers.  
   • Maintain regular sleep, meals, hydration; minimise caffeine/nicotine surges – inexpensive interventions that help both migraine and myasthenia.  
   • If cost is an issue, ask your primary doctor to refer directly to a neuro-ophthalmologist (often one visit + MRI/antibody tests answers more than multiple separate specialties).  



Bottom line  
───────────  
Short, fully reversible bouts of diplopia clustered in attacks most often turn out to be migraine aura or ocular myasthenia gravis.  Neither is life-threatening but each has different treatment, so nailing down whether the double vision is monocular or binocular during the next spell is the first, crucial step.  Take that information—and, if possible, a phone video—back to a neuro-ophthalmologist; it is the fastest, least expensive path to a definitive answer.

158.question: My little brother has random faint spells (or mini epileptic attacks, we are not sure). We want to help him lose weight as that alone would improve his quality of life by itself but the biggest issue we have is that he falls very frequently and he is very heavy. Up until now every fall he has had has not resulted in a major injury thankfull but its bound to happen. I was wondering. Is there a cage/walker product that allows us to take him on walks and would catch him via a harness should he fall? This walker/cage bungee cord contraption would have to be able to hold the sudden shock of 250 lbs of deadweight when he has his faint spells. Please let me know if you know of such a device or what the name is.
158.answer:
Short answer  
Yes – there are walking frames that can hold a person up in a sling or harness when his knees suddenly give way, but they are not the same devices you see in a regular medical-supply shop.  They are called “gait trainers with body-weight support.”  The two products most commonly used in the U.S. for an adolescent or adult weighing 250 lb (113 kg) are:  

1. Rifton Dynamic Pacer XL (rated to 275 lb / 125 kg) with the posterior frame and the “Multi-Positioning Saddle” or “Support Harness.”  
2. Rifton TRAM (transfer-and-ambulation device) – lifts or supports up to 350 lb / 159 kg and lets the person walk while the sling catches any sudden collapse.

An outdoor base with large wheels exists for the Pacer so you can take short walks on pavement.  None of these devices are sold off the shelf; a physical therapist (PT) or rehabilitation supplier measures the user, orders the right harness size and sets the straps so the body is held high enough to walk but low enough to be “caught” if consciousness is lost.

Why a normal walker or rollator will NOT do the job  
• They are designed only for balance support. When 250 lb suddenly drops, the frame tips or the hand grips slip.  
• Even if you clip a climbing harness to a rollator the deceleration forces are easily >5 g – enough to flip the frame, bruise ribs, or shear shoulder joints.  Devices marketed as “fall-arrest walkers” comply with industrial safety standards; ordinary walkers do not.

Terms to give the therapist / DME supplier  
• “Posterior gait trainer with dynamic body-weight support”  
• “Ambulation device with fall-arrest capability”  
• “Overhead track or mobile frame LiteGait system” (if you have space at home)  

Other models worth asking about  
• Ormesa Grillo Bariatric (max 242 lb – may be borderline for your brother)  
• Kaye Large PostureRest with anterior chest support (max 250 lb exact limit)  
• Aretech ZeroG or LiteGait home frame – these are free-standing frames with a ceiling rail; safe but stationary (used indoors or garage/driveway).  

How to obtain one  
1. Schedule a PT/OT evaluation (they write the Letter of Medical Necessity).  
2. Get a prescription or order from the physician (diagnosis: seizure-related falls / syncope, obesity, gait instability).  
3. A durable-medical-equipment (DME) provider comes to the house, measures doorway widths, and brings demo frames.  
4. Insurer approval is usually under the “gait trainer” HCPCS codes (E8000-E8002 or E0637 for TRAM).  If denied, many state Medicaid programs still cover these for safety-related reasons.  

Cautions  
• Even the rated devices must be adjusted so the sling carries only 20-30 % of body weight during normal walking; if he really blacks out, the remaining load is within the device’s shock-absorption travel.  
• A harness around the torso can still compress the chest.  Proper fit is essential.  
• Always have someone walking behind the frame to steer if awareness is lost.  

While you are arranging equipment  
• Push a wheelchair to the park and let him propel with his feet or arms for calorie burn.  
• Water therapy/swimming eliminates the fall problem entirely and is ideal for weight loss in people with epilepsy or syncope.  
• A recumbent stationary bike or an arm-ergometer at home yields aerobic benefit with zero fall risk.  

Don’t skip the medical work-up  
Unexplained “faint spells” in an overweight child or teen can be seizure, vasovagal syncope, cardiac arrhythmia, sleep-apnea–related hypoxia, or even medications/energy drinks.  The safest piece of equipment, and the best weight-loss plan, will never replace a correct diagnosis and treatment.

Bottom line  
Ask a rehabilitation therapist about a “Rifton Dynamic Pacer XL with support harness” or a “Rifton TRAM.”  Both are engineered to arrest a 250-lb sudden collapse and let him keep walking.  Acquire it through a PT-guided fitting and your durable-medical-equipment supplier, not off the Internet.

159.question: 26f. 122lbs, 5'2". Never smoker, rare drinker. On medication (trokendi, fycompa, Yaz, pristiq, creon, Cymbalta, b12 injections, pepsid, abilify). History of epilepsy, migraines, chronic pancreatitis status post tp/ait.Went to ED for abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting that was unremitting for weeks. Had abdominal CT that found incidental liver lesions. Followed up with an MRI with contrast. The below are the findings in my liver. Hpw should I interpret? Is it something to worry about?"There are multiple (at least 7) arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of liver, which are hyperintense on T2 and without internal fat. The dominant lesion measures 1.8 cm and seen in segment 6 of the right lobe (29:67). A few other prominent lesions include 6 mm segment 6 (29:47), 8 mm segment 5 (29:40), and 3 mm segment 2 (29:30). No definite washout however the lesions appear to enhance less then background vessels on delayed phases, arguing against hemangioma.Multiple arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of liver, largest measuring up to 1.8 cm in segment 6 of the right lobe. Imaging features suggest adenoma with the differential including focal nodular hyperplasia."
159.answer:
What the MRI report is saying

•  The radiologist saw at least seven little spots (“lesions”) scattered through both halves (lobes) of your liver.  
•  The biggest one is only 1.8 cm (about ¾ inch); the rest are 3–8 mm.  
•  All of them light-up quickly when contrast first reaches the liver (arterial phase) but then fade so that on later pictures they are the same or slightly darker than the background liver.  
•  They do not contain fat and they do not behave like the very common benign birth-mark-type lesion called a hemangioma.  
•  The way they look most closely matches either  
  – hepatic adenomas, or  
  – focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).  

What those two possibilities mean

1.  Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH)  
   •  A harmless over-growth of normal liver cells with a little scar in the middle.  
   •  Occurs mainly in women 20-40 yr.  
   •  Almost never bleeds or turns into cancer.  
   •  Once the diagnosis is secure, no treatment is needed other than an occasional check-up.

2.  Hepatic adenoma  
   •  A benign (non-cancerous) liver tumor that is often driven by estrogen.  
   •  Much more common in women who use birth-control pills or who have been pregnant.  
   •  Can bleed suddenly and, in about 4–6 % of cases, can transform into a liver cancer (hepatocellular carcinoma), especially if the nodule grows larger than 5 cm.  
   •  Standard management: stop estrogen-containing pills, follow with imaging every 6 months; remove or treat only if the lesion is >5 cm, continues to grow, bleeds, or shows worrisome features.

Why your doctors cannot say “it is definitely X” just from this scan

FNH and adenomas can look very similar on ordinary MRI.  A special liver-specific contrast agent (gadoxetate/Eovist), contrast-enhanced ultrasound, or occasionally a needle biopsy is needed when the diagnosis is still unclear.

How worried should you be right now?

•  Size: all of your lesions are small (<2 cm).  For adenomas, risk of bleeding or malignant change is mainly an issue once they reach 5 cm.  
•  Number: having several small nodules does not automatically mean something bad, but it does make sorting adenoma vs. FNH important.  
•  Nothing on the scan suggests obvious cancer or metastasis.  
•  This is not an emergency, but it does deserve prompt outpatient follow-up.

Recommended next steps to discuss with your physician

1.  Referral to a hepatologist or liver-focused gastroenterologist.  
2.  Consider a liver-specific contrast MRI (Eovist) or contrast-enhanced ultrasound to nail down the diagnosis; biopsy only if imaging still leaves doubt.  
3.  Review medications: because you are on Yaz (estrogen/progestin), stopping estrogen-containing contraception is usually advised until the lesions are fully characterized.  Your other drugs are not well-known for causing adenomas.  
4.  Baseline blood work: complete liver panel, coagulation tests, and possibly an AFP (tumor marker) even though cancer is unlikely.  
5.  Follow-up imaging: if adenoma remains a possibility, most specialists repeat MRI or ultrasound at 6-month intervals for 1–2 years to be sure the nodules stay small and stable.  
6.  Know the red-flag symptoms: sudden severe right-upper-quadrant pain, dizziness, or signs of internal bleeding → go to the ED.

Bottom line

The scan most likely shows benign liver lesions (either FNH or small hepatic adenomas).  Because you are young, female, and taking estrogen, adenoma has to be ruled out carefully.  The nodules are small, so the immediate risk is low, but follow-up with a liver specialist and (almost certainly) discontinuing estrogen-containing birth control are important next steps.

160.question: Hello. This is about my wife who is 19F. Non smoker. Non vaper. No medical issues. No history of epilepsy in her family. I would like to highlight main parts of this inquiry. Not going into too much detail unless required by someone.My wife (19) first time pregnant had an emergency C section at 36 weeks due to breech. Baby passed away. She was fine. Had some headaches and after 6 days at home she felt blurry vision and after about 20 mins got her first seizure ever. Got 2nd one in the ambulance and after reaching hospital had 3 more.In the hospital they performed another spinal tap for her CSF (Lumbar puncture) and MRI. All tests etc were good. MRI suggested some activity in the front part of her brain. But doctors couldn't pinpoint anything. They concluded that it must have happened due to her previous spinal anesthesia for c section which is rare but not impossible.She was discharged 12 days later with Phenytoin medicine for epilepsy. 300mg per day (3 tablets all together) for 3 months. It has been a month and half (or less) and she had no seizure but some strange observations I had about her: Very sensitive to light especially when very sleepy or waking up.She had blurry vision again but partially and in one eye. One day she had in both eyes.e become a deep sleeper and it becomes really hard to wake her up. She would sleep for about 7 to 9 hours and wake up only if we woke her up. When I discussed these observations with the doctor he told me to decrease dosage to 200mg per day. Almost 2 weeks now since lowering her dosage. She has developed this strange itching all over her body that prevents her from sleeping since 3 to 5 days. She also felt her hand vibrate or shake for 2 to 3 secs while sleeping. oday she said that she felt her whole right side of the body vibrate a little and after that her right arm. She seems normal for the most part. No slurred speech, just that she forgot some of the things before seizures and also her journey from home to hospital. So is she at risk of getting seizures again? I am too damn afraid. Even when she itches the whole bed vibrates the same way it did when she had her seizure and this thing keeps me on my toes at all times. I also read that the itching can be due to some neurological issues and I think it might be Multiple sclerosis??
160.answer:
I am very sorry that you and your wife are going through all of this.  I can only give general medical information, not personal medical advice, but the points below should help you understand what may be happening and what you should discuss – soon – with her obstetrician and a neurologist.

1.  Why did she have the first cluster of seizures?
    •  In women who have just delivered, the commonest “first-time” causes are:
       – Post-partum eclampsia or PRES (post-partum reversible encephalopathy) – can occur up to 4–6 weeks after delivery, even if blood pressure was previously normal.  
       – Cerebral venous thrombosis or intracranial hemorrhage.  
       – CNS infection.  
       – Less commonly, a true epilepsy that just happened to show itself now.  
    •  Because her MRI and spinal tap were essentially normal and she is now many weeks beyond delivery, the eclampsia/PRES risk is probably over, and if no structural lesion was found her long-term seizure risk may actually be low.

2.  Why was phenytoin started?
    •  Phenytoin is often given simply to prevent any more seizures while doctors are sorting out the cause.  
    •  It does NOT mean she definitely has lifelong epilepsy.

3.  Common phenytoin side-effects (all can appear or worsen when the dose is changed):
    •  Sedation, “hard to wake up,” imbalance, double/blurred vision, light sensitivity.  
    •  Generalized itching (pruritus) or a rash.  
    •  Tremor–like or vibration feelings, especially when falling asleep.  
    •  These effects become more likely if the blood level is high; phenytoin has “non-linear” kinetics, so a small change in dose may produce a big change in level.

4.  Worrisome reactions that need prompt medical review
    •  Diffuse itching, especially if a rash, hives, fever, mouth sores, swollen glands, or facial swelling occur.  These can precede serious reactions such as DRESS or Stevens-Johnson syndrome.  
    •  New or worsening balance problems, slurred speech, or uncontrollable eye movements – could be phenytoin toxicity.  
    •  Any clear seizure-like episode.

5.  What to do right now
    •  Contact her prescribing doctor or neurologist urgently and describe the itching and “whole-body vibration.”  They will probably:
       – Examine her skin.  
       – Check a phenytoin level, liver tests, and blood count.  
       – Decide whether to lower the dose further, switch to a better-tolerated drug (e.g., levetiracetam), or stop antiseizure medication completely if they feel the postpartum seizure risk has passed.  (Medication should never be stopped suddenly without medical guidance.)  
    •  If she develops rash, fever, swelling of lips/face, or looks generally ill, go to the emergency department.

6.  Could this be multiple sclerosis?
    •  MS rarely presents with only generalized itching and light sensitivity, and seizures are an uncommon first sign.  The normal MRI and spinal fluid make MS very unlikely here.

7.  Is she still at risk of seizures?
    •  If her seizures were due to a postpartum condition that has resolved, her risk is probably low once she is 6–8 weeks past delivery.  
    •  If she truly has a new-onset epilepsy, risk remains, but medication (perhaps a different one) greatly lowers that risk.  
    •  The safest way to know is to let her neurologist reassess now, consider an EEG, and tailor further treatment.

8.  Practical safety precautions until she is cleared
    •  No driving, swimming alone, baths alone, climbing heights, or operating heavy machinery.  
    •  Keep a seizure-first-aid plan handy (lying her on her side, timing the seizure, calling EMS if >5 min, etc.).

Bottom line
Generalized itching, marked sedation, and brief limb “vibrations” shortly after a phenytoin dose change are much more likely to be drug-related than signs of a new neurologic disease.  She needs to be re-examined quickly to rule out phenytoin toxicity or an allergic reaction and to decide whether she should switch or stop antiseizure medication.  Contact her doctor today; go to the emergency department right away if a rash, fever, or swelling appears, or if she has another definite seizure.

161.question: Every so often I get these really weird sensations that feel somewhat neurological that I haven't a clue what they are since they seem so different from anything else I know of. I've been getting them occasionally for over a year now. 25F. I just had one now and it leaves me in such a weird state of mind afterwards.I feel somewhat floaty and dizzy currently, so please forgive me if this isn't constructed well.It begins as a tingling sensation? Like a shiver. That flushes through me. And I feel some kind of emotion that I can't describe, like dread or deja vu or some kind of combination of the two. I become hyperaware of my sorroundings, like reality has become more real? It's very abstract and weird, I know. I usually forget the specifics of these sensations; but I've written them down previously while experiencing them so I can repeat these now. Afterwards, accompanied by a light headache that goes away fairly quickly.(Very, very rarely I get migraines with a visual aura, but this experience is completely different.)I'm really dizzy/floaty this time around and I'm not sure why. It has been a while since it happened; I thought it had stopped happening. It passes after some time and doesn't seem to negatively affect me, though it's very difficult to maintain a conversation or writing while it's happening. I don't think I've ever been this dizzy thoughNo other diagnoses, no medication, or anything else. I don't know how long the shivering phase lasts, but I think its under a minute. The dizziness is fading a little now, and I think its been about 10 minutes, though I have a light headache.
161.answer:
I can’t tell you for certain what the episodes are, but the group of symptoms you describe raises one possibility in particular that is worth having checked by a neurologist:

• Sudden “wave” or “flush,” pins-and-needles or shiver that spreads through the body  
• A very brief, hard-to-describe emotional surge (dread, déjà-vu, hyper-real feeling)  
• Duration a few seconds to under a minute, after which thinking and speaking are difficult for a short while  
• Follow-up period of light-headedness, “floaty” feeling, and mild headache that fades in minutes to tens of minutes  
• Stereotyped (each spell feels essentially the same) and has recurred for > 1 year  

That pattern is classic for a focal aware seizure (formerly called a simple partial seizure), most often coming from the temporal lobe. A temporal-lobe seizure can produce :

• An indescribable rising or sinking body sensation, heat/tingle, or “shiver”  
• A surge of déjà-vu, jamais-vu, sudden fear, dread, or detached unreality  
• Heightened perception of sights and sounds (“world suddenly more real”)  
• No loss of consciousness, but conversation is hard while it’s happening  
• A brief “post-ictal” phase—fatigue, dizziness, headache, or fog that wears off  

Why see a neurologist?  
1. Seizures can evolve or generalize; occasionally they’re a sign of an irritative focus in the brain (scar, infection, tumor, malformation) that needs treatment.  
2. Diagnosis usually requires history, an EEG, and sometimes an MRI.  
3. If it is epilepsy, medication can prevent spells and reduce risk of injury (e.g., while driving or swimming).  

Could it be something else?  
• Atypical migraine aura – possible, but auras usually last 5–60 min, tend to have visual/ sensory spread rather than a single 10-sec jolt, and your emotional component is less typical.  
• Panic or anxiety attacks – usually several minutes, with racing heart, hyperventilation; emotional content is broader, not as stereotyped.  
• Vertigo or blood-pressure changes – typically provoke light-headedness first, without the déjà-vu/ dread “warning.”  

What to do now  
• Make an appointment with a neurologist. Take this written description (or keep a diary) so you don’t have to rely on memory.  
• Ask anyone who has witnessed an episode to write down what they see. If possible, have someone record a spell on a phone camera.  
• Note possible triggers—sleep deprivation, stress, alcohol, illness, flashing lights, hormonal cycle.  
• Until you’re evaluated, be cautious with driving, climbing, swimming, heights, or operating machinery.  
• Go to the ER or call emergency services if you ever have:  
  – loss of consciousness or a spell lasting ≥5 min  
  – one after another without full recovery in between  
  – new weakness, speech trouble, vision loss, or severe headache  

Bottom line: brief, repetitive, stereotyped episodes with a “psychic aura” sensation plus short post-episode fog are much more suggestive of focal seizures than anything else. They’re often very treatable, but you need to be assessed in person.

The ECG came back clear but I was too nervous to stop meds but in 2022 I was recommended to stop meds again and the ECG was clear again too, so I did. Not sure which suspicions have been correct lmao. EEG RESULTS - I wasn't sent the literal results, only the documents. They're in French which isn't my first language so I'll TRY to translate but will include the original French (unless it's obvious) to be safer. Thank you!! Base rhythm/rythme de base : alpha, distribué de façon symétrique. stable fuselé 9 Hz /alpha, symmetrical distribution, stable taper (?) 9 Hz Alpha activity: normal Activité delta : irrégulière fronto-temporale bilatérale occasionnelle / Delta activity: irregular fronto-temporal bilateral occasionally Theta activity/Activité thêta: absent Stop reaction/Réaction d’arrêt : normal Fast rhythms/rhythmes rapides: bi-frontal, non reactive Paroxysm (?? no clue)/Paroxysme: absent Photostimulation reaction: normal (no reaction) Hyperventilation reaction: normal (no reaction) Conclusion: foyer de ralentissement localisé fronto-temporal bilatéral intermittent. Absence d'anomalies épileptiformes franches. / no clue how to translate foyer in this context but intermittent slowness localised in the bilateral fronto-temporal. Absence of epiletiform(??) anomalies. PRIL 2022 (when I stopped meds, also most recent EEG since before the chaos): Base rhythm: alpha, symmetrically distributed. Stable taper(?). Alpha activity: 9 Hz Delta activity: absent Theta activity: absent Stop reaction: normal Fast rhythms: bifrontaux, non reactifs/bi-frontal, non reactive Paroxysm/paroxysme: absent Reaction to photostimulation: normal (no reaction) Reaction to hyperventilation: not tested Conclusion: normal exam
162.answer:
What probably happened – the short version  
• Everything you describe (years of brief “jerks”, a first big seizure after sleep-loss, lifelong sensitivity to missing sleep, seizures coming back the moment medication was withdrawn) is the textbook picture of juvenile-myoclonic epilepsy (JME).  
• In JME the brain is usually perfectly normal between seizures, so routine EEGs are often completely normal. A normal EEG does NOT rule the condition out.  
• Lamotrigine can help the tonic-clonic (“full”) seizures but, in many patients, it does little for – or can even aggravate – the myoclonic jerks. Giving only 25 mg/day is essentially no treatment at all.  
• You were kept seizure-free for years by a workable dose of levetiracetam (Keppra®). When that drug was stopped abruptly and replaced by a sub-therapeutic dose of lamotrigine, your epilepsy was suddenly untreated, so the jerks and finally a tonic-clonic seizure came roaring back.  
• Once JME “breaks through” after being controlled, it can take weeks-to-months on adequate doses again before myoclonus fully settles, and some people never return to the same level of control they had before the break-through.  
• Sleep deprivation, anxiety/panic, irregular medication intake, and alcohol/caffeine all make JME worse, so the more chaotic those factors became during the switch, the more seizures you felt.  

Below is a more detailed breakdown of each issue and what to discuss with your neurologist.

1.  What type of epilepsy is this?  
   • Typical age of onset (mid-teens), years of early-morning “jerks” (myoclonic seizures), generalized tonic-clonic seizure after sleep-loss, normal MRI, often normal routine EEG = juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.  
   • JME involves the entire brain at once. That is why EEG may look normal until an attack is actually captured, and why CT/MRI are usually normal.  
   • About 10–15 % of routine EEGs in proven JME show no epileptiform discharges; your traces fall into that group. The French report simply says “intermittent bilateral fronto-temporal slowing; no frank epileptiform activity” – a nonspecific finding.

2.  Why did things get worse when medication was changed?  
   a) Abrupt withdrawal  
      • Keppra was holding your seizures. Stopping it overnight is like turning the circuit breakers off.  
      • Anti-seizure drugs must always be tapered slowly (usually over weeks) with the next drug introduced and pushed up at the same time (“cross-titration”).  

   b) Sub-therapeutic lamotrigine  
      • For epilepsy lamotrigine is typically 200–400 mg/day (sometimes higher).  
      • 25 mg once daily is just the starter dose used during the first two weeks to avoid rash; by itself it gives almost no seizure protection.  

   c) Drug choice for JME  
      • Lamotrigine sometimes worsens the myoclonic component of JME.  
      • Valproate is most effective for JME but is avoided in women of child-bearing age unless no other drug works because of its high teratogenic risk.  
      • Levetiracetam, topiramate, zonisamide, or brivaracetam are acceptable alternatives.  

   d) Trigger stacking  
      • Switching drugs, anxiety, short sleep, uncertainty about dosage: all are strong seizure triggers in JME.  
      • Once the brain “kindles” back into frequent myoclonus, it can take weeks after restarting adequate doses before the network settles down again.

3.  Why is the EEG ‘normal’?  
   • EEG only shows what the brain is doing during the minutes it is recorded.  
   • Intermittent bilateral fronto-temporal slowing is a nonspecific marker of drowsiness, medication effect, or previous seizures; it is NOT an epileptic spike.  
   • JME often requires a sleep-deprived EEG, prolonged (24-72 h) ambulatory EEG, or EEG with photic stimulation / hyperventilation to capture the classic 4–6 Hz poly-spike-and-wave pattern.

4.  Current treatment – is it adequate?  
   • You are now on levetiracetam 2 g/day + lamotrigine 100 mg morning.  
   • Keppra 2 g/day is an appropriate dose for an adult, but many JME patients need 3 g/day (1.5 g twice daily), or a second broad-spectrum agent.  
   • Lamotrigine 100 mg is low-to-borderline for generalized epilepsies. If it helps mood you might keep it, but if jerks persist you and your neurologist might:  
     – increase Keppra up to 3 g/day, or  
     – add brivaracetam (similar to Keppra but often better tolerated), or  
     – switch lamotrigine to topiramate or zonisamide.  
   • Clobazam is fine as an emergency/back-up drug, but tolerance develops; it should not be the main way to control nightly jerks.

5.  Mental-health interactions  
   • Depression and anxiety are common co-travellers with epilepsy. Keppra can worsen irritability or depression in ±15 % of people, while lamotrigine often improves mood.  
   • Untreated anxiety → poor sleep → more seizures, creating a vicious circle.  
   • Cognitive/attention complaints are also frequent in JME. Formal neuropsychological testing and psychiatric assessment can clarify ADHD, ASD, BPD questions and guide therapy (CBT, SSRI/SNRI, etc.).  
   • Never stop an anti-seizure drug on your own because of mood changes; instead tell your neurologist—dose reduction or switching to brivaracetam, valproate, etc., usually fixes it.

6.  Practical steps to regain control  
   1. Make sure you are working with an epileptologist (a neurologist who subspecialises in epilepsy).  
   2. Stay on a strict sleep schedule; no all-nighters. Even one night of <6 h sleep can trigger clusters.  
   3. Take medication at exactly the same times every day; use pill boxes / phone reminders.  
   4. Avoid binge-drinking, excessive caffeine, and stimulant-type drugs.  
   5. Keep a seizure diary: date, time, what the jerk felt like, triggers, missed pills, menses, stress level.  
   6. Ask for:  
        • A prolonged (24–72 h) or sleep-deprived EEG if diagnosis is in doubt.  
        • Serum drug levels (especially lamotrigine) once a stable dose is reached.  
        • Clear written taper-and-switch plans before any future medication change.  
   7. Discuss contraception & pregnancy planning. Valproate is the most powerful JME drug but must be balanced against fetal-risk issues; if pregnancy is years away it might still be the best option short-term.  
   8. Arrange formal mental-health support; tell providers you have epilepsy so they avoid medications that lower seizure threshold (e.g., bupropion, high-dose clozapine).

7.  When to seek urgent help  
   • ≥5 min continuous tonic-clonic seizure, or a series without full recovery (status epilepticus) – call EMS.  
   • >30 min of near-continuous myoclonic jerks with trouble speaking/walking – ER.  
   • New focal signs (weakness on one side, speech loss) – ER.

Key take-home messages  
• Nothing “mysterious” happened: the condition simply re-asserted itself when effective medication was withdrawn.  
• Normal EEGs do not rule out epilepsy.  
• Juvenile-myoclonic epilepsy usually requires lifelong treatment, especially in people whose first attempt at withdrawal failed.  
• The goal is zero seizures, not “fewer” seizures. With the right drug(s), dose, regular sleep, and mental-health care most people with JME achieve complete control and lead unrestricted lives.

163.question: I, 16(AFAB)(Diagnosed with ASD, GAD, MMD, and ADHD, no physical conditions known, I don't take any medication or supplements whatsoever), have been consistently baffled by what keeps occuring. I have no idea where to look anymore, and this is honestly a last ditch effort to at least point me in the right direction.Starting when I was around 11 years old, periodically, I'd go through a "episode" of sorts where exactly half my body would become completely numb and it became difficult to communicate. When I was 12, this happened during school, and it was so bad I ended up being sent to the hospital. I believe I received an MRI among a few other tests, but ultimately, the episode was over by the time I had arrived. The doctors said I was fine and I was sent home, but since then I have had about 8 more of these episodes.When this occurs, it starts by my entire arm slowly going numb, which spreads through one side of my body, almost as if there's a line going all the way down. The weirdest part is that it's exactly half, and that includes all of that half (no joke, half my tounge and nose too) will go completely numb. Sometimes I will get an extraordinary horrible headache during this that lasts about 5 hours, which makes me incredibly sensitive to any form of light or sound. As mentioned previously, I lose the ability to communicate, but not the ability to think. I am able to recognize what my body is going through the entire time, but all that I am able to do is I suppose cry and wail. I lose the ability to speak English. Sometimes I am able to delay these episodes by doing breathing exercises, but ultimately it's only a delay, and I end up losing vision entirely for at least 15 minutes during this.I have no idea why this happens, as the circumstances are different every time. It seems to be entirely random and completely cripples me for at least 2 hours. I want to know what it is so I can research it and hopefully focus on preventing it, or at least lessening the effects.Any ideas?
163.answer:
What you describe – sudden onset of numbness that respects the exact mid-line of the body, sometimes followed (or accompanied) by an intense unilateral headache, loss of vision, marked light/sound sensitivity, and an inability to talk although your thoughts remain clear – is most consistent with a “complicated” (also called “hemiplegic”) migraine aura.  
  
Why hemiplegic/complicated migraine fits  
•  Aura that spreads gradually over minutes from the hand/arm to the face and tongue, always on the same side.  
•  The sensory deficit can include numbness, weakness or both and may involve speech (expressive aphasia).  
•  Headache often follows but may be delayed or even absent. When present it is usually severe, throbbing, light/ sound sensitive and can last hours.  
•  Visual aura (blackout, flashing lights, tunnel vision) occurs in many patients and may last 5–60 min.  
•  Total duration of the episode (aura ± headache) can be 1–24 h; two-hour spells are typical.  
•  Onset is often in childhood or early teens.  
•  Breathing/relaxation can sometimes “slow the spread,” but cannot abort it – exactly what you notice.  
  
Other problems that can look similar  
1.  Focal seizures with “Todd’s paralysis.” A focal sensory seizure can cause numbness/tingling on one side, last seconds to minutes, then be followed by a period of weakness or numbness (Todd’s) that can last minutes-hours. An EEG during/after an attack is needed to prove this.  
2.  Transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke. Because you are 16 and healthy, this is far less likely, but every first-time event of one-sided numbness must be treated “as a stroke” until proven otherwise.  
3.  Functional neurological (conversion) episodes. These can cause hemi-sensory loss, but they do not usually come with the very stereotyped spreading pattern, visual aura, photophobia, or pounding unilateral headache you describe.  
  
Why work-up is still needed  
•  Hemiplegic migraine can be familial (autosomal dominant mutations in CACNA1A, ATP1A2, SCN1A, etc.) or sporadic (no family history). Genetic counselling/testing can be useful because, rarely, the same genes predispose to ataxia or epilepsy.  
•  A normal MRI done once at age 12 is reassuring but does not substitute for a full present-day neurological evaluation that includes:  
  – MRI brain with and without contrast (plus MRA/MRV if hemiplegic migraine is suspected)  
  – Baseline and possibly attack-state EEG to rule out seizure activity  
  – Basic labs (CBC, metabolic panel, B12/folate, thyroid, clotting profile if there is any vascular risk)  
  
What to do right now  
1.  Keep a headache/episode diary. Note exact time of onset, what you were doing, food/fluid intake, stress, sleep the night before, hormonal cycle, weather, etc. Note which side was affected, how fast it spread, whether vision changed, and what the pain was like. Bring this to every appointment.  
2.  Whenever a new episode starts, treat it as an emergency until a neurologist has given you a firm diagnosis. If there is new weakness, speech loss, or vision loss that lasts more than a few minutes, call EMS – paramedics can get you to an ER where they can image you while the symptoms are still present. A normal scan during an event plus a typical clinical picture virtually clinches the migraine diagnosis.  
3.  Arrange an appointment with a pediatric or adolescent neurologist – preferably one with an interest in headache or epilepsy. Bring the hospital records from age 12 if available.  
  
If it is hemiplegic migraine…  
Acute treatment:  
•  Triptans and ergotamines are usually AVOIDED in hemiplegic migraine because of theoretical risk of constricting blood vessels that are already irritated.  
•  NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen), acetaminophen, anti-nausea agents (ondansetron, promethazine), magnesium glycinate 400 mg, or even intravenous magnesium in the ER are often used. Some centers use calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) monoclonal antibody injections after the age of 18; occasionally they are approved earlier.  
Preventive treatment if attacks are frequent or disabling:  
•  Verapamil, flunarizine, topiramate, acetazolamide, amitriptyline, or beta-blockers. Which drug is chosen depends on blood pressure, comorbid ADHD/anxiety, sleep pattern, and possible side-effects.  
•  Lifestyle: regular meals, steady hydration, consistent sleep schedule, daily light exercise, limited caffeine, stress-reduction (CBT, mindfulness, biofeedback).  
  
If it turns out to be focal epilepsy with Todd’s paralysis…  
•  Anti-seizure medication (ASMs) such as levetiracetam, lamotrigine, or topiramate may be started. Many ASMs also prevent migraine, so treatment can overlap.  
  
Red-flag (go to ER) symptoms  
•  New episode that feels different from the others: worse weakness, double vision, slurred speech, confusion, or loss of consciousness.  
•  Headache that is sudden/thunderclap or the “worst ever.”  
•  Prolonged weakness (>6 h) or any residual deficit after an attack.  
  
Key points for you to remember  
•  What you are experiencing is real and deserves a thorough neurological evaluation – even though prior testing was “normal.”  
•  Complicated/hemiplegic migraine is the leading explanation, but seizure and (rarely) vascular causes must be ruled out.  
•  Keep a detailed diary, seek a pediatric neurologist, and bring someone who has witnessed an attack to describe it.  
•  Until a firm diagnosis is made, treat each episode as you would a possible stroke: call for medical help so that imaging and labs can be done during the event.  
  
I hope this gives you clear next steps and some reassurance that there is a well-recognized neurological explanation for the pattern you’re seeing. Good luck, and please arrange that follow-up as soon as you can – the sooner a diagnosis is confirmed, the sooner effective prevention and acute-rescue strategies can be put in place.

164.question: Age, sex: 23M Height: 5'7" Weight 80kgs Current medications: Glyciphaige SR500 for pre-diabetes, LN Bloc 20 and Moxovas 0.3 for High BP, Thyrox 62.5 for Hypothyroid.Okay so recently i was at a neuro to check if i have Myoclonic Epilepsy. I used to have these shoulder jerks that would last one second, then my whole body started moving in all directions like few months later. For some time it was fine and recently my head started jerking so i finally went to a neuro. The EEG was fine. Looking at my posture and the way i was standing the doc said I've motor tics and AD/HD. So I've been given Tetrabenazine for these movements, Clonidine for ADHD and also Clonazepam 0.25 for emergency when I'm having too many jerks. A quick look at google told me that Clonazepam is used to treat Myoclonic Epilepsy. Should i be worried about these jerks situation because apparently doc Haven't ruled out epilepsy
164.answer:
I’m not your treating physician, so I can’t confirm a diagnosis, but I can help you understand why your neurologist may feel comfortable calling these spells “motor tics” rather than epileptic myoclonus, why clonazepam shows up in both situations, and what questions or follow-up you might consider.

1. How doctors separate tics from epileptic myoclonus  
   • Duration/phenomenology.  Tics are usually brief, but they are often preceded by an uncomfortable inner urge (“premonitory sensation”) and are partially suppressible for a few seconds.  Epileptic myoclonic jerks are instantaneous lightning-like muscle contractions, not voluntarily suppressible, and are not preceded by an urge.  
   • Circumstances.  Tics tend to disappear during deep concentration or sleep and become worse with stress or fatigue.  Epileptic myoclonus often clusters shortly after awakening or is provoked by flashing light or sleep deprivation.  
   • Associated features.  Many people with chronic motor tics have a history of ADHD, OCD, or other neuro-behavioral conditions; this association is not typical in epilepsy.  
   • EEG.  In true myoclonic epilepsy, a routine or sleep-deprived EEG often (not always) shows generalized spike-wave or polyspike-wave discharges that correlate with the jerk.  A normal EEG does not 100 % rule out epilepsy, but it makes it significantly less likely, especially when combined with a clinical picture typical of tics.  
   • Response to medicines.  Tetrabenazine (a dopamine-depleting agent) and clonidine (an α2-agonist) are standard, guideline-supported therapies for motor tics and also help co-existing ADHD symptoms.  They do not treat epileptic myoclonus.  The choice of these two drugs strongly suggests your neurologist believes you have a tic disorder.

2. Why clonazepam is on the prescription  
   • Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine that reduces neuronal excitability in general.  Low, intermittent doses can calm severe tic flurries.  At higher, scheduled doses it is also an add-on medicine for myoclonic epilepsy.  In other words, the drug helps both conditions, so its presence on the list does not necessarily mean your neurologist still suspects epilepsy.  He or she likely gave it to you as an “as-needed” rescue when tics become socially embarrassing or physically uncomfortable.

3. Should you still worry about epilepsy?  
   • Statistically, with a normal exam apart from tics, a normal routine EEG, no loss of awareness, no falls or injuries, and a treatment plan that fits tic disorder, the probability that these jerks are epileptic is low but not zero.  
   • If you or your family ever notice jerks accompanied by blank stares, loss of consciousness, tongue biting, urinary incontinence, or confusion afterward, you should alert your neurologist promptly.  
   • If your jerks always cluster right after waking, are triggered by photic stimulation, or you cannot suppress them even for a moment, mention that as well.  Your neurologist might then order a prolonged video-EEG or sleep-deprived EEG to look again.

4. Practical steps and follow-up  
   • Keep a diary: time of day, trigger, ability to suppress, any premonitory urge, any loss of awareness.  Bring it to your next visit.  
   • Take the medicines exactly as prescribed; sudden stop of tetrabenazine or clonazepam can cause rebound symptoms.  
   • Watch for tetrabenazine side-effects: fatigue, depressed mood, parkinsonism-like slowness.  Report them promptly.  
   • Because clonidine lowers blood pressure, stand up slowly and monitor your BP, especially since you are already on antihypertensives.  
   • Arrange a follow-up EEG or a video-EEG study if your neurologist feels the picture changes.  
   • Until epilepsy is completely ruled out, many neurologists advise driving only if you have been free of jerk-related impairment or loss of awareness for a sufficient period per local regulations.

5. Red-flag symptoms requiring urgent review  
   • Jerks strong enough to make you drop objects or fall.  
   • Any episode with loss of awareness.  
   • New neurological symptoms (double vision, speech problems, weakness).  
   • Mood changes, suicidal thoughts (possible with tetrabenazine).

Bottom line  
Your neurologist’s choice of tetrabenazine and clonidine, together with a normal EEG and the clinical description, indicates that he/she believes these movements are motor tics in the context of an ADHD spectrum, not myoclonic epilepsy.  Clonazepam is a shared medication between the two conditions, so its use here does not imply untreated epilepsy.  Stay in follow-up, keep a careful symptom diary, and alert your doctor if the pattern changes or any red-flag features appear.

165.question: 20 y/o USA white female, 5'5" 145 lbs, currently taking Zoloft, Lamictal (as a mood stabilizer, I'm not epileptic), and have an IUD if that counts as a current med?My psychiatrist and therapist both think I might have atypical ADHD and we're trying out different meds to see if they help. My psychiatrist put me on low-dose Concerta for about 2 weeks and told me to work my way up to 3 pills as a single dose, spending a few days on 1 pill and then a few days on 2 pills and that if it felt like it was working well at a dosage below 3 pills, to just stick with that. I was having some air hunger then but not as much as I currently am. The Concerta was giving me mood swings at the dose where it started to feel like it was working (3 pills) so she decided to have me try Vyvanse instead.It's only my second day on Vyvanse and I'm no stranger to waiting out initial side effects or even to dealing with long-term side effects that suck but suck less than not being medicated for the condition but the air hunger is really getting to me.I'm a classical singer so I do know how to take legitimately full breaths and have been going through the motions of taking full breaths but still never feel like I've got a full breath. I'm not panting or something like that, I'm breathing normally, it just doesn't feel like I'm getting all the air I need. Yawning helps me feel like I got a full breath but only until the next breath and I can't just try to yawn for every breath because while the Vyvanse isn't making me constantly nauseous, it makes it way easier for me to be nauseated and if I yawn too hard too much, I get nauseous.Is there anything I can do? Like I said, I'm hoping that the air hunger will go away once my system gets more used to the Vyvanse but in the meantime I'd really love not to feel this way.
165.answer:
What you are describing – the very uncomfortable feeling that you “can’t quite get a satisfying breath” although your breathing rate and oxygen level are actually normal – is a fairly common early side-effect of stimulant medications.  It can be produced by several overlapping mechanisms:

•  Mild over-stimulation of the brain‐stem respiratory center (the drug is nudging you to breathe a little faster/deeper than you really need).  
•  Increased “sympathetic tone” (the same adrenaline-like effect that can raise pulse and blood pressure tightens chest wall muscles and makes you more aware of every breath).  
•  An anxiety loop: the odd sensation makes you anxious → anxiety makes you hyper-ventilate or tighten chest muscles → the sensation gets worse.  

In most people this fades after the first few days to two weeks as the body acclimates or after the dose is adjusted.  However, any persistent or worsening shortness of breath must be taken seriously because dangerous conditions (asthma, allergic reaction, pulmonary embolus, etc.) can feel similar.

1.  When to seek medical help immediately  
   • Audible wheezing, persistent cough, chest tightness or pain  
   • Breathing so hard you can’t speak full sentences, rapid breathing > 25/min, blue lips/fingertips  
   • Dizziness, fainting, racing heart > 120–130 at rest, hives/ swelling of face or throat  

2.  Call / message your prescriber soon (don’t wait for the next routine visit) if  
   • The “air hunger” lasts longer than a week, keeps you from sleeping, singing, exercising, or is simply intolerable.  
   • You notice new or marked anxiety, agitation, or chest pounding.  
   • You had the same problem on Concerta – that pattern suggests you may not tolerate stimulants well and a lower dose, a slower titration, or a non-stimulant option (atomoxetine, guanfacine, bupropion, etc.) might be better.

3.  Practical things you can try right now  

   Dose-related  
   • If today’s dose is more than yesterday’s, drop back to the lower dose tomorrow and tell your psychiatrist; many people need a slower titration than the package insert suggests.  
   • Take the capsule earlier in the morning (7–8 a.m.) and always with food and plenty of water.  
   • Avoid additional stimulants the same day (coffee, energy drinks, decongestants).

   Breathing/relaxation tricks  
   • “4–7–8” breathing (inhale 4 s through nose, hold 7 s, exhale slowly 8 s through pursed lips) or any diaphragmatic/ singer’s breath exercise.  Doing 5–10 cycles every hour can reset CO₂ levels and break the hyper-ventilation loop.  
   • Sit upright, let the belly expand on inhale, consciously relax the upper chest and shoulders on exhale.  
   • Humidified air or steam (hot shower) will ease the dry, tight feeling stimulants sometimes cause in the airway.  

   General measures  
   • Stay well hydrated; stimulants are mildly dehydrating and dry mucosa can amplify the sensation.  
   • Light aerobic activity (a brisk 10-minute walk) often “uses up” the extra sympathetic drive and normalizes breathing.  
   • Mindfulness apps / progressive muscle relaxation can keep the anxiety component in check.

4.  Keep notes  
   Record dose, time taken, when the air hunger starts, how long it lasts, heart rate, and anything that helps or worsens it.  A short log greatly helps your psychiatrist fine-tune the plan.

5.  What about your other medicines?  
   • Zoloft and Lamictal rarely cause dyspnea by themselves, but Zoloft can raise baseline anxiety for some people; stimulants may accentuate that.  
   • Hormonal IUD isn’t relevant here.  
   • There is no dangerous interaction between these drugs that would be expected to impair lung function, but high combined doses of serotonergic or adrenergic drugs can increase restlessness and subjective shortness of breath.

Bottom line: Mild “air hunger” is a known early stimulant effect and often improves within days, but because shortness of breath can signal serious problems you should (1) discuss it with your prescriber right away, (2) consider backing down to the last comfortable dose, and (3) use paced-breathing, hydration, and light exercise to blunt the sensation in the meantime.  If the feeling escalates or you develop any red-flag symptoms, seek urgent medical care.

166.question: Hi. I just wanna have some guidance in advance if someone can help me :(This hadn't happened to me since March 2020. It happened again last week and sometimes I do feel a bit drowsy or weird but haven't had a full on focal seizure again.What I experienced was:Nausea I saw an aura, or like static? on my right eye that then turned into colors.   My limbs went cold I had a deja vu sensation, like I started to think things I hadn't thought of in two years? I don't know how to explain it I lost all peripheral vision on my right eye for a good while.Speaking was difficult Almost lost consciousness (in 2020 I did lose consciousness and moved my eyes from side to side very rapidly and my face went droopy last time). Back then I went to the ER and they couldn't find anything. Since it never happened again I didn't go see a neurologist but the other day it happened twice so I immediately booked an appointment.
166.answer:
I’m glad you have already arranged to see a neurologist; that really is the key next step.  
While you’re waiting, the points below should help you understand what might be happening, prepare for your visit, and keep yourself safe in the meantime.

1. What your description sounds like  
   • A “focal seizure with impaired awareness” (formerly called a complex-partial seizure) is high on the list. Typical clues:  
     – Aura or visual “static/colours” on one side → activity starting in the occipital or temporal lobe.  
     – Déjà-vu, odd memories, nausea → common temporal-lobe seizure symptoms.  
     – Speech arrest, eye deviation, brief loss of awareness.  
   • Other possibilities that can look similar:  
     – Migraine aura/“ocular migraine” (usually lasts 5-60 min and often followed by a headache).  
     – Transient ischemic attack (TIA) or small stroke.  
     – Metabolic causes (blood-sugar swings, electrolyte disturbances, etc.).  
   Only a careful history plus tests (EEG, MRI, sometimes blood work) can sort these out.

2. What to track right now  
   Bring a brief, factual log to your appointment. It should include:  
   • Date/time of each spell, how long it lasted, and anything you (or a witness) saw—especially eye/head turning, speech issues, jerking, or confusion afterward.  
   • Triggers: lack of sleep, flashing lights, stress, alcohol, missing meals, illness, new medications or supplements.  
   • Recovery: how long until you felt fully normal? Headache afterward? Fatigue?  
   • Phone video: If a trusted person can safely record an event, that 10–30 sec clip is often more helpful than pages of notes.  
   • Current meds (prescription, OTC, herbal), caffeine/alcohol/drug use, and medical history.

3. Safety until you are cleared  
   • Do not drive, climb, swim alone, work at heights, or operate power tools. Most jurisdictions require seizure-free periods before driving; waiting now avoids legal trouble later.  
   • Shower rather than bathe.  
   • Let a roommate, partner, or coworker know what to do (roll you onto your side, track duration, call EMS if a seizure lasts >5 min or clusters without recovery).  
   • Set phone alarms for meds, meals, and sleep—sleep deprivation is a common trigger.  
   • Limit alcohol and avoid abrupt withdrawal from caffeine, benzodiazepines, or sleep meds.

4. When to go straight back to the Emergency Department  
   • A single episode lasting >5 minutes or back-to-back episodes without full recovery (risk of status epilepticus).  
   • New weakness, numbness, slurred speech, or vision loss that does NOT clear within minutes (possible stroke/TIA).  
   • Severe, sudden “worst headache,” high fever, or head injury.  
   • Persistent vomiting or inability to keep anti-seizure medicine down (if one is started).

5. What the neurologist is likely to do  
   • Detailed history & exam.  
   • EEG—ideally a routine EEG soon; sometimes 24-hour or ambulatory monitoring if routine EEG is nondiagnostic.  
   • Brain MRI with epilepsy protocol (higher resolution, looks for subtle lesions).  
   • Blood tests (electrolytes, glucose, CBC, liver/kidney function).  
   • Depending on results, they may start an anti-seizure medication or observe.  

6. Living with the uncertainty  
   • Most focal seizures are controllable once the cause is found.  
   • If it turns out to be migraine aura, preventive or abortive migraine therapy can help.  
   • TIAs require vascular risk work-up and treatment to prevent stroke.  
   • Keep stress manageable—regular exercise, hydration, consistent sleep schedule.

Key takeaway: You did the right thing booking a neurologist quickly. Keep a meticulous diary, prioritize safety, and seek immediate help if episodes lengthen or new deficits appear. With good documentation you’ll give the neurologist the best chance to reach the correct diagnosis and get you treated promptly.

167.question: I’m male, age 19, BMI currently 18.5, location: USA, my issues began at age 12 right after puberty, however, I would get moments of AIWS and vomiting in the middle of the night prior around age 7, I eat fine and have no family history of stroke or blood clot disorders, I have a healthy BMI, and my blood and heart have been tested at 12 and were fine. I think I also have non-epileptic seizures from anxiety due to the different characteristics of PNES vs ES. However, when I was 12 right after puberty, I would wake up in the middle of the night unable to understand speech and I had depersonalization, trembling, ptosis (one eyebrow or eyelid drooping usually in the morning after sleep) and sometimes blurry vision, usually accompanied by AIWS and panic attack, however, at random days I would get blurry vision easily, all these problems were usually accompanied by a food intolerance and would significantly improve a few minutes after passing stool, yet require a day or two to fully subside. Now at 19 I still get these symptoms but much more mild, after eating a food I’m intolerant to, I get slightly blurry vision and panic, then when I slept I woke up in the middle of the night with panic/depersonalization/trembling and restricted circulation and my hearing sounded a little foggy and I had slight trouble understanding words and whenever someone looks at or talks to me I panic and have to hide in my room to block out the sensory, my mouth is also numb and eating food feels weird and gives me a panic attack and then I have to go to the bathroom, after passing stool of the irritating food, the symptoms elevate significantly, I get back the feeling sensation in my mouth and body but just feel very subtly numb for the rest of the day.
167.answer:
What you describe is complicated and no single condition can be blamed with 100 % certainty from an Internet description, but several patterns stand out that are well-known to neurologists and gastroenterologists:

1.  A “migraine-spectrum” picture  
   • Alice-in-Wonderland Syndrome (AIWS), transient aphasia (not understanding speech), depersonalization, blurry vision, ptosis, numbness and panic that come and go are all reported migraine auras.  
   • Migraine auras can last minutes to hours, sometimes longer, and often improve after sleep.  
   • Classic migraine triggers include many foods (aged cheese, chocolate, MSG, gluten or wheat in some people, nitrates, artificial sweeteners), stress and irregular sleep—matching your “intolerance → symptoms → improve after bowel movement” story.  
   • Nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain (so-called “abdominal migraine”) are especially common in children and can persist into adulthood.  
   • AIWS is almost always benign but is most commonly linked to migraine, Epstein–Barr/viral illness or seizures.

2.  Possible focal (partial) seizures vs. psychogenic nonepileptic seizures (PNES)  
   • Temporal-lobe or occipital-lobe seizures can cause déjà-vu, derealization, micro/macro-opsia, speech arrest, panic, autonomic symptoms, and may cluster during sleep.  
   • An EEG done while you are asymptomatic can be normal; sometimes prolonged EEG or EEG with video is required.  
   • PNES tend to last longer and show certain behavioral markers, but only a neurologist with EEG can separate the two with confidence.

3.  Autonomic / mast-cell / histamine or other food-mediated reactions  
   • Histamine or mast-cell mediated reactions, celiac disease/gluten sensitivity, or irritable-bowel-syndrome can cause flushing, tachycardia, brain-fog, panic-like sensations and improve after defecation.  
   • They frequently coexist with migraine because histamine and CGRP are common biochemical pathways.

4.  Rule-outs that warrant at least one good work-up  
   • True neurologic causes of ptosis (partial Horner’s, myasthenia gravis, third-nerve palsy)  
   • Metabolic causes (thyroid disorders, B-12 deficiency, hypoglycemia)  
   • Structural brain problems (tumor, AVM) – unlikely but need one MRI/MRA in anyone with repeated focal neuro deficits.  
   • POTS / dysautonomia, which peaks in late teens, can make you feel panicky when upright and is often associated with GI triggers.

Why the bowel movement helps  
Food triggers set off intestinal nerves and inflammatory mediators (histamine, serotonin, CGRP). For some people, once the offending material is out of the bowel the autonomic storm calms, the vagus nerve stops firing excessively, and migraine or seizure threshold rises again—so symptoms fade quickly.

What to do next – a structured plan

1.  See a neurologist  
   • Bring a diary (time of day, food eaten, GI symptoms, neuro symptoms, level of stress/sleep) for at least two weeks.  
   • Ask for:  
     – MRI/MRA brain (one good scan with and without contrast is enough if normal)  
     – EEG or, if events are nightly/weekly, 24-hour video-EEG or ambulatory 72-hour EEG to rule out focal epilepsy.  
   • If migraine is suspected: discuss preventive options (propranolol, topiramate, amitriptyline, CGRP monoclonals, lifestyle) and abortive therapy (triptans, gepants, ditans, NSAIDs, anti-nausea). Frequent nighttime awakenings sometimes improve dramatically on prophylaxis.

2.  Consider allergy / immunology / GI assessment  
   • Celiac panel (tTG-IgA ± total IgA); serum tryptase, histamine level or a therapeutic trial of low-histamine diet; testing or empiric trial for small-intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) or IBS treatment.  
   • An elimination-and-re-challenge diet (keep gluten, dairy, soy, eggs, nuts, chocolate, caffeine, processed meats, artificial sweeteners out for three weeks, then add back one at a time).

3.  Basic laboratory screen (if not done within a year)  
   CBC, CMP, fasting glucose, ESR/CRP, TSH & free T4, vitamin B-12, folate, 25-OH vitamin D, ferritin, cortisol a.m., lipid profile.

4.  Address anxiety / panic overlay  
   • Even when neurological, repeated frightening episodes condition the brain to over-react.  
   • Cognitive-behavioral therapy or acceptance & commitment therapy plus regular aerobic exercise, breath work, and sleep hygiene often reduce the “secondary” panic layer and thereby the overall severity.

5.  Red-flag situations that should take you to an ER immediately  
   • New or worst-ever headache, sudden one-sided weakness or numbness, slurred speech lasting >1 hour, vision loss in one eye, true vertigo with inability to walk, continuous vomiting leading to dehydration, or any loss of consciousness >1–2 minutes.  
   • Rapidly progressive ptosis with double vision could indicate a cranial nerve III palsy or myasthenic crisis.

Key lifestyle cornerstones while the work-up proceeds  
• Regular sleep, hydration, daily aerobic activity, consistent balanced meals.  
• Limit caffeine and alcohol.  
• Keep screens dim at night; blue-light filtering glasses may help if you are visually sensitive.  
• Magnesium glycinate 400 mg bedtime, riboflavin 400 mg/day and coenzyme Q10 100–300 mg/day have mild evidence for migraine prevention and are generally safe at your age.

Bottom line  
The pattern is most suggestive of food-triggered migraine with prolonged aura and strong autonomic features or, less likely, focal seizures/PNES. Both are treatable, but sorting them out requires (1) a good neurologic evaluation with at least one imaging study and a quality EEG, and (2) systematic identification and elimination of dietary triggers. While you are arranging that assessment, keep a meticulous diary and avoid the foods you already know bring on attacks. Seek emergency care if any episode is markedly worse, new or lasts longer than usual.

168.question: So I was diagnosed with Epilepsy last August and put on Keppra 1000mg twice a day. I did not like how it made me feel, so they moved it to once a day. Still, at times I feel foggy....seeming almost drunk. I was wondering if this is normal or maybe I was taking it at the wrong time of day. Should I take with food? Should I take before bed? I am not on any other meds except Motrin 800 for fake hip. Please let me know what you would recommend. Thank you in advance. I am a 41 year old male, 190 pounds and not a smoker.
168.answer:
I’m not your prescribing physician, so I can’t change your treatment plan, but I can give you some practical information to discuss with your neurologist.

1. Is the “foggy / drunk” feeling a known Keppra (levetiracetam) side-effect?  
Yes. Sleepiness, dizziness, “mental clouding,” and problems with concentration occur in about 10-20 % of patients, especially in the first months or when the dose is increased. Most people either (a) adapt within a few weeks or (b) need a different dose or a different drug.

2. Does the way you’re taking it matter?  
A lot. There are two common formulations:

• Immediate-release (IR) tabs – half-life 6–8 h → must be taken twice a day (q12 h).  
• Extended-release (XR/ER) tabs – designed for once-daily dosing.

If you were given the standard IR tablets but are now taking the whole 1000 mg only once a day, you get a high peak level for several hours (more side-effects) and then a long trough (less seizure protection) before the next dose. That alone can explain why you feel “drunk” at times and foggy at others.
