If you really need a once-daily schedule, ask whether the XR version is suitable for you. Otherwise, most neurologists would split the dose into 500 mg in the morning and 500 mg 12 h later (or a different total dose such as 750 mg × 2 or 1000 mg × 2, depending on seizure control and tolerance).

3. Timing with food / bedtime  
• Keppra can be taken with or without food; food slightly slows absorption and flattens the peak, which can lessen side-effects in some people.  
• Many patients take the evening dose right before bed so the sedating peak occurs while they’re asleep. If you go back to twice-daily dosing, try: breakfast dose + pre-bedtime dose.  
• Keep the two doses ~12 h apart (e.g., 8 am and 8 pm).

4. Other things to keep in mind  
• Kidney function: Keppra is cleared through the kidneys. If you have impaired kidney function the drug can accumulate and cause more side-effects; a simple creatinine / eGFR blood test tells your doctor whether dose adjustment is needed.  
• Drug interactions: Ibuprofen (Motrin) doesn’t interact with Keppra. Alcohol, however, can amplify the “drunk” feeling.  
• Fatigue, sleep deprivation, and stress themselves can worsen both seizures and Keppra side-effects—keep a regular sleep schedule if possible.

5. What you can do right now  
• Keep a daily log: time you take the dose, what you eat, any symptoms, any seizure activity. Patterns often jump out.  
• Call or message your neurologist’s office and tell them exactly what’s happening. Ask:  
  – “Am I on the immediate-release tablets or the XR?”  
  – “Would you prefer I go back to twice a day, or switch to XR 1000 mg once daily at night?”  
  – “Could we try a slightly lower total dose (e.g., 750 mg × 2) or a different medication if side-effects don’t improve?”  
• Never stop Keppra abruptly—doing so can provoke seizures.

6. When to seek help immediately  
• Sudden mood changes with suicidal thoughts or severe irritability (rare but well-described).  
• Worsening dizziness to the point of falling, slurred speech, or confusion that you or others can’t snap out of (could be drug toxicity or even seizure activity).  
• Any new or different seizure pattern.

Key takeaway: The feeling you describe is common and often a dosing-schedule problem. The immediate-release form almost always works best split into two equal doses about 12 hours apart, preferably with the second dose at bedtime and/or with food. Discuss switching to divided dosing or to the XR version, and let your neurologist know how the current regimen is affecting your quality of life.

169.question: Age - 30   Sex - male    Height - 5'8"-174 cm    Weight - 60 kgs.    Duration of complaint - 3 years    Location - Soft palate    Any existing relevant medical issues - Subjective Tinnitus caused by olanzapine and an MRI scan   Current medications - Cinolazepam for sleep, Mysoline for the myoclonus. Is palatal myoclonus treatable?
169.answer:
Palatal myoclonus (also called palatal tremor) is an uncommon movement disorder in which the muscles of the soft palate (and sometimes the throat and middle-ear muscles) contract rhythmically. It can be annoying in its own right and can also generate an audible “click” or a pulsing noise that is heard as tinnitus.

1. Two different forms – different outlooks  
• Essential (primary/idiopathic) palatal myoclonus  
  – No structural lesion on MRI.  
  – May fluctuate or even remit spontaneously in a minority of patients.  
  – Treatability is better.  
• Symptomatic (secondary) palatal myoclonus  
  – Caused by a lesion of the so-called Guillain-Mollaret triangle (dentate nucleus-red nucleus-inferior olive), usually visible on MRI.  
  – The palatal movements can become virtually “hard-wired” and often persist even after the lesion itself has stabilized.  
  – Treatment is aimed at palliation rather than cure.

2. First step – confirm the exact type  
An up-to-date MRI of the brainstem and cerebellum, reviewed by a neurologist familiar with movement disorders, tells you whether there is an underlying lesion. This matters because it sets realistic expectations.

3. Symptom-directed treatments  
There is no single “curative” pill, but several approaches can reduce or abolish the movements (often after some trial-and-error):

A. Medication  
   • Benzodiazepines – clonazepam (most studied), diazepam, or your current cinolazepam.  
   • Anticonvulsants/movement-disorder drugs  
     – Primidone (Mysoline), which you are already taking.  
     – Valproate, carbamazepine, levetiracetam, gabapentin, lamotrigine, topiramate.  
   • 5-HT-precursor agents – some small reports with tryptophan.  
   Effectiveness: 20-60 % get meaningful relief; sedation and cognitive side-effects can limit the dose.

B. Botulinum-toxin injections  
   • Under EMG or endoscopic guidance the toxin is injected into the levator veli palatini (and, if needed, tensor veli palatini) muscles.  
   • Success rates around 70-90 % for both the rhythmic movement and the ear noise.  
   • Effect lasts 3–6 months; repeat injections are usually straightforward.  
   • Main temporary side-effects: hyper-nasal speech, mild swallowing or nasal-regurgitation problems for a few days.

C. Less-common surgical/ablative options  
   • Radiofrequency ablation, laser coagulation, or sectioning of the pharyngeal branch of the vagus have been reported when botulinum toxin fails, but these are considered last-resort; risk of permanent velopharyngeal insufficiency.

D. Supportive measures  
   • Speech-therapy tricks (yawning, certain vocal exercises) sometimes give temporary suppression.  
   • Stress management, adequate sleep, and avoidance of stimulants can lessen the amplitude.  
   • If a clicking tinnitus is troubling at night, a masking sound or soft in-ear noise generator can help.

4. How “treatable” is it realistically?  
• Essential palatal myoclonus: roughly 50 % can be brought to minimal or no symptoms with medication ± botulinum toxin, and a few patients remit completely over time.  
• Symptomatic palatal myoclonus: medication alone seldom abolishes it, but botulinum toxin gives worthwhile relief in most patients; the underlying neurological lesion usually does not “heal,” so ongoing management is the rule.  
• Complete and permanent cure is uncommon, but long-term control good enough for normal daily life is achievable for the majority with current techniques.

5. Practical next steps for you  
1. Review your latest MRI with a movement-disorder neurologist to classify essential vs. symptomatic.  
2. Make sure your primidone dose is optimized; if partial relief only, discuss a trial of clonazepam or levetiracetam.  
3. Arrange an ENT/neurology referral to a center that can perform botulinum-toxin injections if medicines aren’t sufficient.  
4. Keep a symptom diary: severity, triggers, drug doses, sleep quality; this helps fine-tune therapy.  
5. Continue follow-up for your tinnitus; sometimes controlling the palatal movements decreases the perceived noise.

Bottom line  
Palatal myoclonus is usually controllable, though not always curable. Many patients eventually find a regimen (often botulinum toxin plus or minus medication) that leaves the twitching and the associated tinnitus at a tolerable or barely noticeable level. Work closely with a neurologist and an otolaryngologist who have experience with this rare disorder to sort out the best strategy for you.

(Information provided for educational purposes; it is not a substitute for personal medical care.)

170.question: Hi there. I was hoping someone could give me some input on an MRI view. I have access to the MRI so if anyone wants another image, I can view it. This is my most recent MRI, Jan 2021. I also have a disk with the MRI/MRA/MRV I had in 2019 History: 32F. I have a CVST in 2019 on the right side of my brain. This included my superior sagittal sinus, part of my transverse sinus, my sigmoid sinus, and then went down into my jugular. I’m heterozygous Factor V Leiden. Other than that I didn’t get any real information on the cause. I had a DVT in 2012. My eye doctor says my peripheral vision in my right eye isn’t great. I recently was diagnosed with epilepsy, being complex partial seizures that originate in my right temporal lobe. I get de ja vu, kinda black out, zone out. Sometimes I can tell when this happens, other times I have been driving and suddenly not known where I was. Apparently I clench my teeth often, and I also sometimes stutter randomly, like I’ll say “and” a bunch of times in a row for no reason. Around the time the CVST happened, I developed some symptoms that I don’t know if they’re related (but I blame stress). These include temperature regulation issues, mostly when I sleep. Sleep paralysis/some hallucinations/terrors. And insomnia, which I think is just from fear of sleep paralysis. My psychiatrist did say I was having something called exploding head syndrome, which again, I think is just me mentally being terrified to sleep and I jolt myself out of sleeping. The temperature thing includes randomly burning up or freezing, sometimes sweating. Blanket amount and house temp don’t seem to vary this. My boyfriend will either cover me in blankets or ice packs. I have passed out from the heat part if I try to get up. The cold part, I just shake and chatter. These are all ongoing. I currently take Eliquis, propranolol, Keppra, and have taken Vyvanse, Xanax, prazosin, and Ambien, all as prescribed. I stopped taking the Vyvanse about six months ago. The Xanax is occasionally, and the Ambien is rarely. I take vitamin D and a B complex. I drank occasionally but since the epilepsy diagnosis, have cut back. I don’t do any other drugs. Warfarin made me bleed insanely and Zonisamide made me extremely sick. My neurologist wants to send me to Cornell or similar and I guess I’m just trying to avoid everything with Covid going on if I can. Sorry if this post is a little wonky, I’m going on about two days of no sleep. I will try to clarify any questions. Edit: oh I’m 5’4, white, and 180lbs. I put on weight since the CVST. I was originally around 140-150lbs. I used to get severe migraines, since I was a child. I would lose vision, not be able to speak, and it felt like someone beat my head in. Since seeing my new neurologist in 2019 and being diagnosed with the CVST and medicated with Eliquis, I have rarely had migraines.
170.answer:
I’m not your physician and I can’t give you a formal reading of the scan, but I can walk you through what the treating team will be looking for on the January 2021 study, explain how those findings fit (or don’t fit) with the symptoms you’re having, and suggest the kinds of next-steps most neuro-vascular / epilepsy centers (Cornell, Columbia, Hopkins, Mayo, etc.) usually take in a case like yours. Use it as a checklist for discussion with your own neurologist / radiologist.

1. What the radiologist will focus on in a follow-up brain MRI/MRV after a prior CVST  

   a. Patency of the venous sinuses  
      • Superior sagittal, right transverse, right sigmoid, right jugular bulb.  
      • They’ll describe whether the thrombus has completely lysed (normal flow void on MRI, contrast filling on MRV) or whether residual clot, web, or focal stenosis remains.  
      • A chronic organized clot may look like a T1/T2 isointense “plug,” sometimes calcified, and the sinus lumen may be narrowed or irregular.  
      • If there is persistent high-grade narrowing, some centers consider endovascular venous stenting, especially if intracranial pressure is elevated or headaches/visual field loss persist.  

   b. Evidence of prior venous infarction / encephalomalacia  
      • Common in the parasagittal or temporal regions if the draining vein was involved.  
      • Chronic infarct = volume loss, cortical irregularity, gliosis (T2/FLAIR bright, T1 dark).  
      • This scar tissue can be an epileptogenic focus (fits with right temporal onset seizures).  

   c. New parenchymal lesions  
      • Search for anything that could also provoke seizures: low-grade tumor, cortical dysplasia, cavernous malformation, hippocampal sclerosis.  
      • The report should mention hippocampal asymmetry or signal change specifically.  

   d. Signs of raised intracranial pressure  
      • Partially empty sella, optic nerve sheath distention, flattening of the posterior globes, enlarged Meckel’s caves.  
      • These correlate with papilledema / peripheral vision loss.  

2. How the scan might explain your current symptoms  

   • Complex partial (focal impaired-awareness) seizures: déjà vu, automatisms, jaw clenching, speech arrest/stuttering, brief “lost” periods while driving → classic right temporal lobe. A scar in that region gives you both the EEG focus and the MRI correlate.  
   • Autonomic storms at night (flushing, chills, drenching sweats) can be part of temporal-lobe seizures or post-ictal phenomena. Keeping a seizure diary, or wearing an ambulatory EEG patch for several days, can show whether they coincide with ictal discharges.  
   • Sleep-onset hallucinations / exploding-head are often benign parasomnias, but anything that fragments sleep (Keppra, anxiety, nocturnal seizures) makes them worse.  
   • Propranolol and Keppra can each cause cold extremities or hyperhidrosis in some patients, but the “hot/cold” swings you describe are more dramatic than typical side-effects, so exclude nocturnal seizures first.  

3. Why a tertiary-care (Cornell-level) referral is reasonable  

   • You have TWO problems: a) chronic venous thrombosis with a thrombophilia (heterozygous Factor V Leiden + prior DVT) and b) medically refractory or newly evolving focal epilepsy.  
   • Centers with an integrated neurovascular + epilepsy program can:  
     – Perform high-resolution MRV or venography to decide if endovascular sinus reconstruction might help headaches/vision.  
     – Offer 3-Tesla epilepsy-protocol MRI, PET, or MEG to map the seizure focus more precisely.  
     – Do long-term video-EEG to prove nocturnal events are seizures and gauge frequency.  
     – Discuss surgical / laser ablation / neurostimulator options if seizures persist despite meds.  

4. Medication-related points to raise  

   • Eliquis (apixaban) is a reasonable lifelong choice given recurrent venous thrombosis history; warfarin intolerance makes DOAC preference clear.  
   • Vyvanse lowers seizure threshold; holding it was prudent until epilepsy is stable.  
   • Keppra often controls post-stroke/venous-infarct seizures but can aggravate insomnia, irritability, and parasomnias; alternatives include lamotrigine, lacosamide, or brivaracetam.  
   • If nocturnal events turn out to be seizures, adding a bedtime-weighted AED (clobazam, extended-release topiramate, or Perampanel) sometimes helps without daytime sedation.  

5. Red-flag imaging findings that would mean “go NOW despite COVID”  

   • Any new diffusion-restricted area (acute infarct).  
   • Expanding hemorrhage, large venous varix, or new mass lesion.  
   • Progressive narrowing of the dominant remaining venous outflow tract with signs of intracranial hypertension (papilledema, severe headaches, visual field decline).  

6. Practical next steps while you wait  

   • Ask your radiologist/neurologist for: “Comparison with prior 2019 study—please comment specifically on (1) sinus patency, (2) right temporal lobe parenchyma, (3) intracranial pressure stigmata.”  
   • Get a formal visual-field test (automated perimetry) every 6–12 mo if papilledema or sinus stenosis persists.  
   • Keep a seizure/event diary; note temp swings, sweats, confusion upon waking, and look for patterns.  
   • Wear a medical alert bracelet: “Anticoagulation (Eliquis), Seizure disorder.”  
   • Continue vitamin D; aim for BMI reduction if possible—obesity is an additional thrombosis and ICP risk factor.  

Bottom line  
1. The MRI/MRV should tell whether the venous system has recanalized and whether there is a structural scar that matches your seizure focus.  
2. Right temporal lobe scarring from the 2019 CVST can fully explain complex partial seizures and many “autonomic” night episodes.  
3. Persistent sinus obstruction or raised ICP could account for peripheral vision loss.  
4. Because you have overlapping neurovascular and epilepsy issues, a comprehensive center visit is justified; if the January scan shows no acute change, you can schedule it electively once COVID logistics permit, but do not defer if there’s fresh clot, new infarct, or worsening papilledema.  

Take the radiology report plus this checklist to your neurologist and decide together whether to expedite referral. Hope this helps you feel more prepared when you review the images with your team.

171.question: This last year at the ripe age of 32 I developed a myriad of health complications. Primarily nuerological comlications such as myoclonus, seizures, and a serious case of insomnia. Thankfully I am improving now. I was in excellent former health and this came on like wildfire. For 6 months I was in and out of hospitals. I had 6 MRIs done, 4 lumbar punctures, and 7 CT scans in the span of 6 months. The majority of the diagnostics were of low clinical yield and I was empirically treated for autoimmune conditions & epilepsy. I often feel that the excessive imaging(CT) only added insult to injury. I know this is already said and done and there's nothing I can do about it now, but im hoping maybe someone with a bit of knowledge and insight on the subject could ease my nerves about cancer risk etc. Below are the scans preformed and parameters that were made available to me. Where do I stand I'm comparison to radiation workers, patients treated with radiation therapy or gamma procedures, pilots, surviovors of eratic radiation exposure etc. I want to put these worries to rest and move forward with my life. Yes it's a simple as nothing I can do now but move forward and enjoy life. I'm just hoping to hear some people who may have gone through it and shared these worries that your all ok, or for someone with a background and focus in radiation(be it medicine, physics, engineering, etc)to tell me my worries are irrational. CT scans August 16th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 1005.29 September 22nd - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 799 September 23rd - Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis Total Exam DLP: 652 September 25th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 763 November 15th - Chest/abdomen/pelvis W contrast Total Exam DLP: 1291.11 CONTRAST: 80 mL of Iohexol Inj 80 mL November 18th - Full body PET scan Total Exam DLP: A fuck load December 15th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 881.17
171.answer:
Short version  
All the imaging you had in that hectic six-month period probably gave you a total “whole-body-equivalent” radiation dose of somewhere between 40 and 60 mSv.  
• That is well below the annual legal limit for radiation workers (50 mSv/yr in the U.S.).  
• It is thousands of times lower than the doses people receive during radiation therapy or those that cause radiation sickness.  
• Using the most conservative cancer-risk model we have (the linear-no-threshold model) it might add roughly 0.2–0.3 percentage points to your lifetime chance of getting cancer (from ~40 % to ~40.2–40.3 %).  
Statistically that increase is so small that it is very hard to measure in real populations, and for a 32-year-old it is unlikely ever to be noticed. In other words: you have not meaningfully harmed your future health by having those scans, and you can safely put the worry away.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
How the numbers were obtained
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Converting the CT DLPs you listed to effective dose  

   (k-factors from ICRP 103 – they vary slightly from table to table, so I give ranges)

   Head scans     k ≈ 0.002 mSv / (mGy · cm)  
   • 1005 mGy·cm  →  ~2.0 mSv  
   •  799 mGy·cm  →  ~1.6 mSv  
   •  763 mGy·cm  →  ~1.5 mSv  
   •  881 mGy·cm  →  ~1.8 mSv  
   Total head ≈ 7 mSv  

   Chest/Abd/Pelvis   k ≈ 0.015 mSv / (mGy · cm)  
   •  652 mGy·cm  →  ~10 mSv  
   • 1291 mGy·cm →  ~19 mSv  
   Total torso ≈ 29 mSv  

2.  PET/CT on 18 Nov  

   • Typical diagnostic CT that accompanies a PET gives 10–15 mSv, sometimes less if it is “attenuation-correction-only”.  
   • The injected 18-F-FDG (half-life 110 min) adds ~5–7 mSv.  

   Taking the higher end for reassurance: PET/CT ≈ 20–25 mSv.

3.  Grand total  
   About 7 mSv (heads) + 29 mSv (torsos) + 25 mSv (PET/CT) ≈ 60 mSv.  
   If your PET/CT CT part was low-dose the total could be as low as ~40 mSv.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Putting 40–60 mSv in perspective
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Background and everyday comparisons  
• Average natural background in the U.S. ≈ 3 mSv per year.  
  → You received about 15–20 years of background all at once.  

Occupational limits  
• U.S. radiation worker limit: 50 mSv in any single year, 100 mSv over 5 years.  
  → Your dose is similar to one “allowed” heavy year for a nuclear-plant worker.  

Aircrew / frequent fliers  
• Airline pilots accumulate 2-5 mSv each year.  
  → A senior pilot can exceed your six-month dose after 10–20 years in the cockpit.  

Medical therapy / high-dose exposures  
• Curative radiotherapy: 50,000–70,000 mSv to the tumour area (not a typo).  
• Threshold for acute radiation sickness: about 1,000 mSv in a short time.  
  → Your dose is <1/15th of that threshold and <0.1 % of a radiotherapy course.

Chance of causing a future cancer  
A rough, deliberately pessimistic estimate:

   Excess Lifetime Risk (%) ≈ Dose (mSv) × 0.005 % per mSv  
   → 60 mSv × 0.005 % ≈ 0.3 % (1 chance in ~330).  

Baseline lifetime cancer risk in the U.S. is ~40 % (1 in 2.5).  
So your personal lifetime risk might go from 40 % to 40.3 %.  

Even this tiny number is likely an overestimate, because:  
• You are an adult (cancer induction is higher in children).  
• Modern scanners use dose-modulation; the conversion factors already build in a safety margin.  
• The linear-no-threshold model assumes every photon is harmful; it is used for prudence, not because we see clear evidence at these dose levels.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
What you can do now
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Nothing special is required: no screening beyond what your doctors would already recommend for anyone else your age and sex.  
• Keep any imaging records; if you ever need another CT you can remind your physicians you recently had several so they can avoid repetition or use MRI/US when suitable.  
• Live normally—statistically the things that most influence your future cancer risk are still smoking status, exercise, diet, vaccines (HPV, hepatitis), sun protection, etc., not the scans you already had.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Key take-away
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The scans were medically justified at the time, they did not push you anywhere near doses that cause deterministic (immediate) harm, and they give you at most a very small theoretical bump in lifetime cancer probability—smaller than many ordinary lifestyle choices. From a radiation standpoint you can safely close the book on this episode and move forward.

172.question: Suddenly, everywhere I look, people are touting the benefits of stimulating the vagus nerve. What is the vagus nerve, and what does it actually do? Does stimulating it actually have all these positive effects people claim? (Stimulating digestion, lowering blood pressure, helping anxiety, etc.) 35/F/white/115 pounds/sertraline/Canada. Is stimulating the vagus nerve bullshit?
172.answer:
The short version  
• The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is the main “rest-and-digest” highway that carries signals between the brain and most of the internal organs.  
• A surgically implanted vagus-nerve stimulator is an FDA-approved medical treatment for drug-resistant epilepsy and for treatment-resistant major depression.  
• Outside of those two indications, the evidence is still early or mixed. Some physiologic effects are real (slower heart rate, modest fall in blood pressure, changes in gut motility, anti-inflammatory signaling), but that does not mean the everyday “DIY vagus hacks” you see on social media have been proven to treat disease.  
• Practices such as slow breathing, humming, or cold‐water face splashes probably help mainly because they produce a general relaxation response, not because they are specifically “stimulating” one precise nerve. They are safe to try but shouldn’t be counted on as primary therapy for medical problems.

The longer explanation  

1. What exactly is the vagus nerve?  
• Origin: It leaves the brainstem just behind the ear (between the medulla and the jugular foramen).  
• Course: Two branches (right and left) run down the neck beside the carotid arteries, through the chest, and into the abdomen.  
• Coverage: sensory and motor fibers to the voice box, heart, lungs, esophagus, stomach, liver, pancreas, small intestine, colon, and even immune-cell clusters in the gut. Roughly 80 % of its fibers are sensory—carrying information from the body to the brain—while 20 % are motor (brain to body).  
• Function: cornerstone of the parasympathetic (“rest and digest”) nervous system. Main jobs:  
  – Slows the heart rate and can lower blood pressure a little.  
  – Constricts airways slightly.  
  – Stimulates stomach acid, pancreatic enzymes, bile release, and intestinal peristalsis.  
  – Sends “fullness” and “inflammation” signals back to the brain.  
  – Helps modulate the immune system via the so-called “cholinergic anti-inflammatory pathway.”

2. How do doctors actually stimulate it?  
A. Implanted (invasive) VNS  
   • A pulse generator (like a pacemaker) is placed under the skin in the left upper chest; a wire wraps around the left vagus nerve in the neck.  
   • FDA-approved for:  
        – Drug-resistant focal epilepsy (since 1997).  
        – Treatment-resistant major depressive disorder (2005).  
   • Typical settings: 20–30 Hz bursts, 30 s on / 5 min off, 24 h a day.  
   • Side-effects: hoarse voice, cough, throat tickle, sometimes sleep apnea or heart rhythm changes.

B. Non-invasive VNS devices  
   • Hand-held (gammaCore) that presses over the carotid/vagus area in the neck—approved for cluster headache and migraine in several countries.  
   • Ear-clip devices that target the auricular branch of the vagus (still experimental).

3. Claimed benefits versus current evidence  

Digestion  
• Physiologically, vagal activity stimulates stomach acid and gut motility.  
• Clinical trials: small studies in diabetic gastroparesis show mixed results; not an established therapy.  
• Paradox: implanted VNS sometimes causes nausea or delayed gastric emptying—so we are clearly not at the point of prescribing it for routine digestive issues.

Blood pressure / heart health  
• Acute VNS can drop heart rate and systolic BP by ~5–10 mmHg, but the effect is transient.  
• Long-term hypertension trials are small and inconsistent; antihypertensive drugs remain far superior.  
• Heart-failure studies are ongoing; one major trial (NECTAR-HF) showed improved quality of life but no change in ejection fraction.

Anxiety, mood, and PTSD  
• For major depression, there is moderate evidence (hence FDA approval after failure of ≥4 meds).  
• Anxiety disorders: pilot studies only. Some benefit is suggested, but not enough for guideline endorsement.  
• PTSD: experimental.  
• Non-device approaches (slow breathing, meditation) improve anxiety for many people, but the mechanism is multifactorial (cognitive, hormonal, autonomic), not exclusively “vagus stimulation.”

Inflammation / autoimmune conditions  
• Animal data are strong; human data are preliminary. Small studies in rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn’s disease show reduced inflammatory cytokines, but we don’t yet have large controlled trials.

Metabolism / obesity  
• Vagal blockade (the opposite of stimulation) was tried for weight loss (EnteroMedics vBloc) but results were underwhelming; the device was withdrawn. Stimulation sometimes causes weight loss indirectly (nausea, early satiety), not reliably enough to prescribe it for obesity.

4. “Bio-hacks” you see online and what they really do  

Deep, slow diaphragmatic breathing  
• Slows heart rate variability in a pattern that improves “vagal tone” scores on monitors.  
• Safe, clearly relaxes people; likely helps by reducing sympathetic (fight-or-flight) output more than by directly zapping the vagus.

Humming, chanting “Om,” singing, gargling  
• They activate the muscles in the throat that are partly supplied by vagus branches; evidence is anecdotal. Again, the relaxation/mindfulness component probably dominates.

Cold water on the face (“diving reflex”)  
• Temperature receptors signal via the trigeminal nerve to brainstem centers that co-activate vagal output to the heart—slows the pulse a bit. The effect is short-lived but real.

Yoga, Tai Chi, meditation, exercise  
• All improve heart-rate variability and subjectively enhance calm. The vagus is one piece of a larger stress-reduction puzzle.

Fermented foods / “gut vagus axis”  
• Interesting microbiome-immune-nerve research but still speculative. No specific probiotic has proven clinical benefit through vagal pathways yet.

5. Bottom line for you (35 y/o, on sertraline, otherwise healthy)  
• If you enjoy breathing exercises, singing, cold showers, or meditation, keep doing them—they are low-risk ways to dial down overall stress physiology.  
• Don’t count on them to fix hypertension, IBS, or anxiety disorders by themselves. They’re complementary, not replacements for evidence-based care.  
• If someone tries to sell you an expensive ear clip or neck stimulator for general wellness, know that the science is still thin outside a few niche neurologic uses.  
• If you ever hear of VNS as a treatment option for depression that isn’t responding to medication, that is legitimate—but it requires surgery, specialist evaluation, and discussion of pros/cons.

So: “Stimulating the vagus nerve” is not pure snake oil—there really is a nerve and doctors really do stimulate it—but most of the broad lifestyle claims you see on social media are over-promised extrapolations of much narrower, early-stage science.

173.question: i was diagnosed when i was young with a seizure thing that goes away when youre 13, which impairs my ability to concentrate and gave me seizures while im sleeping about once every blood moon and my mom told me it was epilepsy, but see the thing is that shes not very good with english, and i have never had any trouble with seeing flashing lights. is it possible to have epilepsy but no trouble with seeing flashing colors?
173.answer:
Short answer  
Yes.  The great majority of people who have epilepsy have no problem at all with flashing lights.  Photosensitive epilepsy (the kind triggered by flickering or striped patterns) is just one relatively uncommon form.

Why the “flashing-lights” myth sticks around  
• TV news stories and warning labels (“may trigger seizures in people with epilepsy”) have made photosensitivity well known.  
• But only about 3 – 5 % of all people with epilepsy are truly photosensitive.  
• For the other 95 – 97 %, seizures happen for other reasons (sleep deprivation, illness, missing medication, or for no clear trigger at all).

How epilepsy is actually defined  
Epilepsy = a tendency to have unprovoked seizures (two or more) due to abnormal bursts of electrical activity in the brain.  
The type of seizure, the age it shows up, and what can trigger it vary a lot.

What you describe sounds closer to one of the “self-limited childhood epilepsies”  
Examples:  
• Benign (self-limited) Rolandic epilepsy / Benign epilepsy with centro-temporal spikes  
 – starts 3-13 y, often during sleep, facial twitching, drooling, speech arrest, most kids outgrow it by mid-teens.  
• Childhood absence epilepsy  
 – brief staring spells multiple times a day, often affects attention in class, 60-80 % outgrow it in adolescence.  

Both of these:  
• Usually are NOT triggered by lights.  
• Can make concentrating harder (from brief seizures, broken sleep, or medication).  
• Commonly improve or disappear in the teenage years, though follow-up is still wise.

What to do now  
1. Get the exact name of your past diagnosis if you can (old clinic notes, EEG report, ask your pediatric neurologist or family doctor).  
2. Even if you “outgrew” it, schedule one check-in with a current neurologist, especially if:  
 • you still have any spells at night, “spacing out,” or memory blanks;  
 • you’re thinking of driving, drinking alcohol, or operating machinery;  
 • you need proof for school, sports, or employment.  
3. Keep general seizure-smart habits: consistent sleep, manage stress, limit alcohol/recreational drugs, take any prescribed meds exactly as directed.  
4. If concentration problems persist, discuss them; sometimes they’re from subtle seizures, sometimes from ADHD, anxiety, or medication side-effects—each treated differently.

Bottom line  
Epilepsy covers many conditions; light-triggered seizures are just a small subset. Having seizures only during sleep and trouble concentrating is entirely compatible with epilepsy that is NOT photosensitive. A quick review with a neurologist can confirm whether you’re truly in the clear or still need occasional follow-up.

174.question: Does radiation necrosis heal? 31 female 155 lbs Diagnosed w/ Brain AVM & 2 aneurysms 2009. - 3 gamma knife treatments in 2019. edications: Topamax, Trileptal, Zoloft, Wellbutrin, Clonidine, Vyvanse, Vitamin D, Folic Acid & had Kyleena IUD replaced February 16th. - important because vision symptoms started could be coincidence. Shortly after I had my new iud put in I started having issues with my left eye, vision became blurry”ish” on and off. For the next 3 weeks I Had slow thought processing during the time & some confusion. - Hard time finding words. I also had some “left neglect” symptoms but that’s normal for me when I get migraines because my left side goes numb so I related all of this to stress & the migraines until I started having muscle twitching in my left hand & wrist. - I started to improve end of March but My vision is still off sometimes & I’m not as sharp as I used to be. I Had an eeg in April which showed slowing, which I feel like is normal.. but I just had a follow up MRI & this is the report.. is someone able to explain it to me? No one has ever told me I had radiation necrosis. I guess I was always under the assumption my brain would heal itself after my radiation… but 4 years later it just seems to be getting worse. Does radiation necrosis heal/is it dangerous? Could this just be swelling? Did is progress fast from January 2022-April 2023? 4.. Since I’m not getting blood flow there is it basically the same thing as a ischemic stroke? What is FLAIR hyperintensity? Those are just questions off the top of my head. I don’t see a dr until June and google is not my friend.
174.answer:
Below is general information based on what patients with an AV-malformation treated by stereotactic radiosurgery (Gamma-Knife) often ask when the follow-up MRI mentions “radiation necrosis”.  It is NOT a substitute for the opinion of your treating team, who know the exact location, size and evolution of your lesion.

----------------------------------------------------
1. What exactly is “radiation necrosis” (RN)?
----------------------------------------------------
•  After stereotactic radiosurgery the high-dose beam injures the abnormal vessels but can also damage nearby normal brain.  
•  Months to years later the small blood vessels in that zone can close off, the tissue becomes chronically under-perfused, inflammatory cells move in and part of the tissue dies – that late injury is called radiation necrosis.  
•  It is usually accompanied by a rim of swelling (edema) around it.

----------------------------------------------------
2. How common is it and when does it appear?
----------------------------------------------------
•  After a single Gamma-Knife session the risk is roughly 5-10 %.  
•  After multiple sessions (you had three) the risk is higher – some series quote 15-25 %.  
•  Most cases start between 6 months and 3 years; progression can still be seen up to 5-6 years.  So being 4 years out is well within the typical window.

----------------------------------------------------
3. Does it heal?  Will it keep getting worse?
----------------------------------------------------
•  The truly necrotic (dead) core does not “grow back”; the brain will not regenerate that section.  
•  What CAN change is
  – the amount of surrounding edema/inflammation, which can shrink with treatment or even spontaneously, and  
  – the ability of the rest of your brain to reroute functions (neuro-plasticity), so symptoms may improve even if the scar on MRI does not.  
•  Most patients reach a plateau: the lesion enlarges for months to a couple of years, then stabilises or slowly shrinks.  Some show partial or even near- complete radiological regression, especially if treated with steroids or bevacizumab (see below).

----------------------------------------------------
4. Is it dangerous?
----------------------------------------------------
•  It can be, mainly because:
  – The swelling can raise local pressure and trigger seizures, weakness, visual or cognitive changes (exactly the kinds of symptoms you describe).  
  – Very large areas of RN in eloquent cortex can leave a permanent neurological deficit.  
•  It is NOT a cancer and it does not “spread”, but it deserves treatment and close follow-up when symptomatic.

----------------------------------------------------
5. Could this just be swelling and not necrosis?
----------------------------------------------------
•  On MRI the core of RN often enhances after contrast and is surrounded by a bright FLAIR signal (edema).  Advanced MRI (perfusion, diffusion, MR-spectroscopy) or PET can help separate “pure” edema from frank necrosis.  
•  In many patients there is a mixture: a necrotic centre plus a variable halo of reversible edema.  Treatments are aimed mainly at the edema.

----------------------------------------------------
6. Is it basically the same as an ischaemic stroke?
----------------------------------------------------
•  Both conditions end with tissue death from lack of oxygen, but:
  – Ischaemic stroke is sudden – a blood vessel is blocked by a clot.  
  – Radiation necrosis is slow – radiation gradually injures the vessel wall, closes capillaries and sets up chronic inflammation.  
•  Clinically the end result (a permanent scar) is similar, but the tempo, imaging appearance and treatment differ.

----------------------------------------------------
7. What does “FLAIR hyperintensity” mean?
----------------------------------------------------
•  FLAIR is an MRI sequence that suppresses pure fluid so anything that still looks bright must contain excess water IN tissue (edema), gliosis or demyelination.  
•  In your report the FLAIR hyperintensity is the swelling around the necrotic core.

----------------------------------------------------
8. Has it progressed fast between Jan 2022 and Apr 2023?
----------------------------------------------------
•  You did not post the exact numbers, but radiologists usually note the maximal dimensions or volume.  
•  An increase of a few millimetres in diameter or a visible thickening of the surrounding FLAIR signal over 12-15 months is typical rather than “very fast”.  
•  Ultimately the trend is more important than one measurement; therefore most centres repeat MRI every 3–6 months while the lesion is active.

----------------------------------------------------
9. Why does my EEG show “slowing”?
----------------------------------------------------
•  A chronic scar or surrounding edema interferes with the normal, fast electrical rhythm, so slowing over the right hemisphere (for instance) often matches a right-sided RN seen on MRI.  
•  It is a common, non-specific finding and does not necessarily mean on-going seizures.

----------------------------------------------------
10. How are the symptoms treated?
----------------------------------------------------
Step-wise approach most centres follow:

a) Observation
   – If you have mild, stable symptoms and the lesion is not large, your doctors may simply watch and repeat imaging.

b) Corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone)
   – Quickly shrink edema, often improve vision, speech, strength within days.  
   – Used short-term because of side-effects (weight gain, mood, infection risk, diabetes).

c) Bevacizumab (Avastin)
   – A monoclonal antibody given by IV infusion every 2-3 weeks for 4–6 cycles.  
   – In several studies it reduced both edema and contrast enhancement in 60-80 % of symptomatic RN patients and allowed steroid taper.

d) Hyperbaric oxygen, pentoxifylline + vitamin E, laser interstitial thermal therapy (LITT) or open surgical resection
   – Considered when symptoms are severe or refractory.

e) Rehabilitation
   – Occupational, physical and speech therapy help the uninjured parts of your brain take over.

----------------------------------------------------
11. Does the Kyleena IUD, Topamax, etc. influence RN?
----------------------------------------------------
•  No evidence that a levonorgestrel IUD, Topamax or the other listed drugs provoke or worsen radiation necrosis.  
•  However, Topamax and Zoloft can each cause word-finding difficulty in some patients, and Topamax may affect vision (angle-closure glaucoma, myopia).  A routine eye exam can rule out an ocular cause of blurred vision.

----------------------------------------------------
12. When should I seek medical attention before June?
----------------------------------------------------
•  Any new or rapidly worsening left-sided weakness, neglect, vision loss, severe headache, continuous seizures, marked confusion or personality change deserves urgent evaluation – you may need steroids or even hospital admission.

----------------------------------------------------
Key take-aways
----------------------------------------------------
•  Radiation necrosis is a known late complication of stereotactic radiosurgery; it peaks 1–5 years after treatment.  
•  The dead core does not revive, but the associated swelling is often reversible, and symptoms can improve.  
•  It is not a cancer and usually stops enlarging after a few years, but while active it can mimic a tumour or stroke and can be debilitating.  
•  Multiple effective treatments exist – most patients end up with either a smaller, stable scar or at least much less edema and better function.  
•  Keep your follow-up appointment, but do not hesitate to call sooner if symptoms escalate.

Write down your current questions, bring someone with you to the visit, and ask your neurologist/neurosurgeon about:
– the exact size/volume trend between each MRI,  
– whether you should start a steroid trial now,  
– whether perfusion MRI or MR-spectroscopy would clarify how much of the lesion is active edema versus permanent necrosis, and  
– whether bevacizumab or another treatment is appropriate in your case.

I hope this helps you interpret the report and reduce “Google anxiety” until you see your doctors.  Wishing you a smooth recovery.

175.question: Sex: M Age 48 Weight 235lbs Height: 6ft 2" non smoker, non drinker epilepsy since birth, had his hemispheres separated about 15 years ago. Takes anti-depressant (can't remember the name) and Tegertol for seizures. I have been with my husband for 11 years, married for 10 years, so I haven't been a part of his entire journey, but I am here for the rest of it! He has been having increasing seizures in the last 7 years, and the neurologist just ups his meds. December of last year he had a big one. I had to call an ambulance because his active seizure was over 15 minutes. He stayed in a postectal state for over 5 hours. They did a CT scan, and it shows an area of calcification, and his neurologist said that is normal and unchanged.What I have noticed is that before his more major seizures, he will have a bad headache that advil or tylenol will not touch. Then a few hours later, he will have a seizure that will last between 3-5 minutes, with a postectal state ranging from 10 minutes to an hour.Is this something that can even be fixed or managed better? Is it just part of living with someone with epilepsy?
175.answer:
I’m sorry you and your husband are going through this.  Below is some background that should help you understand what may be happening and what practical steps you can take with his medical team.

1.  The headaches that precede the seizures  
   •  In many people a “pre-ictal” or “prodromal” phase occurs hours to days before a seizure.  Common symptoms are mood change, anxiety, irritability, fatigue, or headache.  
   •  The headache can be a type of “ictal headache” (the seizure itself is starting in the pain pathways) or a migraine-like phenomenon triggered by the abnormal electrical activity that is building in the brain.  
   •  It usually means a seizure is coming, but it is not dangerous in itself.  If seizure control improves, the headaches usually improve as well.

2.  Seizures lasting >5 min and post-ictal confusion >1 h  
   •  Any convulsion that lasts >5 minutes should be treated as an emergency (“status epilepticus”) because the odds of it stopping spontaneously drop sharply after the 5-minute mark.  
   •  Every patient at risk for prolonged seizures should have a prescribed “rescue” medicine at home (rectal diazepam, intranasal midazolam, or dissolvable clonazepam) and clear instructions on when to use it.  
   •  Post-ictal confusion lasting several hours is not uncommon after a prolonged or generalized tonic-clonic seizure, but prevention is far better than letting it happen.

3.  “We just keep increasing the Tegretol” is a red flag  
   •  Tegretol (carbamazepine) is an excellent drug for some focal epilepsies, but it is more than 50 years old, has complex drug interactions, and its blood level must be checked.  
   •  Carbamazepine can induce its own metabolism (“auto-induction”): the blood level may fall even though the dose is unchanged, especially in the first months after a dose adjustment.  
   •  After two appropriately chosen and dosed antiseizure medicines have failed, a patient is classified as having drug-resistant (refractory) epilepsy.  Roughly 1 in 3 people fall into this category.  Simply escalating the same drug is usually futile and exposes the patient to more side-effects.

4.  He needs a comprehensive reassessment at an Epilepsy Center (Level 3 or Level 4)  
   A work-up typically includes:  
   •  Detailed history and seizure diary review (triggers, prodrome, duration, recovery).  
   •  High-resolution MRI with epilepsy protocol (even if prior scans were “unchanged”).  
   •  Continuous video–EEG monitoring to capture and identify where the seizures start.  
   •  Laboratory check of current drug levels, liver/kidney function, sodium, etc.  
   •  Review of all other medications (some antidepressants can lower seizure threshold or interact with carbamazepine).  
   •  Neuropsychological testing and mood screening (depression itself can worsen seizure control).

5.  Options that may be offered once he is evaluated  
   a.  Medication optimization  
       –  There are >20 modern antiseizure drugs (levetiracetam, lamotrigine, lacosamide, brivaracetam, perampanel, cenobamate, etc.).  Many have fewer side effects and may work where carbamazepine does not.  
       –  Polytherapy (judicious combination of 2 drugs with different mechanisms) often helps.  
   b.  Rescue plan  
       –  A written seizure action plan and an at-home benzodiazepine rescue medication.  
   c.  Device therapy  
       –  Vagus Nerve Stimulator (VNS), Responsive Neurostimulation (RNS), or Deep Brain Stimulator (DBS) can reduce seizure frequency by 40-70 % in appropriate candidates.  
   d.  Diet therapy  
       –  Modified Atkins or ketogenic diet can be helpful, even in adults, when supervised.  
   e.  Additional surgery  
       –  Fifteen years ago he apparently had a corpus callosotomy.  In some cases focal resection or laser ablation of the true seizure focus is still possible if imaging and EEG localize it.  
   f.  Clinical trials of new medications or devices.

6.  Practical things you can do now  
   •  Keep a seizure diary: date, time, headache beforehand, duration, recovery time, any triggers (missed sleep, stress, illness, missed dose, flashing lights, etc.).  
   •  Make sure he never misses a dose; use alarms or pill-boxes.  
   •  Prioritize adequate sleep, hydration, and stress management; fatigue is a major trigger.  
   •  Check with the pharmacist for interactions between his antidepressant and Tegretol.  
   •  If he is overweight (BMI≈30), weight loss can improve sleep apnea, which in turn improves seizure control.  
   •  Learn and practice seizure first aid and discuss SUDEP (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy) prevention measures (supervised sleep, seizure-detecting devices, good control).  
   •  Schedule an appointment (or ask for a referral) to a comprehensive epilepsy center rather than a general neurology clinic; many centers have waiting lists, so start the process soon.

7.  What is “realistic”?  
   •  Total seizure freedom is always the goal, even in people who have had epilepsy for decades.  If that cannot be achieved, a ≥50 % reduction in frequency/severity is usually possible with modern therapy.  
   •  Accepting frequent, prolonged convulsions as “just how it is” is no longer the standard of care.  Better management is almost always possible.

Key take-home message: The worsening pattern you describe, especially the 15-minute seizure in December, justifies a thorough reevaluation by an epilepsy specialist team.  Headaches before seizures are common, but the seizures themselves need better control, and that very often can be achieved with the right combination of modern medications, rescue therapy, and (if necessary) surgical or device-based treatments.

I hope this gives you a clearer roadmap for advocating for your husband.  Bring this information to his current neurologist and ask specifically for a referral to a Level 3–4 Epilepsy Center so the two of you can explore all available options.

176.question: i'm a caucasian 23 year old female, 5'6" 115 lbs, taking oral BC, trintellix, vyvanse, keppra, and ranitidine (yeah, i kno). things like this have been going on for as long as i can remember. other than the fact that i'm epileptic, i really don't have any other underlying physical conditions that, to my knowledge, would cause this issue. i'm not really active unless you count standing around at work all day. i don't drink, smoke, or do any illicit drugs. i vape though...shhhh.so basically, i'm having what the title says. and when i mean constant, multiple times per day, anywhere on the body, with physical exertion or without.for example, today, i reached behind me to close a damn sliding cabinet door and got a wicked charley horse in my tricep. it throbbed for a few hours after. i'll lean my body to one side, maybe to reach for something further away and i'll get horrible contractions around my neck, upper back, shoulders, you name it. from seemingly normal and not excessively exerting actions.other times, i'll be sitting cross legged in bed, looking at reddit, and out of nowhere, my foot will flip out and the muscle that runs along the tendon on the bottom of the foot will tense like crazy and i'll have to stop what i'm doing to try to relax it, because as i'm sure a lot of people know, charley horses kinda continue to contract unless you move the body part in the opposite way or whatnot.i will get painful muscle contractions ANYWHERE. i get them in my throat muscles if i swallow something funny. i'll get them in my uterus (indiscriminate to my cycle and it feels way different than menstrual cramps). i'll get them in my BUTTHOLE MUSCLES. those are absolutely horrendous because i'll be in excruciating pain for 10-30 seconds and kind of have to position myself around and hold my breath until they relax. i get them in my fingers, wrists, calves, thighs, upper and lower abdomen, pretty much anywhere there's muscle.feel free to ask any other relative questions. i'm really just looking for insight and if anyone else is familiar with something like this.
176.answer:
What you are describing is more than the ordinary “my calf cramped last night” that most people occasionally get.  
Frequent, painful, fast-triggering cramps involving many different voluntary muscles (calf, foot, hand, face, trunk) and even some smooth-muscle structures (uterus, anal sphincter, part of the esophagus) point to a state of “muscle hyper-excitability.”  That state can be produced by several very different problems, and figuring out which one applies to you requires a step-by-step medical work-up.

1.  COMMON, EASILY MEASURABLE CAUSES  
   • Electrolyte or mineral deficiencies  
     – Low magnesium, calcium, potassium, or (less often) sodium or phosphorus all make nerves and muscles fire too easily and cause cramping.  
     – Women on oral contraceptives, people who vape/smoke a lot of nicotine, anyone who is chronically a bit dehydrated, and people who take acid-suppressing drugs such as ranitidine can all end up magnesium- or calcium-deficient without realizing it.  
   • Vitamin-D deficiency or severe vitamin-B12 deficiency.  
   • Thyroid disorders (both hypo- and hyper-thyroidism).  
   • Kidney disease (changes the way electrolytes are handled).  
   • Side effects or drug interactions  
     – Stimulants (Vyvanse), SSRIs/SNRIs (Trintellix), and sometimes Keppra can all list “muscle spasm or cramp” among their adverse-effect profiles.  They don’t do it in everyone, but if you already have a predisposition they can tip you over the edge.  

   FIRST THINGS TO CHECK (simple blood tests)  
   CBC, CMP (includes kidney function, sodium, potassium, chloride, bicarbonate), ionized calcium, magnesium, phosphorus, TSH & free T4, vitamin-D (25-OH), B12, CK (muscle-breakdown marker).

2.  NERVE / CHANNEL DISORDERS (“PERIPHERAL NERVE HYPER-EXCITABILITY”)  
   If routine labs are normal, the next tier is a neurologic evaluation:  
   • Cramp-fasciculation syndrome or benign cramp syndrome  
   • Isaacs’ syndrome (neuromyotonia)  
   • Paramyotonia congenita or other skeletal-muscle channelopathies (sometimes seen in people who also have epilepsy because the ion channels involved are relatives of those in brain cells).  
   These are diagnosed with a neurologic exam, EMG/NCS testing, sometimes antibody panels or genetic tests.  Many respond to specific drugs (carbamazepine, mexiletine, gabapentin) or to immune therapy if an autoimmune form is present.

3.  HORMONAL / METABOLIC STATES  
   • Hyperparathyroidism / hypoparathyroidism (calcium swings)  
   • Pregnancy (not an issue here)  
   • Severe iron deficiency

4.  PELVIC-FLOOR & SMOOTH-MUSCLE SPASTICITY  
   – Proctalgia fugax (sudden anal sphincter spasm) and esophageal spasm are actually quite common and harmless, but the fact you get *many* other skeletal-muscle cramps suggests they are part of the same hyper-excitable state rather than isolated problems.

WHAT YOU CAN DO RIGHT NOW (while you arrange a work-up)
• Hydration: 2–3 L water/electrolyte fluid per day, more if you stand all day.  
• Diet: foods rich in magnesium (nuts, seeds, legumes, dark greens), potassium (bananas, potatoes, avocado), and calcium (dairy, fortified alternatives).  
• Over-the-counter magnesium glycinate 200–400 mg at night often helps—clear it with your physician first, particularly because you take Keppra (rarely interacts, but best to confirm).  
• Daily gentle stretching of the major muscle groups; brief stretches before you reach, lift, or twist at work.  
• Warm shower or bath and a heating pad to quiet muscles before bed.  
• Check nicotine/caffeine: both lower magnesium and constrict blood vessels; cutting back can lessen cramps.  
• Keep a symptom/drug/diet log for 2 weeks so you and your doctor can see whether a medication dose change, dehydration day, or menstrual phase is tied to worse symptoms.

WHEN TO SEEK PROMPT MEDICAL CARE
• Cramps are accompanied by true muscle weakness, dark cola-colored urine, or swelling (could be rhabdomyolysis).  
• You develop numbness, tingling, or new balance problems (possible nerve disorder).  
• Any evidence of low-calcium tetany (tingling lips, carpopedal spasm, facial twitch when you tap your cheek).  
• If lab work shows large electrolyte disturbances.

BOTTOM LINE
Frequent whole-body muscle cramps like yours are almost never “just bad luck.”  They are usually due to an electrolyte/mineral problem, a medication effect, a thyroid/parathyroid issue, or a (treatable) nerve/muscle channel disorder.  Start with your primary-care physician or neurologist for the blood-work panel listed above and a medication review; if those are unrevealing, ask for an EMG/NCS study to look for a peripheral-nerve hyper-excitability syndrome.  In the meantime, aggressive hydration, magnesium/potassium-rich nutrition, stretching, heat, and nicotine/caffeine reduction give many patients noticeable relief.

177.question: Age:20F Had been epileptic for 6 years but last seizure I had was 2 years ago.I have been getting this weird episodes for years now. I suddenly get a weird feeling of an attack/episode is going to happen, and then, I get this strong deja vu feeling about the situation I'm in has already happened, it sort of repeating? I suddenly get overwhelmed with fear and it comes along with panic attack. Heart palpitations, breathing problems(hyperventilation perhaps?), and then I don't really remember what happens. I'm confused after the episode about what really happened or triggered it. It last for an hour or so. It happens in sleep as well sometimes. Usually I end up sleeping after the episode since I get tired everytime it happens. Though, It affects me badly that I'm in fear all day, cause there seems to be lingering of that episode, like it's about to happen again.Yesterday I got about 5 or more episodes like that. 2 while sleeping I'm wondering if it's just because of anxiety issues(simply panic attacks) or is it related to Epilepsy? I have been taking medication once regularly- I take Levetiracetam-750
177.answer:
What you describe sounds much more like focal (partial) epileptic seizures coming from the temporal lobe than “just” panic attacks.

Why these episodes fit epilepsy

1. Typical temporal-lobe aura  
   • Sudden warning that “something is about to happen”  
   • Powerful déjà-vu or “this has happened before” sensation  
   • Intense, unprovoked fear

2. Autonomic symptoms  
   • Heart racing, stomach flip, breathing changes – common when the seizure focus is in or near the amygdala/hippocampus.

3. Altered awareness / memory gap  
   • You cannot recall parts of the event and feel confused afterward (post-ictal period). Panic attacks do not usually leave an amnestic gap.

4. Post-ictal fatigue and need to sleep  
   • Very typical after a seizure; uncommon after panic alone.

5. Occur out of sleep  
   • Genuine panic attacks almost never start from deep sleep; focal seizures often do.

6. Clustering and brief duration  
   • You sense the actual “spell” is short, but the fog afterward makes the total experience feel longer.

Your current medication / dose

• Levetiracetam 750 mg ONCE a day is a low dose for once-daily (XR) therapy and sub-therapeutic if you are on the regular (immediate-release) tablets.  
• Standard adult dosing of immediate-release Keppra is 500-1,500 mg TWICE a day (total 1,000-3,000 mg/day).  
• If you are on the XR preparation, 1,000-3,000 mg once daily is usual.  
• In other words, you may simply not have enough drug in your system to fully suppress seizures.

What to do now

1. Contact your neurologist (or see one urgently if you are not currently followed).  
   • Tell them you are having multiple focal seizures a day, including out of sleep.  
   • You likely need a dose increase, a switch to a twice-daily schedule, or an additional medication.

2. Ask for an up-to-date EEG or, ideally, a video-EEG study to capture an event.

3. Do NOT drive, swim unsupervised, climb, or be in dangerous situations until you are clearly seizure-free again.

4. Keep a seizure diary: date/time, awake or asleep, description, possible triggers, recovery time.

5. If a single episode lasts >5 minutes, or you have back-to-back events without returning to normal, go to the emergency department. That is an evolving seizure cluster/status epilepticus.

6. Basic seizure-trigger hygiene  
   • Take medication strictly on time.  
   • Get regular sleep.  
   • Avoid alcohol/recreational drugs.  
   • Manage stress and illness.

Could anxiety still be involved?

Certainly. Many people develop “anticipatory anxiety” or even true panic disorder after living with epilepsy. You may feel anxious all day because you are dreading another spell. But the core events themselves look epileptic; treat the seizures first, then see what anxiety remains.

Bottom line

Treat these as breakthrough temporal-lobe seizures until a neurologist proves otherwise. With the right medication dose (or combination) most patients regain full control. Please arrange follow-up promptly and stay safe in the meantime.

178.question: Age: 18 ex: Female Height: 150 Weight: 51kg Race: Arab Duration of complaint: a week ny existing relevant medical issues: anemia Current medications: iron pills, beef liver pills, blood building pills. original complaint  When I inhale I feel like my brain is full and nourished and healthy, but when I exhale it gradually worsens and I become very lightheaded and dizzy, I’m talking about normal breathing rates, not meditation breathing or fast rapid breathing, normal breaths.. I can’t sleep because of it, it makes my brain feel like it’s about to fall, like it’s falling, and sometimes I feel my brain vibrating, sometimes I feel an electrical feel going through my brain and moving, it feels like something is gonna happen like a seizure cause it feels like theres too much, like a sudden gush or surge of chemicals or something rushing into my brain and it’s gonna make me have a seizure or something, im not epileptic but there are times when I wake up my body is completely jerking non stop and uncontrollable, my jaw my hands, all of it, it lasts for seconds, and I can’t speak or make a voice, it’s like non stop jerking and twitching and shaking and my jaw constantly jerks along with my body, idk if this is related to what I’m feeling in my brain but iv had these “jerks” since a long time
178.answer:
I’m not able to give you a diagnosis online, but I can lay out the most common explanations for what you’re feeling, why they might be happening together, which warning signs mean “go to the ER now,” and what sort of tests and specialists you should discuss with your own doctor as soon as possible.

1. What could be happening when you inhale vs. exhale  
   • Normal physiology:  
     – When you breathe IN, pressure in the chest drops. More blood returns to the heart, cardiac output rises for a moment, and slightly more blood reaches the brain.  
     – When you breathe OUT, especially if you breathe out a little forcefully, the opposite occurs: venous return and cerebral blood flow dip for a moment.  
     – Most people never notice this transient change.

   • Why you might notice it:  
     – Moderate-to-severe iron-deficiency anaemia (low haemoglobin) already limits how much oxygen your blood can carry. Any tiny drop in flow (during exhalation) can leave the brain briefly under-perfused → light-headed, “brain falling,” buzzing feeling.  
     – Low blood volume or autonomic dysfunction (seen in conditions such as POTS, dehydration, heavy periods, some thyroid disorders) exaggerates the same effect.  
     – Hyper-focusing on breathing because of anxiety or insomnia can also lead to unintentional slight over-breathing (hyperventilation). This lowers CO₂, which in turn constricts brain blood vessels and produces tingling, dizziness and “electric” sensations.

   None of the above is usually dangerous, but the sensations can feel dramatic.

2. The “jerks” or shaking spells on waking  
   • Benign sleep myoclonus (hypnic jerks): very common, brief, conscious, no post-event confusion.  
   • Sleep paralysis with myoclonic activity: you are awake, can’t speak, body jerks for a few seconds. Again, usually benign but scary.  
   • Epileptic seizures: Typically last ≥30 s, you lose awareness, may bite tongue, may be confused afterward. Need EEG to confirm or rule out.

   From what you describe (brief, seconds long, you remember it clearly, happens on waking), benign sleep myoclonus fits better than epilepsy, but only a neurologist can be certain.

3. Problems that need to be ruled out promptly  
   • Haemoglobin <8–9 g/dL or ferritin <15 µg/L (severe iron-deficiency).  
   • Cardiac rhythm problems (arrhythmia).  
   • Dysautonomia / POTS.  
   • Generalised seizure disorder.  
   • Electrolyte or vitamin deficiencies (B12, folate, magnesium).  
   • Thyroid disease.

4. What to ask your doctor for this week  
   • Vital signs: seated and standing pulse/BP.  
   • Full CBC, ferritin, B12, folate, thyroid panel, electrolytes, glucose.  
   • ECG; consider echocardiogram if any murmur or palpitations.  
   • Neurology referral: clinical exam ± EEG, especially if events last >20 s or you ever lose awareness.  
   • Sleep history; consider sleep study only if jerks are frequent/violent.

5. Things you can do right now (if your doctor agrees)  
   • Make sure you’re taking the right iron dose (about 65 mg elemental iron once or twice daily, taken with vitamin C, away from calcium-rich foods).  
   • Hydrate well and add a bit more salt to your diet unless you have a reason to restrict sodium.  
   • Gentle slow nasal breathing (in 4 s, out 6 s) rather than forceful exhalations; this keeps CO₂ from dropping too low.  
   • Avoid caffeine late in the day and keep a regular sleep schedule to reduce insomnia and anxiety-driven hyper-awareness of breathing.  
   • Keep a symptom diary: time of day, body position, recent meals/drinks, stress level, meds taken, how long the jerks lasted, whether you were aware/confused afterwards.

6. Red-flag signs—go to the emergency department if you notice any of these  
   • Passing out or near-syncope.  
   • A shaking episode that lasts >1 minute, especially if you don’t recall it or bite your tongue or lose bladder control.  
   • Sudden severe headache, visual loss, slurred speech, facial droop.  
   • Palpitations + chest pain or shortness of breath.  
   • Vomiting blood or black tarry stools (possible GI bleeding from iron deficiency).

Bottom line  
Your symptoms can be produced by a combination of significant iron-deficiency anaemia, mild hyperventilation, and benign sleep myoclonus, but other conditions (seizure disorder, cardiac rhythm problems, dysautonomia) must be ruled out. Arrange follow-up with your primary doctor within the week, bring a written description of your symptoms, and ask specifically for blood work, orthostatic vitals, ECG, and a neurology opinion. Seek urgent care immediately for any red-flag event listed above.

179.question: So I’ve had three grand mal seizures so far, they happened once a year since 2017 and i went to see a doctor after the third time it happened. I was out with friends when suddenly i got a feeling like i was gonna throw up and the next thing i know i was lying on the ground with a deja vu feeling that i blacked out on a party. I did a MRI which came out normal and two EEGs, one sleep deprived, in which there was some abnormal activities on my left side of the brain. I came back to my neurologist with all the medical reports but he referred me to another neurologist because he wasn’t specialised for epilepsy cases. The investigations have been now dragging on for a year so i started to do a bit of research on my own. I came across the temporal lobe epilepsy and suddenly everything made sense. When i was younger i had those strange feelings from time to time that every sound seemed aggressive and urgent, i got really annoyed by them and usually went to bed where the ceiling was strangely far away and my hands bigger. Anyways I always thought that this was normal stuff. Then I remembered about the times when i had unusual breakdowns when i was a kid, e.g. i refused to go to a place i was visiting every week, without a reasonable explanation. Also I’ve been having deja vu’s quite often e.g. i am scrolling through my phone when suddenly i know exactly what I’m about to see next or have a deja vu about a dream. I also had my tonsils removed (right before my first seizure), because of mononucleosis and other infections. Does this makes any sense? Thanks for any advice
179.answer:
I am not your doctor and cannot make a diagnosis over the Internet, but I can tell you how neurologists usually think through a story like yours and what the next practical steps normally are.

1.  How your description fits the epilepsy “vocabulary”  
   • ­“Grand-mal” (now called tonic-clonic) seizures occurring once a year – those are most often the end-result of a focal seizure that spreads to involve both hemispheres.  
   • ­A sudden “going to throw up” or “rising” feeling, followed by loss of awareness, is a classic temporal-lobe aura.  
   • ­Childhood episodes in which everyday sounds were unbearably loud/urgent, the ceiling looked far away, your hands felt too big/small – these are common perceptual distortions seen in focal aware temporal-lobe seizures (and in the related “Alice-in-Wonderland” syndrome).  
   • ­Frequent déjà vu / “I know exactly what’s coming next” spells are one of the most stereotyped temporal-lobe seizure auras.  
   • ­An EEG that shows “left-sided epileptiform discharges” strongly suggests a seizure focus somewhere in the left hemisphere; the temporal lobe is the commonest place.  
   Put together, the story fits very well with “left focal (probably temporal-lobe) epilepsy with occasional focal-to-bilateral tonic-clonic generalisation.”

2.  Why the MRI can still be normal  
   About one-third of patients with temporal-lobe epilepsy have a completely normal 1.5-T MRI. Very small scars, cortical dysplasias, or hippocampal sclerosis can be missed unless:  
   • ­A high-resolution (usually 3-Tesla) “epilepsy protocol” MRI is done, and  
   • ­The pictures are read by someone who looks at epilepsy scans every day.  
   So a normal MRI does not contradict a diagnosis of focal epilepsy.

3.  Could the tonsillectomy / mononucleosis be related?  
   EBV (the virus that causes mono) can occasionally trigger an encephalitis that leaves a temporal scar, but that is rare and you would usually have been very sick at the time. The tonsillectomy itself is not considered a cause. For most people the two events are simply coincidental.

4.  Why the referral to an “epileptologist” matters  
   Management gets more specialised once:  
   • ­seizures are clearly focal, or  
   • ­they are drug-resistant, or  
   • ­surgery might be an option.  
   Even though you only have one seizure a year, the presence of a focal onset makes it worth seeing someone whose main practice is epilepsy. They will decide whether you need:  
   – An epilepsy-protocol 3-T MRI.  
   – Prolonged video-EEG monitoring (to actually capture a seizure and pinpoint its start).  
   – Blood work for autoimmune or metabolic causes.  
   – Neuropsychological testing (helps in presurgical planning and tracking memory/word-finding functions if seizures come from the left temporal lobe).

5.  Treatment – why waiting carries risk  
   • ­Each tonic-clonic seizure carries a small but real chance of injury, accident, or SUDEP.  
   • ­Even a single focal seizure can affect driving privileges in many countries.  
   • ­The longer the brain keeps seizing, the harder seizures can become to control (the “kindling” phenomenon).  
   Standard practice is therefore to start an anti-seizure medicine (ASM) once a person has had two unprovoked seizures; you have had three. First-line oral options for focal epilepsy include lamotrigine, levetiracetam, lacosamide, carbamazepine, and others. Choice depends on side-effect profile, other medications, mood issues, contraception, etc.

6.  Practical things you can do right now  
   • ­Keep a seizure diary (date, time, warning, trigger, recovery).  
   • ­Avoid known precipitants: sleep deprivation, heavy alcohol, certain stimulants, sudden medication withdrawal, and flashing lights if you know you are sensitive.  
   • ­Make sure at least one family member/friend knows basic first-aid for seizures (turn on side, nothing in mouth, call ambulance if >5 min or injury).  
   • ­If you drive, check legal requirements in your area and with your insurance.  
   • ­Bring someone who has witnessed a seizure to your specialist appointment; eyewitness description is gold.  
   • ­Collect all previous scans/EEGs on a CD so the epilepsy specialist can review them personally.

7.  What to expect at the epilepsy clinic  
   The specialist will re-take the history in detail, review the EEGs, order (or re-read) a 3-T MRI, and discuss starting medication. If medication fails to keep you seizure-free, the next steps (over months, not weeks) can include:  
   – Admission to an epilepsy monitoring unit (EMU) for video-EEG,  
   – PET/SPECT or MEG imaging,  
   – Surgical conference to see whether a small piece of epileptic tissue could be safely removed or ablated, or whether devices such as VNS/RNS/DBS are appropriate.

Bottom line  
Yes—your symptoms, EEG findings, and seizure pattern make very good clinical sense as left temporal-lobe epilepsy with secondary generalisation. A normal MRI does not rule it out. The key now is to (1) get seen by an epilepsy specialist, (2) obtain a dedicated epilepsy MRI/video-EEG if advised, and (3) start preventive treatment rather than waiting for another yearly tonic-clonic. Prompt treatment greatly reduces both immediate and long-term risks.

Bring your records, keep a diary, and push (politely!) for that epilepsy consultation—those are the next concrete steps.

180.question: Hi! So basically, my question is already in my headline. I've got elevated eosinophil levels, my neurologist explained it as though my body is fighting a parasite, but without me having a parasite. I have an appointment with a hematologist in June, but I was wondering if anyone here could have an idea what this means. Age: 26 Sex: Female Height: 1m62/5'3" Weight: 52kg/115lbs Race: Caucasian I don't have any complaints really, aside from being worried, but I'm already on a lot of medication for my epilepsy so I do have side effects from taking those, such as a tingling sensation in my fingers and toes, occasional dizziness (low blood pressure), having trouble falling asleep/having nightmares, loss of appetite... I'm currently on 250mg of Topamax, 2mg of Rivotril and 225mg of Venlafaxine. Thank you. Update: According to my doctor, normal eosinophil levels are up to 8%, mine are 22%. I have no allergies and I haven't been abroad.
180.answer:
What the laboratory found  
• “Eosinophils” are one of the five major types of white-blood cells.  
• Most laboratories report them two ways:  
  1. As a percentage of all white cells (the differential)  
  2. As an absolute number (Absolute Eosinophil Count, AEC = total WBC × % eosinophils).  

Your doctor quoted only the percentage (22 %). A percentage can look dramatic even when the absolute number is not. Example:  
 WBC 6 000/µL × 22 % = AEC 1 320/µL → “mild eosinophilia.”  
 WBC 15 000/µL × 22 % = AEC 3 300/µL → “moderate eosinophilia.”  
So the first thing a haematologist will do is look at (or repeat) the absolute count.

How doctors classify an elevated absolute count  
• Mild: 500-1 500/µL  
• Moderate: 1 500-5 000/µL  
• Severe: >5 000/µL  
Persistent counts ≥1 500/µL for longer than 6 months are called hypereosinophilia and trigger a standard work-up.

Why eosinophils go up  
The mnemonic “CHINA” covers >90 % of causes:

C – Connective-tissue disease / vasculitis  
 (e.g., eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, lupus)  
H – Helminths and other parasites (especially tissue-invading worms)  
I – Idiopathic / primary bone-marrow disorders  
 (myeloproliferative neoplasms, leukemias, the “hypereosinophilic syndromes”)  
N – Neoplasms (solid tumours, Hodgkin & T-cell lymphomas)  
A – Allergy / atopy / asthma & drug reactions  

Where you most likely fit  
• No travel, no GI symptoms ⇒ parasites less likely but still easily ruled out with 3 stool O&P tests and serology.  
• You state you have no known allergies; however “atopy” can be mild or silent. Asthma, eczema, chronic sinusitis or nasal polyps can push eosinophils up even when you feel well.  
• Medications are common culprits. Anticonvulsants (including topiramate / Topamax) and antidepressants (including venlafaxine) are well-documented causes of drug-related eosinophilia. This ranges from a mild lab abnormality to rare but serious hypersensitivity reactions (DRESS: Drug Rash with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms). Absence of rash or fever makes severe drug reaction unlikely, but a simple drug-related eosinophilia is still possible.  
• Primary bone-marrow diseases are uncommon at your age but are the reason you have been referred to a haematologist. One blood test (for FIP1L1-PDGFRA fusion) and, if needed, a bone-marrow biopsy rule these out.

What the haematologist will usually do
1. Repeat CBC with manual differential to confirm.  
2. Calculate AEC and track trend (has it been there on older labs?)  
3. Thorough history: medications, supplements, travel, pets, rashes, asthma, sinus problems, night sweats, weight loss, abdominal pain.  
4. Basic panel: ESR/CRP, liver & kidney tests, vitamin B12, tryptase, IgE.  
5. Stool O&P × 3; sometimes Strongyloides serology (because steroids, if ever needed, can make Strongyloides lethal).  
6. Chest X-ray or CT if respiratory symptoms.  
7. If AEC ≥1 500 and other tests unrevealing, bone-marrow biopsy ± molecular panel (FIP1L1-PDGFRA, JAK2, BCR-ABL …).

What you can do now
• Collect old blood‐test printouts—trend is valuable.  
• Make a complete medication list including over-the-counter drugs, herbal products, protein shakes, etc.  
• Note any seemingly minor symptoms (itchy skin, runny nose, mild wheeze).  
• Ask the doctor who ordered the test to tell you the absolute eosinophil count; knowing whether you’re at 900 or 3 000/µL changes the urgency.

When to seek earlier attention
Seek care sooner than June if you develop  
• Fever, widespread rash, swollen lymph nodes  
• Worsening shortness of breath, wheeze, chest pain  
• Unexplained weight loss, night sweats  
• Severe abdominal pain  

Bottom line  
A 22 % eosinophil fraction sounds high, but the real question is the absolute count and whether it persists. In a healthy 26-year-old the most common explanations are allergy/atopy or a medication effect; parasites are possible but less likely without travel.
