The haematologist’s evaluation is designed to make sure nothing serious (bone-marrow disease, lymphoma, vasculitis) is being missed, and in many cases the cause turns out to be benign or easily treatable. Continue your current medications unless a physician tells you to stop them, and keep the June appointment for a definitive work-up.

181.question: I get a "flash" inside my head occasionally whenever I think of old things. Could this be some milder form of epilepsy?  The first time I remember this happening is when I was 16. I was looking at a Spider man mural from the 80s on the side of a building and when my mind tried to recreate the time period there my ears started ringing really loudly and suddenly, almost like a bang. The ringing faded and didn't last much longer than a second, but while it was happening I was a little out of it. It's hard to describe.It happened again last night at the grocery store while I was thinking about a sticker dispenser I'd just passed by and remembering seeing them during my early childhood. It hit me like a baseball bat as I was walking out of the door and I almost lost my balance. I'm not sure that I've ever had one that strong before, or maybe it just felt different because I was standing that time.This happens about once every week or month or so, and it has been for a long time. My doctor isn't interested in exploring it because it's never been a real impairment to my life, but I've always been curious about it.I guess something about the way my brain attempts to recreate the past sometimes (not always) triggers a "cannot compute" error. It's sort of specific, like when I'll try to place myself there and immerse myself in how I might have felt and experienced that time period, but it has pretty much only ever happened after seeing an older object or an old photo. My thoughts sort of just naturally flow into that sometimes so there's not really anything I can do about it, and I've never been able to recreate it intentionally.Male 27
181.answer:
What you are describing could fit a number of different neurological or ear-related phenomena.  From the outside-looking-in there is no way to make a diagnosis, but I can tell you what possibilities neurologists usually think about when they hear a story like yours and why they would (or would not) worry about epilepsy.

1.  Focal-aware (simple-partial) seizures – especially from the temporal lobe  
   •  The temporal lobe sits next to the auditory cortex, the hippocampus (memory) and the amygdala (emotion).  
   •  Seizures that start there often last only a few seconds, do not cause loss of consciousness, and can present as:  
        – Sudden ringing, buzzing or “whoosh” sounds.  
        – A brief “flash” or sense of being elsewhere in time (déjà-vu, jamais-vu, vivid memory scenes).  
        – A moment of feeling “out of it,” vague nausea or a need to pause.  
   •  Frequency can be once every few days to once every few months.  
   •  People are often able to keep walking or talking, but afterwards feel odd or slightly tired.  
   •  The fact that yours are sometimes precipitated by a memory or nostalgic thought is not unusual; the temporal lobe specialises in autobiographical memory, so a seizure focus there can be set off by internal thought as easily as by external stimuli.  

   What would make a neurologist lean toward this explanation?  
     – Event lasts seconds to 1–2 min, then ends abruptly.  
     – Stereotyped: every spell feels essentially identical.  
     – No warning signs of fainting (light-headedness, blackening of vision).  
     – No migraine headache following.  
   What would make them doubt it?  
     – Only ever occurring once or twice a year.  
     – Spells that are easily interrupted by distraction.  
     – Complete control over stopping or starting them.  

2.  Migraine aura without headache (acephalgic migraine)  
   •  Can cause bright flashes, ringing or muffled hearing, a sense of unreality.  
   •  Usually lasts 5–60 min, not just 1–2 sec.  
   •  May be followed by fatigue or mild light sensitivity even without an obvious headache.  

3.  Exploding head syndrome (a parasomnia)  
   •  A loud “bang” or “snap” in the head, usually in the first moments of falling asleep or upon awakening.  
   •  Not the case here because your episodes occur when fully awake.  

4.  Transient tinnitus / pressure changes in the inner ear  
   •  A short, loud ring lasting a second or two is common; many people notice it a handful of times a year.  
   •  Usually not accompanied by the vivid “time-travel” sensation you describe.  

5.  Near-syncope / vasovagal response  
   •  Sudden ringing, muffled hearing and momentary light-headedness can precede fainting.  
   •  Typically provoked by standing still, heat, pain, emotion; vision greys out; you feel sweaty.  
   •  You specifically link the episodes to a mental act (immersing in an old memory) rather than a posture change, so this seems less likely.

Is it a “mild form of epilepsy”?  Possibly, but not definitively.  The good news is that focal-aware seizures that brief and infrequent are not dangerous in and of themselves.  The two main reasons neurologists still like to evaluate them are:

•  To be certain they are seizures and not something else.  
•  If they are seizures, to identify any structural problem (scar tissue, benign tumour, previous injury) that might be acting as a seizure focus.  Most of the time nothing worrisome is found, but an MRI and (often) an EEG are done to be sure.

What you can do now

1.  Keep a diary for 1–2 months.  Note the exact time, what you were doing, how long the episode lasted, whether anyone else noticed you pause, and how you felt afterwards.  If you can capture one on phone video (e.g., ask a friend or set your phone to record while you describe it right after it occurs) that is extremely helpful.

2.  Make an appointment with a neurologist (not just a primary-care doctor) and bring that diary.  Even if the spells remain rare, a one-time consultation for history, physical exam, MRI and/or EEG is reasonable.  Many neurologists will order an ambulatory (24- or 48-hour) EEG that you wear at home to try to catch an event.

3.  See an ENT only if you also have ongoing tinnitus, hearing loss, vertigo or ear fullness independent of the episodes.

4.  In the meantime:  
   •  Get adequate sleep; sleep deprivation lowers the seizure threshold.  
   •  Limit heavy alcohol binges; alcohol withdrawal can provoke seizures.  
   •  Note whether caffeine, flashing lights or stress cluster around the days you have events and avoid obvious triggers.

When to seek immediate care

•  An episode that progresses to loss of awareness, staring spells >1–2 min, jerking, or a fall.  
•  A first-ever spell that leaves you confused for many minutes or causes tongue-biting.  
•  Any new neurological symptom (weakness, slurred speech, persistent double vision).

Bottom line

What you describe certainly could be a focal-aware seizure arising from the temporal lobe, but it also could be brief tinnitus coupled with a vivid memory illusion or another benign phenomenon.  Because it has been recurrent since adolescence, occurs every week to month, and occasionally makes you lose balance, a one-time work-up by a neurologist is justified—even if treatment never becomes necessary.

182.question: When I was about 2 years old I had epilepsy for some time due to a hard hit to my head. It's been 20+ years since I had an epileptic attack (I'm 26yrs old now). I don't even have memory about any of those episodes 'cause I was too young when that happened to me. Now I'm trying to get a job where I need to get shot with a stun gun as one of the tests. It worries me that somehow it will do some damage and bring back that condition to my life. Should I be worried?
182.answer:
Short answer  
If you had a few seizures only in early childhood after a head injury, have been seizure-free for more than 20 years and have never taken anti-seizure medicine as an adult, the chance that a single, brief TASER/Stun-gun exposure will “bring the epilepsy back” is extremely small. There are no good data showing that a properly used law-enforcement stun device can provoke de-novo epilepsy or reliably trigger a remote, inactive epilepsy. Nevertheless, because the risk is not zero and because every employer who uses these devices should screen applicants for medical problems, the prudent thing to do is to discuss the issue with your personal physician or an occupational-health doctor before you volunteer for the exposure.

Explanation in more detail

1.  Your past seizure history  
   • At age 2 you apparently had a series of seizures after a head injury (“post-traumatic epilepsy”).  
   • You have now gone >20 years without any seizure.  
   • Under current international criteria (ILAE, 2014) epilepsy is considered “resolved” when a person has been seizure-free for ≥10 years, with ≥5 years off medication. Your recurrence risk today is only about 1–2 % per year, not much higher than the general population.

2.  What a stun gun does  
   • Open-circuit voltage ≈ 50–60 kV but the delivered current is only 1–2 mA.  
   • Pulse frequency ≈ 19–20 Hz, pulse duration ≈ 100 µs, usually for 5 seconds.  
   • Current flows mainly through skin and muscle between the two darts; very little reaches the brain.  
   • Main physiologic effects: painful sensory stimulus, involuntary skeletal-muscle contraction, transient sympathetic “adrenaline” surge.  

3.  Evidence regarding seizures  
   • Thousands of healthy volunteers and police officers have been exposed during training; seizures are exceptionally rare.  
   • Large medical reviews (Ho 2009, Dawes 2011, Kroll 2015) did not document a single definite, unprovoked epileptic seizure in research settings.  
   • A handful of case reports exist, but most involved people with known active epilepsy, drug intoxication, or additional noxious stimuli (blows to the head, hypoxia, crystal-meth use, etc.).  
   • No study has shown that a TASER causes brain injury or increases long-term seizure risk.

4.  Factors that could theoretically trigger a seizure  
   • Extreme stress or pain  
   • Sudden spike in adrenaline / blood pressure  
   • Sleep deprivation, hypoglycaemia, drugs/alcohol  
   These are non-specific factors and they apply to anyone with a seizure tendency, but they are not unique to stun-gun exposure.

5.  Practical advice  
   • Talk once with your GP/neurologist; let him/her put in writing that your childhood post-traumatic epilepsy is resolved and that there is no known contraindication to a single, brief CEW (conducted-electrical-weapon) exposure.  
   • Provide that note to the occupational-health department of the employer; most agencies just want documentation that you have no active neurological disease.  
   • Get a normal night’s sleep, avoid alcohol or stimulants the day before, eat breakfast, stay hydrated—good advice for anyone who is about to be stunned.  
   • If you ever have another unprovoked seizure, seek medical review and of course you would then have to reconsider subsequent exposures.

Bottom line  
For someone whose seizures ended in early childhood, the existing medical literature and the electrical characteristics of modern stun devices do not indicate a meaningful risk of re-activating epilepsy. While no medical procedure is absolutely risk-free, the probability of a problem in your specific situation is so low that most physicians would not regard past, resolved childhood epilepsy as a contraindication. Get formal clearance if the employer requires it, but you probably do not need to be worried.

183.question: I am a 23 year old women I was diagnosed with Crohn’s disease and other chronic inflammation about 8 years ago, about 6 months ago I was diagnosed with epilepsy, on top of that I have cysts throughout my body. I am here with two requests from the doctors here.I have looked a bit into the connections between inflammation and epilepsy I’m looking for more information on this and would appreciate any thoughts / leads 2) I am also wondering if the cysts could be connected to inflammation
183.answer:
I am not your treating physician, and the information below is for general education only.  Please discuss anything you read here with your own gastro-enterologist, neurologist, and primary-care clinician before making changes to your care.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
A.  How systemic / gut inflammation and Crohn’s disease may be linked to epilepsy
-------------------------------------------------------------------

1.  Epidemiologic signals  
   •  Several large population studies show that people with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) have a higher incidence of epilepsy than the general population—roughly 1.4- to 1.8-fold.  
   •  The risk appears greatest in the first few years after IBD diagnosis and in those who require steroids or biologics, suggesting that disease activity itself (i.e., inflammation) may matter.

2.  Proposed biologic mechanisms  
   a.  Pro-inflammatory cytokines  
       –  Cytokines released in active Crohn’s (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, interferon-γ) can cross or disrupt the blood-brain barrier (BBB).  
       –  In animal models, these cytokines lower seizure threshold and amplify excitatory neurotransmission (especially glutamate).  
       –  IL-1β has been most studied; blocking its signaling (e.g., with anakinra) reduces seizures in some experimental and small human series.

   b.  BBB permeability & microglial activation  
       –  When the BBB is loosened by systemic inflammation, albumin and immune cells enter brain parenchyma and activate microglia.  
       –  Activated microglia produce more cytokines and reactive oxygen species, creating a positive feedback loop that supports epileptogenesis.

   c.  Autoimmunity  
       –  A subset of epilepsies is antibody-mediated (e.g., anti-LGI1, anti-GAD65, anti-NMDA-R). Chronic immune dysregulation in Crohn’s may raise the likelihood of generating neural auto-antibodies.  
       –  Testing for neural antibodies can occasionally reveal a treatable autoimmune epilepsy.

   d.  Gut–brain axis & microbiome  
       –  The vagus nerve and bacterial metabolites (short-chain fatty acids, tryptophan derivatives) modulate CNS excitability.  
       –  Dysbiosis in Crohn’s may alter these metabolites. Some small studies show ketogenic diet–like changes in the gut microbiome decrease seizures, hinting the gut connection is real.

   e.  Nutritional deficiencies & drug triggers  
       –  Malabsorption of B-vitamins (B6, B12, folate), vitamin D, magnesium, or severe anemia can lower seizure threshold.  
       –  Drugs often used in Crohn’s—metronidazole, fluoroquinolones, cyclosporine, tacrolimus—can provoke seizures in susceptible people.  
       –  High-dose steroids may precipitate seizures through electrolyte shifts or neurotoxicity.

3.  Practical clinical points / questions to ask your team  
   •  How well-controlled is the intestinal inflammation (fecal calprotectin, CRP, colonoscopy)?  
   •  Could any current medication or deficiency be lowering seizure threshold?  (Check B6, B12, folate, Mg, Ca, Na, glucose.)  
   •  Has neural antibody screening been done? (LGI1, CASPR2, GAD65, NMDA-R, amphiphysin, etc.)  
   •  Would a brain MRI with contrast and an EEG source-localization study add information?  
   •  If seizures began during a Crohn’s flare, does more aggressive anti-inflammatory therapy help both gut and brain?

-------------------------------------------------------------------
B.  Are your multiple cysts related to inflammation?
-------------------------------------------------------------------

“Cyst” is a descriptive term: a walled-off, fluid- or semi-solid-filled structure.  The significance depends on origin.

1.  Skin / subcutaneous cysts  
   •  Epidermoid (sebaceous) cysts and “pilar” cysts arise from blocked follicles. Chronic systemic inflammation, smoking, and obesity increase risk.  
   •  Hidradenitis suppurativa, an inflammatory skin disease that can coexist with Crohn’s, manifests with cyst-like nodules in axillae, groin, and under breasts.

2.  Ovarian cysts / polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)  
   •  PCOS is strongly linked to low-grade systemic inflammation (elevated CRP, IL-6).  
   •  Women with Crohn’s have slightly higher rates of irregular menses; chronic inflammation and corticosteroid use may disturb the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

3.  Mesenteric / enteric duplication cysts or abscess-turned-chronic-cyst  
   •  Intra-abdominal phlegmon or abscess is a known Crohn’s complication; after infection resolves, a walled-off cavity can persist and look cystic on imaging.

4.  Liver, kidney, or pancreatic cysts  
   •  Simple cysts here are usually congenital or age-related—not inflammatory.  
   •  Abscesses, however, are inflammatory and can mimic cysts on ultrasound.

5.  Medication or biologic effects  
   •  Anti-TNF agents (infliximab, adalimumab) rarely cause paradoxical skin lesions—some nodular, cyst-like.  
   •  Long-term steroids thin the skin, making follicular occlusion more likely.

Bottom line:  Certain cyst types (epidermoid, HS nodules, PCOS) CAN be promoted by a chronic pro-inflammatory milieu, but many cysts are coincidental.  The best way to know is to (a) catalog every cyst by organ system with ultrasound/MRI, (b) biopsy or drain any atypical lesion, and (c) rule out infection or medication-related causes.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
C.  Steps you can take with your healthcare team
-------------------------------------------------------------------

1.  Coordinate care  
   •  Arrange a joint visit or at least shared records among gastroenterology, neurology, dermatology/gynecology, and possibly rheumatology/immunology.

2.  Control systemic inflammation aggressively  
   •  Tight Crohn’s control (biologics, small-molecule inhibitors, or combination therapy) not only protects the gut but may reduce neuroinflammation.  
   •  Track CRP/fecal calprotectin and correlate with seizure diary.

3.  Screen / correct modifiable pro-seizure factors  
   •  Electrolytes, B6, B12, folate, vitamin D, magnesium, glucose, anemia.  
   •  Review antibiotics, steroids, or calcineurin inhibitors that can lower seizure threshold.

4.  Consider anti-inflammatory or immune-modulating strategies for epilepsy  
   •  Some cases respond to steroids, IVIg, plasmapheresis, or anti-IL-1 drugs when an autoimmune component is present.  
   •  Discuss with your neurologist whether any of these are appropriate in your specific situation.

5.  Characterize the cysts  
   •  Full-body skin check by dermatology.  
   •  Pelvic ultrasound if ovarian involvement suspected.  
   •  Cross-sectional imaging (MRI or CT) for abdominal cysts; biopsy or surgical consult for symptomatic lesions.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
D.  Where to read more / bring to your doctors
-------------------------------------------------------------------

•  “Systemic inflammation and risk of epilepsy: a population-based cohort study.”  Neurology 2014.  
•  “Inflammatory bowel disease increases risk of epilepsy: A nationwide cohort.”  Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2021.  
•  Vezzani & Viviani. “Neuromodulatory properties of inflammatory cytokines and their impact on neuronal excitability.”  Epilepsia 2015.  
•  Marchi et al. “Systemic inflammation in epilepsy— pathogenic or protective?”  Clin Exp Immunol 2020.  
•  Review: “Inflammation and polycystic ovary syndrome.”  Reprod Biol Endocrinol 2019.  
•  NICE guideline NG129: Crohn’s disease management.  
•  Autoimmune encephalitis guidelines (Lancet Neurol 2021).

-------------------------------------------------------------------
Key take-home points
-------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Chronic inflammation—whether from Crohn’s itself, cytokine spill-over, or nutritional/medication issues—can lower seizure threshold and may contribute to epileptogenesis.  
2.  Many kinds of “cysts” exist; some, like epidermoid or ovarian cysts and hidradenitis suppurativa nodules, are indeed more common in pro-inflammatory states, while others are unrelated.  
3.  The practical path forward is thorough characterization of the cysts, aggressive control of Crohn’s activity, correction of metabolic factors, and neurologic evaluation for autoimmune contributions.  

Bring this outline to your care team so they can tailor investigations and treatment to your particular presentation.

184.question: I live in Japan, and so sometimes with doctors there can be some miscommunication. I usually check online to make sure before taking things. Long story short, I was on Zoloft 50mg for 6 years. Started getting twitches, changed to Lexapro, it made my anxiety worse, now I'm off of it. But since about 2 years ago I have had constant off-center / dizziness, along with motor function weirdness (wobbly legs, right hand/right leg cramps, joint pain, trouble with finite motor skills like writing), and speech issues. Though these things are not very noticeable to people (other than that I feel sick due to this perceptual oscilating-like dizziness which has made it difficult to work, it's very noticeable to me. I was prescribed something called KAMPO (I guess it's Chinese medicine) but it didn't have an effect. Now, he prescribed me "SELENICA-R 40%" which is usually used for epileptics. I have had MRI, multiple blood tests, x-rays, seen an ENT, a bone doctor (ultrasound on right hand due to joint pain) and I'm sure more... my next step is I plan to see a doctor to see if I have a pinched nerve or bulged disc etc, but that wouldn't explain my speech and dizziness issues. I'm sorry if I trailed off. Is this medicine within the realm of what I should be taking? Thank you. Age: 36 Sex: Male Height: 5'10 Weight: 190lbs Suffering: 2 long years........ Medication: about 2000mg of Magnesium per day due to bowel issues.
184.answer:
1.  What is “SELENICA-R 40 %”?  
   •  Japanese brand name for sodium valproate/valproic acid (an extended-release preparation; “40 %” refers to the concentration of active drug in the granules).  
   •  Drug classes / usual indications  
     –  Anticonvulsant (epilepsy, focal or generalized seizures)  
     –  Mood stabiliser (bipolar disorder, agitation)  
     –  Prevention of migraine / vestibular migraine  
     –  Occasionally used for certain tremors or myoclonic jerks  

2.  Why might your doctor think it is worth a trial?  
   The cluster of problems you describe—episodic “dizziness” that feels like oscillation, limb jerks/twitches, momentary loss of fine motor control, speech difficulty—can look like:  
   •  Focal (partial) seizures coming from the temporal or parietal lobe, sometimes without obvious loss of consciousness.  
   •  Myoclonic jerks or essential tremor.  
   •  Vestibular migraine (valproate is licensed in Japan for migraine prophylaxis).  
   •  An SSRI-related movement disorder (but those usually improve once the drug is stopped).  

   Valproate is one of the broadest anticonvulsants and also one of the best-studied migraine preventives, so it is a logical “empirical” choice when the physician is not yet certain whether the origin is epileptic, migraine–vestibular, or a mixture.

3.  Does valproate make sense in your circumstance?  
   •  It would not be used for a pinched nerve, muscle strain or simple peripheral vertigo.  
   •  It is reasonable if the doctor suspects sub-clinical seizures, vestibular migraine or wishes to cover both possibilities while further investigations (e.g. prolonged EEG, video-EEG, vestibular testing) are arranged.  
   •  If your MRI and routine bloods were normal, valproate is often tried before moving to more invasive tests.

4.  Typical dosing (Japanese preparation)  
   Granules 40 %: 0.5–1 g/day of granules = 200–400 mg valproic acid. Usually started low (e.g. 200 mg at night) and titrated every 1–2 weeks. Tablets come as 200 mg “R” (slow-release). Always follow the exact instructions printed on the pharmacy label.

5.  What monitoring is recommended?  
   •  Baseline and periodic liver function tests (ALT, AST, bilirubin)  
   •  Full blood count / platelets (valproate can lower platelet count)  
   •  If you develop jaundice, severe abdominal pain, easy bruising, stop the drug and call the doctor quickly.  
   •  Blood level (valproate trough) sometimes checked after a few weeks, but not always necessary at low doses.

6.  Common side-effects (so you know what is drug vs. your underlying problem)  
   •  Sleepiness, fatigue, tremor  
   •  Nausea, mild stomach upset (take with food)  
   •  Weight gain, increased appetite  
   •  Hair thinning, changes in hair texture (reversible)  
   •  At higher doses: tremor, unsteadiness—so if dizziness briefly worsens after starting, let your doctor know; the dose can be reduced.

   With 2 g/day of magnesium you already have loose bowels—valproate rarely worsens this, but sometimes adds mild nausea.

7.  Drug interactions  
   •  SSRIs such as sertraline or escitalopram have minimal interaction with valproate; you are no longer taking them.  
   •  High-dose magnesium has no specific interaction.  
   •  Alcohol increases sedation and liver load—keep low.

8.  Points you might raise with the doctor (to be sure you share the same plan)  
   1.  “Are we treating possible focal seizures, migraine, or something else?”  
   2.  “How long do you want me to try valproate before we judge benefit?” (Typical trial: 6–8 weeks after reaching target dose)  
   3.  “Will you arrange an EEG or vestibular tests if symptoms continue?”  
   4.  “What baseline blood tests will you check and when?”

9.  When you should contact the doctor quickly  
   •  Sudden worsening of balance so that you cannot walk  
   •  New confusion, staring spells, or loss of consciousness  
   •  Yellow eyes/skin, dark urine, vomiting (possible liver injury)  
   •  Unusual bruising or bleeding (possible thrombocytopenia)

10.  Bottom line  
Selenica-R (sodium valproate) is not an obvious choice for a slipped disc or simple vertigo, but it is perfectly reasonable if your physician suspects subtle seizures or vestibular migraine, and it is a standard first-line medicine for those conditions in Japan. It will not harm the work-up you are planning with a spine/neurology doctor, and the dose can be stopped without long taper if ineffective. Make sure you have baseline LFT/platelet tests, take it with food, and keep a diary of any change in your dizziness, twitching, speech or mood so you and the doctor can assess whether it is helping.

As always, the final decision is between you and the prescribing doctor; use the questions above to guide that discussion.

185.question: I (24 years old, male assigned at birth (currently on HRT), middle-eastern) am always curious about different diseases I may get. Mostly because of family/relative backgrounds. Recently for a project, I had a bunch of electroencephalography results to do a bunch of machine-learning experiments with. I found most of those people suffered from Epilepsy, and as I don't know anything about them, I am curious about the disease. Can it happen with no reason? (I mean, a simple misfunctioning in brain) One of my mom's cousins had the disease and it resulted his death. Does it mean I am in danger? or his children are more in danger?     Can drugs/medications result the disease? I read the wikipedia page of the topic. I found smokers or alcoholic people are more in danger. But I am curious about the medications for depression or anxiety (like Citalopram). Ok, I think I asked enough. So, I'll be thankful of your answers.
185.answer:
Epilepsy in one paragraph
Epilepsy is not a single disease but a tendency of the brain to produce recurrent, un-provoked seizures.  About 1 % of the world’s population has active epilepsy at any one time, and about 3 % (≈ 1 in 26) will have it at some point in life.  In roughly half of the people we can point to a structural or metabolic “reason” in the brain; in the other half we cannot, and we call those cases “idiopathic” or “genetic–generalised.”  So yes—sometimes epilepsy seems to appear “out of the blue” even after a normal birth, normal imaging, and no injuries.

1.  Causes and risk factors
•  Structural injury to brain: birth complications, head trauma, stroke, tumour, previous meningitis/encephalitis, neuro-degenerative disease, etc.  
•  Genetic channelopathies or chromosomal syndromes (e.g., SCN1A‐related Dravet, 15q duplication, etc.).  
•  Metabolic or immune causes (hypoglycaemia, hyponatraemia, anti-NMDAR encephalitis, etc.).  
•  In 30–50 % no cause is found on current testing.  

Remember: one isolated seizure from alcohol withdrawal, hypoglycaemia, drug toxicity, fever, etc., is called an “acute symptomatic seizure.”  You are only labelled “epileptic” after two unprovoked seizures (or one with very high risk of another).

2.  How much does family history matter?
Risk of developing epilepsy by relationship  
•  General population lifetime risk 2–3 %.  
•  First-degree relative (parent, sibling, child) with epilepsy: ≈ 4–8 % (about 2–4× baseline, but still a small absolute risk).  
•  Second-degree relative (grand-parent, aunt/uncle, niece/nephew, first cousin): risk is only slightly above baseline, often quoted 2.5–3 %.  

Therefore your mother’s cousin does NOT put you in any meaningful danger.  His own children do carry a moderately higher risk than the average person, but even for them the odds still strongly favour never developing epilepsy.

3.  Can medicines give someone epilepsy?
Ordinary therapeutic use of most medicines does not create chronic epilepsy, but many drugs can temporarily lower the seizure threshold so that a person who otherwise would not seize might have an “acute symptomatic” seizure while the drug is on-board or during withdrawal.

Well-known examples that lower seizure threshold  
Bupropion (especially ≥ 450 mg), clozapine, tramadol, meperidine, theophylline, isoniazid without pyridoxine, cyclosporine, tacrolimus, high-dose penicillins/imipenem, fluoroquinolones, cocaine, amphetamines.  

Antidepressants  
•  Selective-serotonin re-uptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as citalopram, sertraline, fluoxetine: at normal doses the seizure risk is very low—actually lower than the risk posed by untreated severe depression itself.  In overdose or in patients with pre-existing epilepsy the threshold may be lowered slightly.  
•  Tricyclics (amitriptyline, clomipramine) and maprotiline carry a higher risk.  
Bottom line: taking citalopram at usual doses almost never causes epilepsy.

Hormone therapy  
You mention being on hormone replacement therapy.  Oestrogen tends to make seizures slightly easier to trigger and progesterone the opposite, but HRT at replacement doses does not create epilepsy in someone who wasn’t already predisposed.

Alcohol / nicotine  
•  Heavy alcohol USE is not the problem—ALCOHOL WITHDRAWAL is.  The sudden drop in CNS GABAergic tone 6–48 h after last drink is what provokes seizures.  
•  Cigarette smoking itself is not a recognised cause of epilepsy; smokers simply have higher rates of many illnesses, so the association you saw in observational studies is confounded.

4.  Will epilepsy kill you?
Most people with epilepsy live normal lifespans, but the condition carries a small excess mortality from (a) the underlying brain disease that produced the epilepsy, (b) accidents/trauma while seizing, and (c) “SUDEP” (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy) which occurs in about 1/1 000 patients per year—higher if seizures remain uncontrolled.  Good seizure control and basic safety measures (no unsupervised swimming, care with heights, etc.) minimise the risk.

Key take-aways for you
•  The fact that a second-degree relative had fatal epilepsy does NOT place you at substantial risk.  
•  His children do have a somewhat increased risk, but still probably < 10 %.  
•  Citalopram and other SSRIs, at prescribed doses, are safe for most people with respect to seizures; bupropion and a few other drugs are the antidepressants that matter more.  
•  If you have no history of unprovoked seizures, live a brain-healthy lifestyle (seat-belt/helmet use, moderation with alcohol, treat infections promptly, manage cardiovascular risk), your chance of developing epilepsy remains low and is almost certainly far lower than many other everyday risks.

If you ever do experience a first unprovoked seizure, see a neurologist; modern imaging, EEG and genetics can often clarify the cause and, if needed, treatment is very effective for the majority of patients.

186.question: 31 years Male USA Last year I went to a concert and during the show there was a bunch of flashing lights and it made me feel really “off” and I looked away. Tonight I was watching a TV show and there were some flashing scenes and it made me feel “off” again. So now, I’m wondering if I somehow have epilepsy or something, even though I’ve never had a seizure. I found this epilepsy “test” video and forced myself to watch it on the big screen. I honestly felt uncomfortable and some “impending doom” throughout, but I made it through the whole video without passing out. Is it possible I have epilepsy? Or is it normal for flashing to bother people without epilepsy? And is it possible I could be at risk of getting or becoming more susceptible to epilepsy after watching this video?
186.answer:
Key points up-front
• Epilepsy is defined by recurrent, unprovoked seizures. Feeling “off,” anxious, light-headed, or having a sense of “impending doom” is not a seizure.  
• Flashing or rapidly alternating light can make anyone—whether they have epilepsy or not—feel uncomfortable, dizzy, anxious, nauseated, or headachy.  
• Watching a flashing-light video cannot give you epilepsy. It can only provoke a seizure in people who already have the neurological predisposition.  
• True photosensitive epilepsy is uncommon (≈3 % of people who already have epilepsy, and only about 1 person in 4,000 in the general population). It usually starts in childhood or the teenage years, not in the early 30s.  
• If you have never had a seizure, the chance that you suddenly developed photosensitive epilepsy at age 31 is very low, but see a doctor if you ever experience true seizure symptoms (brief loss of awareness, jerking movements, confused recovery, tongue-bite, incontinence, etc.).  

Why flashing lights can make “normal” brains feel strange  
1. Visual overstimulation: Rapid changes in brightness/contrast overload the visual cortex and can produce eye strain, dizziness, mild disorientation, or nausea (similar to motion sickness).  
2. Migraine sensitivity: Many people with or without migraine disorders experience photophobia (light sensitivity) that can trigger a headache, nausea, or “aura-like” sensations.  
3. Autonomic response: Bright strobing can trigger a fight-or-flight response—palpitations, sweating, “impending doom”—especially if you are already worried about having a seizure.  
4. Anxiety/anticipatory fear: Watching a so-called “epilepsy test” video while fearing the worst understandably ramps up anxiety and makes neutral body sensations feel ominous.  

What actually happens in photosensitive epilepsy  
• A specific pattern (usually 10–30 flashes per second, high-contrast red or white light that fills much of the visual field) can trigger a brief, stereotyped seizure.  
• The person typically has a well-defined history of other spontaneous seizures, or an EEG that shows “photoparoxysmal response” during strobe testing.  
• Age of onset is usually 7–19 years. New onset after 25 is rare.  

Can watching a flashing video make me “get epilepsy”?  
No. Epilepsy arises from underlying genetic factors, brain structure, previous head injury, stroke, infection, etc. A light stimulus can reveal an existing susceptibility but cannot create it. You did not increase your long-term risk by watching a test video once (even repeatedly).  

When should I worry or seek medical evaluation?  
See a health professional—ideally a neurologist—if you ever experience:  
• Loss of awareness, blackouts, or unexplained staring spells.  
• Generalised shaking/jerking with loss of consciousness.  
• Sudden falls or “drop attacks.”  
• Confusion or severe headache after an episode.  
• Tongue bite, urinary incontinence, or injury during a spell.  
• New, persistent neurological symptoms (e.g., focal weakness, vision changes).  

What you can do now  
1. Stop testing yourself with flashing-light videos; unnecessary and anxiety-provoking.  
2. Limit exposure to strong strobe effects in concerts, video games, or TV intros; most shows provide on-screen warnings.  
3. If you must be around strobes, sit farther back, turn down screen brightness, or cover one eye (reduces risk even in true photosensitive epilepsy).  
4. Manage general triggers that can lower anyone’s seizure threshold—sleep deprivation, heavy alcohol, certain stimulants. They matter far more in people with established epilepsy but are good brain hygiene for everyone.  
5. If anxiety about this persists, discuss it with your primary-care physician; CBT or other anxiety-management strategies often help more than repeated reassurance.  
6. If you have migraines or vestibular issues, ask your doctor whether preventive or abortive medication is appropriate.  

Bottom line  
Feeling uncomfortable, dizzy, or anxious when lights flash is common and does not mean you have epilepsy. Because you have never had an actual seizure—and because new-onset photosensitive epilepsy at 31 is exceptionally rare—the likelihood you have the condition is extremely low. Flashing lights cannot “give” you epilepsy; they merely reveal it in those already predisposed. If you ever do experience definite seizure-like events, seek prompt medical evaluation, but based on what you describe, reassurance and sensible avoidance of disturbing stimuli are all that is needed.

187.question: Hi, within the past 3 monthsish I have been experiencing these kinds of 'episodes'I will try my best at describing them..I start to feel dizzy, sometimes get a sharp pain in the corner of my eye for a split second, I then feel zoned out and have random memories and visions, deja vu etc, each deja vu memory going through my brain really really fast then on to another. Sometimes I get full blurred vision for a few seconds, I get slurred speech if I'm speaking,hot flushes, I have this weird feeling, like i'm going to be sick. As soon as it finishes i forget everytime i thought about which is why its so hard to explain. They last 1min-2min. Generally after I feel light headed and zoned out for the rest of the day, if someone speaks to me i probably wont even hear it.\I went to the doctor about this, he suggested Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. So I got an MRI, but that all came back clear.My doctor told me to not worry about it, that it could be some kind of migraine or a form of small seizure. Unless it got worse, then to go back. Now yesterday I had three episodes in one day.My question is, should I be worried? And I really do have every single Temporal Lobe Epilepsy symptom, is there a way that the MRI couldn't catch that?
187.answer:
I can’t diagnose you over the Internet, but the description you give—brief, stereotyped spells with déjà-vu, an odd stomach sensation, a brief lapse in awareness, then post-episode fatigue—does sound very much like “focal aware” or “focal impaired-awareness” seizures that originate in (or rapidly spread to) the temporal lobe.  They used to be called “complex partial seizures.”  Migraine aura, panic attacks, TIAs, or certain metabolic problems can look similar, but several points in your story (speed of onset, repetitive identical pattern, rapid return to baseline, and the way you completely forget what rushed through your mind) push seizures higher on the list.

Key facts you should know

1. A normal MRI does NOT rule out temporal-lobe epilepsy.  
   • Up to 40 % of people with definite temporal-lobe seizures have a completely normal‐looking MRI (so-called “non-lesional epilepsy”).  
   • Even when there is an abnormality, it can be subtle and missed unless an “epilepsy-protocol MRI” is done with thin cuts through the hippocampus.  
   • MRI tells us whether there is a structural lesion; it does not tell us whether abnormal electrical discharges are occurring.

2. The principal test for epilepsy is an EEG (electroencephalogram), ideally one that captures an actual event. Routine 20-minute EEGs miss about 50 % of patients. Yield goes up with:  
   • Sleep-deprived EEG  
   • Prolonged (24-72 h) ambulatory EEG  
   • In-hospital video-EEG monitoring

3. The fact that your episodes are increasing (three in one day) means you should be re-evaluated soon, preferably by a neurologist or an epileptologist. Frequent focal seizures can sometimes “secondarily generalize” into a convulsion; treatment lowers that risk.

4. Driving, operating machinery, climbing heights, swimming alone, and bathtub bathing should be avoided until you have a firm diagnosis and, if it is epilepsy, until you are seizure-free under treatment for the period required by your local laws.

5. If an event lasts >5 min, clusters without recovery occur, or you injure yourself, that is an emergency (call EMS).

What usually happens next

1. Neurology referral.  
2. At least one good-quality EEG (often sleep-deprived). If negative but suspicion remains high, prolonged or video-EEG.  
3. Review of the MRI by someone experienced in epilepsy imaging; repeat with epilepsy protocol if needed.  
4. Basic labs (glucose, electrolytes, calcium, liver, kidney, thyroid); sometimes screening for autoimmune causes.  
5. If seizures are confirmed, discussion of antiepileptic medication (levetiracetam, lamotrigine, carbamazepine, etc.). About 70 % of people become seizure-free on the first or second drug tried.  
6. Diary: log each episode’s date, time, duration, triggers (sleep loss, stress, alcohol, hormonal changes, flashing lights), and any witnesses’ observations.

Other conditions that can mimic what you describe

• Migraine aura with or without headache (usually lasts 5–60 min, often visual “sparkles” or zig-zags rather than déjà-vu; no speech after-effects in most)  
• Panic attacks (longer, strong autonomic symptoms, intact awareness of surroundings, recall of event)  
• Transient ischemic attack (rare at your age unless major risk factors; episodes often last longer and are not stereotyped)  
• Vestibular disorders (vertigo prominent, no stereotyped psychic aura)  
• Hypoglycemia (check glucose during an event)

Bottom line / What to do now

• Yes, you should follow up—episodes are becoming more frequent.  
• A normal MRI does not rule out temporal-lobe epilepsy. You still need EEG evaluation.  
• Until you are evaluated and, if necessary, treated, take safety precautions.  
• Make a prompt appointment with a neurologist (ideally an epileptologist) and bring a detailed event diary, any phone videos a witness can record, and your MRI report/disc.

If you suddenly develop a prolonged event, loss of consciousness lasting more than a few minutes, weakness on one side, or confusion that doesn’t clear, seek emergency care immediately.

188.question: My current age is 31. Height: 5'7" Weight: 140 lbs. I have been having convulsive seizures almost every month since I turned 26. These seizures almost exclusively occur within an hour of waking up. I walk around the house for up to half an hour, burning up. Could stress be a trigger for these episodes? I also have times where I get euphoric and nauseous, but they never last very long.Basically, what I want to know is, what is going on in my head. Is this temporal lobe epilepsy? Focal onset seizures with secondary generalization? I had 9 seizures Monday. Keppra is not working for me, and I need to be recommended some other anticonvulsant. Please help me. Thank you.
188.answer:
I’m not in a position to give you a personal medical diagnosis, but I can outline what usually has to be considered when an adult is still having convulsive seizures despite medication and why you need a prompt re-evaluation by an epilepsy specialist (an epileptologist).

1. What the spells probably are  
• The short feeling of euphoria / nausea just before the convulsion sounds very much like an “aura.” An aura is a focal (partial) seizure that can originate in the temporal lobe, insula, or frontal operculum.  
• When that focal discharge spreads to involve both hemispheres, the clinical picture changes into a full convulsion (now called a “focal-to-bilateral tonic-clonic seizure”).  
• The 20–30 minutes of confusion, wandering, or feeling “hot” after the event is typical post-ictal behavior.

So, yes, “temporal-lobe epilepsy with secondary generalisation” is one strong possibility, but only an EEG/video-EEG can confirm this, and an MRI is mandatory to look for structural causes such as hippocampal sclerosis, cortical malformation, low-grade tumor, etc.

2. Why they occur shortly after waking  
Many focal epilepsies show a predilection for the sleep–wake transition: changes in cortical excitability, a cortisol/adrenaline surge, rising body temperature, and relative dehydration all make morning a “high-risk” period. Stress and sleep-loss amplify this. Keeping a strict sleep schedule, good hydration, and stress-management measures (exercise, CBT, mindfulness, etc.) reduce but rarely abolish morning seizures.

3. Why Keppra (levetiracetam) may be failing  
• In adults we usually titrate to 3000 mg/day (occasionally 4000 mg) before declaring failure, provided side-effects are tolerable.  
• Failure of one appropriately dosed antiseizure drug (ASD) does not doom you; many patients respond to the very next medication or to a combination.

4. Next reasonable medication options  
Choice depends on seizure type, comorbidities, reproductive plans, and insurance, but typical second-line agents for focal seizures are:

– Lamotrigine (Lamictal) – titrated slowly to avoid rash; good cognitive profile.  
– Valproate/divalproex (Depakote) – very effective but weight gain, teratogenicity, hair loss, tremor; interacts with Lamictal.  
– Carbamazepine (Tegretol) or Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal) – classic drugs for focal seizures; watch sodium levels, drug interactions.  
– Lacosamide (Vimpat) – well tolerated; few interactions.  
– Topiramate (Topamax) or Zonisamide – useful but cognitive slowing/weight loss, kidney-stone risk.  
– Perampanel, Brivaracetam, Clobazam – newer agents, often used as add-ons.

Often we leave Keppra in place (if tolerated) and add, for example, Lamotrigine or Lacosamide; Keppra + Lamotrigine is a well-studied synergistic pair.

5. Rescue treatment for clusters  
Because you had nine seizures in one day, your doctor should supply a rescue benzodiazepine (intranasal midazolam or diazepam-rectal gel) and create an “acute seizure action plan” for you and anyone who lives with you.

6. When is epilepsy labeled “drug-resistant”?  
If two appropriate ASDs, taken at adequate doses, do not achieve seizure freedom, you meet the definition of drug-resistant epilepsy. At that point you should be referred to a comprehensive epilepsy center to discuss:  
• long-term video-EEG monitoring to pinpoint the focus,  
• epilepsy surgery (resection, laser ablation),  
• neuromodulation (Vagus Nerve Stimulator, Responsive Neurostimulator, Deep-brain stim),  
• ketogenic / modified Atkins diet.

7. Things you can start doing now  
• Take medication at the exact same times every day; use reminders.  
• Sleep 7–8 h nightly, no all-nighters.  
• Avoid heavy alcohol (and never within 12 h of a dose of ASD).  
• Stay well hydrated, especially first thing in the morning.  
• Keep a detailed seizure diary noting time of day, preceding stress, sleep amount, menstruation (if applicable), missed meals, caffeine/alcohol, and any illness.  
• Discuss SUDEP (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy) with your clinician; good seizure control, medication adherence and not sleeping face-down reduce the risk.

8. What to do next week  
• Book an appointment (or ask for an urgent referral) with a neurologist/epileptologist. Tell the office you are having clusters despite medication—this usually accelerates scheduling.  
• Bring your seizure diary, a list of current doses, side-effects, and any prior imaging/EEG reports.  
• If you haven’t had a high-resolution epilepsy-protocol MRI and a prolonged EEG in the last couple of years, expect those to be ordered.  
• Ask about titrating Keppra to the maximal tolerated dose while simultaneously starting a second drug, or switching completely if levetiracetam’s mood side-effects are a problem for you.

Bottom line  
Your history sounds most like focal epilepsy—possibly temporal-lobe—with secondary generalisation, triggered by the sleep-to-wake transition and stress. Keppra alone has not controlled it, but many effective alternatives and combinations exist. Because uncontrolled seizures carry risks (injury, cognitive decline, SUDEP), you should be re-evaluated urgently by an epilepsy specialist, have your imaging/EEG updated, and move on to the next medication strategy or to surgical/neuromodulation options if needed.

Please arrange that appointment as soon as possible; meanwhile, do not drive, operate dangerous machinery, or swim alone, and make sure someone close to you knows basic first-aid seizure management and when to call emergency services.

189.question: 25 Male, 186 CM, 93 KG.I was happy that Johnson vaccine finally arrived at my country. However I started reading about it, there were some concerns reported last month that it may cause Neurological disorder and muscle paralysis.So as a someone who is treating from mild epilepsy (occurred to me only 4 times and usually my diagnosis are good) for about 6 years , should I be concerned about it ? also if I have the chance to take AstraZeneca should I do it ?Would appreciate your response because I can't reach to my Dr. at the moment
189.answer:
Key points up-front  
• Having epilepsy (even if you take antiepileptic drugs) is NOT listed as a contra-indication to any of the currently authorised COVID-19 vaccines, including Johnson & Johnson/Janssen and AstraZeneca.  
• The neurological problem you probably read about is Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).  It is very rare (roughly 8–10 extra cases per million J&J doses given).  Epilepsy does not increase that risk.  
• COVID-19 itself can provoke seizures and many other neurological complications far more frequently than the vaccines do.  
• The AstraZeneca vaccine carries a different very-rare risk: thrombosis with thrombocytopenia (TTS) – about 1–2 cases per 100 000 in people <50; again, far rarer than the risks linked to COVID-19 infection.  
• If the choice is “get vaccinated now with J&J or AstraZeneca” versus “remain unvaccinated for weeks or months”, every major neurological society and epilepsy association recommends: take whichever approved vaccine you can obtain first.  

1. Epilepsy and COVID-19 vaccines  
• Epilepsy is NOT an immune disorder.  None of the current vaccines are known to lower seizure thresholds or interact with common antiepileptic medications (valproate, levetiracetam, lamotrigine, carbamazepine, etc.).  
• Large post-marketing data sets (millions of doses) show seizure rates after vaccination are no higher than in the general population.  When a seizure is reported, it is usually due to fever, missed medication, or sleep deprivation – factors you can control for (see “Practical tips” below).

2. Guillain-Barré syndrome and the J&J vaccine  
• Background: GBS normally happens in ~10–20 people per million per year, usually after infections such as Campylobacter or influenza.  
• After J&J vaccination, regulators saw about 60 reports among roughly 7 million doses (≈8–10 excess cases per million).  Most cases were mild to moderate and responded to standard GBS treatment (IVIg/plasma-exchange).  
• No signal that people with epilepsy were over-represented.  
• Risk of needing ICU care or developing GBS from COVID-19 infection itself is several-fold higher than from the vaccine.

3. AstraZeneca and thrombosis with thrombocytopenia (TTS)  
• Incidence: ~1 case per 50–100 000 in <50 yr olds, somewhat less in men than women.  
• Mechanism appears to be platelet-activating antibodies (VITT).  Not linked to epilepsy or antiseizure drugs.  
• Countries that continue to use AZ in younger adults do so because the benefit (preventing COVID) outweighs the risk, even when infection rates are modest.

4. Comparing the two for a 25-year-old man  
BENEFIT: Both vaccines give ~60–70 % protection against symptomatic disease and >90 % protection against severe disease and death, even against Delta.  
RISKS (per million doses):  
• Janssen: ≈8–10 GBS, ≈1 VITT-like clotting event.  
• AstraZeneca: ≈10–15 VITT, ≈5–6 GBS (EMA data).  
Absolute numbers are tiny.  For a male your age, the difference between them is not large enough to justify delaying vaccination if one is readily available and the other is not.

5. Practical tips for people with epilepsy getting vaccinated  
• Take your usual antiseizure medication on schedule the day before, the day of, and the day after vaccination.  
• Stay well hydrated and keep temperature controlled.  If you tend to have fever-triggered seizures, have paracetamol/acetaminophen on hand and take it if your temperature rises >38 °C.  
• Sleep: try for a normal night’s sleep before and after the shot.  Fatigue/sleep loss is a common seizure trigger.  
• Observation period: remain the recommended 15–30 min after the injection so staff can manage any immediate reaction.  
• When to seek medical help afterwards:  
  – New numbness/weakness that ascends from legs or affects breathing (possible GBS) – urgently.  
  – Severe headache, vision change, abdominal pain, leg swelling within 4–28 days (possible VITT) – urgently.  
  – Fever >39 °C that persists >48 h despite antipyretics.  
  – More seizures than your usual baseline.  
These events are rare, but recognising them early keeps outcomes good.

6. Bottom line decision tree  
A. If J&J is available now and AstraZeneca will require waiting ⇒ take J&J.  
B. If both are available the same day: either is acceptable; if you strongly prefer to avoid the (tiny) GBS signal, pick AstraZeneca, recognising its own very-rare clotting risk.  
C. If an mRNA vaccine (Pfizer/Moderna) becomes available within a similar time frame, that would be the simplest choice because its only significant rare adverse event in young men is transient myocarditis (~3 per 100 000), which is still less severe and less frequent than the above.  

Remember: The risk of serious COVID-19 for unvaccinated young adults—including neurological complications and worsening seizure control—is consistently higher than the combined rare vaccine-related events.

Because individual circumstances (other medical conditions, specific AEDs, local virus circulation) matter, discuss your final choice with your own physician or neurologist when you can reach them. But based on current evidence, having mild, well-controlled epilepsy should not prevent you from receiving whichever authorised COVID-19 vaccine you can get first.

190.question: I am 14, Male I was diagnosed with Photosensitive Epilepsy at a young age if that helps.
190.answer:
Thank you for sharing that information. I’m happy to help in any way I can. Because you mentioned photosensitive epilepsy, here are a few important points that people in your situation often find useful:

1. Common triggers  
   • Flashing or flickering lights (e.g., strobe lights, certain video games, rapidly changing TV scenes).  
   • High-contrast patterns (e.g., black-and-white stripes).  
   • Bright, direct sunlight flickering through trees or blinds, especially while riding in a car or bus.

2. Practical everyday steps  
   • Screen settings: Lower the brightness on phones, tablets, and computer monitors; enable “night” or “dark” modes; use blue-light-filter or anti-flicker apps if available.  
   • Viewing distance: Sit at least an arm’s length from screens, especially large TVs or computer monitors.  
   • Breaks: Follow the “20-20-20” rule—every 20 minutes, look at something 20 feet away for 20 seconds, and blink to refresh your eyes.  
   • Sunglasses/filters: Polarized or specially tinted lenses can cut down on flicker and glare outdoors or under fluorescent lighting.  
   • Gaming: Check for “photosensitive mode” or “reduced flashing” settings in video games. Pause if you feel strange sensations (e.g., eye twitching, dizziness, nausea).  
   • School environment: Ask to sit away from flickering fluorescent lights; request diffusers or alternative lighting if certain bulbs trigger you.  
   • Transport: In cars, consider sitting away from rapidly flickering sunlight through trees (often back seat on the opposite side of the sun). Wearing a peaked cap or tinted lenses can help.

3. General health habits  
   • Consistent sleep: Irregular or insufficient sleep can lower seizure threshold.  
   • Hydration and nutrition: Balanced meals and adequate fluids support overall brain health.  
   • Stress management: Relaxation techniques (deep breathing, gentle exercise, talking with friends or family) can reduce seizure risk related to stress.  
   • Medication adherence: If you’re on anti-seizure medicine, take it exactly as prescribed and discuss any side effects with your doctor.

4. Safety tips  
   • Medical ID: Carry a medical ID bracelet or have emergency info on your phone.  
   • Friends & teachers: Make sure close friends, relatives, and key school staff know what to do if you have a seizure (e.g., protect your head, move harmful objects, don’t restrain you, call emergency services if a convulsive seizure lasts >5 minutes).  
   • Supervision for risky activities: Swimming, climbing, or cycling should be done with someone who knows your condition and basic first aid. Wearing a helmet when biking or skating is critical.

5. Emotional wellbeing  
   • It’s normal to feel frustrated or different. Talking with a counselor, support group, or trusted adult can help.  
   • Many teens with photosensitive epilepsy lead active lives—sports, gaming, social events—by planning ahead and knowing their triggers.

6. When to seek medical help (or tell a parent/guardian to call your doctor)  
   • Seizures change in type, frequency, or severity.  
   • New side effects from medication.  
   • You injure yourself during a seizure.  
   • Mood changes, sleep problems, or any issue that worries you or your family.

If you have specific questions—about school, sports, screens, medications, or anything else—feel free to let me know. I can provide general information, but this should never replace advice from your neurologist or primary care doctor, who knows your medical history best.

Take care, and I’m here if you’d like to dive deeper on any topic!

191.question: I’m (19M) 6 foot 2, 74kg. I’m on clobasam and tegratol for my epilepsy . Don’t smoke and have nocturnal epilepsy (only have seizures in the middle of the night during sleep, often after sleep walking)So basically the doctor I always see has made it very clear that I shouldn’t have more than 2 standard drinks in one night. However I was left feeling like there was more he could have said on the matter but didn’t want to go into it.So when I was younger I set out with a plan to gradually increase the amount of alcohol I drink when I go out to see how I feel drinking more and to see if I can get away with drinking a bit more. This got to the point where I have felt fine every time and I now just drink as much as I feel like at the time. This means I often have between 5-7 standards and on rare occasions above 10.I drink as much as the night entails but am just realising that I could have just been lucky all these times. This is a question I have always want answered and one that doctors always avoid answering or don’t fully answer.So my question is: are some epileptics able to drink as much as any other person and be fine and could I be one of those people OR have I just been lucky all this time and do I need to make some changes?It’s been frustratingly hard to get a straight answer on this dilemma anywhere and it just occurred to me now that I could ask reddit! All comments appreciated :) Thanks in advance
191.answer:
(I’m not your doctor and this shouldn’t replace personal medical advice, but I’ll explain what neurologists usually worry about when alcohol and epilepsy mix so you can understand why the “two-drink” rule is so common.)

1. What alcohol itself does to the seizure threshold  
• A single small drink (≈1 standard unit) usually has little effect on the brain’s excitability.  
• Larger, fast “binge” doses (≈5+ drinks in one sitting) transiently lower the seizure threshold while alcohol is being absorbed and again 6-48 h later as the blood level falls. The second phase (“withdrawal”) is the most common time for alcohol-related seizures, even in people who do not have chronic alcoholism.  
• Because you only seize in sleep, the high-fall-then-withdrawal cycle happens right when you’re in bed and the brain is already in its most seizure-prone state. That is why the advice is extra strict for nocturnal epilepsy.

2. Interactions with your medicines  
• Carbamazepine (Tegretol) and alcohol are both handled by the liver.  
  – A single binge raises your carbamazepine level for a few hours (the liver is busy with ethanol).  
  – Repeated binges induce liver enzymes and later LOWER the level. This up-then-down swing can destabilize seizure control without you noticing immediately.  
• Clobazam is a benzodiazepine. Alcohol plus a benzo = much more sedation, impaired airway reflexes, and shallow breathing in sleep. That increases the risk of SUDEP (sudden unexpected death in epilepsy).  
• Both drugs can intensify the hangover/withdrawal rebound. If you oversleep, vomit, or simply forget a dose after a night out, the seizure risk multiplies.

3. Practical data: are some people “immune”?  
• Studies that have followed thousands of patients show a clear dose-response curve: up to about 1–2 units in 24 h carries little extra risk; beyond 4–5 units at a time the risk of a breakthrough seizure roughly triples, regardless of type of epilepsy.  
• About 50 % of people who binge repeatedly will eventually have an alcohol-related seizure, even if they never had one before. You might simply be in the lucky half—so far.  
• The first alcohol-triggered seizure is often worse (generalised tonic-clonic, longer, harder to recover from) and can cluster because of the withdrawal physiology.

4. Other ways alcohol nights trigger seizures indirectly  
• Missed or late medication doses  
• Dehydration and electrolyte shifts  
• Sleep deprivation / fragmented REM sleep  
• Stress hormones (cortisol, adrenalin) surging the next morning

5. So what do epilepsy guidelines actually say?  
UK, US, Canadian and Australian epilepsy societies all converge on:  
• 0–2 standard drinks on an occasion is acceptable for most adults with controlled epilepsy.  
• Avoid binge drinking (≥4 for women, ≥5 for men in one session).  
• Never skip doses; take the night-time dose at the normal time with water, even if you’re out.  
• Have at least two alcohol-free days per week.  
• If you have any increase in seizure frequency, cut alcohol to zero until stable for several months.

6. Your specific situation  
   – You are 19, which means your brain is still completing frontal-lobe maturation; binge patterns now predict future dependence and poorer seizure control later.  
   – You take a benzodiazepine every day (clobazam) and a liver-enzyme drug (carbamazepine); both magnify alcohol’s risks.  
   – Your seizures happen in sleep, so the timing of alcohol peaks and withdrawals overlaps the most vulnerable period.

That doesn’t prove you will definitely seize the next time you have 7 drinks—but the probability curve is tilted a lot further against you than against your non-epileptic friends. From a neurologist’s view you haven’t proven you’re “safe”; you’ve only proven you’ve been lucky.

7. What to do if you want to keep social drinking in the picture  
• Set an upper limit of 2 standards in a 24-h period. Space them out, drink water between.  
• Take your meds on time (set a phone alarm before you start drinking).  
• Eat beforehand; avoid energy drinks and sleep deprivation.  
• Keep a seizure/alcohol diary for a few months. If even one seizure appears, go to zero alcohol for at least six months.  
• Discuss an honest alcohol history with your neurologist; sometimes medication regimens can be adjusted, or you can have supervised “stress tests” in an EMU (epilepsy monitoring unit) if decisions are genuinely unclear.  
• Make sure friends know basic seizure first aid and that you have a medical alert.

Bottom line  
Some people with epilepsy do seem to tolerate the occasional drink, but nobody is reliably “immune” to the pro-seizure effects of binge drinking. Given your nighttime seizure pattern, clobazam use and age, 5–10 drinks is well inside the danger zone; the fact that nothing bad has happened yet is luck, not proof of safety. If you want to minimize seizure risk—and the additional dangers of SUDEP, falls and medication interactions—sticking to no more than 1–2 standard drinks and avoiding binges is the evidence-based limit.

192.question: 21F. I pretty much have generalized hyperhidrosis but the sweating in my feet, hands, and underarms are what bother me the most. I’ve been looking into Iontophoresis but read that people with epilepsy might not be able to use this treatment. Anyone know anything about this? Thanks!Can someone with epilepsy use Iontophoresis for excessive sweating?
192.answer:
Short answer  
Most manufacturers and clinical guidelines list “epilepsy or a history of seizures” as a CONTRA-INDICATION (or at least a strong precaution) for tap-water iontophoresis.  That means you should not begin the treatment on your own; you need to talk to the physician who manages your seizures as well as the doctor treating your hyperhidrosis and decide together whether the potential benefit outweighs the (largely theoretical) risk.

Why is epilepsy mentioned at all?  
•  Tap-water iontophoresis passes a small direct current (typically 10-25 mA) through the hands, feet, or axillae for 15-20 minutes.  
•  Very little current reaches the central nervous system, and no well-documented cases of a seizure induced by iontophoresis have been published.  
•  Nevertheless, formal safety studies in people with epilepsy have never been done. Because an electrical current is involved, manufacturers and insurers prefer to label epilepsy as a contraindication rather than accept a potential liability.  

What the guidelines say  
International Hyperhidrosis Society, most device Instructions for Use, and several dermatology textbooks: “Do not use in patients who are pregnant, have a pacemaker or significant cardiac arrhythmia, metal implants in the treatment area, or epilepsy.”  
UpToDate and some other medical references list epilepsy as a “relative” (not absolute) contraindication—meaning it can be considered with caution under physician supervision.

If you and your neurologist/dermatologist decide to try it anyway  
1. Make sure seizures have been well-controlled and drug levels stable.  
2. Start with the lowest current (e.g., 5 mA) and short duration; increase slowly.  
3. Have another person present the first few sessions.  
4. Stop immediately if you feel an aura or any neurologic symptoms.  
5. Keep rescue medication (if you normally carry one) nearby.  
6. Use a modern battery-powered unit (isolated circuit) rather than an older wall-plug device to minimize stray currents.

Alternative hyperhidrosis treatments when iontophoresis is ruled out  
• Topical 20 % aluminum chloride (Drysol®, Hypercare®) nightly for 1–2 weeks then taper.  
• Topical anticholinergic wipes/lotions (glycopyrronium cloths, sofpironium gel, etc.).  
• Oral anticholinergics (glycopyrrolate, oxybutynin); dose must be balanced against dry-mouth, blurred vision, etc.  
• Botulinum-toxin injections (effective for palms, soles, and axillae; lasts ~6 months).  
• Microwave thermolysis (miraDry®) for axillae only.  
• Endoscopic thoracic sympathectomy—reserved for the most severe, refractory palmar cases because of risk of compensatory sweating.

Bottom line  
There is no proven direct link between iontophoresis and seizure induction, but because the therapy uses electrical current and safety data in epilepsy are sparse, it is officially labeled “contraindicated.”  Discuss it with your neurologist and dermatologist; together you can weigh the (low but unknown) risk against the benefit or choose another evidence-based treatment for your hyperhidrosis.

193.question: I've been epileptic since i was 14, and i'm concerned about whether this condition increases risk of brain related diseases as i get older.I'm part of the lucky ones, as i have treatment, and don't suffer any full blown seizures normally. My doctor told me that my epilepsy type is one that makes up 12.5 % of all epiletics, which we don't know how it functions. There's an anomaly in my brain, and we know how to treat it, but we don't know why.I've suffered 4 of these total, the first time when i didn't know, obviously. Second time 3 weeks later when i got off my meds when doctors wanted to know if it was a one time thing or not, third time the very next day when i hadn't been back on my meds yet.Then 8 years passed, and i lived with it. I occasionally got part seizures that got me to figure out the 3 things i need for a real one not to occur : get sleep, not skip more than twice on my meds, not get stressed. I can get away with missing one of these requirements, i get part seizures if i miss 2, which whips me right back on track. But last year, i had my fourth seizure.This one was a lot harder than my first ones. I used to get my memory jumbled, which would enventually return. This time i forgot entirely what happened for the full day, my last memory was setting my alarm and seeing i would only have 6h30 of sleep instead of 8. So that's definitely 1 out of 3. I guess i forgot to take my meds in the morning and got a stressful day. I still don't know what happened that day, just that it happened while riding back home on my bike.I thought i'd ask my brain doctor about a lot of things on our following check up, but he rushed our meeting, and straight up told me not to ask so many questions. I thought i'd come prepared this year to ask more, but with the outbreak our meeting was postponed.TL;DR : does epilepsy increase brain related diseases with time ? are seizures and part seizures bad for the brain and should be avoided at all cost ?
193.answer:
Below is the short version first, followed by a more detailed explanation with references.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Key points (the “short answer”)

1. Having epilepsy does raise the lifetime risk of certain other brain problems (stroke, depression/anxiety, and – to a lesser extent – dementia) but most people with well-controlled seizures live normal lives and never develop these complications.

2. A brief self-limited seizure (seconds to a few minutes) almost never injures the brain.  
   – The exceptions are very prolonged seizures (status epilepticus, >5 min) or frequent clusters, which can damage neurons, especially in the hippocampus.  
   – The main dangers of an ordinary seizure are indirect: falls, accidents, sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP), and loss of independence.

3. The fewer seizures you have, the better. Staying on medication, getting enough sleep and avoiding major stressors are still the three best self-management tools we have.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
In more detail

1. Does epilepsy increase the risk of other brain diseases as you get older?

• Stroke.  Large population studies (e.g., INSTINCT, Rochester Cohort, Danish National Registry) show that adults with epilepsy have ≈2–4-fold higher risk of stroke than age-matched controls. The causes are multifactorial (shared risk factors, vascular changes from long-standing seizures, some drug interactions). Good blood-pressure, cholesterol and diabetes control are therefore important.

• Cognitive decline / dementia.  Recent meta-analyses suggest about a 1.5–2-fold higher incidence of late-life dementia in people with longstanding epilepsy. That increase is:
  – strongest in people whose seizures began after age 50 (often meaning an underlying vascular or degenerative brain process was already present)  
  – smaller in people with childhood- or adolescent-onset idiopathic epilepsies that have been well controlled for years.  
Controlling seizures, minimizing prolonged events, keeping cardiovascular risk factors low and staying mentally active are the current best strategies for protecting long-term cognition.

• Psychiatric disorders.  Depression and anxiety are roughly twice as common in people with epilepsy. Part of this seems biologic (shared limbic circuits); part is reactive (living with a chronic condition). Treating mood disorders actively improves seizure control and vice-versa.

• Traumatic brain injury.  Any convulsive seizure increases the chance of head injury or concussion by falls or motor-vehicle/bicycle accidents. Helmets and other safety precautions reduce this risk substantially.

2. Do individual seizures damage the brain?

• Brief focal aware seizures (“auras”) or focal impaired-awareness seizures lasting <2 min are not known to cause permanent injury.

• Generalized tonic-clonic seizures: isolated events rarely cause measurable damage, but repeated convulsions over years can be associated with hippocampal atrophy and subtle cognitive slowing in some patients.

• Status epilepticus (>5 min continuous seizure or recurrent seizures without recovery) clearly can injure the brain; this is why it is treated as a neurological emergency.

• Seizure clustering: several generalized seizures in one day also increases the risk for neuronal injury and SUDEP.

Bottom line: occasional short seizures are generally tolerated by the brain, but prolonged or very frequent ones should be prevented whenever possible.

3. Why did the most recent seizure feel worse and wipe out an entire day of memory?

The longer a seizure or post-ictal state lasts, the more profound the temporary amnesia can be. Sleep deprivation plus missed medication plus stress is a classic “perfect storm.” The seizure itself probably wasn’t fundamentally different, but your post-ictal confusion was longer. One full-blown convulsion after eight seizure-free years is still regarded as good overall control, but it does mean you are not in the “seizure-free for life” group and therefore still need continuous medication.

4. Should sub-clinical or partial seizures be tolerated?

Ideally you want zero seizures of any type because:
  • Even focal events reduce quality of life and can slowly “kindle” networks that make a generalized convulsion more likely.  
  • Any seizure, however small, can occur while driving or cycling and become dangerous within seconds.  
If you are averaging only a few very mild auras a year many neurologists will accept that, but anyone having more than one every few months usually gets an adjustment in medication.

5. Practical steps to keep risk low

Medication adherence  
• Missing one dose of many anti-seizure medicines lowers the serum level into the “sub-therapeutic” range for 12–24 h. Missing two in a row is basically drug withdrawal. Phone alarms, day-of-the-week pill boxes, or switching to a longer-half-life once-a-day drug (e.g., lamotrigine XR, brivaracetam, perampanel) can help.

Sleep discipline  
• Aim for your personal “quota.” Sleep deprivation is one of the most reproducible seizure triggers in all forms of epilepsy.

Stress management  
• Exercise, cognitive-behavioral therapy, mindfulness or relaxation techniques can cut seizure frequency in small controlled trials. Alcohol binges, cannabis withdrawal and some energy drinks are frequent but under-reported triggers.

Follow-up imaging and EEG  
• Because you have a known “anomaly” on MRI, guidelines suggest re-imaging every 3–5 years (or sooner if the seizure pattern changes) to be sure there is no evolving lesion.  
• A repeat EEG after your breakthrough seizure may help determine whether your inter-ictal discharges have increased.

Vaccinations, blood pressure, lipids  
• Since stroke risk is higher, keep vascular numbers in the normal range and get regular primary-care check-ups.

Mood screening  
• If sleep or stress are chronic problems, screening for depression/anxiety and treating them vigorously improves seizure control in randomized studies.

Medical alert / safety  
• When cycling, ski-helmet-type head protection, a Road-ID or medical-alert bracelet and route planning that avoids heavy traffic are smart safeguards.

6. When to ask about other treatments

If you ever a) need two or more drugs yet still have seizures, b) have side effects that limit your daily life, or c) experience status epilepticus, ask for referral to an epilepsy center for an in-depth evaluation (video-EEG monitoring, possible surgery, neuro-stimulation devices, dietary therapies).

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Take-home messages

• Epilepsy moderately increases the risk of stroke, mood disorders and (to a lesser extent) dementia, but good seizure control and the usual “heart-healthy brain-healthy” habits offset much of that risk.

• Ordinary short seizures do not usually damage the brain, but status epilepticus and frequent generalized seizures can.

• Your own data (missing medication + sleep loss + stress = seizure) matches what we see in clinic. Keeping those three factors under control really does matter.

• Bring this written list of questions to your next neurology visit; if time is short, ask for a longer appointment or a separate tele-visit focused only on education.

References (key, recent)

1. Keezer MR, et al. The risk of stroke in people with epilepsy: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Brain. 2016.  
2. Ding J, et al. Epilepsy and risk of dementia: A meta-analysis. Epilepsy Behav. 2019.  
3. Beghi E, et al. Mortality in epilepsy. Neurology. 2015.  
4. Thom M. Hippocampal sclerosis in epilepsy: A neuropathology review. Nat Rev Neurol. 2014.  
5. Trinka E, et al. A definition and classification of status epilepticus. Epilepsia. 2015.  
6. Perucca P, et al. Adherence to antiepileptic drugs. Epilepsy Behav. 2018.

I hope this gives you a clearer picture and some concrete talking points for your next appointment.
