194.question: 31 yrs old Male United States I’ve had a lot of issues with flashing lights, so I’m going on to get a sleep deprived EEG in two weeks.While I wait it over, I’ve realized there’s a lot of times in my life where I don’t always pay attention, have a staring spell and/or feel like I’m spacing off or thinking of something else.For example, people sometimes talk to me or I’m not paying attention and when they ask me a question I say “what” even though I can recall what they’re saying and I’m wondering if this is me just not paying attention or having an absent seizure.Other times I’m stuck in a staring spell state (no more than 15-30 seconds) and it feels good, and then my wife interrupts me and she says I say “why did you do that, I was stuck in a good stare”. So I’m wondering if these things are somewhat normal and people without epilepsy have them? Or if this is indicative of absent seizures and epilepsy.I know I’m probably overthinking this but I’m wondering how often it is to have no diagnoses of epilepsy for 31+ years and never having a serious seizure...but having epilepsy. Any suggestions or input would be appreciated.Thanks
194.answer:
First, a quick reminder: only your own doctor, after hearing the full story and seeing the tests, can tell you whether what you are describing is epileptic.  What follows is background information to help you understand what the neurologist is looking for and why the sleep-deprived EEG was ordered.

1. Do “normal” people ever stare, zone-out, or say “What?” even though they heard you?  
   Yes – all the time.  Day-dreaming, getting absorbed in an inner thought, being sleepy, or having an attention-deficit disorder can all look exactly like a brief “staring spell.”  In fact, brief lapses of attention lasting a few seconds are far more commonly non-epileptic than epileptic.

2. How do absence or other staring seizures usually behave?  
   • Abrupt start and abrupt stop (“someone flipped a switch”).  
   • Typically last 5–15 s (rarely >30 s).  
   • You usually have no memory of what happened during the spell.  
   • Cannot be brought out of it by someone calling your name or shaking you.  
   • Happen many times per day, almost every day, if they are classical childhood-onset “absence” seizures.  
   • May show subtle automatisms: eyelid flutter, lip smacking, finger rubbing.  
   • Hyperventilation for 3 min or strobe lights on EEG can reliably bring them out in susceptible people.  

   In adults, the more common “staring” seizure is actually a focal impaired-awareness seizure (formerly “complex partial”).  Those last 30 s to 2 min, may leave you confused for another minute, and often start from a temporal-lobe focus.

3. What in your description leans more toward ordinary lapses of attention?  
   • You can usually recall what was said.  
   • You seem aware while it is happening (“I was stuck in a good stare”).  
   • Your wife’s voice can break the spell.  
   • They are not happening dozens of times per day.  

   None of those absolutely rule out seizures, but they make day-dreaming, microsleeps (if you are tired), ADHD-type lapses, or anxiety/depressive “mind wandering” more likely.

4. Can someone reach age 31 without ever having a convulsion and still have epilepsy?  
   Possible, but uncommon.  Incidence of new-onset epilepsy in adults is about 50 per 100 000 each year.  Having only absence-like seizures that began in adulthood with no childhood history is rare.  Much more often, adult-onset epilepsy presents with:  
   • Focal impaired-awareness seizures (staring, lip smacking, déjà-vu, 1–2 min)  
   • Generalized tonic-clonic convulsion  

5. Why a sleep-deprived EEG?  
   • Sleep loss makes epileptic discharges more likely to show up.  
   • Hyperventilation and photic stimulation are usually done during the study to look for absence or photosensitive epilepsy.  
   • One normal EEG does NOT completely rule out epilepsy; it only increases the odds that spells are non-epileptic.  Up to 30–40 % of people with epilepsy have a normal routine EEG between seizures.

6. How to prepare / what to bring your neurologist:  
   • Keep a diary: date, time, duration, what you and observers noticed, triggers (stress, bright lights, fatigue, video games, alcohol, etc.).  
   • If possible, have someone record an episode on a phone.  A 15-second video is often more valuable than pages of notes.  
   • List all meds, caffeine/energy-drink use, alcohol or recreational drugs, and sleep habits.  
   • Ask family whether you ever had staring spells or convulsions as a child.

7. Safety while you are being worked up:  
   • Get enough sleep; overtired brains are more seizure-prone.  
   • Go easy with strobe-heavy environments (clubs, VR headsets, certain video games) until testing is done.  
   • No swimming alone, climbing high ladders, or bath-tub soaking unattended if you truly think you might blank out.  
   • Laws on driving vary by state; most advise you not to drive if you believe you are having spells that impair awareness.

8. If the EEG is normal but symptoms persist, your neurologist might:  
   • Order a longer ambulatory or video EEG.  
   • Obtain an MRI to rule out structural brain causes.  
   • Consider a sleep study if microsleeps or narcolepsy are suspected.  
   • Evaluate for attention-deficit, anxiety, or mood disorders if the history fits.

Bottom line  
Brief zoning-out spells are extremely common and most are not epileptic.  Adult-onset absence-type epilepsy is possible but distinctly uncommon, and tends to cause many uninterruptible episodes a day with no memory for the gap.  A sleep-deprived EEG with photic stimulation and hyperventilation is a good next step; keep a detailed spell diary and, if able, a video of an event to give your neurologist the best chance of sorting this out.

195.question: Hi. Over several months I (20f) have been feeling tired very easily. My family say I’ve lost weight - I’ve always had a low appetite but I’ve always done my best to make sure I’m getting enough calories/work around my lack of appetite by eating high calorie food, snacking regularly, and I think I get enough or more calories daily. I’m naturally pretty pale but my family say I’m paler. I decided to go to the doctor bc for about 3 weeks I’ve been extremely thirsty, waking up in the night repeatedly to get water despite drinking tons etc. As my mother has type 1 diabetes she told me to make an appointment Doc mentioned diabetes which thankfully none of the results support!They’ve called back (the gp surgery) to say I have low folate and low ferritin and to make an appointment. They sent over the results which include:VITAMIN B12 Serum vitamin B12 level 398.0 ng/L [211.0 - 911.0]FOLATE (SERUM) Serum folate level 3.89 ug/L [> 5.38] Below low reference limitFERRITIN Serum C reactive protein level < 4 mg/L [0.0 - 6.0] Serum ferritin level 14.2 ug/L [10.0 - 291.0]I had a quick google because I have epilepsy and wanted to know before e appointment if I should ask about contacting my neuro or if it could affect my epilepsy etc. However when I looked I was confused - I can see that someone can have both folate deficiency and, say, iron deficiency with a poor diet, but I always thought my diet was fine? Are there any other ways they can be connected? Obv not huge as hopefully I’ll find out but I’m curious. And could this affect my epilepsy in any way?Possible relevant info: My periods are light, regular and if I take painkillers then I don’t have any pain. I have epilepsy but it’s controlled by Keppra/leviteracetam, which I always take. No other meds. I know anti convulsants can affect ferritin levels etc but it seems to be “anti convulsants except keppra” usually!I exercise a little - 30 minutes of yoga, walk thé dog twice a day, I am in a place where I can walk everywhere to get around. I eat chicken, pork, fish, liver regularly (I have meat basically every day excepté 1 to 2 days per week ), I drink milk fairly regularly, rarely have eggs, always have my 7 a day (I think in America the recommendation is 5 but here it is 7 - mostly from veg e.g broccoli, carrots, squash, spinach, cauliflower, kale, but I also like apples, oranges, satsumas, grapes etc all the time).
195.answer:
What the blood test is telling you  
• Ferritin 14 µg/L  ➔  Your iron stores are almost empty (most laboratories quote ≤15 µg/L as iron-deficient).  
• Serum folate 3.9 µg/L (reference >5.3) ➔ Low folate.  
• B-12 normal.  
If a full blood count was done you would probably see a small-cell (microcytic) picture from the iron lack, sometimes mixed with a large-cell (macrocytic) picture from the folate lack.

Why the two deficiencies often appear together  
Both iron and folate are absorbed in the upper part of the small intestine (duodenum / proximal jejunum). Any problem that interferes with this area can lower both nutrients at the same time:

‒ Coeliac disease (by far the commonest cause in young women who appear to “eat well”).  
‒ Other malabsorption conditions – Crohn’s involving the small bowel, post-surgical bowel shortening, chronic pancreatitis, untreated H. pylori gastritis, etc.  
‒ Certain drugs (but not levetiracetam) or large, regular alcohol intake.  
‒ Very restrictive or unbalanced diet (less likely from what you describe).  

Iron deficiency can also come from blood loss (periods, gastrointestinal bleeding, frequent blood donation) while folate can fall with increased demand (pregnancy, rapid growth, haemolytic anaemia).  When the two coexist, malabsorption is the first thing physicians rule out.

Could levetiracetam (Keppra) be the cause?  
Unlikely. Folate problems are seen with older enzyme-inducing anti-epileptics (phenytoin, carbamazepine, phenobarbital). Levetiracetam has not been shown to deplete folate or iron.

Can low iron / folate affect epilepsy?  
• Mild to moderate deficiency usually does not change seizure control.  
• Severe anaemia can reduce brain oxygenation and may lower the seizure threshold.  
• Marked folate deficiency can elevate homocysteine, which in some studies has made the brain a little more excitable, but this is uncommon and reversible with supplementation.  
So correcting the deficiencies is advisable but there is no immediate danger to your seizure control.

Next steps your GP is likely to take  

1. Confirm the extent of the anaemia  
   – Full blood count: Hb, MCV, reticulocyte count.  
   – Red-cell folate (more stable than serum folate).  

2. Look for a cause  
   – Coeliac screen (IgA-tTG ± total IgA).  
   – Ferritin <15 usually triggers a search for bleeding: stool occult blood test, possibly endoscopy/colonoscopy if there are GI symptoms or positive family history.  
   – Review menstrual history (even “light” bleeding adds up over months).  
   – Review diet, tea/coffee intake with meals, calcium supplements, proton-pump inhibitors, etc.  

3. Treat  
   Iron: e.g. ferrous sulphate 200 mg (65 mg elemental iron) 2–3 ×/day, or a gentler preparation every other day until ferritin >30 µg/L, then another 3 months.  
   Folate: folic acid 5 mg daily for 4 months (longer if malabsorption persists).  
   Both tablets can be taken together.  
   Vitamin B-12 is normal so injections are not needed.

4. Re-check bloods about 4–6 weeks after starting tablets to be sure haemoglobin and ferritin are rising and folate is normalising.

What about the excessive thirst?  
Because your glucose tests were normal, the commonest remaining explanations are:  
   • Habitual / psychogenic polydipsia (especially if you consciously “drink tons”).  
   • Dry mouth from mouth-breathing, anxiety, air-conditioned rooms, etc.  
   • Less commonly: diabetes insipidus, high calcium, kidney disorder.  
Basic blood chemistry (electrolytes, calcium, urea/creatinine) and a urine sample usually pick up the rarer causes. Mention the thirst again at your follow-up so it isn’t overlooked.

Practical tips while waiting for the appointment  
• Take a daily multivitamin if you have it at home (doesn’t replace prescription doses but won’t hurt).  
• Put iron-rich foods (red meat, liver, beans, fortified cereal) together with a source of vitamin C and away from tea/coffee/dairy which block absorption.  
• Keep a simple record of how much water you actually drink in 24 h – it helps the doctor decide whether further tests for polydipsia are needed.  
• Continue taking Keppra exactly as prescribed; there is no interaction with iron or folic acid tablets.

Bottom line  
Low ferritin + low folate in a young woman with an apparently adequate diet almost always warrant a search for malabsorption (coeliac disease tops the list) or occult blood loss.  The deficiencies are easy to correct, rarely interfere with epilepsy, and once the underlying cause is found and treated you should regain energy—and probably notice less thirst—within a few weeks.

196.question: 9 year old (M) had his first seizure. He is 4 ft 5 inches. 37.5 kgs. No medical issues. We went into a state of panic because we never thought it could happen to us. We took him to ER. They did CT scan and found no masses or lesions etc. Usually they wait for a second event to diagnose as epilepsy but they did EEG and said it was abnormal....so based on it they concluded it is primary generalized epilepsy (with tonic clonic seizures??) and decided they dont need to do MRI or anything like that. He was prescribed Depakote ER 250 mg twice a day. After a month, he is supposed to have a longer video EEG done.We asked the Dr a bunch of questions and they were helpful in answering. But I read about Depakote and it seems like a rough one. Some questions -    How come he had abnormal EEG hours after the event? Does he always have that sort of EEG?    Could this abnormal EEG have affected his growth and mental development?    Should we worry about underlying cause? And get an MRI done to look for scarring?    Realistically, what is the quality of life for my son on Depakote? Behavior changes, hairloss, liver toxicity? I am asking for real experience...not the side effects page on WebMD.    I am not a hippie but can we avoid taking Depakote and other anti-convulsive drugs? Instead give him CBD etc?    Should we get a second or a 3rd opinion? Should we get another EEG or just show that EEG to other neurologists?Thanks in advance!
196.answer:
I’m sorry your family had such a frightening experience. Below is the kind of discussion I have with parents in clinic when a child has a first tonic-clonic seizure, an abnormal EEG and is started on valproate (Depakote).  Use it to frame your next conversation with your own neurologist; only the team that has examined your son and reviewed the EEG can give definitive advice.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  WHY WAS THE EEG ABNORMAL A FEW HOURS AFTER THE SEIZURE?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• The EEG done between seizures (the “inter-ictal” EEG) often shows brief spikes, spike-and-wave or poly-spike-and-wave complexes in children with generalized epilepsy.  
• These discharges are NOT the same as a continuous seizure.  They come and go and do not damage the brain.  
• An EEG can be completely normal in many children with epilepsy, but when it is clearly abnormal (as in your son) it raises the risk that another seizure will occur.  That is the main reason treatment was offered after a single event.

Is it always abnormal?  Inter-ictal epileptiform activity can fluctuate.  A repeat EEG on another day may still show spikes, or it may be normal.  The presence or absence of spikes on any single recording tells us very little about current cognitive functioning.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  COULD THE EEG ABNORMALITY HAVE AFFECTED GROWTH OR MENTAL DEVELOPMENT?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• No.  The EEG pattern itself does not stunt growth or development.  
• If a child were having many unrecognized seizures every day (for example, absence seizures dozens of times an hour) learning could be disrupted, but that does not sound like your son’s presentation.  
• Your neurologist will nevertheless keep an eye on school performance, sleep and behaviour because subtle seizures or medication side-effects can masquerade as “attention problems.”

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  DO WE NEED AN MRI TO LOOK FOR SCARRING OR OTHER STRUCTURAL CAUSES?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Guideline summary (American Academy of Neurology / Child Neurology Society):
• If the EEG is strongly suggestive of a primary generalized (also called idiopathic generalized) epilepsy, and the neurological examination is normal, structural brain disease is very unlikely.  MRI can be deferred.  
• MRI is recommended when  
  – the EEG is focal, or  
  – there are focal findings on exam, or  
  – seizures start in the first year of life, or  
  – there is anything atypical about the story (head trauma, infection, developmental delay, etc.)  

Parents sometimes want the extra reassurance of an MRI anyway.  That is reasonable—MRI involves no radiation—but it usually requires the logistics and expense of sedation in a 9-year-old.  Discuss risks, benefits and costs with your team.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  VALPROATE (DEPAKOTE): WHAT IS LIFE REALLY LIKE ON IT?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Why valproate was chosen  
• Still the single most effective broad-spectrum anti-seizure medicine for primary generalized epilepsy in school-age children.  
• Works for tonic-clonic, myoclonic and absence seizures.  
• Your son’s dose: 250 mg twice daily = 500 mg/day ≈ 13 mg/kg/day.  Typical starting range is 10–15 mg/kg/day; so this is a standard low-to-mid start.

The big side-effects we watch for in real children

COMMON, MOSTLY MINOR (5–30 %):
• Weight gain, increased appetite.  Happens gradually; emphasise diet and regular exercise up front.
• Tremor of hands (fine shake when holding hands out).
• Hair thinning/oiliness.  Usually mild; biotin or selenium supplements can help.
• Upset stomach, nausea; less common with the ER (extended release) form you are using.
• Reduced platelet count or easy bruising.  Usually only an issue if the dose is pushed high; detected early on routine blood work.

LESS COMMON BUT IMPORTANT (1–5 %):
• Drowsiness, slowed processing speed in class.  Often improves after the first few weeks.  If persistent, dose can be split AM/noon/PM or another medicine chosen.
• Polycystic-ovary-like changes in teen girls (weight gain, irregular menses).  Not an issue in a 9-year-old boy.

RARE, SERIOUS (<1 : 10,000):
• Liver failure.  Risk highest in children <2 yrs or with metabolic disease.  In a healthy 9-year-old the risk is extremely low, but we still check liver function and a platelet count at baseline, 3 months, and then every 6–12 months.
• Pancreatitis.  Presents with severe abdominal pain/vomiting; parents are advised to seek attention immediately if that occurs.
• Severe allergic rash (Stevens-Johnson) – extremely uncommon with valproate.

Quality of life data  
More than half of children with idiopathic generalized epilepsy become seizure-free with the first medication they try; valproate is the most common first choice in boys because of its high success rate and generally good tolerability.  Most play sports, ride bikes, swim, attend school camps, and live their normal life with a few sensible safety modifications (see section 7).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  ARE THERE ALTERNATIVES TO VALPROATE?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Yes.  First-line broad-spectrum options for generalized epilepsy include:
• Levetiracetam (Keppra) – easy dosing, no lab tests; can cause irritability / mood swing in ~15–20 %.
• Lamotrigine (Lamictal) – weight-neutral, but must be titrated very slowly (8–10 weeks) to avoid severe rash.
• Topiramate (Topamax) – may suppress appetite/weight, can cause word-finding difficulty or tingling hands/feet.
Most paediatric neurologists still start with valproate in boys unless there is a specific contraindication because long-term seizure-freedom rates are highest.

If significant side-effects appear, we switch – you are never locked into a drug.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  CAN WE SKIP MEDICATION AND USE CBD, DIET ETC.?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• Risk of another unprovoked seizure when the first seizure is accompanied by a clearly epileptiform EEG is around 60–70 % over the next 2 years.  
• Each generalized tonic-clonic seizure carries risk of injury, drowning, or rare sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP).   Reducing seizure frequency with a proven medication is considered the safer course.
• Cannabidiol (Epidiolex) is FDA-approved only for Dravet, Lennox-Gastaut and tuberous-sclerosis-related seizures.  Evidence for typical primary generalized epilepsy is sparse; insurance rarely covers it; dosing requires large volumes and can still cause liver enzyme elevations.
• Ketogenic or modified-Atkins diets are effective for some refractory epilepsies but are usually reserved for children who have failed two medications, because they are socially restrictive and hard to maintain.
Bottom line: Drug-free approaches can be adjuncts, but for a first presentation with high relapse risk they are not considered first-line.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  DAY-TO-DAY SAFETY AND LIFESTYLE
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
• Until seizure control is established (generally 6 months seizure-free) use “common-sense water safety”: swim only with direct supervision, shower rather than soak in a tub, wear a life-jacket for boating.  
• No climbing on roofs, trees or high play-structures unsupervised.  
• Biking, skiing, team sports are fine with a helmet once seizures are controlled.  
• Adequate nightly sleep lowers seizure risk.  
• School should be informed so they can respond appropriately if a seizure occurs; an action plan can be supplied.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
8.  SHOULD WE SEEK A SECOND/THIRD OPINION OR REPEAT THE EEG?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Very reasonable to obtain another opinion if:
• You are not fully comfortable with the diagnosis,
• You wish to explore alternative first-line medications,
• You want reassurance regarding MRI or other tests.

A second neurologist will want to see the original EEG and the radiology report from the CT.  Repeating the routine EEG immediately is hardly ever necessary.  The upcoming long-term video-EEG your doctors have scheduled is a nice way to verify the diagnosis and look for any unrecognized seizure types.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
9.  KEY QUESTIONS TO ASK AT YOUR NEXT VISIT
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Could you walk us through the EEG findings in plain language?  
2.  Would an MRI add anything in my child’s specific case?  
3.  What monitoring schedule (blood work, clinic visits) do you recommend?  
4.  If we see weight gain / hair loss / tremor, what is the plan—dose reduction, switch to another medicine?  
5.  At what point can he resume swimming lessons / sleep-overs / trampoline etc.?  
6.  What constitutes an emergency that should bring us to the ER?  
7.  Are there local epilepsy-family support groups you recommend?

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TAKE-HOME
• One generalized seizure plus a clearly epileptiform EEG ≈ high enough relapse risk to justify medication.  
• Valproate is still the “gold standard” in 9-year-old boys; most side-effects are mild and reversible, and serious toxicity is rare with routine monitoring.  
• Most children with idiopathic generalized epilepsy achieve full seizure control and lead typical lives.  
• If side-effects emerge, changing medicines is straightforward.  
• A second opinion is never wrong; bring the EEG on a USB or disc.  

I hope this helps you feel more in control of a very stressful situation.  Wishing your son a long seizure-free stretch and a rapid return to everything he enjoys.

197.question: 25f, chronic anxiety with 7.5mg buspar, ADHD 20mg adderall, acid reflux and Barrett’s mucosa with omeprazole, IBS with dicyclomine.History of epilepsy consisting of one gran mal at age 8, I don’t know what they’re called but it started as seizures in my legs at age 7, and a couple absence due to high fever. My last seizure was at age 11 and it I didn’t have anymore after starting my period at 12.Day before yesterday I was going into work at 6 and took my adderall then. I had an espresso drink and ate espresso beans going into my shift as well. I work at a dive bar and usually we’ll take shots after work/ during our shift. This was my third day there so it was my third day drinking that night.I got home from work around 1am and woke up at 5 and was wide awake. I felt like I was having an aura like that “deja vu” feeling about having a seizure. Around 7 I was still wide awake and turned over onto my stomach and for a good 20 seconds I couldn’t move, open my eyes, or speak. Sound was extremely amplified and my skin and muscles felt like they were vibrating but with no convulsions. I was wide awake and anxious until this happened so I don’t think it was sleep paralysis.After I came to, my body and mind felt very exhausted. I fell back asleep and when I woke up I was groggy the entire day and today I’m feeling down mentally. Today I’m still feeling crappy but I’m back at work at my hospital.Does this sound like a seizure?
197.answer:
I can’t give you a formal diagnosis on-line, but I can go over what typically happens in different kinds of events and how what you describe fits (or doesn’t fit) with each of them, then outline what to do next.

1.  What a focal (“partial”) seizure can look like  
   •  Often begins with an aura: déjà-vu, odd smells/tastes/sounds, a sense of dread, or a rising feeling in the stomach.  
   •  May last 15-90 seconds. People can appear awake but be unable to move or speak, stare, or make small automatisms (lip smacking, fiddling).  
   •  Afterward they’re frequently very tired, confused, or “off” for minutes to hours (post-ictal state).  
   •  Triggers: sleep deprivation, alcohol (especially withdrawal), stimulants, high caffeine, stress, flashing lights, illness, hormonal shifts, etc.  
   •  A past history of childhood epilepsy does leave you with a slightly lower seizure threshold than the general population even if you’ve been seizure-free for years.

2.  What typical sleep-paralysis looks like  
   •  Occurs in the transition into or out of REM sleep (just falling asleep or just waking).  
   •  You feel conscious but can’t move, open your eyes, or speak; lasts seconds to a couple of minutes.  
   •  Buzzing/vibrating sensations, a “pressure” feeling, or imagined sounds/voices are common.  
   •  Once the episode ends, orientation is normal; there isn’t usually prolonged grogginess except what comes from being short on sleep.  
   •  Big risk factors: sleep deprivation, irregular sleep schedule, alcohol, stimulants, shift work—exactly the situation you were in that night.

3.  Panic attack/dissociative spell  
   •  Can include a surge of unreality, déjà vu, body “vibrations,” and a sense of being frozen, but usually there’s rapid heartbeat, hyperventilation, sweating.  
   •  People typically recall the spell clearly and can move if they really try, though it may feel hard. Grogginess next day is less common unless there was no sleep.

How your episode lines up  
•  Aura‐like déjà vu ► could fit seizure or panic.  
•  Complete inability to move or open eyes while lying down ► classic for sleep paralysis, but can also be seen in focal seizures with awareness.  
•  Loud, amplified sounds / whole-body vibration ► described in both REM-related paralysis and some temporal-lobe seizures.  
•  Duration of ~20 s ► on the short side for typical sleep paralysis (usually 30 s–2 min), but within range for a focal seizure.  
•  Marked exhaustion and “off” mental state the entire next day ► more typical for a post-ictal period, but 4 h of sleep after alcohol and stimulants could do the same.

Bottom line: from a description alone it is impossible to be 100 % certain. The event has features of both sleep-paralysis and a possible focal seizure. Given your remote history of epilepsy and multiple seizure triggers that night (sleep loss, alcohol, high caffeine, amphetamine, stress), it’s worth treating it as “possible seizure” until proven otherwise.

What to do now  
1.  Arrange follow-up with a neurologist (or your primary‐care clinician who can refer you).  
    •  They may order an EEG and, if you haven’t had one as an adult, usually an MRI.  
    •  Bring a concise timeline of events, meds, caffeine/alcohol amounts, and any witnesses.  
2.  Until you’re cleared:  
    •  Try to avoid further sleep deprivation, large caffeine loads, or alcohol binges.  
    •  Don’t mix Adderall with alcohol, and keep total caffeine <200-300 mg/day.  
    •  No driving, climbing, swimming alone, or operating dangerous machinery for the next few weeks, or at least until you’ve been formally evaluated.  
3.  If you have another spell with loss of awareness, any convulsions, tongue biting, loss of bladder control, or an injury, go to the Emergency Department and let them know you may have had a seizure.  
4.  Consider discussing with your prescriber whether the current Adderall dose, timing, and alcohol use are appropriate given your anxiety, sleep, and possible seizure risk.  

When to seek urgent care immediately  
•  A second episode within 24 h, any convulsive seizure, new weakness, vision or speech changes, severe persistent headache, or confusion that lasts more than an hour.

Remember: one episode does not necessarily mean your childhood epilepsy is “back,” but getting a proper work-up is the safest route.

198.question: So I was in a car accident back in October as I had a seizure that resulted in me blacking out as I was driving. I have had seizures since I was 15 years old, but I have never been officially diagnosed until recently. My seizures, also what we believe (I have not seen a neurologist yet) is Temporal Lobe Epilepsy, consist of 2-3 minutes of dissociation, aura like feelings, deja vu, and taste/hearing/sight delusions. (https://www.epilepsy.com/learn/types-epilepsy-syndromes/temporal-lobe-epilepsy-aka-tle)... After the seizure is finished, I can go back to doing my normal day-to-day activities, but sometimes they throw my day off, all depends on other circumstances. I have been taking Topiramate (Topamax) 100 mg / 2x daily for about 3 months now and it has been doing wonders. I have not had a seizure since October which is something I thought I could never say. The only reason I have not seen a neurologist is because of lack of health insurance, but I am hoping to see one sometime next year once I can afford to do so. Anyways, back to my presenting problem. I was only going 25-30 mph down a semi-busy street and I crashed into a metal barrier at a store front. I do not remember blacking out. I remember waking up in the ambulance completely restrained and being extremely scared, screaming and yelling at the EMTs because I thought I was in a nightmare/horror scene! Then I must have been sedated a bit and the next thing I remember was being pulled through on a gurney into the ER. For a while I have been experiencing a lot of sharp pain in my left side / lower rib cage area. At first, I thought it was a potential growth/tumor, so I went to my local clinic and had a doctor feel me up to check for anything. She did not feel any lumps or growths, but she did press on my ribs and that gave me a lot of pain. We suspected that maybe when I was in the accident, something with my seat belt, wheel, or airbag could have hit my side so hard that it caused some contusions or internal bruising. My skin isn't red and there isn't any noticeable swelling on my skin. I just feel a constant pressure around my heart and my left lung which really concerns me as that part of my body is the most precious. I wonder if I bruised my lung, have pleurisy? She prescribed me some anti-inflammatory steroids for 5 days to reduce some swelling, so hopefully that helps. I have also been wearing a lot of menthol patches and using analgesic cream to relieve the pain. Just curious if anyone has any more insight into my problems as I don't have the resources to see a doctor right now or get an x-ray.
198.answer:
I am not your doctor and can’t examine you, order tests, or give you an official diagnosis, but I can explain what usually worries clinicians after a crash like yours and what is typically done about it.  Use this information to decide whether you need to be seen again (possibly in an ED), how urgently, and how to look after yourself until you can get formal care.

----------------------------------------------------
1.  Why the left-sided pain matters
----------------------------------------------------
Blunt force to the left lower chest (seat belt, airbag, steering wheel) can injure any of four main structures that sit under or inside the rib cage:

A.  Chest wall itself  
   • Bruised muscles/soft tissue (contusion)  
   • Non-displaced rib or costochondral fracture  
   • “Costochondritis” (sprained rib cartilage)

B.  Lung and pleura  
   • Lung bruise (pulmonary contusion)  
   • Pneumothorax / hemothorax (air or blood between lung & chest wall)  
   • Delayed pleurisy or pneumonia from shallow breathing

C.  Heart and pericardium (rare at low speeds but possible)

D.  Upper abdominal organs protected by the lower ribs  
   • Spleen (left-sided): bruising or delayed rupture  
   • Stomach/colon: less common  

Most of these cannot be confirmed by touch alone; an x-ray (sometimes a CT) is usually ordered in the ED the day of the crash.  Because you never got imaging, the question is whether you might still have (or could develop) a complication that needs treatment right now.

----------------------------------------------------
2.  “Red flag” symptoms that mean “go to an ED today”
----------------------------------------------------
• Shortness of breath, rapid breathing, or need to sit upright to breathe  
• Pain suddenly worse, especially with a “pop” or after a coughing fit  
• Light-headedness, fainting, racing pulse >120 while at rest  
• Coughing up blood, frothy pink sputum, or new wheeze  
• Pain or fullness creeping into the left upper abdomen or tip of the left shoulder (Kehr sign for splenic bleed)  
• Fever >100.4 °F / 38 °C or chills after day 2–3 (possible pneumonia)  
• Any new neurological change (confusion, weakness) that could be related to your head injury/seizure

If any of these occur, you really do need imaging and monitoring right away, even if insurance is a problem—most U.S. emergency departments have financial-aid/charity policies you can apply for afterwards.

----------------------------------------------------
3.  If none of the red flags are present – likely scenarios
----------------------------------------------------
1. Simple chest-wall contusion or non-displaced rib fracture  
   • Sharp pain on one or two spots when pressed, deep breath hurts  
   • X-ray may miss up to 50 % of small rib fractures; CT shows them but isn’t always needed  
   • Heals in 4–6 weeks (sometimes 8) if protected

2. Costochondral (rib-cartilage) sprain  
   • Pain right beside the sternum or where rib meets cartilage  
   • Similar healing time

3. Lung bruise without collapse  
   • Usually peaks in pain in the first 24–48 h, then slowly improves  
   • You would feel short-winded if a large area were involved

4. Pleurisy after the injury  
   • Shallow breathing for a few days → small atelectasis → irritation of pleura  
   • Typically shows up day 3–5; pain is stabbing and worse when you breathe in

----------------------------------------------------
4.  Home management for an uncomplicated chest-wall injury
----------------------------------------------------
(Assuming no contraindications to any of these—stop if anything makes symptoms worse and seek care.)

Pain control  
• Non-prescription NSAIDs (ibuprofen 400–600 mg every 6 h, naproxen 440 mg then 220 mg q12 h, with food) usually work well.  
• If you have kidney disease, ulcers, or are on blood thinners, ask a professional first.  
• The short steroid course your clinic prescribed can reduce inflammation for a few days; finish it as directed.

Cold then heat  
• Ice packs 20 min at a time, a few times a day for the first 48 h.  
• After 48 h, switch to warm compress or a heating pad to relax muscles.

Support but don’t “wrap” tight  
• Do NOT use an elastic ace wrap around the chest—modern practice avoids this because it restricts breathing and raises pneumonia risk.  
• A thin pillow pressed firmly over the sore area while you cough or laugh (“splinting”) makes it hurt less.

Breathing exercises  
• At least once every hour while awake: take 10 slow, deep breaths, holding each for 2–3 s, then cough gently.  This expands the lung bases and prevents atelectasis/pneumonia.  
• If you can borrow an incentive spirometer from a friend/family member who had surgery, use it.

Activity  
• Light walking is encouraged; avoid heavy lifting, twisting, or contact sports for 4–6 weeks.  
• Sleep propped up with pillows if lying flat makes it ache.

Return to work / daily tasks  
• Most people can do desk work when pain is controlled.  Anything that jolts the torso (driving long distances, lawn mowing, weight-lifting) usually has to wait a couple of weeks.

----------------------------------------------------
5.  Follow-up and low-cost options for imaging
----------------------------------------------------
If pain is not clearly improving by about day 7–10, or if it improves then worsens, get an x-ray.  Options when uninsured:  
• County hospital or community teaching hospital (“charity care,” sliding scale)  
• Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) – some have in-house radiology contracts  
• Ask your clinic for a “cash price” chest x-ray script—independent imaging centers sometimes charge US$40–$80 upfront  
• State Medicaid or ACA Marketplace special enrollment if the crash cost you your job/income  
• Epilepsy Foundation, local United Way, and hospital social workers can help with financial-aid forms

----------------------------------------------------
6.  Seizures & driving: a gentle but important reminder
----------------------------------------------------
You already know this, but for safety and legal reasons it has to be said:

• In almost every U.S. state, a driver must be seizure-free for a set period (often 6–12 months) and obtain medical clearance before driving again.  
• DMV reporting rules vary, but crashes related to seizures are sometimes automatically flagged by the hospital or police.  
• Until you have seen a neurologist and met your state’s “seizure-free interval,” using taxis, rideshare, or public transit protects you and other people on the road.

Topiramate working for three months is encouraging, yet most neurologists will still order at least one EEG and usually an MRI brain to confirm temporal-lobe epilepsy, look for surgically-correctable lesions, and adjust medication dose.  Many large teaching-hospital neurology clinics offer sliding-scale/self-pay packages; referral from your community clinic can speed this up.

----------------------------------------------------
7.  When to insist on emergency care despite cost
----------------------------------------------------
Seek an emergency department immediately if you experience:

• Any of the red-flag symptoms in Section 2  
• A new seizure, prolonged aura, or cluster of auras  
• Vomiting that prevents you from keeping medicines down  
• Sudden severe headache (possible head-injury bleed)  
• Vision changes, weakness, or trouble speaking (stroke-like events)

Hospitals must stabilize you under EMTALA laws; you can apply for financial aid afterwards.

----------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
----------------------------------------------------
Given that you still have sharp focal pain when the rib is pressed, a simple rib contusion or small fracture is the most likely cause, but without at least a chest x-ray no one can fully rule out a small pneumothorax, lung bruise, or splenic injury.  Watch closely for any worsening or red-flag symptoms; if they appear, go to an emergency department.  Otherwise, the combination of anti-inflammatory medication, cold/heat, breathing exercises, and time (4–6 weeks) usually leads to full recovery.

Meanwhile, stay strict with your topiramate, avoid driving until you meet your state’s seizure-free requirement, and line up a neurology appointment through a sliding-scale clinic or hospital financial-aid office as soon as you can.

I hope this helps you judge what to do next and gives you some concrete self-care steps.  Feel better soon and don’t hesitate to seek care if anything on the “red-flag” list shows up.

199.question: Age: 16 Height: 5’3 Weight: 190 Gender: Female at birth but identify as male Medications: Onfi, Lamictal XR, Buspirone, Celexa, Quillivant, 5-HTP, Melatonin, Omega Fatty Acid, and birth control pills Smoking Status: never have and never will Existing Conditions: ADHD, Frontal Lobe Tonic Clonic Nocturnal Epilepsy, Aspergers, Generalized Anxiety Disorder,I asked my doctor if I was a candidate for brain surgery to get whatever part of my brain that’s causing seizures snipped out. He offered for us to do three tests. A pet scan, a cat scan, and an mri. Should I do it? I’ll have to have a seizure but I’m terrified of sudep. They said if there’s any signs they’ll probably be able to stop it. Still I’m terrified I’ll go through all this and it’ll be no use. I have frontal lobe nocturnal tonic clinic epilepsy. What do you all think? Is this a good idea? Should I go for it? Or should I stick with just adding medication? I’m 16 years old and I just want this gone. I’m so sick and tired of the fear.
199.answer:
First, a couple of key points so you know exactly what is being discussed:

1.  A PET scan, high-resolution epilepsy-protocol MRI, CT scan (usually for surgical planning), and (most important) video-EEG monitoring are the standard, non-invasive studies that every comprehensive epilepsy center uses to find out
    • Where a seizure starts  
    • Whether that spot can be removed (or treated with a device) without causing new disability  

2.  Agreeing to these studies is NOT the same as agreeing to brain surgery.  
    They simply give you and your doctors the information you need so that you—as a 16-year-old with decision-making capacity—can make an informed choice later.

3.  All of the tests are done in a hospital, on a specialized epilepsy monitoring unit (EMU). Staff are watching you on camera and EEG 24/7; emergency medication and oxygen are literally at the bedside.  
    SUDEP while on an EMU is extraordinarily rare; to date there are only isolated case reports worldwide, and most large centers have never had one.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Why even consider surgery at 16?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Definition of “drug-resistant” epilepsy: lack of seizure control after TWO well-chosen, tolerated antiseizure medicines at appropriate doses. You are already on lamotrigine (Lamictal XR) and clobazam (Onfi). That technically meets the definition. More medicines can be tried (levetiracetam, lacosamide, topiramate, etc.), but with each additional trial the chance of achieving seizure freedom with medication alone drops.

• Nocturnal tonic-clonic seizures carry a higher SUDEP risk than daytime focal seizures—even when they only occur during sleep.

• Frontal-lobe surgery is not as predictably successful as temporal-lobe surgery, but modern series still show:
  • 40–60 % long-term seizure-freedom  
  • Another 20–30 % with major reduction in seizure number or intensity  
  • The alternative (medication only) rarely gets to complete seizure freedom once two medications have failed.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
What happens during an evaluation?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Outpatient imaging
   – Epilepsy-protocol MRI (looks for cortical dysplasia, scarring, malformations)  
   – PET (looks for hypometabolism—brain areas that “burn” less sugar between seizures)  
   – CT (mostly helps the surgeon match the MRI to bone landmarks)

2. Admission to the Epilepsy Monitoring Unit
   – Scalp EEG electrodes + video for 3–7 days  
   – You stay on your usual medicines at first, then they may lower or hold doses to let a seizure occur sooner.  
   – The instant your EEG shows a generalized tonic-clonic pattern, staff are in the room. Oxygen, suction, IV access, rescue meds are ready.

3. If the non-invasive studies clearly show a single, removable focus, you may go straight to surgery OR to device therapy (RNS, DBS, or laser ablation).  

4. If the studies are suggestive but not clear, the next step is usually stereo-EEG (sEEG)—thin depth electrodes inserted through tiny skull openings—to pin down the exact starting point. Even this step is diagnostic, not yet therapeutic.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Benefits vs. risks you should weigh
--------------------------------------------------------------------
BENEFITS  
• Possible seizure freedom or major reduction  
• Lower lifetime SUDEP risk if seizures stop  
• Ability to drive when seizure-free long enough (rules vary by state)  
• Fewer meds = fewer side-effects (weight, mood, concentration)

RISKS (from the surgery itself, not the work-up)  
• 1–5 % risk of bleeding, infection, need for transfusion  
• Small but real risk of weakness, speech, or memory problems, depending on where the seizure focus lies  
• 5–10 % risk seizures eventually come back years later (though often fewer/shorter)

RISKS OF DOING NOTHING (continuing meds only)  
• Roughly 1:150 – 1:300 lifetime risk of SUDEP for uncontrolled tonic-clonics, especially nocturnal  
• Injury from nighttime falls, bites, or apnea not witnessed like they would be in the EMU  
• Cognitive slowing and mood effects from chronic seizures and polypharmacy  
• Restrictions on driving, certain jobs, independence

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Your specific concerns
--------------------------------------------------------------------
“I’m terrified I’ll have to seize during testing and could die.”  
  • Staff watch every EEG channel in real time. Oxygen desaturation or prolonged post-ictal suppression → immediate intervention.  
  • Cardiac telemetry is on; if your heart rhythm changes, they know instantly.  
  • Most centers have hundreds to thousands of seizure events per year with zero in-unit SUDEP.

“I’m afraid I’ll go through all this and it’ll be no use.”  
  • Worst-case: the team decides surgery is not possible.  
    You still gain valuable information (exact seizure map, medication response, prognosis) and can explore VNS, RNS, ketogenic diet, newer medications, clinical trials.  
  • Best-case: there is a clear, safe target and you achieve seizure freedom.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Other options if you decide against resection
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Vagus Nerve Stimulator (VNS): outpatient surgery, 50–60 % achieve ≥50 % reduction, rare complete control.  
• Responsive Neurostimulation (RNS): implant plus leads on seizure focus; records and shocks only when needed. Approved for 18+, but some centers use it at 16–17 with IRB approval.  
• Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS, centromedian or anterior nucleus): 18+.  
• Ketogenic or Modified Atkins Diet: sometimes useful in adolescents.  
• Additional/alternative meds: levetiracetam, brivaracetam, perampanel, cenobamate, etc.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Saying “yes” to the PET, MRI, CT, and video-EEG monitoring only commits you to gathering data, not to having part of your brain removed. 

Because:
• you already meet the textbook definition of drug-resistant epilepsy,
• your seizures are generalized tonic-clonic (highest SUDEP-risk type),
• they happen at night when you are unattended,
an evaluation at a Level-3 or Level-4 epilepsy center is strongly recommended by every professional guideline. 

Almost every patient who ultimately becomes seizure-free after surgery started where you are now—scared, unsure, and worried about whether the work-up was “worth it.” The testing itself is extremely safe, and the information you gain will empower you (and your family) to make an informed choice when all the facts are on the table.

If you still feel uneasy, ask for:
• A visit (virtual or in-person) with the epilepsy nurse or EMU staff to walk you through the monitoring unit.  
• Contact information for another teen who already went through the process (many centers have peer-to-peer programs).  
• A second opinion at a different comprehensive center; surgeons are never offended by this.

Whatever you decide, you deserve freedom from constant fear. Starting the evaluation is the surest way to find out whether surgery (or a device) can give you that freedom.

200.question: Age - 31 Sex – Female   Height - 5'6"    Weight - 120lbs Race – Caucasian Duration of complaint - A few days Location (Geographic and on body) - United States. Full body Any existing relevant medical issues (if any) – Epilepsy Current medications (if any) - Keppra, Prozac I recently went to the hospital due to a generalized dystonia attack. This is the first time this has happened to me. I also have temporal lobe epilepsy. I have been doing a lot of research and have recently started looking into deep brain stimulation for treatment of both. The Keppra I'm taking doesn't seem to be doing much. I have an appointment with my doctor coming up soon, and was hoping to get some information so I could have some good questions to ask regarding treatment, including DBS. Any other recommendations would be great as well. Thank you in advance for your help.
200.answer:
Below is a framework you can take to your next neurology appointment.  It is long, but most people find it helpful to have a written “check-list” they can refer to while they’re in the office.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  FIRST:  Be sure the episode was truly “generalized dystonia”
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  What happened?  Bring a phone video if you have one.  
•  How long did it last?  Was there loss of awareness, eye-deviation, automatisms or a post-ictal period?  
•  Did EEG or exam during the attack confirm dystonia rather than an epileptic seizure with dystonic posturing (“ictal dystonia”) or a psychogenic event?

Ask:
  – “Do we need in-hospital video-EEG monitoring to decide if this is a manifestation of my temporal-lobe epilepsy or a separate movement disorder?”  
  – “Should I have a repeat MRI or other imaging to look for a structural lesion that could cause both epilepsy and dystonia?”  

Why it matters:  
•  If the event is part of your seizures, changing the anti-seizure drug regimen is the first step.  
•  If it is a primary/generalized dystonia, treatment follows a different ladder (medications → botulinum toxin or intrathecal baclofen → DBS).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  BASIC LAB / GENETIC / METABOLIC WORK-UP
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Many centers order the following once “true” dystonia is suspected (especially at your age of onset):

•  Serum copper & ceruloplasmin (rule out Wilson’s)  
•  Thyroid panel, CBC, CMP, ferritin  
•  MRI brain & sometimes spine  
•  Genetic panel: TOR1A (DYT-T1), THAP1, GNAL, GCH1 (dopa-responsive), ATP1A3 etc.  
•  If family history suggests: mitochondrial panel, GLUT-1, ADCY5, PRRT2, etc.

Ask:  
  – “Which tests do you think I still need, and why?”  
  – “Would levodopa challenge make sense to look for dopa-responsive dystonia?”

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  MEDICATION LADDER FOR GENERALIZED DYSTONIA
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A) Oral agents tried FIRST (often in combination)
   •  Anticholinergics (trihexyphenidyl, benztropine)  
   •  Baclofen (oral; later intrathecal pump if severe spastic component)  
   •  GABAergic: clonazepam, diazepam  
   •  Dopamine-depleters: tetrabenazine, deutetrabenazine  
   •  Levodopa (especially if dopa-responsive dystonia suspected)

B) Botulinum toxin (works best for focal segments—neck, limbs, jaw, eyelids).

C) Intrathecal baclofen pump (when spasticity and pain dominate).

Ask:  
  – “Which of these have I tried at adequate dose/duration?”  
  – “What side-effects should I expect and how do we monitor for them?”  
  – “Could my current meds (Keppra, Prozac) be contributing?”  
       •  Keppra rarely causes dyskinesias/dystonia; Prozac can lower seizure threshold and (infrequently) cause akathisia/dystonia.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  DEEP BRAIN STIMULATION (DBS)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Evidence:
  •  Generalized or segmental primary dystonia (especially DYT-T1) – excellent (>60-70 % reduction in Burke-Fahn-Marsden scores).  
  •  Secondary dystonias (stroke, CP, Wilson’s, tardive) – benefit is more modest but still worthwhile in selected cases.  
  •  Temporal-lobe epilepsy – DBS is FDA-approved only for the anterior nucleus of the thalamus (ANT).  Other targets (centromedian, hippocampal, responsive neuro-stimulation) are investigational.

Target for dystonia = bilateral posteroventral Globus Pallidus Internus (GPi).  
Target for epilepsy = bilateral ANT, hippocampus, CM nucleus, or RNS device over seizure focus.

KEY QUESTIONS FOR YOUR DOCTOR / DBS TEAM:
 1.  “Am I a candidate for GPi-DBS for dystonia, for ANT-DBS/RNS for epilepsy, or potentially a combined approach?”  
 2.  “Would we implant one set of electrodes that might help both conditions, or two separate targets?”  
 3.  “How do you predict benefit given my specific diagnosis (primary vs secondary dystonia, type of epilepsy)?”  
 4.  “What pre-operative evaluations do you require?  (Neuro-psych testing, updated MRI, medication wash-outs, genetic results, insurance approval).”  
 5.  “What risks should I weigh? (infection 3-5 %, hemorrhage <2 %, device malfunction, battery replacements, speech or mood changes).”  
 6.  “How long after surgery before settings are optimized?  How many programming sessions?  Who programs if I move?”  
 7.  “What happens to my current medications after DBS?”

Realistic expectations:
  •  Dystonia improvement begins weeks to months after activation (unlike tremor which improves immediately).  
  •  Epilepsy control with ANT-DBS averages ~40–60 % seizure reduction by year 2; rarely a “cure.”

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  EPILEPSY OPTIMIZATION WHILE DBS IS BEING CONSIDERED
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because Keppra has not fully helped:

Ask:
  – “Should we titrate the dose (max 3000 mg/day) before adding/ switching?”  
  – “Which second agent fits my seizure type and mood profile?”  
        •  Lamotrigine, lacosamide, brivaracetam, topiramate, zonisamide, oxcarbazepine, valproate (if not contraindicated).  
  – “Would Prozac dose adjustment or switch to sertraline/escitalopram be safer for seizure threshold?”  
  – “Do I need rescue medication at home (clonazepam wafer, midazolam nasal spray) for prolonged episodes?”

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  NON-PHARMACOLOGIC / REHAB
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Regular physical & occupational therapy familiar with dystonia (stretching, bracing, sensory-trick training).  
•  Yoga / Pilates / Alexander technique – useful for postural control.  
•  Stress-reduction: mindfulness, CBT; emotional stress can exacerbate both seizures and dystonia.  
•  Adequate sleep: 7–8 h (sleep deprivation is a seizure trigger).  
•  Wear a medical alert bracelet noting “Epilepsy / Dystonia – on Keppra, Prozac.”  
•  Driving law: most US states require 3–12 mo seizure-free; ask your neurologist for local regulation.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  SUMMARY – “CHEAT-SHEET” OF QUESTIONS TO BRING
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Diagnosis
  •  Are my attacks dystonia, seizures, or both?
  •  Do I need video-EEG monitoring or additional imaging?

Work-up
  •  Which blood, metabolic, or genetic tests are pending?
  •  Should we do a levodopa trial?

Medications
  •  What first-line dystonia meds should we trial next?
  •  How can we better control my seizures—dose change, add-on, or switch?
  •  Could Prozac or Keppra be part of the problem?

DBS
  •  Am I a DBS candidate?  Which target?  Single vs dual therapy?
  •  Expected benefit for me?  Risks?  Timeline?  Costs/insurance?

Other Therapies
  •  Role of botulinum toxin, intrathecal baclofen, or neuro-pacing devices (RNS, VNS)?
  •  Physical therapy referrals, mental health support, rescue plans.

Lifestyle / Safety
  •  Driving, work accommodations, seizure & dystonia action plans.

Bring a written record of:
  •  Seizure / dystonia diary (date, duration, triggers, meds taken).
  •  Current daily doses (including vitamins/herbals).
  •  Family history of neurologic disease.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
BOTTOM LINE
You have two potentially overlapping neurologic conditions.  The immediate next step is to confirm what happened during your “dystonia attack” and to optimize standard medications.  If the dystonia proves to be primary and drug-refractory, GPi-DBS is the most effective advanced therapy.  For drug-resistant temporal-lobe epilepsy, ANT-DBS, RNS, or other surgical options may also be appropriate.  A specialized comprehensive epilepsy/movement-disorder center can evaluate you for single-or dual-target DBS and guide you through insurance approval, surgery, and postoperative programming.

Write your questions down, take this sheet with you, and don’t hesitate to ask for clarifications—shared decision-making is key to good outcomes.

Best of luck at your upcoming appointment, and remember: the more precise the information you bring, the more precise the plan your neurologist can create for you.

201.question: Girlfriend 20 y.o approx 55kg. Located Sydney, Australia. Jan 2017 my girlfriend had 39.7deg C fevers lasting approx 1 week. She was found in bed unresponsive, with side to side head movements. (One of my questions is what was this? Status epilepticus?) She was taken to ER and then into ICU with uncontrolled seizures, and not recovering inbetween episodes, & put into an induced coma. She was put on phenytoin initially, and I believe levetriacetam and sodium valproate followed shortly thereafter. My guess is also Midaz during the episodes. Her longest seizure (tonic-clonic) lasted 8 and a half minutes. Many tests later, abnormal EEG looking like the seizures were coming from left temporal lobe (her eyes/head get pushed to the right). Unremarkable MRI, all x-rays good. 2x spinal tap as the thoughts were auto-immune encephalitis (results: no evidence to support this aside from ancedotal). Little to no memories from 6 months ago with patchy memory for the last 2 years Discharged from ICU and we were back the next day as she was having more seizures. Was receiving prednisone and had 5 days IVIG for brain immflamation. A day later we were back in the ward, we would eventually be discharged about 3.5 weeks after initial admission. No seizures following the 1.5 months after discharge, but then they came back frequently. Her current seizures are not tonic clonic. She is concious throughout, still body though head, mouth and eyes behave just like a tonic clonic for someone with TLE. Lasting 30 secs to a min most of the time. Frequency is ~2x per week, nocturnal. I do have videos of the seizures. AEDs are: Phenytoin 300mg Levetriacetam (Keppra brand) 2500mg Sodium Valporate 2400mg Looking at introducing Vimpat shortly. My main questions: Was her head to head movement seizure activity? I know she was in status epilepticus/ prolonged seizure activity in ICU/ER. What are your thoughts on what she had? What are your thoughts on the current medication?
201.answer:
I can only give general educational information; the doctors who have examined and investigated your girlfriend are the ones who can make a formal diagnosis and decide on treatment.  
With that in mind, here is a structured way to look at what has happened and the questions you raise.

1. What probably happened the night she was found unresponsive with side-to-side head movements?  
• In neurology that repetitive, forced turning of the head and eyes to one side is called a “versive” movement.  
• When it occurs with loss of awareness and no meaningful response it is nearly always a focal (partial) seizure arising from the frontal or temporal lobe on the side opposite the direction of the turn.  
• Because the events continued or recurred without full recovery she met the definition of convulsive status epilepticus (a seizure or series of seizures lasting ≥5 min without regaining baseline).  
So yes – the episode you describe was almost certainly seizure activity and she fulfilled criteria for status epilepticus when she arrived in the Emergency Department.

2. Why the ICU, coma and multiple drugs?  
Standard Australian/New-Zealand guidelines for convulsive status are:  
• benzodiazepine (e.g. midazolam) → if persistent, add an IV anti-seizure medicine (phenytoin, levetiracetam or valproate) → if still persistent, anaesthetise and intubate (propofol or midazolam infusion) and admit to ICU.  
That is exactly what seems to have happened. An 8½-minute tonic-clonic seizure that did not stop promptly would automatically trigger this escalation.

3. Why the extensive work-up?  
In a previously healthy young adult the main things doctors must exclude are:  
• Structural lesion (stroke, tumour, malformation) → MRI  
• Infection → lumbar puncture, cultures, viral PCR  
• Auto-immune or paraneoplastic encephalitis → 2nd lumbar puncture, serum and CSF antibody panels, CT chest/abdomen/pelvis, pelvic US in females  
• Metabolic / toxic causes → full bloods, toxicology screen  
Her MRI was “unremarkable”; CSF apparently had no organisms or autoimmune antibodies; bloods were OK. That leaves an idiopathic (unknown-cause) focal epilepsy as most likely, but autoimmune encephalitis is still considered if tests are negative yet clinical suspicion remains. (That is why she received steroids and IVIg despite negative antibodies: about 10–20 % of proven autoimmune encephalitis is seronegative.)

4. Where are the seizures coming from now?  
• EEG suggested a left temporal focus (forced head/eye deviation to the right fits this).  
• She remains aware, so these are termed “focal aware motor seizures” (older term: simple partial).  
• Occurring mainly in sleep is typical for focal epilepsy.

5. Memory problems  
A prolonged ICU stay, repeated seizures and drugs such as benzodiazepines or propofol can all leave patchy retrograde amnesia. In addition, the temporal lobes (especially the left in a right-handed person) are central to memory formation: repeated temporal seizures can themselves impair recent memory.

6. How good is the current medication combination?  
Current doses (for a 55 kg adult):

• Phenytoin 300 mg/d ≈ 5.5 mg/kg – a reasonable maintenance dose if serum level is 40–80 µmol/L (10–20 µg/mL).  
• Levetiracetam 2 500 mg/d – close to the top of the usual 1 000–3 000 mg/d range; blood levels seldom needed.  
• Valproate 2 400 mg/d (≈44 mg/kg) – therapeutic if trough level is 350–700 µmol/L (50–100 µg/mL).

So she is already on near-maximal doses of three major drugs and still having about two seizures a week. By definition that is “drug-resistant epilepsy” (failure of two appropriate drugs at tolerated doses).

Issues with the specific agents:

Phenytoin  
• Advantages: cheap, IV form for emergencies.  
• Problems: long-term cosmetic (gum, skin), osteopenia, drug interactions (incl. with valproate and contraceptives), zero-order kinetics (levels can swing). Many epilepsy centres try to wean it in young women once the acute phase is over.

Valproate  
• Very effective for many epilepsies but highly teratogenic (10 % malformation risk; 30–40 % cognitive effects). Current practice is to avoid or minimise valproate in women of child-bearing age unless no reasonable alternative works, and always combine with reliable contraception plus 5 mg folate/day.

Levetiracetam  
• Generally well tolerated but can cause irritability, anxiety or depression; blood tests not needed.

Proposed addition: Lacosamide (Vimpat)  
• Mechanistically different (enhances slow inactivation of sodium channels), often plays well with levetiracetam or valproate.  
• Starting dose 50 mg bid → titrate to 100–200 mg bid.  
• Common side-effects: dizziness, diplopia; few interactions.

Rational polytherapy tries to use drugs with different mechanisms and non-overlapping side-effects, so lacosamide is reasonable. What is equally important, though, is deciding whether one of the existing drugs can be withdrawn (often phenytoin first) once lacosamide is established to keep the pill burden reasonable.

7. What else should be on the table now that seizures persist?

Comprehensive Epilepsy Centre referral (Westmead, RPA, Prince of Wales, Austin etc.). Work-up usually includes:  
• Prolonged video-EEG monitoring to be absolutely certain where seizures start and whether there may be more than one focus.  
• High-resolution 3 T MRI with epilepsy protocol, PET, ictal SPECT, or MEG looking for subtle cortical dysplasia not visible on standard MRI.  
• Neuropsychological testing and formal memory assessment.  
If a single, removable focus is confirmed, surgery (temporal lobectomy, lesionectomy or laser ablation) can offer 60–80 % long-term seizure freedom, which is far better than adding endless medications.

If no clear surgical target emerges:  
• Vagus-nerve stimulation (PBS-funded in Australia for refractory focal epilepsy) can cut seizure frequency by 50 % in ~½ of patients.  
• Responsive neurostimulation and deep-brain stimulation are emerging but not yet widely available here.

Lifestyle / safety / rescue:  
• No driving until 6 months seizure-free (NSW Roads & Maritime guidelines).  
• No unsupervised swimming, heights, or hot baths.  
• Keep an emergency buccal or intranasal midazolam/diazepam at home for any motor seizure >2 min.  
• Regular sleep, avoidance of excessive alcohol, review of all meds for enzyme-inducing interactions (e.g. phenytoin lowers contraceptive and steroid levels).

8. Follow-up for possible autoimmune encephalitis  
If her treating team still suspects an immune basis, longer-term immunosuppression (rituximab, mycophenolate etc.) may be discussed, but only an autoimmune-neurology or epilepsy-immunology specialist can weigh that risk/benefit.

Key take-aways for you to discuss with her neurologist/epileptologist  
• She almost certainly had convulsive status epilepticus with versive head movements at onset.  
• Current pattern is drug-resistant focal epilepsy, probably left temporal.  
• Adding lacosamide is reasonable, but concomitant phenytoin and/or valproate might eventually be reduced.  
• Given ongoing seizures, referral to a comprehensive epilepsy programme for surgical evaluation and/or advanced treatments is strongly recommended.  
• Because she is a young woman, the long-term use of valproate (and to a lesser extent phenytoin) needs a frank discussion about contraception, pregnancy plans, and alternative drugs.

Websites you may find useful  
• Epilepsy Action Australia: epilepsy.org.au  
• Australian & NZ Association of Neurologists Status Epilepticus guideline: anzaed.org.au  
• International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) resources for patients.

Bring the videos you have and a seizure diary (date, time, duration, trigger, recovery) to her next appointment—they are extremely helpful. I hope this gives you a clearer framework to talk with her treating team and to understand why each step of the investigation and treatment has been taken so far.

202.question: Hi there! I recently found out that what I thought was just passing out 2 times were actually seizures. These happened a couple years apart, once in high school and once in college. They were both triggered by kinda similar events but both were from physical sensations. I experienced the aura, ictal and post-ictal phases of a seizure based on the research I have done over the past couple days. All of the feelings that I experienced afterwards line up with the symptoms post-seizure (including even some very strong spiritual connections (which can be associated with epilepsy).The first time I seized was when I got hit with a baseball in high school and was fine until I went to go sit back on the bench and then all the sudden I was like huh, something isn't right. Then next thing I know I wake up to 3 different adults standing over me holding my harms and keeping them from shaking. Luckily when I fell off the bench I fell onto catchers gear on instead of concrete. Then the next time was in college while a friend tried to pierce my ears. I again felt that same aura and began seizing. This time my partner was there and caught me from falling off my chair.I only realized recently that these were seizures after talking to my partner's mom who is a healthcare provider. As I was talking about epilepsy in one of my classes, I was suddenly inspired to look it up and find out more. Is it possible that I have a mild case of it? Should I go get tested? What are the implications for if I do? From the research I have done, it takes at least 2 seizures to get diagnosed so technically I have experienced that but years apart. Should I be worried about this or am I making a big deal out of nothing? I just don't know what to do.
202.answer:
First, try not to panic.  Two brief loss-of-consciousness episodes that occurred years apart do not automatically mean you “have epilepsy,” but they do justify a formal medical work-up.   Here’s why, what the evaluation usually involves, and what the practical consequences may be.

1.  Were they truly seizures?
   •  Vasovagal (fainting) episodes can be triggered by pain, needle sticks, emotional stress, being hit by a ball, etc.  Up to 10–15 % of simple faints are accompanied by a few seconds of stiffening or jerking, tongue biting and even urinary leakage.  These “convulsive syncope” events look very much like epileptic seizures but are caused by a brief drop in blood pressure, not abnormal brain‐wave activity.  
   •  Concussion-related loss of consciousness can also cause confusion, amnesia and a short period of shaking.  
   •  Epileptic seizures, on the other hand, are “unprovoked,” meaning they are not a direct, immediate reaction to pain, head trauma, strong emotion, drugs, fever, etc.

   From what you describe:
      – Episode 1 happened seconds to minutes after a painful blow to the body.
      – Episode 2 happened during an ear-piercing attempt—a painful, anxiety-provoking situation.
   Both are classic vasovagal triggers, so convulsive syncope is at least as plausible as epilepsy.

2.  Why you should still be evaluated
   •  You have now had two transient loss-of-consciousness events with motor activity.
   •  You can’t make the distinction between fainting and epilepsy without an exam and sometimes tests (EEG, possibly brain imaging, maybe a heart rhythm study).
   •  Even if they turn out to be faints, an underlying heart-rhythm problem or blood-pressure disorder occasionally masquerades as “simple” syncope and can be serious.

3.  What usually happens at the doctor’s office
   a)  History and physical:  
        – Detailed account of the events (onset, triggers, how long you were out, how you felt afterwards, tongue biting? incontinence? color change?)  
        – Past medical history, medications, alcohol/drug use, family history of seizures or sudden cardiac death.  
   b)  Basic labs, ECG (heart tracing), orthostatic blood pressures.  
   c)  Neurologic evaluation: often an outpatient EEG and sometimes a brain MRI.  
   d)  If doubt remains, a cardiologist or an “EP” (electrophysiologist) may order longer-term heart monitoring or a tilt-table test to reproduce vasovagal symptoms.

4.  Diagnostic labels
   •  Epilepsy = at least two unprovoked seizures OR one unprovoked seizure with convincing MRI/EEG evidence of a tendency to have more.  
   •  A “provoked” seizure (immediately after a head injury, alcohol withdrawal, severe hypoglycemia, etc.) does NOT equal epilepsy.  
   •  Convulsive syncope is not epilepsy.  

   So, even though you meet the “two events” count, both might be classified as provoked or syncopal, which would not fulfill the definition of epilepsy.

5.  Possible outcomes and implications
   a)  Tests normal, felt to be vasovagal syncope → No antiepileptic drugs; main advice is trigger avoidance (hydration, don’t stand locked-kneed, lie down if warning signs start).  Usually no driving restrictions unless episodes are frequent or unexplained.  
   b)  Definite epilepsy diagnosed → Typically a daily medication is started; you would have a temporary driving restriction (varies by region) until seizure-free for a set period; certain occupations (commercial pilot, heights, scuba, military) might be restricted.  Many people with well-controlled epilepsy live entirely normal lives.  
   c)  Cardiac cause found → Treatment aimed at that (rhythm medications, pacemaker, etc.).  

6.  What to do right now
   •  Make an appointment with your primary care provider or go straight to a neurologist if that’s feasible.  
   •  Gather eyewitness descriptions (partner, coach, friends) and write down everything you remember about prodrome/aura, duration, recovery time.  
   •  Note any medications, supplements, caffeine/energy drinks, alcohol, or sleep deprivation around each event.  
   •  If you drive, consider minimizing solo driving until you’ve been evaluated.  
   •  Teach friends/family basic first-aid for a seizure/faint (protect head, roll on side if possible, don’t force objects into mouth, call 911 if >5 min or injury).

7.  When to seek immediate care
   •  Another unexplained loss of consciousness  
   •  Seizure or faint lasting >5 minutes  
   •  Severe injury, persistent confusion, one-sided weakness, chest pain, rapid palpitations  

Bottom line  
You are not “making a big deal out of nothing,” but the most common, benign explanation (vasovagal syncope with convulsive movements) is in your favor.  A structured evaluation will sort this out and, if it does turn out to be epilepsy, starting appropriate treatment now greatly lowers long-term risks.  Call your doctor, schedule the work-up, and in the meantime stay well-hydrated and avoid known triggers such as pain and prolonged standing.

Resources  
   •  Epilepsy Foundation (epilepsy.com) – Patient guides and first-aid videos  
   •  Syncope Trust And Reflex anoxic Seizures (STARS) – Information on fainting and convulsive syncope  
   •  American Academy of Neurology “Seizure and epilepsy” patient information sheets

203.question: Hello! I saw on the internet that occasionally some epilepsy medications such as Lamictal can react to HRT. This reaction can cause an increase in seizure activity. That of course is not my specific question. My question is does Depakote 1000mg therapeutic level, and Keppra 1000mg once at night reactive towards HRT treatments. As I am considering going through the process of transferring my gender from male to female via HRT treatments and I am rather worried that this may cause an increase in my seizures. My seizure disorder is: Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy Drugs I currently take: 1 1000mg Depakote pill in the AM, 1 1000mg Depakote pill in the PM, 1 500mg Keppra pill at night. 1 Calcium/Zinc/Magnesium supplement pill in the AM, 1 Vitamin D pill in the AM. 1 3mg meletonin pill prior to bed. 10mg of Adderal when needed. Epileptic triggers: Sleep, anxiety. These medications may change a bit, but the general amount will stay the same. If anyone could give me insight on this topic please tell me. As I am a shy person and bringing this up with my neurologist would only complicate my appointments with him. So I’d rather learn more prior to bringing it up. You can be specific in medications, dosages and terminology as I do know a lot about epilepsy and studying neurology currently.
203.answer:
Short answer  
No clinically important pharmacokinetic (“blood-level”) interaction has been demonstrated between feminising hormone-replacement therapy (HRT) and either valproate (Depakote) or levetiracetam (Keppra).  The combination is used world-wide in people with epilepsy who take oral contraceptives or gender-affirming oestrogen without any systematic loss of seizure control.  The situation with lamotrigine is different because oestrogen markedly accelerates lamotrigine clearance, but this does not occur with valproate or levetiracetam.

Below is a more detailed explanation and some practical points you can take to your neurologist / endocrinologist.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Pharmacokinetic (serum-level) considerations
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A.  Valproate  
•  Metabolism: ~40–50 % UGT-mediated glucuronidation (UGT1A6, 1A9, 2B7) and mitochondrial β-oxidation; minor CYP2C9 pathway.  
•  Oestrogens: Ethinyl-estradiol or 17-β-estradiol can induce UGT1A4, which is why lamotrigine levels fall.  Those isoenzymes do not play a dominant role in valproate clearance, and multiple studies of combined hormonal contraceptives have shown ≤10 % changes in total valproate level – well inside day-to-day assay variation.  
•  Bottom line: No dose adjustment usually required; check a trough valproate level 4–8 weeks after each significant oestrogen dose change just to document stability.

B.  Levetiracetam  
•  Metabolism: 66 % renally excreted unchanged; 24 % hydrolysed by plasma esterases; no CYP or UGT involvement.  
•  Oestrogens/anti-androgens: Do not influence renal clearance or esterase activity.  Combined oral contraceptive trials have shown no change in levetiracetam AUC or Cmin.
