•  Bottom line: No known interaction; routine Keppra levels are not needed unless clinically indicated.

C.  Anti-androgens used in feminising HRT  
•  Spironolactone: Not an enzyme inducer/inhibitor at therapeutic doses; no effect on seizure medications.  
•  Cyproterone acetate (outside the U.S.) and GnRH analogues: likewise do not influence valproate or levetiracetam metabolism.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Pharmacodynamic (seizure-threshold) considerations
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Oestrogen has a mildly pro-convulsant and progesterone an anti-convulsant effect in some people (reason for catamenial epilepsy).  
•  Feminising HRT is usually continuous rather than cyclical, so large month-to-month hormone swings are absent; most trans-feminine cohorts do not report a systematic rise in seizure frequency.  
•  If you do notice an increase in myoclonic jerks around dose escalations, adjusting the oestrogen titration speed or adding progesterone (e.g., 100 mg micronised progesterone HS) can sometimes help and is safe from an epilepsy standpoint.  
•  Good sleep hygiene and anxiety management remain crucial in Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy, independent of hormone status.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Practical plan when starting gender-affirming HRT
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Baseline visit  
   – Discuss goals with both your neurologist and the prescriber of HRT.  
   – Document seizure frequency (diary) for 1–2 months before change.  
   – Obtain baseline trough valproate (and levetiracetam if you usually follow it).  

2.  Choice of oestrogen formulation  
   – Transdermal 17-β-estradiol patches or gels are preferred in epilepsy because (a) no first-pass hepatic induction, (b) lower thrombosis risk, and (c) smoother serum levels.  
   – If oral estradiol is used, start low (1–2 mg daily) and titrate every 4–6 weeks.

3.  Monitoring schedule  
   – Re-check valproate level 4–6 weeks after each estradiol dose step-up.  
   – Keep a seizure diary; if ≥25 % increase in frequency or severity appears, notify neurology sooner.  
   – Usual lab monitoring for valproate toxicity (CBC, LFTs) continues unchanged.  

4.  Long-term follow-up  
   – Once a stable estradiol maintenance dose is reached and valproate level verified, no additional epilepsy-specific monitoring is required beyond what you already do.  
   – Any future major hormone change (e.g., addition of progesterone, orchiectomy allowing oestrogen reduction) should repeat the above cycle of documentation and one follow-up level.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Other medications & supplements on your list
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Melatonin, vitamin D, calcium/magnesium/zinc: no interaction with HRT or AEDs.  
•  Adderall (amphetamine) 10 mg PRN can lower seizure threshold at high doses, but adding oestrogen does not potentiate that effect; just continue to use it judiciously.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Key take-aways
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Unlike lamotrigine, neither valproate nor levetiracetam has a clinically meaningful interaction with feminising HRT.  
•  Oestrogen itself can very slightly increase cortical excitability, so keep good sleep and anxiety control and titrate hormones gradually.  
•  Plan objectively: seizure diary + one or two valproate levels after each hormone dose change.  
•  Engage both treating teams early; bringing them data (as above) usually streamlines the conversation.

Good luck on your gender-affirming journey, and congratulations on taking a proactive approach to protecting your seizure control.

204.answer:
I can’t tell you exactly what is wrong with your mom, but I can give you a framework of the most common (and most easily overlooked) things that cause the combination of 1) sudden leg “give-way” spells, 2) tremor/jerks, 3) progressive memory and thinking problems, and 4) repeated falls in a woman in her early 60’s who is on several nervous-system medicines and many blood-pressure tablets.  Use the list below as a “check-off sheet” when you speak with her primary doctor, the neurologist, or—ideally—a new second-opinion neurologist or geriatrician.

1.  Medication-related problems
   • Polypharmacy (too many brain-active drugs at once) is the single commonest reversible cause of both falls and new dementia-like symptoms in older adults.  
   • Valproate/Depakote – can cause tremor, Parkinson-like gait “freezes,” ataxia (legs wobbling), word-finding problems, and frank encephalopathy (confusion, memory loss) that may clear if the dose is reduced or the drug is stopped.  It can raise blood ammonia; high ammonia causes delirium and jerking.  
   • Gabapentin – dizziness, ataxia, sedation, cognitive dulling.  The “official” interaction with valproate is minor, but the combined side-effects are additive.  
   • Unknown “anxiety pill” – if this is any benzodiazepine (alprazolam/Xanax, clonazepam/Klonopin, lorazepam/Ativan, diazepam/Valium, etc.) it can strongly worsen memory, balance, and cause drop attacks.  
   • Blood-pressure drugs – alpha-blockers (e.g., terazosin), beta-blockers, or clonidine can provoke abrupt leg weakness or fainting when standing.  

   What to ask the doctor:
   – “Can we do a full medication reconciliation and see which drugs we can taper, stop, or switch to something more brain-friendly?”  
   – “Can we get a valproate level, ammonia level, and basic metabolic panel?”  
   – “Is there a seizure drug with fewer thinking/balance side-effects—e.g., lamotrigine, levetiracetam, lacosamide?”  
   – “Can we taper completely off gabapentin and the benzodiazepine (if she’s on one) under supervision?”

2.  Seizure versus non-epileptic spells
   • Focal motor seizures can present exactly as you describe: the person stays awake, a limb or both legs shake violently for seconds to minutes, then stop.  
   • “Drop attacks” (atonic seizures) or cataplexy can also mimic “legs suddenly gone.”  
   • Psychogenic nonepileptic events (PNES) can look identical but show no abnormal brain activity on EEG.  
   • Orthostatic hypotension, transient ischemic attacks, or intermittent spinal-cord compression can masquerade as seizures.  

   What to ask:
   – “Can we arrange an in-home or ambulatory video-EEG for 24–72 h so you can actually capture one of her spells while she is in her usual environment?”  
   – “Would tilt-table testing or standing blood-pressure readings help rule out blood-pressure drops?”  
   – “Should we repeat brain MRI with and without contrast to look for new lesions, tight spinal stenosis, or hydrocephalus?”

3.  Vascular brain disease (“white-matter plaque,” small-vessel ischemia)
   • Heavy smoking + long-standing high blood pressure = high risk of multiple tiny strokes that slowly erode walking and thinking.  
   • If the MRI report already mentions “moderate/severe white-matter disease,” she may have developing vascular dementia.  

   What to ask:
   – “Can we optimize blood-pressure targets and stop the smoking (refer to cessation program)?”  
   – “Do we need aspirin or another antiplatelet drug?”  
   – “Would neurologic physical therapy improve her gait stability?”  

4.  Metabolic / deficiency causes of cognitive decline and falls
   • B-12 deficiency, folate deficiency, hypothyroidism, untreated sleep apnea, severe vitamin D deficiency, syphilis, HIV, liver or kidney failure, and (again) valproate-induced hyperammonemia.  

   Ask for a “dementia work-up” laboratory panel:
   – CBC, CMP, TSH, free T4, serum B-12, methylmalonic acid, folate, vitamin D, ESR/CRP, RPR (syphilis), HIV if risk factors, ammonia, liver function, renal function.

5.  Neurodegenerative diseases
   • Parkinson’s disease or Parkinson-plus (valproate may unmask or mimic Parkinsonism).  
   • Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH): triad of gait “magnet feet,” urinary urgency, and memory decline—often improves dramatically if recognized and treated with a shunt.  
   • Alzheimer’s disease or mixed Alzheimer’s/vascular dementia.  Age 61 is slightly young but possible, especially with family history.  A formal neuropsychological test battery can separate medication effect from true degenerative disease.

6.  Safety issues at home
   • Cigarette-related fire risk: strongly consider no smoking indoors, purchase flameless ashtrays, or e-cigarette until quit.  
   • Fall-proofing: grab bars, remove loose rugs, hip protectors, PT gait training, walker or cane as trained by PT.  
   • Medical alert system in case she drops when alone.  
   • Driving: if she still drives, ask neurologist for guidance—may need to stop.  

7.  Insurance / access
   • If household income and assets are low, see if she qualifies for Medicaid (separate from Medicare).  Most states allow dual-eligible Medicare/Medicaid or straight Medicaid for the disabled.  Social-services departments at county hospitals or clinics can help file.  
   • Many brand-name seizure drugs have patient-assistance programs.  The Epilepsy Foundation has state chapters that can steer you to neurology clinics that see uninsured patients on a sliding scale.  

8.  What to bring to the next appointment
   • A written list of ALL medicines (generic + brand, dose, what time taken)  
   • A fall/seizure diary: date, exact time, what she was doing, how long event lasted, how she felt before/after  
   • Phone videos of the spells (with her consent) – the single most helpful thing for a neurologist who has never witnessed one  
   • Blood-pressure log (sitting and standing) if possible  
   • Specific questions written down so nothing is forgotten (“Can Depakote cause tremor and memory problems?”; “Will you check an ammonia level?”; “Can we taper gabapentin?”; etc.)

9.  Take care of the caregivers
   • Caregiver burnout and anxiety are real.  If you, your sister, or step-dad feel overwhelmed, ask the primary doctor for a social-work referral, local caregiver-support groups, counseling, or respite-care resources.  
   • Keep pursuing your career plans; long-term stability for the family often requires at least one member to remain employed and insured.  Set up scheduled “check-in” calls or video chats so you can monitor mom without being physically home 24/7.

Key point: many (not all) of the problems you describe CAN be improved by a thorough medication clean-up, a focused search for metabolic and vascular contributors, and a fresh look at whether the spells are truly epileptic.  Start with the med review and basic labs; those are the simplest, cheapest, and most reversible pieces.  Bring the diary, the videos, and the question list to a second-opinion neurologist if her current doctors are dismissive.  Good documentation plus persistence often turns these “mystery” situations around.

205.question: My daughter is currently 7yrs old, epileptic ("generalized", idiopathic), ADD/ADHD, PDD, 15q26.1 microdeletion (not inherited). She's still illiterate, has issues getting to the bathroom (has a lot of "accidents") and lacks some finesse in her fine & gross motor skills. She's also slightly bow-legged. She's been seizure-free for over two years. When seizures initially presented, she was prescribed Topamax but it made her so dizzy she was unable to walk straight. She switched to a very low dose of valproic acid (maxed at 4mL 2/day). No other regular meds. About six months ago, her neurologist felt safe in discontinuing her valproic acid. Even though it was what the doc considered an extremely low dose, we noticed a huge change in our daughter's behavior. She just seems more "present" and aware of her surroundings. A few times she's had mood swings (sadness and crying) seemingly out of nowhere but all other aspects have been positive. Her PDD-related delays notwithstanding, she's made major strides in language, communication, following directions, etc; it's as if she previously wasn't aware of what was going on around her. When she was 2-3yrs old, we always marveled at what a happy-go-lucky child she was, never crying or throwing tantrums. Without the medication, she seems like she's much more like what we expected from that history. So, what gives? Valproic acid is also used for bi-polar so I can only assume there may have been a mood stabilizing effect of some sort but is there any explanation for the other communication-/social-related behavioral changes?
205.answer:
What you are seeing is almost certainly a medication-effect, not a mysterious change in her underlying disorders.

1. What valproic acid does in the brain  
   • Antiseizure action – It raises brain concentrations of GABA (the main inhibitory neurotransmitter) and blocks voltage-gated sodium channels.  
   • Mood-stabilising action – The same GABAergic effect calms the “highs” and “lows” in bipolar disorder.  
   • Global dampening – Because GABA is a general inhibitor, any brain circuit that depends on rapid information processing (attention, speech-language production, working memory, fine motor co-ordination, continence control, etc.) can also be partially “turned down.” The result can look like sedation, psychomotor slowing or “being in a fog.”

2. Cognitive and behavioural side-effects that have been documented in children on valproate  
   • Daytime sleepiness, fatigue, reduced alertness.  
   • Slowed reaction time and psychomotor speed.  
   • Decreased attention span and poorer working-memory scores.  
   • Speech-language delay and word-finding difficulty in some patients.  
   • Ataxia (unsteadiness), tremor, worsening of fine-motor tasks.  
   • Emotional flattening; fewer tantrums, but also fewer spontaneous social responses.  
   • These effects are independent of dose in some sensitive individuals—small children in particular may show cognitive side-effects even at “very low” mg/kg doses that nicely control seizures.

3. Why she seems “more present” and her language shot forward after the drug was stopped  
   • Removal of the brain-wide GABAergic dampening lets her attentional networks operate closer to normal speed.  
   • Speech-language circuits (Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas, basal ganglia/thalamocortical loops) depend on rapid excitatory firing. Less inhibition → better fluency, more spontaneous language.  
   • Psychomotor speed improves → she can co-ordinate mouth, hands, legs better, so toilet training, fine-motor tasks and gross-motor gait all look better.  
   • Better alertness means she actually notices instructions and social cues, which in turn feeds skill acquisition.

4. Why you are now seeing intermittent crying or mood lability  
   • The “mood-stabiliser” has been removed. Most people without bipolar disorder tolerate this just fine, but emotional range widens—especially in a child who previously had a flat or damped affect. The swings you are seeing are, in large part, normal emotional expression that had been muted.  
   • There can be a transient rebound period (2–3 months) in which irritability or sadness appears while the brain readjusts its receptor balance.

5. Could anything else explain the change?  
   • Natural developmental progress? Possible, but the step-wise improvement exactly when the drug was tapered, after a long plateau while she was ON the drug, strongly favours a medication effect.  
   • “Silent” seizures returning and causing hyperactivity? Unlikely if she remains clinically seizure-free and her functioning is better rather than worse.  
   • Placebo/expectancy? Again unlikely, given the objective gains you describe (toileting, language milestones).

6. Safety points to keep in mind  
   • Relapse risk – Most children who have been seizure-free for >2 years and whose EEG is improving will remain seizure-free off medication, but roughly 20-25 % will relapse, usually in the first 6–12 months. Stay vigilant for staring spells, myoclonic jerks, new clumsiness or night-time events.  
   • Bipolar/behaviour – True bipolar disorder developing at age 7 is rare; if the new mood swings are brief crying spells that resolve on their own, simple reassurance or behavioural strategies suffice. If she begins to have sustained irritability, insomnia or manic-type episodes, let her neurologist/psychiatrist know; sometimes a different, cognitively gentle mood-regulator (e.g., low-dose lamotrigine) is needed.  
   • ADHD symptoms – Because the valproate sedation is gone, her underlying ADHD may become more obvious. If behavioural therapy does not suffice, stimulant or non-stimulant medication can generally be used safely in children with controlled epilepsy, under neurologist guidance.

7. Bottom line  
Valproic acid is an excellent antiseizure and mood-stabilising agent, but in some children—especially those who already have developmental and attentional vulnerabilities—it can blunt alertness, language and social engagement even at “low” doses. Removing the drug lifts that inhibitory fog, so your daughter now appears brighter, more interactive and makes developmental leaps. The trade-off is a slightly wider emotional range and the need to keep a close eye on seizure control.

Continue regular follow-up with her neurologist, inform therapists/teachers of the medication change so they can leverage her new attentional “window,” and celebrate the gains—you are witnessing the genuine child underneath the medication haze.

206.question: I'm a 23 year old guy. I recently had an ambulatory EEG as I occaisionally have partial siezures and I recieved a copy of a letter sent between the person who looked at the EEG recording and my neurologist. In the letter it says "There were spike and wave discharges over the right frontotemporal and central regions maximally frontal". I can't get hold of the neurologist right now so I was just wondering if someone here could tell me what that means as i didn't have an actual siezure at any point during the recording.
206.answer:
What the report is really saying—translated into everyday language—is this:

1. What was seen  
   • “Spike-and-wave discharges” are brief, sharply contoured bursts of electrical activity that the EEG community calls “epileptiform” (epilepsy-like).
   • They showed up over the right side of your head, in the frontal-temporal and central leads, with the largest amplitude (“maximally”) in the frontal area.

2. Why it matters even though you did not have a clinical seizure while you were wired up  
   • In people who have epilepsy, the brain often gives off these epileptiform bursts in the hours, days, or weeks between actual seizures. They are called inter-ictal (between-seizure) discharges.  
   • Catching them on an EEG is useful because it tells the neurologist that your brain is capable of generating seizure activity and roughly where it is coming from, even if a full seizure did not occur during the recording.

3. What “right fronto-temporal / central” suggests  
   • “Right” = the electrical focus is on the right hemisphere.  
   • “Frontal” and “temporal” are lobes of the brain; “central” refers to the area around the central sulcus (roughly the strip that controls movement and sensation).  
   • Putting it together, the EEG implies that the seizure network is probably starting in, or at least strongly involves, the right frontal lobe, possibly spreading toward temporal and central areas.

4. How this fits with “partial” (focal) seizures  
   • A focal (partial) seizure originates from one spot or one network in one hemisphere, rather than simultaneously from the whole brain.  
   • Frontal-lobe focal seizures are often brief, may happen out of sleep or involve odd movements, speech arrest, or brief loss of awareness. If your own spells have some of those features, the EEG finding dovetails with your history.

5. Things it does NOT mean  
   • It does not prove you had a seizure during the test.  
   • It does not measure how often or how severe your seizures will be.  
   • It does not automatically imply brain damage; many people with perfectly normal MRI scans have epileptiform EEGs.

6. Next steps your neurologist is likely to take  
   • Put the EEG result together with your clinical description, MRI (if one was done), and possibly blood tests.  
   • Decide whether medication is warranted (if you are not already on one) and, if so, which drug is most effective for right-frontal focal epilepsy.  
   • Discuss safety issues (driving, heights, swimming, etc.) and seizure-precipitating factors (sleep deprivation, alcohol binges, flashing lights—though lights are less often a trigger for frontal seizures).

Bottom line: The EEG showed interictal epileptiform discharges suggesting a seizure focus in your right frontal region. That finding supports the diagnosis of focal epilepsy even though you did not have a clinical seizure during the study. Your neurologist will use this information, plus your symptom description and any imaging, to fine-tune diagnosis and treatment.  

(And of course, none of this replaces the conversation you’ll have with your own neurologist once you reach them.)
