218.answer:
I’m sorry these episodes are so frightening and exhausting.  
From what you describe, the events fit very well with Recurrent Isolated Sleep Paralysis (RISP) that is being triggered when you are sleep-deprived and possibly worsened by un-treated obstructive sleep apnoea.  Below is some detailed information to help you understand why it happens, how to tell it from seizures, what you can do at home, and when you really do need to seek medical care even during the pandemic.

1. What is happening during sleep paralysis  
• In rapid-eye-movement (REM) sleep the brain turns off the muscles of the body (atonia) so you don’t act out dreams.  
• In sleep paralysis that atonia “sticks” for a few seconds to a few minutes while your mind is already awake.  
• Because part of the brain is still in a dream-like state, vivid hallucinations (sounds, shadows, buzzing, a presence in the room, pressure on the chest or sides, floating, spinning, out-of-body sensations) are common.  Many people also report loud roaring/ringing (“exploding head syndrome”) and whole-body vibration.  
• It is harmless but understandably terrifying; the fear can make the hallucinations feel painful or threatening and leave you drained afterward.

2. Why yours is most likely NOT a seizure  
Feature – Sleep paralysis – Seizure  
– Consciousness: fully or almost fully aware – usually lost  
– Ability to recall event: clear – often patchy or none  
– Timing: only at falling asleep or awakening – can occur any time  
– Duration: seconds–few minutes – typically <2 min for generalized, but confusion lasts longer  
– Paralysis: complete but flaccid, no jerking – rhythmic jerking or stiffening common  
– Tongue-biting/incontinence/injury: absent – more common  
– Post-episode: fatigued but oriented – confusion, headache frequent  

Nothing you mention (no loss of awareness, no incontinence, no tongue biting, no one observing jerking) points strongly to epilepsy.  “Electric” or “buzzing” feelings are classic sensory hallucinations in sleep-wake transitions.

3. Why does it keep coming back?  
The biggest triggers are:  
• Sleep debt / irregular schedule (you already noticed this)  
• Fragmented sleep from obstructive sleep apnoea, which is common at your weight and with side-and-elevated sleeping  
• Stress, anxiety, depression  
• Supine (on the back) sleeping – you are already avoiding this  
• Stimulants (caffeine, nicotine) or sedatives close to bedtime  
• Shift work or jet lag

4. What you can do now, without seeing a doctor in person  
A. Strict sleep schedule  
– Fixed bed-time and wake-time 7 days per week.  Aim for 7.5–8 hours.  
– If you cannot fall asleep in 20 min, get up, do something quiet/dim-light, return to bed when sleepy.  
– Avoid naps >20 min and none after 3 p.m.

B. Sleep-friendly habits  
– No caffeine after 2 p.m.; no nicotine/alcohol in the 3 hours before bed.  
– Screens off or “night-shift” mode at least 1 hour before bed; dim the room.  
– Light exercise every day, but nothing vigorous in the last 2 hours before bed.  
– Small, non-heavy evening meal.

C. Position & breathing  
– Continue side-sleeping; place a pillow behind your back or use a body pillow so you don’t roll onto your back.  
– Raise the head of the bed 4–6 in if it helps breathing.  
– If you snore loudly, choke/gasp at night, or wake with a dry mouth or morning headaches, pursue testing for sleep apnoea when you can (home sleep tests are now widely available).

D. During an episode  
– Remind yourself “this is sleep paralysis, it will pass.”  
– Try to move a small distal muscle first (toe, fingertip, tongue) – that usually breaks the paralysis.  
– Focus on slow, deep breaths; panic makes the feeling of pressure worse.  
– Some people find that deliberately blinking, coughing, or wiggling the jaw ends the spell faster.  
– After it ends, get up, stretch, walk a bit, then return to bed once calm.

E. Stress management  
– Daytime mindfulness, breathing exercises, or a brief guided meditation before bed can reduce nightly episodes.  
– Keep a notepad beside the bed; jot down worries so you’re not mentally processing them as you try to sleep.

F. Weight & general health  
– Even 5–10 % weight loss can lessen possible sleep apnoea and improve sleep quality.  
– Regular aerobic exercise also raises deep-sleep time and lowers stress hormones.

5. When you SHOULD arrange medical evaluation despite COVID / insurance issues  
• Episodes occur outside sleep or nap transitions.  
• Witnessed jerking, loss of consciousness, blue lips, tongue biting, incontinence.  
• New sudden brief losses of muscle tone with laughter or emotion (cataplexy).  
• Excessive daytime sleepiness that doesn’t improve with good sleep hygiene.  
• Loud snoring, choking, or observed stopped-breathing episodes.  
• Worsening headaches, vision changes, or any neurological deficit.  
Most communities have county hospitals, federally qualified health centers, or teaching-hospital clinics that offer sliding-scale fees; many now have tele-neurology or tele-sleep-medicine visits that can be done from home.  A basic visit plus, if needed, an at-home sleep study is far less costly than an emergency evaluation.

6. Resources while uninsured  
• 211 (USA) – can direct you to local low-cost clinics.  
• NeedyMeds.org – list of free/low-cost clinics and prescription assistance programs.  
• American Academy of Sleep Medicine SleepEducation.org – patient handouts.  
• Project Access or similar local charitable physician networks (search your county).  

Bottom line  
Everything you’ve written (preserved awareness, transition-of-sleep timing, hallucinations, vibration, lack of post-ictal confusion) is consistent with recurrent sleep paralysis and not seizures.  It is not physically dangerous, but the fatigue and fear it causes are very real.  Regular sleep hours, addressing probable sleep apnoea, weight control, and stress reduction are the best tools to shorten or eliminate these bouts.  If new red-flag features appear, arrange a tele-visit or in-person evaluation without delay.

I hope this helps you feel safer and gives you practical steps to tame these episodes.  You’re not “crazy,” you’re not seizing, and with some targeted changes many people see a dramatic reduction in attacks.  Take care and sleep well.

219.question: Male 18 75kg 6ft black I started having these episodes last December. So basically it lasts about 5-10seconds and it's where I do something normal and then I recognize soenthing (like deja Vu) then shortly after my head begins to hurt and I get really dizzy and it brings me to a memory (it's the same memory when I always get these episodes) and then after 10 second me have gone I completely forget what that memory was. Now that is not what concerns me. But I've had this other type and I've had it twice so far..The first time maybe in May..and I wake up for work and I feel completely dazzed off..but then I'm okay..dad drives us into work and then I get so nauseous..I go home and I take a nap..I'm okay.. The next day my co worker tells me that he saw me and I told him I didn't recognize him and that I didn't know what to do..(I kind of remember it but not really).Now the reason why I'm writing this is because I had a crash recently and I woke up feeling that exact same way..I go to work and I'm with my mum and we crash into a wall and the car is totalled.. I remember 5minutes before the crash and I remember 5seconds being in the ambulance and a bit in hospital but my memory of the past week before that went.. I can remember bits of the previous week but it's not all there..I came out of the crash uninjured and same with the family.I take no medication I drink and social smoke like every 2 weeks with my friends.Had a panicked attack at work Thursday and had to go home cause I started crying thinking I have a tumor in my brain or epilepsy or something...and a friend suggested it could be an aura epilepsy..
219.answer:
What you are describing – the sudden “déjà-vu” feeling that lasts only seconds, a brief, pounding head pain, dizziness, and then a short period of memory loss or confusion – is very typical of focal (partial) seizures that start in the temporal lobe of the brain.  They are often called:

• focal aware seizures with déjà-vu “aura”, or  
• focal impaired-awareness seizures (formerly “complex partial” seizures) if you lose awareness for a few seconds and cannot remember events.

Important points that strongly suggest seizures rather than ordinary déjà-vu or panic:

1. Episodes are extremely brief (5-10 s) and stereotyped – they happen the same way every time.  
2. A very intense déjà-vu or “memory flash” is common in temporal-lobe seizures because that part of the brain handles memory.  
3. After-effects: brief headache, dizziness, fogginess, missing pieces of memory.  
4. The two longer, “dazed” spells you describe (one in May, one the morning of the crash) may have been bigger seizures or the confused “post-ictal” period that can last minutes to hours.  
5. You had a motor-vehicle crash with no recollection of the moments just before – that can happen if a seizure occurred while driving.

Could it be something else?  Yes, but the list is short:

• Migraine with aura – usually the aura lasts 15-60 minutes, not seconds.  
• Transient global amnesia – very rare at 18 yrs, episodes last hours, not seconds.  
• Panic attacks or dissociation – usually longer, with intact memory afterwards.  
• Tumor, infection, metabolic problem – possible, which is why imaging and lab work are needed, but even if something like that triggered the spells, the spells themselves are seizures.

Why you need to be seen quickly

• Driving: In virtually every country/state you must stop driving until a doctor clears you.  
• Treatment: Seizures are often easily controlled with medication once properly diagnosed.  
• Safety: Seizures around water, heights, machinery, or while walking near traffic can be fatal.  
• Underlying cause: A brain MRI can rule out structural problems (tumor, vascular malformation, old injury, etc.).

What to do now

1. Arrange an urgent appointment with your primary physician or go directly to an Emergency Department. Tell them:  
 “I might be having focal seizures. I have brief episodes of déjà-vu, headache, and memory loss, and I crashed a car during one.”

2. Expect these tests:  
 • Full neurological exam.  
 • Routine blood work (electrolytes, glucose, liver/kidney, tox screen).  
 • MRI of the brain with epilepsy protocol.  
 • EEG (brain-wave test). Sometimes a 24-hour ambulatory EEG or inpatient video-EEG monitoring is ordered if the routine EEG is normal but suspicion remains high.

3. While waiting to be seen:  
 • Do NOT drive, swim alone, climb, work at heights, or operate power tools.  
 • Avoid alcohol, sleep deprivation, and recreational drugs – all lower the seizure threshold.  
 • Keep a diary of every episode (date, time, what you were doing, how long it lasted, how you felt afterwards).  
 • Ask someone who has witnessed your spells (your dad, co-workers) to write down exactly what they saw.

If a seizure occurs in front of someone

• Keep you on your side, loosen tight clothing, put nothing in your mouth, time the event.  
• Call an ambulance if it lasts >5 minutes, occurs back-to-back, or if injury occurred.

Managing the anxiety

It is natural to panic when you suspect seizures or a brain tumor, but the great majority of young people with your story have ordinary temporal-lobe epilepsy that responds well to medication (levetiracetam, lamotrigine, carbamazepine, etc.).  Tumors are much less common.  Once a neurologist confirms the diagnosis and starts treatment, most people return to school, work, sports, and (after a seizure-free interval required by law) driving.

Key take-home message

Your episodes are highly suggestive of temporal-lobe seizures.  You must stop driving and get an urgent neurological evaluation (MRI + EEG).  The sooner you are diagnosed and treated, the sooner you can control the spells and resume normal life safely.

220.answer:
I can’t examine you or look at your test results, so use the information below only as something to discuss with your own doctor.  
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
1.  WHAT IS PROBABLY HAPPENING?  

Everything you describe – prodrome of warmth/clamminess, muffled hearing or ringing, dimming vision, brief loss of consciousness while sitting or just after standing, full orientation within seconds-to-a-minute, no tongue-biting or incontinence – is classic for neurally mediated (vasovagal) syncope.  

Why it is worse in an aircraft:  
• Cabin pressure is equivalent to ~6–8 000 ft altitude → mild hypoxia and relative air “thinness.”  
• Humidity in a jet cabin is <10 % → you dehydrate with every breath.  
• Long immobility → blood pools in the legs.  
• Warm cabin or a blanket after you fall asleep → peripheral vasodilation.  
• A sudden stand-up after dozing gives an extra orthostatic challenge.  

The combination reduces venous return to the heart. The brainstem reflex that is supposed to raise your heart rate and tighten your blood vessels over-reacts, producing a paradoxical bradycardia and sudden vasodilation. Cerebral blood flow drops for a few seconds → you faint.  

2.  WHAT ELSE HAS TO BE RULED OUT?  

Good that you have already had normal ECG, echocardiogram, glucose, EEG, thyroid studies, etc. Items sometimes missed:  
• Orthostatic vital signs or a tilt-table test to be sure you do not have POTS or autonomic failure.  
• Hemoglobin / ferritin (iron-deficiency anemia is common in women who “faint during periods”).  
• B-12 and vitamin D levels.  
• 24-hour Holter or event monitor if there is any suspicion of brief arrhythmia.  

3.  NON-DRUG MEASURES (most important)  

A. Day-to-day conditioning  
• 2–3 L fluids daily, at least 5–8 g of salt (unless contraindicated by another illness).  
• Regular aerobic and leg-strengthening exercise (more calf muscle = better venous pump).  
• Avoid long hot showers, prolonged standing, heavy alcohol binges, skipping meals.  

B. Counter-pressure maneuvers – practice them so they are automatic at the first warning:  
• Cross your ankles and thighs and squeeze (“leg lock”).  
• Tense buttocks and abdominal muscles.  
• Make a fist with both hands and do an isometric “hand-grip.”  
These raise systolic BP 10–30 mmHg within seconds.  

4.  SPECIFIC AIR-TRAVEL STRATEGY  

Before the flight  
• Ask for an aisle seat, ideally just behind the wing (cooler and least motion).  
• Tell the lead flight attendant you have a history of vasovagal syncope – crews are used to this.  
• Bring 2–3 oral-rehydration packets or 1 L bottles of an electrolyte drink; plain water alone can dilute sodium if you over-drink.  
• Pack quick salty snacks: pretzels, salted nuts, trail mix, jerky.  
• Wear knee-high 20–30 mmHg compression stockings and loose clothing.  

During the flight  
• Eat something with salt every 2–3 h (small amounts are fine).  
• Drink 150–250 mL (5–8 oz) fluid each hour; alternate water with electrolyte drink.  
• Every 30–45 min do one of the following:  
  – Flex and extend ankles, lift knees, push toes into floor for 20 sec.  
  – Stand in the aisle and march in place; calf-raise 10×.  
• If you nap, recline a bit; on waking, sit still for 30 s while doing ankle pumps before you stand.  
• At the FIRST hint of prodrome:  
  – Slide forward so your head is between your knees OR ask the attendant if you can lie across three seats or on the galley floor with feet on a seat cushion.  
  – Start the counter-pressure maneuvers.  
  – Cold wet towel on face/neck from the galley ice.  

Useful extras  
• Light caffeine (½ cup coffee or tea) can support BP; if you tolerate it at home, you don’t necessarily have to avoid it.  
• Small dose of anti-nausea medication (e.g., meclizine) if motion sickness is a trigger – check with your doctor first.  
• A personal pulse-oximeter can warn you early if saturation is falling <92 %.  

5.  WHEN NON-DRUG MEASURES ARE INSUFFICIENT  

About 10 % of people with troublesome vasovagal syncope need medication. Options your physician can consider after a tilt-table test:  
• Fludrocortisone 0.1 mg daily – expands plasma volume.  
• Midodrine 5–10 mg every 6–8 h – raises vascular tone (cannot take within 4 h of lying down).  
• Low-dose beta-blocker (e.g., 12.5 mg metoprolol) – may blunt the reflex in some patients.  
These are prescribed only after other causes of syncope are excluded and blood pressure is documented to be on the low side.  

6.  RED-FLAG FEATURES THAT SHOULD PROMPT RE-EVALUATION  

• Syncope during exertion or with no prodrome.  
• Family history of sudden unexplained death <50 y.  
• Palpitations immediately before fainting.  
• Prolonged confusion afterwards.  
• Chest pain, severe shortness of breath, or cyanosis.  

Your history does NOT sound like these, but be aware.  

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––  
BOTTOM LINE  

What you are experiencing appears most consistent with vasovagal syncope made worse by the altitude, low humidity, and immobility of long flights. Hydration + salt loading, compression, frequent leg activity, early counter-pressure maneuvers, and letting the cabin crew know in advance prevent the majority of episodes. If despite scrupulous non-drug measures you still pass out, ask your physician (or a specialized syncope clinic) about a formal tilt-table test and possible fludrocortisone or midodrine for travel days.  

Safe travels!

221.question: When I came down with epilepsy in 2010, I began having a strange change in energy level. At first I thought it was just the medication, but when I go on r/epilepsy and explain it, nobody responds. I don't think they are experiencing the same thing, even though most of them take keppra like I do.Basically, I was going through a big weight loss leading up to the epilepsy. I lost 65 pounds. I would go to the gym for 1 - 1.5 hours and do 20 mile hikes on the weekends. Things were looking up. I even got a new relationship and was about to start a new career in EMS.Then I woke up in the hospital. I had a huge seizure in my sleep and my wife saved my life. I lost my future career and even my job, because I lost my license.So once things stabilized a bit, I tried to reestablish my habits. I found that I had no energy at the gym. After 15 min working out, I would feel like I was going to literally pass out. I would feel this way on short hikes, too.Over time, I was discouraged by my sudden change in performance to where I was less and less motivated. I literally couldn't exercise. I gradually gained all the weight back. If I explain any of this to a doctor now, they will just kind of roll their eyes at me. They think I lost my energy because I'm fat, not the other way around. They don't care to listen.I've been researching a little into leaky gut etc but I think it's hard because people are barely scratching the surface. Do I have seizures because of autoimmune disease?
221.answer:
I can’t tell you what the exact cause of your fatigue is, but I can tell you how doctors usually approach the problem and where “auto-immune epilepsy,” “leaky gut,” Keppra, weight regain, etc., do—or do not—fit in.  If you understand their reasoning you can push the discussion in a productive direction instead of having it dismissed with “you’re tired because you’re overweight.”

1.  How often do seizures really come from an auto-immune disorder?  
   •  They do—just not often.  Well-described examples are NMDA-receptor, LGI-1, CASPR-2, GAD-65, and Hashimoto-related encephalitides, and (less commonly) celiac disease.  
   •  Typical picture: new-onset seizures in an adult, often focal and frequent, sometimes status epilepticus, plus rapidly developing memory loss, psychiatric changes or abnormal movements. Most patients need several anti-epileptic drugs or immune therapy to control the seizures.  
   •  What you describe—one generalized nocturnal seizure in 2010 that has stayed controlled on a single drug—is the opposite pattern.  A neurologist therefore puts “auto-immune epilepsy” low on the list.  If you still want it considered, ask specifically for serum / CSF antibody testing and let the neurologist explain whether the clinical picture warrants it.

2.  “Leaky gut” and epilepsy/fatigue  
   •  There is no proven link between so-called intestinal hyper-permeability and seizure disorders, nor between it and exercise intolerance.  
   •  The one digestive condition we do screen for in epilepsy is celiac disease (tissue-transglutaminase IgA test), because celiac can cause both seizures and fatigue/anemia.  That test is inexpensive and reasonable to request once.

3.  Keppra (levetiracetam) and exercise intolerance  
   •  Fatigue/weakness occurs in ~15–25 % of patients; most tolerate it, some do not.  
   •  Keppra side effects are usually present all day, not just with exertion, but patients do report “hitting a wall” sooner during exercise.  
   •  If the drug is suspected, switching to another agent (e.g., lamotrigine, brivaracetam, topiramate, etc.) is the only way to know.  A slow cross-taper can be done safely under a neurologist’s supervision.

4.  The common, often missed causes of “I crash after 10–15 minutes of exertion”  
   A primary-care or sports-medicine work-up usually starts with these screens (all inexpensive, covered by insurance, and yield a lot of answers):  
   •  CBC (anemia), ferritin, B-12, vitamin D.  
   •  TSH + free T4 (thyroid), morning cortisol if suspicion for adrenal insufficiency.  
   •  CMP (electrolytes, liver, kidney, glucose).  
   •  Fasting lipid/glucose/A1c (diabetes or pre-diabetes).  
   •  Testosterone (in men) if low energy, low libido, loss of muscle mass.  
   •  ECG ± echocardiogram and exercise stress test if there is any hint of cardiac limitation.  
   •  Sleep study if snoring, witnessed apneas, or unrefreshing sleep; obstructive sleep apnea is probably the single most common under-diagnosed reason for dramatic exercise intolerance after weight regain.  
   •  Depression and anxiety screening; mood disorders can halve perceived exercise capacity even when objective VO2max is normal.

5.  The “de-conditioning spiral”  
   •  Aerobic capacity (VO2max) starts to fall measurably after two weeks of inactivity and can drop 15–20 % after three months.  Muscle mass and mitochondrial density follow.  
   •  Regaining 60+ lb and losing muscle means your heart and leg muscles are pushing a heavier load with a weaker engine.  It can absolutely make a previously avid hiker feel washed-out after 15 min.  
   •  The only way out biologically is graded re-training (walk 5 min/day the first week, add 2–3 min every week, progress to intervals) even if it feels embarrassingly slow at first.

6.  Putting it together—what to ask for at your next appointment  
   1.  “I want a systematic fatigue work-up: CBC, ferritin, B-12, vitamin D, CMP, TSH, fasting glucose/A1c, maybe testosterone and a sleep study.”  
   2.  “I’d like to discuss whether Keppra might be contributing and if a trial switch to another AED is reasonable.”  
   3.  “Can we rule out celiac disease with a tTG-IgA, and is there any reason to send autoimmune encephalitis antibodies given my seizure history?”  
   4.  “If the labs are unrevealing, can you refer me for a cardiopulmonary exercise test or to sports medicine/physical therapy for a graded re-conditioning program?”

If your current physician is unreceptive, it is reasonable to ask for referral to an epileptologist (a neurologist specializing in seizures) and/or a different primary-care physician.  Everything above is standard, evidence-based medicine; none of it requires exotic testing or belief in fringe theories.

Bottom line  
•  Auto-immune epilepsy exists but is rare and usually looks very different from a single Keppra-controlled generalized seizure.  
•  “Leaky gut” has no proven connection here.  
•  Keppra, weight regain, de-conditioning, sleep apnea, anemia, thyroid or hormonal issues are far more common and should be ruled out first.  
•  A step-wise lab screen plus, if needed, a medication change and a structured return-to-exercise plan solve the problem for the majority of patients.

222.question: 25F - Last week I laughing gas at the dentist for the time, next day I had an episode with seizure-like movements, hyperventilating and was unable to move or speak. Ever since I’ve been experiencing “freezes” and difficulty processing. Waiting for neurologist appt.Last Tuesday, I had a filling done at the dentist and they gave me laughing gas the first time. It hit me pretty hard - I was given oxygen for 10 mins after and could still barely walk or talk. It took several hours for it to wear off. Wednesday morning, I felt completely fine. Around 1pm, I suddenly felt really bad - extremely nauseous, hot, and faint. Starting writing a simple email and just could not make sense of any of my thoughts or even string a sentence together - very strange feeling of nothing making sense, like I was in a dream. Had real difficulty moving my hands on the keyboard and could not coordinate my fingers to even type properly. My head kept falling back involuntarily. I was going to tell my boss I felt bad, next thing I know I’m sitting on the floor hyperventilating. According to my coworkers, I slammed my hands down on my desk and pushed myself backwards in my chair against the back of my cubicle, and was taking big loud gasping breaths as if I was choking. They helped me to the floor - I don’t remember this. They called 911 because they thought I was having a seizure. I was on the floor for 20 mins hyperventilating - I was aware of others around me but could not shift my gaze from the corner of the ceiling. I also could not move or talk. Paramedics came and took vitals and everything was fine apart from elevated heart rate. Went to the ER, they took bloods, EKG and head CT and all came back clear. Dr said it could be seizure but unlikely, or just a bad reaction to the laughing gas. He referred me to a neurologist for more testing. Basically every day since, I’ve had daily moments of “freezing” which last 10-20 secs. One time I was eating a sandwich, talking to my husband and my body just froze up and I was unable to speak and just felt completely blank and frozen - unable to speak and shift my gaze. Another time we were walking through target and my legs got really weak and locked up, and I felt an “aura” feeling, was unable to speak and just felt completely stuck and removed from reality. I’ve also noticed difficulty processing people talking to me - I’ve been having about 5 second “lags” which isn’t normal for me. Any idea what this could be? FYI no personal history of panic attacks or any anxiety, no family history of seizures, neurological issues etc.
222.answer:
First, the bottom-line:  
No one can tell you for certain what these spells are without seeing you and doing the proper testing.  The two most common explanations for an episode that looks like a seizure but leaves normal ER studies are  

1. real (epileptic) focal seizures, and  
2. psychogenic non-epileptic events (also called dissociative or functional seizures).  

A single brief exposure to nitrous oxide (“laughing gas”) the day before is very unlikely to be the direct cause.

Why nitrous oxide is probably not the culprit  
• Nitrous oxide is eliminated from the body within minutes once it is turned off.  
• What ER doctors worry about after nitrous is “diffusion hypoxia” (low oxygen for a few minutes if 100 % oxygen is not given) and, with very frequent or prolonged use, vitamin-B12 depletion.  Neither one fits a spell that starts 24 h later and keeps recurring.  

What in your description raises the possibility of a seizure  
• The sudden “blanking out” and inability to speak or move.  
• The feeling of an “aura.”  
• Co-workers saw forced movements (slamming hands down, jerking backward).  
• Confusion and slowness to process afterward (“post-ictal” period).  
• Repetitive short events lasting 10–20 s resembling focal impaired-awareness seizures.  

What argues against (or at least does not prove) a seizure  
• You were aware of people around you during the long spell; many seizures cause complete loss of awareness.  
• Hyperventilation and long preserved stiff gaze can also occur in panic or dissociative events.  
• Normal head CT, blood work and ECG are reassuring but do not rule out epilepsy; CT only excludes bleeding or a large mass.  

Other, less likely possibilities ER doctors think about  
– Transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke – CT was normal and you are young; not likely.  
– Metabolic problems (blood sugar, electrolytes, thyroid, infection) – routine labs were normal.  
– Migraine aura without headache – can give odd neurologic spells but usually has a more stereotyped pattern and minutes-long evolution rather than seconds.  
– Cataplexy/narcolepsy – almost always triggered by laughter or strong emotion, not random.  
– Medication or drug effect – none reported except nitrous.  
– Acute B-12 depletion from nitrous – requires heavy/frequent abuse, not one exposure.

What will the neurologist probably do?  
1. Careful history from you and anyone who has witnessed the events.  
2. Focused neurologic examination.  
3. Routine EEG.  If routine EEG is unrevealing but spells persist, they may order  
   – extended (24-72 h) ambulatory EEG or  
   – inpatient video-EEG monitoring to capture an actual spell.  
4. MRI brain (better than CT for subtle structural causes).  
5. Blood tests if not already done (vitamin B-12, folate, ANA, thyroid, etc.).  

How to prepare until you are seen  
• Keep a “seizure diary”: date, time, what you were doing, how long it lasted, what you felt before/after, witness description.  
• If a coworker or family member can video one of the short freezing spells on a phone (safely, without startling you), that can be extremely helpful for the neurologist.  
• Follow standard seizure precautions just in case: no driving until cleared by your physician (laws vary by state), avoid swimming/bathing alone, microwaving or cooking on open flame when alone, working at heights, etc.  
• Make sure someone close to you knows how to roll you onto your side and keep your airway clear if you have a long spell.  
• Get adequate sleep and avoid alcohol or recreational drugs, which can precipitate seizures even in people who do not have epilepsy.  
• If you notice a pattern (stress, skipped meals, dehydration, flashing lights, etc.) try to avoid those triggers.  

When to seek care sooner  
• Any spell that lasts >5 min without recovery.  
• A cluster of back-to-back spells without full improvement in between.  
• New weakness, numbness, vision loss or speech trouble that does NOT clear within minutes.  
• Persistent headache, fever, neck stiffness.  

Take-home points  
• A single, routine dental use of nitrous oxide almost never produces recurrent neuro-events the next day; it is more likely coincidence.  
• Your description fits either focal (partial) seizures with impaired awareness or psychogenic non-epileptic events; distinguishing the two requires EEG/video.  
• Normal ER tests are reassuring but do not rule out epilepsy; follow-up with neurology is the right next step.  
• Until you are evaluated, keep a diary, try to obtain a phone video of an event, follow seizure safety precautions, and seek emergency care if the spells become prolonged or change character.

223.question: I suffered from this as a baby (parents said I almost died at birth and they had to put me in really cool environments and use ice at the hospital since I had low oxygen at birth. For a few weeks I was on some baby monitor ( I was also a c section) did a bit of searching online but couldn't find much discussion about this.About me currently Im a 28 year old Male 28M , the birth asphyxia obviously happened during birthAre there things happening during birth asphyxia that could leads to other issues? I suffer from ADHD or ADD which makes me wonder if this came from birth asphyxia and I have definitely had reactions to strong flashing lights when I was a teenager (still do a bit) i read that seizures could be a complication from birth asphyixia.
223.answer:
What happened then  
“Birth asphyxia” (more often called hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy, HIE) means the brain and other organs did not get enough oxygen and blood flow around the time of delivery. Brain cells that are especially sensitive (cortex, deep grey nuclei, hippocampus, cerebellum) can be injured. The injury can be:

• Mild – temporary irritability, low muscle tone, no permanent damage in most babies  
• Moderate – hours of lethargy, need for ventilation; 15-40 % later have some neurologic or learning problems  
• Severe – coma, multi-organ failure; high risk (40-90 %) of death or major disability

Cooling the baby to 33-34 °C for 72 h (therapeutic hypothermia) is now standard for moderate/severe HIE because it reduces later disability. It sounds as if your doctors improvised a form of cooling in 1995.

Possible long-term effects seen in follow-up studies

Approximate rates after moderate / severe HIE that is treated:

Cerebral palsy…………………………………………… 10-30 %  
Epilepsy (any time in life)……………………………… 10-40 %  
Cognitive / intellectual disability………………… 20-50 %  
Specific learning disability, ADHD, behavioural
or emotional disorders………………………………… 15-35 %  
Vision or hearing impairment………………………… 5-15 %  
No measurable problem……………………………… 30-50 % (mainly those with mild HIE)

So attention-deficit disorder and a lowered seizure threshold are both recognised sequelae. They are not inevitable—many people with HIE have normal cognition—but epidemiological studies do show a higher risk than in the general population.

Why ADHD can follow perinatal hypoxia  
• Pre-frontal cortex and basal ganglia, areas involved in attention and impulse control, are very oxygen-sensitive.  
• Damage need not be large enough to show obvious motor deficits; subtle white-matter or cortical injury can disturb the dopaminergic networks thought to underlie ADHD.  
• Twin and sibling studies suggest prenatal/perinatal hypoxia roughly doubles the risk of ADHD after genetic factors are accounted for.

Light sensitivity and seizures  
Flashing lights can trigger abnormal EEG discharges (“photoparoxysmal response”) in people with a low seizure threshold. Perinatal brain injury is one of many reasons the threshold may be lower. Only an EEG can tell whether your light sensitivity is producing epileptic activity.

What you can (and can’t) do at age 28  

1. Get an up-to-date neurological look-over  
   • Discuss your birth history, ADHD symptoms, and light sensitivity with a neurologist.  
   • An EEG is simple and non-invasive; if it shows a tendency to epileptic discharges you can reduce risk by medication or lifestyle changes.  
   • A brain MRI may show old hypoxic injury, helpful mainly for documentation.

2. Optimize ADHD treatment  
   • Standard pharmacologic (stimulants or non-stimulants) and behavioural strategies work whether the origin is genetic or acquired.  
   • Adequate sleep, regular aerobic exercise, moderated alcohol/​drug use—all lower seizure risk and improve attention.

3. Avoid strong flickering stimuli if they clearly bother you  
   • Gaming displays, strobe lights in clubs, quick cuts in some movies.  
   • Most people only need commonsense avoidance; some choose tinted lenses.

4. Watch for late-emerging issues  
   Even in adults, hypoxic injury can be associated with subtle motor coordination problems, executive-function challenges, or mood disorders. If something interferes with work or daily life, mention the birth history to clinicians so they think of this possibility.

5. No “repair” procedure exists  
   Neuroplasticity allowed you to reach adulthood with relatively mild consequences—good news. There is no current therapy to reverse old hypoxic injury, but a brain-healthy lifestyle and treatment of any identifiable complication (ADHD, epilepsy, mood) keep the practical impact low.

Bottom line  
Perinatal asphyxia can indeed increase the chances of ADHD and of seizures triggered by flashing lights, although genetics and later environment also play big roles. An adult assessment (neurology ± psychiatry) can sort out whether you have an epileptic tendency and ensure your ADHD management is optimal.

224.question: Age – 25 Sex – Male Height - 183cm 6ft Weight - 92kg 200lb Race – Caucasian Duration - Last 3 months Symptoms ive experienced over the last 3 months Around 2months ago i was experiencing Phantom smells, brief periods of 3-4second smells; started off as a blood smell and then startedto get them more frequently and smells were sometimes oranges/flowers. I Have since had an EEG that said i had no Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. I've not had these smells for a few weeks in the last 2 weeks i have started to notice eye floaters that follow where my eye goes only in sunlight. I have also noticed Bright flashing lights from the outter right corner of my eye. Some less worrying symptoms i have had. Sometimes 1 ear will get a high pitch noise that starts loud and fades out Muscle twitching hadaches sometimes. nothing severe Lightheadedness that may be related to anxiety/ or my low iron Sometimes cant think of the word i was thinking of or lose train of thought. Feel like im staring through what im looking at, kinda get daydreamy i guess? Also i do have a front tooth that is decaying / has a hole between the front and front right I have Severe anxiety and depression; and have been through a period of very high stress the last 3 months after breaking up with my long term partner. Is it possible that stress can do all these things to the body... my GP dosent seem worried about brain tumours but i am.
224.answer:
I’m not in a position to diagnose you online, but I can help you make sense of what you’re feeling, outline the “red-flag” reasons to seek urgent care, and suggest the most logical next steps to take with your own doctors.

1.  Phantom smells (phantosmia)
   •  Common, usually benign.  Typical culprits: short-lived viral or allergic sinus inflammation, dental infection, migraine aura, medication side effects, anxiety/​panic, and (much less often) seizures or a mass in the temporal lobe.  
   •  You have already had an EEG that did not suggest temporal-lobe seizures, the episodes were brief, have now stopped, and you have no other focal neurologic signs—those are all reassuring points.  
   •  A decaying upper tooth or chronic post-nasal drip can sometimes produce a persistent “blood” or “metallic” smell (especially if it’s worse when you breathe in through the nose).  Even if that wasn’t the whole story, the tooth still needs treatment to avoid a deeper infection.

2.  Eye floaters and “flashes”
   •  Tiny black/grey spots moving with eye motion in bright light are usually harmless vitreous floaters.  
   •  Bright, brief peripheral flashes, however, can be a sign of traction on the retina.  In someone your age it’s typically a benign posterior vitreous detachment, but because an evolving retinal tear can lead to retinal detachment, every new onset of flashes + floaters deserves a one-time, same-week dilated retinal exam by an optometrist or ophthalmologist.  They can rule out a tear in ten minutes.  
   •  Brain tumours hardly ever cause isolated flashes/floaters. They almost always produce more fixed visual field defects, progressive loss of vision on one side, or other neurologic deficits.

3.  Intermittent tinnitus, muscle twitches, brief attention lapses, “word-finding” glitches
   •  Very often stress-related and amplified by fatigue, excess caffeine, and low iron.  
   •  Brief high-pitched ringing that rises and fades in one ear is usually benign “transient ear tinnitus” caused by momentary spasm in the middle-ear muscles or a fleeting change in inner-ear blood flow.  
   •  Benign fasciculation syndrome (random muscle twitches) is common in anxious people, after exercise, or with low magnesium or iron.  
   •  Word-finding issues, staring spells and feeling “detached” often accompany anxiety/depression, especially when sleep is poor.

4.  Light-headedness
   •  You mention low iron.  Iron-deficiency anaemia is a textbook cause of light-headedness, fatigue and even palpitations.  Correcting the anaemia usually helps.  
   •  Anxiety by itself can also cause mild hyperventilation and light-headedness.

5.  Stress, anxiety and depression
   •  Chronic stress elevates adrenaline and cortisol, sensitising the brain to normal body sensations, and it can mimic or exaggerate virtually every symptom you describe.  When the underlying stressor (break-up, uncertainty) is intense, random bodily sensations are noticed and interpreted as more threatening, fuelling yet more anxiety—the classic “health-anxiety loop.”

How likely is a brain tumour?
   •  In a 25-year-old otherwise healthy male, the odds of a primary brain tumour are about 1 in 20 000.  
   •  Tumours usually produce steadily progressive neurologic deficits (vision loss on one side, weakness, imbalance, speech difficulty), seizures that become more frequent, or headaches that become daily, wake you from sleep, or worsen when you lie flat or strain.  
   •  So far you describe fleeting, non-progressive, stress-linked symptoms—not the usual tumour pattern.  Your GP’s low index of suspicion is reasonable.

When to seek urgent care (today/tomorrow):
   •  A curtain or shadow over part of your visual field, many new floaters like “soot” or a sudden shower of flashes (possible retinal detachment).  
   •  A persistent, worsening headache with vomiting, double vision, limb weakness, loss of balance, or seizures.  
   •  Continuous unilateral tinnitus or hearing loss.  
   •  High fever, facial swelling, or drainage from the decayed tooth (possible spreading infection).

Reasonable next steps (non-emergency):
1.  Eye: Schedule a dilated retinal exam within the week to rule out a retinal tear.  
2.  Dental: Get the front tooth repaired/​extracted and any sinus infection treated—both could be feeding the phantosmia.  
3.  Blood work: CBC, ferritin, B12, thyroid to confirm and treat any anaemia or metabolic contributors.  
4.  Anxiety/​depression: Engage in cognitive-behavioural therapy, consider an SSRI if symptoms are moderate-to-severe, ensure 7–8 h of sleep, limit caffeine/​energy drinks, regular aerobic exercise.  
5.  Follow-up: If new, focal neurologic symptoms appear (weakness, speech or vision loss) ask your GP for a neurological review and MRI for peace of mind.  With your current story an MRI is optional, not urgent.

Practical self-care tips
   •  Hydration, balanced meals, iron supplementation if prescribed.  
   •  30 min brisk walking or other aerobic exercise at least 5 days/​week—shown to reduce anxiety and improve sleep.  
   •  Structured relaxation: diaphragmatic breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness apps for 10 min daily.  
   •  Limit screen time before bed; aim for a consistent sleep schedule.  
   •  Keep a symptom diary—often helps you (and your doctor) see whether things are actually worsening or just fluctuating with stress.

Bottom line
Nothing you’ve mentioned screams “brain tumour.” The group of symptoms does fit very well with a mix of eye vitreous changes, possible retinal traction, dental/​sinus irritation, iron deficiency and—most prominently—stress/anxiety. Still, do have the retinal exam quickly (flashes/floaters), fix the tooth, correct your iron, and work actively on anxiety management. If worrying neurological signs ever appear, seek immediate medical review, but right now your story is far more consistent with benign, stress-exacerbated conditions than with a serious intracranial process.

225.question: Hello all, I had a question about my medication and fasting, if that's alright. I take Keppra twice a day (500mg each), once in the morning and once at night. With Ramadan approaching I was wondering how much time there needs to be in between taking one pill at night and one in the morning, thanks.Let me know if I need to add anything else.
225.answer:
Keppra (levetiracetam) immediate-release tablets are meant to be taken every 12 hours, so in an ordinary situation you would swallow one tablet at (for example) 8 a.m. and the second at 8 p.m. The 12-hour rhythm keeps the drug level in your blood fairly steady, which is what protects you from seizures.

How much “wiggle-room” is there?  
• Elimination half-life: about 6–8 hours in adults.  
• Therapeutic range: fairly wide (Keppra is forgiving of small timing errors).  
• Neurologists generally aim for 10–14 hours between doses at most; anything much shorter than 8 hours or longer than 16 hours on a regular basis can let the level drift too low or too high.

What this means for Ramadan
--------------------------------------------------
Most people will have 8–10 hours between sunset (iftar) and the pre-dawn meal (suhoor). A schedule such as:

• 1st dose: immediately after Maghrib/iftar  
• 2nd dose: just before Fajr/suhoor  

…gives you roughly 8–9 hours between tablets. For Keppra this is usually acceptable; it is close enough to the 12-hour target that the drug level stays in the therapeutic zone throughout the day. Millions of patients worldwide use exactly this arrangement during Ramadan with their neurologist’s approval.

Points to keep in mind
1. Try to be as consistent as possible—take each pill at the same clock time every night and pre-dawn.  
2. Swallow the tablet with a full glass of water; food is optional because Keppra is well absorbed even on an empty stomach.  
3. Do not split or crush the tablets.  
4. If you ever miss the pre-dawn dose and remember it more than ~4 hours late, it is usually better to wait until the next scheduled dose rather than “doubling up,” but follow the specific advice your own doctor has given you.  
5. If the dusk-to-dawn interval where you live is very short (≤7 hours) or you find the two-dose schedule hard to keep, ask your neurologist whether switching to Keppra XR (extended-release) once daily, or altering the dose sizes (e.g., a larger tablet at night and a smaller one pre-dawn), would be safe for you.

Bottom line
• Aim for ~12 hours apart when life is normal.  
• During Ramadan an 8–10 hour gap (iftar → suhoor) is generally accepted for immediate-release Keppra, but confirm with the clinician who knows your seizure history.  
• Never change the dose or the schedule permanently without your prescriber’s approval.

Have a blessed and healthy Ramadan, and speak with your neurologist soon so any needed prescription changes can be arranged before the fast begins.

226.question: Recently I got a hickie, and tons of people started telling me to be careful because I could die, and stuff. Is it that dangerous? Male 17, epilepsy, anxiety, question: are hickies dangerous?
226.answer:
Short answer  
For almost everyone, a “hickie” (love-bite) is nothing more than a superficial bruise. It does not put you at meaningful risk of dying, even if it is on the neck. The alarming stories your friends are repeating come from a handful of extremely rare, sensational case reports—not from something that usually happens.

What a hickie really is  
• A small area where suction and/or biting breaks tiny blood vessels (capillaries) under the skin.  
• The leaked blood forms a bruise that changes color and fades over 5–10 days.  
• No different in principle from the bruise you might get if you bump your arm on a table.

Why people say they are “dangerous”  
1. Stroke anecdotes  
   • Fewer than five single-patient case reports (worldwide, over decades) describe someone getting a neck hickie, then developing a clot in the carotid artery that led to a stroke.  
   • These cases are so exceptional that they are published precisely because they are extraordinary.  
   • For perspective: millions of people get neck hickies every year without any such event.

2. Blood-borne infection myths  
   • A hickie doesn’t break the skin, so no direct risk of HIV, hepatitis, etc.  
   • Only if there is open skin (e.g., biting hard enough to cut) could there be a theoretical infection risk, and even then it is very low.

3. “It might block your airway”  
   • A hickie sits in the skin; it does not swell inward toward your windpipe or “choke” you.

Your specific health conditions  
Epilepsy: A hickie does not trigger seizures.  
Anxiety: Hearing scary rumors can understandably raise anxiety; knowing the facts can help.

When to be concerned (very uncommon)  
See a doctor or go to the ER if, after a hickie on the neck, you suddenly develop:  
• Weakness or numbness on one side of the body  
• Trouble speaking or understanding speech  
• Sudden severe headache or vision loss  
• Persistent, enlarging, painful swelling at the site  
These would be signs of something far beyond an ordinary hickie, and they warrant urgent evaluation no matter the cause.

Basic care  
• You don’t actually need to “treat” a routine hickie.  
• If you want it to fade sooner: 5–10 minutes of cold compress in the first few hours, then gentle massage or warm compress after 48 hours can help disperse the blood.  
• Cosmetics or clothing are your only “cover-up” options.

Bottom line  
Hickies are bruises. They are not inherently dangerous, do not threaten your life, and are not a problem for epilepsy. The dramatic stories involve vanishingly rare complications. Practice consensual, gentle intimate behavior, and if anything truly unusual happens afterward, seek medical attention—otherwise, you can relax.

227.question: 30 AFAB, 158cm/61kg, hispanic, Symptoms: lightheadedness, fatigue, darker urine, light periods. flu-ish [see below] since a month ago.Diagnoses: Epilepsy, ADHD, Endometriosis, 5cm ovarian cyst, migrainesMedications: Lamotrigine 225mg, Ibuprofen for endometriosis pain, very occasional Concerta, haven't used it for a few months, melatonin over the summer (stopped it about two months ago)Others: Drink 1-2 drinks monthly, Slowly stopping smoking down from 6 to 1-2 per day and 1 light snus, last two days have started taking Vitamin D and I have been using a therapy lamp for 20 min every morning for the last two weeks. Good, balanced diet and drink a lot of water. No drugs.Concerns: bad family history of cancer - quality of life affected.In Norway. What should I look out for to justify going to the doc? I would just live at the doctor's if I went every time something happens, especially since I have had several issues since I was a kid, but I also want to be mindful to not ignore things that might be important. I also tend to write off things as just depression/hormones, and once it was an iron deficiency, for instance. Thank you in advance!!   No idea what is related, so I will list things that have changed just in case, in order of concern. EELING FAINT/FATIGUE: I can't exercise much because I feel super lightheaded and I can't do some exercises now because I feel I am going to faint and I have had to cut down my training sessions. Thought I wasn't eating enough, but upped protein intake and started tracking calories and I am at maintenance level.  DEMOTIVATION: I want to be lying on the couch a lot even though it hasn't been typical of me. I am very demotivated, like nothing excites me and I can get a bit weepy (but I have had recurrent trouble with depression in the past so it might be that not being able to do much is making me lightly depressed...). I just moved to a nordic country, so thinking it might be related to the change into the autumn season, I am using a therapy lamp and started taking vitamin D. The lamp worked the first week. URINE: Every time I pee, it used to be clear because I drink so much water and now it is always very yellow no matter how much water I drink. LIGHT PERIOD: My period has become super light since last September, but the last 2-3 times I hardly have had it. I have taken a pregnancy test every 4 weeks just in case. All negative. I used to have 1 very, very heavy day changing tampon at least once an hour and some spotting after. A few years ago it was 3-4 of these very heavy days. OVARIAN PAIN: I have a 5cm cyst (found 10 years ago, grown from 2.5cm) that feels fuller and tender. It has been hurting me so much more than usual, cramping several times this last month and it hurts when I stretch or when I do certain exercises. I only mention this in case you know whether exercise or stretching can cause it to burst or twist the ovary to avoid it or in the off chance that it might be cancer related. I feel my hunger increased, but it might be unrelated, more nausea than usual. I have also been feeling like I am catching a flu constantly and I have already had what seems like a cold twice this month.
227.answer:
I can’t tell you what the diagnosis is, but I can tell you which of your findings would normally make a primary-care doctor (fastlege) in Norway want to see you quite soon, which ones require same-day/ER attention, and what is usually checked first.  

-------------------------------------------------
1. Situations that justify a SAME-DAY or ER visit
-------------------------------------------------
•  Fainting or feeling about to faint that does not improve after sitting/lying down.  
•  Sudden, sharp (“knife-like”) lower-abdominal pain, pain that keeps you from standing upright, or pain + vomiting → worry about ovarian torsion or rupture.  
•  Dark-cola, orange, or red urine, or urine plus pale stools or yellow skin/eyes → possible liver or kidney bleeding problem.  
•  Fever >38.5 °C with flank pain or pelvic pain → possible kidney infection or tubo-ovarian infection.  
•  Persistent vomiting, inability to keep fluids down, or weight loss >2 kg in a week.  

-------------------------------------------------
2. Situations that justify booking an ordinary GP appointment (within a week or two)
-------------------------------------------------
You already meet several of these:  
•  Unexplained fatigue, light-headedness, or exercise intolerance lasting >2–3 weeks.  
•  Change in menstrual flow for ≥3 cycles (much lighter or absent).  
•  Persistent darker-than-usual urine despite good fluid intake.  
•  Pelvic/ovarian discomfort that is new or getting worse.  
•  “Flu-ish” feeling/colds that keep recurring over a month.  
•  Any new depressive symptoms when physical issues are also present (because thyroid, anemia, vitamin D, and other medical problems can masquerade as depression).  

A single appointment can cover all of these; you do NOT need to book separate visits.

-------------------------------------------------
3. What the doctor will usually evaluate first
-------------------------------------------------
Blood work  
•  Complete blood count + ferritin (anemia, iron deficiency).  
•  Electrolytes, kidney function (creatinine, eGFR).  
•  Liver panel + bilirubin (lamotrigine or ibuprofen-related liver stress, hepatitis).  
•  Thyroid (TSH ± free T4): both light periods and low energy can come from hypothyroidism.  
•  CRP/ESR if you feel chronically “flu-ish.”  
•  HbA1c and fasting glucose (diabetes can cause thirst, frequent urination, fatigue).  
•  Vitamin D, B12 if not done recently.  

Urine tests  
•  Dipstick (blood, bilirubin, protein, infection) and microscopy.  

Pelvic imaging  
•  Repeat trans-vaginal ultrasound to measure the cyst, check for torsion risk, endometriomas, or new masses. A 5 cm cyst is the threshold at which many gynecologists consider removal, especially if painful or enlarging.  

Medication review  
•  Lamotrigine: rare but real liver-injury cases.  
•  NSAIDs (ibuprofen): can darken urine via kidney irritation or occult GI bleeding → iron deficiency.  

-------------------------------------------------
4. Why each of your symptoms matters
-------------------------------------------------
Light-headedness / exercise intolerance  
•  Most common causes at your age: iron-deficiency anemia, viral/post-viral fatigue, low blood pressure, thyroid disease, early pregnancy.  
•  Less common but important: dehydration from diabetes, heart rhythm problems, medication side effects.  

Dark(er) urine  
•  Could simply be concentrated urine, but if water intake is high it raises flags for bilirubin (liver), myoglobin (muscle breakdown), blood, or vitamin/supplement dyes.  

Very light periods  
•  Stress or weight change can do this, but so can thyroid disorders, elevated prolactin, early perimenopause, polycystic ovarian syndrome, or intra-uterine adhesions.  

Pelvic pain with known 5 cm cyst  
•  5 cm is the size where torsion risk rises—especially with exercise, sudden twists, or jumps. The goal of imaging is to see if it’s still a simple cyst or something that needs removal.  

Mood change  
•  Seasonal affective disorder is common in Norway; light box and vitamin D are appropriate. Still, medical conditions above can mimic or worsen depression, therefore labs first, therapy/psychiatric follow-up later if physical causes are excluded.  

-------------------------------------------------
5. What you can track or bring to the appointment
-------------------------------------------------
•  1- to 2-week symptom diary: fatigue level, dizziness spells (time of day, precipitating activity), fluid intake, urine color, any fevers.  
•  Menstrual calendar (flow amounts, pain, spotting).  
•  List of all supplements, even herbal/over-the-counter.  
•  Copies of any previous pelvic ultrasounds (to compare cyst size).  

-------------------------------------------------
6. Practical tips while you wait
-------------------------------------------------
•  Keep exercising but avoid high-impact twisting or very vigorous core work until the cyst is re-imaged. Walking, cycling, elliptical are usually safe.  
•  Stay well hydrated; aim for light-yellow urine.  
•  Continue tapering cigarettes—improves circulation and wound-healing if you eventually need cyst surgery.  
•  Take ibuprofen with food and limit to the lowest effective dose; chronic high-dose NSAIDs raise kidney/liver/GI risk.  
•  If you suddenly develop severe pelvic pain or can’t keep food down, go to Legevakt (emergency clinic) rather than waiting.

-------------------------------------------------
Bottom line
You have several persistent, new changes (fatigue, pre-syncope, darker urine, much lighter periods, increasing cyst pain) that warrant a routine but prompt GP visit for labs and a pelvic ultrasound. Go sooner (same day/ER) if you actually faint, develop sudden severe abdominal pain, notice cola-colored urine, or become jaundiced. Don’t assume it’s “just depression” until common medical causes are ruled out—your fastlege will not think you are over-reacting.

228.question: I’m (40F) 5ft 8, 164lbs, caucasian. Medications: Lamotrigine and Sertraline Health conditions: ADHD, Tourette’s, epilepsy and severe degenerative disc disease. I don’t have a current issue but every time I’ve had surgery I wake up completely full of beans, even when I’ve just woken up in recovery. I will stay hyper for hours afterwards and not feel surgical pain for the same amount of time. It can be quite funny, I talk at 100mph and can’t stop giggling. I don’t feel sick at all and always want water and food immediately. Drs/nurses etc have commented it’s like I didn’t even have surgery, but I’ve never asked if there’s a reason why. I’m not sure if it’s related but codeine does absolutely nothing for me and I always need extra anaesthetic at the dentist. I’ve never been told I’m difficult to put under GA. Thank you in advance, I’ve been wondering for years.
228.answer:
What you are describing – coming out of general anaesthesia (GA) “wide-awake, chatty, giggly and pain-free” – is unusual but not mysterious.  In most people it is the result of several normal physiologic and pharmacologic factors that just happen to line up in your favour.  The pattern you report (euphoria + little early pain + poor response to codeine + need for extra local anaesthetic) can be explained by four main mechanisms:   

1. “Emergence excitation” / catecholamine surge  
• As the concentration of volatile agents such as sevoflurane, desflurane or intravenous propofol falls, the brain can overshoot into a transient hyper-aroused state.  
• Adrenaline (epinephrine), nor-adrenaline and dopamine all rise sharply during this period.  
• In many patients this shows up as agitation, restlessness or even confusion; in others (especially adults with an ADHD/​Tourette’s neurochemistry) it is experienced as pleasant stimulation – rapid speech, laughter, feeling “full of beans”.  
• The phase normally lasts 15-30 minutes, but in some people it can continue for a couple of hours as drug levels taper.

2. Stress-induced (endogenous) analgesia  
• Surgery is a major physiologic stress.  In response the body releases endorphins, enkephalins and endocannabinoids that temporarily blunt pain.  
• When you also have a high catecholamine level from the “emergence” phase, pain perception is further dampened.  
• Anaesthetists usually give a long-acting opioid (e.g., fentanyl) and/or non-opioid analgesics before the end of the case, so their effect overlaps that natural endorphin rush.  Six-plus hours later, when those drugs wear off, ordinary postoperative pain begins to break through.

3. Genetic drug-metabolism patterns  
• Codeine is a “pro-drug”; it must be converted to morphine by the liver enzyme CYP2D6 to work.  
• About 8–10 % of people of northern-European ancestry are CYP2D6 “poor metabolisers” – they convert little or no codeine, tramadol or hydrocodone into the active form, so the drug feels useless.  
• The same enzyme is partly involved in the breakdown of many local anaesthetics; poor- or ultra-fast metabolism can both make ordinary dental doses wear off sooner, so the dentist has to top up.  
• That genotype does not make GA itself difficult, because most anaesthetic drugs are handled by other enzyme families (mainly CYP3A, CYP1A and esterases).

4. Interaction with your baseline neurochemistry and medication  
• People with ADHD often notice they feel calmer when stimulated and stimulated when sedated – the so-called “paradoxical” response to sedatives.  
• Propofol and the volatile agents transiently increase brain dopamine, which in someone with a chronic dopamine-deficit condition may feel like taking a stimulant.  
• Sertraline (an SSRI) can, in a small minority, lower the threshold for hypomania/​euphoria when another CNS-active drug is added.  Lamotrigine, conversely, is stabilising and not likely to counteract that brief high.

Putting it together  
1. Anaesthetics are stopped ➔ brain concentration falls quickly.  
2. Catecholamines spike (“emergence”) ➔ you feel energised, talkative, happy.  
3. Endorphins + long-acting opioid/NSAID given in theatre ➔ you feel no pain.  
4. Because you are a CYP2D6 poor-metaboliser, the usual ward drugs (codeine, tramadol) don’t work, so once the theatre medication wears off you hurt more than average unless a different analgesic (morphine, oxycodone, ketorolac, ibuprofen, etc.) is used.

Is it dangerous?  
No.  Most anaesthetists regard a cheerful, oriented patient who wants water and a sandwich as a success story.  The only caution is that you can look “too well” and thereby receive inadequate analgesia later on, especially if the ward relies on codeine-based tablets.

Practical suggestions for future procedures  
• Tell the anaesthetist that codeine/tramadol do nothing for you – ask for alternatives (e.g., morphine, oxycodone, hydromorphone, NSAIDs, acetaminophen, regional blocks).  
• Warn recovery staff that you tend to be very alert and chatty so they know it is your baseline, not delirium.  
• Remind your dentist you usually need extra local anaesthetic; some patients benefit from articaine instead of lidocaine.  
• If post-op pain control has been a problem in the past, discuss a scheduled non-opioid regimen plus an effective opioid that bypasses CYP2D6.

When to seek evaluation  
Only if you ever experience prolonged confusion, hallucinations, severe agitation, or if pain remains uncontrolled despite proper medication.  Otherwise, your “happy wake-ups” are just a quirk of your physiology and genetics.

229.question: 20 year old old Female. I’m taking 500mg of Keppra every morning for my epilepsy and I’ve been on it for about two years. I’ve just recently stopped taking amitriptyline 25mg about a week now. I’ve been going through the withdrawals but it’s been easing and the symptoms weren’t too bad besides the chills and shakes. I also take Ventolin inhalers for my asthma as well as paracetamols for migraines here and there. Anyway, I’ve had this sort of pain months ago. The stomach pain was unbearable and lasted a week or so until it soothed. It completely went away after a month or so. I think the annoying part was I constantly felt like I needed the bathroom. After the first day I didn’t actually need to use the bathroom but it just constantly felt like I did. It was very uncomfortable. I think eating made it worse but I can’t be too sure. I stopped drinking sodas or spicy foods and drank decaffeinated green tea with honey everyday. It went away and now suddenly it’s back. I’m also late with my period by 23 days but I usually have irregular periods. My stomach gurgles a lot too. If my stomach pain isn’t so bad it’s me needing to use the bathroom or my stomach making noises. My distress triggers anxiety attacks and that also doesn’t help.
229.answer:
I’m not able to examine you, order tests or make a definite diagnosis on-line, but I can help you think through what might be going on and what the next sensible steps are.

1. First, rule out anything urgent or easily checked

   • Pregnancy test – Any time a period is ≥1 week late in a sexually active woman, pregnancy has to be excluded, even if cycles are usually irregular.  
   • “Red-flag” symptoms that mean you should seek same-day care or ED review:  
     – Severe or rapidly worsening abdominal pain, pain that wakes you at night, or pain localised strictly to the right lower or upper abdomen  
     – Persistent vomiting, vomiting blood, black/tar-coloured or bloody stools  
     – Fever, chills, sweats, unexplained weight loss  
     – Inability to pass stool or gas, abdominal swelling  
     – Pain with urination, visible blood in urine, flank pain

2. Likely causes when red flags are absent

   A. Return of IBS-type symptoms after stopping amitriptyline  
      • Low-dose amitriptyline is often prescribed for functional gut pain/IBS because its anticholinergic effect calms intestinal spasms and dulls pain perception.  
      • Stopping it can “unmask” the old bowel pattern: cramping, gurgling, an almost constant urge to open the bowels (“tenesmus”) even when little comes out, bloating, anxiety flares.  
      • The timing (symptoms re-emerge 1-2 weeks after stopping) fits your story.

   B. Gastritis/peptic irritation  
      • Presents with upper-central abdominal pain that flares after food or when stomach is empty, lots of burping or gurgling.  
      • Can be triggered by soda, caffeine, spicy foods, stress.  
      • Paracetamol is stomach-friendly, but if you sometimes take ibuprofen or other NSAIDs this would aggravate it.

   C. Functional dyspepsia or anxiety-gut feedback loop  
      • The gut has many serotonin/noradrenaline receptors; withdrawal of a tricyclic, plus general anxiety, can heighten gut sensitivity and motility.

   D. Urinary or gynaecological causes (less likely but need checking)  
      • Urinary tract infection or interstitial cystitis can mimic “need to go” bowel sensations.  
      • Ovarian cysts, endometriosis, or pelvic inflammatory disease can give crampy lower-abdomen pain and alter bowel/bladder sensations.  

   E. Less common but important: inflammatory bowel disease, coeliac disease, gallbladder or bile-duct problems. These usually have persistent symptoms, blood or mucus in stool, weight loss, anaemia – things you haven’t mentioned.

3. How your current medicines fit in

   • Keppra (levetiracetam) – can cause nausea or abdominal pain in some users, but after two years it’s less likely to suddenly start doing so.  
   • Amitriptyline withdrawal – chills, shakes, vivid dreams, gut upset typically peak days 3-7 then fade; gut motility can remain altered for 2–3 weeks.  
   • Ventolin (albuterol) – high doses sometimes cause mild GI upset, but inhaled doses rarely cause persistent abdominal pain.  
   • Paracetamol (acetaminophen) – safe on the stomach unless huge overdoses.

4. What you can do now

   Lifestyle / symptom-control
   • Hydration: water or non-caffeinated, non-carbonated fluids.  
   • Small, bland, frequent meals; avoid large fatty or spicy meals for a week to see if pain settles.  
   • Keep a 1-week food-symptom diary; note stools on the Bristol chart (Google image).  
   • Over-the-counter options (if no contraindications):  
     – Peppermint-oil capsules or a gentle antispasmodic (e.g. Buscopan/hyoscine) for cramping.  
     – Simethicone for bloating.  
     – A gentle fibre supplement (psyllium) or probiotic may help if stools are hard or infrequent.  
   • Heat pad on the abdomen, relaxation/breathing exercises to break the anxiety-pain cycle.

   Medical follow-up
   • Schedule a GP appointment; ask for:  
     – Pregnancy test (if home test unsure), urine dipstick, simple blood work (FBC, CRP, coeliac serology, metabolic panel) and stool test if diarrhoea or blood.  
     – Consider restarting low-dose amitriptyline or a gut-specific alternative (e.g. low-dose nortriptyline or an antispasmodic) if IBS-pain proves to be the main issue.  
     – Possibly an H. pylori breath or stool test if upper-stomach symptoms dominate.  
     – Pelvic exam / ultrasound if gynaecologic cause suspected or periods continue to be very delayed.  

5. When to be more urgent

   If pain becomes sharp and localised (appendix, gallbladder, ovarian torsion), if you develop fever, vomiting, rectal bleeding, or if the withdrawal symptoms worsen rather than improve, go to urgent care or ED.

Key take-away: Because you’ve stopped a medicine that often masks gut symptoms, IBS-type pain is high on the list, but pregnancy, infection, stomach inflammation, or a pelvic cause must be ruled out. A prompt GP review with a pregnancy test and basic labs is the next smart step while you use diet, hydration and simple OTC antispasmodics to stay comfortable.

230.question: Gender: Female, Age: 9, Height: Idk tbh, Location: Head, How long ago: 1 week.So my co-workers daughter was just diagnosed with grey matter heterotopia. She was crying her eyes out today, and I felt really bad. She brings her daughter to work quite often and we love her here. She is a wonderful kid, and we were all really sad with the news. I was hoping to shed a little bit of light, maybe some information on what their options are. They have to wait until October for their doctor to talk to them about the subject while her daughter still has seizures and her parents just suffer. I wanted to brighten up her day, and even if the news are bad or there aren’t many options... at least I wanna give her some clarity. Any and all responses are welcomed.Thank you!
230.answer:
I’m sorry your colleague and her family are going through this—in the middle of waiting for answers it can feel overwhelming and frightening. While every child is different, there are some reassuring facts, practical steps, and treatment options that may help your co-worker feel a little less “stuck” between now and the October visit.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
1. What “grey matter heterotopia” actually means
-------------------------------------------------------------------
•  During fetal brain development, neurons are “programmed” to migrate from deep inside the brain out to the cortex (the brain’s outer layer).  
•  If some neurons stop short, they form little islands (nodules) or a band of normal-looking grey matter in the wrong place—this is heterotopia (“hetero” = other, “topos” = place).  
•  The condition is congenital—present at birth—and usually NON-progressive: the misplaced tissue doesn’t grow or spread over time.

Types your co-worker may hear about  
•  Periventricular nodular heterotopia (PVNH) – small nodules lining the ventricles.  
•  Subcortical band heterotopia (SBH or “double cortex”) – a smooth band deeper than the true cortex.  
•  Focal subcortical heterotopia – one localized lump, often under a single gyrus.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Common symptoms and outlook
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Seizures  
•  70–90 % of children with heterotopia develop epilepsy. Seizures can start at any age.  
•  Roughly half can get good to excellent seizure control with medication alone.  
•  Others have “medically-refractory” epilepsy and may need advanced options (ketogenic diet, VNS, surgery, etc.—see below).

Development / intelligence  
•  Wide range. Some children have normal cognition and go to regular school, others need special education help.  
•  Heterotopia itself does NOT continuously damage the brain; any developmental issues are usually set at birth.

Associated findings  
•  Some forms have related heart or connective-tissue findings (especially when a gene called FLNA is involved), so doctors often order an echocardiogram and genetic testing.  
•  Migraines, reading difficulties, or subtle motor problems can occur.

Life expectancy  
•  Usually normal, provided seizures are managed and safety precautions are followed.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
3. What can be done between now and the October appointment?
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Seizure safety  
•  Keep a diary: date/time, what happened, how long, triggers, recovery. Bring it to every visit.  
•  Discuss a rescue plan with the current pediatrician (e.g., intranasal midazolam or diazepam if a seizure lasts >5 min).  
•  Make the home “seizure-safe”: shower instead of tub baths, no swimming alone, use helmets for biking/skateboarding, padded corners on furniture, consider a seizure monitor at night if seizures have occurred during sleep.  
•  School: write an emergency seizure action plan and share it with the nurse/teacher.

Try to expedite care  
•  Primary doctors can sometimes move neurology referrals sooner if uncontrolled seizures are occurring—politely but firmly ask.  
•  Epilepsy centers often have cancellation lists; being flexible can shave weeks off the wait.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Medical treatment options the specialist will discuss
-------------------------------------------------------------------
First-line (always tried)  
•  Anti-seizure medications (ASMs). Choice depends on seizure type, EEG pattern, side-effect profile.  
•  Ketogenic or modified Atkins diet can reduce seizures in about half of suitable children.

Advanced / when meds fail  
•  Vagus Nerve Stimulator (VNS) – an implanted pacemaker-like device that “paces” the vagus nerve; can cut seizures 40–60 % on average.  
•  Responsive Neurostimulation (RNS) – approved for ages ≥18 in the U.S.; some centers use it off-label in older teens.  
•  Epilepsy surgery: If EEG and imaging prove most seizures start in a single heterotopic focus, that area can sometimes be removed (craniotomy) or destroyed with MRI-guided laser ablation (LITT). Success rates vary (40–70 % seizure-free in carefully selected cases).  
•  Corpus callosotomy or deep-brain stimulation may be considered for drop attacks or generalized seizures.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Questions your co-worker can jot down for the neurologist
-------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Which type of heterotopia does my child have on MRI?  
2. What seizure type(s) and EEG pattern are present?  
3. Do you think her epilepsy is likely to respond to medication alone?  
4. Should we start genetic testing, and if so, which panel?  
5. Any related heart or connective-tissue screenings needed?  
6. Are we eligible for ketogenic diet, VNS, or surgical evaluation if meds don’t work?  
7. What developmental or neuropsychological testing do you recommend?  
8. What activity or sports restrictions do you advise?

-------------------------------------------------------------------
6. Emotional & practical supports
-------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Epilepsy Foundation (epilepsy.com) – local chapters run family groups and seizure-response training.  
•  PVNH Support & Awareness (pvnhsupport.com) – active parent-to-parent network, research updates.  
•  RareConnect “Grey Matter Heterotopia” community.  
•  Social media (private Facebook groups) can be a lifeline while waiting for appointments.  
•  Ask the neurologist for a referral to a pediatric psychologist if anxiety or mood issues arise in child or parents.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
7. The bottom line you can share
-------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Grey matter heterotopia is a structural glitch that happened before birth and does not spread or get worse.  
•  The main challenge is epilepsy—and there are multiple layers of treatment beyond just the first medication. About half of children end up with good control, and even those with stubborn seizures often gain significant reductions with advanced therapies.  
•  Cognitive outlook is variable but not doomed; many kids attend mainstream school and lead fulfilling lives.  
•  While October feels far away, there ARE concrete things the family can do right now: seizure-safety measures, a detailed seizure diary, and politely pushing for an earlier neurology slot if seizures continue.  
•  They are not alone—specialty epilepsy centers and family support groups have helped many children with this exact diagnosis live active, happy lives.

I hope this gives your co-worker a clearer roadmap and a little relief while they wait. Let her know there is genuine reason for cautious optimism, and that help—medical and community—really is out there.

231.question: 25F, 200lb, 5’4, asthma, current medications wellbutrin SR, vyvanse, lexapro, montelukast, spironolactone. i do not drink any alcohol, use cannabis 5-7x a weekOccasionally, I will have an intense sensation of deja vu, followed by a sensation that I can only describe as disoriented. It’s almost like a combination of intense nausea, dizziness, and confusion, which will be very intense for a few seconds before dissipating. After the initial peak, I will feel “weird” for anywhere between 10 mins to a half hour afterwards, sometimes I will be nauseous for awhile, sometimes I will need to lay down, sometimes I feel too overwhelmed to socialize, etc. (I do sometimes experience deja vu WITHOUT the weird sensations too, just the general feeling of unease that comes with a cognitively dissonant experience like deja vu.)This used to happen a lot more as a kid, and stopped for awhile, but recently it’s happened once or twice and made me wonder why it happens. When I was younger I think I used to be able to “control” whether it progressed if I caught the sensation early enough?
