For example, if I started having that “I’ve been here before” feeling, if I leaned into it and tried to figure out if it was a dream, what came next, etc, the strange feelings would come on; occasionally if I tried to move on from the topic it would just stop at the deja vu and leave me just a little bit weirded out by the experience.I do tend to remember my dreams very vividly, and I have read online that people who do tend to be more susceptible to deja vu. Occasionally I can even tell when I have the sensation and am in fact experiencing the set-up to a dream (i.e opening a closet and then waiting for the “next scene” so to speak from the dream). I am just curious if this is normal, if these weird feelings are just part of deja vu or if it’s something else?
231.answer:
What you are describing sounds less like the “garden-variety” déjà-vu most people notice now and then and more like a brief neurological episode that uses déjà-vu as its opening act.  
The two most common medical causes we think about are:

1. Focal (partial) seizures coming from the temporal lobe.  
   • Typical pattern: a sudden, vivid déjà-vu (or jamais-vu, a strange smell, a wave of fear, etc.) that lasts a few seconds, may be accompanied by nausea, light-headedness, throat or stomach “rising” sensation, and is followed by several minutes of feeling wiped-out, confused, or “spacy.”  
   • Consciousness can be preserved (focal aware seizure) or mildly altered (focal impaired-awareness seizure). People often can “remember it happening but not feel quite right afterward.”  
   • While not dangerous in itself, it matters because seizures can generalize or become more frequent.

2. Migraine aura without (or before) headache.  
   • Déjà-vu, visual distortions, dizziness, or nausea can precede or substitute for the headache phase.  
   • Auras usually last 5–60 min, not just seconds, so your very short episodes make seizures somewhat more likely—but migraine can still present atypically.

Less common considerations: transient drops in blood pressure/glucose, panic attacks, vestibular disorders, or medication/cannabis effects, but the very stereotyped, seconds-long “electrical” feel you describe most strongly suggests a temporal-lobe event.

Why it matters in your case
• You are on bupropion (Wellbutrin) and a stimulant (Vyvanse). Both lower the seizure threshold, especially together or if a dose is missed, delayed, or combined with dehydration, sleep loss, or cannabis.  
• Daily cannabis can both provoke and mask subtle seizures in some people.  
• You drive, work, and climb stairs: even brief impaired awareness could pose a safety risk.

What to do next
1. Schedule a visit with your primary‐care clinician or directly with a neurologist. Bring a detailed description (time of day, what you were doing, duration to the second if possible, what happens afterward, any triggers, recovery time).  
2. Expect the neurologist to order:
   • An EEG (brain-wave study). Even if it is normal, it can still be a seizure disorder, but an abnormal result is very helpful.  
   • Possibly a brain MRI to look at the temporal lobes.  
3. Review all medications and recreational substances. Sometimes simply lowering or switching Wellbutrin or Vyvanse, or reducing cannabis use, stops the events.  
4. Until you are cleared, be cautious with driving, climbing ladders, swimming alone, etc. One rule of thumb many neurologists use is “no driving until seizure-free for 3 months,” but local laws vary—ask your doctor.  
5. Keep a diary. Note sleep, stress, missed meals, medication timing, and cannabis use to look for patterns.

Signs that warrant urgent attention
• An episode that evolves into loss of consciousness, limb jerking, tongue-biting, or loss of bladder control.  
• Episodes occurring in clusters or lasting longer than 1–2 minutes.  
• A new severe headache, double vision, weakness, speech difficulty, or collapse.

Bottom line
Brief “déjà-vu + wave of nausea/dizziness + post-episode fog” is classic for a focal temporal-lobe seizure aura. It is treatable, but you need an evaluation to confirm the diagnosis and to decide whether medication changes or an anti-seizure medicine are appropriate. Bring this up with your clinician soon.

232.question: ’m a 60yr old fit male with Gerd due to a Hiatal hernia. Have been on PPIs for 22 years. Have had a history of passing out on occasion after weight lifting/working out. Doctors did cardio tests /tilt table with no results for explanation. One neurologist said I had epilepsy another one said absolutely not. No one seemed to take into account the PPI and Gerd condition and that this only happened after work outs. Could the weight lifting be affecting the Vagus nerve and causing the light headedness and the seizure like passing out episodes?
232.answer:
Short answer  
Yes – a spell that comes right after heavy lifting can be produced by a “reflex” mechanism that travels through the vagus nerve and rapidly slows the heart or drops the blood pressure, and the presence of a sliding hiatal hernia / severe reflux can amplify that reflex in some people.  That can lead to a typical faint (vasovagal or “reflex syncope”).  The resulting brief loss of brain blood flow may include a few jerking movements that look like a seizure, which is why one neurologist thought of epilepsy.  However, this explanation is only one possibility; more common and more dangerous cardiac problems must still be excluded carefully.

Below is a longer, step-by-step explanation and a practical plan you can take to your physicians.

1.  HOW HEAVY LIFTING CAN MAKE SOMEONE PASS OUT  
   •  During a hard lift most lifters instinctively hold their breath and strain (Valsalva maneuver).  
   •  The Valsalva raises the pressure inside the chest, squeezes the vena cavae, and cuts the amount of blood coming back to the heart for a few seconds.  
   •  The sudden fall in cardiac output and blood pressure can trigger a vagally mediated reflex bradycardia or vasodilatation → faint.  
   •  When the faint is abrupt, a few seconds of brain hypoxia can cause tonic-clonic jerks (“convulsive syncope”) that mimic an epileptic seizure.

2.  WHY GERD / HIATAL HERNIA CAN AUGMENT THE REFLEX  
   •  A sliding hiatal hernia can ride up and down with changes in intra-abdominal and intra-thoracic pressure.  
   •  Stretching or acid irritation of the distal oesophagus activates sensory fibres that feed into the vagus.  
   •  In a small subset of patients this produces “swallow syncope,” “belch syncope,” or “reflux-associated syncope.” Case reports show dramatic bradycardia or AV block that stops once the hernia is repaired or reflux is controlled.  
   •  Heavy lifting exaggerates these stimuli: acid reflux, hernia slides further into the chest, intra-oesophageal pressure spikes – all of which can add to the vagal outflow already provoked by the Valsalva.

3.  COULD 22 YEARS OF PPI USE BE INVOLVED?  
   •  PPIs themselves do not cause immediate syncope.  
   •  Chronic use can rarely induce severe hypomagnesaemia or hypocalcaemia which predispose to arrhythmias/QT prolongation, but this develops slowly and would not be tied tightly to a workout.  A basic metabolic panel and magnesium level once a year is wise.

4.  WHY CARDIAC CAUSES STILL MUST BE RULED OUT  
   The age of 60 and the exertional setting demand exclusion of:  
   •  Ventricular tachyarrhythmias or high-grade AV block  
   •  Obstructive lesions (severe aortic stenosis, HOCM)  
   •  Coronary ischaemia  
   •  Aortic dissection (Valsalva can precipitate)  
   •  Pulmonary embolus  
   •  Carotid sinus hypersensitivity from the lifting belt or bar

   A normal baseline ECG, treadmill stress and echocardiogram are reassuring but not definitive; some rhythm problems only show up sporadically.

5.  HOW TO SORT IT OUT (WHAT TO ASK FOR)  
   •  Detailed history focused on prodrome (nausea, warmth, tunnel vision) versus sudden collapse, duration of unconsciousness (<1 min typical for syncope), post-event confusion (longer in epilepsy).  
   •  Continuous ambulatory rhythm capture: 2-week event monitor or implantable loop recorder if events are infrequent.  
   •  Exercise stress test with blood-pressure monitoring; if tolerated, simulate the triggering lift in lab with beat-to-beat BP and ECG.  
   •  Echocardiogram if not done in the last 2 years.  
   •  Lab screen: CBC, electrolytes, Mg, Ca, troponin if episode was severe.  
   •  24-hour combined pH-impedance/manometry study can prove vigorous reflux or hernia movement with strain; some centres can do it while the patient performs Valsalva-like manoeuvres.  
   •  If a true vagal-mediated syncope is confirmed, atropine or pacing during provocation may reproduce/abolish the event and clinch the diagnosis.

6.  MANAGEMENT OPTIONS  
   Non-surgical  
   •  Avoid breath-hold – exhale through the sticking point (teach “blow as you go”).  
   •  Decrease weight / increase repetitions; circuit or resistance bands instead of maximal lifts.  
   •  Stay well hydrated and avoid lifting fasted.  
   •  If reflux is a big trigger, time exercise 2-3 h after eating; continue PPI or switch to H2 at night; add alginate/antacid before workout.  
   •  If documented cardio-inhibitory reflex: low-dose beta-blocker or midodrine sometimes helps, rare cases need a pacemaker.

   Surgical  
   •  Laparoscopic hiatal hernia repair / fundoplication has cured swallow-related vagal syncope in published cases.  
   •  It often allows reduction of, or discontinuation from, life-long PPIs.

7.  WHEN IT IS REALLY EPILEPSY  
   •  Events not linked to posture or specific strain  
   •  Occur during sleep or rest, tongue-biting, prolonged (>5 min) post-ictal confusion, abnormal inter-ictal EEG.  
   •  One normal EEG/scan does not rule it in or out; however, the tight linkage to lifting makes a reflex syncope far more plausible.

Key take-away  
Heavy resistance exercise can precipitate a vagally mediated reflex faint; a sliding hiatal hernia and acid reflux can potentiate this reflex in susceptible individuals.  That mechanism fits your history better than primary epilepsy, but you still need a careful cardiac and rhythm evaluation before settling on that diagnosis.  Discuss the above testing pathway and the option of hernia repair or lifting-technique modifications with your cardiologist, gastroenterologist, and (if needed) an electrophysiologist.

233.question: 29F, height 165cm, weight 74kg, caucasian. I do not smoke or have regular dairy. Weekly alcohol consumption would be 2-7 standard drinks per week at most.  also regularly have lean meat and 3 veg for lunch and dinner and a fruit smoothie for breakfast. Current diagnoses: epilepsy, mild chronic pancreatitis Regular medications are: AM: 500mg Kepra, vitamins D+magnesium PM: 500mg Kepra, vitamin D+magnesium I am awaiting follow-up with a gastroenterologist about why my pancreas could be nibbling on itself (lypase has been found to be between 70-100 on multiple occasions). I have a history of treating my anxiety with alcohol and fast food but over the last 8 years or so (since my early 20's) I've gone to therapy and gotten it really well under control. I never had these symptoms before when I had unhealthy habits but over the last year my pancreas has not been having a good time. Every month or 2 I get these very specific pains that I now know is mild chronic pancreatitis. It's never brought on by a change in routine, it's always random.
233.answer:
I’m glad you have a gastro-enterology appointment coming up; the evaluation of recurrent / chronic pancreatitis in a relatively young, low-alcohol, non-smoking woman is a bit different from the typical “gallstones or years of heavy drinking” story and it’s worth taking a step-by-step, cause-finding approach.  
Below is the framework most specialists use, with suggestions on which tests or history points usually come next, what you can do in the meantime, and what red-flag symptoms would require urgent care.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  How do we know it is chronic (or recurrent acute) pancreatitis?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Typical pain (deep upper-abdominal, radiating to the back, worsened by food) + mildly to moderately elevated amylase/lipase (your lipase 70-100 U/L is only 1–2× the upper limit, which is common in chronic disease).  
•  Imaging: CT, MRCP, or endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) looking for calcifications, ductal narrowing/dilation, or atrophy. If you have not yet had an MRCP or EUS, they are usually the next tests.  
•  Functional changes: fat-malabsorption (oily/floating stools), new-onset diabetes, low fat-soluble vitamin levels; these show the pancreas is already losing function.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Broad differential – why would a 29-year-old get pancreatitis?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
(“TIGAR-O” is the mnemonic many gastroenterologists use.)

Toxic-metabolic  
   • Alcohol – even if you currently drink little, a heavy binge pattern during your late teens / early 20’s can set the stage. Ask yourself: Did I ever average >4–5 standard drinks most nights or have repeated bouts of heavy weekend drinking for years?  
   • Hypertriglyceridaemia – fasting TG > 5.6 mmol/L (> 500 mg/dL) can attack the pancreas. A simple lipid panel rules this out.  
   • Hypercalcaemia – check a calcium and PTH.  
   • Certain drugs – common offenders: valproate, azathioprine, oestrogens, thiazides, furosemide, GLP-1 agonists; Keppra is rarely reported but not near the top of the list.

Idiopathic  
   • Around 10–30 % remain “idiopathic”; many of these turn out to be genetic or anatomical variants when scrutinised.

Genetic / Inherited  
   • CFTR, PRSS1, SPINK1, CTRC mutations → hereditary pancreatitis, often presenting in teens-30’s, sometimes without obvious family history.  
   • If episodes started before 35 and no clear trigger, most specialists now send a pancreatitis genetic panel (blood or saliva).

Auto-immune  
   • Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) can give waxing-waning pain, mild enzyme bumps, and responds dramatically to steroids. Check serum IgG4, ANA; CT/MRCP may show a characteristic “sausage-shaped” pancreas or stricturing of the bile duct.

Recurrent (post-acute)  
   • After an episode of severe acute pancreatitis, 20-30 % of patients develop a chronic form. If you ever had one big attack that required hospitalisation, scarring may now be the issue.

Obstructive / Structural  
   • Gallstones or sludge passing intermittently. A right-upper-quadrant ultrasound and MRCP look for this.  
   • Pancreas divisum, ductal strictures, sphincter of Oddi dysfunction – best seen on MRCP or EUS, and sometimes treated endoscopically.  
   • Tumours/cysts (IPMN, neuroendocrine tumours) – more likely >40 y but ruled out on imaging.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  What tests will the gastroenterologist usually order?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
•  Blood: fasting lipid profile, calcium, PTH, IgG4, HbA1c, liver enzymes, vitamin A/D/E/K levels.  
•  Imaging: pancreas-protocol MRCP with secretin, or EUS (often superior because it sees small stones/sludge and early parenchymal changes).  
•  Genetic panel if you’re <35 with no smoking/alcohol trigger or if there is any family history of pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis, or early unexplained diabetes.  
•  If autoimmune pancreatitis is suspected, sometimes a short steroid trial or biopsy via EUS.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Day-to-day self-management while you wait
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Diet  
   • True “low-fat” means <20 g of fat per day or about 15 % of calories; this helps minimise pancreatic stimulation.  
   • Small, frequent meals rather than two large ones.  
   • Stay well hydrated.  
   • Consider keeping a detailed food / symptom diary; sometimes hidden fat (smoothies made with coconut/almond butter, store-bought sauces, nuts) correlates with attacks.  
   • Total alcohol abstinence until a firm diagnosis is made; even moderate intake can perpetuate low-grade inflammation in a sensitised pancreas.

Medications / supplements  
   • Normal-dose NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) often help mild pain; narcotics can worsen sphincter of Oddi dysfunction and are best avoided unless prescribed.  
   • Over-the-counter pancreatic enzyme replacement (e.g., Creon, Zenpep) is not harmful; some people find empirical trials reduce pain after meals.  
   • Continue vitamin D and magnesium; monitor D level 25-OH yearly because malabsorption can accelerate deficiency.

General lifestyle  
   • Keep BMI in the mid-20’s (you’re very close already). Each 5 kg weight loss if overweight improves metabolic stress on the pancreas.  
   • Absolutely no smoking/vaping (doubles rate of progression).  
   • Maintain good glycaemic control and blood pressure; chronic pancreatitis can tip into diabetes (“type 3c”).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Red-flag symptoms – go to ED if:
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Pain suddenly becomes severe, constant, and band-like with vomiting.  
• Fever >38.5 °C or chills (risk of infected necrosis).  
• Jaundice (yellow eyes/skin), dark urine, pale stools (suggests a bile-duct obstruction).  
• Persistent tachycardia, dizziness, or inability to keep fluids down.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  What to ask the gastroenterologist
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Have you ruled out gallstones or microlithiasis with EUS or MRCP?  
2. Should we send a genetic pancreatitis panel?  
3. What are my triglycerides, calcium, and IgG4 levels?  
4. Could this be autoimmune pancreatitis, and would a short steroid trial be reasonable?  
5. Would you consider pancreatic enzyme supplementation or antioxidant therapy for pain control now?  
6. If imaging shows pancreas divisum or ductal strictures, am I a candidate for ERCP + minor sphincterotomy or stenting?

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Key take-away
--------------------------------------------------------------------
In someone your age with only light current alcohol use, the leading culprits are (a) gallbladder microlithiasis/sludge, (b) genetic or anatomical duct variants, (c) autoimmune pancreatitis, or (d) residual damage from a past heavy-drinking period. A structured work-up—blood chemistries, fasting lipids, autoimmune markers, pancreas-protocol MRCP/EUS, and possibly genetic testing—usually identifies the cause in >70 % of such cases.  
While you wait, strict alcohol avoidance, a low-fat divided-meal diet, good hydration, and OTC enzymes if tolerated are the safest measures to reduce flare-ups. Seek urgent care if pain suddenly intensifies, you develop jaundice, or cannot keep fluids down.

I hope this roadmap helps you steer the discussion with your specialist and gives you practical steps to feel better in the meantime. Best wishes for a clear diagnosis and smooth management ahead!
